HEADLINE: Hydropower Under Review In Albany Bill

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 16

 BODY:
Making a highly unusual foray into foreign policy that New York power officials denounced as unconstitutional, the state Assembly today approved a bill that would require an exhaustive environmental review before New York State could buy power from a enormous hydroelectric complex that Quebec wants to build in the Canadian subarctic.
The bill, which would aid environmentalists seeking to scuttle or at least delay the project, has generated fierce opposition from the Quebec Government and equally fervent support from Cree Indians who live in the affected region and whose leaders have traveled to Albany to urge its passage. 
 The fight now moves to the Republican-controlled State Senate, where officials said the measure's fate is uncertain.
New York has been intricately drawn into the controversy over Hydro-Quebec's planned expansion of hydroelectric plants in the remote James Bay region because the state is by far the largest foreign customer for the power and because, several Canadian analysts said, its payments would represent a critical part of the capital Quebec needs for the expansion.
 
Delayed Decision
 Last summer, in the face of environmental complaints and projections of an electricity glut, New York put off until this November a final decision on whether to go ahead with a $19 billion, 20-year contract it signed in 1989 to buy 1,800 megawatts of hydropower a year, roughly enough to supply 10 percent of the state's demand.
The bill passed by the Democratic-led Assembly today, on a vote of 122 to 17, would require the state to delay the decision again, because the review it calls for could not be completed within a few months.
Quebec officials denounced the measure as unwarranted because Canada has already begun at least five different sets of environmental hearings. They say these hearings will help insure that the project, despite warnings from the Cree and many environmental groups, will not destroy the taiga, the wildlife or the Cree way of life in the James Bay area.
The main sponsor of the bill, William B. Hoyt, a Buffalo Democrat and the chairman of the Assembly's Energy Committee, argued during a debate in the chamber that the state should back out of the purchase entirely because Hydro-Quebec's plans, which include flooding an area the size of New Jersey and damming parts of 20 wild rivers, will be "an environmental, human rights and economic disaster."
But an opponent of the bill, Chris Ortloff, a Republican of northern New York, countered that by passing it New York was in danger of "throwing away" an opportunity to buy significant amounts of power that would be far cleaner for New Yorkers than generating electricity with oil or coal.
 
'Illegal Intrusion'
 Richard M. Flynn, chairman of the New York Power Authority said that the bill would violate the United States Constitution by giving New York the power to regulate international trade.
"The Assembly unfortunately has passed legislation that calls for an unwarranted and illegal intrusion into the affairs of a foreign country," he said, "and could seriously jeopardize New York's ability to secure low-cost energy supplies from out-of-state sources in the future."
New York already buys 800 megawatts of power during the spring and summer months from Hydro-Quebec, under a contract signed in 1978.
But the new contract has led to far more controversy both because it substantially increases the state's commitment to the power and because the environmental effects of the hydroelectric projects in James Bay have come under increasing scrutiny.
In addition to raising questions about how the flooding and rerouting of rivers will alter the James Bay ecosystem, the Cree have denounced the projects because methyl mercury poisoning caused by decomposition in flooded areas has led Quebec officials to place strict limits on the consumption of fish, a Cree staple.
The ultimate decision on the James Bay power will be up to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who has asked his state agencies to conduct their own review of both environmental and economic questions surrounding the contract.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Primaries;
CLINTON FOES PUSH ELECTABILITY ISSUE

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, March 16

 BODY:
The Michigan and Illinois primary campaigns roared to an angry close today with former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. and former Senator Paul E. Tsongas struggling to raise doubts about Gov. Bill Clinton's ability to win in a general election.
Mr. Brown, who some Democrats believe could knock Mr. Tsongas out of second place in Michigan, pressed a fierce new attack on the ethics of Hillary Clinton's working for a law firm that does business with the State of Arkansas. 
 "There is only one issue," he told reporters outside Detroit today, pushing accusations that he raised at fever pitch in Sunday night's debate. "It's Mr. Clinton and his electability and what are we going to do about this scandal a week."
 
Tsongas Looks to Northeast
 Mr. Tsongas, trying to take the edge off expected losses to the Governor from Arkansas in both states on Tuesday, told reporters in Moline, Ill., today that he would stay in the race until the Democratic National Convention.
"At the convention, there will be one question: Who can beat George Bush?" said Mr. Tsongas, who is already trying to redirect attention to the next major contests in the Northeast, the March 24 primary in Connecticut and the April 7 vote in New York. "Who has an economic message that can attract Republicans and independents?That is the question; you are looking at the answer."
Mr. Clinton, whose aides seem at once flustered by the latest attacks and euphoric over the prospect of taking a major step toward the nomination on Tuesday, fought back today against Mr. Brown, as Mr. Clinton did in the debate on Sunday night in the most venomous exchange of the campaign.
Campaigning in Chicago, Mr. Clinton asserted, "If somebody jumps on my wife, I'm going to jump them back."
Hillary Clinton, with more of a new age appeal, sought to make it an issue of women's rights. "I suppose I could have stayed home and baked cookies and had teas," she said. "But what I decided to do was pursue my profession, which I entered before my husband was in public life."
Mr. Brown's attack, stemming from a Washington Post article on Sunday, revolves around Mrs. Clinton's position as a partner with the Rose law firm, a major institution in Little Rock, Ark., that represents numerous business clients with potential interests before the state, as well as, on occasion, the state government itself.
Mr. Brown maintained that Mr. Clinton "funnels" state business to his wife's law firm and that the fact of her being a partner is an inherent conflict of interest.
The Clintons flatly dismiss the accusation that the state funnels business to the firm and maintain that there is nothing wrong with Mrs. Clinton's position because she accepts no income from the firm's direct representation of state agencies. They also maintain that Mrs. Clinton does not lobby the state or its agencies, although she was listed on one occasion as representing a friend's savings and loan that was subject to state regulation. Clinton campaign officials say she did not play an active role in the case.
The bitterness of today's exchange reflects the intense struggle under way to slow Mr. Clinton, who had a double-digit lead in both states in polls released this past weekend. There are 295 pledged delegates up for grabs on Tuesday, and Mr. Clinton enters the contest with an already formidable lead from his Super Tuesday sweep: According to a compilation by The New York Times, he has 728 delegates to Mr. Brown's 89 and Mr. Tsongas's 343.
The Clinton campaign manager, David Wilhelm, said Mr. Clinton could emerge from Tuesday with nearly half the 2,145 delegates needed to win the nomination and, because of Democratic primary rules, would be hard to overtake. The rules of proportional representation make it difficult for a candidate to catch fire late in the game, win several big states and catch up with the front-runner, Mr. Wilhelm and several other analysts said.
Many Democrats agree that twin victories for Mr. Clinton on Tuesday will begin a new phase of the campaign. "We're at a transition point in the campaign," said Geoffrey Garin, a Democratic poll taker, "where the process becomes much more of a referendum on Bill Clinton than a choice among candidates."
Mr. Clinton's rivals are trying to make "electability" an important part of this referendum. Mr. Brown, in particular, argues that Mr. Clinton has been embroiled in far too many controversies to be a strong opponent against President Bush. "What are we supposed to do?" Mr. Brown demanded. "Wait for George Bush to bring it up?"
The Clinton campaign counters that it has shown, again and again, its ability to take punches and keep on winning. For example, Mr. Wilhelm asserted that Mr. Clinton's angry defense of his wife on Sunday night, when he seemed close to veering from finger-jabbing to actual contact with Mr. Brown, would serve Mr. Clinton well with the voters. "Here's a guy who at the 11th hour does a cheap shot of going after Bill Clinton's wife, and Bill Clinton forthrightly defends her," Mr. Wilhelm said. "He certainly does not have Mike Dukakis's problem."
In a 1988 debate, Michael S. Dukakis was thought to be badly hurt by his cerebral response to a hypothetical question about how he would react to the rape and murder of his wife, Kitty.
The sniping among the candidates today took place at a distance, as all three embarked on a final swing of the industrial Midwest. Mr. Tsongas, whose campaign faltered badly last week on Super Tuesday and had hoped to right itself here, began his day in Chicago, then headed on to Moline and Ann Arbor, Mich. He reiterated his call for a leadership willing to make "hard choices" on the economy, and once again assailed the idea of a middle class tax cut, a pet proposal of Mr. Clinton's.
"I don't want to buy your vote," he told a rally at Moline. "I want to build your future."
Mr. Brown, who has sought to harvest the discontent of many blue-collar voters in Michigan, campaigned around Hamtramck today. If he finishes strongly in that state, some analysts said, he could be a wild card yet again in the New York primray and a vehicle for those who want to stop Mr. Clinton.
"If Brown has a solid second in one of the two, then just like 1976, Brown becomes the un-Clinton," said Sam Popkin, a professor of political science at the University of California at San Diego. That year, Mr. Brown ran strongly in the later primaries, although not strongly enough to stop another Southern front-runner, Jimmy Carter.
John A. Marino, chairman of the New York Democratic Party, said today, "If Brown shows some strength tomorrow, he'll come into New York with a little head of steam."
Mr. Clinton, meanwhile, was poised for passing a major threshold. "It's not conclusive," said Ronald H. Brown Jr., chairman of the Democratic Party. "But certainly if Bill Clinton does what has been predicted by a number of those polls, it would be a giant step toward the nomination."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Why Hasn't G.M. Switched Even One Agency Since '58?

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
THE auto makers are perhaps the best illustration of advertisers' tendency to dismiss their agencies more frequently during a recession. Since last summer, Isuzu, Mercedes-Benz and Subaru have changed shops, while Jaguar's account has gone into review.
One car maker that is certainly troubled is the largest, General Motors, which plans to close 21 plants and eliminate 74,000 jobs by 1995. Yet, the last time G.M. dismissed one of its national agencies, Dwight D. Eisenhower was President: In 1958, G.M. switched its Buick division from the Kudner agency to McCann-Erickson, where it has remained. 
 Of course, there is no proof of an inverse relationship between the length of time an agency handles an account and the effectiveness or creativity of its work. But in a period when G.M., which spends more than $1 billion a year on advertising, is radically revamping its operations and when critics have intensified complaints about prosaic, uninspiring advertising, will it take seven more Presidential administrations before G.M. dismisses an agency?
"I don't know why they haven't entertained the idea of going to smaller, more creative shops," said Christopher Cedergren, senior vice president at the Auto Pacific Group, an automotive marketing and product consulting company in Santa Ana, Calif. "If I were having problems in a marketplace, I would look at all possible avenues to develop ways of increasing my business."
(Ford last changed an agency in 1979, and Chrysler in 1987.)
In a telephone interview, Philip Guarascio, G.M.'s executive in charge of corporate marketing and advertising in Detroit, passionately supported the penchant of the giant auto maker for decades-long relationships with its agencies.
And in a separate interview, Richard D. O'Connor, chairman and chief executive of Lintas Campbell-Ewald in Warren, Mich., which has created Chevrolet campaigns since 1914, said that his agency worked on that account as if every day could be its last, rather than its 28,500th or so.
"I don't think we have to fire an agency to send a signal," Mr. Guara scio said. "We feel we're able to resolve issues without resorting to that."
He added, "You need to think about our relationships with our agencies as living, as opposed to relationships that are static." For instance, he continued, in recent years, G.M. has begun "to call upon agencies' entire worldwide resources for what we do in the States, rather than working with one isolated parent agency."
As a result, he said, "you've seen tremendous changes at agencies in how they are staffed and who does the staffing. When we think we need a fresh point of view, we can get our agencies to bring in people who can give a point of view that's different."
G.M.'s agencies also "know we're talking with other agencies all the time," Mr. Guarascio added. "In the last three months," he continued, "we had meetings with at least two non-G.M. agencies, to make sure there are no silver bullets out there we're not aware of."
G.M. will occasionally hire other agencies for special projects, he continued, as well as consult with executives like Stephen O. Frankfurt, chairman of Frankfurt Gips Balkind, a small New York advertising, communications and design shop.
As for critics of G.M.'s advertising, Mr. Guarascio said, "A third are agencies looking for car accounts, a third are agencies that had car accounts and lost them, and a third are people who've never written advertising for a living."
"I think, generally speaking, while we're not home yet," he said, "we've turned the corner on some issues more than people give us credit for." He praised campaigns by Lintas Campbell-Ewald for Chevrolet and Geo, McCann for Buick and D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles for Cadillac.
At Lintas Campbell-Ewald, Mr. O'Connor said he was "well aware of the critics of the associations that have existed between the Detroit auto makers and their agencies."
He continued: "It's easy to sit on the outside and pick apart individual ads. All they have to do is come in and demonstrate they can do the job better."
The fact that his agency's 78-year relationship with Chevrolet "looks permanent doesn't permeate our relationship," he said. "I started at this agency in 1956 and I've lived constantly, for almost 36 years, in fear Chevrolet would say, 'We want a new agency,' " he added. "Anybody who feels the account couldn't move tomorrow morning is living with a sense of false security."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Week;
Top Candidates Duck And Hope Nothing Hits

BYLINE: By HOWELL RAINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, March 16

 BODY:
With the voting here and in Michigan on Tuesday, the first wave of big primaries will be over, and the big news is that the backwash has left both parties with cold feet. Indeed, the front-runners look more like shipwreck victims who have washed up on the beach than sure-handed captains of the ship of state. As a result, a make-the-best-of-it mood has gripped Democrats and Republicans alike.
The rolling psychodrama of Gov. Bill Clinton's campaign has been a blessing for President Bush because it has diverted attention from an equally striking spectacle of the early primaries -- the tattering of a reputation for political competence that he had spent three decades building. 
 Mr. Bush's image of rudderlessness now seems as rooted in the public mind as President Ronald Reagan's out-to-lunchness or President Jimmy Carter's vacillation. To prevent further damage, the Republican hierarchy has signaled Patrick J. Buchanan that enough is enough. After a few face-saving growls, Mr. Buchanan must strike the tent of his medicine show or risk permanent labeling in his own party as the G.O.P.'s snake-oil salesman.
With Mr. Buchanan tamped down, the White House could drag Mr. Bush back to the dressing room, give the public time to forget his squeakiness and try to bring him back at convention time with one of speechwriter Peggy Noonan's patented paeans to manly politics. The political pros still bet that Mr. Bush will be bailed out by the economy and Democratic crashes, but the dispirited Bushies all know that the magic is gone.
If the members of the Washington Democratic establishment could say publicly what they say privately today, it would be this: Even if Clinton wins big in Illinois and Michigan, let's keep Paul E. Tsongas alive. There is near universal agreement that the party has to maintain a fallback candidate in case the Clinton campaign collapses. A smaller number of Democrats keep clinging to the hope that they can inflate the former Senator from Massachusetts into a credible national candidate.
So far, Mr. Tsongas has not managed to convert an image for honesty and his civic-club economics into a salable mainstream campaign message. At this point, future political scientists can credit him with proving that it is hard to win a plurality of Rustbelt Democrats by advocating tax cuts for top contributors to the Republican National Committee. If former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California nicks Mr. Tsongas for second place in Michigan on Tuesday, the Beltway Democrats will look toward the New York primary on April 7 and keep chanting "More time for Paul." But they will begin thinking, "Get the hook."
The party leadership does not have the stomach to take Mr. Brown seriously and, as was the case with Mr. Carter in 1976, will do so only if the voters demand it. Should Mr. Brown do well in Michigan, look for a major effort later in the week to discredit him as the champion of Wallaceite grumps, tree-huggers, latter-day hippies and wealthy trend-heads.
Showing the way, Mr. Clinton reached into his Southern trick bag in the debate Sunday night to club Mr. Brown as the candidate of "family money and $1,500 suits." But the more telling line came when he denounced Mr. Brown as the mouthpiece for Patrick H. Caddell, the former Carter poll taker who is widely regarded in Democratic circles as a Svengali wannabee.
If nothing else, Mr. Clinton has enlivened the campaign season by emerging as the political equivalent of Hank Williams Sr. -- that is, a son of the South whose flaws are as large and fascinating as his talents. Big margins for Clinton here and in Michigan would deepen the admiration that set in last week among professionals in both parties for the Clinton campaign's three-pronged plan for damage control.
One element is to label any inquiry into Mr. Clinton's veracity, finances or performance as Governor of Arkansas as "an attack by the press." Prong 2 is to depict the ordeals brought on by Mr. Clinton's youthful indiscretions as character-building exercises that have prepared him for the Presidency. Prong 3, which has emerged as a major theme in Mr. Clinton's speeches, is to depict "perfection" in personal conduct as a prudish and ultimately disqualifying personality tic in his opponents.
Four weeks ago, no political consultant in Washington thought those lines would sell. Now they are tipping their hats to the Clinton team. But these people are realists. After Tuesday, their gossip du jour will switch to discussion of what the Republicans have on Mr. Clinton in the way of an October Surprise. That is because everyone believes that the minute Mr. Clinton becomes the nominee, the Democratic Party will have the same motto as a 12-step program: One day at a time.
Anticipating this, Clinton supporters are already stepping up their pressure on the press to look searchingly into President Bush's past in an effort to give their man a level playing field on the character issue. That is the kind of elevating year it has been so far. If Mr. Bush and Mr. Clinton are the winners tomorrow, they will leave the Rust Belt carrying the kind of cuts and bruises that normally show up on the losers.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Memo;
Clinton Speeches Echo Messages of His Rivals

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, March 16

 BODY:
The apparent success of Bill Clinton's Presidential campaign stems, at least in part, from his skill in appropriating the best ideas of his opponents and incorporating them into his plans and promises.
It is not wholesale thievery, and it is a technique used by other candidates. By making a deft selection of emphasis, the Arkansas Governor sharpens his message in areas that have proved popular for other Democrats and presents himself as the best of every candidate -- an effort to win over his opponents' former supporters. Especially in Michigan and Illinois, this approach is a way to woo traditional, mainstream Democrats and to cast his rival, former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts, as conservative. 
 Mr. Clinton has taken a cue, for instance, from Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, who dropped out of the Presidential race two weeks ago, and increased the number of times he now refers to himself as the candidate who can bring the most change to Washington. At a Texas debate last week, Mr. Clinton even borrowed Mr. Kerrey's most-used phrase to say he is for "fundamental change."
Mr. Clinton's portrayal of himself as an outsider owes a debt as well to former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California, who has won the Colorado primary and who could manage a strong finish in Michigan with an outsider's message that rails against the monied and the powerful. Speaking to an audience in Macomb County, Mich., on Thursday, Mr. Clinton picked up that theme.
"The executives continue to raise their pay and their perks while the workers got the shaft," he said.
 
Borrowing From Harkin
 Echoes of Senator Tom Harkin, who dropped out of the campaign a week ago, also turn up in Mr. Clinton's speeches and debate appearances. When he spoke at a rally in the Southern Illinois city of Carbondale last week, Mr. Clinton, like the Senator from Iowa, praised ethanol, a grain byproduct that is touted by farmers as a substitute for gasoline.
Mr. Harkin's exit from the race has also provided Mr. Clinton with an opportunity to redefine Mr. Tsongas. Early in the campaign, it was Mr. Clinton who had to defend himself against attacks from Mr. Harkin, who campaigned as a voice for liberalism. Mr. Harkin asked whether the Governor's centrist views made him a "real Democrat." Now it is Mr. Clinton who is making the argument, this time over whether Mr. Tsongas is a "real Democrat," in an apparent effort to push Mr. Tsongas to the right on social issues.
Mr. Clinton's aides resist the notion that the Governor is using anybody else's ideas, though they concede that when a useful distinction is made by another candidate, it is not a bad idea to keep it in mind.
"The point of distinction changes as the field changes," said Paul Begala, a top Clinton adviser. "That's true."
George Stephanopoulos, Mr. Clinton's deputy campaign manager, asserted that the essentials of his candidate's message have not changed, and disavowed any notion that Mr. Clinton was unfairly borrowing from Mr. Tsongas. The former Senator, he said, "stole the 'new idea' mantle from us. We're snatching it back."
 
Renewed Focus on Economics
 That is especially true of Mr. Clinton's economic proposals, which got lost in all the attention to the character question in New Hampshire. But beginning in Georgia, as Mr. Clinton regained his footing, he has been able to focus the economic discussion on three or four issues.
Instead of relying on the booklet containing his economic plan, which was distributed widely to the detail-oriented New Hampshire voters, the Clinton campaign is now attacking Mr. Tsongas's economic ideas, painting the former Senator in a 30-second television advertisement as a friend of business, a foe of the elderly and a fan of nuclear power.
Many of Mr. Clinton's strongest statements, of course, remain exclusive to him. No other candidate speaks in as much detail about social issues like the need for racial unity, child support enforcement and welfare reform. And he is not alone in the game of appropriating ideas.
Mr. Brown, for instance, in a Friday night debate here, used a line borrowed from the Rev. Jesse Jackson to say that building enterprise zones in poor neighborhoods would curb the drug trade and make "hope blossom and dope decline."
And in Mr. Tsongas's new advertising, he has claimed Mr. Kerrey's call for "fundamental change" as well.
Mr. Clinton and his aides say the true test of their constantly evolving message is in the truth of their words.
"I think thay it's pretty hard to turn reality into unreality if there's any factual basis, anything for the voters to tie it to," Mr. Clinton said recently.
He was talking about negative advertising at the time, but his observation could apply to his front-runner's message as well.

HEADLINE: Trenton Vote Splits Raise in Wage Law

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, March 16

 BODY:
The Republican-led Assembly today approved legislation spreading out over two years an 80-cent-an-hour increase that would have made New Jersey's minimum wage the highest of any state in the country on April 1.
That bill and another one approved today, which would deny farm workers a rise in the $4.25-an-hour minimum, drew unexpected opposition from some Assembly Republicans. 
 The two bills also face an uncertain future in the State Senate, where the Republican leadership has suggested that they may not even be brought up for a vote. A constitutional quirk gives Gov. Jim Florio, a Democrat, the power to ignore action by the Legislature and allow the 80-cent raise to take effect as planned.
Under a bill that passed with bipartisan support in 1990, when the Democrats controlled the Legislature, all minimum-wage workers were to receive the 80-cent raise on April 1. But in a 49-to-26 vote today, the Assembly approved a 40-cent raise to take effect on April 1, bringing the minimum wage to $4.65 an hour, and a second 40-cent increase on April 1, 1993, raising the wage to $5.05 an hour.
"Many New Jersey businesses and industry already face an uncertain future because of the dire economic straits we are in as a result of the current recession," said Assemblyman Scott Garrett, the Republican who sponsored the legislation to postpone the increase. "Increasing the state minimum wage the full 80 cents at this time will only serve to inhibit our economic recovery."
 
'Competitive Disadvantage'
 Two Republican Assemblymen, Frank LoBiondo and Robert Shinn, sponsored the bill exempting farm workers from any increase in the federally mandated $4.25 an hour minimum, saying that a raise would put the state's farmers at "a dangerous competitive disadvantage."
"Forcing New Jersey farmers to pay employees 80 cents per hour more than neighboring states will take away their ability to compete fairly," Mr. Shinn said.
The bill was passed, 44 to 28. The Republicans hold a 58-to-22 majority in the Assembly.
"By voting to cut the minimum wage, the Republicans have told the citizens of New Jersey that it is too generous for businesses to pay working men and women wages that are above the poverty level," said Assemblywoman Stephanie R. Bush, a Democrat from East Orange who two years ago sponsored the measure to raise the minimum wage to $5.05. "This is a mean-spirited bill. I urge Governor Florio to make sure that it never sees the light of law."
The Republicans have enough votes to override a veto by Mr. Florio. But the State Constitution gives the Governor 45 days to act on a bill. That means Mr. Florio could refuse to act on one or both of the minimum-wage bills for the next two weeks, allowing the 80-cent raise to take effect on April 1 and putting the Republicans in the uncomfortable position of having to take the money back.
Mr. Florio has not said how he will deal with the matter, but a spokeswoman for the Governor suggested he was opposed to both bills. "He's hard pressed to see how somebody earning $200 a week is a drain on the economy," said the spokeswoman, Jo Glading.
At $5.05, New Jersey's minimum wage would be higher than that of any other state and second only to the minimum in Washington, D.C., which is as high as $5.25 an hour.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Increasing the state minimum wage the full 80 cents at this time will only serve to inhibit our economic recovery," said Scott Garrett, the Republican Assemblyman who sponsored the legislation to spread out the increase in the minimum wage. Mr. Garrett addressed the Assembly in Trenton. (Laura Pedrick for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices Mixed in Negative Market

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed in fairly active trading yesterday. Traders said market sentiment remained very negative, despite the rise in interest rates over the last two months.
"I like the market, particularly securities with maturities of four years or less," one government securities trader said. "But it is hard to fight what is going on." 
 Many market participants seem convinced that recent strong economic reports are signaling an upturn in the extremely sluggish economy, and they have pushed up short-term and long-term market interest rates accordingly.
 
More Statistics Today
 Most analysts expect those data to be released today, including industrial production and housing starts for February, will tend to support that view. At the same time, they added that recent figures overstate the rebound's strength.
"Some of the changes to cash flow taking place in the first quarter, from mortgage refinancing to a speedup in payments of tax refunds and the change in payroll tax deductions, are sort of what pump-priming is all about," said Neal M. Soss, chief economist at the First Boston Corporation.
"Those factors may have pushed us to a 2 percent growth path, up from 1 percent or less," he continued. "That accleration is palpable: when you increase speed to 20 miles an hour from 5 miles an hour, you feel it. But after a while, you recognize that 20 miles an hour is not so fast."
And Brian J. Fabbri, chief economist at Midland Montague Economics, said, "The market is way ahead of the economy."
 
Treasury Bill Auction
 A reminder of the rise in interest rates was provided yesterday at the Treasury's weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills, as rates on the new securities rose to their highest levels since December.
Three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 4.09 percent, up from an average rate of 4.02 percent a week ago. The latest rate is the highest on three-month bills since the auction on Dec. 16, when the average rate was 4.14 percent.
Bids on the new six-month securities generated an average discount rate of 4.27 percent, up sharply from the 4.13 percent average rate at last week's sale. The rate is the highest on a new six-month bill since it averaged 4.39 percent on Dec. 2.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, prices of long-term notes and bonds weakened slightly while prices of short- and intermediate-term issues firmed a bit.
By late in the day, the 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 997/32 , down 2/32 , to yield 8.06 percent, unchanged from late Friday.
Among outstanding note issues, the 6 3/8 percent seven-year notes were offered at 94 5/8, up 1/8 point, to yield 7.38 percent. And the 5 3/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 996/32 up 1/32 , to yield 5.82 percent.
 
Corporate Offerings
 In the investment-grade corporate bond market, ICI Wilmington, the American subsidiary of the British giant Imperial Chemical Industries, offered $225 million of five-year notes through an underwriting group led by Merrill Lynch & Company.
The 7 5/8 percent securities, which mature on March 15, 1997, were priced at $99.81 to yield 7.671 percent, 55 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, more than the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 6 3/4 percent five-year notes at the time of pricing. The securities are rated AA-3 by Moody's Investors Service and AA- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Separately, J. P. Morgan Securities Inc. acted as lead manager on a $100 million offering of 12-year securities for the Crane Company.
The 8 1/2 percent notes were priced at $99 to yield 8.636 percent, 96 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing. The issue is rated Baa-2 by Moody's and A- by Standard & Poor's.
 
New York City Bonds
 In the tax-exempt municipal bond market, New York City priced $99 million of variable-rate bonds through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.
The bonds were initially priced to yield 2.20 percent on securities maturing in 2020. Rates on the securities will be reset daily.
A guarantee of repayment of principal and interest on the bonds is being provided by the Financial Guaranty Insurance Company, a subsidiary of GE Capital. It is the first time a non-bank financial company has provided such a liquidity guarantee in the municipal bond market.
Because of the credit enhancement provided by the guarantee, the securities are rated MIG-1 by Moody's and SP-1 by Standard & Poor's.
Participants in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds said prices of the most widely quoted securities rose by about 1/8 point in sluggish trading.

HEADLINE: Archbishop's New House Raises Eyebrows

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WEST HARTFORD, March 15

 BODY:
As the new Archbishop of Hartford, one of Daniel A. Cronin's first decisions was where to live.
But his choice -- a $430,000 house with a swimming pool in this upscale Hartford suburb -- has put the archdiocese on the defensive just as it is beginning a major fund-raising drive. 
 The archdiocese insists that it is quite common for bishops and archbishops to live in single-family homes and argues that the money to buy the house will come from a special fund set aside for such expenses, not from parishioners' donations.
But officials of the archdiocese fear that the purchase, at a time of widespread layoffs and general economic malaise, may upset some of the state's 800,000 Catholics. They are so concerned about the potential impact on the Archbishop's Annual Appeal, which raised more than $4 million last year, that they have sent out a fact sheet on the purchase to individual priests.
 
Send in Those Contributions
 In a cover letter, the Rev. Charles W. Daly, fiscal officer of the archdiocese, wrote "Your presentation from the pulpit will be the major factor in helping to clarify any misperceptions of the house purchase, which misperceptions could prove to be a negative factor surrounding Appeal '92."
The fund drive began over the weekend, and a mailing will go out this week. Parishioners have until after Easter to send in contributions, and those making a long-term pledge can do so from May until November.
The Rev. Douglas A. Clancy, the director of the appeal, said most parishioners have read about the purchase and were aware of the facts.
At services over the weekend, he said: "Most said nothing. Others said everything from 'I don't see what the problem is, Father,' to 'Gee, this is something that should be brought up.' "
Archbishop Cronin, who was installed in January, did not return repeated calls today and over the weekend. But Father Daly said in a telephone interview: "What Archbishop Cronin proposes to do is reasonable and rather universally done. For people who are worried about the money, it's a good investment."
The purchase of the six-bedroom house, which has an in-ground swimming pool, is contingent on approval of a zoning permit which would allow more than three unrelated people to live in a single home.
Father Daly said in the fact sheet that the house's size suited the Archbishop's needs.
"The swimming pool is not a requirement of the archdiocese," he said. "It happens to come with the house. The pool was installed for the benefit of the present owners' seven children and their friends."
Father Daly said that one of the six bedrooms in the house in West Hartford would be divided into two bedrooms. Diocesan officials have said the seven bedrooms are needed for the Archbishop, his secretary, three nuns who will staff the residence, and to allow for two guest rooms.
The oversized white and brick colonial is at 36 Braintree Road, a quiet, residential neighborhood of neat, well-kept homes. The street is a short distance from a busy shopping and office district known as Bishop's Corner.
Archbishop Cronin is now living in the rectory at St. Joseph's Cathedral in Hartford.
The former Archbishop, John F. Whealon, who died in August, had sold his predecessor's mansion in 1974 for $288,000, and had chosen to live in two rooms at a retirement home in West Hartford.
Father Daly said the money from the sale of the mansion had been invested and would cover the current proposed house purchase. Buying, he said, was preferable to renting.
"Even though the cost of a house remains fixed, the rentals would be going up," Father Daly said. He said the original asking price for the house was $560,000.
He said it was unclear how many people objected to the proposed purchase, but said he doubted it was a significant number when considering the 47,000 parishoners who contributed to last year's fund-raising appeal.
"I don't know for how many people this is an important issue," Father Daly said, "but for the benefit of those for whom it is an issue, we thought that we should explain the matter, primarily because the impression was given that the house was going to be purchased with the money from the Archbishop's Annual Appeal."
He said the Archbishop "wishes that it were a non-issue, and is probably surprised that it is an issue, because practically every bishop in the country lives in a separate residence."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off in Slow Session; Traders Awaiting New Data

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was marginally lower against most major currencies yesterday as many traders chose to stay out of the market until today's release of statistics on housing starts, industrial production and consumer prices.
"There was no incentive for heavy trading," said Mike Faust, an analyst with MMS International. 
 It remains unclear, however, how much the new data would move the dollar. The dollar's recent advance has come amid increased optimism that the economy is regaining strength. But improvement in the economy has now been factored into the market, Mr. Faust said, and traders may need more than numbers to move the dollar higher.
With a stronger economy, investors see a possibility that interest rates might rise, which would make American investments more attractive to overseas buyers and increase their demand for dollars.
Ronald Holzer, vice president and chief trader with the Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago, said activity in other currencies dominated the markets yesterday.
In Japan, stock prices plunged yesterday, with the Nikkei average falling below the 20,000 level. But the yen stayed relatively steady because the foreign exchange markets expected a drop in stocks, Mr. Faust said.
The British pound put in a strong performance in response to a pre-election opinion poll showing the incumbent Conservative Party leading the Labor Party; the voting in Britain is April 9.
The dollar ended the day in New York at 133.90 yen, up from 133.625 on Friday. In Tokyo, the dollar rose 0.75 Japanese yen, to 134.30 yen; in London, it was quoted at 133.90. The dollar fell to 1.6620 marks in New York, from 1.6685 Friday. In European trading, the dollar fell to 1.6650 German marks from 1.6660.
The pound gained against the dollar, rising to $1.7220 in New York, from $1.7085 Friday. In London, sterling rose to $1.7170 from $1.7120.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's quotes, included: 1.5070 Swiss francs, down from 1.5100; 5.6425 French francs, down from 5.6660; 1,249.75 Italian lire, down from 1,253.00, and 1.19875 Canadian dollars, up from 1.19735.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates Friday, included: 1.6650 German marks, down from 1.6660; 1.5085 Swiss francs, down from 1.5113; 5.6560 French francs, down from 5.6565; 1,252.00 Italian lire, up from 1,250.00, and 1.1988 Canadian dollars, unchanged 1.1988.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Gold Drops $3.40 an Ounce As Australia Producers Sell

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Gold prices dropped to their lowest level in more than five and a half years yesterday as Australian producers sold large quantities and American investors stayed on the sidelines.
Gold for spot delivery fell $3.40 an ounce, to $343.30 on the Commodity Exchange, the lowest daily settlement for a spot gold contract since June 24, 1986. The active April gold contract fell $3.40, to $343.90 a troy ounce. 
 Silver futures also retreated on New York's Commodity Exchange while platinum ended barely changed on the New York Mercantile Exchange. March silver fell 3.7 cents, to $4.06 a troy ounce; March platinum ended unchanged at $358.50 a troy ounce.
On other commodity markets, energy futures were mixed; grains and soybeans were mostly lower, and livestock and meat futures were mostly higher.
 
Reasons for Selling
 Analysts said the selling in gold came from three sectors: Australian mining companies, Japanese investors who needed cash to meet margin calls in the weakening Tokyo stock markets, and commodity fund managers who read the price drop as a forecast of further declines.
The price drop nearly matched the cumulative loss of the two previous sessions but stopped short of the collapse that some experts had predicted after last week's slip below the $350 level.
Experts said losses were limited by jitters about today's referendum in South Africa, where whites are voting on whether to share power with the country's black majority. South Africa is a major producer of gold and platinum.
Stirrings of unrest in Russia, another major gold-producing country, also kept prices from collapsing, said Randy Donney, chief of commodity research at Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J.
Crude oil futures were little changed on the New York Mercantile Exchange, and other energy futures ended mixed. The crude market shrugged off a Middle East newsletter's report that OPEC was approaching its output-reduction goal.
Light sweet crude oil for April delivery fell 3 cents, to $19.15 a barrel. April heating oil rose 0.29 cent, to 53.65 cents a gallon. April unleaded gasoline rose 0.67 cent, to 60.02 cents a gallon, and April natural gas rose 1.5 cents, to $1.227 for 1,000 cubic feet.

HEADLINE: Pension Funds Becoming a Tool for Growth

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, March 16

 BODY:
Public pension funds in many states are increasingly being viewed by elected officials not just as sources of retirement income for millions of state and local employees, but as potentially powerful tools for creating jobs, promoting economic growth and meeting social needs.
With political pressure mounting to create or save jobs and provide more social services, cash-short state and local governments are pushing their pension funds to invest in local businesses, housing and other ventures in ways intended to bolster the economy. 
 These so-called economically targeted investments have picked up in size and number in the last several years. And although many fund managers have gone along with the trend, some of them have reservations about the prudence of investments selected for economic and political reasons. And they are concerned about the increasing overt pressure from elected officials to rethink their investment policies.
"Economically targeted investments will be more and more in the forefront as states and municipalities continue to feel the impact of fiscal strain," said Francisco L. Borges, Connecticut's State Treasurer. "The trick will be to structure economically targeted investments in such a way that they will be able to generate a market rate of return at the same level of risk as other assets within the portfolio."
In New York City, public pension funds, under the direction of Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman, have doubled their investments in affordable housing, small business loans and other targeted investments in the last two years, to $850 million. In Alabama, the state retirement system has invested in steel and pulp mills. Colorado has invested in car washes and biotechnology companies.
In the largest single economically targeted investment to date, California's main public pension fund voted recently to invest up to $375 million in building single-family houses in the state, a move that could create thousands of new jobs in the state's dormant construction industry.
The decision by the California Public Employees Retirement System came just a month after Gov. Pete Wilson asked the fund if its money could be safely invested "in ways that would stimulate California's economy to a greater degree than is already the case."
Officials of the retirement system said their investment decision had not been prompted by pressure from Governor Wilson, a Republican who has previously clashed with the fund's board. Indeed, the investment has been supported not just by Mr. Wilson, but by prominent Democrats who are board members, including Kathleen Brown, the State Treasurer.
"We're in a period of great financial transition and I think pension funds have a role to play," Ms. Brown said. "It's not a role that should provide risk-capital financing for the entirety of the marketplace. But certainly where sound fiduciary decisions can be made and where the pension funds can make a contribution to the overall economy or the state economy, that's entirely appropriate."
Still, some pension fund managers worry about whether, in the rush to benefit the residents of their cities and states, they are losing sight of their responsibility to millions of retirees. Muddying up investment decisions by factoring in job creation or economic benefits could lead to below-market returns or losses on the investments, they say.
"I see political motivation to encourage these types of investments in an effort to stimulate the economy," said Carlos Resendez, the executive secretary of the National Conference on Public Employee Retirement Systems. "But public pension funds across the board are being very cautious because they recognize that while it could stimulate the economy, the overall investment risk is most definitely increased by dabbling in these sorts of investments."
 
Some Big Losers
 In a number of cases, economically targeted investments have proved to be big losers. The most notable example occurred several years ago in Kansas, where the public pension fund invested heavily in a number of Kansas-based companies, including a savings and loan association that later failed and left the fund with a loss of $65 million.
"It's a slippery slope," said Edward V. Regan, who as New York State's Comptroller oversees the state's pension funds. Mr. Regan said pension funds in too many states were making investments without researching the risks.
"The money doesn't belong to the public," Mr. Regan said. "You don't just set up a new asset class and make a new kind of investment without studies and research and background, and that's exactly what's happened."
Mr. Regan also cautioned that economically targeted investments could risk politicizing the function of public pension funds. That is especially true, Mr. Regan said, at a time when fund trustees in many states are feuding with their governors and legislatures over whether cash-short governments should be able to reclaim surplus pension fund assets or reduce their contributions to the funds.
 
Wringing More Benefits
 "If we -- the trustees and fiduciaries -- use assets for purposes that are not directly related to the benefit of our beneficiaries, then governors, mayors and legislators have a perfect right to do the same," Mr. Regan said.
Still, many officials believe that cities and states can wring more benefits from their pension funds without putting retirees at risk.
A survey of the nation's largest state and local pension funds conducted in 1989 by the Institute for Fiduciary Education, a research group based in Sacramento, Calif., found that 41 of the 99 retirement systems that responded had economically targeted investment programs. Bob Toigo, the institute's president, said that the group was conducting a follow-up study and that he expected to find the number of targeted investment programs had grown.
Advocates of the practice said many opportunities existed for targeted investments that served the public good and also generated solid returns for pensioners. The New York City Employees Retirement System said its targeted investment program yielded an average return of 13 percent over the last five years, compared with 12.1 percent for the overall portfolio.
 
California's Expectations
 In California, officials believe that the investment by the retirement system in building single-family homes within the state will generate returns of up to 22 percent while creating jobs and increasing the supply of moderately priced homes. They said the investment would help ease a credit crunch that has left developers unable to start projects despite a growing population and mounting demand for new homes.
"There's no question that there's some political appeal to it," said DeWitt Bowman, the chief investment officer for the California retirement system. "But we do feel there's a very sound investment basis."
In other cases, though, what seemed to be sound investments have run into unexpected trouble. Mr. Borges, the Connecticut Treasurer and one of the strongest proponents of targeted investing, decided two years ago to help the state save 1,000 jobs by investing $25 million from the state's pension funds in the Colt's Manufacturing Company, which makes Colt firearms. The investment was the linchpin of a deal that allowed investors, managers and workers from the Hartford-based company to buy Colt from Colt Industries.
 
State Changes Its Plans
 The $25 million was originally intended to serve as a "bridge loan," a temporary financing package. Mr. Borges intended to sell the state's 47 percent interest in the new company within a year or so. But the company's sales have been hurt by the collapse of the Soviet Union and the resulting decline in military spending, Mr. Borges said. The company has also had to replace outdated equipment, necessitating larger- than-planned capital expenditures.
"At this point, our plans for an early exit have been modified, based on our unanticipated difficulties," Mr. Borges said. It is impossible to say what the state's 47 percent stake in Colt is currently worth. But Mr. Borges said that in the case of Colt, as in other investments, he took a patient, long-term approach, and that the performance of the overall portfolio was ultimately the most important factor.
Mr. Borges is pushing ahead with plans to invest as much as $300 million, or 3 percent of the state's public pension fund assets of $10 billion, in Connecticut-based enterprises. Like funds in a number of other states, the Connecticut funds are also providing financing for a mortgage program that offers in-state home buyers more generous terms than those offered by traditional lenders.
"I look at economically targeted investments as a separate asset class," Mr. Borges said. "We want to create a mini-portfolio that performs no better and no worse than the rest of the portfolio."

HEADLINE: A.T.& T. to Cut Rate on Card

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 16

 BODY:
A.T.& T. Universal Card Services said today that it planned to drop its annual percentage rate by one percentage point, to 15.4 percent, for a certain group of card holders.
The lower rate will become effective April 1. The card's introduction of a variable annual percentage rate in March 1990 has been a reason for the card's popularity and a catalyst for other large credit card issuers to revise their policies and offer cheaper rates. 
 The Universal Card's variable annual percentage rate, which is pegged to the banking industry's prime lending rate, has dropped a total of three and a half percentage points since April 1991. Credit card interest rates average about 19 percent nationwide.
"As our costs decline, the right thing to do is pass the savings along to consumers," Paul Kahn, president of A.T.& T. Universal Card Services, said in a statement from the company's headquarters in Jacksonville.
A.T.& T. Universal plans to lower the rate for its so-called 8.5 million charter members, or customers who signed up during an introductory period for the card. The current rate is 16.4 percent and the new one will be 15.4 percent.
In addition, more than four million card holders who signed up after the charter membership period will also see their rate drop a percentage point, to 16.4 percent from 17.4 percent.
The A.T.& T. Universal Card now ranks third in the country with nearly $4 billion in receivables and $13.2 billion charged on the card last year, the company said.

HEADLINE: Careers;
Stepping Up The Training In Ecology

BYLINE: By Elizabeth M. Fowler

 BODY:
WITH corporations increasingly being held responsible for the impact of their products and manufacturing processes on the environment, more colleges and universities are offering courses in environmental science.
One of the newest such academic programs, at the University of Rochester, is expected to begin this fall. The program will offer two degrees: a bachelor of science and a bachelor of arts, both with majors in environmental science. 
 "We have not publicized the new program yet," said Dr. Udo Fehn, associate professor of geological science and head of the program, "but at least 10 students have signed to take it next fall."
Dr. Fehn said students seeking the bachelor of science degree are expected to have a background in the basic sciences of biology, chemistry, physics, geology and mathematics.
Graduates with such a degree, he said, might work as scientists for corporations, the Government or other organizations, doing research and providing the science background to help solve environmental problems.
He said the bachelor of arts program was for students who might go on to law school or medical school or enter areas like education, public policy or journalism. For this program, students must have strong backgrounds in public policy, with courses like economics, political science and sociology, as well as some science courses.
He said environmental studies were definitely a growth industry because companies were now often held accountable when ecological damage occurred. As examples from recent years he pointed to the huge oil spill in Alaskan waters by an Exxon Corporation tanker and the deadly gas leak in Bhopal, India, from a factory affiliated with the Union Carbide Corporation. Both companies were held liable for millions of dollars in damages.
Other colleges have undergraduate programs in environmental science, including Columbia University, the University of California at Berkeley, Johns Hopkins University and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
But there has been less success in persuading graduate schools of business to add environmental courses or to integrate such knowledge into existing courses like economics and management.
Educators say that many top corporate managers are concerned that business faculty members do not appear to understand the need.
Indeed, Richard Mahoney, the chief executive officer of the Monsanto Company, a chemical manufacturer, recently told a group of business school students at Washington University in St. Louis that environmental knowledge "is not just a matter of interest, but of genuine survival" for business.
In the latest issue of Newsline, a publication of the American Assembly of Collegiate Schools of Business, an article stated that business school faculty often had misgivings about adding environmental courses to an already crowded academic curriculum. In many cases, the article said, graduate business schools lack the professors to do such teaching.
To deal with that obstacle, Tufts University in Medford, Mass., two years ago began a program to train educators to teach environmental science.
The program, headed by Dr. Anthony Cortese, dean of environmental programs at Tufts and the first to hold such a title at the university, is supported by a group of corporations. Called the Tufts Environmental Institute, it helps educators introduce environmental studies into existing courses or start new courses.
So far, according to Dr. Cortese, more than 75 educators have taken the program, including about 5 from business schools.
"Educators have to do a better job of integrating issues across the curriculum," he said.

HEADLINE: Russians Seeking U.S. Tours Don't Wait Patiently in Line

BYLINE: By ALLAN KOZINN

 BODY:
The Russians are coming! The Russians are coming! But in the rush for hard currency, they are stepping on each other's toes. And the impresarios who are bringing them over are getting mighty upset.
A case in point is the battle of the St. Petersburg opera companies, two of which are about to make their American debuts. Tonight, the St. Petersburg National Opera, a descendant of the experimental Maly Theater, begins a three-week run at the New York State Theater. It is offering productions of Mussorgsky's "Boris Godunov," Tchaikovsky's "Pique Dame" and Rimsky-Korsakov's "Coq d'Or." 
 In July, the better-known Kirov Opera, also based in St. Petersburg and as internationally renowned as the Bolshoi, arrives at the Metropolitan Opera House with nearly identical repertory: "Boris Godunov," "Pique Dame" and Prokofiev's "Fiery Angel."
The presenters of the competing tours are not amused by the companies' repertory intersections. Indeed, they are charging each other with parasitical opportunism, predatory competitiveness and other varieties of unfair competition.
 
A Last-Minute Plan
 John Cripton, the executive director of the Satra Entertainment Corporation, the company that brought over the Bolshoi last year and is importing the Kirov this season, complained that the St. Petersburg National's visit was arranged at the last minute to pre-empt the Kirov's series.
"We have been planning this visit for 18 months," he said. "The other company knew what we were doing, including our programs, because we had discussions with them in October. They saw an opportunity to jump in first. All's fair in art and war, I guess."
Kazuko Hillyer, who runs International Festivals and Events, a presentation company that is importing the St. Petersburg National, confirmed that the company's tour was planned hastily but said it was a matter of humanitarian urgency. In November, when she was presenting a Japanese tour by Zubin Mehta and the Israel Philharmonic, she was approached by the Acting Russian Minister of Culture, Anatoly F. Kostakovich, who had accompanied the St. Petersburg troupe on a Japanese tour.
"He begged me to bring the company to the United States," she said, and promised that the tour would have the ministry's imprimatur. "I could have waited a year or two. But right now, the company hardly has money for light bulbs. They really have nothing, but they are so eager to perform. And who knows what the situation would have been two years from now?"
 
Answering Some Charges
 Ms. Hillyer said she liked what she saw of the company's performances in Japan and went to St. Petersburg to hear more around Christmas. She said she was touched by the desperate conditions in which it has been working since the collapse of the Soviet Union ended Government subsidies. And she said that if the company knew anything about the Kirov's plans, it didn't mention them to her.
"If I knew the Kirov was coming," Ms. Hillyer said, "I might not have done this. Although, I might have anyway, because I was really moved by the company's situation."
"They have been trying to bash us, and doing terrible bad-mouthing," Ms. Hillyer said of Satra. "First they tried to stop us from using the word National in the company's name. But that's its name. Now they are telling everyone, even my own friends, that this is a fake company. And that's not true. They performed in Paris two seasons in a row and in England. I saw them in Japan last November and in St. Petersburg in December, and I thought their productions were wonderful."
Both Mr. Cripton and Marcus Ticotin, Satra's director of operations, said that to their knowledge no one at Satra had called the St. Petersburg company fake.
Mr. Cripton did say the company "has changed its name in order to capitalize on the name St. Petersburg," adding: "They are certainly an old company, no question about that. But I've seen some of their productions, and they're not in the form one would hope they would be in to come to New York City."
Both presenters have plenty of money at stake. Given the expense of importing elaborate productions and hundreds of singers and musicians, such tours are frequently lucky to break even. Mr. Cripton said the Kirov Opera's visit would cost about $4 million, some of which is to be underwritten by corporate sponsors, including Baltia, a new American airline that flies to Russia and the Baltics, which is providing free transporation.
The St. Petersburg National is touring with fewer performers and smaller sets, but Ms. Hillyer estimated the cost of the visit at $2 million, which she is guaranteeing herself. She also runs a concert management business and an art gallery, and has put up some of her artworks as collateral. But her decision to bring the company over on three months' notice cost her the possibility of finding corporate support.
Clashes like the one between the St. Petersburg National and the Kirov are likely to become more frequent as orchestras, ballet and opera troupes, choruses and soloists of the former Soviet Union, suddenly able to tour without special Government dispensation and facing economic disarray at home, raid the West in a quest for hard currency, durable goods and, almost as an afterthought, international artistic recognition.
"This is just one altercation we're involved in," Mr. Cripton said. Another involves the Aleksandrov Red Army Song and Dance Ensemble. Calling it by its more familiar name, he said: "We brought over the Aleksandrov Red Army Chorus in 1989, and we scheduled another tour for this year. We have an ironclad agreement with the Ministry of Defense that no other group would tour under the ministry's auspices. Lo and behold, another group billing itself as the Red Army Chorus is touring right on top of our group. And now we've learned that a third Red Army Chorus is going to tour the West Coast."
Ms. Hillyer and Mr. Cripton have different notions of their companies' merits.
"The sense I have, as a regular visitor to Russia since 1974," Mr. Cripton said, "is that the Kirov is at an all-time high in its ability to put together a production that represents the best of what Russian opera can be. The tradition in Russia is to build massive, wonderful sets that absolutely take over the stage, and there are lots of changes so that there's never a boring moment. A production like 'Boris' involves the equivalent of 17 40-foot containers of material, and there are 385 people in that production alone."
For Ms. Hillyer, one attraction of the St. Petersburg National is that it avoids all that. Only 250 singers and musicians are taking part in the entire tour. In its earlier incarnation, as the Maly Theater, founded in 1918, the company was known for productions that were small scale and often adventurous. It was at the Maly that Shostakovich's "Lady Macbeth of Mtsensk" and "The Nose" and Prokofiev's "War and Peace" first came to life. And the theater has long maintained its ties with the St. Petersburg Conservatory, where its current director, Stanislav Gaudasinsky, is a professor.
"The point about this company is that its productions are closer to the musical theater than to the big Russian productions I have seen at the Bolshoi and the Kirov," she said. "The traditional companies overwhelm you with the number of people on stage and with glittery costumes and sets. This company's tradition is to concentrate on stage direction. The characters are more important than the spectacle, and there is a real sense of ensemble."
Financially, the two companies are at opposite ends of the scale. The Kirov, a well-known international troupe with an even more famous ballet company, has in Mr. Cripton's words "anticipated certain things" and has earned a great deal of hard currency through its recordings and tours. The St. Petersburg National Opera, though it has been touring lately, has not done so well.
 
Other Hard-Luck Cases
 Ms. Hillyer has a history of taking on such hard-luck cases. In the late 1970's, she led a successful battle to save the Beacon Theater in Manhattan from the wrecker's ball. She has presented exhibits of Soviet emigre art at her Gallery International 57. She founded Save the Boat People to aid Southeast Asian refugees and has presented benefit concerts for other causes, from Unicef to the homeless in New York.
In that spirit, she has arranged "From Russia With Love," an art show to benefit the St. Petersburg company. Fourteen screens, prints, lithographs and watercolors, including works by Larry Rivers, Robert Rauschenberg, Alex Katz, Roberto Mirotte and David Salle, will be displayed on the promenade at the New York State Theater during the company's run. The proceeds from a silent auction of the works will go to the company.
The Kirov, while comparatively well off, will be doing some charity work of its own during its tour.
"The money they bring back from their tours is shared by everyone in the company, including those who are not coming on the tour," Mr. Cripton said. "They also bring back tons of food, which they will make available to people who did not tour. I've seen this myself. When I have to bring over 10 containers for sets that I know can fit into 8, I know what the extra 2 are for."

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
Trying to Tickle the Liberal Pulse of America

BYLINE: By HERBERT MITGANG

 BODY:

The L Word
An Unapologetic, Thoroughly
Biased, Long-Overdue
Explication and Celebration
of Liberalism
By David P. Barash
233 pages. William Morrow & Company. $21.
 
God and Other
Famous Liberals
Reclaiming the Politics of America
By F. Forrester Church
167 pages. Simon & Schuster. $19.
Two current books on the nature of liberalism in this Presidential election year owe a debt of gratitude -- albeit one that is dripping with sarcasm and despair -- to Presidents Reagan and Bush. "The L Word," by David P. Barash, a professor of psychology at the University of Washington in Seattle, and "God and Other Famous Liberals" by F. Forrester Church, the Unitarian pastor of All Souls Church in New York City, may not revive the liberal impulse in this country, but it won't be for lack of trying. Opposing the anti-liberal sound bites that have played so well in middle America, they want to remind the Democratic candidates of the party's proud liberal past. 
 At the Republican national convention in 1988, Mr. Reagan said that the "masquerade" was over and that it was time to mention "the dreaded L word, to say the policies of our opposition" were "liberal, liberal, liberal." The phrase by the former Great Communicator stuck; it doesn't seem to be heard too loudly on the Democratic hustings in 1992. Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, who espoused some of the old liberal New Deal ideas early in the primaries, has since dropped out of the race.
Picking up the L-word theme in his first Presidential campaign, Mr. Bush attacked the liberals as "remnants of the 1960's, the New Left, campus radicals grown old, the peace marchers and the nuclear-freeze activists." In response, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, the Democratic standard-bearer, retreated from identifying himself as a liberal, saying the election was about competence, not ideology.
Professor Barash writes that by denying his liberal political heritage, Governor Dukakis caused many voters to question their own liberalism. "The L Word" wanders all over the place as the author offers his "unapologetic, thoroughly biased, long-overdue explication and celebration of liberalism." He writes in an anecdotal style that must go over well in the classroom, but given the complex history of liberalism on the American scene is not always compelling on paper.
His book is sprinkled with familiar aphorisms by Ambrose Bierce (a conservative is "a statesman who is enamored of existing evils, as distinguished from the liberal, who wishes to replace them with others"), by Will Rogers ("I don't belong to any organized political party. I'm a Democrat") and by a number of modern journalists and historians.
Professor Barash is most original when writing about the "cold-war liberalism" practiced by Democrats, which matched the Republicans in jingoism and military adventurism. He reminds readers of the split personalities of some liberals in domestic and foreign affairs and deplores the fact that "it was J. F. K. and Lyndon Johnson -- two notable liberals -- who got us most deeply involved" in Vietnam.
"Cold-war liberalism has been, in part, an effort to give the lie to Heywood Broun's criticism that a liberal is someone who leaves the room whenever a fight begins," he writes. "In its origins, cold-war liberalism was also energized by the Keynesian recognition that Federal spending was good for the economy."
For the 1990's, Professor Barash suggests that liberals don't need new ideas nearly as much as they need faith and confidence in their old ones. The future of liberalism, he says, is essentially to put "old wine in new bottles, so long as the wine is of good vintage."
In "God and Other Famous Liberals," Dr. Church arrives at his liberalism from a different direction. Rooted in personal experiences, his book is a compelling blend of religion, humanism and, yes, politics. Like his father, the late Frank Church, who was an outstanding liberal Senator from Idaho, Dr. Church was an early opponent of the Vietnam War and of keeping secrets from the American people. Like many students who lived through the 1960's, Vietnam was a turning point in the author's thinking.
The reader learns that Dr. Church's political and religious heritage fortify his liberal stands. He challenges military and religious icons with equal fervor. For instance, he criticizes Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North for his hawkish flag-waving during the Iran-contra hearings and scorns Jerry Falwell, the evangelist, for writing that God is in favor of "property ownership, competition, diligence, work and acquisition."
The author wonders whether he and the evangelist are reading the same Bible, "the one in which the last worker to arrive in the vineyard receives the same pay as the first, and the rich man is told to give away everything he has to the poor if he wants to go to heaven." As for the flag, he wonders whether Colonel North and he are "talking about the same country, when he (convicted felon or not) calls on us to 'be faithful to those ideas and values that made this country what it is.' "
At the heart of both books is President Franklin D. Roosevelt. Dr. Church writes that anyone looking for a new liberal agenda need look no further than his Presidential papers and, specifically, the conclusion of his message to Congress on Jan. 6, 1941.
In that address, Roosevelt said there was nothing mysterious about the foundations of a healthy and strong democracy. The basic things expected by the American people were simple. He said those included equality of opportunity for youth and others; jobs for those who can work; security for those who need it; the ending of special privilege for the few; the preservation of civil liberties for all, and the enjoyment of the fruits of scientific progress in a wider and constantly rising standard of living.
Dr. Church's "God and Other Famous Liberals" leaves the distinct impression that a half-century after F. D. R. expressed these thoughts, neither liberals nor conservatives would dare to speak this openly during the 1992 Presidential campaign.
Any candidate who did so might be accused of using the "dangerous" L word.
