HEADLINE: New Studies Predict Profits In Heading Off Warming

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS

 BODY:
FAR from being ruinously expensive, efforts to head off a feared global warming could actually save money or even turn a profit in the long run, environmentalists, government analysts and even some business leaders and economists say.
The view is contrary to that of the Bush Administration, which in international talks has resisted placing limits on emissions of carbon dioxide, a heat-trapping gas. The Administration has found support from studies indicating that the costs of ultimately reducing emissions could run to tens of billions of dollars a year. 
 But now the opposite view is being pressed with increasing insistence. Citing studies of their own, advocates argue that reducing the emissions would force the economy to use energy more efficiently and at less cost in the long run, would free up large amounts of capital for expansion if the right governmental policies were followed, and would make American business more competitive internationally.
"To ignore the economic opportunities is to fail to seize the moment, to become paralyzed by exclusive focus on one side of the economic ledger," Dr. Robert N. Stavins, an economist at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University, said at a recent conference on the subject at the Smithsonian Institution in Washington.
A recent study by four environmental groups, coordinated by the Union of Concerned Scientists, concluded that aggressive action to lower carbon dioxide emissions by 70 percent over the next 40 years could cost the economy about $2.7 trillion. But it could also save consumers and industry $5 trillion in fuel and electricity bills, the study found, for a net saving of $2.3 trillion.
And unofficial studies by Environmental Protection Agency analysts conclude that the gross national product would rise, not fall, over the next 20 years if emissions were reduced through a "carbon tax" on the extraction of coal, oil and natural gas -- and the tax revenues were "recycled" back into the economy through investment tax credits for industry, thus spurring capital investment.
Competing studies consider different factors and operate on different assumptions, and no consensus on the net economic effect of reducing carbon dioxide emissions has emerged. But the economic debate has been joined, and its outcome could be critical in the attempt to deal with a global environmental concern of the first magnitude.
Carbon dioxide and other gases, chiefly methane, trap heat in the atmosphere much as glass panes trap it in a greenhouse. An international panel of scientists convened by the United Nations has predicted that if current emission rates continue, the earth's average surface temperature will rise by 3 to 8 degrees Fahrenheit by the end of the next century. Many scientists believe this could have a catastrophic effect on climate.
Global warming and energy are inextricably linked because carbon dioxide, the most abundant and important greenhouse gas emitted by industrial society, is produced by burning fossil fuels like coal and oil. The United States, which lags behind other industrialized countries like Japan and Germany in energy efficiency, is the world's leading emitter of carbon dioxide. Thus, greater efficiency of energy use in this country is viewed as essential in trying to stabilize or reduce carbon dioxide emissions.
Analysis by the Environmental Protection Agency suggests that modest energy-efficiency measures already under way will allow American per-capita emissions of carbon dioxide to stabilize at 1990 levels by the year 2000, at little or no cost to the economy. The European Community has called for overall emissions to be stabilized at 1990 levels by 2000; although the United States has opposed such a target and timetable, the E.P.A.'s analysis suggests that as a practical matter, it will be close to compliance anyway.
Nevertheless, an American-European impasse on emission ceilings has held up agreement on a climate treaty, which would be signed at a United Nations-sponsored summit meeting on the environment in Rio de Janeiro in June. The final round of talks will start April 30 in New York.
But even if an agreement is reached, it may be only a first step.
 
Sharp Reductions Urged
 Many scientists believe that sharp reductions in carbon dioxide emissions -- not just a stabilization -- will ultimately be necessary. They say that at 1990 rates of emission, atmospheric concentrations of carbon dioxide would still grow. And in this context, the debate on the economic effects of reducing emissions takes on even greater importance. Answers will be needed if it becomes clearer in the next few years that the threat of warming is indeed serious.
One major study made public last December, commissioned by Congress and carried out by the Department of Energy, concluded that reducing carbon dioxide emissions by 20 percent from 1990 levels would cost $95 billion a year in 2000. In general, its conclusions are consistent with those of a number of other Government and private studies.
But the study is based on the assumption that the economy is already using energy in the most efficient way possible, said Alden Meyer, an energy analyst with the Union of Concerned Scientists. "That assumption is flat-out false," Mr. Meyer said.
He said the market contained many barriers to the adoption of more efficient practices and technologies. For instance, a landlord may have no incentive to install more energy-efficient appliances or windows because tenants pay electricity bills. If the landlord was offered a subsidy to do so, the barrier could be overcome.
 
Incentives for Efficiency
 Electric companies in a few states are indeed paying customers to install more efficient lighting, cooling and heating systems, for example, in lieu of building new emission-producing power plants. The companies are allowed to recover the money by increasing rates. The saving to the economy comes in the form of lower electric bills for the building owner. The restraint on emissions comes both from lower energy use and not having to build a new power plant.
The study, coordinated by Mr. Meyer, found that if an aggressive policy to expand energy efficiency and switch to clean, renewable energy sources were pursued, the economy would reap a net saving of $2.3 trillion over the next 40 years and carbon dioxide emissions would be reduced by 70 percent.
Participating in the study along with the Union of Concerned Scientists were the Alliance to Save Energy, the American Council for an Energy-Efficient Economy and the Natural Resources Defense Council, all nonprofit organizations that advocate greater efficiency of energy use.
But an analyst at the Department of Energy, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said that while the department favored the removal of barriers to greater efficiency, consumer behavior was more complicated than the environmentalists' study assumes. That could make the barriers more difficult to remove, he said.
He said the environmentalists' study assumed that the economy would continue to shift away from manufacturing as it has in the past, which he called a questionable assumption. He said the study also assumed a lower basic growth rate for the economy: 2.5 percent a year as compared with 3 percent in the Department of Energy study. A higher growth rate means emission reductions are more difficult and costly to achieve.
Mr. Meyer criticized the Administration's projected 3 percent growth rate as unrealistically high, a view that is shared by many private economists.
Analysts for the Environmental Protection Agency say the Energy Department study does not reflect the ways in which, according to the unofficial study by their agency, the proceeds of a carbon tax could be recycled through the tax system to spur economic growth. The analysts found that if the tax revenues were used to reduce personal income taxes or the Federal budget deficit, this would barely offset, if at all, the negative effect of the tax.
That negative impact would come when the coal and oil industries passed on the carbon tax to their customers in the form of higher prices. But if the revenue was used to encourage business investment through tax credits, they found, the effect of the carbon tax would be more than offset, producing a net gain for the national economy.
A combination of investment tax credits and personal income-tax reductions -- to make the tax more acceptable to consumers -- could achieve substantial reductions in carbon emissions at no cost, according to the analysis.
Market-based solutions of this sort could also make the price of American goods and services more competitive with those of the more energy-efficient economies of Europe and Japan, said Dr. Stavins.
While the current anti-tax mood of the United States discourages the adoption of a carbon tax, at least for now, the European Community is seriously considering it as the centerpiece of its efforts to reduce emissions.
Relatively cheap energy in the United States has made this country less efficient and therefore less competitive worldwide, Stephan Schmidheiny, a Swiss industrialist, told the Smithsonian conference. Mr. Schmidneiny is the principal adviser for business and industry to Maurice F. Strong, the secretary general of the U.N. environment meeting.
Shakeouts are painful, and the move to an energy-efficient market would undoubtedly produce some transitional pain, even if the end result is a more robust economy. Coal and oil producers and their employees, for example, could be heavily hit by a carbon tax, even if other sectors benefited from the recycling of the tax.
 
The Ultimate Cost
 Beyond all this, another question arises: What would be the cost of not taking action if serious global warming occurs?
Few economists have addressed it. One, Dr. William D. Nordhaus of Yale University, has published a "best guess" estimate that a doubling of atmospheric carbon dioxide would reduce this country's gross national product by one-fourth of 1 percent. But Dr. Nordhaus notes that many important factors are not included in economic accounts. These include "human health, biological diversity, amenity values of everyday life and leisure, and environmental quality," he wrote in a 1990 monograph.
It may be impossible to place monetary values on some of these big factors, even though they are clearly valuable. Biologists, for instance, fear that global warming will catastrophically speed a steady loss of biological species that is now occurring worldworld. They also believe that the world's forests harbor untold billions of dollars worth of biological riches that could be exploited for pharmaceuticals and other products without harming the environment. But their worth has not been gauged.
The effort to do so is "low on the totem pole of what is of interest to our discipline," Allen Sinai, chief economist of the Boston Company Inc., said recently at a debate on development and the environment held in Cambridge, Mass., under the sponsorship of Earthwatch, a Boston-based scientific research and education organization.
Some scientists believe economists should refrain from even making the attempt until more is known about the biological world. The tropical forests, for example, are mostly unexplored and only a fraction of species with economic value have been identified. Pending more knowledge, Dr. E. O. Wilson, a conservation biologist at Harvard University, said at the Cambridge debate, economists "should avoid fruitless and dangerous exercises in cost-benefit analysis which is far beyond their reach and join in the ethic of saving every scrap of biological diversity possible."

HEADLINE: ON HORSE RACING;
There's Still Some Unfinished Business in Florida

BYLINE: By Joseph Durso

DATELINE: HALLANDALE, Fla.

 BODY:
The winter racing season in Florida produced some stirrings of economic revival, a slight gain in attendance and record betting despite a one-day boycott of Gulfstream Park by the local trainers.
But it failed to produce its two main goals: an agreement on racing dates among the three contending tracks in the Miami area, and a dominant horse to challenge Arazi for the Kentucky Derby and beyond. 
 An agreement on racing dates is essential to keep the business from deteriorating into a free-for-all. A dominant horse is essential to keep the Triple Crown from dwindling into a one-man show.
Neither goal was in sight when Gulfstream Park ended its two-month meeting on Sunday; neither will be in sight when Calder opens its six-month season today. The only sure thing is that both issues will have been resolved, for better or worse, by the time Hialeah opens in the fall.
The leading jockey at Gulfstream this winter was Julie Krone, who switched her act here from New York for the first time and rode 72 winners in 371 races. The leading jockey in terms of quality performance was Jerry Bailey, who rode nine stakes winners, including D. J. Cat in the Swale Stakes on Saturday and Technology in the Florida Derby four races later. The leading trainer was Sonny Hine, who saddled 22 winners, including Technology.
But none of the winners in Florida's winter will head for Kentucky or New York with a loud and clear challenge to Arazi, who races and wins and trains in France for flying visits to America. He made his debut in this country last Nov. 2 by circling the field of 14 and winning the Breeders' Cup Juvenile in a smashing performance. He will try to make a smashing return on May 2 when he runs in the Kentucky Derby. No horse in history has commuted from Europe and swept America's championships.
But then, no horse in Florida has raced to the top of the heap this winter the way Fly So Free did last year when he opened the season as the juvenile champion and then won Gulfstream's three classics for 3-year-olds and established himself as the horse to beat in Kentucky. He was not alone.
Strike the Gold stalked him in the Florida Derby and finally outran him in the Blue Grass Stakes and the Kentucky Derby in Kentucky. And Hansel, who ran third in the Florida Derby, later outran everybody in both the Preakness and the Belmont.
Even the filly Meadow Star was undefeated at this time last year and seemed ready to challenge colts for the Triple Crown. She didn't, but she was another symbol of the depth of the 3-year-old division. However, nobody in last season's 2-year-old division developed into the same sort of superstar, except Arazi.
"You wonder about last year's 2-year-olds," said Leroy Jolley, who trains Meadow Star. "You have to wonder if they were just an exceptionally mediocre bunch. None of them seems to have stayed at the top all year. So, now you have Arazi on top, and a lot of others trying to work their way up to that level. And he hasn't even raced yet this year."
You don't have to remind D. Wayne Lukas, who has saddled more winners than any other trainer in the country in the last 10 years. He trains Dance Floor, who came out of California as a hotshot spoiling for a fight with Arazi. He even imitated Arazi by flying into town, winning the Fountain of Youth Stakes at Gulfstream and then flying home to rest on his laurels. Then he flew back to Gulfstream, ran second in the Florida Derby, suffered some pulmonary bleeding and flew home one more time to California as a bowed and maybe beaten candidate.
Lukas, putting it into terms that might be best understood by his friend Bobby Knight of Indiana University, said: "The senior division of racing, the handicap division, is like the N.B.A. with its stars already established. The 3-year-old division is like the N.C.A.A. tournament: The horses are still sorting themselves out for the Triple Crown."
So, Arazi reigns in France these days while the opposition tries to get sorted out. Bertrando won his 1992 debut in California on Sunday, and Lure won his debut in New York on Sunday. But nobody mounted the challenge in Florida.
On the business side of the business, Gulfstream counted 11,062 customers on the average, a gain of nearly 2 percent over last year. And betting, both at the track and at a widening number of offtrack sites, rose by nearly 25 percent to a daily average of $2.5 million. But then, the average may have been higher because the season was 30 days shorter, and the bettors had to act fast.
Next for Gulfstream Park: the Breeders' Cup championships on Oct. 31. But some answers to the steepening problems of racing in Florida had better be found long before.

HEADLINE: Invest in Venezuelan Democracy

 BODY:
A month after dodging assassination during a military coup attempt, President Carlos Andres Perez of Venezuela still fights for survival. He has struck back with political reforms meant to revitalize one of Latin America's oldest democracies. The U.S., with a strong interest in his success, can help. No economic bailouts are needed, just more consistent political engagement and follow-through on existing initiatives.
The coup attempt revealed deep fractures behind Venezuela's democratic facade. Government patronage and consumer subsidies financed by oil surpluses had helped build a broad consensus. When oil prices fell and world markets became more competitive, Venezuela had to retrench. 
 President Perez deserves credit for pushing through needed reforms. But the new policies alienated poor and middle-class Venezuelans who felt that the rich and the politically connected evaded a fair share of sacrifice. Mr. Perez has now moved to ease pressures on the middle class and reduce the influence of party machines. A wider range of political forces has been invited into the Government, and a constitutional assembly summoned.
Foreign commitments are not a high priority with U.S. voters this year. But middle-income countries like Venezuela are not looking for handouts. They seek commercial investments and free access for their goods in world markets. Washington can encourage investment by more adequately financing the seed money projects of the Enterprise for the Americas program. And it can help Venezuela reduce its dependency on oil by successfully concluding the Uruguay Round trade negotiations.
Even more important, Washington can help restore confidence in Venezuela's political stability by consistently standing behind the hemisphere's beleaguered democracies. The recent military challenges in Haiti and Venezuela make strengthening the collective security mechanisms of the Organization of American States an urgent priority.
Such measures cost relatively little and promise high dividends. President Perez is taking brave risks. He deserves Washington's support.

LENGTH: 458 words

HEADLINE: Can Democrats Do Better on Race?

 BODY:
The issue of race has long divided American society and does so today. Republican exploitation of the issue simply made matters worse. Yet the Democrats who aspire to the White House, with one exception, have paid little attention to race. Bill Clinton has addressed the issue more shrewdly and boldly than his opponents, but even he focuses mainly on cures for the sagging economy.
That's an understandable preoccupation: the economy is Topic A. But while the dangerous racial climate may not be as corrosive as the recession, it surely runs a close second. And it surely deserves far more attention than the people who aspire to lead a united nation give it. 
 When not wholly ignoring the issue, Republicans from Ronald Reagan on have often exploited it for partisan advantage. President Bush's stubborn opposition to the civil rights bill, which he falsely labeled a quota bill, is a recent case in point. And Mr. Bush has hardly responded at all to the divisive fulminations of Patrick Buchanan.
Among the Democrats, Mr. Clinton was first to recognize the need for a message of conciliation that would apply equally to worried whites and blacks. On Super Tuesday, poor blacks and blue-collar white voters supported him, suggesting that Americans can transcend racial divisions and look to their mutual interests.
By contrast, race has hardly been mentioned in Paul Tsongas's campaign. Though he has long demonstrated a personal commitment to racial harmony and justice, he has chosen now to stress his program for economic growth instead. Jerry Brown also has excellent credentials as a conciliator, but he too has emphasized economics.
In Chicago, even Mr. Clinton seemed to dodge. The Windy City is the most segregated of America's major cities. Demographers call it "hypersegregation." The city's dismal race relations could well become the norm across the nation. Mayor Richard M. Daley inflames matters further by promoting a redistricting plan that's brazenly aimed at diminishing black political power.
The three Democrats waltzed through Chicago, oblivious to the circumstances around them. Apart from Mr. Brown's brief criticism of Mayor Daley's plan, race scarcely came up at all. Mr. Clinton closed the first debate by underscoring efforts he had made in Michigan to bring white and black communities together. Those efforts were laudable. But his comments in the debate ignored dramatic racial divisions right before his eyes.
The Democrats are correct to assume that the recession is topic A. But they are terribly wrong if they've decided to soft-pedal race. The nation's racial climate has deteriorated in the last 10 years. That damage will only grow worse if the Democrats shrink from the task of repairing it.

HEADLINE: The Right Message

BYLINE: By William Julius Wilson; William Julius Wilson is professor of sociology and public policy at the University of Chicago.

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
Three years ago on this page I argued that the promotion of programs to unite, not divide, racial minorities and whites would strengthen the Democratic Party's position in the 1992 Presidential election. Bill Clinton's campaign provides an interesting test case for this strategy. He drew a clear majority of lower- and middle-income white and Hispanic voters and an overwhelming majority of black voters across the South. Recent opinion polls indicate a similar pattern for today's Illinois and Michigan primaries.
Many point to the modest success of Jesse Jackson's "rainbow coalition" four years ago to argue against the idea that race can be removed as an obstacle in a political campaign. But the Arkansas Governor built this biracial coalition during a time of intense racial tension in this country. The media, more concerned about his personal past than with substantive issues, are only beginning to grasp the significance of this accomplishment. 
 If Mr. Clinton is able to hold this coalition together in the remaining primaries, he will pose a far more serious challenge to President Bush than anyone thought possible before the campaign. Why has he been able to bring together antagonistic racial groups even in Louisiana where a majority of white voters supported David Duke in last year's gubernatorial election?
I first got a clue to the answer while watching a televised speech Mr. Clinton gave in a church in Houston this month. His message to the all-black audience could have been delivered to a solely white one. It included two important aspects: an explicit acknowledgment of the racial tension in America and the need for leadership to unite, not divide, the races; and a discussion of programs intended for all low- to moderate-income groups, not just minorities.
It is important that leaders channel the frustrations of citizens in positive or constructive directions when times are hard. But just the opposite has been more likely to occur in the last few years: the negative populist appeals of a David Duke and the black solidarity oratory of an Al Sharpton have exacerbated racial tensions.
The Clinton message has been a sharp contrast for those who have grown weary of destructive racial rhetoric. In his campaign speeches, he argues that demogogy forces us to turn on each other -- race against race -- instead of associating our declining real incomes, increasing job insecurity and growing pessimism with the failed policies of the White House. He points out that people who are employed are working more hours for less money and people who are unemployed are looking harder for work with less satisfactory results. Americans are paying more for housing, education, health care and taxes while services have been cut. Mr. Clinton's success in the primaries makes it clear that both whites and blacks of low to moderate incomes relate to this approach.
They also relate to his proposed solutions that include job creation and training, education, support for the working poor, tax relief for lower- and middle-income groups and affordable health care for all. Other candidates have stressed these issues and have proposed similar solutions. But only Mr. Clinton has integrated them into a vision to promote racial unity.
Mr. Clinton has destroyed the myth that blacks will only respond if a candidate highlights race-specific issues and programs. African Americans, devastated by unemployment and concerned about adequate health-care coverage and education, have reacted favorably to his approach. It has allowed blacks to display their political sophistication and show their willingness to identify with a candidate who addresses them without narrowly focusing his message on race. Likewise, Governor Clinton's interaction with black voters reflects respect for their judgment and an understanding of the depth and breadth of their concerns.
This is not to suggest that he does not boast about his own civil rights record and equal opportunity accomplishments in Arkansas -- including reducing the number of unemployed black youth and adults by 24 percent between 1983 and 1991. But this is not the core of his message when addressing black audiences.
Some observers believe that race is so divisive in America that whites, especially the poor and working class, will not support a candidate who receives overwhelming support of the blacks who vote. But this fails to consider what draws minority support. If the message is tailored to a black audience, whites draw back, just as blacks draw back when the words are tailored to a white audience. But if the message emphasizes issues and programs that concern the families of all racial and ethnic groups, whites will see their mutual interests and join in a coalition with minorities to elect a progressive candidate.
There is a general view today that the Democrats will once again self-destruct with a weak candidate in November. Those who express such an opinion may be in for a surprise. They may have failed to appreciate the significance of Mr. Clinton's remarkable biracial coalition.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Sequestering Juries Guarantees Trial System

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Outrageous! That is the only appropriate response to "Greed, Sequestered" (Topics of The Times, Feb. 28). It might appear that the expenses of sequestering a jury overnight while it is deliberating its verdict far outweigh the value of sequestration in difficult economic times. Repeatedly, however, we have demonstrated that claims of the saving to be gained by eliminating jury sequestration are inaccurate. Our position has been supported by data taken from the New York State Office of Court Administration budget.
Eliminating sequestration of jurors would be a blatant invitation to violence, tampering and unfair solicitation, not to mention the cause of numerous mistrials. You are likely to spend more, not less, to maintain the credibility of the trial process by eliminating sequestration. We believe the law works perfectly for those it is designed to protect: the public and crime victims. 
 And we resent the "greedy court officers" characterization. Our members are hard-working, dedicated professionals, whose collective reputation does not deserve such slander. We are not alone in our belief that sequestration should remain unchanged. Supporters of sequestration include the New York District Attorneys Association; the New York City and Nassau County Patrolmen's Benevolent Associations; the Suffolk, Nassau and Westchester court employee unions; and the New York State A.F.L.-C.I.O.
We find it amazing that you would take such a callous view toward the safety of those upon whom we all depend to make our court system effective.
 
GLENN T. RIDDELL
First Vice President
Supreme Court Officers Association
New York, March 2, 1992

HEADLINE: With Apologies to Havel, Let Reason Rule;
A Wan Spirituality

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"The End of the Modern Era," (Op-Ed, March 1), Vaclav Havel's New Age maundering, would not be so ominous if he were not in charge of a newly democratized nation, and thus the focus of a certain hopeful expectancy. To Mr. Havel the end of Communism is a "message to the human race" that employing the scientific method and accumulated objective knowledge to help bring about commonly agreed-upon social goals is not the way to go.
Instead, he offers a wan spirituality in which we are led by a new breed of politicians, each with "trust in his own subjectivity as his principal link with the subjectivity of the world." 
 If this is how Mr. Havel views himself we are all in trouble. His call to irrationalism will be of little help against the population explosion, the greenhouse effect, holes in the ozone layer, the dramatically widening gap between the rich north and the poor south, the danger of famine, the depletion of the biosphere and the mineral resources of the planet, and the expansion of commercial television culture, all of which he points to as signs that civilization is in danger.
Mr. Havel's embrace of the free-market system, which many consider a major contributor to these disasters, can only be justified by a commitment to a scientific attitude in which policies are continually reassessed in relation to experience.
Few would begrudge the Czechoslovak people and other Eastern Europeans their newly won freedom to experiment with new social and economic directions. But in their attempts to avoid previous errors of both the communist and capitalist systems, they will not be helped, in our opinion, by the sort of dangerous obscurantism represented by Mr. Havel's words.
 
STUART A. NEWMAN
FELIPE C. CABELLO
Valhalla, N.Y., March 3, 1992
The writers are, respectively, professor of cell biology and associate professor of microbiology, New York Medical College.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 1825 words

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN;
CLINTON WINS BIG VICTORIES IN 2 MIDWESTERN PRIMARIES; BUSH INCREASES G.O.P. EDGE

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, March 17

 BODY:
In a big stride toward the Democratic nomination, Gov. Bill Clinton won commanding victories in the Illinois and Michigan primaries today and dealt a serious blow to former Senator Paul E. Tsongas.
The gains of Mr. Clinton edge him toward the halfway mark in the number of delegates needed to wrap up the nomination. The losses of Mr. Tsongas were heightened by his placing a weak third in Michigan, behind both Mr. Clinton and former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California.
 
Big Leads in Delegates
 
 President Bush won by huge margins in both states over Patrick J. Buchanan, the conservative commentator. Despite Mr. Buchanan's attempts to mine Michigan's economic discontent, Mr. Bush won 67 percent and his challenger 25 percent nearly 90 percent of the votes counted. In Illinois, with more than 90 percent of the votes counted, Mr. Bush had 76 percent and Mr. Buchanan 22 percent. In a statement from the White House, the President said the voters had "virtually assured" his nomination.
On the Democratic side, Mr. Clinton had 51 percent of the vote in Illinois with almost 90 percent of the vote counted. Mr. Tsongas followed with 26 percent, and Mr. Brown had 15 percent. In Michigan, with almost 90 percent of the votes counted, Mr. Clinton won 48 percent, followed by Mr. Brown with 28 percent and Mr. Tsongas with 18 percent.
Voters in Illinois delivered a stinging anti-incumbent message, as two relatively unknown political figures, defeated Senator Alan J. Dixon and Representative Gus Savage in the Democratic primary. The victor in the Senate race, Carol Moseley Braun, could become the Senate's first black woman. [Page A19.]
 
Insurmountable Bush Lead
 Mr. Bush held his insurmountable lead in the Republican nomination race, picking up at least 140 more delegates, for a total of more than 720. At his current pace, Mr. Bush will have a majority of delegates, 1,105, by the Pennsylvania primary on April 28. Mr. Buchanan won no delegates, remaining at 46.
Mr. Clinton also maintained a commanding lead in the Democratic delegate contest, but his race was more unsettled. Mr. Clinton won about 160 delegates tonight, making his total at least 973 delegates, including the "super delegates" -- party officials, governors, former elected leaders and members of Congress. To win the nomination, 2,145 delegates are needed.
Mr. Tsongas is well behind in delegates, picking up only about 70, for a total of about 425. Mr. Brown won about 60 delegates, for a total of about 157.
Mr. Clinton, who swept the South in last week's Super Tuesday primaries, was euphoric tonight. Claiming victory in Chicago, the Governor of Arkansas declared: "I ask you to remember what people have voted for. They have voted for change."
Mr. Tsongas, whose aides insisted he was in the race through the Democratic National Convention, was already in Connecticut, campaigning for next Tuesday's primary and arguing that the Democrats wanted "an alternative" and that he was it. In a speech to students at Trinity College in Hartford, the former Senator from Massachusetts congratulated Mr. Clinton, saying, "The fact is he went into two large states and did well."
Still, Mr. Brown's performance in Michigan, where he offered himself as the roaring voice of blue-collar outrage, signaled to some Democrats that he would be competing hard with Mr. Tsongas for the role of "Clinton alternative."
Campaigning tonight in Wisconsin, which votes on April 7, Mr. Brown congratulated Mr. Clinton but added that the race was anything but over. "Bill Clinton has an enormous machine," Mr. Brown said. "Ours takes longer, but the race is turning into a two-man race and will now give a chance for America to make a choice, a real choice."
At stake in today's voting were 295 pledged delegates to the national convention. But the battle for Michigan and Illinois turned into a flat-out brawl over who was the best champion of working America and who was the "most electable" opponent against Mr. Bush next fall. Mr. Brown tried to slow Mr. Clinton by assailing him as a candidate who produced "a scandal a week." But the Governor, with a big boost from his Super Tuesday victories and a formidable organizational edge, quickly took huge leads here.
Some political professionals asserted tonight that it would be difficult to stop Mr. Clinton now in his drive for the nomination. Ronald H. Brown, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said: "I think Bill Clinton has taken a major step toward the nomination. It's clear the end game has begun, but we're still too early in the process to declare anyone the de facto nominee."
Mr. Brown added, "The fat lady hasn't sung -- but she's sure doing her sound checks."
New York's primary, to be held on April 7, is almost always a stern test, even for a front-runner.
 
Sacrifice? Enough Already
 Each state that voted today has about 5.8 million registered voters. In Illinois, with competitive Congressional primaries, 1.5 million people voted in the Democratic Presidential primary and about 700,000 voted in the Republican primary. In Michigan, there were about 500,000 voters in each party.
The exit polls show that Mr. Tsongas was a victim of his own demographics. His message of economic sacrifice, which plays so well among upper-income and better-educated suburbanites, was simply overwhelmed in a region where layoffs are a chronic anxiety and where many voters feel they have sacrificed enough. In Michigan, more than half the voters in union households backed Mr. Clinton; just 1 in 10 went for Mr. Tsongas.
"There was a lot of disaffected labor," said Dennis Kanin, Mr. Tsongas's campaign manager. "Paul was very forthright in his views on striker replacement and it hurt him." Indeed, Mr. Tsongas was often asked why he, unlike his rivals, refused to endorse legislation that would outlaw the hiring of permanent replacement workers for striking employees.
But the problems of the Tsongas campaign ran far deeper than that. The former Senator also paid a price for his inability to break through to another crucial part of any Democratic primary coalition: black voters. In Michigan, he received fewer than 1 in 20 votes cast by blacks; in Illinois, about 1 in 10. He had a hard time coping with the burst of good publicity Mr. Clinton received after Super Tuesday. And Mr. Tsongas once again seemed out-organized and out-planned by the Governor.
Moreover, Mr. Tsongas let his message -- particularly his attempt to cast himself as a candidate above politics-as-usual -- seem muted by his tough television campaign against Mr. Clinton.
 
Blaming the Establishment
 At a news conference in Hartford tonight, Mr. Tsongas portrayed Mr. Clinton's victories as the product of money and "the political establishment."
"It's not easy being an agent of change," he said. "It's not easy to try to tell the Democrats that you're going to have to worry about the economy and stop pandering with all these giveaways and invest in our future."
Still, the Tsongas campaign itself had touted this region as neutral turf. "Mr. Tsongas needed to win one of these two states to convince the pundits and the money people that he had a chance at stopping Mr. Clinton," said Tony Coelho, the former House majority whip from California.
 
Brown's Varied Appeal
 Mr. Brown clearly succeeded in filling a political vacuum in Michigan. With his United Auto Workers jacket and his angry stand against "fast track" authority for a free-trade agreement with Mexico, he deftly moved into the position left open by the departure of Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, the favored labor candidate. Mr. Brown picked up more than a third of the votes from union households. He also ran well among younger voters and and, not surprisingly, among voters who said a major factor in their decision was a candidate's ability to "shake things up."
Underscoring the unusual coalition he put together, Mr. Brown received a vote of nearly 4 in 10 of the voters with some post-graduate education.
Once again, Mr. Clinton succeeded in forging a coalition of whites and blacks that put him easily over the top. He received about 7 in 10 black votes in Michigan and Illinois. But he also ran strongly among middle-income voters, and in Illinois received about half of both white Protestant and white Catholic votes. He split Jewish support with Mr. Tsongas.
Mr. Clinton alluded to the broad nature of his support tonight in a victory rally at the Palmer House hotel in Chicago, where he took the stage amid flags and confetti and the gospel strains of "Oh, Happy Day," and where he was formally introduced by Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, Democrat of Connecticut. Mr. Clinton pleaded for an end to racial divisions and said his campaign succeeded because it was a unifying appeal.
"When an 8-year-old child is shot by another 8-year-old child in this city, this is not a racial problem," Mr. Clinton declared, referring to an incident that occurred last week. "It's an American problem."
The magnitude of Mr. Clinton's victories tonight prompted many Democrats to declare that the race was all but over, although they pointed to Mr. Brown's expected strength in the June 2 California primary. Phil Angelides, the chairman of the California Democratic Party, said, "It appears to be drawing to a conclusion, but in 1992, American politics is very volatile."
In addition, the Democratic Party's rules of strict proportional representation tend to slow down the nominating process. Mr. Clinton will have to increase his victory margins greatly or pick up a large chunk of the 560 uncommitted delegates to attain a nominating majority before California.
But his margins could quickly shoot up if another candidate drops out of the race. And the same rules that make it hard for him to pick up a nominating majority make it hard for his rivals to catch fire late, win some big states and overtake him.
Still, there remains a chance that the Democratic National Convention could convene without an undisputed nominee.
On the Republican side, Mr. Bush declared tonight that Michigan and Illinois had "virtually assured" his nomination. "The voters of Michigan and Illinois have endorsed my approach to change in America," he said in a written statement.
Edward Rollins, a Republican consultant, said, "I think the President has got the primaries behind him."
The Buchanan campaign, meanwhile, was scrambling for excuses. Paul Erikson, Mr. Buchanan's national political director, asserted that votes were siphoned from the conservative challenger by Mr. Brown. "Many of the crossover voters that would have gone to Buchanan were probably absorbed by Jerry Brown," Mr. Erikson said.
Despite his latest setback, Mr. Buchanan vowed to stay in the race, though his top campaign aides have conceded the nomination to Mr. Bush. These aides say the challenger will temper his attacks on Mr. Bush.

HEADLINE: Vermont Jobless Get Free Classes

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: MONTPELIER, Vt., Sept. 17

 BODY:
About 800 unemployed Vermonters are getting a chance to learn vocations ranging from computers to automotive repair for free at local adult vocational centers.
"It was a brainstorming idea that really caught on," said Allen Evans, state coordinator of adult technical education. "The high unemployment rate is depressing. Our perspective is that education can mean a lot in people's lives in terms of getting a job." 
 The 800 taking part in the courses, which started last month, represent about 10 percent of the state's unemployed.
The 16 adult vocational centers run by local school boards have been offering low-cost classes for adults for about five years, with about 5,000 people normally enrolled. People who are out of work and receiving unemployment benefits were permitted to enroll free in any classes in which there were vacancies. None of those eligible for the free classes had to be turned away.
"We're trying to make things a bit easier for people going through difficult times," said Donna Stratton, adult education coordinator at the Barre Vocational Center.

HEADLINE: How to Press North Korea

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 17

 BODY:
Despite a flurry of pledges in recent weeks from North Korean leaders that they are nearly ready to allow nuclear inspections, officials in Seoul and Washington say they are mired in a game of diplomatic hide-and-seek in which no one really knows how much time is left.
The officials say they are likely to let the negotiations play themselves out until June or a little beyond, the time North Korea and South Korea set Saturday for the first inspections to establish that neither side is developing or deploying nuclear weapons. 
 After that, they believe, enough evidence will have been assembled to argue to the United Nations Security Council that North Korea, much like Iraq, is dragging out negotiations in a play for time to build a bomb.
Because estimates vary widely on how much time North Korea needs to begin producing its own supplies of nuclear fuel, and then to make weapons, there are sharp differences of opinion over how long it is useful to keep the North Koreans talking.
 
No Attack Plan Now, but . . .
 Few believe that a full-scale crisis is imminent, and American military officials say there are no preparations under way for a military strike against nuclear plants. But that could change quickly, they say, if any evidence emerges that North Korea has begun to produce weapons-grade plutonium, a development many believe could take place this year.
"In the next few months we will know what it will be, a major crisis for Asia or a peaceful resolution," Francois Heisbourg, director of the International Institute for Strategic Studies in London, said recently. "And we will also see a major test of the relations between the U.S. and South Korea."
In recent weeks, Bush Administration officials have been in Seoul to try to defuse those tensions and to keep up the pressure on the North. But each new agreement, the latest of which creates a Joint Nuclear Control Commission between North and South to coordinate inspections, seems ridden with loopholes and chances for delay.
So does a separate agreement signed by North Korea in June to allow in the International Atomic Energy Agency. That still requires ratification by the North Korean Parliament, a step expected next month, and then the atomic energy agency will negotiate the sites and the nature of the inspections.
 
Providing a Way Out
 "You must play a game with them," said James R. Lilley, Assistant Secretary of Defense for International Security, at a recent conference. "We are trying to create a series of clear incentives and disincentives and still leave them a face-saving way out."
The evidence is murky about how quickly the North Koreans are proceeding. In recent months, senior American officials say, reconnaissance satellites have detected "a changed picture" around Yongbyon, a secret research site north of Pyongyang.
Trucks have been sighted pulling up to the recently completed fuel-reprocessing plant, where the North Koreans are thought to be trying to make weapons-grade plutonium. But the reconnaissance photos, officials say, do not make it clear whether the trucks are loading or unloading.
If they are unloading, some theories go, the plant will soon be fully equipped and presumably ready to begin operations. If they are loading, the equipment is perhaps being moved elsewhere in anticipation of inspections.
 
Sanctions Against a Hermit?
 Either way, American and South Korean officials concede that their leverage is limited. It is difficult to impose harsh economic sanctions on a nation with virtually no foreign trade. South Koreahas all but dismissed a military strike, because Seoul is situated only 35 miles from the 38th Parallel and its nuclear power plants would be vulnerable to retaliation.
North Korea has repeatedly denied that it is developing nuclear weapons.
Seoul and Washington have agreed on a basic objective: to force the North into a series of intrusive, short-notice inspections, both by the atomic energy agency and by South Korean teams to verify that the Communist Government has no nuclear intentions.
The two allies have coordinated their actions closely, especially in December, when the United States said it would allow North Korea to inspect its bases in the South to prove that nuclear weapons had been removed.
But recently, South Korean officials have said that the best strategy is to keep the two sides talking, meeting all the deadlines set under a reconciliation agreement reached in December. Last weekend, Seoul abandoned its long insistence on a clear set of dates and places for inspection before setting up a Joint Nuclear Control Commission.
The Pentagon has taken a generally harder line, urging the South to insist on specific inspection regimens rather than let the North win a propaganda battle by initialing vague agreements.
"We distrust the North's motives as much as the United States does," a South Korean negotiator said recently. "But as Koreans, we think we know more about how to negotiate effectively with the North."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Campaign Finance;
Presidential Field Raises Much Less Cash This Year Than in '88

BYLINE: By NEIL A. LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 17

 BODY:
This year's Presidential candidates have been able to raise only a fraction of the money that their counterparts raised four years ago. As a result, analysts say, money seems to be having a far smaller impact on primary races this year than it did in 1988.
A principal explanation for the decline, many fund-raisers say, is the recession, which has made it harder to squeeze money out of donors, especially from political action committees representing industries that are suffering. Among those with smaller resources are committees representing the automobile industries, realty agents and home builders. 
 Most strikingly, what this has meant is that the money raised and spent by this time in the 1988 election cycle, when no incumbent was running, was about five times what it is this year.
By Jan. 31, 1988, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, who went on to become the Democratic nominee, had raised nearly $15 million. By Jan. 31 of this year, the top Democratic fund-raiser was Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, who had received a little more than $5 million in donations.
All told, the 18 candidates for President four years ago had raised more than $149 million by Jan. 31, 1988. The corresponding amount for this Jan. 31 is $32 million for the 13 candidates.
The effect of the bigger pool of money was enormous four years ago, fund-raising experts said in interviews. "By this time last time around, Dukakis had just about blown away the field with his money advantage," said Leonard Riggio, chairman of Barnes and Noble and a major New York fund-raiser for the Democrats. While Governor Clinton is both the apparent leader in the race for the nomination as well as in fund raising, his advantage in cash on hand has not had the same effect. "This year, no one has exited because of money," said Mr. Riggio, who had been one of Senator Bob Kerrey's finance chairmen until Mr. Kerrey dropped out of the race because of his poor showing at the polls.
 
A 'Cheap' Nomination?
 As for the two remaining Democratic challengers, former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts, had raised $1.9 million by Jan. 31, and former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California had raised $940,000.
Herbert E. Alexander, a political science professor at the University of Southern California, said, "Whoever gets the Democratic nomination this year it will get it on the cheap."
On the Republican side four years ago, George Bush had raised nearly $25 million through Jan. 31. This time, he has raised about $10 million, compared with the $1.7 million raised by his challenger, Patrick J. Buchanan.
Four years ago, Mr. Bush faced stiff competition in the primaries. He was not even the leader in fund raising. That distinction went to Pat Robertson, the television evangelist, who had raised about $28 million.
The political action committees, those groups that special interests set up to support candidates, are also having a difficult time so far.
For example, the Dealers Election Action Committee, which represents domestic automobile dealers, had more than $2.3 million to spend four years ago. This year, by the end of January, it had only $1.2 million, according to records at the Federal Election Commission.
Another political action committee that represents both domestic and foreign dealers, Autopac, raised about $4.2 million four years ago. This time, it faces competition from a splinter group, Americans for Free International Trade. But both groups together have raised only about $1.3 million so far this year.
But Mr. Alexander and others agreed that that that situation would probably change sharply in the upcoming Congressional elections. Because of redistricting and the general anti-incumbent feelings among voters, many more seats are susceptible to change.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Voters;
Brown's Supporters: a Diverse Group

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, March 17

 BODY:
Former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California finished a strong second in the Michigan Democratic primary today because he scored well with a diverse group of voters: blue-collar workers, people with postgraduate degrees and those whose primary interest was the environment.
But from the surveys of voters leaving the polling places, it was difficult to discern a dominant pattern to the Brown vote, and his relative success in Michigan may have been due more to his advertising on television for the first time than to his personality or any particular position he took on issues. 
 In Illinois, where Mr. Brown did not advertise on television, he finished a distant third among the same kinds of voters with whom he did well in Michigan. For instance, he won less than 15 percent of the votes from union households and less than 20 percent from Democrats with advanced degrees.
Throughout the campaign, Mr. Brown has emphasized his view that the political system is totally corrupt. In Michigan, about one voter in seven said corruption in Government was an important element in how they voted, and Mr. Brown carried those voters by a large margin. But in Illinois, Mr. Brown finished well behind Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas and former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts among those who felt that corruption was a central issue.
Mr. Brown also apparently benefited from the endorsements he received from some local labor leaders who had been supporting Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa before he dropped out of the race last week. He won about a third of the Michigan voters from union households and about a third of those who said someone in their family worked in the automobile industry.
 
Bush and Clinton's Strength
 Despite the interest surrounding Mr. Brown's second-place finish in Michigan, the exit polls underlined the ability of President Bush and Mr. Clinton to lead by large margins among almost every age, ethnic and demographic group in Illinois and Michigan alike.
Still, the surveys turned up patterns that shed interesting light on the leading candidates' strengths and weaknesses.
For example, only slightly more than one Republican in five in the two states described the economy as "poor," but Patrick J. Buchanan, the conservative columnist who is challenging Mr. Bush for the nomination, won a clear majority of those voters.
Among Democrats, about 20 percent of the voters said that a candidate's willingness to tell the truth was one of the most important factors in their choice of whom to vote for, and of these, only about a quarter voted for Mr. Clinton.
The survey of voters leaving the polling places also underscored Mr. Tsongas's inability to win the votes of more than a small fraction of blacks, union members, blue-collar workers and those from households with annual incomes below $50,000. That has basically been true throughout the primary season. But after the voting in the South last week, Mr. Tsongas maintained that the pattern would change when the campaigns moved onto the neutral ground of the northern industrial states.
For example, Mr. Tsongas won about 10 percent of the black vote in the two states. Among self-described blue-collar workers, Mr. Tsongas took only about 1 Democratic vote in 10 in Michigan and about 2 in 10 in Illinois.
 
Varied Economic Outlook
 The exit polls demonstrated some important differences between Democratic and Republican voters. For instance, about half the Democrats in both states but only a quarter of the Republicans said their personal financial condition was worse than it was four years ago.
Less than 1 Democrat in 10 in Illinois and Michigan described the nation's economy as "good" or "excellent," but a fifth to a quarter of the Republicans characterized the economy that way.
Although Mr. Tsongas did not fare well today at the polls, one of his issues seems to have caught on with voters.
By ratios approaching 2 to 1 in both states, Democrats said that "providing incentives for economic growth" was a higher priority than "a tax cut for the middle class." That has been Mr. Tsongas's position throughout the campaign, while Mr. Clinton and the Democratic leaders in Congress have been emphasizing tax cuts.
Republicans were not asked the tax and growth question.
In both states, Mr. Clinton won a plurality of conservatives, moderates and liberals. More than half the Democrats who called themselves conservative or moderate voted for him as did more than two-fifths of the liberals.
In the Republican primaries, Mr. Bush won at least 70 percent of Republicans regardless of whether they identified themselves as conservative, moderate or liberal.
A gap between male and female voters showed up in the Republican primaries again today. As has been the case all year, Mr. Buchanan did much better among men than among women, winning close to 30 percent of the votes of men but only about 20 percent of the votes of women.

HEADLINE: Soviet Die-Hards Fume by Candlelight

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, March 17

 BODY:
A much-ballyhooed attempt by hard-line former Communists to revive the old Soviet parliament turned farcical today as only 217 former deputies showed up, fewer than a fourth of the number predicted by organizers, and the congress ended up meeting by candlelight at a state farm outside Moscow.
A somewhat more potent show was mounted later by some 10,000 die-hard champions of the old Soviet Union who gathered outside the Kremlin under red flags to sing the old Soviet anthem and to nominate an army general, Albert Makashov, for president. 
 General Makashov, who garnered 3.7 percent of the vote in the Russian federation presidential election last June and who was one of the organizers of the congress, declared that he would always be a "general of the Union of Soviet Soviet Republics," and said that "betrayers of the fatherland and the people should be publicly whipped."
The demonstrations, which were timed to mark the first anniversary of the referendum in which a majority of Soviet citizens voted to maintain a union, had alarmed proponents of political and economic reform.
 
Delegates Outnumbered
 But the small turnout for the "Extraordinary Sixth Congress of the Peoples' Deputies of the U.S.S.R." -- whose 217 "delegates" were overwhelmed by about 800 reporters -- and the now-familiar chants of the demonstrators on Manezh Square downtown seemed only to underscore the impotence of the old-line Communists.
Organizers of the congress had claimed that they would muster more than 1,000 members of the 2,250-seat Soviet assembly, which was chosen in 1989 as the first Soviet body to which delegates were freely elected.
The project was given additional attention by the decision of the new Russian parliament to declare the Congress unconstitutional. From the outset the proceedings went awry -- only a few dozen delegates came, and the buses they had ordered arrived late.
The organizers, who included a militant Communist from the northern Caucasus named Sazhi Umalatova, General Makashov and Col. Viktor Alksnis, announced that they would meet in Podolsk, outside Moscow. But when the buses arrived, the only hall available was the auditorium of the Voronovo State Farm -- and there the electricity went out.
Organizers darkly charged that the glitches were intentional, and nobody denied the possibility. Illumined by a single battery-powered bulb and candles, the delegates quickly adopted a sheaf of documents passed out in the bus, including a curious resolution titled "On the Inadmissibility of Involving the Country in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization."
Nonetheless, Mrs. Umalatova claimed that the very fact the meeting took place was a major success. "Now nobody can say there is no Union," she declared. "I congratulate you all, and myself as well."
The rally, which was allowed only at the last minute by Moscow authorities, continued late into the night with denunciations of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, President Boris N. Yeltsin, Western capitalism, high prices and the many other plaints of those disenfranchised by the collapse of the Soviet Union.
 
Cheers for TV Host
 Some of the loudest cheers went to Aleksandr Navzorov, a television show host from St. Petersburg who is known for his Soviet and nationalist views.
"We do have a real government," he declared. "Only it's in prison." The reference to the jailed plotters of the August coup drew a loud applause.
In the end, however, it was hard to find any genuine program or plan among the demonstrators, only a shared antagonism to the turn history has taken. Mingling with the Communists were monarchists, neo-fascists and a band of anarchists who hopped around in black leather jackets chanting "Eat gaseous worms." Nobody figured out what that was supposed to mean, but the slogan stirred considerable commotion.
The clashes many had feared never materialized. A group of about 20 young Yeltsin supporters chanted his name, infuriating demonstrators nearby, but there were no fisticuffs. The police kept a low profile.

HEADLINE: Private Interests Are Said to Benefit From U.S. Plan for Needy

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 17

 BODY:
A significant portion of a $3-billion-a-year Federal program intended to help needy communities is spent in ways that provide them few benefits and sometimes enrich private interests, Congressional investigators say.
The program, run by the Department of Housing and Urban Development, is supposed to build housing, raze slums, create jobs or provide other community benefits, primarily to those with modest incomes. But the investigators say many of program's projects fail to do so and are offering as examples low-interest loans to a minor-league hockey team in Troy, N.Y., a Saudi sheik in Miami and corporate giants like Sears. A Congressional subcommittee on Wednesday will discuss how one nonprofit group outside Philadelphia incurred more than $5 million in illegal expenses, including $10,148 for a dinner at a golf club, $3,258for model airplanes and a $345 limousine ride. 
 Some of the examples cited by Congress, like that from Philadelphia, have come from outright fraud and have led to criminal convictions. But a larger number of activities that are drawing criticism stem from disputes over the program's intentionally broad guidelines, which are meant to give communities wide latitude in spending the money.
 
Some Actions Defended
 In some of the instances cited by Congress, local officials have defended their decisions as being consistent with the program's purpose but Federal housing officials have disagreed and demanded the money be repaid. In other instances, the projects may meet the letter of the law, but critics question whether they fulfill the program's spirit.
In Miami, for instance, critics said the loan provided an unnecessary subsidy to a wealthy businessman who could have financed the project himself. But Federal housing officials say it met the program's guidelines since it brought a renovation in a blighted area.
Housing officials say they have already caught and corrected most of the violations being cited by Congress. They say this is evidence that their program oversight works, and they have called the program one of the Government's most effective.
Anna Kondratas, the assistant housing secretary who runs the program, said Congress was focusing on old and unrepresentative examples.
"It's probably less than 1 percent of the whole program doing clear violations of the law, and maybe up to 5 percent doing some questionable things," she said. "But that's a maximum."
But Representative Tom Lantos, the California Democrat who is conducting the House's investigation, has said housing officials provide lax oversight and that violations of the program's rules are "significant and widespread." And investigators at the housing agency's inspector general's office, which audits about two dozen communities each year, agree that the rule violations are not isolated. They say communities may be using the money for many more ineligible activities than have already come to light.
"Almost any time we go to a city and look at a small portion of their activities, we find lots of questionable activities going on around it that we did not previously know about," said Chris Greer, the assistant inspector general for audit who will testify at Wednesday's hearing.
The allegations of misused money in the program, Community Development Block Grants, come as local and state governments are reeling from the recession, cutting programs for the poor and demanding more Federal aid.
They also strike a sensitive chord at the housing department, where Secretary Jack F. Kemp has established a reputation for having cleaned up the many scandals he inherited from the Reagan Administration.
Mr. Lantos, who headed Congress's investigation into those matters, said the problems he has found in the block grant program do not rise to the level of national scandal. And unlike the Reagan-era scandals, no one is accusing top housing officials of criminal wrongdoing. But, he added: "As in the case of the original investigation, I think we are on to something."
The allegations also have a significance beyond this program itself, since conservatives, including some within the Bush Administration, have long called for making greater use of block grants as a tool of social policy.
Both sides agree that the majority of the development funds are not being abused, and that the program offers hundreds of success stories.
 
870 Cities and Counties
 Housing officials disburse about $2 billion a year to 870 cities and counties, based on a formula that includes their size, the extent of their poverty, and the condition of their housing. In addition, the officials give about $900 million to state governments. Cities and counties can spend the money themselves, or make loans or grants to corporations or nonprofit groups that use it for eligible activities. By law, communities are free to make the awards without first seeking Federal approval, and housing officials review their decisions later.
At least 70 percent of the money has to help people the Government defines as having low or moderate incomes, a figure that varies by region but on average reaches households with incomes as high as $30,000. The remainder can be used to eliminate slums or blight, or meet "other urgent community development needs."
In Troy, N.Y., the city drew on development funds to give a $1 million loan in 1990 to a group of local investors to buy the Capital District Islanders, a farm team for the National Hockey League. When Federal housing officials learned of the loan they said it was an ineligible use of the money and required the city to repay it. But city officials then used development funds to make a second loan, of $650,000, to help the team meet its operating costs, in what housing officials called "blatant disregard" of their warnings. The Department required the city to repay that loan, too.
City officials have said both loans meet Federal guidelines, arguing that the team would create jobs for the needy. While development money can be used to help corporations create jobs, Federal officials said the hockey team was unlikely to do so, citing a report by one of the city's own planners that said that "new job creation opportunities are likely to be minimal."
In 1990 Jacksonville, Fla., officials gave a $5 million interest-free loan in 1990 to Sears, Roebuck & Company to help the corporation build a new distribution center. Sears had told local officials it planned to move its center to Georgia, as a cost-savings measure, and city officials defended the loan by saying it would keep and create jobs and bring in new tax revenues.
But an audit by the inspector general's office said the city had failed to scrutinize the corporation's assertions. The city could not say how it had arrived at the figure of $5 million and had little evidence that the center would bring the jobs and tax revenues it promised.
The audit concluded, "the city had no defensible basis for making the loan," and called it part of a broader pattern, by which businesses "were often unduly enriched."The loan has been repaid.
From 1984 to 1989, Pennsylvania's Delaware County, which includes the suburbs west of Philadelphia, channeled more than $5 million in its development funds to a nonprofit group called the Partnership for Economic Development. Its chairman was Curt Weldon, who is the district's Republican Congressman.
Last year, the group's former executive director, William Tancredi, pleaded guilty to conspiring to defraud the Government of $327,000 by spending the money on a host of activities, including lavish banquets and no-bid contracts to political associates.
He has described the Partnership as Mr. Weldon's "private little campaign war chest," and is cooperating with prosecutors in an ongoing investigation.
Mr. Weldon has not been charged in the case and has denied any criminal wrongdoing.
 
Program Chief Faults Congress
 The program's head, Ms. Kondratas, said there would be fewer questionable expenditures if Congress agreed to past Administration proposals to target the program more directly on antipoverty efforts. But local officials have lobbied hard against any reduction in their autonomy and Congress has refused.
In lobbying for new restrictions several years ago, the Administration itself prepared a list of projects that are now legal but that it considers questionable.
These included $94,000 for an automatic park irrigation system in San Diego and more than $1 million for a facelift to a commercial strip in Chicago.
"Within the current rules, grantees can, and do, carry out activities that are relatively frivolous," said the proposal.
But Mr. Lantos said that housing officials "share responsibility for the failures," through "inadequate staffing, inadequate program guidelines, and a failure to enforce sanctions."
Ms. Kondratas acknowledged that current monitoring staff was now "stretched pretty thinly" and would grow more so next year as several new housing programs are being created without new staff members. One of her deputies has told community development officials that there would be "a rather dramatic drop" in the number of sites monitored through visits next year.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Representative Tom Lantos said the problems of a Federal program for needy communities are "significant and widespread." (Paul Conklin)

HEADLINE: New Japanese Envoy Seeks to Ease Tensions

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 17

 BODY:
The new Japanese Ambassador to the United States says that one of the fictions he wants to dispel when he takes up his duties later this month is that of Japan as a musclebound economic colossus challenging American leadership.
"I don't think most people in Japan feel we are a seven-foot-tall economic giant looking down on the United States," the diplomat, Takakazu Kuriyama, said in a recent interview. "I don't think we have an image of the United States becoming a second-rate economic power." 
 That the new Ambassador would have to say these things is a measure of the prevailing tensions between Tokyo and Washington, especially after various Japanese leaders and writers have commented that the United States is a nation in decline and that its workers are lazy and unproductive.
Like many ambassadors, the 60-year-old Mr. Kuriyama, a veteran diplomat who until recently held the highest ranking post in the foreign service, has studied in the United States and served before in diplomatic posts in New York and Washington. But he also brings an unusual perspective to the new post.
 
Father Warned Against Axis
 During the 1930's, his father was Japan's Ambassador to Belgium, and he warned against Tokyo's proposed alliance with Germany. After Japan joined the Axis, the elder Kuriyama left the foreign service and became a judge. Today his son is one of the staunch pro-American diplomats in the Japanese Foreign Ministry.
"I would rather be called 'pro-Japan-U.S.' because I have always believed that a close relationship between the two countries is in Japan's best interest," he said recently. "America is a country for which I have come to hold deep respect and admiration."
Angular and thin with a meticulous speaking style, Mr. Kuriyama is said by colleagues to have been given instructions to get out and about more than his predecessors and serve as a more effective spokesman for Japan.
Speaking meticulously and cautiously in flawless English, Mr. Kuriyama said he plans to convey the view that both Japan and the United States must resolve deep-seated social and economic flaws that have led to the economic imbalance between the two countries.
 
Both Sides Must Adjust
 The United States must learn to invest in science, education, research and industry restructuring, he said, while Japan must make its rules of the marketplace conform more to those of international trade, so that foreign products and even investments are more welcome. Japan, he said, has begun this process and deserves credit for doing so even though it must do more.
Mr. Kuriyama was one of the diplomats most associated with the unsuccessful effort last year to get Japan more involved in the Persian Gulf war, and the as yet unsuccessful attempt to get Japanese military forces to paticipate in United Nations peacekeeping operations.
Both efforts have run afoul of the anxieties of some Japanese over rearming or deviating from the pacifist position Tokyo has adopted since World War II, and Mr. Kuriyama was criticized for trying to push too fast on the matter from within the Government. Many said his ambassadorship to Washington, once a sure thing, was thrown into doubt for a time.
Now he travels to the United States acknowledging that Japan's responses on such crises haved "not been rapid enough." His colleagues hope that his willingness to admit defects in his own country may make his appeal to the United States to put its own house in order more palatable.

HEADLINE: Senate Panel Told of New Danger From Ex-Soviet Arms Technicians

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 17

 BODY:
United States officials said today that an effort to prevent a "brain drain" of top Russian weapon developers to third-world nations had focused little attention on thousands of technicians capable of putting an atomic weapon together.
The officials said it was these people -- chemical engineers, for example -- who possessed the skills to fashion a bomb using technology sold by American and German companies and plutonium from the thousands of warheads the Soviet Union will dismantle. 
 Robert Gallucci, a State Department official coordinating the effort to create an International Science and Technology Center to provide jobs for Russia's scientific elite, said the top priority had been on scientists capable of overseeing an entire nuclear weapons project.
Last week the United States and the European Community each committed $25 million for the center, which is intended to provide the Russian scientists with stable jobs for two years during the transition of their military-driven economy to a free market.
The center will be opened near Moscow by summer, Mr. Gallucci told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. But its focus will be on scientists, theorists, managers and other "knowledge" experts rather than on technicians who actually fabricate and assemble weapons, he said.
"The center does not address that last group," Mr. Gallucci testified in response to a question from Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, Democrat of Maryland. "I think we should have somebody look at it."
Mr. Gallucci and Dr. D. Allan Bromley, President Bush's science adviser, told the Senate panel there was no confirmed evidence that any Soviet scientist or engineer had gone to work for Iraq, Libya or other third world countries or that any Soviet missile or nuclear technology had been diverted to such nations.
Dr. Bromley said Russian officials "are as concerned as much as we are and they are making an historic effort" to insure that scientists do not defect under such circumstances.
Mr. Gallucci said more than 100 proposals to employ Russian weapon scientists and engineers in civilian research had reached his office in the last month. Dr. Bromley said those efforts faced several impediments, the biggest of which was that the Russians "do not understand the role of entrepreneurial development that occurs here."
