HEADLINE: SUDANESE TROOPS PUSH INTO SOUTH

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya, March 17

 BODY:
Fortified by far larger numbers of soldiers than before and new heavy weapons from Libya, Iran and China, the Sudanese Army is moving through the southern Sudan in its strongest effort yet to win the decade-long civil war there, according to diplomats and aid workers.
The army took Pochala, an important center in the eastern Sudan on the Ethiopian border, a week ago and on Friday bombed Kapoeta, the major town held by the rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army. 
 The intensified war effort has resulted in a cutback in international efforts to deliver food rations to about 200,000 southern Sudanese displaced from their homes by the fighting, United Nations officials here said today. United Nations food convoys from northern Kenya into the southern Sudan have been attacked by local militiamen, apparently armed by the Government.
The civil war in the Sudan is between the northern Arab and Islamic fundamentalist Government in Khartoum and a southern based African rebel group, the Sudan People's Liberation Army, whose members are mostly Christian or animist. The Government has stepped up its military effort at the same time as it is hardening its enforcement of Islamic law the north.
In the last several months, the United States has said the Government has allowed international terrorist groups to use the Sudan as a haven. Washington has also expressed concern that Iran, which recently forged military and economic pacts with the Khartoum Government, is using the Sudan to export its Islamic fundamentalism into other Muslim areas of Africa.
Supplementing the regular Sudanese Army on the current offensive is a contingent from the newly formed Popular Defense Forces, a paramilitary group organizing along the lines of the Iranian Revolutionary Guard, a Western diplomat said in Khartoum today. The diplomat said the paramilitary recruits had been rounded up in Khartoum several weeks ago and sent to the front in the name of holy war.
The Government forces number about 50,000 and are moving out from the three main Government-held centers of Malakal, Juba and Wau with tanks and artillery, diplomats said. But in its capture of Pochala, on the border with Ethiopia, the army apparently used mercenaries from the Anyuak tribe, who mostly live in Ethiopia, diplomats and aid workers said.
The rebels accused the new Ethiopian Government, which is on friendly terms with the Sudanese leadership, of giving the Sudanese Army free passage and of allowing Ethiopian troops to be used in the operation at Pochala. The Ethiopians denied the accusation.
 
Aid Workers Taken Out
 Western diplomats said they doubted that the Ethiopian Government had knowingly abetted the Sudanese military movements but said Ethiopia had little control over its borders in that area.
Five workers of the International Committee of the Red Cross stationed at Pochala to help more than 20,000 Sudanese refugees displaced by the civil war said that they were flown out of the town to Khartoum by Sudanese military aircraft after the town was taken. In Kapoeta, the United Nations has advised international agencies to scale back their activities because of fears of stepped up bombing.
The Government offensive coincides with an internal split within the rebel group led for the last decade by John Garang, a former member of the Sudanese Army. A breakaway group of rebels led by Riek Machar is said to have given the Sudanese soldiers safe passage as they move south from Malakal.
The rebels have also been weakened by the loss of their bases inside Ethiopia after the change in government there in May.

HEADLINE: Bangkok Journal;
It's Business as Usual in Thailand (Votes for Sale)

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, March 17

 BODY:
It is election time in Thailand, which means that many of the country's major political parties and politicians are out on the campaign trail not to win votes, but to buy them.
The leader of Chat Thai, one of the nation's largest political parties, insists that he does not buy votes. But he was spotted several days ago leaving 500 baht, or about $20, to pay for a 50-cent bowl of steaming noodles and bean curd at a noodle stand in southern Thailand. After leaving such a large tip, he may well have been hopeful of the startled vendor's vote. 
 The general election scheduled for this Sunday was supposed to be different. It will be the first election in Thailand since February 1991, when the Thai military staged a coup to oust what it described as -- and much of the public believed was -- a wildly corrupt civilian Government.
Nevertheless, Thailand's parliamentary candidates are buying votes and rigging polls as never before.
All that seems to have changed for many Thai politicians are the techniques of vote buying -- they are more inventive -- and the cost, which has become much more expensive.
 
'Politician by Accident'
 The newest bout of dirty politics comes even as Thailand's 57 million people have had their aspirations for good government raised.
While the junta, which calls itself the National Peacekeeping Council, holds absolute power in Thailand, and seems certain to remain in charge after the election, it can take credit for having appointed an interim Prime Minister, Anand Panyarachun, whose administration has been described as the most capable and honest in Thailand's recent history.
Mr. Anand, a former Ambassador to Washington, insists that he is a "politician by accident" and that he will leave government after the election, a decision that has added to the frenzy as political parties scramble to have a say in who replaces him.
"We have no magic wand to stop political corruption," said Gothom Arya, a human rights advocate who is a leader of Poll Watch, an organization that is planning to deploy 30,000 volunteers to monitor polling stations in hopes of what Mr. Gothom described as a "less corrupt election."
It will not be easy. Thailand's economic boom -- despite the global recession, its economy is growing by nearly 8 percent a year -- may have worsened political corruption by flooding the major political parties with cash.
There are reports of brazen vote buying all across Thailand, with candidates and their local representatives, known in Thai as kamnan, or canvassers, handing out everything from 500-baht notes to movie tickets to live ducks to lipsticks. Even small gifts are appreciated in a nation in which the per capita income, while rising quickly, is still only the equivalent of $1,500 a year.
In the northeastern province of Nakhon Ratchasima, one candidate is reported to have paid tailors to mend the clothes of local voters, while in central Chachoengsao province, a political party has offered voters free appointments with a dentist.
In what Mr. Gothom described as a particularly clever scheme, canvassers are taking bets on the election outcome.
In a typical case, a party canvasser goes into a village and takes a bet of 5 baht, or about 20 cents, from a villager, agreeing to pay out 500 baht if the party's candidate wins. The villager is then left with a strong financial incentive to support the party.
There is nothing to guarantee that Thai voters will vote for the candidate who gives them money or a handsome gift. But even Thai politicians who condemn the practice admit that vote buying has often worked.
It has lingered in Thailand -- especially in rural areas, which account for nearly three-quarters of the population -- for reasons that can go beyond money and involve the value placed here on the concepts of community and personal loyalty.
Political canvassers do indeed carry around suitcases stuffed with baht notes for payoffs. At the same time they tend to work in the same region for years and often serve as the only real connection many voters have to their government.
The most likely outcome to the election, Thai politicians say, is some sort of coalition government, possibly led by Gen. Suchinda Kraprayoon, Thailand's army chief and an architect of last year's coup.
Several candidates are trying to stop General Suchinda, most notably Chamlong Srimuang, a retired army major general and devout Buddhist who earned the title "Mr. Clean" during his seven years as Governor of Bangkok.
He stepped down from that post to seek election to Thailand's parliament on a platform calling for an end to political corruption. The Palang Dharma, or Power of Virtue, party, which he leads, has pledged not to buy votes.
While polls show that Mr. Chamlong is one of Thailand's most popular politicians, it is unclear whether his support extends outside Bangkok to rural voters, who are thought most susceptible to vote buying.
A Palang Dharma candidate in the central Thai province of Nonthaburi attended a religious ceremony last week in which he and his competitors were asked to swear they would not buy votes.
During the ceremony, the candidates sipped from a bowl of holy water gathered from temples around the nation and, with a Buddhist monk looking on as witness, demanded divine retribution if they violated their no vote-buying oath.
It was a punishment that most of their opponents were apparently unwilling to risk. Of the 34 provincial candidates invited to the ceremony, only 7 showed up.

HEADLINE: Conflicting Aims in Booming Health Care Lobby Help Stall Congress

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 17

 BODY:
Leading members of Congress say they are swamped with conflicting messages from a growing number of lobbyists and lawyers representing all facets of the health-care industry.
Moreover, no one expects those trends to be reversed in the next decade as the Government assumes a bigger role in financing health care. 
 "On the whole, health-care lobbyists have had the effect of retarding change and blocking it," said Jack A. Meyer, president of New Directions for Policy, a Washington research institute. "That's because most of the effort has come from smart, well-financed groups that have a vested interest in the status quo. They do a good job of pointing out the potential risks and costs of change, but there is little information about the broader public interest in the benefits of change."
The number of national health groups that have offices here or employ Washington representatives has grown to 741, from 502 in 1986 and 117 in 1979. The numbers are tabulated by the National Health Council, a Washington forum for health-care advocates.
 
$60 Million in Donations
 Many of the health-care groups try to influence legislation by contributing to lawmakers' re-election campaigns. Data compiled by Common Cause, the citizens' lobby, show that health and medical organizations have contributed $60 million to candidates for Congress in the last decade, including $19 million since January 1989.
Consumer groups, the elderly and labor unions also have lobbyists, but Gail E. Shearer, manager of policy analysis at Consumers Union, said: "The voice of the consumer is a very small and quiet one. On most health issues we are outnumbered and outgunned."
Democrats and Republicans have introduced dozens of bills to restrain soaring health costs and to assist the 35 million people who have no health insurance. Lawmakers agree that the current situation is unacceptable but say there is virtually no chance Congress will pass comprehensive legislation on the issue this year.
While lobbyists did not create the current impasse, their forceful advocacy has magnified differences among competing interests. Umbrella groups like the American Medical Association and the American Hospital Association are still important. But many specialty and subspecialty groups have set up shop here to gain more direct access to Administration officials and members of Congress.
 
Effectiveness Equals Spending
 The effectiveness of these groups contributes to the increase in national health spending, as each seeks more money for its members and their special concerns without advocating cutbacks elsewhere in the Federal budget. These groups often achieve their goals by focusing on complex technical issues, like payment for kidney dialysis, X-rays and anesthesia services.
"The larger the number of groups, the greater the paralysis," said Robert J. Blendon, professor of health policy at Harvard's School of Public Health. "The number of groups that have to agree on an issue is so large, it's almost impossible to reach consensus."
The Washington representatives include such diverse figures as Peter Barton Hutt, the nation's leading authority on food and drug law; Hope S. Foster, a lawyer and lobbyist for clinical laboratories since 1973; Deborah L. Steelman, an unpaid political adviser to President Bush, who has registered as a lobbyist for insurance and drug companies, and Kevin Walker, who dispenses more than $3 million dollars every two years from the political war chest of the American Medical Association.
The advocates also include William A. Bailey, a person with AIDS who lobbies on AIDS-related issues for the American Psychological Association; Paul R. Willging, chief lobbyist for the nation's nursing homes, and Michael D. Bromberg, the politically well-connected director of the Federation of American Health Systems, which represents 1,400 investor-owned hospitals.
Harvey A. Yampolsky, former chief counsel to the inspector general at the Department of Health and Human Services, explained the need for specialization this way: "You wouldn't go to a dermatologist if you needed heart surgery. These days a doctor shouldn't go to a general-practice attorney if he has technical Medicare questions."
While lobbyists may stymie major changes in the health-care system, they can also define areas of consensus. Business executives and labor union leaders have come together in coalitions -- inconceivable a few years ago -- to advocate changes, including a requirement for health insurance coverage of all workers.
 
A.M.A. Redefines Itself
 Afraid of being excluded from the debate, the American Medical Association has repositioned itself as an advocate of change, and the doctors' group often finds it has more in common with the A.F.L.-C.I.O. than with the Bush Administration.
Henry J. Aaron, director of economic studies at the Brookings Institution, said: "The leaders of the A.M.A. have gone from a rejectionist position into a true negotiating mode. They are very constructive participants, right in the mainstream of the current debate on health-care reform."
The lobbying process feeds on itself, as new coalitions form to counter the message of other lobbyists. One of the more influential groups, the National Leadership Coalition for Health Care Reform, includes labor unions and corporations like Chrysler and Bethlehem Steel. In November, it endorsed a plan, like one favored by Senate Democrats, under which employers would have to provide health insurance for workers or pay a tax to finance such coverage.
Another coalition is combating such proposals. The new group, the Health Care Equity Action League, includes scores of small businesses and drug, hospital and health insurance companies. The league, like the Bush Administration, wants to make it easier for small businesses to buy health insurance, but says new taxes and Government mandates would bankrupt many small businesses, destroying jobs.
 
Divided Industry
 Internal conflict can be found in almost every part of the vast health-care industry, which now employs 8.4 million people and accounts for nearly 14 percent of the nation's economic activity.
The Health Insurance Association of America, which represents 300 commercial insurers, opposes Federal regulation of premiums and underwriting practices. But within the organization, there is sometimes a split between small companies and big companies. Some of the big companies are willing to accept the idea of Federal regulation, as are many nonprofit Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans.
Members of Congress sponsoring legislation to regulate health insurance say they hope to exploit such divisions to overcome opposition to their bills.
The American Medical Association complained loudly about a Bush Administration plan to cut Medicare payments to doctors last year. But the American Academy of Family Physicians did not leave the fortunes of its members entirely to the medical association. It pursued its own lobbying campaign to make sure its members got the increases they had been promised by Congress.
The American Hospital Association has also experienced internal strains. Teaching hospitals, Roman Catholic hospitals, Protestant hospitals, public hospitals, rural hospitals, children's hospitals and psychiatric hospitals all have their own lobbying organizations.
 
Drug Makers Win One
 The Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association is more cohesive and therefore more effective than many trade groups. On March 11, it helped defeat a Senate proposal intended to hold down prices on prescription drugs.
The sponsor of the proposal, Senator David H. Pryor, Democrat of Arkansas, said the drug companies "have a tremendous impact politically and are very well organized in their lobbying."
Health groups enhance their influence by sponsoring political action committees. In its study of campaign contributions from the health-care industry, Common Cause said the biggest donor by far was the political arm of the American Medical Association, which gave $11.9 million to Congressional candidates from 1981 to 1991.
The next most generous donors were the political action committees for the National Association of Life Underwriters, who sell health insurance, the American Dental Association, the American Academy of Ophthalmology and the American Hospital Association, the report said.
In a separate study, the Center for Responsive Politics, a nonpartisan research group, said the health and insurance industries gave $19 million to Congressional candidates in the 1990 elections, as against $14 million of donations from agricultural interests and $8 million from military contractors.

HEADLINE: Tradition of Inequity;
States Are Urged to Show Less Favoritism To University Systems' Flagship Campuses

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d

 BODY:
A series of lawsuits and court decisions charging discrimination have put pressure on states to distribute more fairly the money they give to various campuses in state university systems.
The equitable financing issue, now being contested in four states, is steeped in both tradition and bias. In most states, legislatures for decades have given more money to one university than others in the same system, arguing that the state needs a showcase institution of higher education. But civil rights groups and individuals who have brought lawsuits in Mississippi, Texas, Alabama and, three weeks ago, in New York assert that these states' allocations for public university systems are rooted in racial and ethnic discrimination. 
 The newer campuses tend to have more students from minority groups, fewer professors with doctorate degrees and fewer or no graduate divisions or professional schools. Whether this is due to discrimination or to tradition is an issue that could land more states in court, say many education consultants and analysts.
"You can make an argument on both sides," said Caspa L. Harris, president of the National Association of College and University Business Managers.
 
Finding Racism in Budgets
 In December, a Federal judge ruled that Alabama's university system had vestiges of racial discrimination and that two historically black universities had been shortchanged by about $10 million each. The Legislature was ordered to revise its distribution of education money. Mississippi is awaiting a Supreme Court ruling in a similar case.
Last month in Texas, a judge ruled that the state's method of financing its two university systems was unconstitutional because universities in South Texas, which have a predominantly Hispanic enrollment, did not receive enough state aid and did not offer enough advanced degree programs. The universities in South Texas are 30 to 40 years old, with less history than the century-old University of Texas at Austin and Texas A&M University, the flagship universities in the two different state systems.
And three weeks ago a lawsuit was filed against New York State by more than 250 professors and students in the City University of New York system, where the majority of students are black or of Hispanic descent. The suit contends that state officials allocate more money for the State University of New York system, whose enrollment is mostly white, and that the disparity is discriminatory.
"What we have all begun to realize in the past 20 years in civil rights work is that the barriers that exist are no longer de jure sorts of barriers," said Susan E. Brown, a lawyer in San Francisco for the Mexican-American Legal Defense and Education Fund, which brought the equity suit in 1987 against the Texas Higher Education Coordinating Board, which supervises the state's 116 public institutions. "What exists now are more subtle mechanisms, and funding is one of the more pervasive in terms of lack of equality."
 
Less Money to Pacify
 In healthier fiscal eras, states sidestepped the equity issue and claims of discrimination by giving institutions with mostly minority enrollments more money every budget year. But this still did not lift them to parity, and now the recession has made it more difficult to mask a flawed system of state appropriations to public universities.
"Institutions got a little bit during the good times, but they still have not received the funding and the programs that would make them competitive and equal institutions," said Julius Chambers, director counsel of the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund in New York.
But to charge that discrimination is the only factor in the debate over equity is simplistic, others argue. Many state university systems have long focused their energy on one or two leading institutitions, building up law schools, medical schools and professional schools.
As public university systems have grown, campuses have been created near major industrial and economic centers, often dictated by employer needs. In the Texas suit, the Mexican-American legal group asserted that the six public universities near the Mexican border had been discriminated against in state appropriations. But that region of the state is largely rural, with little industry.
 
Re-Slicing a Smaller Pie
 "Education tends to follow the economy and not the other way around," said Dennis Jones, president of the National Center for Higher Education Management Systems, a private, not-for-profit management consulting group in Boulder, Colo. "You aren't going to find many engineering schools in places where there isn't a lot of industry. That's a function of 100 years of evolution."
That evolution is difficult to reverse. As a result, Mr. Jones said, it is unrealistic for public universities that are not the flagship university to expect to get the same financing and the same academic programs.
But because state education budgets are shrinking and opposition to the current distribution system is growing, education experts say, legislatures around the country may be forced to give the flagship campuses less and others more. That approach is not expected to be popular among the universities that have grown accustomed to advantages. "Reallocation," said Mr. Jones, "comes hard."

HEADLINE: U.S. Takes Lead Back In Exports

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: GENEVA, March 17

 BODY:
The United States overtook Germany last year as the leading exporter of goods, regaining a spot it last held in 1989, the world's main trade body said today.
Germany's figures were hurt by the weakening European economy and the rebuilding of eastern Germany. United States export growth, while slightly down from 1990, rose by five times the world average. 
 United States exports rose 7.5 percent to $422 billion, while exports of most West European countries stagnated or shrank, the survey said. Germany's foreign sales dropped 4.5 percent, to $403 billion, and slipped to second place. Japan, France and Britain followed.
 
Trade Growth Slows
 Growth in world trade volume slowed for the third consecutive year, to 3 percent in 1991, the head of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, Arthur Dunkel, said in an annual report to delegates. It was the smallest gain since 1983 and down from 5 percent in 1990.
But Mr. Dunkel also told the group's 103-nation council that "a modest economic recovery may now be under way," World trade growth could increase to 4 percent this year, he said.
A new world trade agreement could help revive economic growth by raising business confidence, Mr. Dunkel said. He urged delegates to finish the five-year-old talks known as the Uruguay Round, the organization's most comprehensive effort to lower barriers to commerce and rewrite trade rules.
 
Account Deficit Shrinks
 The GATT report came as America said that its record level of export sales helped to shrink its current account deficit last year to $8.62 billion, the nation's best performance in international trade in nearly a decade. That marked a sharp turnaround from a $92.12 billion deficit in 1990. In addition to higher exports sales, the improvement came from foreign payments to cover the costs of the Persian Gulf war and from lower import demand caused by the recession.
In value, world merchandise exports rose 1.5 percent, to $3.53 billion, last year, the smallest growth since 1985, GATT said. Foreign sales of services rose 5 percent, to $810 billion.
Germany's exports were cut by the sluggish economies of the country's European trade partners and the collapse of East European sales, GATT economists said. Reconstruction in eastern Germany consumed goods that otherwise would be exported.
United States export growth, while down slightly from 8 percent in 1990, was broad based and partly attributed to several years of slow wage increases and low inflation during the recession, the economists said.
United States sales increased significantly in Mexico, Southeast Asia, Germany and the Middle East, the economists said. Exports of motor vehicles, aircraft, chemicals and iron and steel rose more than average, they said.
Asia recorded the strongest trade growth last year and continued to gain market share. Hong Kong replaced the former Soviet Union as the 10th-biggest exporter. China passed South Korea and Switzerland to become No. 13.
 
Developing Countries Improve
 Spain, Singapore, Mexico and Malaysia also improved their export performance, the survey said.
Developing countries, especially Asia and Latin America, are opening markets and integrating their economies into the world economy, Mr. Dunkel said.
Exports by Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union fell an average 20 percent last year, and the region cut imports 25 percent, GATT estimated. The former Soviet Union alone reduced imports 42 percent.

HEADLINE: Blacks in Science Program Shatter Stereotype

BYLINE: By MICHEL MARRIOTT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CATONSVILLE, Md.

 BODY:
On a recent afternoon at the University of Maryland Baltimore County, virtually the only sounds in a classroom came from chalk skipping over a blackboard, scrawling a profusion of mathematical expressions, symbols and formulas.
Many of the 13 students in the class peered up from their notes with preoccupied looks. But for Lance Hester and Gary Young, electrical engineering majors in a special black scholarship program, the blackboard jumble seemed rather standard fare. 
 "It was pretty much a review; she was just going over the basics," said Mr. Young, a 20-year-old junior, referring to the teacher. "So far it is not too bad."
He and Mr. Hester, 21, are the only blacks in the class. It is their habit to sit in the front so that, in Mr. Young's words, "the teacher will recognize us."
 
Exploding Stereotypes
 In the last three years, many of this university's professors, administrators and students have come to recognize the tightly knit group of 70 academically talented black students known as Meyerhoff Scholars. Almost from their first days in 1989 on this predominantly white campus of 10,000 students, these scholars began exploding racial stereotypes about blacks' ability to excel in the study of science and technology.
"We've had three years of experience and many of the presuppositions are gone," Michael K. Hooker, the university's president, said of the program. "Now, very often the best student in a science or math or engineering class is going to be a black student. That has brought about a whole cultural change among their fellow white students and among the faculty."
The Meyerhoff program was created in 1988 by Robert Meyerhoff, a white Baltimore philanthropist. His aim was to help a score of academically exceptional black male students who were committed to studying science by giving them extensive financial assistance and academic guidance. Mr. Meyerhoff said he started the program because he had been disturbed by the plight of so many young black American men. In its first year the program was solely financed by a $522,000 grant from the Robert and Jane Meyerhoff Foundation.
After the first year the program expanded to include black female students. It also began drawing national attention and financial contributions from the National Science Foundation, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, American Telephone & Telegraph and Apple Computer.
 
Paid Internships
 All Meyerhoff Scholars are given full, four-year academic scholarships. They also get books, personal computers and software, adult mentors, paid summer internships and field trips.
The students are encouraged to be assertive in seeking advice or tutoring, studying in groups and getting to know the university faculty and staff, program officials said.
Of 71 students who have begun the program, only one has dropped out, changing to a non-science major. The students have a cumulative grade point average of 3.4 out of a possible 4.0, university officials said.
Dr. Hooker said that the program is an important part of the university's life and that senior faculty members and department heads are actively involved.
For example, Catherine Fenselau, chairwoman of the chemistry department, helped arrange a summer internship in England for a Meyerhoff Scholar. That enabled the student, Maceo Thomas, a 20-year-old biochemistry major, to do research work with histamines in a hospital laboratory at the University of London, and that led to his being the co-author of a scientific paper developed during his internship.
"It has been extremely gratifying," said Mr. Meyerhoff, a 68-year-old businessman and engineering graduate of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who, with his wife Jane, has given the program more than $1 million. "I always felt that black students had more disadvantages in the sense of not having the economic advantages that a typical white college student had."
As the program evolved, however, it became apparent to those who ran it that the disadvantages that even the most promising black students face at predominantly white colleges and universities had less to do with economic conditions than with a sense among blacks that there was no place at the universities for them. Today, Meyerhoff Scholars repeatedly talk enthusiastically about how the program helps connects them to the institution.
"We feel a sense that we can do well here," said one student.
Most of the students are from Maryland, but they represent a broad socio-economic cross section. Some are the children of professionals while others come from single-parent households in which mothers struggled to feed and clothe their children.
Among the students are honor society presidents, valedictorians and straight-A students, some of whom are equally comfortable with a football or a microscope or a microphone. Self-possessed and accomplished, they are the brightest of the bright, among the top two percent of black students in the United States.
"What they have in common is that they are very high-achieving students," said Dr. Freeman A. Hrabowski, a black mathematician who is the university's executive vice president and who helped Mr. Meyerhoff launch the program. "What we see, as we do research on the students, is that the family support has been extraordinarily strong."
 
Support at Home
 Aliceson Y. King's mother, Carolyn King, became so interested in continuing to help her 19-year-old daughter that she founded a Meyerhoff parents support group a year ago. Now Carolyn King, a former teacher, is also working toward a doctorate in computer science. She is on the campus almost as often as her daughter, a pre-med and business major with a 3.6 grade point average.
All the Meyerhoff Scholars talk of similar examples of love and support from at least one parent, and some tell of a certain teacher who harbored high expectations for them.
Yet for all their ability and promise, the Meyerhoff Scholars need special attention, explained Dr. Hrabowski. It is not uncommon for science and mathematics majors, whether they belong to minorities or not, to change their minds about wanting to pursue such difficult and demanding subjects. Without guidance and support, many of them, despite their outstanding academic backgrounds, are likely to become discouraged and change majors.
Such guidance, said Dr. Hrabowski, is critically important for black students, who are often more isolated than white students and do not have black role models, mentors or fellow students who have traveled the course before them.
 
Battle of Expectations
 "Sometimes I think too much is expected of me," said Oletha Minto, an infectiously upbeat sophomore. This semester, for example, she was disappointed with herself because she received a 'B' in geography -- the first grade lower than an 'A' she had been given in a class in the last three years.
"I called Dr. Hrabowski and talked to him about it," she said. "I'm surprised he has any ears left."
His advice to her was basically to do her best and, if she was convinced that she was doing that, not to worry.
But Miss Minto also recently earned the highest-score in her organic chemistry class, becoming the first black student to receive an A in organic chemistry since the university was founded in 1966.
Interest in black students pursuing science degrees comes amid rising concern that the nation's leadership in science and technology is slipping at a time when racial and ethnic minorities are projected to become an increasing part of the nation's work force.
 
Looking to the Future
 Today there is a dearth of minority scientists and mathematicians. The National Science Foundation, which supports the Meyerhoff program with an annual grant of $200,000, discovered in 1989 that of the 861 doctoral degrees awarded in mathematics, 11 went to blacks.
For Meyerhoff Scholars, the road to the program begins with an extensive search for the most qualified applicants. Typically, Meyerhoff Scholars had grade averages of B-plus or higher in high school and combined S.A.T. scores in math and language skills in the mid-1200's; the highest possible combined score on the test is 1600. One Meyerhoff Scholar scored a 780 out of a possible 800 on the math portion.
Many Meyerhoff students said they had turned down full scholarships to more prestigious institutions, like the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Stanford University and the University of Pennsylvania, to be part of the program.
Charles Hines 3d, a lanky 20-year-old who is combining majors in biology with psychology, said becoming a Meyerhoff Scholar is "probably one of the best decisions I've made."
Voicing a common complaint among these students, Mr. Hines said that in high school he had often encountered hostility from other black students who did not share his enthusiasm about learning. "Here, I have found cooperation," he said.
Miss Minto, who was raised with seven brothers and sisters in Silver Spring, Md., said nothing in her life prepared her for her first days in the program. But it was not that she found the work difficult. She was simply overwhelmed, she said, by images she had never seen.
"I'd never seen so many smart black people in one place at one time in my life," she said, with a knowing grin. "The brain power. I was just in awe."

HEADLINE: Two Giant Banks Plan To Merge

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, March 17

 BODY:
Midland Bank P.L.C., Britain's third-largest bank, and the parent of the giant Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation announced today that they had agreed to merge.
The merger would create a bank that would rank about 10th in the world, with assets of more than $270 billion and capital, or shareholders' funds, of about $12 billion. 
 In a statement, the companies said their boards had agreed for Hongkong and Shanghai's parent, HSBC Holdings P.L.C., to buy Midland for "a significant premium" above its market price before the deal was announced. On Monday, Midland's shares were valued at a total of 1.98 billion, or about $3.43 billion, on the London Stock Exchange.
No other specific details were disclosed.
 
First Step Toward a Merger
 The Hong Kong bank bought a 14.7 percent stake in Midland in 1987, in a move seen as the first step toward a merger. The two seem like a good geographical match, with Midland's significant presence in Europe and HSBC's strong position in East Asia and foothold in North America, where it owns Marine Midland Bank in the United States and Hong Kong Bank of Canada. In addition, the two have also developed close management and operational ties since 1987.
But analysts suspect that the prime impetus for the merger is the approach of 1997, when Hong Kong, now a British colony, will be handed over to China.
William Purves, HSBC's chairman, said in an interview in the British magazine The Banker in December: "There's no evidence of us turning our back on Hong Kong. It's a very important market for us and we're continuing to expand our business here."
Still, while China's Communist Government has promised to keep Hong Kong's capitalist system largely intact, many corporations are nervous. And analysts say HSBC seems eager to reduce its dependence on its home market.
HSBC incorporated itself in Britain in April. And while its headquarters remain in Hong Kong, several analysts speculated today that if the merger went through, headquarters might be moved to Britain. It would be Britain's largest bank.
Analysts predicted that the takeover price for Midland would be 3.50 to 4 a share, or a total of $4.75 billion to $5.43 billion. In London, Midland's stock price soared 30 percent today, to 3.29.
The price for the Midland shares HSBC does not already own would be $4.05 billion to $4.63 billion if analyst estimates prove accurate.
Some analysts note that the merger would produce a global giant that might be able to exploit the decision by large Japanese and American banks to reduce their international lending because of financial problems at home or the need to increase their capital to meet international standards.
"There is an opportunity to take a greater share of the international lending markets and enjoy greater profit margins on that business," said Simon Adamson, a banking analyst at IBCA Ltd., a credit-rating agency.
 
Questioning a Strategy
 But Christopher Wheeler, an analyst at Lehman Brothers International Ltd., questioned the strategy of trying to create a global bank, given how many other banks have tried and failed.
"International strategies have been pretty well discredited," he said. Noting that HSBC already has plenty of problems with its existing foreign operations, he asked, "Will such a company be more efficient or are we going to see another part of its enormous geographic empire with difficulties every time we turn around?"
HSBC, which has assets of $160.5 billion and capital of $7.23 billion excluding undisclosed reserves, earned $728 million in 1991 after taxes and minority interests. On a comparable basis, Midland, which has assets of $111 billion and capital of $4.39 billion, lost 39 million, or about $72.8 million.
Analysts say the desire of HSBC to reduce its dependence on Hong Kong helps to explain its purchase in the 1980's of Marine Midland, which has had no connection with the Midland Bank of Britain, and James Capel & Company, the London-based brokerage house.
 
Problems at Midland
 "But the bulk of their earnings are still from their domestic operations," said William Vincent, an analyst at Nomura Research Institute Europe Ltd.
Midland is widely seen as the one that most needs the merger. In the last decade, it has been badly weakened by its disastrous acquisition of the Crocker National Bank of California, loans to less-developed countries, high costs, a bad guess on the direction of interest rates in Britain and a growing pile of bad debts. Crocker has since been sold to Wells Fargo & Company of San Francisco.
With Midland seeming to make slow progress in tackling its problems and with HSBC mired in its own difficulties, the two called off previous merger plans in December 1990.
In March 1991, Midland reported that it lost $349.2 million in 1990 and announced it was cutting its dividend in half, the first such action taken by a leading British bank since the 1930's. It also announced that it would replace its chairman and chief executive, Sir Christopher McMahon, the following June.
 
Bank's New Leaders
 Sir Christopher was succeeded by two men. The new chairman is Sir Peter Walters, the retired chairman of British Petroleum P.L.C., who had been deputy chairman of National Westminister Bank P.L.C. until he joined Midland. The new chief executive is Brian Pearse, the former finance director of Barclays Bank P.L.C., Britain's largest bank.
But Midland surprised analysts on Feb. 27, when it announced that pretax profits in 1991 had more than tripled to 36 million, or about $67 million, and that it was maintaining its dividend. Its performance improved as a result of its success in holding down costs, a drop in the second-half charge for bad and doubtful loans and growth in interest and fee income.
At the time, Mr. Pearse said he suspected that competitors were considering making a bid for Midland.
But since Midland reported its earnings, its stock price has climbed. Analysts speculated today that HSBC might have decided to make its move now out of concern that the Midland's stock price would continue to increase, raising the cost of a merger.
 
Another Possible Suitor
 There has also been speculation that another big British bank, Lloyds Bank P.L.C., is interested in merging with Midland. Analysts said Lloyds might want to try to lower its costs by merging with a competitor to achieve greater economies of scale in its domestic market, as big banks in the United States have been trying to do.
For its part, HSBC has had its own problems. Its expansion has been anything but smooth. Marine Midland, James Capel and an Australian subsidiary have been plagued with losses and HSBC has made big changes in their managements and operations.
These efforts appear to be working, which may be another reason for reviving the Midland merger. Marine Midland, based in Buffalo, and the Australian operation sharply reduced their losses last year and Capel moved into the black.

HEADLINE: Housing and Output on the Rise, Spurring Talk of Recession's End

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 17

 BODY:
Government reports on industrial and housing activity today provided what many analysts regard as conclusive proof of economic recovery.
"The long recession is over," asserted Lawrence A. Hunter, chief economist for the United States Chamber of Commerce. "The jump in February housing starts and industrial production -- in addition to markedly improved business confidence and retail sales -- signal a clear turning point for the economy." 
 Builders broke ground on new homes at an annual rate of 1,304,000 during the month, the Commerce Department reported. The pace was 9.6 percent above that of January, which itself was substantially stronger than first estimated. The broadly based gain also raised the pace of housing starts to the fastest in nearly two years.
And at the nation's factories, mines and utilities, output was up six-tenths of 1 percent in February after falling in each of the three preceding months, the Federal Reserve reported. A rebound in production of motor vehicles and parts accounted for about half the gain.
In yet another report, Labor Department figures showed that inflation at the consumer level rose three-tenths of 1 percent during the month as jumps in the prices of food and clothing were partly offset by falling prices for energy. [Page D21.]
Although the economy has still not demonstrated more strength than it did during the short-lived recovery of 1991, analysts cite various factors in contending that this rebound is likely to be a sustained one, albeit one with probably less than the usual vigor.
"What you have got going for you this time is substantially lower interest rates, so housing affordability, for example, is substantially greater," said William C. Melton, chief economist for I.D.S. Financial Services in Minneapolis. "You also have a much better inventory situation, which means sales are translated more quickly into new production than 9 or 12 months ago."
Taken as a whole, today's batch of statistics was the most convincing evidence so far that a recovery has now firmly taken hold.
Housing, for example, "is fueling a sharp rebound in housing-related retail sales," observed Edward Yardeni and Deborah Johnson, economists at C. J. Lawrence. Last week the Government reported January and February data showing the best back-to-back retailing advances in more than six years, with furniture and household equipment averaging increases in sales of nearly 2 percent.
The White House, however, mindful of how the rebound in late spring and early summer 1991 suddenly dissipated, greeted today's figures with caution.
"It's very good news," said Michael J. Boskin, the President's top adviser on economics. "But while the economy clearly has improved for the last couple of months and the data are consistent with the early stages of a recovery, we should wait for broader signs of recovery for a longer period of time before jumping to any conclusions."
Mr. Boskin's tentative view was seen by various private analysts as protecting the President against possible charges of over-optimism during the election campaign should the economy relapse. They also said that an acknowledgment of a solid recovery would reduce pressure on the Federal Reserve to provide some monetary-policy "insurance" of a rebound.
Leading Congressional Democrats, quick to point out negatives in the economic picture in recent weeks, volunteered no comments today. An aide to Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Senate majority leader, said his office had no statement.
 
Housing Starts
 It was the housing results, which were even better than expected, that seemed to impress economists most. Starts climbed 9.6 percent in February after a January increase that was revised upward, to 6.4 percent. Single-family homes accounted for the entire February gain.
Moreover, all regions of the country posted solid increases, in constrast to January, when the Midwest boomed while the Northeast, South and West all had modest declines.
Once again, the Northeast did the worst of the four, suggesting a slower recovery there than in other regions, but its construction pace did pick up to a rate of 155,000 in February from 144,000 in January.
For the Midwest, the annual pace spurted to 360,000 from 315,000, while the South advanced to 504,000 from 472,000 and the West rose to 285,000 from 259,000.
Over all, single-family starts jumped 14.7 percent, to 1,146,000 from 999,000. Apartments and other multifamily dwellings declined moderately, continuing in the doldrums as the oversupply of existing units is worked off.
Builders have now stepped up groundbreaking in 10 of the latest 12 months, with February's pace, at 1,304,000, representing a 29.4 percent gain over February 1991.
"The housing recovery looks very, very strong, and it looks solid," said Norman Robertson of Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh.
This, combined with the industrial production data, prompted him to raise his estimate of gross domestic product for the politically sensitive second quarter to a rate of 3 percent or more, from the range of 2 to 2.5 percent Mellon had been estimating.
The housing report also showed that permits issued for new homes, a predictive indicator, climbed 4.2 percent in February, to a rate of 1,160,000. This followed a 5.3 percent increase in January, with the latest pace 32.4 percent ahead of February 1991.
Shipments of mobile homes, the department reported, climbed 9.1 percent in January to a rate of 192,000. These figures lag behind starts and permits by a month.
 
Industrial Output
 The advance of six-tenths of 1 percent in industrial output, one of the chief contemporaneous indicators even though it covers only about one-third of the economy, was largely as expected in light of the Government's employment report early this month showing increases in the number of people with jobs and the hours they worked.
The report confirmed the impression of a sustainable recovery, with increased activity in most categories. Factory output rose seven-tenths of 1 percent, with durable goods up 1 percent and nondurables up three-tenths of 1 percent.
Mining, rebounding from a sharp January decline, rose three-tenths of 1 percent last month, while utility output fell for the third straight month, affected by a continuation of relatively mild winter weather.
The nation's industries operated at 78.2 percent of capacity in February, up from 77.9 percent, the first increase since a tiny one in September.
 
Autos Show Strength
 Motor-vehicle assemblies rebounded to a 9.1 million annual pace after tumbling to 8.2 million in January, the report stated. Consumer goods excluding automotive products climbed 1.3 percent, mainly because of a substantial rise in output of appliances; nonetheless, this category remained below the level of late summer. Nondurable consumer goods edged up as increases for food and chemicals were nearly offset by declines for clothing, paper products and energy.
Business equipment rose three-tenths of 1 percent, not counting vehicles, while construction supplies rose slightly, the Federal Reserve reported.
January's decline in overall production was revised to a drop of eight-tenths of 1 percent, instead of nine-tenths, but December's output fell six-tenths of 1 percent rather than the four-tenths originally reported.

The Economy
Conclusive proof of economic recovery -- that is what analysts see in Government reports on industrial and housing activity. Housing starts rose 9.6 percent from January. And output at factories, mines and utilities climbed 0.6 percent. [Page A1.]

HEADLINE: Le Pen Is Everybody's Problem

BYLINE: By Flora Lewis; Flora Lewis is Senior Columnist of The New York Times. Anna Quindlen is on vacation.

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
The extreme nationalist right is rising in France to the point where it has become the central issue of national politics. Regional elections on Sunday will produce a map and a measure of the fever, expected to run as high as 30 percent of the vote in some areas.
French commentators have compared the phenomenon to Patrick Buchanan's surprising showing in the U.S. Republican primaries. The campaign slogan of Jean-Marie Le Pen's National Front party this year is "the French first." 
 But Mr. Le Pen is going for power, not just sending a message. He has already had some influence; some mainstream politicians have tilted toward his xenophobic line in hopes of winning some of his supporters.
Former President Valery Giscard d'Estaing came out for changing the basis of French citizenship to blood lines rather than place of birth. This would deny citizenship to children of Arabs and Africans settled in France.
The former Prime Minister, Jacques Chirac, expressed sympathy for French workers in low-cost housing living next to a migrant family "with father, three or four wives, about 20 kids, earning $10,000 a month without working." "If you add to that the noise and the smell, the French worker goes crazy," he said.
Although the governing Socialist Party denounces the National Front as proto-fascist, and some Socialist mayors have refused to rent city-owned halls for its meetings, Prime Minister Edith Cresson suggested organizing charter flights to send illegal immigrants back home.
There has been violence in clashes between pro- and anti-Front demonstrators, although nothing as brutal as some incidents provoked by skinheads in Germany. But the German extreme right is marginal, dramatized by world media that are ultra-sensitive to any display of German racism. The French movement has much more political weight, and it is tinged with anti-Semitism as well as anti-alienism.
It is also to some extent anti-European, drawing on fears of losing French identity and independence to the European Community. Foreigners crowding out Frenchmen are blamed for chronic unemployment, although immigrants mostly do dirty, unskilled jobs the French don't want.
Mainstream politicians blame one another for the rise of Mr. Le Pen, a florid, bouncy man with a nasty edge to his voice. Socialists point out that the center-right gives him respectability when candidates make electoral deals to squeeze out the left.
Conservatives stress that the proportional election system introduced by the Socialist Government for the 1986 parliamentary elections enabled the Front to become a highly visible national force with 33 deputies. The Socialists adopted the system, which gives parties representation based on their percentage of votes, in hopes that it would assure them of a majority. But the rightist parties won anyway. Now, President Francois Mitterrand is talking about returning to a proportional system for 1993 legislative elections, when the Socialists are expected to lose a large number of seats. Voter participation has dropped substantially, reflecting a distaste for traditional politics that only serves to enhance Mr. Le Pen's importance.
Conventional analysis attributing his rise to recession, immigration and frustration doesn't seem to account for the trend. It has to do with something deeper about perceptions of government and politicians, and France is not alone in that. It is dangerous and tempting to demagogues. France's chief rabbi has called it a threat to the nation, and Archbishop Albert Decourtray of Lyons had warned against "an adventure that could lead to the rise of some new Hitler."
Democracy's triumph is never final. Its quibbles and power plays open the door to anti-democrats in the name of nationalism. This must concern free people everywhere. It's not just a domestic issue anywhere.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
New Top Management For Hambrecht & Quist

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER

 BODY:
In a management realignment yesterday, Hambrecht & Quist, the San Francisco investment banking firm, named Daniel Case, its executive vice president in charge of investment banking, to be president and co-chief executive. William R. Hambrecht, who had been president, will become chairman and continue as co-chief executive.
Hambrecht & Quist, which was founded in 1968 by Mr. Hambrecht and George Quist, who is deceased, was the first investment banking firm to specialize in emerging growth companies. 
 The firm came to prominence in the early 1980's when it managed the initial public offerings of Apple Computer, Genentech and Peoples Express, only to stumble later in the decade before regaining its strength.
Hambrecht & Quist has raised $800 million in six initial offerings and four follow-on financings in 1992. Eight additional companies are currently in registration, and Hambrecht & Quist is the lead underwriter for five.
Mr. Case, who is 34, and Mr. Hambrecht, who is 56, together succeed Gordon S. Macklin, 63, currently chairman and co-chief executive. Mr. Macklin, who will leave the company on April 30, joined the firm in 1987 in a five-year arrangement. He will return to Washington, where his family lives.
William R. Timken, executive vice president-syndicate, was elected vice chairman, a new position.
Although Hambrecht & Quist is primarily known for its work in venture capital and initial public offerings, Mr. Case said that the firm was now focused on providing better service in what is known as the aftermarket, where research, private financing and merger and acquisition advice is provided to companies after they go public.
"We want to broaden the products and services offered, to make our clients want to stay with us as they grow," Mr. Case said.
One measure of the firm's success in this area is that "of all the companies we've taken public since June 1988, every one that's done a second deal has come back to us," Mr. Case said.
Mr. Case, who has spent his entire professional career at Hambrecht & Quist, began work with the firm as a summer intern in 1979 and returned full time in 1981. Like Mr. Hambrecht, he is a graduate of Princeton University, where he received a B.S. degree in economics and public policy and was named to Phi Beta Kappa. He was subsequently a Rhodes Scholar, specializing in economics and management studies.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Exxon Is Facing A Tougher Year

BYLINE: By Thomas C. Hayes

DATELINE: DALLAS

 BODY:
Last year was the most profitable ever for the Exxon Corporation, mostly because of stunningly high earnings from its European and Far Eastern refining operations when prices for jet fuel and kerosene rose sharply during the Persian Gulf war.
But 1992 is shaping up as much tougher for Exxon and the other oil giants. Analysts expect first-quarter earnings to drop by 50 percent for Exxon and even more for most other global oil companies. 
 Prices of crude are moderately lower than in the first quarter a year ago and domestic natural gas prices have collapsed to the lowest winter level in more than a decade. Recession in the United States has crimped profits from gasoline and other refined products, and for chemicals.
Meanwhile, weakening economies overseas could make things worse for Exxon, which derived three-fourths of its $5.6 billion in earnings last year outside the United States. Europe, led by Germany, appears on the verge of recession. Even the fast-growth economies of the Far East, from Hong Kong to Japan, have slowed.
"I'm writing this year off," said George F. Friesen, senior oil analyst at the Deutsche Bank Capital Group. "I don't see the fundamentals improving for the industry until 1993."
Through yesterday, Exxon's share price this year had dropped 7 percent. That is better than oil stocks generally, which are down 9 percent since Jan. 1. But it is worse than the broader index of the Standard & Poor's industrials, which are down 1 percent for the year to date. In yesterday's New York Stock Exchange trading, Exxon shares were unchanged at $56.875.
Analysts fret that oil stocks, with the exception of Exxon, are now into their fifth consecutive quarter of underperforming the broader market -- an unusually long losing streak for the once-mighty sector. Mr. Friesen thinks the slump will extend at least into the summer.
Last year, share prices of the 15 largest oil companies declined 2 percent as a group, compared with a 27 percent gain in the Standard & Poor's industrial index. But shares of Exxon, the world's largest oil company, bucked the downward trend among oil stocks, with a price gain of 17 percent in 1991.
If economic recovery brings higher demand for gasoline, chemicals and other petroleum products in the United States this summer, oil companies whose businesses are more dependent on the domestic market, like ARCO, Unocal and Amoco, will benefit more than global behemoths like Exxon.
"The place to be in 1992 is in U.S. refining, rather than in Europe or the Far East," said Bryan Jacoboski, an analyst at Paine Webber Inc. Chevron, ARCO and Unocal, which lost money in gasoline pricing battles on the West Coast early last year, he said, are now benefiting from lower refinery output there and firmer prices.
Yet William H. Brown 3d, an oil-market analyst and vice president of E. T. Petroleum Inc., in New York, said oil companies "are desperately looking" for, but have not seen, signs of rising gasoline demand throughout the United States.
Despite Exxon's strong 1991 performance, slumping demand overseas for refined products threatens to turn Exxon's shares into an industry laggard for awhile, said Michael Mayer, an oil analyst with Wertheim Schroder & Company.
Mr. Mayer estimated that Exxon's 1992 earnings, excluding special items, would fall by 13 percent, to $3.65 a share, from $4.20 in 1991. (Net income including special nonrecurring transactions was $4.45 last year.) The Wall Street consensus currently is for Exxon's earnings to fall to $3.90 a share.
"Earnings will be down this year for virtually everybody" in the major oil group, Mr. Mayer said. "But if you look further out, you can see some nice increases in 1993."
Mr. Mayer said he expected Exxon to earn $4.10 a share next year. He bases that forecast on several projections: a rise in crude prices to an average of $21 a barrel, from near $19 now; an increase in natural gas prices to perhaps $1.50 for 1,000 cubic feet, compared with the current $1.20, and rising demand for chemicals and gasoline.
He also expects Exxon to approve a modest dividend increase later this year, to an annual rate of $2.80, from $2.68. That would keep its dividend yield near 5 percent if, as he predicts, the stock rises to about $60 a share by the end of the year.
"The yield is a good reason for owning energy stocks now," he said.
As with most major oil companies, the biggest jolt to Exxon's earnings is likely to be the first quarter. Mr. Mayer said the company's profits in foreign refining and marketing will plunge by more than $700 million, to about $250 million, from $937 million in the first three months of 1991 -- the company's best quarter ever.
Earnings for the first quarter should fall by about $1 billion, Mr. Mayer said, to 85 cents a share, compared with $1.78 a share a year ago. Mr. Jacoboski agreed with that earnings forecast, although he predicted that the decline would mean Exxon would be unable to raise dividends this year.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls Despite Signs The Recovery Is Continuing

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell against most major currencies yesterday despite new statistics indicating that the economy continues to recover.
The dollar fell after the Government released figures that showed housing starts were up 9.6 percent in February and industrial production rebounded six-tenths of 1 percent after three months of declines. The Government also said consumer prices rose a moderate three-tenths of 1 percent. 
 Economists said the figures indicated the recession was fading.
But the dollar, which has rallied since January on improving economic numbers, lost ground despite the positive data. Analysts say traders now want to see extraordinary numbers before they will move the dollar higher.
Analysts said profit taking was responsible for some of yesterday's losses.
The dollar ended the day in New York at 132.80 Japanese yen, down from 133.90 Monday. In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.98 yen, to 133.32 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at 133.45.
Japan is expected to cut its interest rates to help speed its economic recovery. That could bring a turnaround in the yen, which has been depressed by the stagnant Japanese economy.
The dollar also fell to 1.6460 German marks in New York, from 1.6620 on Monday. In European trading, the dollar fell to 1.6525 marks from 1.6650.
The British pound gained against the dollar, rising to $1.7350 in New York, from $1.7220 Monday. In London, sterling rose to $1.7315 from $1.7170.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's quotes, included: 1.4900 Swiss francs, down from 1.5070; 5.5985 French francs, down from 5.6425; 1,237.00 Italian lire, down from 1,249.75, and 1.19315 Canadian dollars, down from 1.19875.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Monday, were: 1.4960 Swiss francs, down from 1.5085; 5.6105 French francs, down from 5.6560; 1,242.25 Italian lire, down from 1,252.00, and 1.1971 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1988.

HEADLINE: When U.S. Helped Poor College Students

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Proposing that President Bush should increase Government programs to help needy students attend private colleges, Samuel Hynes (Op-Ed, Feb. 29) cites the G.I. Bill, which provided one month's college tuition for each month a World War II veteran served on active duty. He could have mentioned National Youth Administration assistance for poor college students, predating the war.
Through that agency, the Federal Government provided money to colleges, which hired needy students to perform needed chores on campus. The work ran the gamut from cleaning urinals to washing test tubes and setting up lab experiments. 
 The pay may have varied, but in 1939 manual labor earned 35 cents an hour. That was not as paltry as it seems, because tuition at some of the finest schools ranged from $300 to $400 a year (Stanford's tuition after the war was $500 a year), a dormitory room cost $12 a month, and cafeteria bills seldom exceeded $10 a week. Through National Youth Administration income and summer employment indigent students managed.
Not only college students were assisted by the agency's programs. In the summer of 1941, when the Government foresaw the need for welders, machinists and other crafts for expanding military production, unemployed inner-city youths from Massachusetts were recruited, fed, housed in college dormitories and received daylong training for three months in the crafts shops of the local high schools in Springfield. That was a successful and worthwhile program.
 
ANDY SYKA
Sunnyvale, Calif., March 4, 1992

HEADLINE: Bank Yields Show Mixed Trend for Week

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
Yields on bank money market accounts and certificates of deposit went in mixed directions again last week, according to The Bank Rate Monitor, which tracks bank rates
Robert K. Heady, publisher of The Monitor, said yesterday, "This is the fifth consecutive week that short-term certificate of deposit yields have remained flat, while yields on longer-term accounts such as the two-and-a-half-year and the five-year C.D.'s continue to rise slightly." 
 "Normally you would see a rebound," he continued, "in all rates after the fifth week following the end of a down cycle, but that is not happening this time. And the longer it takes for an upward movement to begin, the more likely we will see slow economic recovery."
Among commercial banks in the New York area the average yield on money market accounts dropped 5 basis points, to 3.42 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of 1 percent.
Among savings institutions, money market accounts averaged 3.95 percent, off 4 points from a week ago.
Marine Midland reduced the yield on its money market account by 31 points -- the biggest decline among the area banks. In the opposite direction, the yield on six-month certificates went up 22 points at the New York branch of the Bank of Tokyo Trust. In three-month certificates, Astoria Federal Savings led the way down, with a cut of 21 points.
The Bank Rate Monitor said the average yields at 20 large banks outside the New York area held steady at the previous week's 3.58 percent, while their six-month certificates averaged 3.89 percent, up 3 points from last week.
At the Treasury's weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, the average rate was 4.09 percent and 4.27 percent, respectively.

HEADLINE: Consumer Price Index Rises 0.3%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 17

 BODY:
Consumer prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent in February, the Government reported today, and analysts said inflation should remain low the rest of the year despite signs of more economic activity.
"Typically, what we see in the early stages of a recovery is a window of six to nine months that inflation stays the same and then begins to notch up," said Michael P. Niemira, an economist with the Mitsubishi Bank in New York. 
 The Labor Department said the February advance in the Consumer Price Index followed increases of one-tenth of 1 percent in January, two-tenths in December and four-tenths in November.
 
Annual Rate Is 2.2%
 Extended over a full year, consumer prices rose at a 2.2 percent rate in the first two months of 1992. Most analysts expect prices to rise between 3 percent and 3.5 percent for the year. That is a bit higher than last year's 3.1 percent but well below the 6.1 percent increase in 1990 when the recession began.
Energy prices declined nine-tenths of 1 percent in February, the second straight drop. But Mr. Niemira said the recovery would eventually increase demand for energy and bring higher prices.
Food prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent for the month, and John M. Albertine, head of a Washington economic forecasting company, said that should not be a source of concern.
"Food prices have been amazingly low for the last year," he said. "Considering the bizarre weather we have had, a small jump in food prices should not come as much of a surprise."
 
Some Categories Jump
 Excluding the volatile food and energy categories, consumer prices were up four-tenths of 1 percent in February, the steepest advance since a similar gain last September.
Still, the Labor Department said much of that advance was attributed to a 1.5 percent rise in apparel prices accompanying the introduction of spring and summer clothing. Analysts said it was unlikely that the increase would be repeated.
A 1.5 percent jump in fresh fruit and vegetable prices accounted for nearly all of the increase in food prices. The cost of tomatoes soared 43.1 percent, helping to raise the overall price of vegetables 8.9 percent.
Meat prices, which had declined in January and in most of 1991, rose moderately. Beef was up five-tenths of 1 percent, and pork rose seven-tenths.
Cereal and bakery products were up three-tenths of 1 percent, while dairy products declined one-tenth.
In the energy sector, natural gas prices fell 1.3 percent, electricity declined 1.1 percent and the cost of home heating oil was down four-tenths of 1 percent.
Gasoline prices were down five-tenths of 1 percent in February after a 1.9 percent drop in January. They are now 18.6 percent lower than their peak in November 1990 after the flow of foreign oil was disrupted by the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait.
The various changes left the Consumer Price Index, before adjusting for seasonal variations, at 138.6, compared with 134.8 a year ago. That meant that goods costing $134.80 in February 1991 would have cost $138.60 last month.

HEADLINE: $8.62 Billion Trade Gap in '91 Was the Lowest in a Decade

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 17

 BODY:
America turned in its best performance in international trade in nearly a decade last year as the country's current account deficit shrank to $8.62 billion, the Government said today.
That marked a sharp turnaround from a $92.12 billion deficit in 1990. Nearly half the improvement came from foreign payments to cover the costs of the Persian Gulf war. But a record level of American export sales and the recession, which cut into import demand, also helped. 
 The current account is considered the best gauge of a country's international competitiveness because it measures not only trade in merchandise but also trade in services and investment flows between countries.
The current account deficit also declined in the final three months of the year, dipping to $10.27 billion compared with a revised $11.62 billion in the third quarter.
President Bush is counting on continued trade improvements this year to help propel the economic recovery and blunt campaign criticism that his Administration has failed to aggressively attack trade barriers against American products.
But many private economists predicted the 1992 current account deficit would shoot up to $50 billion or higher, as the gulf war payments dry up and export growth slows because of weakness overseas.
C. Fred Bergsten, head of the Institute for International Economics in Washington, said the good news in the current account performance was that it showed American businesses were becoming more competitive.
But he said growing economic weakness in Europe and Japan would cut into export growth this year while the improving United States economy would mean imports would start rising again.
The country's trade performance over the last two years was an important factor in helping to reduce the severity of the recession, but few analysts said they believed trade would be a positive factor this year.
"Whatever recovery we manage to have in 1992 will have to be home grown," said Bruce Steinberg, an economist at Merrill Lynch. "Our export growth is going to slow down because of recessions in other countries."
Until the 1980's, the United States normally ran surpluses in the current account as its earnings on overseas investments and service trade like banking and tourism offset perennial merchandise deficits.
However, as Americans transferred billions of dollars overseas to pay for imported oil, televisions and cars, the United States was transformed from the world's largest creditor country into the world's largest debtor nation.
Last year's current account deficit was the smallest imbalance since a deficit of $5.87 billion in 1982. The current account had swelled to a record $160.2 billion in 1987.
For all of 1991, the deficit in merchandise trade fell to $73.6 billion from $108.1 billion in 1990 as exports increased 6.9 percent, to a record $416.5 billion, while imports declined 1.5 percent, to $490.1 billion.

HEADLINE: Federal Express to Trim European Operations

BYLINE: ADAM BRYANT

 BODY:
Underscoring its long-term difficulties in Europe, the Federal Express Corporation has said it will significantly scale back its operations there.
Its plan to halt delivery between countries in Europe starting May 4, a move resulting in a $254 million charge, is the second restructuring by the company in just over a year. In February 1991, the company drastically cut its operations in Britain, cutting 25 percent of its staff and taking a $121 million charge against earnings. 
 The latest cuts, analysts said, are the result of several missteps by Federal Express in its effort to repeat in Europe the success it continues to experience in the United States, where it holds almost half the market that it created two decades ago.
Federal Express plans to maintain operations in 16 major cities - down from 125 in Europe now - and subcontract deliveries outside those core markets to other carriers. The restructuring, announced on Monday, will reduce its European work force to 2,600 from 9,200.
The company also reported a quarterly loss of $298 million, compared with a deficit of $168.7 million in the period a year earlier. Revenues were $1.89 billion, up from $1.86 billion.
"The operations needed to support our intra-European service have been extremely costly, and we have not generated adequate revenues to cover our costs," said Frederick W. Smith, chief executive of Federal, in a statement.
Analysts said they were uncertain of the degree to which the cuts would reverse the company's European operating losses. For example, they are unclear whether the remaining 16-city European operations are profitable.
"The street is really puzzled about the extent of the reduction of the loss," said James D. Parker, an analyst with the Robinson-Humphrey Company in Atlanta. He noted that part of the troubles of Federal Express in Europe, particularly for its air-cargo business, resulted from sluggish economies there. Kevin Murphy, an analyst with Morgan Stanley, estimated the cuts would result in savings of up to $150 million a year. The company declined to speculate.
 
Improved Earnings Predicted
 Analysts generally predicted improved future earnings in the wake of the report. Federal Express shares, which trade on the New York Stock Exchange, closed yesterday at $55.25, up $1.75.
Mr. Murphy of Morgan Stanley said the company mistakenly tried to secure a stronghold in Europe too quickly, an undertaking that should have been given 20 years to succeed. United Parcel Service, another established competitor in Europe, required 11 years to become profitable in Germany, he noted.
In Europe, consumer loyalty to the more established competitors, such as DHL, is high. Also, Mr. Murphy said the name Federal Express connoted a distinct United States flair that probably did not sit well with European customers. "It just wasn't their market," he said.
The company said that a unit of Australia's TNT Ltd. would buy the French operations of Federal Express and would serve as the agent of Federal Express for deliveries in 10 European countries. In Britain, Federal Express said it intends to sell its assets to Securicor Omega Express Ltd., the largest express-delivery company there.
The latest restructuring adds to the list of failed experiments by Federal Express to achieve "second generation" growth beyond its core market. In 1986, it ended its electronic mail service known as Zapmail. The move resulted in a $340 million pretax write-off, adding to their $317 million in losses suffered by the service from the time it was introduced in 1984.
