HEADLINE: Big Job Loss in Los Angeles Us Expected

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Federal cuts in military spending could result in the loss of up to 420,000 jobs in Los Angeles County by 1995, a study group said yesterday.
The county receives more Federal military dollars than any other county in the nation, leaving it exposed to sharp spending cuts made possible by the end of the cold war. 
 The county's Aerospace Task Force called on local, state and Federal officials to help the industry make a transition to commercial projects.
"The aerospace decline is not primarily the result of market forces, or a failure of the industry or community to maintain competitiveness," the group said. "It is instead the result of a major change in Federal policy in response to new international circumstances."
The group's analysts estimated that military spending in Los Angeles County would fall to $3.5 billion to $4.9 billion in 1995, compared with $8.88 billion in 1990.
"This would result in the loss by 1995 of between 210,000 to 420,000 direct and indirect jobs within the county," the report said.
As of December 1991, the county had 225,600 workers directly employed in the aerospace industry, accounting for 5.3 percent of non-farm employment and 28.3 percent of manufacturing jobs.
The group estimated that for every $8 lost in military revenue, the county economy would lose $28.
The estimated loss includes the cost of unemployment insurance, public assistance, losses in personal income and retail trade, a downturn in residential and commercial construction, and losses in public sector revenues.
"Large defense firms are not easily able to convert their technology and manufacturing resources to commercial projects," the group said. "Large aerospace firms are still devoting a majority of their research and development eforts to developing new products for the Department of Defense."
The group recommended the formation of a privately financed venture capital fund to help in the transition of technology from aerospace and military uses to commercial applications like electric vehicles.

HEADLINE: Telmex to Triple Dividend

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, March 17

 BODY:
Investors scrambled to buy stock in Telefonos de Mexico today on news that the company planned to triple its dividend.
Analysts said the dividend, which would rise to 75 pesos, or 49 cents a share, from 25 pesos, or 16 cents, would still be too low by itself to justify buying the stock.
But they said the dividend move should bolster buyers' confidence in the stock. 
 The telephone company's American shares closed up $1, to $55.125, on the New York Stock Exchange. On the Mexican bolsa, Telmex L shares ended up 3.3 percent, lifting the broader market sharply higher.
Telmex shares have been under pressure since the Mexican Government said this month that it might sell its 9.5 percent stake in May or June.
Analysts said Telmex might have decided to consider a dividend hike to appease investors. They also said that dividend yields tended to be low in Mexico because of inflation.
The proposed increase to 49 cents an American share would translate into roughly a 1 percent dividend yield. That compares with yields of about 6 percent for regional telephone companies in the United States.

HEADLINE: Dow Up 19.68 on Favorable Economic Data

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks closed with strong gains yesterday on the heels of new economic data that gave further evidence of an economic recovery and a manageable inflation rate. A slight bounce back in the Tokyo market from its steep selloff the previous day also helped lift American shares.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 19.68 points, to 3,256.04. Traders said equity gains were underpinned by a firm bond market, which managed to erase its own earlier losses. 
 The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 3.19 points, to 409.58. Birinyi Associates, the Wall Street research firm, noted that the large block traders who were the big sellers on Monday were the big buyers of issues in the Dow and S.& P. 500 yesterday, after the economic data fell within expectations.
 
Other Gauges Higher
 Trading on the American Stock Exchange pushed the composite index up 2.76 points, to 405.64, while the Nasdaq composite index rang up a 5.33-point gain, to 623.27, led by technology and health-care issues. The Russell 2,000 index of smaller company stocks gained 1.1 points, to 207.21.
Investor confidence was lifted another notch or two by the positive economic data and by some follow-through from Monday's blue-chip rally. Other positive factors included the Tokyo rebound and gains in London.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was a marked improvement over the previous day -- 188.8 million shares, up from Monday's 156 million, with gaining issues outpacing losing ones by 1,051 to 651.
The economic reports included stronger-than-expected February housing starts and Consumer Price Index data that were in line with forecasts. Industrial production was below expectations, and capacity utilization, while shy of predictions, still displayed some improvement.
Paul J. Kronlokken, the technical analyst at Piper, Jaffray & Hopwood Inc. in Minneapolis, described the trading session as interesting, with a roller-coaster ride in bonds ending in a round trip that finally added some support to stocks.
He said, collectively, all the data were neutral, but individually they added early volatility to bonds, which limited the gains in stocks.
 
Elan Corp. at $46.50
 Among the issues posting gains yesterday, the Elan Corporation rose 1 5/8, to 46 1/2, on the Amex, after saying it would seek approval from the Food and Drug Administration by the end of the year for a new wearable drug delivery device called "panoject." It would be used to administer powerful pain-killers in hospitals, initially morphine and approved analgesics.
Telemex, known as Telefonos de Mexico, rose 1, to 55 1/8, after it said its board would recommend increasing the dividend at its April 10 meeting.
The company received a "buy" recommendation from Stephanie Georges, an analyst at Salomon Brothers Inc., who also liked Southwestern Bell, up 3/8, to 58 7/8, which owns 10 percent of Telemex and is part of a consortium with voting powers on the company's board.
Following its announcement late on Monday of a European restructuring, Federal Express gained 1 3/4, to 55 1/4. The package-delivery company said it was taking a $254 million charge for the restructuring. David Guthrie, an analyst at Morgan Keegan & Company, said, "If this doesn't allow them to reach the break-even point for their international operations within a couple of years, nothing will."
Applebee's International rose 3, to 18 1/2, yesterday. Traders noted that on Monday the restaurant franchiser publicly offered 2.8 million common shares at $15 each through underwriters led by Piper, Jaffray and Montgomery Securities.
Microsoft jumped 3 3/4, to 128, based on expectations of a strong reception for a soon-to-be-introduced upgraded version of its graphical system software. The company expects the product to overshadow a rival system upgrade that I.B.M is expected to introduce on March 31.

HEADLINE: As the Rich Get Leaner, The Poor Get the French Fries

SERIES: Resetting the Table: The Changing American Meal -- Last of four articles.

BYLINE: By MOLLY O'NEILL

 BODY:
IT was called "The Gourmet Revolution," "The Dietary Revolution," "The Awakening of American Taste." And now the revolution is complete. Sun-dried tomatoes and extra-virgin olive oil, once rationed to a chosen few, are now displayed in supermarkets and widely distributed. The exotic cuisines that people traveled the world to sample are now as close as the local frozen-food department.
"I knew it had peaked last year when a Midwestern menu made a pun on 'blackened redfish' and offered 'reddened blackfish,' " said Michael Batterberry, the editor of Food Arts magazine, a trade journal published in New York. "And then there are those prepared chicken entrees in the grocery that come complete with fake grill marks and a packet of mesquite flavoring for that fresh-grilled taste." 
 The revolution, which bridged generations and crossed class lines, began almost 20 years ago when the health-food consciousness of the Woodstock era combined with the dietary concerns of the buttoned-down establishment. Buoyed by the free-flowing cash of the 1980's, the alliance expanded into epicurean territory. It rearranged grocery shelves, rewrote the menus of luxury restaurants and McDonald's alike and reordered the national dietary guidelines. And just as rock-and-roll songs were tamed into Muzak, exotically seasoned avant-garde food was retooled as mall fare. Lite rock, lite food.
The revolution dovetailed with wider social changes as well, and eventually mirrored the disparity between the rich and the poor that the 80's economy amplified. The more that health concerns shaped the country's most expensive cuisine in restaurants and the higher the price rose on "healthful" designer vegetables, olive oils, pasta, fish and fat-reduced food products, the more the ingredients for healthful eating were beyond the reach of poor people.
Analyzing household food expenditures from 1980 to 1988, the Agriculture Department found that the average weekly grocery budget rose slightly or remained constant in middle- and upper-income households, said James T. Blaylock, an analyst of food spending with the department's Economic Research Service. At the same time, he said, food spending fell 13.1 percent in the nation's poorest households.
While the gap between the high and low ends of the national food chain widened, the types of food that people bought completed a reversal, said Dr. Nan A. Rothschild, an anthropology professor at Barnard College and the author of "New York City Neighborhoods" (Academic Press, 1990), a sociological study of 18th-century New York based on excavations.
"At that time," she said, "wealthy areas could be identified by the remains of heavy meat bones. There were few food remains in poorer neighborhoods, where people ate cheap vegetables and fish."
By 1984, when Dr. Rothschild was commissioned by the City of New York to study trash in various neighborhoods, the remains showed that eating patterns had reversed.
"The poorest neighborhoods had the heaviest meat remains by far," she said. Households in blocks of the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn discarded as many take-out containers as those on Park Avenue, she said, though the former were typically from Kentucky Fried Chicken and the latter from Maxim's de Paris. In poor neighborhoods, she found cans that had contained regular soda; on wealthier blocks, diet-soda cans. Poor areas threw out bags that had contained high-fat and high-salt chips; the privileged discarded cans that had contained low-salt peanuts.
The change in food remains reflected the social correctness that the food revolution assigned to light, fresh eating. "The lighter the food, the higher the status." said William Woys Weaver, the author of "America Eats" (Harper & Row, 1989). And Clark Wolf, a consultant to the food industry, observed, "At the very best restaurants, the biggest growth area in both selection and price is in salads and vegetables."
But greengrocery items evade the grasp of some poor people, said Elizabeth Crockett, the nutrition coordinator for the Food Bank of Central New York in Syracuse. Because of poor grocery distribution in low-income neighborhoods, she said, fresh vegetables are few and typically much more expensive than in suburban stores. The prices can be prohibitive.
In a study at Syracuse University, Ms. Crockett compared a shopping list drawn from the Thrifty Food Plan, the Agriculture Department plan used to determine food-stamp allotments, with a shopping list drawn from the department's 1990 dietary guidelines.
"The Surgeon General's recommendations are healthier, but they cost 25 percent more in groceries than previous eating plans,' she said. "Someone living on the current food-stamp allotment couldn't afford to eat the healthy plan."
Whether by limited finances or personal preference, health concerns are a great divider between the haves and the have-nots today. Dr. Robert Schnee, a senior vice president of BAI, a market research concern in Tarrytown, N.Y., interviews as many as 600 people a year to construct consumer profiles.
"When I hear the words, 'I don't care if it's good for me or not,' I know that I am talking to somebody poor," he said. "Almost nobody above the poverty level says that anymore."
But food preferences have long conveyed more than the simple distinction between the poorest and everybody else. "People tell a very detailed story about themselves by what and how they eat," said Mark Miller, an anthropologist and the chef and owner of the Coyote Cafe in Santa Fe, N.M., and Red Sage, a restaurant in Washington.
The revolution substantially changed the traditional rank and file of food symbolism; one doesn't encounter Brie or fillet of beef with bone-marrow sauce at the best dinner parties today. But from the generation that rebelled against the rules of the effete cuisine that featured Brie and beef, another strict pecking order of high-status foods is emerging.
Rare ingredients have long conveyed luxury, but in the aftermath of the revolution, rarity is harder to come by. Crucial to the change in American taste, said Raymond Sokolov, the author of "Why We Eat What We Eat" (Summit Books, 1992), was the speedy transport of far-flung ingredients and the rapid dissemination of information about them. As the difficulty in obtaining exotic ingredients decreased, appreciation of their nuance became necessary.
"Anybody recognizes the taste of fresh ginger," Mr. Miller said. "The epicurean can now discern the flavor of young ginger from Hawaii, or the difference between green and black cardamom."
Mass-market availability is the nemesis of chic. After regional Cantonese and Hunan dishes replaced chop suey and chow mein in the frozen-food section of supermarkets, Southeast Asian cuisine climbed past them on the food social ladder.
"Lemon grass, dried Thai condiments and chilies are in now," Mr. Miller said. Farm-raised game birds like squab, quail, duck, "the birds that are hardest to find in the supermarket," are the darlings of chic menus, he said.
Mr. Miller noted the rise of "cross-status foods," typically with plebeian ingredient that bespeak a oneness with the common person, which is then elevated by rare commodities. He recently sampled an appetizer of two thin potato slices sandwiching a thick slice of white truffle pan-fried in butter and served with shredded veal-tongue crackling and a cabbage confit.
In addition to rarity and complexity, environmental correctness adds status to food, Mr. Weaver said. He cited the popularity of "biodynamic beef, free-range chickens, organic vegetables, long-line tuna."
Some environmental correctness may go too far. "Scuba-harvested scallops?" Mr. Batterberry asked. "Venezuelan rain-forest honey?" After noticing the items on a Manhattan menu recently, he said, "It's tough to keep ahead of the mass market, but this is getting absurd."
With rarity and exoticism teetering so close to parody, the handwork and epicurean erudition required to produce dishes like the potato-truffle sandwich confer high status to food. "Time is a precious commodity these days, so food that has received attention and time is more valuable than food that hasn't," Mr. Batterberry said. The peeled fresh carrots and pre-rinsed lettuce that command premium prices in supermarkets signal the value that time adds to food.
Noting the recent introduction of a high-priced clarified butter in upscale groceries, Mr. Batterberry said, "There is a little of Marie Antoinette at the dairy in all of this."
Ripples of populist scorn are already washing across post-revolution conceits. There may even be a market for retro-cuisine. After years of championing "spa" cooking and small nouvelle portions, the major food magazines have recently featured recipes for "he-man pork dinners" and "those gooey old-fashioned desserts." The editorial tone is consistent: "We know better, but what the heck."
Books like "The Bad for You Cookbook" (Villard, 1992), a collection of recipes rich in fat and full of passe preservatives, are selling well. "Real people are real sick of the elitist food police," Chris Maynard, one of the book's authors, said shortly before the book was published.
"Real people never really heard the food police," said Michael Stern, who along with his wife, Jane, began traveling America's back roads and sampling regional food in 1972. The food revolution put club soda and yogurt, pita bread and salad bars into Piggly Wiggly stores in the South, Mrs. Stern said. "But once you get away from the small foodie enclaves on either coast," she said, "most Americans are eating about the same as ever."
Harry Balzer, the vice president of the NPD Group, a market research concern in Chicago, agrees. Every three months for the last 15 years, he has analyzed the dining habits of 13,000 people who keep detailed diaries of what they eat.
"People talk a better game than they eat," he said. "Eighty percent of the American population never changes its eating habits. That 20 percent who can afford to experiment drive the market and are responsible for the thousands of new products that are introduced each year, 9 out of 10 of which fail. Capturing a sliver of a percent means you've started a trend. If it lasts more than a year, you've found a niche."
The revolution may have increased the amount of talk about food among Americans; it may have boosted the amount of money that the middle and upper classes spend on certain foods, and may have widened the gap between the diet of the privileged and that of the poor. But Mr. Balzer said he expected the movement's enduring icon to be the word "lite."
Lest the food conscious think their efforts in vain, he is quick to cite the other significant change. "Turkey sandwiches are competing with peanut butter and jelly sandwiches and tuna fish," he said.
 
The Series So Far
 THE third article of this series, which appeared on March 11, described the rise of ethnic foods in the American diet. The second article, on March 4, described the love-hate relationship between American consumers and convenience foods. The first article, on Feb. 26, detailed the war of words between the advocates of good health and the advocates of food-for-pleasure, and the confusion of consumers caught between the two.

HEADLINE: At the Meals on Reels Film Festival, Chicken Soup and a Tasty Frenchman

BYLINE: By GEORGIA DULLEA

 BODY:
RANDOM notes while watching random clips from Meals on Reels, the first film festival devoted only to food, which is to be held Saturday at New York University School of Law in Manhattan:
STARVING ARTISTS' COOKBOOK, by Paul Lamarre and Melissa Wolf (video, 41 minutes). Surreal dishes prepared by artists, some famous, some not. William Wegman, the art world's reigning dog photographer, demonstrates how to pop vitamins. He drops vitamin C capsules into a pan of hot oil on the stove, covers the pan, turns up the burner. He shakes the pan. Rattling sounds are heard. He lifts the cover to reveal . . . popcorn. Oops! He spills it on the floor. An off-camera Weimaraner devours it.
Debby Davis, a Bronx sculptor, makes Flashlight Jell-O, using lime gelatin and a loaf pan longer than a flashlight. The effect is ectoplastic.
M. F. K.: A DOCUMENTARY ON THE LIFE of MARY FRANCES KENNEDY FISHER, by Barbara Wornum (video, 45 minutes). At the age of 83, the master food writer is still a wicked beauty. In one scene, Mrs. Fisher, in chiffon and long, sparkly earrings, speaks from her wheelchair to an audience in San Francisco. Asked whether she reads current food writing and, if so, what she thinks of it, she seems to wince.
"Even in the worst book," she says, waving a microphone, "there is one jewel, the jewel in a toad's head. I just don't have the time anymore to look for it. All these idea books. The story of bread or the story of potatoes. Some editor will say, 'Well, write about peanuts.' And some poor soul does."
HOW TASTY WAS MY LITTLE FRENCHMAN, by Nelson Pereira Dos Santos (film, 80 minutes). A wry look at eating at the very top of the food chain, cannibalism, by one of Brazil's Cinema Novo directors. When the film was first released, in 1971, judges at the Cannes Film Festival withdrew it from competition because of its nudity and cannibalism, according to the program notes. It didn't help that the main item on the menu was French.
Still hungry? There are 26 other courses in this cinematic feast that celebrates, scrutinizes and satirizes -- in art films, documentaries, commercials, music videos and cartoons -- what, how and why we eat.
The festival is sponsored by City Lore, a New York center for urban folk culture, and the Culinary Historians of New York. It runs from 11 A.M. to 11 P.M. on Saturday at the N.Y.U. law school, at 40 Washington Square South (between MacDougal and Sullivan Streets). Tickets are $10, or $6 for students and those 62 and above. For more information, call (212) 529-1955.
Barbara Kirshenblatt-Gimblett, a folklorist, who is a power in both groups, served as the matchmaker as well as the author of the introductory program notes. "Meals on Reels," she said, "suggests the many ways we organize our social life and cultural values through the malleable and ephemeral medium of food."
Garlic has never been accused of being ephemeral. GARLIC IS AS GOOD AS 10 MOTHERS, by Les Blank (film, 31 minutes) is a hymn to the culinary and curative powers of the stinking rose. It visits a garlic festival in Gilroy, Calif., and Chez Panisse in Berkeley for an all-garlic meal. Screened in Mr. Blank's "aromaround," which means garlic cooking in the theater.
Audience watching could be an entertainment in itself. Food critics as well as film critics are expected, along with anthropologists, folklorists, historians and, of course, foodies.
Chefs, too, may drop by to see stars like Paul Prudhomme perform on camera, or in FLYING MORNING GLORY (ON FIRE), by Skip Blumberg (video, 4 minutes), an acrobatic cook in Thailand. Silliness itself. A Thai street cook stir-fries morning glory leaves in a wok. Flames. The cook yanks the wok from the burner and hurls the morning glory leaves into the air. Half a block away, a waiter catches the leaves on a platter. Instant replay follows.
Since the organizers ruled out obvious titles like "Babette's Feast," the festival's director, Eric John, worried at first that there would not be enough food footage for a program. As it turned out, he had leftovers.
Mr. John experienced cravings for Cajun cooking -- YUM, YUM, YUM!, by Les Blank and Maureen Gosling (film, 31 minutes). He contemplated a trip to Gill's restaurant in Brooklyn for a West Indian meal -- RICE AND PEAS, by Karen Kramer (video, 12 minutes). And he longed to visit the kosher kitchen of a grandmother who sings in Yiddish to the chicken in her pot -- CHICKEN SOUP, by Kenny Schneider (film, 14 minutes).
Only one film was an appetite suppressant: SUMMER OF THE LOUCHEUX, by Graydon McCrea (27 minutes), showing a practice in Alaska of burying fish until it decays.
The festival opens with a 1949 documentary of a slaughterhouse on the outskirts of Paris, THE BLOOD OF BEASTS, by Georges Franju (film, 22 minutes). The butchers literally whistle while they work. Steam rises from the blood on the killing floor.
In a sobering look at food production, a changing economy has forced Appalachian women into minimum-wage, part-time, dead-end jobs, in FAST FOOD WOMEN, by Anne Johnson (video, 29 minutes).
Hunger is the theme of two entries. One, SHAPING THE IMAGE, by Ilan Ziv and Freke Vuijst (video, 29 minutes), explores the role of television in the political exploitation of famine in Africa.
The other, THE FAMINE WITHIN, by Katherine Gilday (film, 90 minutes), examines the reasons behind American women's obsession with weight and dieting, and the sad consequences of bulimia and anorexia. Surveys mentioned in the film indicate that many women consider losing weight more important than moving ahead on the job or having a satisfying love life, that fear of fat may be more powerful than fear of death.
Finally, from the rusty film cans of yesteryear comes a look at how food has been advertised, promoted and taught since the 1930's. In A PRESENTATION OF FOOD COMMERCIALS AND INDUSTRIALS, by Richard Prelinger (film and video, 90 minutes), laugh along with "Breakfast Pals, starring Snap, Crackle and Pop." Have your pencils ready for "Let's Make a Meal in 20 Minutes." And, in the light of current nutritional wisdom, hiss "The Four Food Groups."

HEADLINE: Poll Says Home Rule Could Bend To Ward Off Sprawling Growth

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, March 17

 BODY:
New Jerseyans are willing to give up one of the state's most hallowed political traditions, control over local land-use rules, to keep sprawl from eating up too much open space, according to a recent Rutgers University opinion poll.
They are also generally satisfied with the way their state has grown in recent years, the poll suggests, and believe more growth is important for economic reasons. 
 The survey was sponsored by the Center for Analysis of Public Issues, a nonprofit research group, to test public opinion about a central objective of a new state growth plan, which is to be released this summer. The plan will urge a strengthening of state and county roles in channeling growth into compact, already developed centers.
Asked how strict they thought growth controls should be in New Jersey, 32 percent of the 800 respondents said "very strict" and 52 percent answered "somewhat strict."
 
Trading Power for Growth
 And to the question of whether state government should "be actively involved in determining how and where the state grows," 78 percent said it should, and just 19 percent disagreed. The state plan grants no special powers to Trenton, but state regulation of new roads, sewers and utilities, which are essential to any development, are likely to be governed by the plan.
Although the state's 567 municipalities have sole constitutional power to regulate land use within their borders, 61 percent of the poll's respondents said they would be willing to give up some of their town's land-use powers in return for more planned and coordinated overall growth.
The poll, conducted in February by the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers, has a margin of error of plus or minus 3.5 percentage points.
 
Focusing Concerns
 "The survey shows that home rule is dead and buried in the minds of most New Jerseyans," said Neil Upmeyer, president of the analysis center, which is based in Princeton.
Some of the strong support for planned development may result from population shifts during the 1980's, Mr. Upmeyer said. The northern counties of Essex, Hudson, Bergen and Union lost 100,000 residents during the decade, while the six counties that form the waist of the state -- Somerset, Hunterdon, Middlesex, Mercer, Monmouth and Ocean -- gained 300,000 residents, and gave up to development 50,000 acres of once-open land, an area larger than Hudson County.
Mr. Upmeyer said he believed the population shift helped focus many respondents' worries about suburban sprawl. "What is a concern to people is that they do not get into a situation where, given the development, they wind up with the same ills that they fled," particularly traffic congestion, he said.
State residents have mixed but generally good feelings about growth in their communities so far, the poll reported. Thirty-three percent said that development had made their communities better places to live, and 29 percent said it had made them worse, while 35 percent said it had made no difference.
By a wide margin, 88 percent, respondents said that continued growth and development is very important or somewhat important to the state's economic health.

HEADLINE: Dissolve Bridgeport? No One Embraces the Idea

BYLINE: By ANDREW L. YARROW, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRIDGEPORT

 BODY:
Until this month, Lee A. Samowitz was little known beyond the Bridgeport district that he represents in the Connecticut General Assembly. But thanks to a recent legislative proposal that could be characterized as somewhere between radical and off the wall, the 39-year-old Democrat has been cast into the limelight.
Mr. Samowitz has been a lifelong resident of Bridgeport and lives in the middle-class Black Rock district, but if his proposal were to be enacted, he and Bridgeport's 140,000 other inhabitants would suddenly become residents of the adjacent towns of Trumbull, Fairfield and Stratford. 
 Bridgeport would simply vanish.
Mr. Samowitz said he never imagined that his suggestion to dissolve Bridgeport would draw such animosity from other public officials and such interest from the news media.
His proposal -- to parcel the economically beleaguered city out to three neighboring, well-to-do towns -- was a "cry for help," he said, never one to be taken seriously.
Mr. Samowitz said his intent was to force politicians to address a very real and rather messy issue -- the fiscal, social and political relationship between poor, decaying cities and their more affluent suburbs.
 
'Plantation Mentality'
 "Bridgeport is the victim of a plantation mentality in this state," said Mr. Samowitz, a lawyer who is serving his fourth term in the House of Representatives. "We take care of the whole region's trash, we provide the hospitals and homeless shelters, and the suburbs send us their welfare cases. We pay the highest property taxes in the state -- two to three times as much as some suburbs -- for these services, so there should be some way to equalize the tax burden regionwide."
While many Bridgeport politicians may share that view, they have little enthusiasm for Mr. Samowitz or his proposal. Mayor Joseph P. Ganim, a fellow Democrat, has disparaged it, saying, "I don't think it's a productive bill."
State Representative Joe Grabarz, whose east Bridgeport Assembly district includes some of Connecticut's poorest areas, is less charitable.
"Samowitz's proposal is an incredible waste of legislative effort," he said. "It would be a better use of the Legislature's time to try to use the state as a mechanism to take resources from the region to develop practical, regional approaches to Bridgeport's problems."
In neighboring Fairfield, First Selectwoman Jacquelyn C. Durrell is not taking the idea seriously.
"I think it was done in jest," she said. "But if you go back 350 years, originally we had Black Rock. If they're serious about it, and they'll give us Black Rock, we'll be glad to take them up on it."
 
Addressing Immediate Needs
 Mr. Samowitz, who is one of 13 assistant majority leaders in the House, says he would prefer solving Bridgeport's financial problems by levying property taxes on suburban shopping centers or altering what he considers onerous "sweetheart" contracts with the city's police officers and firefighters.
"The assembly is in no mood to impose additional layers of taxes," he said. "And these solutions would impose no new taxes on individuals."
One alternative being considered by legislators would create a regional economic-development commission that could issue bonds and perhaps collect taxes to pay for public services like schools and welfare in Bridgeport, Fairfield, Trumbull, Monroe, Easton, Milford and other nearby towns.
But Mr. Samowitz said such an approach might be too "long term" to address Bridgeport's immediate needs. And Michael Lawson, the director of intergovernmental finance for the Connecticut Conference of Municipalities, warned that regional government could "create another level of bureaucracy."
 
City vs. Region
"The state already has a lot more weapons in its revenue-raising arsenal than towns do," he added. "And it would be more efficient and equitable for the state to fund and operate social services."
But if these approaches fail in this year's legislative session, Mr. Samowitz said, the state should seriously consider pulling the plug on Bridgeport and returning to the geographical boundaries of the early 19th century, before Bridgeport was carved out of pieces of Stratford and Fairfield. He said that despite opposition from most corners, "I've gotten lots of favorable attention from my constituents on this."
Mr. Samowitz said that, in addition to urban affairs, his chief concern now is to create "magnet high-tech high schools." He described himself as "in the twilight of my public service," and suggested that after he saw his city "back on track," he wanted to devote himself to his law practice in Bridgeport.
Most Connecticut politicians dismiss Mr. Samowitz's proposal to abolish Bridgeport as a headline-grabbing gambit, but they grudgingly acknowledge that it does highlight the need for regional approaches to city problems.
"The suburbs feel the way to preserve their life style is to wallop all their social problems into urban areas," said Lennie Grimaldi, a top aide to Mayor Ganim. "But the poor in Bridgeport are not just Bridgeport's poor. They're the region's poor."
Bridgeport, which is a largely an island of poverty in the midst of wealthy Fairfield County, tried to declare bankruptcy last summer and on Thursday presented a new plan to close this year's $19 million budget deficit with a combination of more layoffs and service reductions.
The city's budget gap is expected to reach $40 million next year, and it would be saddled with a sharp increase in its welfare costs under Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s proposal to reduce state reimbursement for local welfare payments from 90 percent to 67 percent.
"It's the Moe, Larry and Curly routine," Mr. Samowitz said. "Moe, the Federal Government, slaps Larry, the state, who slaps Curly, the cities. And then there's no one else to slap."

HEADLINE: Report Cards on Schools Show Some Improvement

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, March 17

 BODY:
The State Education Commissioner, John Ellis, released the second annual "report cards" on New Jersey schools today, saying that there had been improvements but too few of them to keep the state competitive.
The report cards grade each of New Jersey's 555 public school systems in three major areas: finances, teacher-to-student ratio and student performance on national tests like the Scholastic Aptitude Test. 
 Mr. Ellis said he was encouraged by some results, including the fact that the state ranked fifth in the nation in participation in the aptitude tests.
"There are encouraging signs, but we have not yet made significant progress," he said. "Our schools simply are not as good as they need to be to make New Jersey internationally competitive."
 
Criticism From Union
 The teachers' union, the New Jersey Education Association, criticized the report as a "numbers game" and a waste of time and money. "It is a very negative approach that says no matter how much our students have improved, it's just not enough," said Karen Joseph, a spokeswoman for the 138,000-member association. "If we don't stop concentrating on the negatives, we are never going to improve on education."
The report card program is meant to stimulate public discussion of the schools, but in its short history it has produced more controversy than discussion.
Last year there were complaints that the study was riddled with errors, including miscalculated teachers' salaries. There were also complaints about the timing of the report cards, which were distributed only weeks before school district elections. This year's elections are scheduled for April 7, but the Republican-controlled Legislature has passed and sent to Gov. Jim Florio a bill that would postpone the elections until April 28.
The report card program is a joint effort of the State Education Department and the Business Roundtable Education Initiative of New Jersey, a consortium of nine major corporations that paid the $85,000 cost of compiling and distributing the critiques. The companies -- A.T.& T., Johnson & Johnson, McGraw-Hill, Prudential, American Cyanamid, CPC International, American Home Products, Merrill Lynch and Merck -- have agreed to pay for the report cards for 10 years.
P. Roy Vagelos, the chairman of Merck and the head of the consortium, said today that he was worried about the education system's ability to produce qualified workers. "New Jersey needs highly educated workers to continue to produce the high-tech products and complex services that are the strength of our state's economy," he said.
The New Jersey School Boards Association, which a year ago assailed use of the report cards, gave its reserved approval to this year's effort.
"Like all statistics, those in the report card can be interpreted in many ways," said the group's executive director, Robert E. Boose. "However, the 1992 report card is a vast improvement over last year's and is something that school districts can work with to inform their communities about the public schools."
Responding to the criticisms last year, officials revised their method of evaluating schools. For example, this year they used current-year information on spending and compared districts with similar systems in their regions. The changes made it impractical to compare this year's findings with last year's.
But the New Jersey Education Association said it still found the report virtually useless.
"This new and improved version of the New Jersey state report card does nothing to advance a more positive attitude toward our children, our schools or the men and women who have dedicated their lives to education," said the association's president, Betty Kraemer.
"All of the information included in the report card can already be obtained at the local school level and is customarily made available by district superintendents each school year," she said. "The Business Roundtable would better serve our children by contributing its time, resources, and dollars directly to our schools."

HEADLINE: Personal Health

BYLINE: By Jane E. Brody

 BODY:
AMERICAN women have far more to fear from the men they know and once loved than from any stranger on the street. Domestic violence is the leading cause of injury and death to American women, causing more harm than vehicular accidents, rapes and muggings combined.
Each year an estimated six million women are beaten by the men they live with, and 30 percent of women who become homicide victims die at the hands of men with whom they have a "family" relationship. While there are some cases of domestic violence in which the wife is the abuser as well as problems of abuse among gay couples, in the overwhelming majority of cases, women are the victims at the hands of their men. 
 When such cases gain wide attention, the public tends to blame alcohol or drugs or poverty as the provocation. But are they? A chemical high may release inhibitions against physical abuse but it does not create a violent, power-hungry person who needs to control a spouse even more tightly than a master rules a slave. As for poverty, experts say well-educated, well-off professional men are hardly immune; they are simply better at escaping punishment.
Even when the victim's charges of abuse are believed, she is often blamed for staying with her abuser, for not throwing him out or picking up the children and leaving. Sometimes she is blamed for hooking up with a violent man, or even for provoking his attacks.
"Why did she stay?" is the leading question. Far fewer people ask, "Why did he do it?" Yet understanding the nature of spouse abuse and the forces that foster and perpetuate it is crucial to establishing effective social and legal mechanisms for protecting the victims, breaking these violent patterns and preventing such cases from developing in the first place.
 
Why Men Do It
 As more communities mandate therapy for men convicted of domestic violence, the extent and origins of their abusive behavior is at last undergoing professional scrutiny. For example, Cyndee Pattison, a therapist who runs groups for men who batter women, said: "Most of the time the men don't understand that what they are saying or doing is offensive. It's like a reflex, something they've done all their lives." She says men tend to minimize their actions and the consequences, saying things like "we had a little argument," even when the woman required stitches to close facial wounds.
Ms. Pattison, who works for Victim Services, a private nonprofit agency in New York City that aids battered women, said the men are acting on beliefs they learned from their parents and society. "Boys are taught to settle problems and disputes with their fists, whereas girls are taught to use their mouths," she said.
John Aponte, a founder of the Victim Services counseling program for men who batter, said batterers were at the extreme of a continuum of men who "carry the seeds of superiority given to them" at an early age. "Men may use intimidation, threats, economic control or emotional abuse," he said. "It's when these control tactics don't work and a man's authority is challenged that he feels he has to resort to physical abuse."
Experts say many abusive men are the products of a vicious cycle in which they were abused as children or witnessed their fathers abusing their mothers physically or psychologically by belittling them.
The issue, Ms. Pattison said, is power and control. "Historically, women were property and men had to keep them in line," she said. An abusive man may control his wife's access to money, not allow her to work and make her account for every penny she spends. He may try to isolate her from social contacts by disapproving of her friends, escorting her everywhere she goes and alienating her from her family. And he may constantly berate her until she is convinced she is worthless. When he is through, she has nowhere to turn for support and affirmation but to him, her abuser.
 
Why Women Stay
 Dr. Samuel C. Klagsbrun, psychiatrist and medical director of Four Winds Hospital in Katonah, N.Y., points out that most abusive relationships start out normally as loving, romantic and exciting. When abuse begins, women have trouble believing that something initially so wonderful is turning sour. There is a lot of apologizing and making up, and the woman thinks everything will go back to the way it once was. Slowly, barraged by repeated abuse, she becomes dehumanized, helpless and unable to see herself as a separate person and to distinguish right from wrong.
Dr. Klagsbrun, who treated Hedda Nussbaum, the abused companion of Joel Steinberg, the New York lawyer now in jail for fatal child abuse, said such women end up surviving in the same way that prisoners of war, hostages or concentration camp victims do: by trying to behave well, by accommodating their captors, by living from hour to hour. An abused woman may even begin to believe her batterer's rationalization that the beating is for her own good.
When a woman finally musters up the courage to leave a man who abuses her, she typically encounters insurmountable obstacles. Sarah Buel was herself once the victim of an abusive spouse. She eventually escaped with her young son, put herself through college, went to Harvard Law School on scholarship and is now an assistant district attorney for Norfolk County, Mass., and a leading advocate for battered women and court reform nationwide. She lists some problems faced by battered women who try to leave:
*Most do not have enough money to live on and cannot earn enough to support themselves or their children, particularly if the children require day care. If they have no street address, many cannot get welfare.
*Most have trouble finding a place to live. Five women are turned away for every one who seeks shelter, and 95 percent of shelters will not accept women with children.
*Leaving an abusive spouse does not necessarily bring safety; it often triggers more serious violence. More women are killed in the process of leaving than at any other time. For example, last week a Milwaukee woman was stabbed to death in the courthouse by the man from whom she was seeking court protection.
*Women who leave are afraid they will lose their children. The men, who control the money, are often able to hire good lawyers and fight successfully for custody of the children. In Massachusetts, 70 percent of men who try to gain custody succeed.
More often than not, the law fails to protect a battered woman. Abusive men, instead of being prosecuted and jailed for committing acts of criminal violence, are either not arrested or are released by disbelieving judges. They are then able to hound and terrorize their spouses until the women are forced to return. Having nowhere else to go, half of them do.


GRAPHIC: Victim Services says that a woman who answers "yes" to any of these questions may be in an abusive relationship.

 * Prevent you from seeings family or friends?

 * Prevent you from going where you want when you want?
 * Force you to have sex when you don't want to?
 * Humiliate or embarass you in front of others?

HEADLINE: MANY ISRAELIS SEE LOAN AID AS LOST

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, March 17

 BODY:
Although high-level negotiations were still under way in Washington, some senior Israeli officials and newspapers wrote what amounted to obituaries today for the $10 billion in United States loan guarantees that Israel has requested.
This left Israelis pondering the economic, political and diplomatic consequences, both for the country and for the Middle East peace talks, a process that some argued would not be enhanced if Israel felt it could no longer rely on its chief ally. 
 Anti-Government critics said that Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir had no one but himself to blame for the deadlock over the loan guarantees because he had defied the Bush Administration and made what they consider a misguided priority of Israel's right to build settlements in occupied territories.
But many Israelis also expressed bitterness over what they perceive as American unfairness.
 
'No More Free Lunches'
 Recent accusations in Washington -- vigorously denied by Israel -- that Israelis surreptitiously re-exported American weapons technology without getting United States approval has further deepened feelings among some people that they had better think harder about going it alone from now on.
"The message from the United States is becoming clearer," Yoel Marcus, a columnist for the newspaper Haaretz, wrote in a widely shared opinion. "The relations between the two countries will never be the same again, and there will be no more free lunches."
If anything, the general sense of siege intensifed tonight with reports that at least 10 people were killed and almost 100 wounded in a bomb explosion at the Israeli Embassy in Buenos Aires.
Officially, Israel has not withdrawn its bid for the loan guarantees, which it first requested a year ago to help absorb what was then a torrent of new immigrants from the former Soviet Union. Now, however, the stream of immigrants is much thinner.
"Why should we make life easier for the Bush Administration?" one official said. "Let them be the ones to say no."
 
Going It Alone
 But several top officials suggested that the aid package was all but clinically dead, a theme echoed by some newspapers.
Defense Minister Moshe Arens, who met in Washington today with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, said in radio interviews broadcast here that Washington's insistence on no new settlements in the occupied territories amounted to "impossible terms" that "no Government in Israel could accept."
"We will have to raise the necessary funds for absorbing immigration from the Soviet Union ourselves, with the help of Jewish communities around the world," said Mr. Arens, who is close to Mr. Shamir and is No. 2 on the ruling Likud Party's list of candidates for parliamentary elections in June.
Referring to the loan guarantees, he said, "In my opinion, there's no point to another request."
Simcha Dinitz, chairman of the Jewish Agency, the quasi-governmental body responsible for immigration, told Israel radio that there was no longer any reason for the Government to press its search for aid.
 
What's Next?
 All this raised questions about what Israel would do now.
While Mr. Dinitz said the loan guarantees were essential, other officials said Israel could get by without them, even if it might cause the economy to limp a bit more heavily.
The idea of the guarantees is not that the United States would give Israel $10 billion but that it would stand behind Israel when it goes to private institutions to borrow the money. Two billion dollars' worth of such loans were included in Israel's 1992 budget, which may have to be recalculated.
With the guarantees, interest rates would be lower and loan terms more favorable; repayment might be stretched out over a much longer period, for example. Without the guarantees, some economists say, the country faces rougher sledding. Foreign investors may even view the lack of guarantees as a vote of no confidence that casts doubts on the wisdom of putting any money into Israel.
 
Defining Alternatives
 Saying that the "writing is on the wall," Dan Gillerman, head of the Israel Federation of Chambers of Commerce, called for a "crash program" to revitalize the country's lumbering economy. Senior officials of the Bank of Israel, who have been among the most insistent on the importance of the guarantees, met tonight in a long session but announced no decisions.
Still, Finance Minister Yitzhak Modai said that the country "can manage in the worst-case scenario" and that there were alternatives.
The newspaper Maariv reported that Mr. Modai had made a secret visit to Europe to persuade Jewish millionaires that, in the probable absence of the guarantees, now was the time to come to the aid of the country. He reportedly came away feeling confident.
The $10 billion in loan guarantees anticipated an average of 200,000 immigrants a year in the next few years. But thus far in 1992 the pace has slowed to 5,000 a month, an annual rate of 60,000. And while officials say that conditions are so unstable in the former Soviet Union that immigration could surge at any moment, they acknowledge that they may have extra breathing room.
 
The Bigger Picture
 Dollars aside, some argue that the shabby state of United States-Israeli relations is likely to make Israel more skittish in the peace process, which has bumped along inconclusively for five months.
"To the extent that Israelis perceive that they don't have the cushion of a firm, reliable American ally, it might affect their willingness to take what they perceive as security risks," said Harry Wall, who heads the Israel office of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith.
There were no public comments on the loan guarantees today from the opposition Labor Party. But it seemed inevitable that Labor would seize the moment to repeat charges that Mr. Shamir had sacrificed a Zionist opportunity to increase Jewish immigration on an ideological altar: his commitment to Jewish settlement in the occupied West Bank and Gaza. Labor, like the United States, has called for a freeze on such settlements.
But Mr. Shamir, some commentators said, may respond with an argument that the Americans have it in for Israel and, with or without settlements, the aid request was in trouble.
In any event, the Prime Minister told reporters that he would not alter his policies and that he expected ultimately to prevail.
"If we do not change, and continue our political path," he said, "I have no doubt that also the stance of the other side will change over time."

HEADLINE: Nassau's Mortgage Crunch;
Backlog in Record Keeping Compounds Fiscal Problems

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MINEOLA, L.I., March 17

 BODY:
Millions of dollars in mortgage taxes and recording fees are stashed in envelopes in the Nassau County Clerk's office, rather than on deposit in banks, because layoffs have created a three-month backlog in the recording of deeds and mortgages.
Coming at a time of fiscal crisis that has forced widespread cutbacks in Nassau County government, the unusual backlog has deprived local governments of desperately needed revenue from mortgage taxes. 
 The backlog is by far the worst in the state. In New York City and Westchester County, for example, there is a two-day delay in recording mortgages; in Suffolk County, it is three days, and in Albany there is no delay.
The Nassau County Clerk, Harold W. Connell, estimated that the boxes stuffed with thousands of unrecorded deeds and mortgages represented $5.2 million in undeposited funds.
"I'm not proud of it, but there's not very much I can do," he said today. "This is what I'm trying to tell the powers that be, I need some help to get these things moving."
The backlog, which has grown from 8 weeks in October to 13 weeks, has been aggravated by budget cuts that eliminated 54 of the County Clerk's 130 employees and by an antiquated system of recording mortgages that is labor-intensive.
"It's absurd," said the North Hempstead Supervisor, Benjamin J. Zwirn, who estimates that North Hempstead is being deprived of at least $3 million due it in mortgage taxes. Had North Hempstead been getting its share of the mortgage taxes more quickly, Mr. Zwirn said, he probably could have avoided some of the 135 layoffs the town has made.
"In part, the layoffs are attributed to the failure of revenues to come in," he said. The backlog has also worried the state's title insurance industry, whose trade association, the New York State Land Title Association, won a court order last week demanding that the county comply with state law and record mortgages in a timely fashion.
Mr. McConnell, an elected Republican who has worked in the County Clerk's office since 1947, said that while deeds and mortgages go unrecorded, mortgage lenders are left without any legal claim on properties, theoretically opening the way for another lien to take precedence and leaving the county open to lawsuits.
Mr. Zwirn complained that the slowdown was damaging North Hempstead's credit rating because the town borrowed money against expected revenue that came in short. And it has played havoc with the town's attempts to close out its 1991 fiscal record.
 
Major Source of Revenue
 Both Mr. Zwirn, a Democrat, and Donald P. DeRiggi, a Republican from Glen Cove, said they planned to send local employees to the County Clerk's office to examine the documents and amounts of revenue involved.
"I'm at that point of asking if we can come down there," Mr. DeRiggi said, "and if not process the papers and checks, at least get a sense of how much money we're talking about."
The 1 percent mortgage tax is the single biggest source of revenue for the cities and towns of Nassau County. Half the amount collected goes to the city, town or village in which the house is located, with the rest split between the state-run Metropolitan Transportation Authority and the State of New York Mortgage Association.
Also involved are recording fees that go directly to Nassau County, and transfer taxes that are earmarked for the state.
In a memorandum, the clerk's office calculated that combined fees and taxes deposited during the first two months of this year were $6.3 million, down from $11.5 million in the first two months of last year. Though home sales have dropped in Long Island with the recession, Mr. McConnell said, home refinances and equity loans have kept the volume of paperwork unchanged.
This afternoon, Victor Provenzano, supervisor of the receiving department, tackled three stacks of mortgage papers that came into the office on Dec. 9, 1991, for transactions dating to last fall. He estimated that it took workers two days to get through one box of mortgages, but said they arrived at a rate of two a day.
While Nassau County's lag in recording mortgages and land transfers has been a longtime problem, the budget cuts have brought it to a state of crisis. In a recent letter, Lawrence F. Keeley, acting director of the Transaction and Transfer Tax Bureau of the state Department of Taxation and Finance, reminded the County Clerk of his obligation to promptly remit the real property gains tax and real estate transfer tax.
"I am compelled to write now because by all appearances the situation is progressively getting worse," Mr. Keeley wrote in the Jan. 31 letter. "It is imperative that you take the steps necessary to meet your statutory duty and comply with these legal requirements."
 
Streamlining Measures
 Guy F. Paquin, executive vice president of the New York State Land Title Association, said the backlog left title insurers vulnerable legally. "When an intervening lien can take priority over a mortgage, the bank can find itself in second instead of first place with its mortgage on a property," he said.
Robert J. McDonald, chief deputy in the office of the County Executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, said he had been looking into ways to streamline the operation of the County Clerk's office.
He said that in the future, only one employee would check each paper that came in, rather than three or four, and that the county would stop providing time-consuming services that it is not legally required to perform. For example, he said, it would no longer match deeds against tax maps to check the boundaries of properties purchased.
"We're not going to be able to serve up the whipped cream and the cherry -- just the dish of ice cream," he said.
He said he hoped the new procedures would ease the backlog within the next few weeks.

HEADLINE: Clinton in Driver's Seat;
Nomination Now Seems to Be His to Lose, But Foes Still Hope He Trips in New York

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, March 17

 BODY:
The double-barreled Midwestern showdown put Bill Clinton in the fast lane toward the Democratic Presidential nomination today and left Paul E. Tsongas and Edmund G. Brown Jr. to squabble over which one could better pick up the pieces if Mr. Clinton should crash.
Unless he spins out of the race, it will be hard to deny Mr. Clinton the rest of the delegates he needs, because the proportional system awards large blocks of votes to both winners and runners-up. It will be all but impossible to overtake him if he can keep putting together broad biracial coalitions like the ones that swept him to victory last week and this, in the Sun Belt and Rust Belt alike.
New York's Democratic primary on April 7 now takes on fresh meaning. After Mr. Clinton's triumphs by thumping margins in both Michigan and Illinois, it may offer the last chance for his challengers to stop him.
"It's almost a done deal," said John Marino, the New York Democratic chairman, who often expresses the viewpoint of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.
The nagging questions about Mr. Clinton's personal life, most recently his financial affairs and those of his wife, Hillary, probably represent a larger threat to the Arkansas Governor's progress than rival candidates do. They are trying to convince people that he is not electable, and in the meantime they are staying in the contest in the hope that some new revelation will bring him down.
 
Hoping for a Stumble
 "Every morning Bill Clinton gets out of bed," said a senior figure in the Tsongas campaign, "he faces the possibility of some media disaster unfolding that day. We would be fools to get out at this point. You stay in, you soldier on, you try to remain a constructive alternative, so if . . . "
President Bush held Patrick J. Buchanan to only a quarter of the vote in Illinois and Michigan as the Republican protest continued to fade. Mr. Buchanan's purse is almost empty, to judge from his small-scale television campaign in Michigan, and he now plans to cut back his campaign, bypassing most tests to concentrate on the June 2 California primary. He hopes he can lay the groundwork there for a conservative crusade in 1996.
That approach amounts to a concession that the President is going to be nominated again and clears the way for Mr. Bush to be more Presidential. He spent Election Day in Clinton-land, traveling to Bentonville, Ark., to present a medal to Sam Walton, the retailing wizard, and talking about the American dream instead of chasing votes.
Next Friday, the deadline Mr. Bush has set for Congressional approval of his economic package, will pass, giving him the opportunity to redefine himself as the implacable foe of a do-nothing opposition Congress, a role that won President Harry S. Truman a lot of votes in 1948.
But Mr. Bush still has plenty of problems. In Illinois, a state that has gone with the winner in nine of the last 10 Presidential elections, a Chicago Tribune poll last week showed Mr. Clinton beating him, and Mr. Tsongas, the former Massachusetts Senator, tying him. It indicates that only a third of the electorate thinks he can solve the nation's economic problems.
There were also strong rumblings of anti-incumbent feelings in Illinois, and they cannot have cheered the President much. Senator Alan J. Dixon and Representative Gus Savage were beaten, while Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the hitherto untouchable chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, had to resort to heavy advertising for the first time in his career to pull out a victory.
A lot will change between now and November, of course. But in swing states like this, Mr. Bush must find a way to convince people that he is not an economic klutz. He needs most desperately to find the formula among the blue-collar voters of various Eastern European ethnic groups who for the last five or six elections have backed Republicans for President.
In Michigan, where there are large numbers of such "Reagan Democrats," he has a very long way to go; a Detroit News poll last week found that 94 percent of Democrats, an unheard-of majority, had lost faith in his economic stewardship. The task may well be beyond Mr. Bush or any President. Many of the jobs lost in the recession that has devastated the American automobile industry have probably been lost forever, which is a politically unspeakable truth.
 
Credibility for Brown
 That kind of weakness in an incumbent makes Democratic politicians keen for the hunt. In normal circumstances, they would be closing ranks around Mr. Clinton, judging him a big winner after his 10 victories in two weeks. But they are not; they are worrying about Mr. Clinton's vulnerability in the general election, a vulnerability that encourages the claims of the also-rans.
For the moment, Mr. Brown has the better of the argument, in terms of credibility if not delegates, in which he trails Mr. Tsongas. The former California Governor's advantage results from his strong second-place finish in Michigan, an economically devastated industrial state where he demonstrated strong appeal to union members and ethnic voters.
It was by far his best showing in a major contested primary.
Mr. Brown plans to take his low-cost insurgent campaign to all the remaining industrial states, and his fund-raising has improved to the point where he was able, for the first time this year, to run a television commercial in Michigan. He is building toward the California primary, but he is also talking about putting together a permanent reform movement.
 
Dismaying for Tsongas
 A third-party candidacy cannot be ruled out, in the view of some Democrats who have watched Mr. Brown turn himself almost overnight into a populist evangelist denouncing big business, free trade, high taxes and the kind of opulently financed campaigns that he once specialized in.
Mr. Tsongas finished second in Illinois. Mr. Brown made little effort here, but Mr. Tsongas apparently still failed utterly to sell himself to any significant number of blacks or blue-collar whites.
The actual figures in polls of voters leaving the booths today were dismaying for the Tsongas camp. In Illinois and Michigan, only about 1 black voter in 10 backed Mr. Tsongas. Likewise with blue-collar voters; Mr. Tsongas won only 1 in 10 in Michigan, only 2 in 10 in Illinois.
Granting the former Senator's strength among independents, well-educated technocrats and suburbanites -- all of whom are important in building an eventual majority coalition -- it is hard to see how he can win in November, if nominated, unless he can greatly broaden his appeal.
 
Eyes Toward New England
 But Connecticut, back in Mr. Tsongas's native New England, is the next primary test, followed by Vermont a week later and New York (plus Wisconsin and Kansas) a week after that. The former Massachusetts Senator has enough money to carry on that long, aides say, and try to restart his effort by reaching out to less well-off voters.
Ted van Dyk, who has signed on as an adviser to Mr. Tsongas in the last few days, conceded that a failure in New York would dry up the flow of dollars quickly. Still, said Mr. van Dyk, a longtime political strategist, "It will take Bill months to get an absolute majority of delegates, and there's at least a 50-50 chance, in my mind, that he'll be blown out of the water before he accomplishes that."
Many members of the Democratic establishment welcome Mr. Tsongas's determination to persevere, and some welcome Mr. Brown's searing attacks on Mr. Clinton.
But Jody Powell, who was President Jimmy Carter's press secretary and helped plan the strategy of his two Presidential races, said the party would be "much better off getting things settled early," so it could turn its attention to President Bush.
Senator Paul Simon of Illinois, himself a candidate for President four years ago, urged party leaders tonight to fall in behind Mr. Clinton.
 
 The Feb. 26 article also referred incorrectly to an Op-Ed page article written by Mr. Van Dyk about Mr. Tsongas. The article appeared in The Los Angeles Times, not The Washington Post.

HEADLINE: F.A.A. Warns Port Authority On Transit Links to Airports

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG

 BODY:
The Federal Aviation Administration is threatening to block plans to build mass-transit links to the metropolitan region's three main airports unless the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey abandons efforts to strengthen jet-noise restrictions at the airports.
For months, the F.A.A. has been trying to discourage the Port Authority from taking a tougher stand on noise at the airports than the Federal agency demands, but it has made little headway. In linking the mass-transit plan to the noise-control dispute, the aviation agency is hoping to bolster its position. 
 At stake for the authority is a $2 billion plan to build a network of airport rail links to Kennedy, La Guardia and Newark Airports. Planners have long sought the links to relieve automobile congestion, a critical component of the airports' economic viability.
 
A Passenger Tax
 The F.A.A.'s weapon against the Port Authority is its power to reject a $3 passenger tax that would be levied on airline tickets to finance the mass-transit plan. The authority said yesterday that it could not construct the mass-transit links without the money from the passenger tax, which is expected to generate $100 million a year.
At stake for the Federal agency is its attempt to protect the airlines from having to quickly scrap or refurbish older, noisier aircraft. The F.A.A. has its own noise rules for airports, which would use a slower method of phasing out such aircraft than the Port Authority is proposing.
After the dispute had been at a standoff for months, an F.A.A. official stepped up the fight with the Port Authority last week, writing the authority to say that its proposal for noise regulations could cause Federal officials to reject the $3 passenger charge.
Michael C. Moffett, the official who wrote the letter, said the Port Authority's rules, which have yet to be proposed to its board, "might well be found" in violation of Federal regulations. Under those regulations, Federal officials said yesterday, the F.A.A. can reject an airport's application for a tax on passengers if the airport is deemed not to be following Federal noise rules. The F.A.A. would contend that by imposing stricter rules, the Port Authority was not following the Federal rules.
"We once again urge the Port Authority to move off a course that will inevitably lead to costly legal confrontation," wrote Mr. Moffett, the assistant administrator for policy, planning and international aviation at the F.A.A. in Washington.
 
'Incensed' Over Link
 David Z. Plavin, the Port Authority's director of aviation, responded in a letter on Tuesday saying that he was "incensed that you would choose to link the approval of our passenger facility charge" with the proposed noise restrictions.
Federal law allows the authority to impose the tax on passengers with the permission of the F.A.A. The Port Authority applied on Feb. 28 for permission to levy such a tax.
Under the Federal Airport Noise and Capacity Act of 1990, the airlines must gradually phase out or upgrade the noisiest aircraft in their fleets -- including the 727 and DC-9 -- over the next 10 years. As they reach each of several deadlines set for throughout the decade, the airlines must bring an increasing percentage of their fleets into compliance.
Under the Port Authority's rules, the airlines would have to cut down on the actual number of noisy planes that arrive at and depart from the region's airports. The authority's rules also seek to speed up the Federal schedule for compliance.
 
Complaints From Neighbors
 Port Authority officials said they do not believe that the Federal rules would have much of an impact on New York and New Jersey, which have a disproportionately high number of noisy flights. The officials said their tougher rules were in response to the complaints of the airports' neighbors.
But in his letter to the authority, Mr. Moffett said the Port Authority's rules would have "potentially severe economic and operational impacts throughout the national air transportation system." He estimated the rules could cost the airlines in excess of $1 billion and might increase the noise problems in other cities, thereby undermining the national effort outlined in the 1990 law.
John M. Meenan, the assistant general counsel of the Air Transport Association of America, an industry trade group, said his organization was flatly opposed to the authority's proposed rules, which he said would add to the airlines' costs when they are financially strapped.
The chairman of the Port Authority, Richard C. Leone, said the agency would continue to solicit comment on the rules and would not bring a proposal to its board of commissioners until May, at the earliest.
"We would like to work with the F.A.A., the airlines and the community groups to come up with a proposal that everyone can live with," Mr. Leone said. "We don't want to have to resort to a political or legal battle. I don't know if that's possible."
 
Other Improvements
 F.A.A. officials said they had until the summer to review the Port Authority's application for the $3 tax, which would be collected by the airlines on the tickets of departing passengers and then forwarded to the authority. In addition to mass transit, the Port Authority said it would use revenue from the tax to pay for other access improvements at the airports.
Plans for the mass-transit links to the three airports are in their infancy, and no routes, timetables or costs have been made final. In one proposal, which has been endorsed by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York, a $1.6 billion light-rail line would connect Kennedy and La Guardia Airports with the subway and the Long Island Rail Road in Queens. A similar rail line would connect Newark Airport with mass transit in Newark and would cost an estimated $400 million to $500 million.
Carl E. Van Horn, policy director for Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey, said the Governor supports the Port Authority on both the noise and mass-transit issues.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Connecticut;
Clinton Taking the Campaign to Tsongas Turf: Connecticut Is Looming as Vital Battleground

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, March 18

 BODY:
Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, fresh from decisive victories Tuesday in Illinois and Michigan, laid the groundwork today for his campaign in Connecticut, the backyard of Paul E. Tsongas, which is reeling from the effects of the depressed economy.
Mr. Tsongas, badly battered by a second-place finish in Illinois and a third-place effort in Michigan, raised the stakes for himself today. The former Massachusetts Senator proclaimed at a news conference in Hartford that Connecticut was now a "must win" state for him. 
 Just weeks ago, Mr. Tsongas was heavily favored in the Democratic contest here, and such a statement would have seemed far-fetched. But the combination punch in the two Rust Belt states clearly enlivened the March 24 Connecticut primary.
While Mr. Clinton and most of his staff spent the day in Little Rock for some rest and reassessment, they pointedly noted that Mr. Tsongas was already back in New England -- with all the advantages of operating on home turf.
 
Rally Hastily Arranged
 Behind the scenes, however, Mr. Clinton's staff began a television advertising campaign this afternoon, going head to head with Mr. Tsongas's advertisements in the Hartford television market. And a rally was hastily organized for Thursday night in downtown Hartford, where Mr. Clinton plans to appear.
Edmund G. Brown Jr., who fought his way to a second-place finish behind Mr. Clinton in Michigan on Tuesday, arrived in Connecticut tonight for at least three scheduled campaign stops over the next six days. So far, there has been little if any speculation that the former California Governor will finish higher than third. But he tapped the bitterness of anxious blue-collar workers in Michigan, and Mr. Tsongas cannot afford to count him out in Connecticut, particularly in areas hit hard by unemployment.
Across this diverse, depressed state of blue-collar factory towns, white-collar office parks, distressed cities and slumping military contractors, the signals were subtle but unmistakable: Mr. Tsongas was in the spotlight and looking vulnerable.
Speaking of Mr. Tsongas, Jonathan Pelto, a Democratic strategist, said. "Two weeks ago, I would have given him 60 percent to 70 percent of the vote." Mr. Pelto, who managed Gary Hart's Connecticut campaigns in 1984 and 1987, said the "conventional wisdom" still calls for a Tsongas victory but by a far narrower margin.
Such is the delicate position Mr. Tsongas now finds himself just weeks before the far more expensive and delegate-heavy New York primary on April 7. On the other hand, if Mr. Clinton declares a full assault in Connecticut and loses, Mr. Tsongas would get an even bigger lift by appearing to fight off a determined challenge.
Campaign coordinators for Mr. Clinton said on Tuesday, before their candidate's primary victories in Michigan in Illinois were certain, that he would make perhaps one appearance in Connecticutbefore the primary there. And a Clinton news release called Mr. Tsongas "heavily favored" as a regional candidate.
But today a Clinton campaign spokesman, Craig Sutherland, said Mr. Clinton's Connecticut effort would now include at least three appearances. Television advertising in the Hartford market was also bought today, with the possibility of more to come, although Mr. Sutherland emphasized that the Connecticut campaign budget was still "very, very small."
"Next week we hope to move into our neighbor's yard," Mr. Sutherland said.
Mr. Tsongas has also stumbled -- to Mr. Clinton's benefit, and perhaps Mr. Brown's as well -- over one of the crucial emotional issues in the state: the Seawolf submarine. Navy contracts for the submarines, built in Groton by the Electric Boat Division of General Dynamics, would be scrapped under President Bush's military budget and under many of the plans put forward by Democrats in Congress. The result would be thousands of layoffs over the next decade in the southeastern corner of the state.
Mr. Clinton has said he thinks it is possible to maintain submarine-building capacity in Connecticut -- a stance that Mr. Tsongas attacked last weekend as "pandering" and misleading to a state that must face the facts that the Seawolf is doomed under almost any post-cold war scenario. The result is what a Tsongas campaign spokesman called the "mistaken perception" that Mr. Tsongas is against even trying to save the Seawolf.
"Seawolf is going to be the litmus test," said Ernest Kulka, an electronics technician from Torrington who came to see Mr. Tsongas at a rally in Hartford on Tuesday night at Trinity College. But Mr. Kulka said he was not sure whom that would help or hurt. "When Clinton gets down there, you're going to see a lot of waffling," he predicted.
Mr. Clinton has also allied a formidable array of powerful Democratic endorsements here, including those of the former state party chairman, John F. Droney Jr., and Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, who appeared at Mr. Clinton's side in Chicago on Tuesday. Speculation began flying immediately that Mr. Lieberman was being groomed as a possible running mate.
 
A Dull G.O.P. Contest
 Mr. Tsongas said today it sound more like the rumor of the week. "It's a good strategy -- there were stories about Mayor Daley last week," he said, referring to Mayor Richard M. Daley of Chicago.
So far, the Republican primary seems to be conforming to the expectations of dullness. Neither President Bush nor Vice President Dan Quayle has any campaign appearances planned, and the Republican challengers on the ballot, the conservative columnist Patrick J. Buchanan and the former Ku Klux Klan leader David Duke, have little or no formal organizations to get supporters out to the polls.
The main issue in that race, politicians in both parties say, is how many people vote against Mr. Bush out of protest, and where they are concentrated, with the Seawolf country of southeastern Connecticut again considered ripe for a statement of outrage. Given Mr. Bush's roots here -- his father, Prescott Bush, was a United States Senator from Connecticut -- the standard of failure is pretty low by some measures.
The state Democratic party chairman, Edward L. Marcus, said he thought a 15 percent protest would be significant in Connecticut, where Democrats outnumber Republicans, but where Republicans and independents have combined their votes to give the Republican candidate victory in the state in every Presidential election since Richard M. Nixon won in 1972.
