HEADLINE: U.N. Sending Envoy to Aid Burmese Refugees

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, March 18

 BODY:
The United Nations Secretary General plans to send an envoy to Southeast Asia early next month in an effort to stop the expulsion of the Muslim minority from Myanmar, formerly Burma, to neighboring Bangladesh, diplomats and United Nations officials said today.
The envoy, Under Secretary General Jan Eliasson of Sweden, the senior United Nations official in charge of humanitarian aid, is expected to travel first to Bangladesh to inspect the growing number of Burmese refugees arriving there. 
 If Myanmar's military rulers will receive him, he will then seek to persuade them to stop persecuting the Muslim Rohingyas, as they are called, living in Arakan province. He will also try to get the junta to take back the more than 150,000 who have fled to Bangladesh since October, apparently to escape a campaign of torture, killing and forced evictions by the Burmese Army.
The refugees, who are living in makeshift encampments along the border, are continuing to arrive at a rate of 5,000 to 6,000 a day, Bangladeshi diplomats say. Arakan province is thought to have a population of about 2.2 million, of whom some 1.4 million are Muslims.
The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees has appealed for $27.5 million in emergency aid for the Burmese refugees.
Myanmar's military rulers have shown themselves impervious to outside criticism in recent months. Both the United Nations General Assembly and the Human Rights Commission in Geneva have adopted resolutions criticizing what they see as the Government's flagrant abuse of human rights.
And the five members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations -- Thailand, Singapore, the Philippines, Indonesia and Brunei -- have also sought unsuccessfully to bring about a change of policy by quiet persuasion.
Western diplomats now say they hope China, which is one of the few countries with ties to Myanmar's increasingly isolated leadership, may also be able to use its influence to obtain a change of policy.
Myanmar's junta maintains that the Rohingyas are not ethnic Burmese and asserts that those fleeing to Bangladesh are really illegal immigrants without official identity papers. But many of those crossing the border say the army forcibly confiscated their papers before expelling them.
"The army seems to be following a policy of Burmization in Arakan by ridding the province of its Muslims," Bangladesh's United Nations representative, Humayan Kabir, said. Most of Myanmar's people are Buddhist.
In 1978, Burma forced about 200,000 Rohingyas out of Arakan into Bangladesh but was eventually persuaded to take most back.
In a new display of Congressional anger with Myanmar's military rulers, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee last week attached conditions to the confirmation of Parker W. Borg, a Foreign Service officer, as next United States Ambassador to Myanmar.
The committee recommended that the full Senate delay formal approval of Mr. Borg's appointment until the Bush Administration states publicly that the military junta does not represent the Burmese people, withdraws the American military attache from Myanmar and supports an arms embargo against the country as well a suspension of all United Nations aid.
At the same time as it seeks to dislodge the Rohingyas from Arakan in the west of the country, the Burmese Army is stepping up its offensive against rebels from the Karen tribe in eastern Myanmar who are fighting for independence from bases just inside Thailand, Asian diplomats say.
Myanmar's international reputation has been in sharp decline since 1990 when the military junta, which had taken power in 1988, organized elections and then refused to hand over the Government to Daw Aung Sang Suu Kyi after her opposition party won a sweeping victory. Mrs. Aung Sang Suu Kyi, who was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize last year, is under house arrest in the capital, Yangon, formerly Rangoon.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Media;
CLINTON STRATEGY TO DEFUSE RUMORS

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, March 18

 BODY:
The Clinton campaign, concerned that questions about the candidate's character could be the last remaining hurdle to his nomination, is taking a number of steps to try to defuse the issue before the April 7 New York primary.
Throughout the campaign, the Arkansas Governor's aides have assembled notebooks full of background information on competitors like Paul E. Tsongas, Bob Kerrey, Edmund G. Brown Jr. and President Bush. Now, they are trying to face down their most critical enemy: rumors about Bill Clinton himself. 
 As part of that strategy, some aides have recently shown reporters a statement from a former Miss America denying that she had an affair with the Governor. The denial came from the Clinton campaign even before nude photographs of the woman, Elizabeth Ward, were to be published in the May issue of Playboy magazine. Speculation about the content of the Playboy layout has been part of the undercurrents within the Clinton campaign in recent weeks.
A spokeswoman for Playboy would not confirm the contents of the upcoming issue, which will be on newsstands April 7 -- the same day as the New York primary -- but she said, "I can confirm to you it is not harmful to Clinton."
Top Clinton aides have already had an advance look at the Playboy magazine feature on Ms. Ward.
 
Sex Allegations
 Ms. Ward was one of five women alleged to have had sexual relations with Mr. Clinton in a civil suit filed in September 1990 against Mr. Clinton by a disgruntled former employee of the state government. The man who filed the suit has since withdrawn it, saying he had no evidence, and four of the women have denied any relationship. The fifth, Gennifer Flowers, sold her story of an affair to a supermarket tabloid this year.
Governor Clinton has denied having had an affair with any of the women.
As devised by campaign aides, the move to deal with any rumors about the Playboy feature is part of a broader effort to dominate the news with positive campaign developments and to knock down persistent speculation that some future scandal could derail Mr. Clinton's drive for the nomination.
"New York media is a monster," said James Carville, a Clinton strategist. "You have to feed it every day, and you have to feed them cheeseburgers and french fries, not just lettuce."
Another element of the news media strategy involves having Mr. Clinton directly confront the question of whether there is some damaging information yet to come.
On television today, Mr. Clinton said there would be "no debilitating disclosure" that would be revealed as true that would "make me unfit to be President."
In an interview, Mr. Clinton elaborated on his theme that his substantial primary election successes have proved that the press and his political rivals are more interested in questions about his past than voters are.
 
Call for 'Higher Standard'
 "Of all the states in the country, New York ought not to want another campaign where the personal destruction of the candidate is the centerpiece of the campaign," Mr. Clinton said in an interview. "With all the stories of the kids' being shot and black kids painted white and white kids assaulted in retaliation, all the real heartbreak. The real human suffering and loss ought to call the people of New York to a higher standard. And I think it will."
Even before securing victories in Illinois and Michigan this week, Clinton strategists were preparing for what they expect to be a barrage of negative attention by setting plans in motion to consistently present positive images based on his appeal for economic revival and racial unity.
By stopping rumors before they begin and by anticipating the needs of an event-hungry New York press corps, the Clinton campaign has already sketched out a schedule that will take Mr. Clinton around the state stressing that New York voters have more pressing issues to worry about than rumors about Mr. Clinton.
In recent days, Mr. Clinton has also started sending another message, often from the pulpits of churches. No person, he has said, should be asked to meet a standard of perfection.
"When your pastor said I was not perfect, I started to say 'Amen' and stand up and lead a shout," Mr. Clinton said after being introduced warmly at a Baptist church here on Sunday. "This is a place not for saints, but a place for sinners."
Mr. Clinton said in the interview that he expected voters in New York to be drawn to a candidate who "would lay it all on the line and make a real commitment.
"I think that rough and tumble politics is nothing new to New York," he said. "So if I take a few more blows there, it won't surprise them. They've been watching it all unfold anyway."
A core group of Clinton advisers, enhanced by a New York lawyer, Susan Thomases, and Mr. Clinton's state campaign manager, Harold Ickes, are convinced their strategy will allow the Arkansas Governor to pick his way around potential minefields.
"This is not a bunch of hayseeds coming to New York," said Stan Greenberg, Mr. Clinton's poll taker.
"Bill Clinton is the story," Mr. Greenberg said. "The issue is, do we become Bill Clinton the story as the tabloids try to write it, or do we become Bill Clinton the story about trying to change the nation?"

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Voters;
Primaries Drawing Fewer Blacks as Overall Turnout Declines

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, March 18

 BODY:
Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas picked up about three-quarters of the black vote in Tuesday's Democratic primary in Illinois, but the black turnout in this state was much lower than it was four years ago.
That has been the case in much of the country this year, and Democrats will be hurt in November if blacks continue to stay away from the polls. 
 In part, the falloff in black voting in this year's primaries reflects an overall trend of decreased voter participation, which has occurred in nearly two-thirds of the party primaries in 13 states. But the decline among blacks also clearly happened because no black candidate was in contention the way the Rev. Jesse Jackson was in 1988, said Sonia R. Jarvis, executive director of the National Coalition on Black Voter Participation in Washington.
She added that it was perhaps more important that none of the Democrats generated enthusiasm in black neighborhoods or conducted aggressive drives to get out the vote. While Mr. Clinton's success in winning endorsements from black politicians kept his percentage of the black vote high, it did not mean that large numbers of blacks were turning out for him, she said.
 
November May Be Different
 A survey of people as they left the polling places on Tuesday found that 19 percent who voted in the Illinois Democratic primary were black, while four years ago 28 percent were. In Georgia two weeks ago, a similar survey showed a 29 percent of the voters in the Democratic primary were black, down from 35 percent in 1988. In Tennessee last week, 13 percent were black, down from 27 percent four years ago.
The polls were conducted by Voter Research and Surveys, which was created 1990 by ABC News, CBS News, CNN and NBC News, and those for Illinois and Michigan had a margin of error of plus or minus three to four percentage points.
While most states are seeing fewer black voters and fewer voters over all in the primaries than they did in 1988, Curtis Gans, director of the Committee for the Study of the American Electorate, said that if history was a guide, the low turnout in the primaries this year said little about the size and nature of the turnout in November. For example, the high black turnout in the 1988 primaries was not replicated in the general election, and that worked to the serious disadvantage of the Democratic candidate, Michael S. Dukakis.
This year the number of primary voters for both parties has been lower than it was in 1988 in 17 of 26 party primaries, and in many cases the difference has been significant. In Florida, for example, turnout last week was down by 60,000 from 1988, even though the number of people of voting age has increased by about one million. In Texas, the turnout was down nearly one-fifth to 2.3 million from 2.8 million, and in Louisiana, it fell by a third, to 515,000 from 770,000.
Looked at another way, 19 percent of Floridians of voting age voted in this year's primaries, while 23 percent did so in 1988; in Texas, the participation was down to 18 percent from 23 percent.
The main exception to the rule was New Hampshire, where the turnout was more than one-fifth higher than it was in 1988. In Illinois, despite the drop in the number of blacks voting, the overall turnout was about the same as it was four years ago.
 
Boost From the Undercard
 Turnout varies enormously from state to state, and the reasons are often difficult to come by. This week, for instance, 15 percent of the people in Michigan of voting age went to the polls, while 27 percent did so in Illinois. In 1988, Michigan did not hold a Presidential primary.
The record high voter participation in the New Hampshire primary apparently was mainly a result of the flagging economy there and the desire of voters to register their protest about it. Furthermore, because the Iowa caucuses were not seriously contested this year, the candidates spent more time campaigning in New Hampshire than was the case in 1988.
In Illinois, the relatively solid turnout was probably the result of several tight Congressional races, including the three-way fight for the Democratic Senate nomination. Senator Alan J. Dixon, running for his third term, was defeated by Carol Moseley Braun, the Cook County Recorder of Deeds.
Primary turnouts have fallen consistently since 1972, said Mr. Gans of the Committee for the Study of the American Electorate who has conducted extensive research on voting participation. The main reason, Mr. Gans said, is that no cutting issue has distinguished the candidates in the primaries from one another.
"Take this year," said Mr. Gans. "The differences between the Democrats is minuscule compared with, say, the differences over the war in Vietnam in 1972."
As a general principle, he said, "you get high turnouts when people have something to decide."
For example, Louisiana had a record turnout for a Senate race in 1990 when Senator J. Bennett Johnston, a Democrat, was challenged by the former Ku Klux Klan leader David Duke. And North Carolina also set a record that year when Senator Jesse Helms, the extremely conservative Republican, ran against Harvey Gantt, the former Democratic Mayor of Charlotte, who is black.
In the same vein, Mr. Gans said, a high rate of voter participation can be expected in the Presidential race in November if the economy stays sour. But if the economy improves noticeably, he said, more people are likely to stay home out of a lack of interest.
In recent years nationwide, about 20 percent of eligible voters have turned out for Presidential primaries, as against about 50 percent in general elections.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Congress;
The Rumble of Discontent Rattles Illinois Incumbents

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 18

 BODY:
The Illinois primary blew a chill breeze over Congressional incumbents today as a Senator and two Representatives were beaten by challengers and two veteran House members survived with some difficulty.
There was an expected pattern of anti-incumbent voting in the Chicago area, fanned by last week's public disclosures that 355 current and former House members had written thousands of overdrafts on the House bank. In that clouded political air, three Democrats -- Senator Alan J. Dixon and Representatives Charles A. Hayes and Gus Savage -- were defeated. And Representatives Dan Rostenkowski, a Democrat, and Philip M. Crane, a Republican, won with less than three-fifths of the vote. 
 The House bank scandal had an obvious effect on only one race, the defeat of Mr. Hayes. After it was disclosed that Mr. Hayes had written 716 overdrafts in 39 months, the five-term incumbent was defeated by Alderman Bobby Rush, a former Black Panther leader, in his Congressional district on Chicago's South Side.
Being one of the House's leading writers of overdrafts appeared to tip the balance against Mr. Hayes in a race that was already close. Mr. Rush got 42 percent of the vote to 39 percent for Mr. Hayes. For Mr. Rush, the victory marked a new level of acceptance in his journey from militant opponent of the white power structure in the 1960's to South Side Alderman in 1983 to deputy chairman of the state Democratic Party two years ago.
 
Danger of Not Looking Ahead
 Don Foley, executive director of the Democratic Senate Campaign Committee, said he thought the bank issue could "spill over" into other races even if it bore no direct connection to a vulnerable incumbent. He said the scandal, which has stoked the anger of a recession-weary public, could strengthen a "sense of frustration that nothing is being done in Washington" about the nation's problems while lawmakers worry about themselves.
Mr. Foley said the Illinois results also underscored the fact that if incumbents dwelt on their records rather than conveyed some vision of what they planned to do, they took a grave risk. In the Senate race, he said, the incumbent was so preoccupied defending himself against the $3 million television campaign waged by Albert Hofeld, a lawyer, that "I'm not sure Dixon ever got to talk about the future."
In the end, both were defeated by Carol Moseley Braun, the Cook County Recorder of Deeds who entered the race against Mr. Dixon after he voted to confirm Clarence Thomas to the Supreme Court last fall. If she wins in November against Richard S. Williamson, a conservative former assistant secretary of state who was recruited to run in the Republican primary, she would be the first black woman to serve in the Senate.
Largely overlooked, and treated civilly by the other two candidates, Ms. Braun plainly profited from their attacks on one another. With 99 percent of the precincts reporting, she had 538,496 votes, or 38 percent. Mr. Dixon had 495,577, or 35 percent, and Mr. Hofeld had 389,624, or 27 percent.
But the bulk of Washington's attention was fixed on the state's House races, although analysis was complicated by redistricting. Illinois lost 2 of its 22 seats. The new lines were drawn to discomfit Democrats, forcing one Democratic retirement and two races between Democratic incumbents.
 
Turmoil of Redistricting
 Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader, said the Illinois returns showed once again that "incumbents have to fight to gain re-election." He said that even before Tuesday's results, "Anyone who didn't understand that was not in the real world."
But in fact only one incumbent had been denied renomination before Tuesday. She was Representative Beverly B. Byron, a seven-term Maryland Democrat who traveled widely for the House Armed Services Committee and apparently lost touch with her district, taking too lightly a challenge from Thomas A. Hattery, a State Representaive who upset her March 3.
The other incumbent who was upset, Mr. Savage, suffered a resounding defeat that plainly exceeded any possible impact of the bank scandal. Redistricting, however, was critical. Melvin J. Reynolds, a businessman who had challenged Mr. Savage twice before, won the race 59,243 votes to 34,717, piling up almost all of his winning margin in the enlarged suburban section of the district.
Mr. Reynolds said his victory over the six-term Congressman was a message to all politicians not to run on racial themes. He had attacked Mr. Savage as being hostile to whites and particularly Jews. Mr. Savage explained his defeat by saying, "We have lost to the white racist press and to the racist reactionary Jewish misleaders." Both candidates are black.
 
Not Business as Usual
 Mr. Rostenkowski, with 57 percent, and Mr. Crane, with 55 percent, had closer challenges than most political analysts had expected, and Chicago experts attributed those results to the revised districts that brought each man before many new voters, to antagonism from voters who disliked their anti-abortion stands and to distaste over the bank scandal. But the veteran lawmakers, respectively the chairman and third-ranking Republican on the Ways and Means Committee, prevailed over their much lesser-known challengers.
The anger against an image of business as usual in Washington prevailed even in the two contests pitting Democratic incumbents.
In a district spreading from Chicago into its southwestern suburbs, Representative William O. Lipinski prevailed with 58 percent over Representative Marty Russo after attacking him as a deal maker on the Ways and Means committee. But the fact that much of Mr. Lipinski's old district was in the new one helped, too.
In Southeastern Illinois, a heavily outspent Representative Glenn Poshard got 62 percent of the vote against Representative Terry L. Bruce after taking issue with his refusal to accept contributions from political action committees.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Primaries;
Brown and Tsongas Search For Victory in Connecticut

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr.

 BODY:
More in hope than in expectation, Paul E. Tsongas and Edmund G. Brown Jr. began a dogged pursuit of votes in Connecticut yesterday, following a pair of decisive defeats at the hands of Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas in the Midwest on Tuesday.
Both hope they can use the Connecticut primary next Tuesday as a political trampoline to gain some energy for the big event, the New York primary two weeks later, which may be their last chance to halt Mr. Clinton's powerful progress toward the Democratic nomination. Confident, almost cocky, the Clinton entourage holed up in Little Rock, Ark., for rest and reassessment, and the front-runner will not arrive in Connecticut until late this afternoon.. 
 But defeating Mr. Clinton in New York, another industrial state with many similarities to Michigan and Illinois, will not be easy. And Ronald H. Brown, the Democratic chairman, said that if Mr. Clinton could win in New York, with its 244 convention delegates, second only to California's, it would be time to think about "rallying around our eventual nominee."
 
Buchanan Staying In
 In a sense, that process began yesterday in the Republican Party. Patrick J. Buchanan, President Bush's conservative challenger, said that "only celestial intervention" could block Mr. Bush's renomination. He pledged to tone down his criticism, drop negative television commercials and support the President in the fall.
But the pugnacious former White House speech writer, who has lost 16 straight primaries to Mr. Bush, did not quite drop out. He said he would "show the flag" on a one-day trip to Connecticut and then concentrate on North Carolina, which votes May 5, and California, which votes June 2. By then -- in fact, by April 28, the date of the Pennsylvania primary -- Mr. Bush is expected to have more than the 1,105 delegates needed for nomination.
Even after the California primary, Mr. Buchanan said at a news conference outside Washington, he intends to press his views at the Republican National Convention, especially in the platform committee. The Bush forces would not "have the guts to kick me out of that convention," he said.
The conversion of the Buchanan campaign into a symbolic quest was an obvious plus for the President, as were the improving economic statistics released on Tuesday. Mr. Bush is also the captain of his own fate, able to shape the fall campaign, to a greater degree than Mr. Clinton, who even if nominated faces the constant danger of fresh, reputation-damaging accusations about his private life.
 
Endangered Incumbents
 As the baton of populist protest passed from Mr. Buchanan to Mr. Brown, who hoisted himself into second place in Michigan on Tuesday by blaming all the country's ills on the rich, Illinois voters threw a scare into Congressional incumbents by ousting a Senator and two Representatives. Two other usually super-safe Representatives, Dan Rostenkowski, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, who is a Democrat, and Philip M. Crane, a prominent Republican conservative from the Chicago suburbs, saw their margins shaved to less than 60 percent.
"We could see historic numbers of members pitched onto the streets this fall," said Robert Beckel, who managed Walter F. Mondale's Presidential campaign in 1984. "And the incumbent-in-chief, George Bush, the stereotypical political professional and Washington insider, has reasons to worry, too."
The House bank fiasco appeared to have doomed Representative Charles A. Hayes, who was listed as having written 716 overdrafts; he lost to Alderman Bobby Rush of Chicago, a former Black Panther. But by contributing to a "throw-the-bums-out" mood, the scandal also hurt Senator Alan J. Dixon, who went down to defeat at the hands of Carol Moseley Braun after 29 consecutive elective victories.
 
Clarence Thomas Factor
 Polls of voters leaving the booths in Illinois suggested that Ms. Braun, who is black, had been greatly helped by support among women and members of minorities who resented the Senate's confirmation of Judge Clarence Thomas for the Supreme Court despite Prof. Anita F. Hill's accusation of sexual harrassment. If such resentment proves lasting and pervasive, it could be bad news for the President, Justice Thomas's champion, especially if combined with an anti-abortion decision this summer when the Supreme Court is expected to rule on a challenge to Roe v. Wade.
Ms. Braun, who would be the first black Democrat and the first black woman to sit in the Senate if elected in November, carried all the Chicago suburbs, where opposition to Justice Thomas appeared to run especially high.
Almost half the Illinois Democratic women interviewed in an exit poll by Voter Research and Surveys, the four-network consortium, said they objected to the confirmation, but only a third of the women said they liked Mr. Dixon, who voted to confirm Justice Thomas.
Ms. Braun and Mr. Dixon, known locally as "Al the Pal" because of his glad-handing ways, split the vote of women who backed confirmation or were not sure, but she beat him better than 2 to 1 among those who opposed confirmation.
The other Representative to lose his seat was Gus Savage, a militant black politician whose habitual diatribes against Jews, whites and the press cost him dearly in new suburban wards added to his previously urban district. Mel Reynolds, a former Rhodes scholar, beat him 2 to 1.
 
Distrust and Disgust
 Although Mr. Bush will no doubt use the bank scandal as a campaign weapon this fall, blaming it on the Democratic leadership in Congress, the issue cuts both ways. He, too, is an incumbent, and therefore at risk with all the others in a climate of distrust and disgust. In addition, several Republican members of Congress, and three former ones who now serve in Mr. Bush's Cabinet, are on the House ethics committee's list of members whose accounts had been overdrawn.
The largest number of House members to be defeated since World War II was 83 in 1948, when President Harry S. Truman successfully campaigned against a "do-nothing, good-for-nothing" Congress. In recent years, the number has remained below 40 and often below 20. Mr. Beckel predicted it would "easily exceed 100 this year."
Tuesday's results contained some suggestions that the Reagan Democrats -- the white, blue-collar voters, mostly Roman Catholics with roots in Southern and Eastern Europe -- were ready to abandon their two-decade flirtation with Republican Presidential candidates and come home.
Exit polls in both Illinois and Michigan showed about 4 of 10 Democrats or independents who voted for Mr. Bush in 1988 voting for Mr. Clinton this time. In Macomb County, north of Detroit, where racial fears had helped convert tens of thousands of conservative, working-class Democrats into Republicans, the Demcratic primary drew almost 10,000 more participants than the Republican primary did.
Burton Yale Pines, a conservative analyst at the Heritage Foundation, said that Mr. Buchanan had "sent up a flame" and could have shown Mr. Bush how to hold the Reagan Democrats, but that the White House had not responded.
"Republican conservatives may not have any place to go other than Bush," Mr. Pines said, "although they can always refuse to vote. But Democratic conservatives, the ones who gave Reagan his landslides, can simply return to their roots. I think that's what will happen, and it might cost George Bush a close election."
With 2,145 delegates needed for nomination, a New York Times tally shows Mr. Clinton with 991, or 46 percent, Mr. Tsongas with 423, Mr. Brown with 143 and 563 undetermined. Among Republicans, Mr. Bush has 729 of the 1,105 he needs, or 66 percent, Mr. Buchanan has 46 and 6 are undetermined.
 
Weak Third
 Mr. Tsongas was grievously wounded by the returns on Tuesday night, because he had called Illinois and Michigan the neutral turf where he could respond to Mr. Clinton's show of strength in his home region on Super Tuesday. The former Massachusetts Senator was not able even to finish second in both states, falling to a weak third in Michigan behind the resurgent Mr. Brown.
The problem, once again, was Mr. Tsongas's inability to attract blue-collar workers and blacks. That could hurt him badly in Connecticut, which his managers described as a state he must win, along with New York. Although he has an advantage through his New England connections, cities like New Britain, New Haven and Hartford have large Italian-American and Irish-American working-class populations. Many of the suburbanites to whom he might otherwise appeal vote Republican in the primaries.
Mr. Clinton is counting on his longstanding ties to the state, where he attended Yale Law School and met his wife, Hillary. He has the backing of Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, who introduced him at a victory rally in Chicago. And unlike Mr. Tsongas, he has pledged to maintain production of the Seawolf submarine, which the Bush Administration wants to phase out. The $2-billion vessels are built by the Electric Boat division of the General Dynamics Corporation at Groton, Conn.
If Mr. Tsongas can convert his status as the favorite in Connecticut into a big victory, he will then try to capitalize in New York on the antipathy between Mr. Clinton and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.
But that is a thin reed on which to build a Tsongas comeback, and few professionals gave him much chance of surviving New York. Mr. Brown, who campaigned in Wisconsin and Pennsylvania before speaking in New Britain last night, seems to have a somewhat better chance, because he has been doing better with core Democrats and because he needs less money to continue.
That seemed to be the Clinton campaign's judgment, too. George Stephanopoulos, Mr. Clinton's deputy campaign manager, called the former California Governor "a political terrorist" and promised that if he mounted further attacks on Mr. Clinton's character the Arkansas Governor would take the offensive against him, even though he preferred to focus on Mr. Bush.
 
Brown on the Attack
 Unrepentant, Mr. Brown described Mr. Clinton as a member of the political establishment that raised its own pay and bounced its checks. He seemed determined to fulfill the prophecy of Brian Lunde, the former political director of the Democratic National Committee, who said Tuesday night, "This process now becomes a referendum on the front-runner."
But Mr. Brown conceded later that he was very much a long shot for the nomination and said that his real goal was to put together a movement similar to the Rainbow Coalition formed by the Rev. Jesse Jackson as part of his 1988 Presidential bid.
Despite all his combative tactics, despite his anti-boss language, despite his adoption of a light-blue sateen United Auto Workers jacket as a campaign uniform, Mr. Brown could not gain the bulk of the blue-collar or union vote in Michigan. That went to Mr. Clinton, the exit polls showed, but Mr. Brown got the second-largest slice, far ahead of Mr. Tsongas, and it helped to establish him in the spoiler's role for the rest of the campaign.
In Ypsilanti Township, home of the big General Motors plant whose coming closure Mr. Brown seized upon as an example of an economy gone haywire, he took 35 percent of the vote, compared to Mr. Clinton's 46. In Macomb County, the Reagan Democrat stronghold, the figures were 30 and 46.

HEADLINE: Israel Considers Effect of Rebuff by Bush on U.S. Loan Guarantees

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, March 18

 BODY:
Israeli economic planners today began the tough and perhaps painful process of how to rearrange Government spending priorities now that the country's request for $10 billion in United States loan guarantees seems to be dead.
Leading the call for a thorough reassessment was the governor of Israel's central bank, who said that "difficult decisions" lay ahead and that the national budget had to be studied. 
 But the governor, Jacob Frenkel, said that Israel would still look for billions of dollars in overseas loans even though its credit standing is likely to be lowered because it will not be able to count on the American guarantees.
 
Silent on Specifics
 Government officials were almost stonily silent today about what specifically they intended to do next. Although Mr. Frenkel and private economists said that Israelis would have to tighten their belts, probably with a combination of spending cuts and tax increases, the exact nature of the Government's next moves were unclear.
Among the complications it faces is that Israel is at the start of a campaign for June parliamentary elections, not normally a period graced with fiscal rectitude and budget austerity.
Nevertheless, there were no signs that senior officials were in a panic a day after President Bush said he would oppose a Congressional compromise that would have given Israel the loan guarantees but also, to the President's displeasure, would have allowed the Israelis to continue building settlements in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.
While technically the aid package remains alive, it is viewed here as no longer an issue, at least not while Mr. Bush is President and Yitzhak Shamir is Israel's Prime Minister. Both men are running for re-election this year.
 
No Immediate Pressure
 Real financial pressure will not be felt for at least several months, several economists said, although they added that the country did not have the luxury of waiting indefinitely to decide what measures to take.
"The issue is not pressing in terms of months," said Dan Halperin, a former Finance Ministry official who works with an economic consulting concern in Tel Aviv. "But next year's budget has to be shaped differently. Israel will have to take a second look at its priorities."
The American guarantees -- which originally were supposed to be spaced over five years at the rate of $2 billion a year -- had been intended to make it easier for Israel to obtain favorable conditions on money it intends to borrow from private banks and other financial institutions. Ever since it first asked for help a year ago, Israel has characterized it as humanitarian assistance to ease the burden of absorbing hundreds of thousands of Jewish emigres from the former Soviet Union.
One of the many questions facing the Israelis now is how badly they need that $10 billion. The figure was reached on the basis of a projected immigrant flow of 200,000 a year. In recent months that tide has receded to a rate translating into only 60,000 a year.
Mr. Halperin argued that the borrowing needs remains large because Israel still had to contend with the 350,000 Soviet Jews who have already arrived here since mid-1989. It is not just the immediate cash that counts, he and others say, but also the investment and economic growth that would be encouraged.

HEADLINE: Miami Journal;
When a City Newspaper Is the Enemy

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, March 18

 BODY:
Since January, two of this city's most powerful institutions have been engaged in an increasingly bitter war of words. The latest salvo is an advertisement appearing on the sides of dozens of buses here. In bold black letters on a yellow background it says in Spanish: "I don't believe The Herald."
The advertisement, which is also scheduled to appear on billboards, is sponsored by the Cuban American National Foundation, an influential Miami-based lobbying group that says it speaks on behalf of more than one million Cuban-Americans who want to see Communism ousted from their former homeland. 
 The target of the group's ire is The Miami Herald, the largest newspaper in Florida and, to some Cuban exiles here, a symbol of liberal Anglo establishment.
Although The Herald has been a consistent critic of Fidel Castro's Communist regime, the foundation questions the newspaper's devotion to the cause and treats any skepticism of its own policies and activities as a slur against all Cuban-Americans. Not surprisingly, that attitude awakens deep passions in a city whose political and economic life is now dominated by Cuban-Americans, and in which the distinction between events in Havana and purely local issues has long been blurred.
Over and over again, leaders of the foundation have accused the newspaper of waging a campaign of "unjust harassment" and "distortion and disinformation" against the largest ethnic group in the Miami area. One attack against the paper came in a 4,000-word article published on the op-ed page of The Herald itself.
The Herald has retorted that such accusations, which have coincided with acts of vandalism and threats against its employees, are part of an effort to turn Miami into "a totalitarian society," just like the one from which many Cuban exiles here fled.
The fight began in mid-January, when The Herald published an editorial opposing a bill in Congress that would tighten the American economic embargo of Cuba. On the same day, the newspaper's Spanish-language edition, El Nuevo Herald, carried a column criticizing exile leaders who advocate military action against Cuba but who are unwilling themselves to stir from the comfort and safety of Miami.
Jorge Mas Canosa, chairman of the foundation, quickly took to the city's Spanish-language radio stations to accuse The Herald and its sister paper of "manipulating information just like Granma," the newspaper of the Cuban Communist Party. Mr. Mas Canosa said the papers had allowed themselves to become tools of the Castro regime and intimated that Cuban intelligence agents had infiltrated the staffs of both newspapers.
Mr. Mas Canosa, who has acknowledged harboring presidential ambitions in a post-Castro Cuba and is a powerful force in Republican Party politics here, also urged the editor of El Nuevo Herald and the president of the Miami Herald Publishing Company, both of whom are Cuban-Americans, to resign. The two men should step down, he said, to protest what he called the Herald's "continuous and systematic campaign against Cuban-Americans, their institutions, values, ethics and ideals."
Shortly after Mr. Mas Canosa's first wave of denunciations of The Herald, the paper's publisher, David Lawrence Jr., and both of the Cuban-American executives received an unsigned death threat written in Spanish. In a letter to the Miami police chief, Mr. Lawrence said the newspaper had also received a telephoned bomb threat.
In addition, dozens of the Herald's vending boxes have been vandalized, their coin slots often jammed with gel or glue. Some have been smeared with feces or painted over with Spanish-language graffiti like "comunistas!"
Mr. Lawrence, who has also met with the Federal Bureau of Investigation, has not accused Mr. Mas Canosa of direct responsibility for any of the threats or vandalism. But in a signed column last month, he said that "wild and angry accusations" against the newspaper "stir up the less well-intentioned and the more misguided."
Earlier, in an op-ed article entitled "Come On, Mr. Mas, Be Fair," Mr. Lawrence wrote, "You are a powerful person, here and in Washington, and you would like to hurt us, destroy us if you could." The publisher concluded by saying, "We cannot promise you, or anyone else, that we will stop printing certain opinions or certain stories."
Several reporters and editors at both editions of The Herald have said they are enraged by the foundation's verbal attacks and wish Mr. Lawrence would defend the paper more vigorously. Public support for The Herald has also come from some exile factions, though many prominent Cuban-Americans have remained silent.
Raul Masvidal, a former mayoral candidate who broke with Mr. Mas Canosa in the mid-80's, wrote in a letter to the editor: "Please don't allow The Herald to be pushed around. You have an obligation to the future of Cuban democracy and the Cuban people."
The Cuban American National Foundation has issued a statement saying it "condemns any acts of violence and intolerance" and called for "an immediate investigation." Mr. Mas Canosa has also suggested that the vandalism and threats against the Herald are the work of "Castroite agents" seeking to discredit exiles.
In addition, the foundation leader has hinted that he might organize a boycott of the newspapers. At the least, he said in a recent radio broadcast, his campaign would continue until "The Miami Herald respects the ideals and values of the Cuban-American community and embraces the cause of freedom for Cuba."
With that goal in mind, Mr. Mas Canosa, joined by Mayor Xavier Suarez of Miami and other prominent local Cuban-Americans, recently helped organize the Cuban Committee Against Defamation. To no one's surprise, the first complaint the new organization received was filed by the Cuban American National Foundation against The Miami Herald and El Nuevo Herald.
The strife is so bitter that it attracted the attention of the Inter American Press Association, which more commonly defends freedom of the press against left-wing and right-wing dictatorships in Latin America. The organization said last week that it would investigate "recent vandalism, threats of boycott and warnings of physical attack" against The Herald. It was the first time, members said, that the group has felt the need to stand up for a newspaper under political siege in the United States.

HEADLINE: Yeltsin Says Ukraine Will Give Up Nuclear Arms

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, March 18

 BODY:
The Russian President, Boris N. Yeltsin, said today that he had been assured that Ukraine's battlefield nuclear weapons would be transferred to Russia by July as planned. But there was no confirmation from Kiev that the Ukrainian President, Leonid M. Kravchuk, had reversed his order to halt the move.
According to the news agencies Itar-Tass and Interfax, Mr. Yeltsin told Russian members of parliament that Mr. Kravchuk had told him on Tuesday by telephone that he would meet the July 1 deadline for moving all tactical weapons to Russia for destruction. 
 The elimination of the weapons was agreed on between the United States and the former Soviet Union last fall, and once the Commonwealth of Independent States was formed by 11 former Soviet republics, Ukraine agreed to transfer its weapons to Russia for dismantling.
But last Thursday, Mr. Kravchuk unexpectedly announced that he was suspending the transfer, saying he had no guarantees the weapons were being destroyed. He suggested that Ukraine might set up its own dismantling plant, and asked for Western money to do so.
The declaration disturbed Washington. In Moscow, it was viewed largely as a ploy by Ukraine to wrest a share of Western funds earmarked for the dismantling, and as a political maneuver in advance of the meeting Friday of Commonwealth leaders in Kiev.
The fate of the vast Soviet military machine is high on the agenda, and Ukraine has been especially adamant in resisting Russia's claim to the bulk of the former Soviet Army. Though couched largely in terms of nation-building, the kernel of the dispute is widely viewed here and in Kiev to be the potential commercial value of military hardware.
Earlier this week, on his return from a two-week vacation, President Yeltsin announced that Russia was setting up its own Defense Ministry, with himself as acting minister. At a briefing for members of parliament, Mr. Yeltsin was quoted as saying that he regarded establishment of a defense ministry as a transitional step, and that it did not portend the transfer of former Soviet troops to Russia.
Until now, Russia has argued for the maintenance of a unified Commonwealth army; Ukraine, Azerbaijan and Moldova have insisted on forming independent armies and disbanding all but the strategic nuclear arm of the former Soviet forces, which would remain under a unified command.
Military issues are expected to be at the top of the agenda of the meeting on Friday. Mr. Yeltsin's spokesman, Alexei Novikov, said today that the agenda included an agreement on relocating of nuclear materiel, a decision on the united command and a convention on not using force among Commonwealth members.
The leaders will also deal with the status of troops in the stormy Caucasus region, where ethnic clashes have left hundreds dead. Mr. Yeltsin was quoted as saying that it was unclear who controlled the troops there.
 
Touchy Issue of Caucasus
 Senior generals in Moscow, backed by the Russian Vice President, Aleksandr V. Rutskoi, himself an Air Force officer, have been increasingly anxious to withdraw Commonwealth troops from the Caucasus, where they have been regularly raided for arms and have been drawn into local frays.
Past meetings of republics' leaders have managed only to paper over differences over the military, and disputes over military issues ranging from the tactical weapons to oaths of allegiance have been a primary factor in the growing rift between Ukraine and Russia.
In a move that underscored his concern, Mr. Yeltsin's office disclosed today that he had named Yuri V. Dubinin, former Soviet representative at the United Nations and ambassador to Washington, as chief negotiator with Ukraine on political, military and economic issues.
Mr. Dubinin, 62 years old, was recalled from France after the coup last August, when he was accused of failing to resist the plotters. He is nonetheless considered one of the ablest diplomats that Russia inherited from the Soviet state.

HEADLINE: BANGLADESH CHIEF VISITS WASHINGTON

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 18

 BODY:
A year after taking office in the first peaceful and democratic transfer of power in Bangladesh, Prime Minister Khaleda Zia came to Washington this week to ask the Bush Administration, Congress and international bankers not to overlook one of the most vulnerable nations in the rush to create a new world order.
The year has been a cruel one for Prime Minister Zia, only the second woman to head a modern Islamic country. Weeks after her Government was installed, Bangladesh was struck by a devastating cyclone that killed more than 100,000 people. 
 Now the country is being overrun by tens of thousands of Burmese refugees fleeing at the rate of 5,000 or more a day from a Burmese military campaign against that nation's Muslim minority. The Bangladesh Army, never hesitant to enter politics, is watching that crisis build, experts in Washington say.
"We are a poor country with a large population and it is not possible for us to care for such a large community from across our border," Prime Minister Zia, the 47-year-old widow of an assassinated former President, Gen. Ziaur Rahman, said in an interview on Tuesday. On Thursday, she is to go to the United Nations to discuss the refugee crisis with Secretary General Boutros Ghali.
 
Crucial Areas of Progress
 Despite the unending cycle of human-made and natural tragedies that afflict Bangladesh, Prime Minister Zia is getting a good reception in Washington. For the first time in the South Asian country's 20-year history, there is a sense that Bangladesh is addressing some of its fundamental problems.
Officials at the World Bank, in the Bush Administration and in private organizations no longer call Bangladesh a "basket case." Over the last five or six years -- even under Lieut. Gen. H. M. Ershad, the country's last military ruler, now in prison on corruption charges -- Bangladesh has shown that progress can be made in critical areas of economic and social development with very slender resources.
In South Asia, Bangladesh is gaining a reputation as the most innovative and receptive nation in making use of grass-roots organizations, like the rural Grameen Bank movement, which gives support to village entrepreneurs.
Between 1985 and 1991, the percentage of infants and young children immunized against the six most common childhood diseases rose from 2 percent to 62 percent, and the figure is expected to reach 85 percent within the next five years, according to World Bank figures. Nongovernmental organizations have carried out the immunization program in neighborhood centers with the help of the United States Agency for International Development and other donors.
"What makes this a hopeful country to look at is that there are so many examples of grass-roots projects which have made a difference to people's lives," said Teresita C. Schaffer, Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Pakistan.

HEADLINE: Washington at Work;
On a Dark, Stormy Republican Night

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 18

 BODY:
Senators do it. Journalists do it. Even the alienated daughters of former Presidents do it. So Marilyn Quayle and her sister said, let's do it, let's write a book.
"Embrace the Serpent," by Marilyn T. Quayle, the Vice President's wife, and her older sister, Nancy T. Northcott, is due out from Crown Publishers on April 3, the latest entry in this year's Washington celebrity power-novel steeplechase. 
 The former Tucker sisters of Indianapolis have spun a plot to warm the heart of anyone skeptical about glasnost. The Cubans tend to have bad teeth and reek of garlic. The Russians are nefarious, and greedy to boot. The journalists are craven, the Democrats corrupt, perverse or Russian dupes, and the Central Intelligence Agency has been "emasculated" by national security wimps.
 
Secure in Their Knowledge
 The Republicans are able to see through Russian disinformation; they live secure in the knowledge that "Star Wars" could save the world, if the craven, the corrupt and the wimpy would permit it.
After years of circling the flame of power, famous Washingtonians not infrequently decide to write novels. Margaret Truman has published 10 murder mysteries. Several years ago, Senators William S. Cohen of Maine and Gary Hart of Colorado wrote a bipartisan thriller. Patti Davis, daughter of President Ronald Reagan, wrote a roman a clef.
"Embrace the Serpent" is joined by three other new novels: "Capitol Secrets," by Maureen Dean, wife of John Dean of Watergate fame; "The Candidate's Wife," by Patricia O'Brien, a former journalist and spokeswoman for Gov. Michael S. Dukakis in the 1988 Presidential campaign, and "Capitol Hill," by Catherine Mann, wife of Representative Fred Grandy, the Iowa Republican who played "Gopher" on "The Love Boat."
"There are two different kinds of Washington novelists," said Sally Quinn, a former reporter for The Washington Post who has written two novels set in Washington. "One is the Washington celebrity who decides they want to write a novel -- the Gary Hart, Bill Cohen, Marilyn Quayle, Maureen Dean syndrome. Then there are writers, who happen to live in Washington, like Larry McMurtry, or who write about Washington, like Ward Just."
 
'I'm Not a Celebrity'
 Ms. Quinn, who said she started in the first category and wants to be in the second, described the celebrity tome this way: "Why don't I try my hand at a novel? I know Washington. I know how it works. It is a genre book. The President gets sick, whatever, goes blind, becomes a dupe of the K.G.B., or what used to be the K.G.B. The Senator sleeps around, or the candidate sleeps around, usually with the foreign diplomat's wife. They're interchangeable."
Mrs. Quayle and Mrs. Northcott bristle at the comparison.
"I'm not a celebrity," Mrs. Quayle said in an interview. "There's a mind-set, and I don't think I've got that. But Nancy and I undertook this more because we really wanted to write a book. It's not a book about my life in Washington as the wife of the Vice President."
 
The Cigar Lingers On
 It begins with the C.I.A.'s ultimate fantasy: Fidel Castro dropping dead while smoking a cigar. "The magnetism and vitality had vanished; all that remained was a torn uniform below a scraggly beard littered with fading embers and ashes."
The Russians, in thrall to the Arabs after having sold off their assets to save their crippled economy, allow military officers pining for the old days to launch "Operation Romanov." They murder Raul Castro, Fidel's brother, and put a puppet, Cesar Valles, in power.
Meanwhile, Gen. Jose Moya, leader of the underground movement La Causa, languishes in prison. "Even he realized that gaining freedom was improbable at best, but he also knew no man's sanity could withstand the horror of a never-ending existence in this hellhole."
The Russians aim to undermine America through arms and drug traffic. And the Democratic President, a gullible fellow who does everything for personal gain, is unwittingly duped by Russian intelligence into supporting Valles.
 
Sex and Disguises
 The hero, Senator Robert Hawkins Grant, Republican of Georgia, knows better. With the help of friends in the Cuban resistance and his loyal aide (who does not have any mommy-track conflicts, since her husband had been "shot by a druggie"), he works to foil the plot and make General Moya the President.
Washington novels generally have two additional characteristics: sex and characters disguised just enough to avoid lawsuits.
It irritated Mrs. Quayle and Mrs. Northcott to think that people were thumbing through their book looking for sex scenes. There are none.
There is romance, between Alejandro, the brave soldier of La Causa, and Maria, who bravely poses as a maid in the Presidential Palace to help him. "But Castro's Cuba was no place for love."
 
The Passion of Marriage
 It is a measure of the steaminess of "Embrace the Serpent" that the love passages (mostly between married couples) can be quoted: " 'Love you,' he said with a quick kiss. 'Mmm,' he whispered, pulling her closer and nuzzling her ear. As always, the sweet smell of her warmed him. 'Thanks for being so understanding.' After another much more satisfactory kiss, he released her." (And then left for work.)
"Journalists can write much more freely about sex than other people can," said Ms. Quinn, whose books have plenty of sex scenes. "Politicians are not supposed to have sex."
Not even with their spouses? "Well, it's possible, but risky," she said.
 
A Certain Wednesday
 The President in "Embrace the Serpent" is a Democrat who, curiously, appears to have beaten George Bush in the 1992 elections. The action begins on Wednesday, Jan. 25, after the fall of the Soviet Union. The only Wednesday, Jan. 25, after that in this century is in 1995.
So definitely not George Bush, right? This fictional President, Peter Evans, is a man who likes to say he is from a Southern state, when in fact he's a Northeastern establishment type. "He was careful to emphasize his Kentucky heritage: he was just a good old boy. Funny how few had keyed on his real history: boarding schools in the East. Ivy League college, first jobs in the East as well."
President Evans is protected by journalists, including a cynical, left-leaning Washington newspaper editor. Journalists are not treated gently by Mrs. Northcott and Mrs. Quayle, who has viewed reporters with clenched teeth since Dan Quayle's trials in the 1988 campaign.
The authors acknowledged that they did fit one characteristic of the Washington celebrity novelist. "We first started talking about writing a book about 10 years ago, having read many, and thought we could do as well," Mrs. Northcott said.
 
A Labor of Three Years
 The sisters spent three years on this book. Mrs. Northcott, who lives in Tullahoma, Tenn., with her husband, Thomas, an oral surgeon, said she waited until her four children were old enough to fend for themselves.
Like another political wife, Hillary Clinton, Mrs. Quayle is a lawyer. Unlike Mrs. Clinton, she no longer practices, so her career has not been a political problem. "This is my time," she said. "I've worked hard for everyone the last three and a half years, so I don't think anyone begrudges me this time."
Mrs. Quayle and Mrs. Northcott said they prized their ability to work together. But Esther Newberg, the New York literary agent who represents Paul E. Tsongas, the former Massachusetts Senator and Democratic Presidential candidate, found celebrity Washington novels and two people writing fiction together equally unnerving.
 
'The Mind Boggles'
 "The idea that they finish each other's sentences!" she said. "Does that mean we have to read a Bill Clinton-Hillary Clinton book? I mean, she already finishes his sentences. The mind boggles."
A favorite pastime for readers of Washington celebrity novels is uncovering political messages. Mrs. Quayle and Mrs. Northcott said theirs is not a political tract, although they acknowledged a "conservative perspective."
When an interviewer noted that the Democrats in the book are, well, dumb, Mrs. Quayle said, "That's real life."
Indeed, "Embrace the Serpent" is a primer on conservative political correctness.
The hero, Senator Grant, is black -- a fact introduced with the phrase "he'd smiled at her, his straight teeth white in his black face" -- and had been a career Navy officer. Grant ran for office reluctantly, because the Democratic incumbent was an outrageous pork-barrel politician who had sex with teen-agers.
Mrs. Quayle is unrepentant about painting the Russians as bad guys. There are, however, limits.
Talking about rewriting passages after the fall of Soviet Communism, Mrs. Northcott said, "We just guessed that they'd start selling their assets and doing all that."
Mrs. Quayle: "We've been shocked" at how prescient that was.
Mrs. Northcott: "Delighted."
Mrs. Quayle: "No, now come on. What a word to use. Geez. Strike that."

HEADLINE: Japan Sets Lower Ceiling for Auto Exports

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Thursday, March 19

 BODY:
In an election-year gesture to the United States, Japan today announced a big reduction in its ceiling for automobile exports, saying it would limit exports to 1.65 million a year, down sharply from 2.3 million now.
While the move marks a significant concession by Japan, its impact on the reeling American automobile industry is likely to be limited. In part because of the depressed auto market and in part because of the increasing number of cars manufactured at Japanese "transplant" factories in the United States, Japan exported only about 1.76 million cars to the American market in 1991, or only 110,000 above the new ceiling. That was the fifth consecutive year that Japanese exports to America fell below 2.3 million, the level that has been in effect since the mid-1980's. 
 Though there will be little effect on the actual number of cars shipped to the United States, Japanese officials are betting that the Bush Administration will be able to greet the announcement as a victory. Mr. Bush's ill-fated trip to Japan in January focused tremendous attention on the automobile issue -- autos make up about 75 percent of the trade deficit -- and the Japanese clearly hope the Administration will be able to cite the lowering of the export limits as a response to pressure from the President.
[In Washington, an American trade official declined to discuss the new export level announced by the Japanese, but said, "What the U.S. is after is opening the Japanese market." ]
In recent weeks, as Japan's powerful Ministry of International Trade and Industry has debated whether to keep the formal limit at 2.3 million or to reduce it, officials have made little secret of the fact that they were keeping one eye on the Presidential primaries.
The unexpectedly deep cut in the limit seemed to suggest that the growing calls for protectionism in the United States jolted the Japanese auto industry and the Government into taking an action that they have resisted for several years. But it is not clear whether the Japanese strategy -- to offer a concession now in hopes that it will defuse any movement for sharper limits that might emerge later in the campaign -- will prove successful.
"Japan-U.S. relations are quite important," Kozo Watanabe, the Trade Minister, said recently. "Economic policy must be developed to make Japan-U.S. relations better."
The new export restraints will go into effect on April 1, the beginning of the Japanese fiscal year. The trade ministry has estimated that exports to the United States would total 1.73 million cars in the new fiscal year, meaning that the auto industry will have to trim its plans slightly. Presumably, some manufacturing could be moved to American transplants, which are not affected by the limits.
This will be the 12th consecutive year for the restraints, although they were originally conceived as a temporary measure to give Detroit a chance to grow more competitive.
Japanese officials say in private that the initiative has largely failed and that they see little evidence that the American auto makers used the voluntary limits to lift productivity or reduce the price of American autos. But they view the restraints as politically useful, at little cost to the Japanese economy. Every year for five years Japanese car exports have been well below 2.3 million, but the market share of Japanese cars has risen above 30 percent.
Japanese auto makers have also seen their revenues from export rise, largely because they are shipping larger, more expensive cars to the United States, vehicles like Toyota's Lexus and Honda's Acura. The American transplant factories have been used to produce less expensive, higher-volume models.

HEADLINE: Analysts Consider Recovery Too Weak To Make Jobs Yet

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
For all the robust gains showing up in recent economic reports, most economists say that the evidence available so far is not sufficient to demonstrate that a strong enough recovery is under way to generate new job growth.
Unless job growth resumes soon, they say, there will not be enough additional family income to sustain the jump in consumer spending that began 60 days ago. That could mean a renewal of the recession or, at the very least, a continuation of the stagnation that has plagued the American economy for three years. A similar surge in consumer spending last spring, also hailed as the first stage of a recovery, came to a halt in August after failing to increase jobs. 
 "I don't think you can go past May without significant job growth and keep a recovery going," said David Wyss, senior economist at DRI/McGraw-Hill, a data-gathering and consulting service. One million fewer Americans hold jobs since the recession began in July 1990.
Healthy increases in retail sales, new home construction and auto and truck production since December have encouraged many economists to predict that by midsummer, the economy will be growing at an annual rate of more than 3 percent. The Federal Reserve's periodic survey of regional economic conditions released yesterday confirmed the upturn in consumer buying, but noted that manufacturing layoffs persisted. [Page D2.]
A 3 percent growth rate by mid-summer would mark the first time since the winter of 1989 that the growth rate has exceeded even 2 percent -- a slowdown that has blurred the distinction between stagnation and recession.
Strictly speaking, a recession means that the gross domestic product, measuring all the new wealth created in the United States in a given period, is shrinking, as it did from the summer of 1990 until last spring. Since then, growth has been so anemic that economists and the public alike have often called it a recession.
The reason for this blurring of definitions is the loss of jobs. By almost every estimate, if jobs are to be created again, rather than lost through layoffs and attrition, then the gross domestic product must grow at an annual rate of more than 2 percent for several quarters, and perhaps by as much as 3 percent. Only then, said Nancy Lazar, senior economist at ISI Group, a consulting firm, would there be "a tone change in the economy."
Three percent growth, adds Robert M. Solow, a Nobel laureate in economic sciences, "is just about enough to keep the unemployment rate constant or slightly diminishing."
 
Something for Everyone
 Whatever the long-term outlook, President Bush can point to the incipient upturn as evidence that an election-year recovery is under way. And his Democratic opponents, with equal authority, can hammer away at the missing jobs and the rising unemployment rate: 7.3 percent today, compared with 5.3 percent when the recession started. "They'll each be able to put their spin on the data," Mr. Solow said.
Ms. Lazar and some other forecasters say that 3 percent growth is likely by Election Day, and could endure into 1993. They base their optimism on two conditions lacking last spring, when consumer buying also surged. One is the decline in interest rates for mortgages and auto loans since last year, although some rates have recently turned up a bit. The other is healthier banks, specifically those that have written off many of their uncollectable loans and now seem more willing to finance new activity.
But in a dozen interviews with economists, their doubts about job growth, the most important factor of all, repeatedly came to the surface.
"A lot of manufacturers have not yet seen a significant pickup in orders, despite the healthy rise in retail sales," said Thomas M. Hoenig, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City, whose territory includes Midwestern states that have weathered the recession better than other regions. "I cannot tell you that anyone is suggesting to us that they are in a strong rehiring mode at this moment. They are hopeful, but they are also cautious."
 
New Cut in Rates?
 Reflecting this caution, David W. Mullins, vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, suggests that the Fed might bring short-term interest rates even lower than their present 4 percent level if the upturn shows signs of fading. "In the current, complex, sluggish environment, we are watching the situation very carefully because last summer, the economy started to take off and the environment snuffed out that recovery," he said, noting that rising rates a year ago had discouraged consumers and businesses.
Perhaps the main reason for the current upturn is a sudden rise in personal disposable income, the money Americans can spend or save after paying their taxes. After declining for most of last year, total disposable income jumped 1.5 percent in January from December's level, even after adjusting for inflation. And February brought an additional 2.2 percent increase.
These were far and away the largest increases since the summer of 1990, when the recession began -- but they did not come from job growth or from noticeably higher wages, economists say. The bulk of the gains came from more fragile sources: a rise in overtime pay, the extended unemployment benefits recently granted by Congress, higher Social Security checks and the Government's early mailing of veterans' benefits and income tax refunds.
"We do have some stimulus out there and our surveys show a recent strengthening in consumer confidence, suggesting a turnaround," said Richard T. Curtin, director of the University of Michigan's monthly consumer sentiment surveys. Mild inflation -- the Consumer Price Index is rising at an annual rate of less than 3 percent -- also helps to stretch family budgets, and lower interest rates have reduced millions of mortgage payments, Mr. Curtin noted.
 
Doubts on Employment
 "But more fundamentally," he said, "when consumers look to the year ahead or to the next five years, they are not seeing the employment problem solved and that will inhibit any recovery."
Thomas Plewes, associate commissioner of the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics, also doubts that the employment problem has been solved, although 164,000 jobs were added to the labor force in February, the first rise since last November. "The figures that we put out were not incompatible with a recovery, but they did not demonstrate one either," he said.
Most of the reported job gains were at retailers and auto factories. But the rise in retail jobs was partly artificial: a formula used to adjust for seasonal variations increased retail employment by 133,000 instead of the 50,000 or so jobs actually created. And the more than 10,000 new jobs at auto makers mostly represented call-backs of hourly workers temporarily laid off, industry executives said.
 
Auto Industry Reluctance
 The auto industry illustrates how reluctant many American companies are to add to their job rolls. At the Ford Motor Company new hiring would come only if assembly lines were speeded up or a shift were added, "and that sort of quantum leap is way down the road," said Joel Pitcoff, a Ford researcher and analyst.
Car and truck production is currently running at an annual rate of nearly 13 million vehicles. "I suspect that if we get a sustained demand for 13.5 million cars and trucks a year, then employment will start to grow in the auto industry," said Wynn Van Bussman, a Chrysler Corporation economist.
The current upturn has to weather three other hazards, economists say. One is a possible decline in exports. What growth there has been in recent months has come partly from strong exports, now threatened by declining economies in Europe and Japan.
Another hazard is rising imports. When the economy revived last spring, a portion of the new purchases was imported goods, creating jobs abroad but not at home.
Finally, many economists argue that a consumer-led recovery cannot, by itself, sustain sufficient growth, unless rising production also stimulates investment in new machinery and factories. That would require a reversal of a trend that saw net new investment in plant and equipment drop to 5 percent of the gross domestic product in the late 1980's from 7.8 percent in the late 1960's.
"One thing that saved us in the 1980's was investment by foreigners in the United States," Mr. Wyss of DRI/McGraw-Hill, said. "Lately, there has not been enough consumption to make investment rise."

HEADLINE: Dim View of Economy From Oil Industry

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Whatever the tea leaves show in other parts of the American economy, the oil industry said yesterday that the nation was still in recession, with February's refinery output at its lowest level in nearly five years. Domestic crude-oil production also continues to fall sharply.
But overall demand was up in February compared with last year, because of an anomaly: February 1991 was a depressed month because of the Persian Gulf war. 
 Oil use is neither a leading indicator of the economy nor a trailing indicator, but a measure of current activity, according to Charles DiBona, the president of the American Petroleum Institute. He said that from the statistics released yesterday, "we don't see any evidence the economy is reviving."
 The institute, the industry's main trade association, said that deliveries of refined products were up 2.5 percent compared with February 1991, when deliveries were at a five-year low. But the institute said that on a month-to-month basis, taking seasonal variations into account, "there has been no real sign of strengthening in deliveries since mid-1991."
Domestic crude production fell about 250,000 barrels a day, or 3.4 percent, to 7.299 million barrels a day, from 7.552 million. Imports rose about six-tenths of a percent, to 6.888 million barrels a day from 6.844 million.
The average demand for imports is substantially higher, the institute said, in the range of 7.7 million to 7.8 million barrels a day, but stocks were drawn down by a larger amount than average last month.
Refinery utilization fell to 79.9 percent, from 84.4 percent a year earlier.
 
 
Mobil Cuts Spending Plans
 The nation's weather has been generally warm, but weather is a fairly small factor in overall oil demand.
In line with generally glum news on oil, the Mobil Corporation said yesterday that it would cut its capital spending this year to $4.8 billion, about $1 billion less than previously planned. It was the second straight year in which Mobil cut expenditures during the year. And the company's chairman, Allen E. Murray, said that about $800 million more might be deferred unless conditions improved.
The company also said it would take $105 million in first-quarter charges, mostly for restructuring.
