HEADLINE: Debt Deal For Trump On Plaza

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. HYLTON

 BODY:
Donald J. Trump has reached an agreement to turn over 49 percent of his interest in the landmark Plaza Hotel in Manhattan to a group of banks led by Citibank, people involved in the talks said yesterday.
The nearly completed deal is one of the last in a long line of debt restructurings that Mr. Trump has reached with his creditors. It would cancel $125 million of Mr. Trump's personally guaranteed debt, plus accrued interest, and would give the developer more favorable terms on the remaining $300 million of mortgage debt. 
 The Plaza deal is similar to other Trump deals in swapping mortgage debt for equity, and it would leave Mr. Trump in control of the hotel, although his equity would be heavily encumbered by bank liens.
To keep control of the Plaza, as well as two Atlantic City casinos, Mr. Trump must meet certain business projections over the next several years. If he failed to meet the projections and make the required interest payments, he would lose control of his remaining stake in the hotel.
 
Subject to a Lien
 Mr. Trump's 51 percent stake would still be subject to a lien held by the banks that lent him $125 million. He would be allowed to pay interest as low as 5 percent on the $300 million of mortgage debt if he could not pay the original floating rate.
The deal, which was reached last week, values the Plaza at about $260 million. Mr. Trump paid $409 million for the hotel in 1988 and will retain a $300 million mortgage on it. In 1990, the Trump Organization estimated the value of the Plaza at $830 million, while the Kenneth Leventhal Company, which was retained by Mr. Trump, put the value at $413 million to $500 million.
"The deal has been agreed upon by the whole group of banks and Mr. Trump, and it is 49 percent for the banks and 51 percent for Trump," said Richard Wilhelm, president of the Plaza Hotel, yesterday.
The banks and Mr. Trump still have to sign a final agreement for the deal to take effect.
Despite the formidable array of problems and the billions in debt facing Mr. Trump, he has managed to convince scores of creditors that they should grant him more time in which to try to increase the value of his deeply indebted assets and that they should release him from his guarantees for hundreds of millions of dollars of debt.
In the case of the Penn Yards, a 76-acre tract of undeveloped land on the West Side of Manhattan, Mr. Trump has been able to improve the value by negotiating for zoning approval with city officials and community groups.
If the Plaza proposal goes through, Mr. Trump will be personally liable for at least $115 million in debt, down from roughly $900 million in 1990.
But Mr. Trump is far from out of the woods. In June 1993, about $350 million in mortgage debt will come due and it is unclear whether the banks will roll over the debts or demand payment. The $300 million mortgage on the Plaza comes due in 1995. In addition, Mr. Trump's $115 million of personally guaranteed debt matures in 1995. Whether he will be able to pay that plus tens of millions more that will have come due by then is anyone's guess.
 
Eleventh-Hour Negotiations
 For two years, Mr. Trump has faced 11th-hour negotiations to shore up his empire, which has been crumbling as a result of his heavy borrowing to buy high-profile assets at inflated prices during the 1980's. With the collapse of real estate prices at the end of the decade and the troubles in the gaming and airline industries that were aggravated by the recession, Mr. Trump became trapped in a cash squeeze and was finally rescued by banks that stood to lose hundreds of millions of dollars if he was forced into bankruptcy.
Between bondholders of his Atlantic City casinos and the banks that liberally lent him hundreds of millions of dollars, Mr. Trump and the top executives of the Trump Organization managed to cobble together a series of deals that give him more time to improve the performance and value of some of his assets.
Banks have also taken back some assets in lieu of the debt on them. Among these are the Trump Shuttle, which USAir is now operating; the Trump Princess Yacht; a 50 percent interest in the Grand Hyatt hotel in midtown Manhattan; a 28 percent stake in Alexander's department store; three Atlantic City land parcels, and hundreds of New York condominiums in the Trump Palace and another Manhattan building.
 
Action at the Casinos
 In addition, Mr. Trump has swapped 50 percent of Trump's Castle casino and 50 percent of the Trump Taj Mahal, two Atlantic City casinos, for more favorable debt terms granted by holders of junk bonds that he sold to finance the casinos.
In the case of the Plaza Hotel, the proposed deal underscores the developer's difficulties. He bought the hotel for about $409 million in 1988, or about 25 times the hotel's 1988 cash flow of $16 million, from the Robert M. Bass Group of Fort Worth. With accrued interest and other borrowings, the total debt on the property before this latest deal exceeded $430 million and interest was accruing at a floating rate.
The new deal would leave the original $300 million mortgage and its floating-rate debt in place, but it would allow Mr. Trump to pay as little as 5 percent interest and accrue the balance. By trading the personally guaranteed $125 million debt for 49 percent of his equity in the hotel, and through other such deals, Mr. Trump is trying to clear the way for a financial comeback.
 
Remaining Questions
 Final details of the new partnership agreement are still being worked out. It is not known whether the banks will be free to sell their 49 percent equity interest in the Plaza.
The Plaza, which is rated as one of New York's best hotels and has been performing strongly for the last few years, has not been able to generate enough cash to make its debt payments for several years now. In 1990, interest payments on the acquisition debt cost about $41.3 million, but the hotel had only $21 million in cash flow. Last year, the hotel's cash flow totaled $17.6 million, while the total accrued debt-service cost was about $42 million.
This year, Mr. Wilhelm estimates, the hotel will generate nearly $21 million in cash flow before its debt-service cost, which will be about $15 million.

HEADLINE: President's Plan Seeks to Create a Market for Cars That Pollute

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 18

 BODY:
Pressing its drive to cut the cost of complying with Government regulation, the Bush Administration today announced a series of initiatives in the transportation sector that includes a "cash for clunkers" program, under which states and companies can meet Federal clean-air requirements by buying and scrapping the old vehicles that generate the most pollution.
The buy-up of old cars, to be left largely to market forces under guidelines to be established by the Environmental Protection Agency, could begin within a few months. 
 "This is just one example of the innovative, market-based approaches to pollution reduction that have been pioneered by our Environmental Protection Agency," President Bush said in a statement. "The result is a cleaner, healthier environment and a more competitive economy."
 
Debate on Fuel Standards
 But the Administration pulled back from a plan to relax fuel-efficiency standards for cars burning cleaner fuels, a fiercely debated issue. Many environmentalists seek to make the current 27.5-mile-a-gallon standard even tougher. That standard, known as CAFE, for corporate average fuel economy, is a minimum for the average fuel economy of each auto maker's fleet.
Officials said this initiative was postponed on technical grounds, but there were also indications of a strenuous internal argument about the wisdom of reducing the standard, which would reportedly fall to an average of 26.5 miles a gallon.
In general, American auto makers oppose the standards, which they say forces them to skew production to build more small cars and fewer large cars than customers would prefer. This hurts both profitability and safety, they maintain.
Anticipating a rollback announcement that did not come, at least today, the Sierra Club issued a statement denouncing any reduced standard as "outrageous and illegal," and as bad for the economy, for jobs and for the environment.
 
Study of Ethanol Not Done
 Michael J. Boskin, the President's chief economic adviser and a leader in the Administration's campaign to streamline regulations, said the postponement of any rollback decision was specifically tied to the fact that the E.P.A. had not yet finished its analysis of ethanol in reformulated gasoline. An announcement on that study would be made "in the very near future."
Although today's initiatives also contained various measures involving truck and rail transportation and ocean shipping, the bulk of attention centered on the cash-for-clunkers program to get the vehicles that pollute the most off the road. The Administration made no grand claims for the plan, however, which is patterned on one conducted by the Unocal Corporation in California in 1990 and 1991.
Under the Government program, a power plant or other "stationary source" could buy the right to continue polluting by reducing pollution from vehicles. The idea is that the new cars that would replace the old ones would be cleaner.
 
Economic Benefit Possible
 Officials said the cash-for-clunkers program would do no harm to the environment and might improve it somewhat. It might also act as a mild stimulant to the economy, as drivers of at least some clunkers replace their vehicles with later-model used cars or, in some cases, even new ones.
The General Motors Corporation, the nation's largest auto maker, said it supported the basic premise of a scrap program, which it said could prove "a cost-effective policy alternative for improving the environment and reducing fleet fuel-consumption."
As sketched out at a White House briefing, the cash-for-clunkers program would be run by individual states, cities and companies with the aid of federally provided data on the pollution and other characteristics of each kind of car. The main target is the four million pre-1971 cars still on the road, but officials said many cars from the 1980's would also likely be bid for, depending on such things as their pollution rating and estimated years of remaining useful life.
 
Unocal's Experiment
 In its program, Unocal bought more than 8,300 pre-1971 cars at $700 each in the Los Angeles area. Old cars emit as much as 20 times more in pollutants than those of the 1990's.
As an example of how the Government program would work, said Richard D. Morgenstern, director of the E.P.A.'s Office of Policy Analysis, a refiner in danger of exceeding its pollution limits might place an advertisement in the newspaper listing what it would pay for various kinds and vintages of cars and, having made the purchases, would apply the resulting credits to its own "account."
To prevent junkyard entrepreneurs from peddling wrecks, cars qualifying for purchase would have to be continuously insured for the past year and be driven in under their own power.
Although the oldest cars would tend to bring the highest prices, a car's value would also depend on its type, its mileage and its likely remaining life.
The pollution credits could be traded but could not be applied outside the program area, officials said.
Of the remaining Administration initiatives today, perhaps the most important was to accelerate a proceeding under which truckers would no longer have to obtain a registration stamp for each vehicle from each state in which they operate. Instead, a designated base state would do this work with no change in the amount of revenue each state collects.
This would save an estimated $250 million to $500 million a year, the Administration estimated.

HEADLINE: Vote Sought On Gasoline In California

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
A group of oil companies that oppose California's strict new requirements on gasoline moved yesterday to block the rules with a statewide referendum. The move, prompted in part by concern that similar rules would be introduced elsewhere in the nation, would apparently be the first electoral test of whether people think that changes made in gasoline to reduce air pollution are worth the higher price.
The group plans to ask the California Legislature to put a measure on the ballot that would require another analysis of benefits and costs before proceeding with the rules, which the California Air Resources Board recently approved and are to take effect in 1996. The referendum would be phrased broadly to cover all environmental rules, said a spokesman for Texaco, one company involved. The spokesman, David J. Dickson, said the goal was to address "structural problems" in the California economy, which he said was being hurt by high costs for environmental compliance.
 
Conspicuously Absent
 ARCO, California's biggest gasoline marketer, was conspicuously absent. ARCO has voluntarily reformulated some of its gasoline and supported the Air Resources Board in its plans to enforce stricter rules. 
 Several factors beyond concern over California's economy appeared to play a role. While the ostensible target of the referendum would be the California rule, many executives of national oil companies say that whatever steps the state takes are likely to be adopted, in whole or in part, in the Northeast and in other parts of the country. Eleven Northeastern and Middle Atlantic states have said they plan to adopt the California standards.
Texaco, which has only about 7 percent of the California market but a bigger share in the East, has been especially vigorous in arguing against the California rules.
In addition, according to refining analysts, the cost of meeting new rules will differ substantially from company to company, depending on the age and configuration of their refineries. ARCO, which is predominantly a California company, would find the rules relatively easy to meet, refining experts say.
The composition of the group that met yesterday was unclear. Mr. Dickson said it was the directors of the Western States Petroleum Association. But a spokesman for the association, Jeffrey B. Wilson, said that the issue was not on the board's agenda, and that it was not addressed while the board was in session.
Shortly after California passed the new rule last October, the association considered and rejected a proposal to challenge it.
 
Meeting in Sacramento
 Mr. Dickson said other participants in the meeting in Sacramento yesterday included Chevron and Mobil. Chevron referred all comment to the association. A spokesman for Mobil said he was unaware of any meeting.
But a spokesman for the Air Resources Board, William Sessa, said he had heard some talk of an effort by the companies to oppose the rule.
At ARCO, Robert J. Trunek, the senior vice president for manufacturing, engineering and technology, said the idea of requiring a cost-benefit analysis was "just silly," because the Air Resources Board's enabling legislation required an analysis before the regulation was imposed. He added that cars contributed more than 50 percent of the pollution, and that "if you don't do as much as you can on the big emissions sources, you're going to have to do something just ridiculously strenuous on stationary sources." The latter are factories and other sources of pollution.
The California rules, which would take effect in April 1996, require gasoline with less benzene, a carcinogen, and more oxygen to reduce production of carbon monoxide.

HEADLINE: Stocks Mixed in Busy Day; Dow Off 1.79

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks were narrowly mixed in heavy trading as investors with no fresh data to direct them had little incentive to buy, locking the market in a narrow range most of the day. The Dow Jones industrial average barely moved, closing at 3,254.25, down 1.79 points.
Even though the Federal Reserve's "beige book" report, a summary of economic activity, saw some improvement in economic conditions, it had no more impact on the market than Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady's comments that a recovery is under way. Analysts said that while these might have provided some relief, the market was still waiting for a pickup in corporate earnings. 
 Pressure was also felt by the approach of the "triple witching hour," which actually will be played out over two days. It had investors moving around cautiously, as bonds posted small losses and offered no support to stocks yesterday. The 8 percent yield on a Treasury long bond remains an attractive alternative to equities.
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks slipped 0.43 point, to 409.15, while the American Stock Exchange dropped 4.67 point, to 400.97, which traders said might have been influenced by a more than 62 percent drop in the share price of the Chambers Development Company traded there.
The waste management company, which plunged 19, to 11 1/4, revised its 1991 earnings to 3 cents a share from 83 cents, because of an accounting change. That was later followed by a change in recommendation from Douglas Augenthaler, an analyst with Oppenheimer & Company, who cut his rating on the the stock to "sell" from "market performer."
 
Waste Management Companies
 Other waste management companies caught up in the selling by unhappy investors included Waste Management Inc. off 2 1/4, to 40 1/2, and Browning-Ferris Industries, off 3/8, to 22 1/2.
In Nasdaq trading, the composite index rose 1.67 points, to 624.94, as the Russell 2,000 index of smaller company stocks gained 0.93 point, to 208.16.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was 194.1 million shares, up from 190.8 million on Tuesday, as gaining issues putpaced losers by 917 to 798.
Blue-chip issues came under pressure in early trading, bounced a couple of times and ended lower. The weakness in the market came from a number of directions, one of them, losses in overseas markets to set the tone, while high yields in Treasury securities also weighed on stocks.
Traders said that without news, program trading is likely to dominate market activity over the next couple of days and provide direction ahead of "triple witching" expirations today and tomorrow of options on individual stocks, stock indexes, futures and options.
Birinyi Associates, a Wall Street research firm that tracks program trades, clocked four program trades that combined to raise the Dow by 6.27 points.
Dennis Jarrett, chief market analyst at Kidder, Peabody & Company, said "it was as if the market was running in place." He saw a lot of situation buying instead and thinks that there may not be as much volatility in the market during the "triple witching" expirations as some may have come to expect. "It may have slipped through the market earlier in the week," he said.
In trading yesterday, NBD Bancorp fell to 28 7/8, down 7/8, after the company said it had signed a definitive agreement to acquire INB Financial, up 7, to 43. The agreement is valued at about $876 million, and provides that NBD would exchange 1.6 shares of its common stock for each share of INB.
Elsewhere, shares of Seagram Company Ltd. jumped 5 3/8, to 117 1/8, on news of a 12 percent dividend increase and proposed 4-for-1 stock split that accompanied a better-than-expected fourth-quarter earnings report. The dividend increase hinges on shareholder approval of the stock split, traders said.

HEADLINE: Blocks Seen to Trade Pact With Canada and Mexico

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 18

 BODY:
The Bush Administration is almost certain not to seek Congressional approval of a free-trade agreement with Mexico and Canada this year, although it hopes to conclude talks on a pact in the coming months, senior Administration officials said today.
The officials also said that it seemed increasingly unlikely that there would be a successful conclusion to global trade talks in Geneva this year. Because the United States and the European Community have been unable to resolve their disagreements over agriculture, many countries have stopped negotiating on other issues in the world talks, Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, said. 
 As a result, an Administration that a year ago had hoped for two major agreements to open foreign markets will now end up with what one senior official termed one-third of one agreement: the completion of negotiations on a pact with Mexico and Canada to replace an agreement struck with Canada alone in 1988.
 
 
A 3-Stage Process
 Three stages are needed to complete a pact: negotiation, legislative drafting and Congressional approval. All the Administration is likely to end up with on the Canada-Mexico pact, the official said, is the first stage.
Administration officials emphasized that a sudden breakthrough in negotiations with Mexico and Canada could still make it possible to seek Congressional approval this year. But they acknowledged that such a development was unlikely.
Not one of the 19 negotiating groups in the trade talks with Mexico and Canada has reached an agreement, and talks in the highly contentious energy and auto negotiating groups are still "in the concept stage," Mrs. Hills said.
No efforts have been made to assemble the needed coalition in Congress for either the Mexico-Canada trade agreement or the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade pact being discussed in Geneva, and no such effort is planned soon, Administration officials and senators said.
Both sets of negotiations have already gone on too long for the Administration to force Congressional consideration this year under the so-called fast-track authority for the President that Congress renewed last year after considerable debate.
 
 
Fiercely Contested Issue
 The proposed free trade agreement with Mexico and Canada in particular has become a fiercely contested issue in the Presidential election campaign, especially in industrial states of the Midwest, where there is concern about possible job losses to low-wage workers in Mexico.
Former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California, who finished second to Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas and ahead of former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts in Michigan's primary election Tuesday, had strongly criticized the proposed pact, while Mr. Clinton endorsed it.
Both Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who heads the Finance Committee, and Senator John C. Danforth, the Missouri Republican who is the ranking minority member of the Subcommittee on International Trade, said there had been no Administration contacts about organizing a Congressional coalition to support the Canada and Mexico pacts.
Mr. Danforth said that it would be difficult in an election year to push either trade agreement through Congress, adding, "I'm not sure we'll be any better off next year, post-election."
 
Pointing to Mexico
 Placing the onus on Mexico rather than American politics, a senior Administration trade official who insisted on anonymity told reporters this morning that the refusal of Mexican negotiators to discuss a sweeping revision of bilateral trade relations had bogged down talks on the free trade agreement.
Current Mexican officials want a pact to lock their successors into preserving the new openness of the Mexican economy, and the United States wants an agreement that further opens the Mexican economy and can serve as a blueprint for future agreements with other Latin American nations, the official said.
President Bush spoke by telephone to President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico on Tuesday. A senior Mexican Government official said today that the two leaders agreed that progress was being made in the talks but that President Bush made no pledge to put an agreement before Congress this year.
Mr. Salinas and Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada, who spoke to Mr. Bush by phone last week, both said publicly on Tuesday that they expected an agreement to be reached soon, but they expressed doubts that it would be approved by Congress this year, according to Reuters reports from Ottawa and Mexico City.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Tax-Free Fund Yields Up; Taxables Are Mostly Stable

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
Yields on both tax-exempt and taxable money market funds are beginning to reflect the overall rise in market yields, according to IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report.
The report, issued yesterday, collects figures on tax-exempts for the week ended Monday and on taxables for the week ended Tuesday. 
 Referring to the taxables, Walter Frank, economist for IBC/Donoghue, said that "the long decline in yields on taxable funds is ending, at least temporarily, reflecting the recent rise in short-term open-market yields, such as those on commercial paper, and Treasury bills."
 
More Increases Seen
 Mr. Frank added, "Unless we get another move toward easing money by the Federal Reserve, we expect to see some increase in the money fund yields over the next few weeks."
The seven-day compound average yield of the tax-exempt funds rose to 2.6 percent, up 10 basis points from the previous week, while the seven-day simple yield rose to 2.56 percent from 2.47 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
During the same period, the 30-day compound tax-free yield was 2.58 percent, down from 2.61 percent; the simple yield was also down 3 basis points, to 2.55 percent.
 
Highest Returns
 Among the funds with the highest yields in the region, the top Connecticut fund again was the Fidelity Spartan Connecticut Municipal Money Market Portfolio, which reported a seven-day compound yield of 2.97 percent, up from 2.91 percent.
In New Jersey, the top fund was New Jersey Municipal Inc., reporting a yield of 2.91 percent. It is new to the list of recent leaders.
In New York, the top fund again was the Salomon Brothers N.Y. Municipal Money Market fund. It had a seven-day compound yield of 3.41 percent, up from 3.36 percent.
Assets of tax-exempt funds dropped by $663 million, to $98.2 billion. Donoghue said the average number of days to maturity of securities held in tax-free portfolios remained unchanged at 52 days for the third week.
Of the tax-free funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue with assets larger than $100 million, the Strong Municipal Money Market Fund, Milwaukee, led once again with a seven-day compound yield of 3.45 percent, up from 3.38 percent the previous week.
 
Drop in Assets
 Assets of the taxable funds, meanwhile, declined by $1.8 billion, to $497.2 billion. Mr. Frank noted that institutions accounted for $1.4 billion of the total $1.8 billion outflow.
Mr. Frank said the average days to maturity of holdings in taxable funds declined to 56 days from 57.
The average seven-day compound taxable yield was unchanged at 3.79 percent, while the seven-day simple yield was also unchanged, at 3.72 percent.
At the same time, the 30-day compound yield on taxables declined 2 basis points, to 3.82 percent, and the 30-day simple yield also dropped by 2 basis points, to 3.75 percent.
The Fidelity Spartan Money Market Fund led the way as the highest-yielding taxable fund, with a yield of 4.42 percent, compared with 4.45 percent a week earlier.
By comparison, the average bank money market account, a prime competitor of money funds, was at 3.66 percent, off 2 basis points, according to The Bank Rate Monitor's national index.

HEADLINE: Surveys by Fed Find A Bit More Optimism

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 18

 BODY:
Adding to recent reports of economic upturn, the Federal Reserve said today that business sentiment nationwide was "moderately more optimistic" than it was at the beginning of the year, although some caution remained.
Based on interviews as recent as last week, the survey, which comes out eight times a year, was noticeably more upbeat than in January, when the Fed characterized economic activity as "lackluster." 
 The report, compiled from surveys by the Fed's 12 regional banks in the two months ended March 9, said that home sales, auto sales and retail sales were improving and that there was little indication of strong upward pressure on retail or wholesale prices.
 
Manufacturing 'Flat'
 The report was less buoyant about manufacturing, saying the manufacturing sector "remains generally flat, with layoffs and rising unemployment often noted." It added that commercial construction "remains moribund," but said that residential mortgage lending "is often mentioned as a bright spot."
Today's survey, which follows strong reports over the last week on retail sales, housing starts and industrial production, confirms a widespread sentiment that a recovery is starting to take hold. In reaction to these positive signs, an increasing number of economists say they doubt the Federal Reserve will lower interest rates in the near future, its usual strategy for stimulating the economy.
The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported that department store sales in the New York area were stronger than expected in January and February. The bank added that home builders in New York and New Jersey reported a "significant increase in customer interest, with actual sales improving though still light."
It said labor-market developments in the region remained unfavorable, with unemployment rising and "a continued heavy schedule of planned corporate layoffs."
The survey said that in most Federal Reserve districts, there was "guarded optimism" on the part of merchandisers, except in the West, where retail sales "remained soft." The Federal Reserve added that most districts reported increased auto sales, with only the Texas region reporting a decline.
 
Layoffs Continued
 "The manufacturing sector is probably best described as 'mixed,' " the report said. The Federal Reserve banks of New York, Minneapolis and San Francisco all reported that factory layoffs continued in their regions, while the Philadelphia, Richmond and Dallas districts saw modest gains in factory shipments or output. Several districts also reported declining inventories.
All Federal Reserve districts reported "at least modest improvement in real estate sales or residential construction or both." The Richmond, San Francisco and Chicago districts said housing prices were flat in their regions, but Minneapolis and Dallas saw some increases.
The San Francisco district noted a decline in the price of commercial buildings, while New York reported a rising vacancy rate for commercial office space.
According to the survey, several districts reported a pickup in sales of furniture and other home related goods. Several districts also mentioned that lumber prices had soared because of increased construction activity and restricted supply. The San Francisco bank said some grades of lumber were selling at record prices in the West.
Health care was the only other sector in which many districts reported large price gains.
But, reflecting the high interest rates that many banks continue to charge, the report said loan demand was "generally flat" nationwide. It also said that credit standards were "largely unchanged," which is sure to disappoint many businesses and the Bush Administration, which have complained that banks are holding back the recovery by their reluctance to make loans.
The report added that while most districts said the wave of mortgage refinancings was continuing, that trend appeared to have slackened because of the recent rise in mortgage rates. One bank economist in the Chicago region reported that several corporations were seeking financing to begin capital spending programs that had been postponed in the fourth quarter.
For New England, the survey said that retailers appeared to be emerging from the recession ahead of manufacturers, although the stores were uncertain whether their increased sales presaged a significant turnaround. The region reported weakness in its military production sector.
In the West, the survey found that economic conditions range from "persistent weakness in California to moderate growth in intermountain regions." Employment continued to fall in several sectors in that region: defense-related manufacturing, banking, law and government.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Mixed in a Slow Day; Gold Prices Continue to Fall

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was mixed in lethargic trading yesterday as investors adjusted their holdings before the release today of United States trade figures.
Gold, which is trading at its lowest levels in six years, continued to fall in nervous New York trading. Although some buyers were interested in gold at its current depressed price, they were hesitant to make major commitments because of fears the metal would remain weak, traders said. 
 Gold closed on the New York Commodity Exchange at $338.40 a troy ounce, down $1.70 from Tuesday. The Republic National Bank quoted a late price of $338.40, off $1.75.
In currency trading, dealers said they expected the dollar to remain sluggish. Investors were waiting for news that would give them an incentive to trade in either direction, they said.
Walter Simon of Bank Julius Baer & Company said traders were staking out positions before the Government's announcement today of merchandise trade figures for January.
Analysts said that transactions among other currencies dominated the markets yesterday.
The Japanese yen strengthened against all major currencies as traders waited for the Government in Tokyo to take steps to stimulate the stagnant Japanese economy. Among the anticipated moves is a drop in Japanese interest rates. The Japanese Government has indicated it will introduce measures to stimulate the economy.
Mr. Simon said there was also talk that the central bank of Malaysia dipped heavily into the market yesterday, buying yen and selling pounds and marks.
The dollar ended the day in New York at 132.30 Japanese yen, down from 132.80 late Tuesday. In Tokyo, the dollar fell to 133.20 yen from 133.32, and in London, it was quoted at 132.05 yen.
But the dollar was higher against the German mark in New York, closing at 1.6535, up from 1.6460 late Tuesday. In earlier European trading, the dollar fell to 1.6500 German marks from 1.6525.
The British pound also fell against the dollar in New York, slipping to $1.7280. from $1.7350 late Tuesday. In London, the pound rose to $1.7320 from $1.7315.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's quotes, included: 1.4965 Swiss francs, up from 1.4900; 5.6145 French francs, up from 5.5985; 1243.75 Italian lire, up from 1237.00, and 1.19425 Canadian dollars, up from 1.19315.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Issues Flat in Light Trading

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were little changed in light, listless trading yesterday.
Bond prices fell slightly early in the session, but recovered after a report on the economy compiled by regional Federal Reserve banks was released. 
 The banks reported some improvement in economic conditions, but said businesses were not adding workers to payrolls. The report emphasized that the pickup is free of inflationary pressures.
"The Fed keeps harping on the theme that inflation is not a threat," said Joseph Liro, a senior vice president and money market economist at S. G. Warburg & Company.
"And if inflation can be held at around 3 percent or so, and economic data for March and April are less robust than the February numbers, we may have seen the end of the rise in interest rates."
Michael Evans, the president of Evans Economics Inc., a Washington consulting firm, said an informal poll of the firm's clients echoed the Fed's findings.
 
No Hiring Seen Yet
 "They are all saying the same thing," Mr. Evans said. "Business is a little bit better, but they aren't going to hire anybody. And until hiring picks up, we aren't going to see much of a recovery."
While the steady deterioration in prices of Treasury securities appears over for now, traders expect difficulty in coping with record auctions of two-year and five-year notes next week and say yields on short- to intermediate-term securities may increase.
The Treasury announced yesterday that it would sell $14.75 billion worth of two-year notes on March 24, and $10.25 billion of five-year notes the next day.
The size of both auctions was increased by $500 million from the amount sold by the Treasury last month.
In when-issued trading following the announcement, the two-year notes were offered at a price to yield 5.86 percent. The five-year notes were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 7.07 percent.
 
Long Bond Is Unchanged
 In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 9930/32 , to yield 8.00 percent, unchanged from late Tuesday.
Among outstanding Treasury note issues, the 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 999/32 , down 2/32 , to yield 7.60 percent. And the 6 3/8 percent seven-year notes were offered at 9431/32 , up 1/32 , to yield 7.32 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates were unchanged.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 4.04 percent, the same rate as late Tuesday. And six-month bills were steady at a late-offered rate of 4.22 percent.
The highlight of activity in the tax-exempt municipal bond market was a negotiated sale of $717.59 million of general revenue bonds for the Massachusetts Water Resources Authority.
The offering is the third in a series that is projected to raise $5.5 billion for the cleanup of Boston Harbor.
The issue consisted of callable and noncallable bonds, most with long-term maturities.
Yields on the securities range from 6.72 percent on noncallable bonds due in 2007 to a maximum yield of 6.97 percent on bonds maturing in 2021.
 
Strong Demand for Issue
 Demand for the securities was so strong that the size of the issue was increased from $675 million.
Merrill Lynch & Company acted as lead manager for the underwriting. The securities are rated A by Moody's Investors Service and A- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
In the corporate bond market, the Treasure Island Finance Corporation, a subsidiary of Steve Wynn's Mirage Resorts Inc., offered $300 million worth of first-mortgage bonds to investors in the high-yield junk bond market.
The 9 7/8 percent securities, which mature in 2000 and are noncallable for three years, were priced at $100, or par.
Salomon Brothers acted as lead manager for the transaction. The securities are rated Ba-2 by Moody's and BB by Standard & Poor's.
In the investment-grade corporate bond market, Goldman, Sachs & Company acted as lead manager for an offering of $300 million worth of 12-year notes for E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company.
The 8 1/8 percent notes were priced at $99.701 to yield 8.164 percent, 53 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7.50 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
The securities, which are noncallable for life, are rated AA-2 by Moody's and AA by Standard & Poor's.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, traders said that prices of most issues were unchanged on the day.
And participants in the secondary market for tax-exempt securities said prices of most widely quoted issues were unchanged to up an eighth of a point.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Attacks Planned in Newspaper-Phone Company Turf War

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 18

 BODY:
The battle between telephone companies and newspapers heated up today, as the chairman of the House Judiciary Committee vowed to introduce "comprehensive" legislation favoring the publishers, and the seven Bell companies prepared a bare-knuckled counterattack.
"There is now a window of time in which Congress can take action to establish competitive safeguards before they fall to the spreading chaos of deregulatory zeal," said Representative Jack Brooks, Democrat of Texas, the committee chairman. While refusing to spell out details, Mr. Brooks has made it clear in recent hearings that he strongly favors rolling back a recent court decision and continuing restrictions on the Bell companies' ability to offer information services, as well as to manufacture equipment or enter the long-distance business. 
 The newspaper industry is waging an aggressive lobbying campaign to keep telephone companies from owning services that would compete with their own offerings and drain advertising revenue. Newspaper publishers argue that the telephone companies will use their near-monopolies on local calling to compete unfairly.
 
 
Study Critical of Newspapers
 Executives of the Bell companies plan to punch back on Thursday with a study that they said would show that newspapers often used their own local monopolies to raise advertising rates above the inflation rate or faster than the rates for radio and television. The study will cite data from dozens of cities that the Bell companies argue are dominated by newspaper monopolies.
"This issue is not about journalism," said Janice Rylander, a spokeswoman for the Pacific Telesis Group. "It's not about the First Amendment. It's about advertising revenue.
"Newspapers have a monopoly on advertising in many cities, and where they don't have a monopoly, their rates go down."
Mr. Brooks's action makes it more likely that the House will adopt a measure that reinstates at least part of the ban on information services that was included in the antitrust settlement that broke up the old Bell System in 1984. That ban was reluctantly lifted in July by Judge Harold H. Greene of the United States District Court in Washington after a Federal appeals court ordered him to reconsider the issue.
 
 
White House Position
 But the ultimate prospects for such legislation are uncertain. The House Energy and Commerce Committee has been trying to draft legislation as well, and some lawmakers on that committee favor easing the restrictions while preserving "safeguards." The White House supports the elimination of restrictions on manufacturing and information services and would almost certainly veto a bill with stiff prohibitions.
Indeed, lobbyists for some of the Bell companies are quietly betting that the House will not complete action this year. Leaders on the House telecommunications subcommittee have tried for months to come up with a measure that had enough support to survive, but have yet to introduce a bill.
In support of continued restrictions on the "Baby Bell" companies, state regulators from New York, Pennsylvania and Minnesota testified that it was virtually impossible for either state utility commissions or the Federal Communications Commission to prevent the telephone companies from abusing their monopolies.
 
 
Nynex Case Is Cited
 "History is not on our side," said Willam J. Cowan, general counsel for the New York Public Service Commission. Mr. Cowan noted that his agency had carried out an exhaustive investigation of purchasing practices by the Nynex Corporation, which was eventually charged with buying equipment at inflated prices from a subsidiary, the Material Enterprises Company.
The state commission and the F.C.C. later charged that Nynex had rolled those costs into its rate base, which is used by regulators to decide the rates a telephone company can charge. In 1990, Nynex settled charges with the F.C.C. by agreeing to pay $1.4 million and accepting a one-year price rollback.
But New York officials think that the actual overcharges may have been much greater. Mr. Cowan argued that telephone companies will always find ways to evade the rules.
Hubert H. Humphrey 3d, the Minnesota Attorney General, added that there was no pressing need to lift the restrictions. "The markets are already healthy as it is," he said.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Industry Begins to Rethink The Importance of Awards

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
As the contretemps over the Clio Awards continues, imperiling the advertising industry's best-known prize, there are indications that its problems are affecting not only other awards but the industry's predilection for measuring success by the statue.
Since June, when the Clios collapsed amid disrupted and canceled ceremonies, industry executives have been rethinking a belief that awards validate their work. 
 Yet attitudes will not be altered overnight. Yesterday, a day after Clio Enterprises Inc. filed for bankruptcy in New York, announcements were made concerning four other awards. And Ruth L. Ratny, an advertising trade publisher hoping to revive the Clios, said the filing would not disrupt her plans.
The most tangible evidence of a sea change in attitudes is the growing number of award competitions reporting declines in entries or extending their entry deadlines. For instance, entries received by the Magazine Publishers of America for its 1992 Stephen E. Kelly Award for creativity fell 25 percent from last year.
John Schenck, the association's vice president of promotion, ascribed the fall-off to "the Clio factor, that awful picture of everyone grabbing trophies off the table." His reference was to a memorable photograph on the front page of Adweek magazine last June that captured the chaos when executives rushed a stage to swipe Clio statues.
The fading of award fervor has coincided with the advertising industry's steep recession, which has dampened agencies' eagerness to spend extravagantly to enter scores of award competitions.
"The Clio debacle was found money," said Gerald M. Goldberg, president of the New York Festivals, a competition that presents awards in categories like print and broadcast advertising, "budgeted funds they didn't have to spend. Once that started, they said: 'This is a good cutback. Let's make some more.' "
While entries for the New York Festivals' print categories are higher than last year, he added, he expects radio entries to decline at least 25 percent.
Richard Kirshenbaum, executive creative director at Kirshenbaum & Bond in New York, described a deepening "resentment of awards that are considered just a money-making machine," an allusion to complaints that the Clios precipitously added categories to increase entry-fee income.
Still, he joined an advisory committee for the New Clios, as Ms. Ratny, editor and publisher of Screen magazine in Chicago, has dubbed her restoration effort.
"While I'd rather see awards that are more relevant and more supportive of the advertising community," Mr. Kirshenbaum said, "the industry has suffered. Anything that would be good for advertising now, I am supportive of."
Another committee member, Marcio M. Moreira, vice chairman and international chief creative officer at McCann-Erickson Worldwide in New York, expressed similar sentiments.
"Yes, the Clio got out of hand," he said, "and yes, it tried to cover too many categories."
He asserted that creative executives must "send a signal to advertisers that we are a responsible bunch of people, and we just don't have an artistic, hedonistic view."
"If we don't send that signal out, we'll fail," he added.
Even so, he said, "whether it is Ratny, or anybody who has a reputable background in this business, I would like the Clios to survive, because they have become a standard."
Ms. Ratny said yesterday that she would proceed with a planned production of a 1992 Clio ceremony on Sept. 14 in New York. As part of the bankruptcy filing, Wayne L. Deas, a financial adviser to Bill Evans, owner of Clio Enterprises, had sought to block her plans; Mr. Deas has disputed the contention by Ms. Ratny that a $10,000 payment she made last year to Mr. Evans bought her the Clio trademark.
Ms. Ratny is running advertisements in trade publications, created by Frankenberry, Laughlin & Constable Inc. in Milwaukee, that try to dispel concerns over Clio's fate. They humorously contrast the awards with George Armstrong Custer, Amelia Earhart and other historical figures who "never made it back."
Whether the industry will find the Clios a laughing matter is doubtful.
"What happened was so horrible and so messy, I don't know if they will ever redeem it," said John E. O'Toole, president and chief executive of the American Association of Advertising Agencies.
As for introducing other awards to fill any vacuum a Clio disappearance might create, he added, "I think maybe we have enough."

HEADLINE: Review/Film;
Idealism And Reality At Hormel

 BODY:
"American Dream" was shown as part of the 1990 New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 6, 1990. The film is at the Angelika Film Center, 611 Broadway, at Houston Street.
Barbara Kopple is well remembered as the director of "Harlan County, U.S.A.," her outstandingly fine and troubling 1977 documentary about a strike by coal miners against a power company in eastern Kentucky. Now, in her account of another walkout, this time by factory workers at the George A. Hormel Company meatpacking plant in Austin, Minn., Ms. Kopple has found and illustrated another American tragedy. 
 "American Dream," her devastating look at this strike and the profound damage it left behind, begins in the mid-1980's with a matter-of-fact look at meat processors at work. It's a dirty job, but in the town of Austin it was then also a good one, paying $10.69 an hour and providing steady employment. "American Dream" is about what happened to Austin when Hormel tried to roll back those wages to $8.25. Unlike "Harlan County, U.S.A.," which observed a more violent struggle that was simpler, "American Dream" is no David and Goliath story. The David here, Local P-9 of the meatpacking division of the United Food and Commercial Workers' Union, pits itself against two Goliaths and embarks on a suicide mission. Rebelling against both Hormel and its own international parent union, Local P-9 resisted the idea of lower wages. "The unions are getting their teeth kicked in," said Jim Guyette, the local's president. He was right.
"American Dream" begins with Ronald Reagan, since it sees his economic policies as the root of Austin's troubles. Early in the film, workers protesting the wage cut visit the home of a Hormel executive and are asked (by a wife speaking to them through a screen door), "Why do you stay if you aren't happy?" Corporate spokesmen cite "the welfare of the long-term future of the company" to counter the workers' demands. One of Local P-9's first moves, in response to such stonewalling, is to hire Ray Rogers of Corporate Campaign Inc., a one-man army whose specialty is turning media attention into a secret weapon.
Although Mr. Rogers is a colorful figure and his tactics have an element of mischief, "American Dream" is no "Roger and Me." Ms. Kopple spends much less time questioning the behavior of Hormel's management than she does studying the terrible predicament in which it places the workers. As the protest moves inevitably toward a strike, Local P-9 meets opposition from employers, its parent union and even inside its own ranks. "That'll destroy us quicker than anything will," one union member says.
Ms. Kopple's camera observes all of this at very close range, at the kitchen tables of those who are most painfully affected. When the prospect of a strike becomes inevitable, she films two brothers who are on different sides of the dispute and agree they will not speak again if one crosses the picket line. Once the strike is under way, with nonunion workers earning $10.25 an hour, she captures the misery and bewilderment of those on the picket line. "You see all these people you talk to every day, and it makes you want to cry," one picket says. Above all else, "American Dream" is about the destruction of Austin's ideals.
By the end of the film, the limb onto which P-9 has ventured has been sawed off. P-9's parent union has ousted the renegades and made its own settlement with Hormel, making no allowance for restoring jobs to those who honored the picket lines and agreeing on a $10.25 wage. It didn't take long, Ms. Kopple notes in a closing title, for Hormel to sublease the factory to a company that paid $6.50 an hour.
What hits home most powerfully in "American Dream" is the film maker's sense of how deep this damage ultimately runs. When the defeated strikers try to claim victory or when a woman tearfully packing her belongings insists, "We're not leaving, we're just taking our fight elsewhere," it's clear how crushing the full weight of this debacle will be.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Barbara Kopple's film "American Dream," which was shown at the 1990 New York Film Festival, is now at the Angelika Film Center. (Miramax)

HEADLINE: Union Rejects Pact for Buses And Subway

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
New York City bus and subway workers decisively rejected a new three-year contract yesterday, sending union leaders and transit officials back to the negotiating table and raising the possibility of work slowdowns and other disruptions by discontented transit workers.
By a ratio of nearly 2 to 1, members of Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union turned down a tentative agreement that union leaders and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority reached in January. The mail ballots, submitted over the last two weeks, were counted yesterday. 
 The local's president, Sonny Hall, said in a statement that he hoped to reopen negotiations. He said he would not rule out any options, but he also said that arbitration was not desirable and that a union walkout -- which is forbidden by state law -- was "the course of last resort."
 
'No More Money Available'
 Anonymous fliers distributed at a rally by dissident union members two weeks ago said workers should consider slowdowns and even a shutdown of the subway system during the Democratic National Convention in July if they did not obtain a more generous labor settlement.
The chairman of the transportation authority, Peter E. Stangl, said he was disappointed by the vote, and he indicated strongly that his agency would not increase its offer. He said a decline in ridership, a sharp drop in state operating subsidies and the city and state's financial distress had left the agency in a bind.
"The proposed agreement reflects the full measure of our ability to finance a labor settlement," Mr. Stangl said in a statement. "Simply put, there is no more money available."
"I will not sacrifice the quality or level of service or raise the fare again in order to meet unrealistic expectations," he added.
 
Setback for Hall
 The tentative agreement called for a raise of 4.5 percent this year and an additional 2 percent next year. The proposal also included a $1,000 payment to cover inflation since last May, when the previous contract expired.
Under the old contract, bus drivers are paid a base salary of $34,676 a year. They would have been paid $36,961 next year under the the proposed settlement. Pay for train operators would have risen to $39,325 from $36,894 and for conductors to $34,307 from $32,186..
The rejection was a clear setback for Mr. Hall, who was challenged aggressively on the contract by several dissident factions within the union that are unhappy with his leadership. It also reflected broad economic dissatisfaction among the union's rank-and-file.
Interviews with several dozen subway conductors, train operators and maintenance workers earlier this month indicated sweeping discontent with many provisions of the proposed contract and a general anger that the 32,000 unionized transit employees have been working without a contract since last May.
Opponents of the contract mounted two large protest rallies in the last month, each of which drew more than 1,000 transit workers.
But several leaders of the largest dissident union faction, called New Directions, discounted the chance of a transit shutdown. "No one wants a strike," said Cecile Clue, a subway conductor who is a member of New Directions and is also on the union local's executive board. "We're not saying strike. We can hurt them in other ways, but I can't discuss that right now."
 
Workers' Complaints
 When they reached the tentative pact in January, union leaders said it was the best they could get in a severe recession, particularly since transit officials had just approved a 10-cent fare increase and another fare increase remained a possibility this year. The Transit Authority, the subsidiary that runs the subway and buses, is still struggling to find city and state subsidies to balance its 1992 budget, even after the fare increase.
But transit workers said repeatedly in recent interviews that they thought their leaders could gain additional concessions and that the proposed raises were too small. They also said that the $1,000 payment did not constitute a raise, and that it was unacceptable because it would not have figured in their base salaries, in subsequent raises or in the calculation of their pension benefits.
The proposed contract also called for additional contributions by the Transit Authority to maintain the basic level of workers' medical benefits -- an area in which many unions have been forced to make concessions in recent years as health costs have skyrocketed.
But the tentative agreement would have required transit workers to begin paying $10 of the cost of each doctor's visit, and union members said in the interviews that they strongly opposed the provision.
Several dissident union members said yesterday that union leaders had also failed to obtain contract provisions that were important to them, like leave for fathers of newborns and measures guaranteeing alternative work assignments for pregnant women.
Under state law, the transportation authority is required to begin a new round of negotiations if Mr. Hall requests it. If no progress is made, either party could then seek a declaration of an impasse from the State Public Employment Relations Board. If the state board ruled that an impasse had been reached, the dispute would then go to arbitration.
"If they want to come in and negotiate a new contract that is going to cost us more, those negotiations are going to be very short," said Gary J. Dellaverson, the transportation authority's director of labor relations. "There is no more money available, end of discussion."
Mr. Hall, who did not respond to a request for an interview, said in his statement that the contract's rejection "represents a nationwide feeling of dissatisfaction among workers" who feel that they are bearing the burden of what he called mismanagement and misguided policies by the city, state and Federal governments.

HEADLINE: Rising Poverty Threatening Elite 'Projects'

BYLINE: By MARIA NEWMAN

 BODY:
Evelyn McClendon practically beamed as she surveyed her meticulously neat two-bedroom apartment in the St. Mary's Park Houses in the South Bronx. She has lived there, in apartment 8A, since the day the project opened 34 years ago.
"People in New York hear the word 'projects' and they think rundown and nasty," she said recently. "But it's not that way here at St. Mary's. It's terrific and I've always enjoyed it. 
 "Until last night."
That night, several weeks ago, a man was shot to death in the stairwell just outside her apartment.
Mrs. McClendon's ambivalence reflects the two faces of New York's public housing, home to 590,000 people, more than the populations of Buffalo and Rochester combined.
Throughout its 58-year history, the New York City Housing Authority has provided stable homes for hundreds of thousands of working-class citizens, and its 325 projects have never suffered the same degree of blight, danger and hopelessness as projects in other big cities.
But as a new chairwoman, Sally Hernandez-Pinero, takes over the authority, the largest in the country, she confronts increasing complaints of crime and disrepair, compounded by the prevalence of drugs and aging housing. The authority is also under pressure to reduce a waiting list of 200,000, the largest ever.
"New York City has had a history of being at the forefront of public housing -- both in terms of its decision more than 50 years ago to build it, and it is the most professional and the best managed staff in the country," said Joseph B. Rose, executive director of the nonprofit Citizens Housing and Planning Council. "But public housing throughout the country has been extremely hard-hit during these hard economic times."
Ms. Hernandez-Pinero, a 39-year-old lawyer with extensive financial and housing experience, was sworn in to her job yesterday. She lived at the Twin Parks West project in the Bronx with her family from age 16 to 26.
 
Some Problems 'Intractable'
 "I know about elevators that don't work," she told a City Council committee recently. "I know delayed repairs. I know especially about the need for a secure and amenable place to live.
"Suffice it to say that New York City public housing has its troubles -- difficult, sometimes even intractable," she said. "But we also have the bragging rights to the best public housing program in America."
Unlike those in other cities, New York's projects -- ranging from small, two-story rehabilitated tenements to sprawling mini-cities of tall towers -- are almost always 100 percent occupied. Detroit, in contrast, has about a 44 percent vacancy rate. Empty apartments are an invitation to gangs and drug dealers, housing experts say.
The New York authority "has to my knowledge never abandoned or lost a unit of housing, unlike Newark or Chicago or St. Louis," said Peter Marcuse, a Columbia professor who is writing a book on the authority. "The waiting list still far exceeds the number of units available, and that's some indication of the way it is regarded in the community."
 
Economic Balance
 New York's public housing, always intended primarily for the working poor, differs from that of other cities in its demographics. The share of families on some form of public assistance is now 28 percent, a proportion that has been slowly but steadily increasing. But in other cities the rate is as high as 90 percent, said Joseph G. Schiff, an assistant secretary of the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development. That means higher costs to the authorities for social programs and more Federal aid to support each apartment.
The authority works hard to maintain an economic balance among families on public assistance, working families with very low incomes and families with somewhat better incomes. The income limit for a family of four is $29,500 a year; the average income in 1991 was $12,173.
But because the Federal Government has required housing authorities to take in more and more people in greater need, like the homeless, the population of New York's public housing will become more dependent on the government, Mr. Schiff said.
 
Families Doubling Up
 One growing problem for the authority, which has a budget of $1.5 billion and 15,000 employees, is doubling up, largely because of a citywide lack of low-cost housing. Of 590,000 residents, the authority estimates that 130,000 are living illegally with relatives or friends.
That shortage has also kept families in the projects longer. Just over 4 percent of tenants move out each year, making the average wait for an apartment 8 to 10 years.
At the same time, crime and physical deterioration are eroding the projects' stability.
There are many projects where drug dealers have taken over entire stairwells, lobbies or elevators, where graffiti completely cover some walls and the elevators reek of urine.
Tenants tell of being mugged in elevators. Others complain about rodents, no hot water, walls mildewed from leaking pipes and elevators that constantly break down.
Tenants in the Edgemere Houses in Far Rockaway, Queens, recently went to Ms. Hernandez-Pinero's office, complaining that stoves and refrigerators in many apartments had broken but had not been replaced. Some families cannot keep food fresh, said Helene O'Brien of the Association of Community Organizations for Reform Now, or Acorn, which brought the families together.
"Families are getting sick from spoiled milk and rotten meat," she said. Plaster is falling and pipes and roofs are leaking, she said.
 
Fear of Rising Crime
 Jeanne Nathan, a spokeswoman for the authority, said records for 1991 show that all emergency complaints, like gas leaks or burst water pipes, were corrected or abated within 24 hours. Of nonemergency complaints -- they rose by 4.8 percent last year, to 2.1 million -- 1.6 percent went unattended for at least a month, but that number has been steadily dropping, Ms. Nathan said.
By far the most frequent complaint from tenants is about rising crime. Housing authority officials have long boasted that crime is lower in the projects than in the rest of the city, but statistics show it is increasing more quickly in the projects.
The number of murders in public housing has more than doubled in a decade, and the murder rate is now about the same as in the rest of the city. Last year, 200 people were killed in the projects and 944 random shootings were reported. In 1980, 89 people were killed.
Rosa Hunt, who has lived at Claremont Village Houses in the Bronx for 35 years, said fear defines the life of tenants in her project. Three bodies were found in the parking lot outside her building last summer, she said. It wasn't always like that, she said.
"That's when the Bronx was the Bronx," she said about the era three decades ago when Claremont Village was new. "It was nice then."
Now, she said, "you're afraid going out and you're afraid coming in."
Through her church, Mrs. Hunt has become involved in the Tenant Union for Public Housing, organized by the South Bronx Churches. So far, 12 projects have joined. The group plans to ask officials to assign armed security guards to every building.
 
The Scourge of Drugs
 The Housing Authority's own police force of 2,200 patrols the projects, but the officers themselves concede that the increase in drug-related crime is difficult to control.
Officer Eugene F. Madden and his partner, Officer Kenneth C. Finn, see it in the area they patrol in Brooklyn, which includes East New York and has one of the highest concentrations of projects and one of the highest rates of police calls.
One day recently, the two officers' 4 P.M.-to-midnight shift began with a call about a sniper shooting from the roof of the Louis H. Pink Houses on Linden Boulevard. A man and his young son were injured; the police never found the sniper.
"It's usually drug dealers who come up here to test their firearms," Officer Madden said, pointing to a heater pockmarked with bullet holes.
Ms. Hernandez-Pinero knows that being landlord to one of every 12 New York City residents will not be easy.
 
Tenant Participation
 She said in a recent interview that she would make maintenance her top priority. She wants to set a deadline of 24 hours to fix broken front door locks, and is considering a policy for cleaning graffiti within a few hours.
"We can't 100 percent solve the security issue, because there are crime problems; there is a crack problem," she said. "We can't unilaterally solve those. But the maintenance issues are much more within our control. So that's why I've made that our primary focus."
That is not to say she is conceding some projects to drug dealers and other criminals. The authority is working with the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration and has stepped up its own police patrols at about 40 different sites, she said.
But Ms. Hernandez-Pinero said that tenant participation was the most important factor in making any project more livable, and that she would work to encourage it "Without the tenants it can't work," she said. "That is the absolute prerequisite for turning around a project, because they are there every day."

HEADLINE: Improv, in Chapter 11 Protection, Is Still Joking

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI

 BODY:
It is no laughing matter. The Improvisation on Manhattan's West 44th Street -- grandfather of comedy clubs and spawning ground for a virtual Hall of Fame of comics -- has filed for bankruptcy protection.
The 29-year-old club, a victim of the recession, will stay open for the time being. Seven comics and a master of ceremonies appeared last night. The schedule was full for every night this week, the manager, Errol Edwards, said yesterday. 
 The Improv's owner, Silver Friedman, could not be reached for comment. But in court documents filed on Tuesday, she said the club "operated profitably until losses were sustained because of the recession, causing the debtor to fall behind." Under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, the club is protected from its creditors as it tries to reorganize. It listed assets of $55,000 and liabilities of $270,043.
The Improv opened at 358 West 44th Street, at Ninth Avenue, on April 20, 1963, the first of a breed of clubs that let aspiring comics try their routines, and possibly fall on their faces, before a tough public.
 
Well-Known Survivors
 On a wall just inside the club's front door are photographs of some of the Improv's alumni, including Richard Pryor, Whoopi Goldberg and Robin Williams. "They all come through and become famous after starting here," Mr. Edwards said.
Among others who have played there over the years are David Brenner, Robert Klein, Steve Landesberg, Stiller and Meara, Professor Irwin Corey, Rodney Dangerfield, Jimmy Walker, the late Andy Kaufman and Richard Lewis.
Mr. Lewis once said that he began hanging out at the Improv "in 1973, long before every carpet store in America started having 'Remnant Comedy Riot Night.' " The actor Danny Aiello worked as a bouncer and Bette Midler was a waitress at the Improv.
The club was founded by Ms. Friedman's former husband, Budd. In 1973 Mr. Friedman moved to Los Angeles and established an Improv there. The Manhattan club has always been an informal place where where agents and other performers come to see who and what is new in the business.
And there have been impromptu comic jam sessions at the club, like the time Joe Piscopo and Gilbert Gottfried were suddenly joined onstage by Robin Williams, or when Stevie Wonder came up and, ignoring the piano, did 20 minutes of stand-up.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (79%); 

STATE: CALIFORNIA, USA (67%);

HEADLINE: WILLIAMSBRIDGE JOURNAL;
If Only, an Inventor Says, He Could Invent Capital

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ

 BODY:
For more than a decade, Wilbert Murdock has struggled to market his inventions -- gadgets ranging from a computerized golf club that corrects mistakes in the swing to a motion analysis system that could help doctors and coaches provide better treatment for sports and other injuries.
Name a problem and the self-described "George Washington Carver of technology" will offer inventive suggestions to do the work faster and quicker. But his degrees in bioengineering and constant tinkering have yet to rig up a solution to his biggest hurdle -- lack of capital. 
 No stranger to necessity, you could call him the brother of invention.
"A lot of people don't like the way I look," said Mr. Murdock, neatly dressed in a conservatively cut blue suit. "The people I met in the investment community are not comfortable with my outer skin."
Mr. Murdock, who is black, is the chairman of Motiontronics for Science, a company he and several friends founded to develop and manufacture computer-based sports simulators and biomechanical analysis instruments that could be used for training and physical rehabilitation.
He left a job at a Veterans Administration hospital to devote himself full time to the venture, financing his research through temporary office work, investments from his parents and the support of his partners.
His single-minded pursuit has cost him his car and his apartment -- he lives with his mother in Williamsbridge, in the northeast Bronx -- and he frets that perhaps he has wasted 10 years of his life.
"I don't understand how we can give billions to the world, and I can't get anything," said Mr. Murdock, who is 34 years old. "Before I lost my father last year, he always repeated to me -- what's most important is the mission, the goal. Personal things mean little if you're trying to help your country."
Mr. Murdock said he and his company spent thousands of dollars to develop the Computerized Golf Master, which helps golfers perfect their swings to hit the "sweet spot" by using audible tones to tell them if they are hitting the ball too far outside or inside on the club.
A buyer at a major toy retailer who has seen the golf club said it was an "interesting" product with market potential. Other people familiar with both Mr. Murdock's inventions and his work as a student said they were impressed with his creativity and determination.
In describing his design approach, Mr. Murdock sounded almost Zen-like. "I became the golf ball," he said. "I designed the technology around the golf ball because it is the only variant that does not change. We had to make the golf club intelligent."
His interest in sports also led him to design a computerized shadow boxing system that uses sensors to tell sparring partners standing six feet apart when they have connected a punch.
He has patented a brace-like knee alignment device that detects stresses and strains. A similar interest in biomechanics led to the development of a motion analysis system that compares stored images of optimal physical performance with videotaped images of a person performing a similar series of physical movements. He said his system costs a third of those being currently used in hospitals.
All that matters little without financing, which is difficult to get for some high-tech medical devices, according to Joel Snyder, a member of the Motiontronics board of directors.
"Financial people feel the medical electronics field has a low return on income," said Mr. Snyder, who is also a professor of engineering and computer science at Polytechnic University, Mr. Murdock's alma mater.
In his quest for money, Mr. Murdock has deluged politicians and government officials with letters, but no money has come his way. He also shot back to a Japanese publication that had published an article denigrating the creativity and work habits of American minorities.
"I wrote to them that the only traits we have that are negative is our lack of access to economic opportunity," said Mr. Murdock.
Mr. Murdock says he would like to use his inventions to build a company that would employ urban youths and minorities.
"Without interesting them in technology, the technological race in this country is over," he said. "They are the work force of the future."
His latest brainstorm is a sports technology learning center where he would use his sports inventions to get young people interested in computers and innovation.
"It just takes a few things to turn this thing around, this kids killing kids," he said. "Nobody comes from nowhere. They need to know they fit into this society."
Typically, he does not have a penny to finance the venture, but he said he hoped to persuade computer manufacturers to donate equipment. If need be, he would go back to working at odd jobs to help raise funds.
"All we ever wanted was a chance," he said. "Not promises, just a real chance to build a real company."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "The people I met in the investment community are not comfortable with my outer skin," said Wilbert Murdock, chairman of Motiontronics for Science. He held one of his inventions, a computerized golf club. (Nancy Siesel for The New York Times)
