HEADLINE: New Haven Is the Target of Inquiry

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN, March 18

 BODY:
Federal investigators swooped down on this city's municipal offices this week, taking away boxes of documents that may figure in a fraud inquiry focusing on the rehabilitation of a rundown commercial area.
It is the third Federal investigation of a major Connecticut city's government in three years, and some here are wondering why the state seems suddenly to be a favorite target for United States attorneys. 
 "Until a couple of years ago, a Federal municipal government corruption investigation was unheard of," said Hugh Keefe, a New Haven lawyer who is defending the former Mayor of Waterbury, Joseph J. Santopietro, against Federal corruption charges in a trial in Bridgeport. Mr. Keefe also defended the former Mayor of Danbury, James E. Dyer, in a 1990 Federal corruption case in which Mr. Dyer was convicted of filing a false income-tax return, but acquitted of other tax charges as well as racketeering and extortion.
 
Cases Are a Priority
 An expert with the American Bar Association in Washington said the recent rash of Connecticut cases may reflect a particular emphasis by the United States Attorney, Albert S. Dabrowski, but it also shows that such cases are a priority for the Department of Justice.
"Connecticut has no monopoly on public corruption," said the expert, Tom Smith, the associate director of the association's criminal justice section. "There has been a Federal presence in prosecuting local political corruption for many years that has reached high levels and low levels."
In 1989, 1,349 public officials were indicted nationwide and 1,149 of them convicted, said Doug Tillett, a spokesman for the Justice Department. Each case "involved abuse of the public trust," he said.
Details remain sketchy in the New Haven case, since the United States Attorney's office and the Federal Bureau of Investigation refused to comment on it. They are conducting the investigation along with the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development.
A subpoena served on Tuesday at City Hall demanded that officials turn over documents related to a business-relocation program that ran from 1987 to this year. Under the program, Federal money was used to help business owners move from the dilapidated Ninth Square neighborhood so that it could be rebuilt as a complex of apartments and stores.
The subpoena, dated March 12, also demands applications and requests made to the city for loans from the Small Business Administration and the Women and Minority Business and Development programs from January 1987 to December 1989. It also demands documents "relating in any way to services performed or offered to be performed" by a local company called Fucci Construction, also between January 1987 and December 1989.
 
Daniels Pledges His Help
 All documents requested predate the term of the current Mayor, John C. Daniels, who took office in 1990. Efforts today to reach his predecessor, Biagio DiLieto, who is also a former police chief here, were unsuccessful.
In a statement issued Tuesday, Mr. Daniels pledged his "continued cooperation" and added, "It is my sincere hope that this issue, as painful and difficult as it is, will be brought swiftly and equitably to a close."
Nancy A. Fucci, the owner of Fucci Construction, said, "I've been in contact with the U.S. Attorney's office and I've indicated that we're willing to cooperate in any way necessary to assist them in this investigation."
All work her 50-employee company did for the city, she said, was awarded because the company made the lowest bids. Most of the projects were for street improvements, such as installing benches and lights and replacing asphalt with brick paving.
John J. Sennett, a spokesman for the F.B.I. in New Haven, said, "No specific individual or individuals are being targeted in this investigation," and added, "we are only pursuing allegations of wrongdoing, and the investigation will take us where it takes us."
A state investigation of a similar city-financed program resulted in the arrests of 11 people last year. That program, known as the Neighborhood Commercial Revitalization Program, repaid people for up to $15,000 in renovation work on properties in designated neighborhoods around the city.
Investigators charged that it became riddled with false applications for reimbursement from people applying on behalf of properties they did not own or inflating claims of how much they spent on renovations.

HEADLINE: Not All Bounces Are Bad

 BODY:
The scandal at the House Bank is generating a storm of criticism out of proportion to the sins committed. Whatever sloppiness occurred -- and whatever shady acts may have been performed by a few -- the scandal threatens to tar unjustly the reputations of scores if not hundreds of representatives whose offenses appear minor.
Perks like the bank are galling because they reflect a self-indulgent legislature that is often sorely out of touch with the real world. But as voters ponder the overdrawn checks of their own representatives, they need to discriminate carefully between major abuses or even crimes, if there were any, and minor transgressions. 
 What most inflames the public is the spectacle of "privileged" Congressmen getting a benefit (free overdraft privileges) that is not available to the average person. The bank did its best to keep House members happy, providing yet another example of how many members live in a cocoon, insulated from the pressures that make life miserable for many constituents. That may help some legislators concentrate on their jobs; but others no doubt lose touch with real-life concerns.
In contrast to most banking scandals, this one does not appear to have victimized anybody financially. The House members were not guilty of writing "bad" checks that "bounced," leaving the recipients of the checks without payment. The House Bank honored nearly all the checks, even if the members did not have enough money in their accounts to cover them.
The accurate charge, then, is that many members "overdrew" their accounts without having to pay the high interest or service fees that ordinary mortals must pay for overdrafts. But no taxpayer funds were used to cover the overdrafts. Instead the House Bank used money from the accounts of other members, who were in effect making interest-free loans to their overdrawn colleagues. But it cost them nothing to do so because they were not earning any interest on their own accounts.
Many of those caught up in the scandal have offered persuasive defenses. Dick Cheney, now Defense Secretary, said he was dismayed to find he wrote at least 21 checks against insufficient funds while a Congressman from Wyoming. Mr. Cheney, who prides himself on paying bills promptly and avoiding purchases on credit, said he had no way of knowing of the overdrafts. Under the bank's haphazard administration he was never notified, and the bank routinely jiggered its monthly statements to show that accounts were in balance.
Even one of the worst offenders, Stephen Solarz, Democrat of Brooklyn, who wrote hundreds of overdraft checks over a 39-month period, may have done little more than treat his account as if it were an American Express card. As he explains it, he and his wife paid monthly expenses from the account, were informed by the bank when they were in overdraft and promptly, within a week or two, deposited enough money to cover the deficiency. They did not, he insists, use the bank to obtain a long-term interest-free loan that rolled over from month to month.
The House ethics committee found that 24 members, including Mr. Solarz, seriously abused their privileges, but has yet to release details. If there were cases of fraud, tax evasion or campaign finance violations, they should be prosecuted. And writing overdraft checks to invest elsewhere for personal gain might raise ethical questions.
But as voters feel their blood pressure rising in anger over the scandal, they need to measure the overdraft issue carefully. In choosing a legislator to handle issues ranging from the economy to education reform to world affairs and national defense, overdrafts will generally be a minor consideration.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
A New South Africa

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
A political-science theory used to have it that no group holding absolute power in a modern society would ever give it up short of physical overthrow. Thus Jeane Kirkpatrick propounded that Communist totalitarianism in any country could not be ended by political means.
The theory was shattered as to Communism by the Gorbachev years and the fall of the Soviet Union. Now something just as dramatic has happened in South Africa: The whites who had absolute power in that society have voted to give it up. 
 This was not a mere decision to let a minority have civil rights, as in the American South 25 years ago. It was a decision to let the overwhelming majority, 80 percent of the population, have rights. The result must be power for that majority.
How did it happen? Why would a privileged minority -- very likely the most privileged in the world -- take such a step?
The broad answer is that politics worked: politics both local and international. The "armed struggle" by black resistance groups never made a dent in the power structure. Political pressure and political leadership persuaded whites that their own best interests lay in peaceful transition to a democratic South Africa.
Economic sanctions were much debated. But no one can really doubt, now, that they were effective in making businessmen and more and more white individuals in South Africa see that apartheid had no prosperity in its future.
Sanctions also produced a sense of isolation that bore heavily on many South Africans. So did the international sports boycott, which greatly troubled a sport-loving people.
There was a moral element. Along with international disapproval came increasing religious condemnation of apartheid, finally by the Afrikaners' own Dutch Reformed Church.
All those factors worked over time. But there is no saying when they would have changed the racial system if it had not been for the political daring and courage of F. W. de Klerk. In two and one-half years as President he has transformed the country, opening it up to free political debate for the first time and negotiating with the black leadership.
Mr. de Klerk's boldest stroke was the calling of a referendum among whites on whether to continue on his path of change. He risked all. With violence rising in the country, and with the economy in a prolonged recession, many observers thought the white public would be frightened of change and would at best give Mr. de Klerk a narrow victory.
But the conservative opposition offered no real alternative to the voters, no vision of a workable system of white power. It offered only fantasies of a separate white state or a return to apartheid and legal tyranny over the black majority.
Faced with that choice, most whites understood that non-racial democracy, though a gamble, gave them more hope than a return to racism and isolation. They had a realistic chance, at least, of keeping much of their good life. That was the calculation that led the British upper classes to enlarge the franchise in the 19th century, trading some political power for continued economic privilege.
The 69 percent yes vote for Mr. de Klerk should open the way to early agreement in the negotiations on an interim government of all races. The parties have already agreed on much: votes for all adults, a judicially enforceable bill of rights and an elected body of some kind to write a new constitution.
It would be fatuous to predict an easy transition for President de Klerk and his essential negotiating partner, Nelson Mandela. There are still enormous obstacles to a peaceful, functioning democracy in South Africa.
The huge gap between blacks and whites -- in income, property, education -- would stagger any social system. The expectations of younger blacks for quick economic benefits are dangerously high.
And then there is the violence. Growing evidence suggests that much of it has been inspired by Gatsha Buthelezi, the Zulu leader, to force concessions to him. But there is also evidence that elements in the state security forces have engaged in random violence against blacks, to obstruct change. A big question is whether Mr. de Klerk can and will stop that.
But the change to a new South Africa cannot now be stopped.

HEADLINE: Socialism Makes Everybody Equally Poor

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 I strongly disagree with Andrew Schotter in "Improve Capitalism. Use Some Socialism" (Op-Ed, Feb. 29). He calls for more socialism to deal with poverty and health care problems. Mr. Schotter gives us an excellent example of a mother of four, stating that "the economic battle for her is probably lost." 
 I think Mr. Schotter does not know what real poverty is. I lived for 35 years in Russia, where my next door neighbor was Anna Uskov, a mother of six children, who lost her husband in World War II. The family lived in a single room with a kitchen shared with four other tenants, no water supply and no bathroom.
Most of the time the kids were hungry, and they ran barefoot in the snow because their mother was unable to provide shoes for them. When the oldest daughter married, for years she slept with her husband and two small children in the same bed. There was no welfare for that family because the fathers of socialism Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels decreed, "If you do not work, you do not eat."
The streets of our suburb were infested by crime, yet all the children in my neighbor's family became good and decent citizens. The mother worked hard as a janitor, and in the most important corner of their tiny apartment hung a traditional Russian icon, the symbol of God. The love and strong belief in moral norms, not Government programs, gave them the key to success.
In no country in the world has socialism, even in small portions, made people happy. Not in Russia and not in Sweden, which has the highest rate of suicides in the world. Our problem is not that we don't have enough socialism; it is that we have too much of it.
The way socialism works is this: By distributing the wealth, it does not make all the people rich. It makes all the people poor.
 
JEFF MANEVICH
Cliffside Park, N.J., Feb 29, 1992

HEADLINE: Socialism Makes Everybody Equally Poor;
Huge Inequities

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Andrew Schotter (Op-Ed, Feb. 29) writes: "In a capitalist system, people are in effect paid according to how much society would lose if it were to do without their services." This is a myth perpetuated by ideologists of the right. That it is picked up and repeated by one who advocates government intervention to correct inequities that arise when markets allocate resources shows how successful those ideologists have been. 
 However, in our free market society there is no definite relationship between what people are paid and their contribution to social welfare. This becomes clear if we compare the earnings of a teacher or a police officer or a social worker or a research scientist with the $4.5 million that Lee Iacocca made as chairman of Chrysler Corporation, the $7.6 million earned by the 17-year-old tennis star Monica Seles, the $54 million that the New Kids on the Block took in for their music, Madonna's $24 million, the fabulous sums made from advertising or selling tobacco and alcohol or the millions won by people who pick the right numbers in lotteries.
Nor is there necessarily a relationship between how hard people work and their relative standard of living. Many people, for example, live better off returns from inherited assets than those who must depend on wages and salaries alone. Indeed, there is really no good moral justification for the extent of the wealth and income inequalities that exist in our country.
We have 60 families or individuals who have a net worth of $1 billion or more. If they hold their wealth in interest-bearing accounts, they will take home $50 million a year or $137,000 a day for doing nothing. At the other extreme are the more than 33.6 million people (13.5 per cent of the population) with almost no assets and annual incomes below the poverty line. Over the last 15 years the real income of these people has declined, while the real income of the rich has increased.
Yes, as Mr. Schotter and others point out, our capitalist system has made us one of the most productive countries in the world. We produce enough to provide every individual in the country with $22,000 worth of goods and services a year. And yet we do such a bad job of distributing that output that more than 33 million citizens, 40 percent of them children, live in families that lack adequate housing, good health care or many of the other goods and services that have been defined as necessities.
Therefore, as Mr. Schotter suggests, we need to do more to help the poor. But at the expense of this issue and other issues relating to the inequitable distribution of wealth and income in the United States, the Presidential candidates and the news media devote their attention to economic growth. Thus, everybody knows that the rate of growth of output in Japan is faster than here. But how many know that the income of the richest 20 percent of the population to the poorest 20 percent is 9 to 1 in our country but only 4 to 1 in Japan?
Until we do something about the inequalities reflected by this second set of statistics, no matter how fast the United States grows, we will always be behind.
 
PAUL CANTOR
Norwalk, Conn., March 1, 1992
 
The writer is a professor of economics at Lehman College, CUNY.

HEADLINE: Japan Has Learned From Bypassed Giants

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "How Economic Empires Are Born" (Op-Ed, Feb. 25), Jean Strouse finds in the relationship between the United States and Japan echoes of the economic confontation between Britain and the United States in the late 1800's. Writing of Andrew Carnegie's long-term view, she asks, "Sound familiar?" This question recalls a statement by John Maynard Keynes in his "General Theory": "Practical men, who believe themselves to be quite exempt from any intellectual influences, are usually the slaves of some defunct economist." 
 The economist statesman whose theories are implicit in the article is Alexander Hamilton (1757-1804). In his "Report on Manufacturers" (1791), Hamilton states that the future of the American economy lay in the development of its industrial base. To that end he advocated its protection, an approach that has been derided: the fallacy of the infant industry argument.
Historical evidence suggests that Britain, America and now Japan have used this policy to their advantage at various times. Yes, this is familiar territory.
 
TOM CATE
Associate Professor of Economics

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Primaries;
TSONGAS ABANDONS CAMPAIGN, LEAVING CLINTON A CLEAR PATH TOWARD SHOWDOWN WITH BUSH

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 19

 BODY:
Former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts withdrew from the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination today, a decision that many in his party said all but insured the selection of Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas.
Mr. Tsongas announced his departure at a news conference in Boston, where he said his campaign did not have enough money to continue. His move leaves only former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California to compete with Mr. Clinton in the remaining primaries and caucuses in 21 states. 
 Without adequate money to win, Mr. Tsongas said, "the alternative was to play the role of spoiler."
 
'That Is Not Worthy'
 "That is not what I'm about," he continued. "That is not worthy. I did not survive my ordeals in order to be the agent of the re-election of George Bush." [Excerpts, page A14.]
Mr. Clinton is already close to the halfway mark in the number of delegates needed to win the nomination and has a 7-to-1 edge over Mr. Brown, who is running a maverick, anti-establishment campaign. Many Democrats said that barring an unexpected collapse by Mr. Clinton's campaign, it is difficult to see how Mr. Brown can overtake the Governor.
"It certainly brings it much closer to a conclusion," said Ronald H. Brown, the Democratic national chairman. "You could argue that it's theoretically possible for Jerry Brown to mount a come-from-behind challenge, but the math and the reality of Bill Clinton's momentum certainly work against him."
Mr. Brown, campaigning in Connecticut, vowed to stay in the Democratic race until the end and seemed to relish a head-to-head contest with the well-financed front-runner.
"It's not over, because this is not just a game of politicians," the former California Governor said in an interview on the Cable News Network. He said the "soul of the Democratic Party is up for grabs."
Mr. Clinton hailed Mr. Tsongas at a rally in Hartford tonight but was clearly focused on the general election, delivering fierce criticism of Mr. Bush.
"He's acting like he's been on Mars for the last three years and just dropped down and can't believe what a mess people made of things," the Governor said as he attacked economic burdens on the middle class.
At a news conference afterward, Mr. Clinton declared: "I don't want to give anyone the impression that the race is over. I'm going to do my best to wage a national campaign."
Mr. Tsongas, whose campaign soared with his victory in New Hampshire's primary just a month ago, stunned much of the political world with his decision.
He was the third Democrat to withdraw from the race in the last two weeks, following Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska and Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, as the rapid succession of primaries took a heavy toll on a field that was politically young, late to get started and always scrambling for money. Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia dropped out of the race before even getting to the primaries.
Mr. Tsongas had lost heavily in the South last week and was widely seen as crippled by his losses in Tuesday's primaries in Michigan and Illinois. Still, he had been expected to fight on through next week's primary in Connecticut and the April 7 vote in New York.
But at his news conference, which was remarkably good-humored although tinged with regret, he said:
"The hard fact is that the nomination process requires resources, and last evening it was clear that we did not have the resources necessary to fight the media war in New York. We simply did not have the resources. I would have been defined by others, and have been unable to defend myself. Worse, my message, my message would have been wounded, and all that we worked for, for this past year, would have been put at risk."
And so, he said, he decided to abandon his campaign, bringing an end to what he described as "a hell of a ride."
Mr. Tsongas, who left the Senate in 1984 to battle cancer and underwent a successful bone marrow transplant more than five years ago, had cloaked his campaign throughout as an enterprise of serious moral purpose.
Many Democrats today hailed him for bringing a new focus on economics to the political debate. He had campaigned as the economic truthteller in the field -- "I'm no Santa Claus" was his rallying cry -- and urged such against-the-grain policies for the Democrats as a cut in the tax on capital gains to encourage investment, and a rejection of a tax cut for the middle class. Many of his positions, he asserted today, cost him political contributions.
Mr. Tsongas's supporters, who stuck with him through the long months of 1991 when many analysts viewed his campaign as a decidedly minor one, cheered today when he declared: "We stood for something. We stood for something."
 
Talk of Unity
 The former Senator said today that he was "suspending" his campaign, rather than officially withdrawing, a technicality that keeps many of his delegates from being automatically redistributed to Mr. Clinton and Mr. Brown. Mr. Tsongas said he was declining to endorse either of the candidates at this stage.
But the attitude among many party leaders today was that the race was winding down. Many said it was time for the party to begin turning its attention to the battle against Mr. Bush.
"I think we have the chance to bring the party together around the presumptive nominee as early as I've ever seen it," said Steven Grossman, the chairman of the Massachusetts Democratic Party. Phil Angelides, the chairman in California, said, "Today is really the day we start the general election campaign against George Bush."
Mr. Angelides and many other Democrats said Mr. Clinton needed to keep campaigning hard in the coming primaries to define himself for the fall election.
According to a compilation by The New York Times, Mr. Clinton had 991 delegates this week, while Mr. Brown had 143. It takes 2,145 delegates to secure the nomination. The Democratic rules allocate delegates on the basis of strict proportional representation -- rather than winner-take-all -- which means that it could still take considerable time for Mr. Clinton to attain the magic number. But those same rules make it harder for Mr. Brown to catch fire late, win some big states and overtake him.
"George Bush will secure his magic number before Bill Clinton, but it seems inevitable that both of them will reach their magic number, sooner rather than later," said Peter Hart, a Democratic poll taker.
 
A 'Dangerous' Brown
 Still, Mr. Hart and many other Democrats caution that Mr. Clinton still has a race to run, against an opponent who delights in flouting the conventions of politics. "Jerry Brown is going to be extremely dangerous," Mr. Hart said, "because in essence he's going to be the Che Guevara of the 1992 Presidential election. He'll go anywhere and fight with any tools available."
In Michigan, where he knocked Mr. Tsongas out of second place, Mr. Brown showed he could court disaffected labor. John A. Marino, the Democratic state chairman in New York, said Mr. Brown's appeal to labor, coupled with the fact that he is now the only choice for the anti-Clinton vote, would make Mr. Brown a serious factor in the New York primary.
"I think Brown gives him a run in New York if Brown spends time in New York," Mr. Marino said.
Moreover, Mr. Brown has shown a willingness to push hard on the "character issues" that have dogged Mr. Clinton, most recently questions about his wife's partnership in a law firm doing business with the State of Arkansas.
Mr. Brown, the party chairman, seemed to be trying to send a warning today to Mr. Clinton's sole remaining challenger. "Jerry Brown is a former Governor, a former state party chairman, and this is his third run for the White House," he said. "I hope and I expect that he is as anxious to beat George Bush as I am. I would hope and trust that would cause him to focus on the issues."
But the former California Governor has based his campaign on attacks against career politicians and the way they do business. In Connecticut today he asserted: "If you feel things are more or less O.K., that's Bill Clinton. If you feel this country is decidely on the wrong track, this is your campaign."
Mr. Clinton spoke with Mr. Tsongas by telephone this morning, soon after learning of the former Senator's withdrawal, said George Stephanopoulos, the Clinton deputy campaign manager. "Clinton was a little overwhelmed by the news," Mr. Stephanopoulos said.
Mr. Clinton still has considerable work to do, not least of which is courting New York, an important part of any Democratic coalition.
Many Democrats, including many committed to Mr. Clinton, took pains today to praise Mr. Tsongas, who entered the race almost a year ago, when Mr. Bush was near 90 percent in the public opinion polls and when the silence on the Democratic Presidential front was deafening.
"When other people looked at the polls, Paul Tsongas looked at what needed to be done for the country," Mr. Angelides said.
Mr. Tsongas's message of bitter economic medicine played well among educated, affluent suburbanites, but seemed to fall flat among core Democratic constituencies like blacks and labor. Still, he said today that he believed he had helped alter the debate. And in the end, he added, he sat down Wednesday night and made the kind of hard choices he believes the nation needs to make.
"This is not a day for regrets," he said this afternoon.

HEADLINE: Warmest Winter Slips (on Ice) Into History

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Winter, or what there was of it, ended this morning at 3:48 A.M. Eastern time. The National Weather Service is counting this winter as the warmest in the 97 years records have been kept.
Nationwide the average temperature from December through February (the Weather Service's "winter," for record-keeping purposes) was about 4 degrees Fahrenheit above normal, but that hid large variations. Eastern Montana was 11 degrees above normal; Chicago was 6 degrees above normal. Major Northeast cities recorded temperatures 2 degrees above normal. 
 But the weather statisticians could tell without looking at the numbers. "I didn't put on my long underwear this year," said Dr. David R. Rodenhuis, director of the National Weather Service's climate analysis center in Camp Springs, Md., near Washington.
Some public officials and people worried about the environment fear that rather than just talking about the weather, people are doing something to it, releasing pollutants that are changing the global climate. But scientists remain skeptical that a single North American winter, or even the string of warm years since the late 1980's, is evidence of a long-term global trend.
Still, said Dr. John W. Firor, a specialist in the greenhouse effect at the National Center for Atmospheric Research in Boulder, Colo., "their resolution to be skeptical" had been weakened."
As if to demonstrate the variability of nature, the last full day of winter produced snow across a broad band of the Northeast, in some cases the only major snowfall of the season. In fact, the last few days of winter came with a blast of cold air, a phenomenon that Natural Gas Intelligence, a weekly newsletter, called "Indian Winter." It said the weather arrived "as if to tease producers about what might have been." Gas is the largest winter heating fuel, and this was the second year in a row of low gas use.
"We had a normal winter about three years ago," C. J. Silas, president of Phillips Petroleum, said with a nostalgic glow, referring to an extended cold stretch in December 1989. "It was cold for three weeks. We used to have a month or two of that."
Mr. Silas, who is chairman of the oil and gas industry's main trade association, the American Petroleum Institute, said his industry did not know what was going on. "We haven't found a consultant to explain it," he said. "We could go to church, maybe, and talk to them."
In Glasgow, Mont., where it was 11 degrees warmer than normal, there were few regrets. "It's been a beautiful winter," said Nancy Runningen, the office manager in the city water department. "Right now there is no snow, my tulips are up and sticking their noses out, and I've seen a few robins."
 
Need for Rain
 She recalled one winter when the temperature stayed below zero for 78 straight days; this year, the temperature climbed above zero almost every day, she said. But the temperature was not the most important oddity of this year, she said. Local farmers and ranchers will miss the moisture if it does not rain soon, she said. Along with Montana, Idaho, Oregon and Wyoming experienced one of the five driest winters in the last 97 years.
Around the United States, the only areas where temperatures were not above normal were parts of western Maine, the central Rockies and northern and western Alaska, according to the climate analysis center.
The Government figures, for the sake of simplicity, count winter as running from Dec. 1 until the end of February, although astronomically winter runs from late December through late March, when the sun crosses the Equator in the vernal equinox.
While North America was warm again, the North Atlantic was colder, and so was North Africa. Jerusalem had more than a foot of snow, and Cyprus had its first snow in 40 years. Athens, Beirut and Shanghai, where it rarely snows, all had snow this winter.
Siberia and Eastern Europe were also warmer than normal, according to meteorologists.
A short-term explanation of the weather may be the existence this year of El Nino, a current in the Pacific Ocean that flows toward South America, and is generally correlated with warmer weather in the midwestern United States.
Drawing a global picture is difficult, said Dr. Firor, and generalizing from the experience here is risky. "The U.S. is in the neighborhood of 6 percent of the globe," he said. "We don't amount to a hill of beans in the grand average." Another problem is that while temperature in this country is recorded on 10,000 thermometers, the South Atlantic, which is an area almost as large, has 2. "We've got a real problem with the data set," he said.
"I am a firm believer that the world is in deep trouble," he said. "We are going to have a climate change that is too rapid for easy adaptation." But the data are not adequate to support that, he said.
Dr. Rodenhuis said that the calendar year 1991 was the second-warmest year on record, considering air temperature over land around the world. The warmest was 1990. Globally, he said, 7 of the past 10 calendar years were warmer than average, which he said was not proof of global warming, "but part of the growing evidence."
Daniel H. Graf, a meteorologist at the Weather Communications Group at Penn State University, said: "The major climate events are cast in terms of tens of thousands of years. We have a record of 97 years that we work with here in the U.S. "You would figure that every 100 years you would have an unusual group of years. It's hard to say if that's really something bizarre. If you were to have 1,000 years of records, you'd see a lot of strange things."
Is it global climate change? "We don't have proof," he said. "We have some concerns."
Though the causes of the recent warm winters in this country may be in doubt, there is little doubt about the effects on energy suppliers. Warm winters meant lower heating bills for almost everyone. Nationally, the demand for heat was down about 10 percent this heating season compared with normal demand, according to Weather Service statistics. On the West Coast, it was nearly 14 percent lower than normal. The south Atlantic area was 11.5 percent warmer than usual and the mid-Atlantic region was 10 percent warmer.
This is of most importance to gas producers, because gas heats more than half the nation's homes. Electricity has the second-largest share, followed by oil, but oil companies say that because most oil is used in transportation, mild winters do not have a major effect on oil prices. But gas prices are at their lowest in 10 years.
The gas industry has numerous problems, said Theodore Eck, an economist at Amoco, which holds extensive gas properties, and warm weather is simply adding to the problems. But, he vowed, "We will have winter, one of these years."
Another gas expert, Robert A. Hefner 3d of the GHK Company, of Oklahoma City, a gas producer, said: "Nature is fickle. You'll have some good ones and some bad ones." But the experience of the last few years, he said, was that "we can't live for the next cold winter." Gas companies will have to cut overhead to survive, he said, and to seek regulatory changes.

HEADLINE: INVESTIGATORS SAY U.S. SHIELDED IRAQIS FROM BANK INQUIRY

BYLINE: By DEAN BAQUET, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 19

 BODY:
Enmeshed in a doomed courtship with Saddam Hussein, the Bush Administration in 1989 and 1990 repeatedly frustrated its own criminal investigators and regulators examining Iraq's role in a multibillion-dollar bank fraud scheme in Atlanta, interviews and internal Government documents say.
Government investigators involved in the case said they were blocked by the State Department from traveling overseas to interview key witnesses and suspects. 
 Additionally, the State Department discouraged prosecutors from filing criminal charges against a Jordanian shipper with extensive political and diplomatic connections, and against the Central Bank of Iraq, Justice Department and State Department documents show.
 
Fierce Government Debate
 Interviews with regulators and investigators, and a review of remarkably revealing internal records describe a fierce debate among Government agencies, and offer evidence of how seriously the Administration pursued its goal of courting the Iraqis to counterbalance Iran in the region.
On Feb. 28, 1991, the day after President Bush ordered a cease-fire in the Persian Gulf war with Iraq, Dick Thornburgh, then the Attorney General, announced indictments against Iraqi officials and former executives of the Atlanta branch of a state-controlled Italian bank, the Banca Nazionale del Lavoro, also known as Bank Lavoro.
The investigation, said Mr. Thornburgh, had exposed "an international white-collar crime scheme with dire global consequences" -- a scheme that has so far resulted in guilty pleas by some former bank officials who admitted making illegal loans to Iraq.
What Mr. Thornburgh did not say was that prosecutors actually sought an indictment more than a year earlier, and that in 1989 and 1990 the Justice Department asked Federal Reserve Bank officials in Washington and New York to delay regulatory action.
Indeed, the Government's handling of the Iraqis was so delicate that in March 1990, prosecutors deprived of any other means of interviewing key targets were reduced to inviting Iraqi suspects to fly to the United States, all expenses paid, to be interrogated.
The Iraqis did not show up.
Government investigators and regulators say that in late 1989, once it became clear that high-level Iraqis were involved in the $4 billion bank fraud, they tried unsuccessfully to persuade the Agriculture and State departments to deny guarantees for $500 million in loans to the Iraqi Government. The agencies ignored their entreaties and approved the loan guarantees, and the United States Government is now liable for much of that money because the Iraqis defaulted.
Robert L. Barr Jr., the former United States Attorney in Atlanta who oversaw the early stages of the investigation, would not discuss specifics of the inquiry. But he acknowledged that in the Bank Lavoro case considerations of foreign policy had become entwined with those of law enforcement.
Mr. Barr, a prominent Atlanta Republican, said that the State Department had become involved early on, and that the case "became complex both legally and because of foreign policy concerns."
Asked about the accounts of investigators who said in interviews that they had become increasingly frustrated with the State Department's role, he said, "As a hypothetical matter, and I'm not talking about this scenario, certainly in any case when you have a good case and there are policy matters, the delay can be frustrating."
Lawrence Urgenson, now the Acting Deputy Associate Attorney General, said foreign policy considerations had played no role in the investigation.
 
Scheduling Problems Blamed
 Mr. Urgenson said that if any trips were prohibited scheduling problems were the reason.
Colin Cleary, a spokesman for the State Department, issued a brief statement today asserting that the Justice Department had consulted with the State Department because the Bank Lavoro case "focused upon senior officials of the Iraqi Government." He said State supported Justice's indictment, but, along with other agencies, including the Department of Defense, opposed the indictment of the Central Bank of Iraq because it might set a bad legal precedent.
After the war with Iraq, the Government accused two former Bank Lavoro executives of conspiring with Iraqi officials to illegally arrange more than $4 billion in unauthorized loans and export credits to Iraq.
The 347-count indictment charges that executives of the bank in Atlanta defrauded the parent bank in Rome by arranging loans for Iraq without its knowledge. Prosecutors assert that some of the bank executives received hundreds of thousands of dollars in kickbacks from merchants seeking to sell goods to Iraq, goods the war-ravaged nation would have been unable to buy without huge infusions of cash.
At the time the illegal scheme took place, between 1985 and 1989, the United States was trying to build ties to Iraq. After the Iran-Iraq war ended in 1988, the United States began helping Iraq rebuild its economy.
Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, a Texas Democrat whose banking subcommittee has reviewed many internal State Department documents related to Bank Lavoro, said the war with Iraq illustrated how the Government's earlier policy was "dead wrong."
The case began in earnest on Aug. 4, 1989, when the agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and officials of the Federal Reserve, acting on a tip, raided the bank's Atlanta office and seized thousands of pages of records.
After the raid, the Government shut down the Atlanta branch of Bank Lavoro, one of Italy's largest banks.
Almost immediately, the case attracted the attention of intelligence and diplomatic officials.
"The loss of B.N.L. financing and, more important, any reduction in U.S. agricultural credit guarantees because of negative publicity about the scandal probably would damage U.S.-Iraqi commercial ties," the C.I.A.'s Directorate of Intelligence wrote in an memo dated Nov. 6, 1989.
In May 1990, the American Embassy in Baghdad, concerned that the Agriculture Department was considering removing Iraq from the loan-guarantee program, weighed in with a cable arguing that "from a foreign policy perspective," this would be a mistake.
The documents seized in the August raid provided evidence so clear-cut that Mr. Barr proposed returning an indictment by October 1989, internal records show. That date passed, and on Jan. 9, 1990, in a letter to the Federal Reserve Bank, Mr. Barr referred to the "anticipated indictment early next month."
In a series of interviews, law enforcement officials and lawyers involved in the case, speaking only on the condition of anonymity, said that in late 1989 or early 1990, the Government actually wrote an indictment, though it was not presented to a grand jury. These officials said the indictment was passed along to Justice Department officials in Washington, and that they do not know what came of it. Mr. Urgenson said the Justice Department would not discuss the indictment.
The officials said that during this period they sought the State Department's permission to visit Turkey and Iraq to interview key conspirators. They said Mr. Barr's office told them they could not make these trips.
They also said they were rebuffed in their requests to interview a Jordanian businessman, Wafai Dajani, whose brother is a former Jordanian Cabinet minister.
Mr. Dajani was listed in court documents in Atlanta as an unindicted co-conspirator. Gale McKenzie, the Assistant United States Attorney in charge of the case, said Mr. Dajani remained a target of the inquiry.
In a telephone interview from London, Mr. Dajani said he had never been contacted by investigators or regulators.
On March 26, 1990, the investigators in Atlanta, now anxious, came up with a highly unusual plan to interview the Iraqis whom they suspected of helping to plan the scheme.
At their request, the Justice Department wrote a letter to Michael Young, then Deputy Legal Adviser for the State Department, asking for permission to fly the Iraqi suspects in for interviews.
According to the letter, the Government would assure the Iraqis that they would not be charged while in this country and that the Government would pay for their travel.
In late February 1991, shortly before the allied victory in the Persian Gulf war, the State Department expressed reservations about the indictment being drafted by Atlanta prosecutors.
The memos quoted Justice Department officials as saying it was important to indict the Central Bank of Iraq, because it had over $1 billion in American assets that could be seized for fines. According to the memo, the prosecutors in Atlanta were particularly adamant that indicting the Central Bank was important. The State Department objected, arguing that the Central Bank was like a government agency, and that its indictment would set a bad legal precedent.
The State Department's memo, addressed to Robert Kimmitt, then Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, did not strongly object to indicting individuals. But it warned of problems, particularly with Mr. Dajani.
Mr. Dajani is a powerful figure in Jordan, and his brother, it pointed out, "is a former Minister of the Interior, and Wafai himself is considered well connected to the King and to U.S. grain exporters." It continued, "His indictment would be seen as a further U.S. attempt to 'punish' Jordan" for its support of Iraq.
Neither the Central Bank nor Mr. Dajani were in the indictment, which was returned within a few days of the internal memo.

HEADLINE: Haiti Accord Is Set Back in Parliament

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, March 19

 BODY:
Diplomats said today that their effort to win a reversal of the military coup that ousted Haiti's elected President in September had all but collapsed after Parliament failed to ratify an internationally brokered settlement.
The assessment emerged after a raucous parliamentary session on Wednesday in which conservative lawmakers seemed to deliberately torpedo the accord, which was reached after months of painstaking negotiations. 
 Diplomats and Haitians agreed that those lawmakers now appeared categorically opposed to the accord, which would have provided for the return of the deposed leader, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide.
After repeated procedural delays, the scheduled vote on Wednesday had been anticipated as a moment of truth in which Haitian legislators, weary of the economic misery resulting from sanctions imposed after the coup, would vote to dismiss the country's provisional leadership and recognize Father Aristide's legitimacy.
 
Shoving, Shouting and Guns
 What unfolded instead was a tumultuous session that diplomats said had all of the subtlety of a professional wrestling exhibition. After four hours of shouting, shoving and brandishing guns on the assembly floor, several conservative members abruptly walked out of the House of Deputies after an apparent dispute between close allies.
The protest deprived the legislature of a quorum and allowed the conservative president of the assembly, Dejean Belizaire, to end the session, all but killing any chance of ratifying the settlement anytime soon.
"We have had enough of this nonstop debate over the return or non-return of Aristide," said Senator Thomas Eddy Dupiton, a conservative who joined the walkout. "We have work to do."
Asked if the disruption had been deliberate, one angry and flustered Western diplomat said it apparently "was right on cue."
"I guess you have a group of people in the executive and certain politicians who are still looking to get theirs," the diplomat said. The diplomat was referring to allegations by politicians that a number of conservative lawmakers were receiving payoffs from the army in exchange for opposing any agreement on Father Aristide's return.
 
'Shock to the System'
 Officials of the Organization of American States were even more dejected, having acted for months as a tenuous bridge between this country's bitterest enemies in the hope of reaching a settlement.
"This latest delay has really been a shock to the system," a senior official with the organization in Washington said by telephone. "Up until now, our people had believed this agreement was going to be approved. A few still do, but the prevailing feeling around here is that we are heading instead toward a major crisis.
"We are thinking again of moving to the punitive mode," the official said, referring to a long-delayed move by the regional organization to freeze bank accounts and cancel visas of supporters of the military coup.
Diplomats noted that the proposed settlement had been reached only with great difficulty. It calls for the creation of a broad coalition government headed by a Prime Minister who is a longstanding rival of Father Aristide and sets no timetable for his return.
Drafting a new agreement or amending the current one to demand further concessions from Father Aristide would be impossible, they said.
Father Aristide, who governed Haiti for eight months after winning the country's first democratically elections, was ousted on Sept. 30 in a violent coup organized by the army. He has since been living in exile in Venezuela.
Aside from doubts about the sincerity of many of Haiti's civilian politicians, many diplomats now suspect that Haiti's military leadership "is at least two-faced," the O.A.S. official said. He said army leaders had privately indicated that they would support the accord.
Thousands of Haitians have fled the country in rickety boats since the coup, citing economic misery and violent repression by the military.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN;
Suddenly, the Choices Are Clearer

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 19

 BODY:
With the abrupt withdrawal of Paul E. Tsongas from the contest for the Democratic nomination, the likely shape of the 1992 Presidential race has suddenly come into sharper focus. A long, fierce and possibly close fight is in prospect between President Bush and Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas.
Election Day is more than seven months away, but a few things can be said with confidence. 
 It will be a fight between a self-described agent of "fundamental change" and a longtime champion of the status quo, a fight between an older generation (Mr. Bush is 67 years old and fought in World War II) and a new one (Mr. Clinton is 45 and graduated from college in the year of the big Tet offensive in Vietnam).
It will also be a fight between two men who have spent almost their whole adult lives in politics. Mr. Clinton calls himself an outsider, but he is as much a part of the Democratic establishment as Mr. Bush is a member of the Republican hierarchy.
Not for 50 years, what's more, have the habitually fractious Democrats settled so early on their nominee. Not since John F. Kennedy was chosen in 1960 have they done so with so little bad feeling and so few overt concessions to special-interest groups of the kind that then hurt them in the fall.
Perhaps the oldest of political maxims holds that elections are won or lost in the middle, not on the extremes, and Mr. Clinton seems positioned to challenge Mr. Bush on that ground, as Jimmy Carter successfully challenged Gerald R. Ford in 1976, the last time the Democrats won the White House.
Mr. Carter, a moderate Southerner without Washington experience, like Mr. Clinton, ran against a wounded Republican incumbent, like Mr. Bush, although the opprobrium of having pardoned Richard M. Nixon was small potatoes compared with Mr. Bush's economic woes, which have driven his overall approval rating down to 40 percent.
 
Character Issue
 The Arkansas Governor remains vulnerable, of course, to fresh accusations about his private life, of the kind that have plagued him for months, and former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California, his sole remaining Democratic rival, intends to keep pressing his attacks on the man he calls the "scandal a week" candidate. The White House is expected to take up where Mr. Brown eventually leaves off.
"We've been keeping track this winter," said a Bush campaign official who spoke on the condition that he not be identified, "and you can rest assured that we will be exploring the nature of Mr. Clinton's character."
Political prognostication is a mug's game in the best of times. Few will attempt it with conviction this year, when bitter, frustrated voters have turned vindictively upon a President they lionized a few months ago.
Still, because of Mr. Bush's lack of popularity, the broad appeal to the traditional Democratic constituencies that Mr. Clinton has demonstrated in the primaries, and the political moxie the Governor demonstrated in holding his campaign together when he was under constant attack, he is widely considered in both parties to be the Democrats' strongest candidate since the Vietnam era.
If -- always that "if" -- if he does not self-destruct.
There are other "ifs" as well. If the economy bounces back, as some statistics published on Wednesday suggested it might be doing, and if it does so in a way that becomes palpable to the voters, the advantages that typically accrue to a President seeking re-election should reassert themselves.
 
Liability of Incumbency
 Among those, the capacity to focus the nation's attention is primary; the mere arrival of a President and his big red, white and blue airplane are enough to dominate the news in most cities and states. In a communications era, the power to command audiences is very serious political magic.
If, on the other hand, Mr. Bush allows himself to be defined as "the incumbent in chief" in a year when incumbents as powerful as Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, have to fight for their political lives, the trappings, powers and perquisites of high office could turn out to unexpected liabilities.
The key for Mr. Bush, said Ed Rollins, a White House political director under Ronald Reagan, is "not asking people whether they are better off than they were four years ago, but telling them where they are going, explaining what you want the Bush Administration to be remembered for in the history books and not just trying to get your ticket punched again."
So far, he said, not only has the White House not developed a plan of action for the next four years, it has not begun to think about one.
For Mr. Clinton, said Paul Tully, the political director of the Democratic National Committee, the key is making himself better known to the hundreds of thousands of Democrats and independents who still do not know much about him or his ideas.
 
Needing More Exposure
 "We're trying to invent a new generation of Democratic leadership," Mr. Tully said. "None of our guys had ever run for national office before, so Clinton is still a stick figure to a lot of people, a cartoon figure who's a bit better defined for a lot more and a fully rounded person only in the states where he's run."
In that sense, Mr. Clinton could be hurt if there is no full-fledged Democratic contest in big states like Ohio, Pennsylvania and California. In New York, where the primary is scheduled for April 7, John A. Marino, the Democratic state chairman, said Mr. Clinton should go all out for the next three weeks as a means of introducing himself to a potentially pivotal state.
"He's got to talk about gun control, the homeless, crime and rebuilding the cities," Mr. Marino said. "He needs to spend time in the suburbs. He needs to forget about rallies and visit drug rehabilitation centers and homeless shelters and learn about our problems firsthand."
A New York Times/CBS News survey that ended on March 1 showed Mr. Clinton trailing Mr. Bush, 50 percent to 40 percent, with the rest saying they did not plan to vote or had no opinion. But that was before the Arkansan's impressive string of victories on March 3, on Super Tuesday and this week, and subsequent polls in major states like Illinois have shown Mr. Clinton leading in such trial heats.
 
Factor of Independents
 Mr. Bush's ability to attract independent voters and to hold on to the Democrats who crossed over to support him in 1988 will be major factors.
In the voting on Tuesday in Michigan and Illinois, the omens were not favorable for the President. Exit polls in both states showed about 4 of 10 Democrats or independents who backed Mr. Bush in 1988 voted for Mr. Clinton this time. Over all, 685,000 independents voted in the primary in Illinois this year, and 71 percent asked for Democratic ballots; in Michigan, of 292,000 independent primary voters, 64 percent cast Democratic ballots.
Those figures shed no light, of course, on the predilections of independents who skipped the primary, and they may be skewed because of more interesting local races this year on the Democratic side of things.
Republican and academic theorists have speculated for years about whether the Republican Party has developed an "Electoral College lock," in which geopolitical trends have made it all but impossible for the Democrats to recapture the White House. They have won only once in six elections.
But this year, both Republican and Democratic strategists believe the supposed lock could be picked. One reason is Mr. Clinton's Southern roots, which may give him a chance in a few Southern states and most of the border states, like Maryland, Oklahoma, Kentucky and Missouri, although his prospects are poor in Florida and not a great deal better in Texas.
 
Belt of Industrial States
 All through the West, from the Plains States to the Pacific, Democratic strength has been improving. Michael S. Dukakis, the 1988 Democratic nominee, did 10 percent better nationally than Walter S. Mondale, the 1984 nominee, but Mr. Mondale did 22 percent better in the Western region.
California, the biggest prize in the region and the nation with 54 electoral votes, is leaning heavily Democratic at the moment and would give Mr. Clinton a huge boost.
The election could then be won or lost by the Democrats in the belt of industrial states stretching from Wisconsin through Illinois, Ohio and Pennsylvania to New Jersey and New York, where American elections, more often than not, have been decided since the 19th century. At the moment, Illinois, Michigan, Pennsylvania and New York all look winnable for Mr. Clinton.
"But they shouldn't be worrying about that now, or about attacking each other," said Mr. Rollins. "It's not Labor Day. The public doesn't want circuses yet. It wants ideas, solutions, ways out of this mess."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Connecticut;
Protest Vote Looms in State Once Vital to Tsongas

BYLINE: By MICHAEL SPECTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, March 19

 BODY:
Paul E. Tsongas had a hard time firing up his ambling race for the Presidency. In Connecticut, at least, he may have an even tougher time shutting it down.
"As far as we are concerned, the Tsongas for President campaign is alive and well and it will go forward," said Tom Sullivan, Mr. Tsongas's state campaign director. He met today with nearly three dozen volunteers -- all of whom said they would continue to support the man who is no longer running. Mr. Sullivan said he had no desire to cancel a Tsongas fund-raising event scheduled for Saturday here. And next Tuesday, when the state's unhappy voters go to the polls, Mr. Tsongas, whose name will still be on the ballot, may be the recipient of a lively last rite, a protest vote he may not have received if he had not withdrawn today from the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination.
 
Seeking the Outrage Vote
 It is too early to gauge the impact of Mr. Tsongas's withdrawal here, in part because the Connecticut primary seemed irrelevant a week ago, when the former Senator from Massachusetts was expected to win, and truly important on Wednesday, when it looked as if Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas was closing in and former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California appeared ready to challenge Mr. Tsongas for the outrage vote. 
 Now it may again become irrelevant. But Connecticut, with its high unemployment rate and its troubled major cities, has plenty of rage stored up. So the vote next Tuesday may say more about the psyche of angry voters than it does about those who are seeking their votes.
"People here know when they are being lied to," said Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., a former Republican who was elected as an independent in 1990. "I think they would have respected what Paul had to say. He is a decent and honorable man."
Mr. Weicker, who last year introduced the state's first income tax, an act that has brought him the most consistently abysmal ratings in public opinion polls in the state's history, said he was not endorsing any candidate. But he added: "Nobody called. My polls are not of such a distinguished height that it would lead a politician to seek to associate himself with me."
The race in Connecticut will be an attempt by Mr. Clinton to sell his message in a state that had until recently embraced Mr. Tsongas. Labor leaders here have already started to flock to Mr. Brown, who tapped the bitterness of blue-collar workers in Michigan to finish second in that state's primary on Tuesday.
"This is like some black comedy," said Jerome P. Brown, president of District 1199 of the New England Health Care Employees Union. "Clinton is supposed to have exactly one thing going for him: he is electable. Well, after the Republicans spend $20 million on attacking him this fall, and turn the election into a referendum on his character rather than our dying economy, we will see how electable Mr. Clinton really is."
"Jerry Brown is a political terrorist," said John F. Droney Jr., a former Democratic state chairman who is running the Clinton campaign in Connecticut. "He is capable of tossing bombs and hurting people. What he can't do is help his party."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: White House;
Bush Plans to Withhold Spending In Fight Over Economic Program

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 19

 BODY:
President Bush plans to mark the passage of his March 20 deadline for Congressional enactment of his economic-growth legislation by announcing on Friday that he will not spend $4 billion that Congress has allotted for Federal programs, White House officials said today.
Mr. Bush's refusal to spend appropriated money, an action that is called rescission, was also employed by President Reagan. But it proved ineffective because Federal law requires Congressional approval of such actions. Congress has generally chosen not to rescind its own actions, and it is not likely now to approve any cuts Mr. Bush sends it. 
 The President's announcement, in a speech scheduled for mid-afternoon, appeared to be the only administrative action planned so far in the political war that Mr. Bush has long threatened if Congress sends him a package of economic legislation that he finds unacceptable.
Congress appeared ready tonight to do just that, sending Mr. Bush a bill that contained some version of the seven anti-recession measures he has demanded, but also included an increase in taxes on the well-to-do that the President has said he would veto.
 
Republicans See Confusion
 Some Republican officials tonight were sharply critical of the White House and strategists in Mr. Bush's re-election campaign for what they said was confusion and reluctance among top officials to confront Congress more toughly.
They said the scope of Mr. Bush's political retaliation against Congress was unsettled, mired late today in a debate between the White House and Mr. Bush's campaign organization over what the President should do and when he should do it.
"They don't have the most minimal understanding or sense of how to orchestrate an event or make something work," one Republican official, who refused to be identified, said today of the White House staff. "It's distressing."
A second official said, "It's not just the White House. The campaign has its share of problems, too."
Congressional reaction to the White House plans was dismissive. Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who heads the House Ways and Means Committee, questioned whether the President would actually be able to make the rescissions.
"I'm sure that he doesn't have that constitutional authority," Mr. Rostenkowski told reporters tonight during a dinner break from a conference drafting a compromise on the Democratic House and Senate tax bills.
Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, acknowledged that, "We propose this to Congress, and then they have the right to vote the cuts back in (the budget) on an item-by-item basis."
At the peak of Mr. Reagan's political popularity, in 1981, Congress agreed to rescind nearly three-quarters of the $16.5 billion in programs that Mr. Reagan proposed cutting. But in 1986 and 1987, when the White House was enmeshed in the Iran-contra affair, Congress approved only 1 percent of Mr. Reagan's rescissions, according to a tally by the magazine National Journal.
Mr. Bush plans to announce unilateral cuts on "hundreds" of Federal programs, White House officials said, from construction projects to research programs of the sort that former Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, used to ridicule with "Golden Fleece" awards.
But with a potentially bruising election season under way and Mr. Bush's own popularity at its lowest, the actions are effectively theatrical and have virtually no chance of reducing Federal spending significantly.
Even if those cuts were to be approved, the $4 billion that Mr. Bush proposes not to spend is only a tiny fraction of a Federal deficit that approaches $400 billion annually. Most of that deficit is made up not of the sort of discretionary programs that the President is attacking but of programs like Medicare, food stamps and student aid, whose levels are set by law.
The list of cuts to be announced on Friday was still being assembled tonight, White House officials said.
 
'Line in the Sand'
 The President's action comes nearly two months after he invoked the language of the Persian Gulf war to press Congress on economic issues, drawing "a line in the sand" for Congress to enact his anti-recession legislative package by March 20 or face a political firefight.
White House officials said tonight that Mr. Bush would chastise Congressional Democrats in his afternoon speech, accusing them of prolonging the national economic slowdown.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Bowing Out;
Tsongas, in Quiet of Home, Faces Realities of Finances

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, March 19

 BODY:
For the candidate of "hard choices" and "fiscal responsibility," Wednesday was the day of reckoning.
At 9:30 in the evening, Paul E. Tsongas sat in the living room of his Lowell, Mass., house as his campaign manager and best friend, Dennis Kanin, delivered the bad news: Not only was the campaign broke, but it also needed at least $1 million to compete in the New York primary. 
 Mr. Tsongas said he would sleep on it, but it was clear to his wife, Niki, and a few other confidants who were there that the ever-stubborn former Massachusetts Senator would not waver: what he called "a great adventure," running for President, was about to end.
 
More than 'Growing Pains'
 By all accounts, it was a crushing and emotional moment for a campaign that was written off by the Democratic establishment as a pipe dream when it began just one year and 12 days ago and made it into the history books when Mr. Tsongas won the New Hampshire primary last month.
In the end, the factors that briefly turned him into the Democratic front runner crushed him as he struggled to expand his campaign into a national effort. They were more than "growing pains," as Mr. Tsongas called them: He and his aides were unable to adjust to the demands of competing in several states against Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, whose organization and preparation around the country they could never match.
For the same reasons that Mr. Tsongas appealed to voters in New Hampshire -- as a no-nonsense, truth-telling politician -- he failed as a national campaigner. He would not budge in the face of his advisers' entreaties to sweeten his blunt message of economic pain and sacrifice.
Mr. Tsongas was so unwavering in sticking to his message that some of his friends and advisers say he put it above winning the Presidency. And that is why he said he bowed out today: He was confident about his showing on home turf in the Connecticut primary next week, but feared that if he were trounced in New York, he would lose his credibility and his remedies for the nation would sink with him.
At a news conference this afternoon at the Parker House hotel here, Mr. Tsongas recalled that his momentum in the polls before the Texas primary stalled after Mr. Clinton bombarded the state with commercials and he could not respond effectively.
"That's the reality I had to face last night," he said. "That in New York I would run into the same thing.
"The message would have been hurt in the process," he said.
The chain of events that led to today's announcement began only two days ago with the Illinois and Michigan primaries. As he traveled from Chicago to Hartford on Tuesday night, Mr. Tsongas turned again and again to his aides for the latest figures from those contests. The news never got better: his losses were devastating.
So later that night, the former Senator instructed Mr. Kanin to come up with an accounting of the campaign's finances. It was "unspoken," Mr. Kanin said, but the idea of pulling out was on both their minds.
 
Stunned Advisers
 Their thoughts turned to words on Wednesday afternoon when, Mr. Kanin said, Mr. Tsongas "threw out as a possibility" the idea that he would withdraw. He went to a fund raising event here anyway, only to return to his living room that night to make the fateful decision.
It was a decision that stunned many of Mr. Tsongas's aides and even close friends. Peggy Connolly, the press secretary who late Wednesday afternoon was still speaking confidently of Mr. Tsongas' game plan in New York, said she was "shocked" when word came last night.
Ed Jesser, a senior adviser, was also surprised, saying that many candidates faced with similiar political realities would not have bowed out so quickly. "The sun was not shining on the horizon for us," he said. "And he chose not to get into what was a semi-hopeless endeavor."
 
'Who's Goofy'?
 Mr. Tsongas broke the news at his headquarters here this morning to nearly 100 campaign aides. Several people who were there said he stood on a chair so people could see him, and he immediately broke into tears before thanking everyone.
"There were shouts of 'Stick with it,' " said Tak Takvorian, the doctor Mr. Tsongas credits with helping him overcome cancer. "There was a certain dejection but he had some wit."
Describing his mood, Ted Van Dyk, another adviser, said "He was down, down, down."
The announcement today was particularly unexpected because Mr. Tsongas and his advisers had insisted as recently as Wednesday that they were in for the long haul. "I want to be heard in California," Mr. Tsongas said at a news conference on Wednesday.
But Mr. Tsongas seemed to be going through the motions on Wednesday, a sharp contrast to his animated, witty performance today.
"I've spoken to all of the other five candidates," he said. "Bob Kerrey was in Disney World. I told him I would be there too at 3 o'clock. You can decide who's goofy."
Most surprising at the news conference was Mr. Tsongas's explanation that his campaign's financial troubles were why he withdrew. At the Hartford news conference Wednesday, he disputed that his campaign was broke, saying donations have "increased over time -- not diminished" and that "We've had the best fund raising we've ever had."
Mr. Tsongas backed down today from his optimistic outlook, saying that the campaign did not have the resources to compete effectively in New York. "This campaign was lost in 1991 because of lack of resources," he said. "It was almost rescued in 1992 by the message."
But Mr. Tsongas's change of heart on money suggests that there were other factors affecting his decision , like his own future political viability. For days, he has insisted that he would never serve as Mr. Clinton's Vice President, saying a few days ago, "I would not want to be part of an administration whose economic views I so strongly disagree with."
Today he refused to rule out running on a Clinton ticket, saying that he promised his advisers last night that he would "make no statements on my future."
Mr. Jesser, for one, said that now that Mr. Tsongas has left the race relatively unscathed, it would not be farfetched for the Democrats to turn to him later should Mr. Clinton stumble.
 
Damaging Frankness
 All Mr. Tsongas would say today on that note was, "I will be a player because I am now the message that people responded to."
He said that there no hidden reasons for his withdrawal. Dr. Takvorian said he spend today fending off inquiries about Mr. Tsongas's health, insisting, "There's no health issue at all."
As polls in recent days showed that Mr. Tsongas faced an increasingly uphill climb against Mr. Clinton, his close advisers grew more frustrated that he was damaging his prospects by being more blunt with voters than necessary.
They blamed his embarrassing third-place finish in Michigan on his opposition to a bill that would forbid companies to replace striking workers. Though the advisers said he would look like he was pandering if he backed down from that position, they said he could have softened his opposition.
His aides also cringed in Miami Beach before the Florida primary when he praised Anwar Sadat, the slain President of Egypt, before an audience of elderly Jewish voters. A week later, in Flint, Mich., he offered little immediate hope to unemployed blue-collar workers who wanted to know how he would get them jobs.
"This state is in agony -- and he tells them that," Mr. Jesser said after midnight Tuesday, once the results from the Midwest primaries were clear. "The most Machiavellian political person on the planet couldn't see any good in that. He's not going to change his opinion for political advantage."
His aides were equally baffled by his comments until today that he would never serve as Mr. Clinton's Vice President. Even if that were the case, the aides said making such an early declaration would hurt his fund raising efforts among donors who thought he might not win the nomination but was a possible vice president.
"You don't throw those cards away," Jim King, another top aide, said early Wednesday. Speaking of how Mr. Clinton has hammered away at Mr. Tsongas's vulnerabilities, he went on: "Most of the politicians I've worked for would have made moves politically that would have precluded much of it. He didn't. He won't."
Mr. Tsongas's advisers also said that he never was comfortable attacking Mr. Clinton and that those efforts came off poorly and damaged the campaign.
For his part, Mr. Tsongas seemed to take pride in not always following the script of his advisers.
"At times," he said at the news conference, "we were under a great pressure to change our views to accommodate various interests. I chose not to. My principles could not have been compromised without destroying that message." But, he acknowledged, "those decisions cost us dearly."
Something else may have been at work in Mr. Tsongas's decision to quit the race. His advisers suggest that a man who thought he was going to die from cancer has goals that go beyond being President of the United States, that he really did want his message to be heard.
"He isn't totally, utterly, subsumed by his candidacy for President of the United States," Mr. Jesser said. "This is not the fight of his life. He's had the fight of his life."
