HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Front-Runner;
Clinton Campaign Watches as Obstacles to the Democratic Nomination Fall

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL

 BODY:
Little more than two weeks ago, aides to Gov. Bill Clinton believed that his campaign was in desperate shape. Slumped over their morning coffee at an Atlanta hotel on March 3, three of his top advisers braced themselves for bad news from Georgia and Maryland, where there were primary elections that day.
But Mr. Clinton got the victory margin he needed in Georgia, finished within seven percentage points of former Senator Paul E. Tsongas in Maryland and so built up enough speed to steamroller the Super Tuesday primaries the next week. 
 By the time they arrived in Chicago last week to kick off a campaign for votes in Illinois and Michigan, the Clinton organizers were able to throw a raucous, balloon-strewn victory party for the local television cameras. The party was intended to send voters a distinct message: Bill Clinton would inevitably be the Democratic nominee.
 
Getting a Nearly Clear Path
 That likelihood grew markedly yesterday with Mr. Tsongas's decision to drop out of the race, handing the Clinton campaign, at turns battered, resilient and victorious, a nearly clear path to nomination.
Mr. Clinton and his staff learned of Mr. Tsongas's decision at their morning strategy conference call in Little Rock, Ark., yesterday. One adviser was summoned away from the telephone to answer a call from a reporter, and returned minutes later to stun the others with the news.
As the aides absorbed the surprise, this adviser said, Mr. Clinton immediately began issuing orders about what steps to take next.
Campaign aides tend to depict their candidates as perennially in charge, but indeed the Clinton organization has always seemed candidate-driven.
In its recurring periods of crisis, the Clinton camp has depended almost entirely on the candidate's personal skills as a tireless stump performer with vast confidence in his own ability to convince voters that he is an honorable man who deserves to be President.
 
Strength 'at Every Juncture'
 As a result, the campaign and its candidate have rejuvenated themselves at every critical hairpin turn. "We've had scrutiny since December," said Frank Greer, Mr. Clinton's media adviser, voicing a recurring campaign theme. "And at every juncture Bil Clinton has been strengthened."
The campaign's two most crucial tests occurred in Georgia on March 3 and in New Hampshire two weeks earlier. 
Mr. Clinton and his advisers knew they had to win decisively in Georgia to counter what was by then a burgeoning Tsongas campaign that was proving itself attractive to more-educated, white-collar voters in Colorado and Maryland, two of the three other states with primaries that day.
A leading Clinton strategist, James Carville, was dispatched to Atlanta to help Gov. Zell Miller, a Clinton supporter, work the state. Mr. Clinton himself set a frantic schedule, returning repeatedly to Georgia. He wound up with 57 percent of the vote, to Mr. Tsongas's 24 percent, and, having won there, traveled to 21 cities across the South in the six days before Super Tuesday.
Similarly, in the week before the New Hampshire primary last month, Mr. Clinton embarked on a breakneck schedule of live half-hour television shows and public appearances. After placing second to Mr. Tsongas in New Hampshire while weathering a flurry of reports about his marital life and whether he had sought to avoid military service, he christened himself the "comeback kid."
Now he has gone on to eliminate all his opponents, except for former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California.
It took more effort to hurt some than others. Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia, who was initially presumed to be a potential threat in the South and among black voters, dropped out before the first votes were cast. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York decided not to run at all.
Among those who did mount active campaigns, Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa faltered almost from the outset. Senator Bob Kerrey, too, failed to live up to expectations after a brief challenge in Georgia, where he predicted that Republicans would shell Mr. Clinton in November "like a soft peanut."
The Clinton campaign is now negotiating for Mr. Harkin's endorsement, and two of Mr. Kerrey's top fund raisers, Bob Burkett and Marvin Rosen, have begun working for Mr. Clinton.
But it was the challenge from Mr. Tsongas that frustrated Mr. Clinton most. The questions about his marital life and his draft status bothered him less than the evidence that voters were choosing Mr. Tsongas for the specificity of his economic message.
In an interview earlier this week, the Governor said: "One of the most emotionally difficult periods of this campaign for me was after the storm passed over all the personal hits, I realized that all of the work I had done for years and years and years to establish a whole new direction for the Democratic Party, to come up with some new ideas and new approaches, that all of that had been erased from the public consciousness, unavoidably, by all the events that had taken place."
Mr. Clinton said he had survived the subsequent attacks directed at him by Mr. Kerrey and Mr. Tsongas, who described him as not electable, because voters started listening to his message once more.
"Once voters started voting for us, it validated us," said Mr. Carville, the Clinton strategist. "It carried on to the next one."
The Governor said that after he began pounding home that message, which stressed "opportunity with responsibility" on welfare, student loan programs and trade issues, he became confident that his campaign was "back on our own strategy."
"I think it just took a long time to get people back to the listening stage again," Mr. Clinton said.
Then he paused.
"It didn't take a long time," he continued. "It took two weeks, but two weeks in this process, and particularly during this particular month, it's an eternity."
Before Mr. Tsongas's withdrawal, Mr. Clinton had said he intended to take his campaign to every remaining primary state even if his nomination was a foregone conclusion. His aides said yesterday that although he had already scaled back his plans for Connecticut, that approach would not change.
"I think you've got people in New York and Pennsylvania and Ohio and Indiana and Wisconsin and New Jersey and California and all the states that haven't voted yet, I think they want to be heard," Mr. Clinton had said.
Aides to Mr. Clinton said Mr. Tsongas's withdrawal would give the Governor an opportunity to challenge President Bush early.
"Everybody hoped we'd have a nominee early," said Dee Dee Myers, Mr. Clinton's press secretary. "Now we're not there yet, but I think we're one step closer. Now the job is to define George Bush and to make this a two-person race."
That approach assumes that the other remaining Democratic candidate, Mr. Brown, will share the spotlight for only a short time.
For the past several days, Mr. Clinton and his aides had been convinced that the support they needed would eventually gravitate to them even if Mr. Tsongas and Mr. Brown remained in the race. An anybody-but-Clinton movement, they were predicting, would diminish with every success that showed Mr. Clinton's message getting through to voters.
"If the election demonstrates that I can do that in the midst of all the personal rocks and stones," the Governor said this week, "then I think the politicians who want to be part of that will come to us."

HEADLINE: Democrats Prepare Veto Friendly Tax Bill

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 19

 BODY:
Struggling to settle the terms for a politically attractive middle-class tax cut in time for action before President Bush's Friday deadline, House and Senate negotiators worked tonight to try to finish sweeping tax legislation they knew would not become law.
At 10 P.M., a Senate aide said that Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas and Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, designated by the other conferees to work out a bill, intended to finish tonight, no matter how long it took. But he said they would not brief other conferees before morning and would not reveal their agreement to reporters or the public until then either. 
 The election-year measure is expected to include some version of each of the seven points Mr. Bush said in January were essential to spur the economy. His demand included a deep cut in capital gains taxes, accelerated depreciation for business investment and several measures to help the real estate and housing industries.
But the expected tax increases on upper-bracket taxpayers, needed to pay for the middle-class tax cut, have provoked threats of a veto no one expects to override.
Indeed, passage of the measure on Friday is not viewed as a sure thing. But leaders of both houses arranged for unusually quick delivery of the bill to Mr. Bush on Friday evening if it is passed, thus meeting the timing deadline he set, if disregarding the content he demanded.
Earlier versions of the bill were passed by only 12 votes in the House and 3 in the Senate in an air of widespread skepticism that the tax cuts were worth much either to the economy or as election-year slogans for the Democrats. But there was an even stronger concern that failing to pass anything would make the Democratic Congress look even worse than passing a bill Mr. Bush would reject and they could argue about.
 
Early Caucus Today
 House Democrats scheduled an early-morning caucus to round up support for whatever emerged from tonight's bargaining. Extra persuasion may be critical because of widespread unhappiness with the way Democratic leaders have handled the House bank scandal, which became public late last week, two weeks after passage of the House version of the tax bill.
For most of the day, Mr. Bentsen, who heads the Senate Finance Committee, and Mr. Rostenkowski, who heads the House Ways and Means Committee, met together with only a few aides.
Other lawmakers on the conference had agreed to leave it to them to try to cut a deal, and they went over 141 large pages comparing where the two measures were identical, similar or contradictory.
The biggest difference was on the political heart of the Democratic effort to portray themselves in an election year as friends of the middle class.
The House bill provides a temporary, two-year tax credit of up to $400 for working couples. The credit is for one-fifth of the Social Security and Medicare taxes a worker pays, and the $400 level would be reached at an income level of about $26,000. The House credit would be refundable, meaning that if someone's income taxes were not as large as the credit owed, he or she would get a check from the Treasury for the balance.
 
The Senate Version
 The Senate bill, in contrast, is focused on children. It provides a $300 credit for each child under 16 claimed as a dependent, for couples with adjusted gross incomes under $47,500. The credit would be gradually reduced for couples with incomes up to $60,000, and eliminated above that level. Despite complaints from some liberal Democrats, it would not be refundable; low-income parents would not benefit.
Another major difference is that the Senate bill includes provisions on health insurance. It would prohibit insurance companies from canceling coverage or excluding members of small groups because of existing health problems or prior claims, and try to eliminate gaps in coverage for workers changing jobs. It would also seek to eliminate wide disparities in health insurance premiums.
While including these elements in the bill sent to Mr. Bush for a veto would enable the Democrats to attack him on another politically advantageous front, House Democrats were resisting including these elements in the final version of the bill because they have not yet considered the issue.

HEADLINE: New Jersey's New Treasurer Defends Budget to Assembly

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, March 19

 BODY:
New Jersey's new state treasurer is not officially on the job until Friday, but he was at work today defending Gov. Jim Florio's proposed $15.7 billion budget against Republican attack.
The treasurer, Samuel Crane, whose nomination was confirmed last week by the Senate and who is to be sworn in Friday, was the first member of the administration to formally testify over a budget proposal that has become the major strain in the power-sharing between a Democratic governor and a Republican-led Legislature. 
 "Obviously there are some clear differences," Mr. Crane said in an interview after completing his testimony to the Assembly Appropriations Committee. "Overall, I didn't think it was as bitterly partisan today as most people thought it would be."
The committee meeting opened with a direct attack on Mr. Florio by the Republican chairman, Assemblyman Rodney P. Frelinghuysen. He called the budget "the cornerstone of Governor Florio's plans to remake his battered public image at taxpayers' expense."
 
Sales Tax at Issue
 Mr. Florio based his budget in part on a 7 percent sales tax rate despite the Republicans' warnings that they intended to roll back the sales tax to 6 percent to fulfill a campaign promise. The Governor's budget proposal also increases aid to public schools by $341 million, maintains a home rebate program and keeps transit fares at current levels.
"Governor Florio has made this budget document so politically charged that it attempts to thwart this legislature's efforts to do what the public wants -- craft a smaller, more efficient government and lower taxes," Mr. Frelinghuysen said.
The state constitution requires that New Jersey have a balanced budget in place by the start of its fiscal year, July 1.
During nearly three hours of testimony today, Mr. Crane doggedly defended his department's budget projections in civil, but sometimes pointed, exchanges with the Republicans.
In his prepared text, Mr. Crane ended with a swipe at the Republicans' plan to roll back the sales tax to 6 percent, which would mean a $608 million loss in revenue in the next fiscal year and $638 million the following year.
"If you have an economic analysis which shows that the repeal will, indeed, jump-start the state's economy, please share it with us and the public before acting solely on the basis of faith," Mr. Crane said.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Memo;
In TV Age, Tsongas Built A Campaign on His Book

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, March 19

 BODY:
In the end it was not enough to win, but Paul E. Tsongas deserves to be remembered for a remarkable achievement in the television age. He based a political campaign on a book that he wrote himself.
Few voters read it, of course, but the mere existence of "A Call to Economic Arms" gave Mr. Tsongas credibility and helped inspire a battle of the books. He and Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas took their campaigns to the reference desk of local libraries in New Hampshire, where voters could compare Mr. Tsongas's work with Mr. Clinton's "A Plan for America's Future." 
 Both he and Mr. Clinton addressed a classic literary theme, the American dream, with similar plots: Nation gets dream, nation loses dream, nation gets five-point plan to get back dream. Both introduced heroic figures: Mr. Clinton's New Covenant, Mr. Tsongas' New American Mandate. But Mr. Tsongas was more thorough in character development -- maybe too thorough. A reader could come away with a good idea of why his campaign went the way it did.
There was no mistaking his sincerity and moral conviction, the qualities that initially appealed to many voters. Mr. Tsongas admirably discussed unpopular ideas like higher gasoline taxes or lower Social Security benefits for the wealthy.
Unfortunately, unpopular ideas that sound reasonable in a book do not fare well on 30-second commercials. Mr. Clinton demonstrated this in commercials showing a copy of "A Call to Economic Arms" and flipping through its pages. Underlined words appeared on the screen, complete with page citations, a rare and apparently successful use of footnotes on television.
Mr. Tsongas might have benefited if voters had bothered to read both candidates' books, because they would have seen Mr. Clinton's penchant for urging bold action without actually offending anyone. But they would have noticed another difference, too. If Mr. Clinton at his worst was an unprincipled glad-hander, Mr. Tsongas was a messianic pedant.
This preachy side of Mr. Tsongas was probably one of the chief reasons that his campaign eventually faltered. It came out only gradually on television, but it was obvious long ago to anyone who read the 86-page book.
 
Orders of Narrator
 The omniscient narrator incessantly issued orders ("must" was a favorite word) and proclaimed sweeping truths. He knew everything from the most beautiful place on earth (Alaska) to the greatest mystery in climatology (his discussion of global warming began, "The issues here are well known.").
His plan for reorganizing American business was particularly revealing. There was nothing unusual about Mr. Tsongas's enthusiasm for a national industrial policy -- although he and the other Democratic candidates had trouble planning their own schedules more than a day in advance, none of them shied from plotting the course of entire industries through the end of the century. But Mr. Tsongas' attitude was singularly confident.
"Take a deep breath," Mr. Tsongas warned the believers in laissez-faire economics. "It's a brave new world out there. Adam Smith was a marvelous man but he wouldn't know a superconductor or memory chip if he tripped over one."
For an economic planner to dismiss Adam Smith in one sentence is a little like a rocket engineer casually pooh-poohing the laws of gravity because Isaac Newton would not know a solid-fuel booster if it landed on his head. Mr. Tsongas elevated this year's political discourse, but his own discourse might have benefited from a touch of self-doubt. "The Wealth of Nations" is going to stay in print a lot longer than "A Call to Economic Arms."

HEADLINE: As Gun Debate Rages, Ammunition Makers Are Quietly, and Busily, at Work

SERIES: 200 Million Guns -- Sixth article in a series

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
Although making billions of rounds of ammunition annually is a big business and thousands of people are killed or injured by misuse of some of those products, the nation's ammunition industry hums along in quiet obscurity, all but ignored by opponents and supporters of gun control.
In most states, all anyone needs to buy ammunition is a driver's license. No special records are kept of the purchase, which is just as likely to be made at a K-Mart or a gas station-convenience store as a gun shop. 
 By law, convicted felons are prohibited from buying ammunition, but retailers are not obliged to make any special effort to determine if their customers have a criminal record, and they virtually never do. In the few cities like New York and Washington where ammunition is much harder to buy, it still flows readily to criminals, along with illegal handguns, from neighboring states.
 
Lonely Battle for Moynihan
 The inattention to the ammunition market frustrates Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat, who has waged a lonely drive to ban the manufacture and sale of ammunition used in many handguns.
But most law-enforcement officials and policy makers believe that the easy availability of ammunition has little to do with the nation's gun problems. They say that criminals tend to use ammunition sporadically and in such small quantities that a minute fraction of the available supply is all they need. In addition, the officials say, any effort to choke off the commercial production of ammunition would almost certainly be undercut by a homemade supply.
"You could work for years and never learn to machine a gun," said John C. Killorin, head of public affairs for the Federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, and Firearms. "You could take a 20-minute course and learn how to make ammunition."
Simply comparing the ammunition industry with other businesses turns up other reasons for its low profile, starting with who owns it. Large industrial conglomerates like the Olin Corporation, which owns Winchester, and E. I. du Pont de Nemours, which owns Remington, control the major producers. But for the industry giants, the ammunition makers are minor subsidiaries.
 
$843 Million Annual Sales
 Another major producer, CCI-Speer, is a division of Blount Inc., a sprawling privately held concern that is making industrial products and sporting goods and owns a construction company. In addition, a substantial part of the ammunition business is in the hands of individuals and small-scale enterprises that produce new ammunition from recycled shells.
While many small-scale producers, especially those that reload used shells, are not included, domestic production of "small arms ammunition" had an estimated wholesale value of $843 million in 1990, according to the Commerce Department, with a portion of the sales going abroad. By comparison, production of firearms had a wholesale value of $1.14 billion in 1990. About 10,000 people are employed in the industry.
Profits, executives say, are under constant pressure, especially in the most popular calibers, for which prices are low and competition intense. Although specialty ammunition used to hunt big game may cost as much as $5 a cartridge. The average cartridge sells for about 15 cents.
To survive, companies need to offer higher-priced, specialty cartridges as well as commonplace ones, said Les Jones, director of sales for the Federal Cartridge Company, a subsidiary of Pentair Inc. that is pushing Remington for second place in the market.
 
Stable Business
 If one word characterizes the industry it is stability. Fashions in the kinds of ammunition purchased come and go with changing tastes in guns, but not with the speed and force of, say, money-spinning shifts in clothing fashions. Imports have crimped profits but the fallout has been modest compared with the havoc in automobiles and electronics. Environmental problems have altered products and operations but hardly as traumatically as in many other industries.
Commercial ammunition sales growth stalled in the mid-1970's, hurt largely by falling demand from hunters. Growing handgun sales and target shooting has led to renewed, although slow, growth in recent years. Military sales, which account for 10 percent to 15 percent of the total sales, are about half of what they were during the early years of the Reagan Administration. Part of the decline is the result of the armed forces' use of Government arsenals for a larger percentage of their requirements.
"I think we bottomed out about five years ago," said G. W. Bersett, president of Winchester.
 
Competitors
 At Winchester, History in Motion
 Perhaps the single best place to get an overview of the ammunition industry is East Alton, Ill., the Mississippi river town just north of St. Louis that is home to Winchester, believed to be the largest ammunition manufacturer. Winchester's factory complex, next to an Olin brass mill that supplies it, produces about 350 different cartridges and shells, totaling more than a billion rounds a year, according to a company spokesman who would not be more specific. They range from industry standbys like 9-millimeter cartridges to specialty rounds like bulletless ramset shells that the construction industry uses to blast nails into concrete.
Winchester's complex is in some areas a finely honed working museum. The first step in forming lead shot, for example, is a two-century old process in which molten lead fed through a sieve solidifies while falling seven stories into a pool of water that cushions its impact. Low-volume products are still loaded at rates of 40 to 60 a minute on machines designed by John Olin long before his family's Western Cartridge Company acquired the bankrupt Winchester rifle company in 1931.
Elsewhere, Winchester looks a lot more like a company with its eye on the 21st century. Only a few yards from the Olin loaders, computer-controlled Manuhrin cartridge loading stations imported from France churn out 9-millimeter cartridges and other big sellers at rates of up to 450 a minute.
With millions of dollars invested in such automation during the 1980's, Winchester has followed the strategy of low-cost, high-volume producers in other industries by steadily reducing its work force while improving quality and increasing output.
 
Remington the Chief Rival
 Winchester's main rival over the years has been Remington, which manufactures about 1.5 billion rounds annually at Lonoke, Ark., according to Paul Kvederis, a spokesman at Remington's headquarters in Pittsburg. Olin's sale of Winchester's domestic and foreign firearms operations during the 1980's made Remington the only major ammunition producer also active in the market for traditional firearms, which has been only intermittently profitable.
Ammunition industry executives say rumors that DuPont is anxious to sell Remington never cease. Remington executives declined to comment on the rumors or any aspect of the company's business.
The third major competitor is Federal, the descendant of a company that was at one time supported by the Olin family to preserve competition in the industry and keep antitrust officials at bay. After going through a management-led leveraged buyout in 1985, Federal was sold to Pentair in 1988.
"You are a little bit at the mercy of lead prices and other raw materials whose costs are determined by demand in other industries, but ammunition is more stable and less vulnerable to recession than some of our other businesses," said Richard Ingman, vice president of corporate development for Pentair, a conglomerate with interests in paper and a variety of industrial products.
 
40 Million Reused Rounds
 Winchester, Remington and Federal, along with CCI, which concentrates largely on .22-caliber ammunition and inexpensive cartridges that do not have recyclable brass casings, account for most new ammunition sales. A number of smaller specialty manufacturers, like Nosler Bullets Inc., have developed reputations for innovative designs later adopted by bigger manufacturers.
Several hundred million rounds of ammunition a year are made by reloaders, who recycle used shells. They range from target shooters trying to save money for themselves and their acquaintances to relatively sophisticated "remanufacturers," who turning out as many as 40 million rounds a year for law-enforcement agencies and military forces to use on practice ranges.
Of the major remanufacturers, only 3-D Ammunition of Doniphan, Neb., has made a major effort to expand from the law-enforcement market into commercial realms like hunting. Police detectives say that it is unusual to find recycled ammunition in guns used by criminals but that reloading would undoubtedly expand rapidly if supplies of new ammunition were somehow interrupted.
For now it is a specialty business, with each region of the country dominated by one remanufacturer living largely off contracts too small to attract the major new ammunition manufacturers.
 
Marketing
By the U.S. Mail Or at K Mart
 Ammunition is sold directly to customers by mail order -- something not allowed for guns -- through sporting goods stores and general retailers and at gun shows. In some municipalities and a handful of states, there are restrictions governing both who can buy and who can sell such products.
New York City is among the strictest, with rules forbidding the sale of ammunition to anyone who does not show a legal permit to use a gun firing the type of ammunition being bought. And New York City gun shop owners are required to record every ammunition sale, even though shopkeepers and police detectives agree that the information is useless in criminal investigations.
"I don't recall ever having a police officer look at the book," said Pat Lozito, owner of Alpine Arms Corporation, a gun shop in Brooklyn.
A similar reporting requirement for the whole nation was eliminated by Congress in 1986 as part of legislation banning the production, sale or importation of "cop-killer" bullets that could pierce "bullet-proof" vests. That ban, the only measure ever to limit directly the sale of any form of small-arms ammunition, was ultimately supported even by the National Rifle Association.
Shops like Mr. Lozito's account for a declining share of ammunition sales nationwide, according to ammunition distributors. Because ammunition can be sold to anyone with a driver's license in most of the nation, chains like Wal-Mart and K Mart have regarded it as just one more product to plug into their highly efficient operations.
They have snapped up somewhere between 30 percent and 50 percent of sales, according to Markham Dickson Jr., owner of Sport South Inc. in Shreveport, La. Big gun shops that once bought up to 300 cases a year now purchase as few as 10, Mr. Dickson said.
 
Concerns
 Pushing Shooting, Battling Imports
 Not surprisingly, ammunition makers and their employees are generally strong opponents of efforts to restrict the freedom of gun owners to buy, sell or use firearms. "Strict enforcement of the laws that are on the books can do more for controlling misuse than additional gun controls," said R. G. Phelps, president of 3-D Ammunition and Bullets Inc.
Ammunition industry executives almost always endorse the National Rifle Association's positions on arms and ammunition. But they officially identify with the National Shooting Sports Federation, which is dedicated to promoting hunting and target shooting, and its sister organization, the Sporting Arms and Ammunition Manufacturers Institute, which sets voluntary national standards for bullet diameters and other aspects of ammunition and firearm design.
The sports federation never lobbies and its sister organization rarely does so, said Robert Delfay, executive director of both organizations.
Ammunition companies have donated millions of dollars over the years to organizations that encourage hunting or shooting, including conservation groups trying to rebuild wildlife populations and preserve wetlands.
"I'm personally just as concerned with the anti-hunting and animal rights people as I am the anti-gun people," said Mr. Jones of Federal Cartridge. "Ten years from now we could wind up with all of our guns and ammunition and nothing to shoot at."
Hunting represents about 80 percent of the commercial ammunition market, but that segment has been stagnant at best. Target shooting, which often involves semiautomatic pistols, has been the best commercial growth area.
For that reason, the industry concedes, it does have a direct interest in the fate of semiautomatic weapons that are not typically used for hunting. Winchester officials, for example, say that they noted a drop in sales in Los Angeles County after a number of military-style weapons were banned there.
On the environmental front, the banning of lead pellets in shotgun shells for some types of hunting and concerns about high exposure of shooters to lead at indoor shooting ranges have spurred efforts to redesign products that are radical by historical standards. Steel components in the place of lead completely change the performance characteristics of bullets,
The industry has also faced a challenge from imports. Ammunition is imported from a number of European countries, as well as Israel and Brazil, among others, but it was a surge of low-cost supplies from the Far East in the early 1980's in tandem with weakening demand that shocked domestic manufacturers.
Cost cutting since then seems to have held imports to less than 20 percent of the market. Now, a number of American manufacturers are thinking more globally and pursuing export opportunities of their own.

HEADLINE: VANCE SEES TRUCE IN ENCLAVE STRIFE

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: YEREVAN, Armenia, March 19

 BODY:
The special United Nations envoy to the Caucasus region, Cyrus R. Vance, said today that a cease-fire accord had been reached in the disputed enclave of Nagorno-Karabakh and that he would travel to the territory on Friday.
Mr. Vance, a former American Secretary of State who recently negotiated a plan to send United Nations peacekeeping troops to Yugoslavia, has described his initiative in the Caucasus as a fact-finding mission. 
 Armenian and Azerbaijani forces have fought for four years for control of Nagorno-Karabakh, a mountainous enclave inside Azerbaijan that is inhabited mainly by Armenians. The fighting has intensified since the breakup of the Soviet Union, and Mr. Vance had said that he wanted a cease-fire in place before he traveled to the territory.
He announced that he would visit Nagorno-Karabakh at a news conference after three days of talks with Government officials in Armenia and Azerbaijan, but said he was not trying to mediate the dispute.
 
'To See for Myself'
 "I consider this to be extremely important, because I think it is absolutely essential to my mission that I have the opportunity to see for myself, listen with my own ears and talk to those who are residents in the area," Mr. Vance said.
Iran's official press agency reported that the President of Armenia, Levon Ter-Petrosyan, had agreed to the terms of an Iranian-brokered cease-fire in Nagorno-Karabakh on Wednesday night after meeting in Yerevan, the Armenian capital, with an envoy from Teheran.
Previous efforts to reach a durable truce in the enclave have failed.
Armenia and Azerbaijan signed a tentative agreement on Sunday in Teheran to try to "normalize the situation" in Nagorno-Karabakh but tensions between the two former Soviet republics remain high.
Armenia declared a state of emergency on Wednesday, saying that an Azerbaijani rail blockade of fuel and other necessities had caused a sharp deterioration in its economy.
More fighting was reported in and around Nagorno-Karabakhtoday. Armenian reports said two people were killed and 15 were wounded in Stepanakert, Nagorno-Karabakh's administrative center, by rockets fired from the predominantly Azerbaijani village of Shusha.

HEADLINE: Japan's Gift to Bush

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 19

 BODY:
Well before the Presidential primary season began, Japanese officials and industrialists made no secret that their candidate was President Bush. But it was not until this morning, when the Government announced a new, more restrictive limit on Japanese auto exports to the United States, that those who run Japan Inc. found a way to make their first campaign contribution..
Unlike virtually every other trade concession made in recent years, this one was Japan's idea, not America's. Moreover, timing was crucial. In discussions in the last few weeks, Japanese involved in the decision said they wanted to act late enough to avoid accusations that Japan was meddling in the primaries, but early enough to head off election-year calls for more restrictions on Japanese products, perhaps including those produced in the United States. 
 In the end, true to form, Japan's industrial leaders opted for the plan that they guessed would cost them the most in the short term but the least in the long term. Late Wednesday, after a last-minute analysis of the results in the Michigan primary, they decided to impose the tightest limits in the 12-year history of the voluntary export ceilings, hoping that even if auto companies were forced to forgo some sales in North America this year, they would avoid a big backlash as the election approaches. More carefully timed concessions may follow, perhaps with an announcement about new limits on steel exports sometime around the Pennsylvania primary.
"I don't think that we are making that big a sacrifice, and we are presenting a big gift," a senior executive of one of Japan's biggest auto makers said today, insisting on anonymity for fear of retribution by the Japanese Government. "The main idea is that we are sending a political message. And the message is that we are not an uncaring juggernaut, cruising into the U.S.A. We know how much trouble the Big Three are in, and we are willing to act accordingly."
Under the plan announced today by Kozo Watanabe, the Minister of International Trade and Industry, the ceiling on auto exports to the United States will be set at 1.65 million, effective April 1, far below the current ceiling of 2.3 million. But over five years, as Japan opened more "transplant" factories in the United States, Japanese auto makers have not come close to the old limit. Last year, one of the worst of recent times in the American car market, they shipped only 1.76 million cars to the United States, and until today it seemed the number would be likely to hold this year.
Now, the Japanese car makers will have to forgo sales of about 100,000 cars, or quickly move their production to plants in North America. Only cars actually shipped from Japan fall within the voluntary export limits. That means Japan's share of the American auto market, now 30 percent and still growing, is unlikely to be affected.
Publicly, Japanese officials tried to position their move as a peace offering to the American automobile industry and, by extension, to Americans angry at Japan's success. "The action was taken in consideration of the significance of coexistence and co-prosperity for the Japanese and U.S. auto industries, which are essential for maintaining the free-trade system," Mr. Watanabe said.
But in private, Government officials and Japanese business executives quickly volunteer that the decision was a careful calculation intended to bolster Mr. Bush, whom the Japanese regard as the best bet for maintaining the economic status quo under which Japanese firms have prospered.
Senior Japanese officials view the President as a man more committed to reducing trade tensions with Japan than fundamentally altering the economic status quo. He has no radical plans for reducing the trade deficit, despite the fact that it shows evidence of once again rising quickly. Rightly or wrongly, Mr. Bush is regarded by many in Japan as essentially uninterested in the details of trade negotiations or industrial competitivness.
But in discussions in recent weeks, Japanese officials and industrialists have expressed the fear that Mr. Bush will be forced to change his stripes on trade, under pressure from Democrats on the left and Patrick Buchanan on the right. The idea was to set up a concession that Mr. Bush can take credit for winning, even if the cut was three-quarters symbolism.
Publicly, neither the Government nor any of the nation's leading industrial groups will voice official support for Mr. Bush, and add that if they did try to help him their effort would probably backfire. "If there is really such an impression" that Japan is pushing for the President, "then I would be very concerned," said Takakazu Kuriyama, who later this month will become Japan's new ambassador to the United States. "It would give the impression that we are getting involved in American domestic politics, in an election year."
But all winter, each candidate has been described in the press and on television here through the single lens of trade politics, each labeled "free trader" or "protectionist" or, in a few cases, as "basher." Few candidates received more coverage than Tom Harkin, who dropped out of the race, but who espoused the most protectionist views. Now that he and Bob Kerrey are out of the race, the Japanese may feel that even deeper concessions for the United States may be unnecessary.
One problem for the Japanese is that their list of potential campaign gifts -- export ceilings, commitments to buy more American cars and high technology, new restraints on machine tools and steel -- all smack of "managed trade," something both Mr. Bush and the Japanese insist they oppose.
"It would be best if we could maintain free trade without resorting to such measures," Mr. Watanabe, the Trade Minister, acknowledged today. "But staving off protectionism or regionalism in the U.S. will mean advancing free trade in the end." Mr. Watanabe said, however, that Japan's managed-trade generosity had its limits: he said there were no plans to impose similar limits on auto exports to the European Community. The Europeans have already criticized Japan harshly for failing to treat its trade partners equally, bowing to pressure from the United States, Japan's biggest market, but not from others.

HEADLINE: E.P.A. Research Lags, Report Finds

BYLINE: By WARREN E. LEARY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 19

 BODY:
Research conducted by the Environmental Protection Agency suffers from uneven quality, inadequate funds, poor direction and a lack of first-rate scientists and equipment, a report made public today says.
The report, discussed at a hearing of the House Committee on Science, Space and Technology, said the environmental agency neither conducts environmental research as well as it could nor uses science effectively in considering and writing regulations. 
 Critics charge that many of the agency's policies are driven by response to a crisis rather than by research. William K. Reilly, the Administrator of the E.P.A., says that is not the way it should be.
Concerned about the poor reputation of its science, Mr. Reilly appointed a special advisory committee of prominent scientists last year to assess the work of the E.P.A.'s Office of Research and Development and the agency's overall use of technical information.
 
'Uneven Quality' Found
 "The panel affirms that the E.P.A. needs its own strong science base to provide the background required for effective environmental protection programs," the committee said. "Currently, E.P.A. science is of uneven quality, and the agency's policies and regulations are frequently perceived as lacking a strong scientific foundation."
The committee recommended that the agency take steps to improve matters, including bringing in promiment scientists and appointing a high-ranking science adviser for the agency.
Mr. Reilly, testifying at the hearing, praised the report and said he would begin immediately to carry out many of its suggestions. He promised to appoint science advisers at different levels in the agency, have himself regularly briefed on technical issues, and create and publish an annual research agenda that establishes priorities.
"Sometimes our decisions are based on partial information, and we need to be clearer about our sources of data and the quality of the data," Mr. Reilly said in an interview. "The time has come when science should be what we do and what we are seen to do. We are not eco-cowboys and we don't want to be seen that way."
Representative George E. Brown Jr., who is chairman of the Science, Space and Technology Committee, noted that the E.P.A. conducted little basic research on fundamental environmental processes and health effects. The agency has to do more than short-term applied research if it wants to reduce scientific uncertainties that hamper efforts to create thoughtful, cost-effective regulations, he said.
Mr. Brown, a California Democrat, praised Mr. Reilly's quick response to the science study and said he would try to get more money for environmental research. An analysis by the committee found that even though the environmental agency's research and development budget had been rising modestly in recent years, it still had not recovered from deep cuts that were made under the Reagan Administration.
The research budget increased from $358.1 million in the fiscal year 1991 to $525.9 proposed for the fiscal year 1993. But the analysis found that, after adjusting for inflation, the budget was 3 percent less than it was in 1981.
Dr. Bernard D. Goldstein of Rutgers University, a member of the four-member panel of scientists that studied the E.P.A.'s research, said the panel held three public meetings, interviewed 30 scientists and other experts on environmental issues and received additional comments from 25 others.
 
Science Counseling Urged
 "There is a perception that the quality of science at the E.P.A. is uneven and that the agency's policies and guidelines lack a strong scientific foundation," Dr. Goldstein said at the hearing. The agency needs to recognize the importance of quality science, he said, and include scientific advice "early and often in its deliberations."
When it considers regulations, Dr. Goldstein said, the environmental agency "always has someone from the general counsel's office to assure that what it is doing is in compliance with the law." He added, "We suggest the same role for science in these deliberations."
Responding to the report's recommendations, Mr. Reilly said he wanted agency policies to be driven by rational priorities based on dealing with the greatest environmental risk, and not on the popular crises of the day.
Science and research play a major role in determining both risks and priorities, he said, and have been improving at the agency in recent years.
 
'Pro-Science' Culture Sought
 Saying he wanted to "alter the culture at the agency to be more pro-science," Mr. Reilly said the E.P.A. would try to attract prominent enviromental scientists and engineers to the agency for permanent positions by establishing the equivalent of six endowed chairs at the agency, at $1 million for each.
Other parts of the plan are these:
*Reorganizing the staff into areas by issue, so that work can be conducted long in advance of crises. Some of the areas would include drinking water pollution, climate change, species loss and indoor air pollution.
*Increasing the involvement of academic scientists with the agency by reducing contract research at E.P.A. offices and laboratories, and offering more competitive grants for university researchers.
*Establishing a new standard for research done by the agency, making all of it of publishable quality and assuring taht all of it gets reviewed by a panel of peers, which Mr. Reilly said is often not the case now.
*Creating a board of scientific counselors, made up of the best scientists in academia, government and industry, to advise the E.P.A.'s research division.
*Starting programs to encourage young scientists to choose the E.P.A. as a career to supplement the agency's aging cadre of scientists, and seeking more money to update aging equipment at its laboratories.
"I believe that the steps we are proposing to take will fundamentally alter the way in which scientific information is developed and used in the E.P.A.," Mr. Reilly said.

HEADLINE: Report in California Recommends Customizing High School Studies

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, March 19

 BODY:
Rejecting the traditional "shopping mall" approach of most high schools, a state-sponsored study group today recommended that California students be asked to take two years of a tougher core curriculum, then customize their studies in the last two years to better prepare them for college or the workplace.
The report, the result of a two-year study by a 69-member High School Task Force, proposes routing juniors and seniors into "majors" that would be organized either by career fields, like health care, or by academic disciplines, like the humanities. These focus areas could lead to college, further technical training or directly into a job. Students would have the option of changing paths. 
 Commissioned by the State Department of Education, the report was heartily endorsed by Bill Honig, the state superintendent of public instruction, who said he would hold several workshops to explain the recommendations, in the hope of persuading school boards to adopt them.
 
Tightening of Standards
 The recommendations reflect ideas being discussed by leading educators nationwide about how schools can better prepare students for the work force, ideas that Marc Tucker, president of the National Center on Education and the Economy, said would "bring us into line with the rest of the world."
The California report recommends a tightening of standards for the first two years of high school, requiring students to follow a more rigorous core curriculum that includes language arts, mathematics, history and science as well as other disciplines. The specialization of the final two years would be coordinated with businesses and parents to assure that students are being prepared for the world they will face after graduation.
In presenting the report, its sponsors avoided the term "tracking," which indicates that high and low achievers are separated and is a concept that has aroused strong opposition from people who fear that students will be unfairly labeled and pigeonholed. In contrast to tracking systems, the report's sponsors said its recommendations were meant to let students choose their path, but to require all students to take the rigorous core curriculum.
"There is a concern on the part of the business community and the world at large that kids coming out of high school are not prepared for the work force," said Susie Lang, a spokeswoman for the State Department of Education. "There is a sense that unless a kid is on a college-prep track, the rest of the kids are left to just kind of wander through, and then suddenly they have a diploma and, 'Now what do I do?' "
 
Reorganizing Teaching Time
 The report also recommends a reorganization of teaching time to foster closer teacher-student relationships and a refocussing of academic work to emphasize underlying processes rather than rote acquisition of facts.
David D. Marsh, a professor of education at the University of Southern California who helped write the report, said that although some of its elements were already in use in some California schools, broad implementation would be slowed by budget constraints and entrenched attitudes about teaching.
To dramatize the intent of the recommendations, a summary of the report was made public today at Pasadena High School, where students can elect to join the school's Graphic Arts Academy. This program, developed in partnership and with money from the Printing Industry Association, includes a paid work internship and offers both vocational training and a focus on related academic subjects like chemistry, history and applied arts.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Verbatim;
Excerpts From Tsongas's News Conference on His Withdrawal

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: BOSTON, March 19

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the news conference where former Senator Paul E. Tsongas today announced his withdrawal from the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination.
 
 It had been my intention to make only one announcement today, but because of a phone call that came in an hour ago I have two to make. One is that I will suspend my candidacy for President of the United States, and because of the second phone call I am pleased to announce that I have agreed to accept the presidency of the Speedo bathing suit company. . . . 
 A year ago, you and I began our journey of purpose. We undertook this journey out of love of country. America faces economic peril and social disharmony. That is not what America's all about. America is a great nation and we are a great people and we must be called to that greatness.
This journey had two missions. The first was to redefine the Democratic Party, to combine economic growth with our traditional social compassion. America needs such a Democratic Party. I believe the force of our message and our sheer survival has caused people all over this country to see a new path.
It is a steeper and harder path, but it is more compelling and more noble. It is the path of America's future. At the end of that path lies a prosperous and humane America. More importantly, it is the path of our generational responsibility. Our young deserve our willingness to make hard choices. Their fate lies in our resolve. To turn away from that sacred responsibility is to violate the legacy of our ancestors. That message, that sacredness, that resolve, was my mission, and I feel deeply fulfilled. The obligation of my survival has been met.
The second mission was to secure the nomination, take the party and take the fight to George Bush. I believe that I could have brought in independents and moderate and disaffected Republicans to combine with traditional Democrats and become President of the United States.
But the hard fact is that the nomination process requires resources, and last evening it was clear that we did not have the resources necessary to fight the media war in New York. We simply did not have the resources. I would have been defined by others, and have been unable to defend myself.
Worse, my message, my message would have been wounded, and all that we worked for, for this past year, would have been put at risk.
The message must endure.
At times we were under great pressure to change our views to accommodate various interests. I chose not to. My principles could not have been compromised without destroying that message. Those decisions cost us dearly, and the resources simply were not there to make up the difference, and thus today's announcement to suspend the campaign.
The alternative was clear. The alternative was to play the role of spoiler. That is not what I'm about; that is not worthy. I did not survive my ordeals in order to be the agent of the re-election of George Bush.
My task is to pay homage to principles. In the larger sense it is our collective -- you and me -- our collective commitment to a set of values. That is what will endure. We stood for something. We stood for something.

 	 	 		. . .	 	My heart is hopeful for America. I congratulate Bill Clinton and Jerry Brown. I look forward to the convention, and I look forward to a Democratic victory in November.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Q. [Inaudible] using the words "suspending" your campaign?
A. The difference -- the reason I'm using the word 'suspension' -- is that we have delegates who wish to go to the convention, and by suspending the campaign they're intact and they can go. And we've got a number of calls urging us, pleading with us, to do that. And so that's why we're doing that.
Q. Senator, [inaudible] problem was not money, that you had plenty of money to go on. What changed in the last 24 hours?
A. The problem is not money coming in; the money was coming in. I mean the amount of money coming in, the numbers I think you're familiar with, 300,000 in February -- 300,000 in January.
I will say this is totally aside -- I can now wander freely --
But I'd like to apologize for three remarks I made during the campaign. One, Molly is in the fourth grade not the fifth grade.
The second is I have three children, not four.
And the other thing I said the other day was I got cancer at the age of 38, not 42. So let me -- gotten all those things straight.
This campaign was lost in 1991 because of a lack of resources. It was almost rescued in 1992 by the message. We came into 1992 without any money and in debt. So the 300,000 that came in in January, the 1.4 million that came in February, and the 1.4 we've raised already in March, I mean that was wonderful, but the problem is we were starved.
If money is the mother's milk of politics, our mothers didn't show up until late January.
And so what happened was we had no reserves. As we then moved into the states with all the media buys, what we were bringing in was fine, but there was no reserves to play, and what we found out in Texas, Florida, Michigan and Illinois was the fact that if someone goes on television and defines you and you have no capacity to respond, people's impression of you is not what you are but what you are defined by your opponent.
And it was obvious that to go into New York, defenseless in terms of financial resources, being unable to get up the air in the Buffalos, Schnectadys, et cetera, would have meant that we could not compete. And the danger was, and the great agony, was that the message, if I had gone down in that way, that the message would have been so damaged, that all that we have endured would have been hurt.
So I have no complaints about what was coming in in the last month or so. What affected us was not having the capacity to organize to do things back last year, and to come into 1992 basically in a state of poverty.
And I've spoken to all of the other five candidates. Bob Kerrey was in Disney World.
I told him I would be there, too, at three o'clock. You can decide who's goofy.

HEADLINE: Workers Mourn Maxwell House's Last Drop

BYLINE: By EVELYN NIEVES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOBOKEN, N.J., March 19

 BODY:
Twenty-one months after the conglomerate that owns Maxwell House announced that it would phase out its operation here, the last big factory on this famous waterfront is sputtering to an end.
Today, the day before their last, union workers had a farewell lunch at the plant cafeteria and finished cleaning out their lockers. They pick up their final paychecks Friday. Then, save for about two dozen employees who will remain to tie up loose ends by July 1, the sprawling brick complex off Frank Sinatra Drive, once the largest producer of coffee in the world, will be empty. 
 At a time when businesses throughout the country have been closing with little warning, the protracted quality of this plant's death has done little to reduce the impact on Hoboken. To many who live here, Maxwell House was more than a factory. It seemed to define the city -- from the smell of roasted coffee that wafted through the streets 24 hours a day to the landmark "Good to the Last Drop" sign with its tilted coffee cup dripping neon drops into the Hudson.
 
Dwindling Consumption
 And for more than a decade Maxwell House has been Hoboken's largest taxpayer and employer. It had 640 workers in June 1990, when its owner, Kraft-General Foods, a Philip Morris subsidiary, announced that the Hoboken plant had lost out to one in Jacksonville, Fla., in a competition to see which would stay and which would go.
Company officials blamed dwindling coffee consumption and an excess of production capacity, with four plants operating at a net of 55 percent of capacity, for the decision to close one of its two East Coast operations; the Hoboken plant, where some workers earn $15 to $20 an hour, was chosen because its labor costs were 20 percent higher than those in Jacksonville and because it sits on 22 acres of valuable waterfront land.
Nan Redmond, a corporate affairs director for General Foods U.S.A., which directly oversees the Kraft-General Foods plant, said the company has no plans for now to remove its famous sign and that it has hired real-estate consultants to evaluate "a full range" of possibilities for the property.
 
Jobs and Taxes
 After Friday hundreds of people at the Hoboken plant who made the company their life's work and are now 40 or 50 or older will be unemployed. And Hoboken will have only a small barge-repair company that employs 75 people left on the waterfront, said Peggy Thomas, director of Hoboken's Department of Planning and Community Development. "The biggest impact is the loss of jobs," she said.
Scores of workers who have been at the plant 30 years or more have said they are bitter at the way the closing was handled. James Reilly, who joined Maxwell House after graduating from high school 35 years ago, called the last year the worst of his life. "It's like we had a disease and have been wasting away," Mr. Reilly said. "It would have better if they shot us in the head."
Mr. Reilly, who lives in Jersey City, and other members of Local 56 of the United Food and Commercial Workers Union say they were dealt a bad hand in the final contract negotiations. Mr. Reilly will not receive the pension or medical benefits he has been expecting because he will not turn 55 until next February.
He blames the union president, Leo Cinaglia, for negotiating an agreement that sets both 55 years of age and 25 years of seniority as minimum requirements for a pension. Mr. Cinaglia pleaded guilty in January to accepting payoffs from the owner of a meat-packing company in Pennsauken, N.J.
Ms. Redmond, the corporate affairs director for General Foods U.S.A., said the company had tried to negotiate a fair deal for its employees. She said it provided an extensive package of support services during the months leading to the closing, including an on-site transition team available for resume writing and other job services, a $2,500 stipend for those who want training in another field, even a Dale Carnegie course, bonuses for those who stayed on after the closing announcement and offers to relocate workers to other plants.
"The company recognizes that the employees have put in long years of loyal service," she said. "We really worked very hard to make the agreement as fair as possible."
Fourteen employees have moved to plants in Houston or Jacksonville, Ms. Redmond said.
Earlier this week, management negotiated a final agreement that added three months of medical benefits to the original severance package, which included at least three months of medical coverage.
Under the agreement, employees who will turn 55 by the end of the year may stay on with the company so they can retire with full pensions. Mr. Reilly is not among them.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Daniel Cappiello, left, who has worked at the Maxwell House plant for almost 25 years, speaking outside the plant with James Reilly, who joined the company after graduating from high school 35 years ago. (William E. Sauro/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Democratic Convention Attracts Corporate Help

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON

 BODY:
With the opening session of the Democratic National Convention four months away, New York City and the Democrats have begun lining up corporate sponsors for not necessarily partisan projects inside and outside Madison Square Garden.
The city said last month that A.T.& T., American Express, New York Telephone and Time Warner had pledged $2 million in cash, equipment and supplies to the New York '92 Host Committee, a nonpartisan public and private partnership set up to manage the city's convention preparations. 
 The four companies and the committee plan to recruit 6,000 volunteers and raise $6.5 million more for convention-related functions. A.T.& T. is providing computers and technical support for the host committee.
The city estimates it will spend $20.8 million to provide services and support for the convention, which is expected to generate $190 million in business. It will be held from July 13 through 16.
 
Special Services
 To help delegates find their way around, American Express will give them its "Pocket Guide to New York" and will charter buses to carry them and their families on a shopping spree. The delegates will also be able to consult a special convention telephone directory being donated by New York Telephone listing delegations, convention facilities and hotels.
Some of the convention-related projects are not for conventioneers only. New York Telephone is giving the host committee advertising display space on 400 telephone booths in the five boroughs, and Mayor David N. Dinkins announced plans yesterday for a nonpartisan students' guide to the Presidential election process.
The Board of Education will distribute the guide to 25,000 social studies teachers next month. Scholastic Inc., which will edit the guide, is spending $10,000 on the project and is donating additional labor costs. The New York Times gave the host committee $25,000 to finance the guide.
"There couldn't a better time to excite New York students about the electoral process than now," said Arthur Sulzberger Jr., the publisher of The Times. "I believe the convention will galvanize the city as it did in 1976, when the city had gone through a similarly troubled economic time. Then, as now, many of us were down but not out."

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Success in House Splits Party Leadership

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 19

 BODY:
Just when the House Republican leaders have forced the Democrats into retreat over the House bank scandal, they are showing more strain than glee.
Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, the minority leader, today distanced himself from his second in command, Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, whose slashing attacks on what he calls Democratic corruption have dominated the debate on the House bank. 
 "Newt's personality is Newt's, and mine is mine," Mr. Michel said at a breakfast with reporters today. "We each do our own thing. I am not in any position to tell Newt what to say or when to say it."
The differences between the two have more to do with style and tactics than with philosophy. Mr. Michel likes to go head to head with Democrats over policy matters on the floor by day and play gin rummy with them by night. Mr. Gingrich, for his part, plays political hardball every waking hour.
The fissures developing between the ranking House Republicans also reflect the fault lines emerging in their party as the comity of the Reagan era fades. Mr. Gingrich is somewhat more conservative than Mr. Michel, and he is more closely associated than Mr. Michel with Republicans like Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp who promote supply-side economics.
 
'This Aura of Purity'
 Asked if most House Republicans supported the Gingrich tactic of aggressively politicizing the bank scandal, he said, "You better be doggone sure you are pure yourself before you take on all this aura of purity." He was clearly referring to Mr. Gingrich, who after several days of blaming Democrats acknowledged that he had overdrawn his own House bank account about 30 times, and to other prominent House Republicans who have written checks against insufficient funds.
"There are some in our side who say when they are on the ropes, push them over and revel in it," Mr. Michel said. By contrast, he said he himself had "devoted my entire professional life" to the House and concluded that "politics can be a respected profession."
Asked to comment on Mr. Michel's remarks, Mr. Gingrich said: "That's a very honest assessment. We are very different personalities. I tend to be more aggressive and risk-taking."
"I think Michel intellectually believes it is possible to have an honest bipartisan relationship with the current Democratic leadership, and I believe and have for a number of years that one of our major institutional obligations is to end a 38-year monopoly of power," he said. But he said he and Mr. Michel "coordinate on dozens of things" and that he hopes to someday serve as majority leader when Mr. Michel is Speaker.
Some Republicans are plainly uncomfortable with Mr. Gingrich's attack on Werner W. Brandt, the newly appointed acting sergeant-at-arms, who he suggested without offering evidence may have been involved in a cover-up of cocaine selling by an employee at the House post office.
"Nobody is comfortable with all the finger-pointing because clearly a sufficient number of prominent Republicans have become entangled," said Representative Henry J. Hyde, Republican of Illinois. "I'm speaking particularly of the Cabinet members whose embarrassment has been demonstrated. I rather think Mr. Gingrich started down the bobsled course before he realized the nature and extent of this entire debacle."
Three of President Bush's Cabinet officers called news conferences this week to announce that they, too, had overdrafts while they were House members.
At the same time, Mr. Hyde said that "some people feel Bob is too nice for his own good." Mr. Michel's remarks today, according to some members, could help toughen up his nice-guy image a bit.
 
Trying to Define Himself?
 "He's trying to define himself," said Representative Jim Leach, an Iowa Republican who thinks differences between Mr. Michel and Mr. Gingrich reflect a similar division over tactics and ideology in the national party. "There's a kind of leadership combat going under way."
The skirmishing comes as Mr. Michel is negotiating with Speaker Thomas S. Foley over working out a new system of House administration. Democrats hope to enlist Mr. Michel, thereby driving a wedge between Republican conservatives and moderates.
Mr. Gingrich has publicly said that he, too, is willing to work with Democrats as long as they are willing to share full responsibility and powers of administration, a position the Democratic leadership finds unacceptable.
Mr. Michel wants to create the post of chief financial officer, who would watch over the financial accounts now under the control of the House clerk. Democratic strategists think Mr. Michel's proposal has some merit, though they say his demand that the officer be selected by a two-thirds majority of the House would weaken Democratic control of the chamber. But Mr. Foley said today that he is prepared to compromise with Mr. Michel.
Privately, Democratic strategists say they expect that Mr. Gingrich will not allow Mr. Michel to compromise with the Democrats, since that would undercut efforts to exploit the bank affair and elect a Republican House majority in November.
At the breakfast today, Mr. Michel said he did not know if Mr. Gingrich planned to challenge him and run for leader after the election. Most Republicans say they do not believe Mr. Michel can be unseated, and they noted that White House officials have urged Mr. Michel to run for re-election and continue in his post. But a few Republican members say that Mr. Gingrich could gain the advantage and win the top leadership post should the Democrats win the White House, and House Republicans feel they need a more partisan and aggressive leader.

HEADLINE: Trade Gap Narrowed In January

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 19

 BODY:
The merchandise trade deficit narrowed slightly in January to $5.77 billion, even though American exports fell for a third straight month, the Government said today.
The Bush Administration called the weakness in exports temporary, but private economists worried that the lull could prove more lasting and imperil chances to mount a sustained recovery. 
 The Commerce Department said the January trade deficit was 3.9 percent lower than December's $6 billion imbalance. Imports, held down by weak demand in the United States, dropped 1.4 percent, to $41.30 billion, while exports fell 1 percent, to $35.54 billion.
 
January Improvement Hailed
 The Administration, attacked on the campaign trail for failing to do enough to fight unfair foreign trade practices, hailed the January improvement in the overall deficit.
The new Commerce Secretary, Barbara Hackman Franklin, insisted that the long-term trend for American exports was still bright because of "growing U.S. competitiveness in world markets."
Last year, the merchandise trade deficit fell to an eight-year-low of $66.26 billion, down from $101.72 billion in 1990.
 
Rising Deficit Foreseen
 But many economists are forecasting that the deficit will resume its upward climb this year as the recovery spurs Americans' demand for imports and spreading weakness overseas cuts into export growth.
"The good news is that our economy has hit bottom and is coming out of the recession, but one of the costs of that rebound will be a wider trade deficit," said Jay Goldinger, an economist at Capital Insight, an investment firm in Beverly Hills, Calif.
John Endean, a vice president with the American Business Conference, a trade group for mid-size corporations, said that United States companies would face growing competition from countries trying to make up for weak domestic demand by export sales.
"Japan and Germany are making no secret of their intention to ignite their faltering domestic economies through more exports and less imports," he said.
As usual, the country's largest deficit was rung up with Japan, at $3.82 billion in January, or two-thirds of the total, although that was down by $645 million from the December deficit. The second-biggest imbalance was with China, a deficit of $1.4 billion.
Japanese officials, concerned about an anti-Japan backlash in the United States, announced that they were lowering their voluntary limit on passenger-car shipments to the United States to 1.65 million a year, down from the current 2.3 million.
But United States auto makers blasted the announcement today, saying it would do little if nothing to lower the trade deficit between the two countries.
 
Surplus With E.C. Climbs
 America's surplus with the 12-nation European Community climbed by $713 million, to $1.88 billion in January. This gain was cited as an encouraging development by Stephen Cooney, trade expert at the National Association of Manufacturers.
The 1 percent drop in exports followed a 2.8 percent December decline and a 2.3 percent November drop. The decline was led by a $270 million decrease in sales of aircraft and parts and a drop of $283 million in farm shipments, reflecting weaker demand for soybeans in particular.
The 1.4 percent decline in imports was led by an 8 percent drop in petroleum imports, which fell to $3.62 billion in January. Non-petroleum imports were down a smaller seven-tenths of 1 percent, to $37.69 billion.

HEADLINE: At the Bar;
Keeping tabs on legal fees means going after the people who are hired to go after people.

BYLINE: By David Margolick

 BODY:
"If a client does not complain about a bill, it isn't high enough." This aphorism was part of the lawyerly wit and wisdom John J. McCloy, the former diplomat and New York lawyer, gave each year to the tenderfoots in his law firm.
But such an attitude was by no means limited to Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy. Reluctant to dirty themselves on such unseemly matters, lawyers long set their fees arbitrarily, often erring on the side of extravagance. Conversely, clients, either intimidated by counsel or unduly deferential to them, rarely kept close tabs. 
 In the last few years, though, as the economy has slumped, belts have tightened, and sentimental traditions have yielded to hard-headed pragmatism, all this has begun to change. For a fee, a number of companies will now monitor legal bills. The oldest and busiest, it seems, is Legalgard Inc. of Philadelphia.
In its promotional literature, the company describes its mission euphemistically. "Legalgard conducts an objective and detailed review of in-force attorney billing and utilization practices to determine a baseline for billing and case management problems and to identify opportunities for savings," it states. Translated into English, that means investigating ripoffs.
The growth of Legalgard, which primarily serves insurance companies and corporations, reflects the fertility of the territory. Begun only five years ago, it has expanded 300 percent annually ever since. It has opened branch offices in Woodland Hills, Calif., Tampa, Fla., and Chicago and now employs 80 people. Most are lawyers-turned-investigators, presumably familiar with all the fine points of padding.
"Lawyers were the last of the sacred cows, the last people on the face of the earth to be held accountable to anyone," said Legalgard's chairman, John J. Marquess. He recalled how, only a few years ago, a potential client of his balked at second-guessing his lawyer. "He told me, 'If you can't trust your lawyer, it's like not being able to trust your wife,' " Mr. Marquess said. "I told him, 'Based on what your legal costs have looked like for the last five years, maybe you should go home and check what your wife is doing.' "
Mr. Marquess, who practiced law for 15 years himself, said his investigators found irregularities on four of every five legal bills, ranging between 10 and 30 percent of the total. With legal fees in the United States totalling $100 billion a year, he said, "The target market is gigantic."
Since 1987, Mr. Marquess's minions have found all manner of machinations, including these:
*A lawyer in Century City, Cal. who, on three occasions, billed a client for 50-hour workdays. "I don't care what you say, nobody has an excuse for billing more than 24 hours a day," Mr. Marquess indignantly declared.
*A Los Angeles lawyer who charged a client in 135 separate cases for the same piece of legal research: the meaning of a "collapsed" condominium.
*A San Francisco law firm that passed on to clients the $17,000 cost of its program for summer law clerks -- all under the guise of "legal research." "It was really devious," Mr. Marquess said.
*Boston lawyers who billed their clients for the cost of either heating and air-conditioning their offices or commuting between their homes and offices.
*A lawyer in Cleveland who charged his client for the suit, shirts, and underwear he purchased in the midst of a long trial.
*A prominent New York law firm which charged $375 an hour for time spent by one of its partner to make photocopies.
*A Chicago law firm that put 79 of its 82 lawyers, along with all of its paralegals, on a single products-liability case, racking up a $6 million tab for work which, Mr. Marquess estimates, should have cost no more than $200,000. Another Chicago lawyer, he said, charged $25,000 for "ground transportation" during an assignment in San Francisco. "Either the attorney was renting a limousine on top of a rental car or was renting an escort," Mr. Marquess said.
*A firm in New Orleans that routinely billed four hours of work for letters that were one sentence long.
Since he signs confidentiality agreements with his clients, Mr. Marquess would not identify any of the malefactors. But he offered some clues.
Abuses, he said, tended initially to be more novel on the West Coast. But the worst offenders, he said, were the largest and ostensibly the most prestigious law firms, a fact he attributed to a combination of bureaucracy and arrogance.
"The big firms on Wall Street are having it both ways: they're billing $400 an hour and massaging the billings on top of that," he said. Their preferred modus operandi: overstaffing. "A matter that takes 10 lawyers and 3 paralegals in one firm will typically take 25 lawyers and 12 paralegals in New York," he said.
