HEADLINE: Paul Ylvisaker, 70, Educator and Urban Planner

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
Paul N. Ylvisaker, who championed cities and the urban underclass as a planner, government official, foundation executive and educator, died on Tuesday at George Washington University Hospital in Washington. He was 70 years old and lived in Cambridge, Mass.
He died of heart failure, his family said. 
 Dr. Ylvisaker headed President Lyndon B. Johnson's Task Force on Cities and helped forge his model-cities program. As the Ford Foundation's public affairs director, he funneled money to social programs predating the Federal war on poverty.
Lamenting the decline of cities, he wrote in Life magazine: "Men may find God in nature, but when they look at cities they are viewing themselves. And what Americans see mirrored in their cities these days is not very flattering."
He taught at Princeton, Yale and Harvard, where he was also was the dean who led the Graduate School of Education in a sometimes wrenching decade of transformation. He remained on the faculty until his death, teaching ethics and philanthropy.
He served as New Jersey's first state Commissioner of Community Affairs. He unveiled a visionary concept of an urban complex for the Meadowlands, then a marshland of foxtail reeds and world-class garbage dumps. He headed a commission that ended decades of deadlock and eventually led to the construction of the stadium, arena and racetrack and nearby stores and housing.
He also proved to be a man of courage and gritty street smarts. Soon after he took office, in 1967, riots erupted in Newark, killing 26 people. In the tense aftermath, the State Police and the National Guard were conducting a house-to-house search for weapons in Plainfield. Leading the contingent were four armored personnel carriers, mounted with machine guns and loaded with soldiers bristling with bayoneted rifles, pistols and submachine guns.
Fearing the ominous symbolism and possible reaction, he ran into the street waving his arms in front of the convoy and shouting, "Stop! Stop! This is a peaceful community." The vehicles halted. After he conferred with authorities, the search resumed, but in less provocative jeeps.
 
Harvard Degrees
 Dr. Ylvisaker (pronounced EL-vuh-saw-ker) was born in St. Paul. His father was a Lutheran minister and college president. He graduated from Mankato State Teachers College in 1942 and at Harvard earned a master's degree in public administration in 1945 and a doctorate in political economics and government in 1948.
Leaving government in 1970, he taught at Princeton and Yale.
He returned to Harvard as dean in 1972, when Federal grants were drying up and enrollment was plummeting. He guided the education school to explore broad education theory and philosophy and child development. In later years, he focused on practicality, with courses on politics, computers, school leadership and community support. He also expanded the ratio of women and minorities among students and faculty.
His wife of 44 years, Elizabeth, died last year. He is survived by a daughter, Elizabeth of Meredith, N.H.; three sons, Mark, of Fort Myers, Fla., Peter, of Hightstown, N.J., and David, of Washington; two brothers, John, of Michigan, and David, of Indiana, and two sisters, Elizabeth Brush, of Florida and Barbara Newsom, of New Hampshire.

HEADLINE: OUR TOWNS;
The Last Picture Show? Not if He Can Help It

BYLINE: By Andrew H. Malcolm

DATELINE: TEANECK, N.J.

 BODY:
BOB AND ESTELLE SPIEWAK shuffled ahead in the movie line, along with dozens of others outside the Movie City Theater on Cedar Lane here. The line moved unusually fast. In fact, the line itself was unusual in this old dark downtown.
Soon, the Spiewaks confronted Melissa Paget, the teen-age cashier. 
 "Two please," said Mr. Spiewak.
"That's $2," said Miss Paget.
"No," said Mr. Spiewak, controlling his impatience with another moronic youth, "we want two tickets."
"That's $2," repeated Miss Paget, controlling her impatience with another adult who'd yet to hear the good news. "Tickets are $1 each."
Yeah, right, thought the Spiewaks, real New York types who scanned the lobby for the bad news. Perhaps this was a scratchy film print or a benefit for the Reverend Moon. Above the candy counter hung a sign: "Popcorn $1. Drinks $1. Candy $1." O.K., but how long is this suspicious sale?
"It's permanent," said Howard Grant, who ought to know. He's the owner, who's determined to ride the recession into prosperity with a ridiculous, revolutionary thought for an often economically myopic America: lower prices might increase sales in tough times. If New Jersey can survive a gas war with fuel prices below $1 a gallon, how about a movie war with $1 tickets? So far, the first few thousand customers seem up to the shock.
"This is great!" Roger Nelson said. "It gets people out of their homes and we'll have a community again."
"I can handle this," said Benno Groeneveld, who handed Miss Paget a $5 bill and received $1 back with four (!) tickets. With popcorn, drinks and free parking, the entire evening cost his family $12.
And Mr. Grant's three screens are not showing "Godzilla's Revenge" or obscure Angst epics from prewar Sweden. Tonight, he's offering "The Prince of Tides," "Stop! Or My Mom Will Shoot," "Shining Through" and "Father of the Bride." This weekend's matinees are "Hook" and "My Girl." All shows are $1 at all times.
For $1, who cares about Mr. Grant's economics but, briefly, here's how it works: Movie City gets only 10 percent of the $6.07 after-tax income on a $6.50 first-run ticket. That's about 61 cents. Film distributors keep the rest. On an almost first-run show, one that's been out a month or two, Movie City keeps about 65 percent of the 93-cent after-tax ticket price, or 61 cents.
That's the same. But people weren't paying $6.50 at this theater just west of the George Washington Bridge. Faced with a recession's uncertainties, they stayed home with free TV or rental movies. Movie City routinely closed Mondays and Tuesdays. Other times only a handful appeared. "Many nights," Mr. Grant said, "it wasn't worth turning on the heat." On the weekend before $1 tickets began in February, 212 people paid $6.50.
Last weekend, 3,782 people flowed through the turnstile at $1 each; two-thirds also bought food. "I'm very excited," said Mr. Grant, a pigtailed, 39-year-old cinematic impresario who's loved movies since the 50-cent double features of his youth on the Jersey Shore.
The National Association of Theater Owners says it's been 28 years since movie prices averaged $1 nationally. That was back when "Mary Poppins," "Goldfinger," "Doctor Zhivago" and "Zorba the Greek" packed them in. Today the average at the nation's 23,814 screens is $4.50.
Mr. Grant thinks he may be on to something at his 61-year-old Art Deco cinema, which he bought in 1984. He divided it into three theaters and watched attendance dwindle. "Now," he said, "if we can keep these weekend numbers and boost weeknights, we'll make it work."
He also regards himself as an admittedly less-than-altruistic educator. "People are used to two movie dates," he said. "First-run right away and video rentals months later. Now, I want them also to think of nearly first-run one month later for only one buck."
The words "one buck" seem to spread quickly in the New York area. Movie City's three phones ring constantly. Callers this week even sought directions from Staten Island, where using a bridge for one minute now costs more than a 90-minute movie.
"We've lived here 20 years," said LaRease Limerick, "but we got out of the movie habit. This is fun and exciting. Cedar Lane is full of evening life again."
Here's something else weird. When one $6.50 movie ended, some people always tried to sneak into a second film. But for $1, they're more honest. They actually pay again. "I don't remember when I last saw people make a two-movie night of it," said Mr. Grant, who was smiling as Mr. Spiewak turned back toward the cashier with his two $1 tickets and a question.
"What about a senior-citizen discount?"
"Good luck," Mr. Grant replied.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Long-Term Rates Drop Below 8%

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Long-term interest rates fell below 8 percent yesterday, continuing a cautious downward move that began earlier in the week.
Trading volume, however, was once again light, and participants said that despite the improvement the negative tone dominating the market for much of the last two months remained largely intact. 
 Searching for reasons to explain the rise in bond and note prices, traders said much of the move was a correction from oversold positions at the end of last week. And foreign accounts are doing some buying, they said.
"Some overseas demand is showing up, mainly from Europe," one government bond trader said. "Most of those countries are looking at elections of one sort or another fairly soon, and some investors who had been saying they wanted to be in dollar-denominated assets are moving money now. Also, we have heard of Middle Eastern money moving money out of short-term securities and into 10-year and 30-year issues."
 
'No Politicians Were Talking'
 Jay Goldinger, a principal at Capital Insight, a bond brokerage firm in Beverly Hills, Calif., said Japanese investors purchased securities during overnight trading in Tokyo.
Mr. Goldinger and others also said that the market benefited yesterday from the absence of important new economic reports and the increased possibility that Congress and the White House will reach a stalemate over a fiscal stimulus package.
"No politicians were talking," Mr. Goldinger said. "The market has tended to do better when that happens."
Today is the deadline President Bush set for Congress to enact his economic plan to stimulate the economy. An alternative plan forged by Democrats in the House and Senate is almost certain to be vetoed.
Credit market participants have worried for months that lawmakers would cobble together a package so stimulative that it would rekindle inflation and add to the already burgeoning Federal budget deficit.
For the most part, traders shrugged off a drop in weekly unemployment claims and trade data showing that exports fell for the third consecutive month.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 10013/32 , up 14/32 , to yield 7.96 percent, compared with 8.00 percent late Wednesday.
It is the first time bond yields have closed below 8 percent in more than a week.
Among outstanding Treasury note issues, the 7 1/2 percent 10-year securities were offered at 9921/32 , up 3/8 point, to yield 7.54 percent. The 6 3/4 percent five-year notes were offered at 9830/32 , up 6/32 , to yield 7.00 percent. And the 5 3/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 9910/32 , up 2/32 , to yield 5.75 percent.
Rates on short-term Treasury bills were unchanged or down slightly.
Three-month bills were offered late yesterday at a discount rate of 4.04 percent, unchanged from late Wednesday. Six-month bill rates fell by one basis point, or a hundredth of a percentage point, to 4.21 percent. And one-year bill rates fell by four basis points, to a late-offered rate of 4.45 percent.
 
Many Corporate Debt Issues
 Issuance of new corporate debt securities was heavy.
By far the largest amount of new debt priced was a two-part, $2.07 billion offering of securities backed by auto loan receivables from the General Motors Assistance Corporation.
One part of the offering consists of $1.066 billion of senior certificates with an average life of 0.64 years.
These 5.20 percent securities were priced at $100, or par, to yield 5.256 percent.
The remaining $1.012 billion of the issue was sold as senior certificates with an average life of 1.32 years.
The 5.95 percent securities were priced at $99.968 to yield 6.05 percent.
The First Boston Corporation acted as lead manager for the underwriting. The securities are rated AAA by both Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
The Philip Morris Companies offered $350 million worth of five-year notes through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch & Company.
The 7.50 percent notes were priced at $99.50 to yield 7.662 percent, 60 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 6 3/4 percent five-year notes at the time of pricing.
The noncallable notes are rated A-2 by Moody's and A by Standard & Poor's.
The Kroger Corporation offered $175 million worth of high-yield junk bonds through an underwriting group led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.
The 12-year, 9 3/4 percent securities were priced at $100, or par.
The issue is rated B-1 by Moody's and B by Standard & Poor's.
 
M3 Off $4.2 Billion
 In other developments, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday that two of the three measures of the nation's money supply it tracks on a weekly basis rose during the week ended March 9.
M-3, the broadest money measure, fell by $4.2 billion.
The money numbers were in line with market expectations, and had no impact on prices in the credit markets.

HEADLINE: New Jobless Claims Fall In Week

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 19

 BODY:
The number of workers filing for first-time jobless benefits fell in the first week of March, the Goverment said today, but analysts said it was too early to predict an upturn in the job market.
 The Labor Department said 433,000 people filed new claims for state jobless benefits in the week that ended March 7, down from a revised 460,000 the previous week. 
 The drop of 27,000 was larger than expected, as private economists, on average, had forecast a decline of only 6,000.
 But despite other signs the economy is healing, analysts said they do not expect a significant improvement in the job market until a recovery has been under way for several months. They cite the normal lag between the time business activity picks up and companies start rehiring workers.
 Carol Stone, senior economist at Nomura Securities International, said it was too early to say whether the claims figure heralded a recovery in the job market. The nation's unemployment rate hit 7.3 percent last month, the highest in six and a half years.
 
 
New Claims Average
 The department said the four-week average number of new claims, considered a more accurate measure of the job market, slipped to 447,000 from 451,750 in the period ended Feb. 29.
 Economists monitor new jobless claims as a barometer of the labor market and the overall economy.
 The department said Michigan, Texas and California reported the biggest drops in new claims. Michigan officials said the 4,423 drop in filings was a result of fewer layoffs by auto makers.
 Missouri was the only state with an increase in claims of more than 1,000. The state said its 1,699 new claims were a result of layoffs in the food processing and transportation industries.

HEADLINE: Job Cuts Set In Bank Deal

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, March 19

 BODY:
The BankAmerica Corporation said today that it expects to eliminate 10,000 to 12,000 jobs over the next three years after its planned merger with the Security Pacific Corporation.
BankAmerica said that the actual number of employees laid off would probably be fewer than 10,000 to 12,000 because of attrition. The company did not say where the job losses would occur. It is expected, though, that a large number will be in Los Angeles, where Security Pacific is based, and also in San Francisco, where BankAmerica has its headquarters. 
 The two banks now have a combined work force of 91,000. In addition to the positions to be eliminated, the work force will be reduced by the sale of branches to satisfy antitrust concerns.
The number of job reductions has been one of the major unanswered questions about the huge merger, contributing to apprehension about the deal, particularly in California, where the economy is already weak and where both banks have most of their employees.
Cutting the work force is key to BankAmerica's plan to save $1.2 billion in annual operating expenses from the combined bank. Without such a saving, the purchase of Security Pacific, which is troubled by bad loans, would be hard to justify.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Carried Higher By Report on Trade Deficit

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar closed up yesterday in sluggish trading, carried higher by the Government's report of a decline in the trade deficit.
The Commerce Department said the trade deficit improved slightly in January, falling 3.9 percent from December, to $5.77 billion, the lowest level in two months. 
 Kermit Claytor, a currency market analyst with MMS International, said that the dollar rose on the trade report, but that trading was slow, with traders reluctant to make major commitments.
"We'd need a rather convincing event to break out of the dollar ranges on either side," Mr. Claytor said. "There's more scope for a downside move on a bad number than an upside move on a better-than-expected number."
Dollar trading has been lethargic since last week, when the Government released solid retail sales figures that did not move the dollar as expected.
"It's discouraging when you fail to see a significant rally," Mr. Claytor said.
Some analysts attributed yesterday's sluggish trading to a snowstorm in New York that caused some dealers to head home early.
Another Government report showed that the number of newly laid-off workers applying for state unemployment insurance fell in the first week of March, to 433,000. That represented a drop of 27,000 from the previous week and was a sign of an improving economy, which makes the dollar more attractive to investors.
The dollar ended the day in New York at 133.65 Japanese yen, up from 132.30 late Wednesday. In Tokyo, the dollar fell to 132.55 yen from 133.20. Later, in London, it rose to 133.30 yen.
The dollar was also higher against the German mark in New York, closing at 1.67125 marks, up from late Wednesday's 1.6535. In earlier European trading, the dollar closed at 1.6705 marks, up from 1.6500.
The British pound also fell against the dollar in New York, slipping to $1.71075, from $1.7280 late Wednesday. In London, sterling fell to $1.7105, from $1.7320 late Wednesday.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Drug Stocks Slip Into the Doldrums

BYLINE: By Milt Freudenheim

 BODY:
THE big drug stocks got off to a dreary start in 1992, losing more than 11 percent of their value in 10 weeks. Some equity fund managers were quick to cut back their holdings, having profited from strong price rises in December.
Hoping for an economic upturn, many funds moved away from supposedly recession-proof stocks like drugs, food and beverages to cyclicals like autos, banks, chemicals and paper. 
 "It wasn't a dumping of the pharmaceutical shares but a lightening of positions," said Ray Pryor, a partner in New York with McCormick & Pryor, a stock-monitoring and proxy-solicitation firm. "As for the larger companies like Merck," he said, "the funds almost have to own them."
Much depends on when the economy comes back, analysts said. If it does not strengthen, many large investors will probably resume buying drug stocks later this year.
In the scramble, block trading in the 10 largest drug and diversified health-care companies soared to 100 million shares a month in January and February, up from an average of 80 million in 1991, according to Autex, a Thomson Financial Services unit, which records large sales and purchases by institutional investors. John Boehmke, an Autex product manager in Boston, said Pfizer led the group last month with 15 million shares in block trades. Warner-Lambert, hit by disappointing news concerning Lopid, its leading cholesterol-lowering product, was next at 12 million shares.
Anthony Forstmann, a partner in Forstmann Leff Associates, an institutional money manger with $3.5 billion in assets, said his firm had trimmed its holdings in the big drug companies to 8 percent, from 10 to 12 percent in December. "Our biggest position is Pfizer," he said. "We thought the stock was fully priced when it got to over 20 times 1993 estimated earnings." Pfizer has since fallen back to 17 times the 1993 estimate, closing at $70.875 yesterday.
But like many fund managers, Mr. Forstmann is enthusiastic about Pfizer's rich pipeline of new products like Zithromax, an antibiotic that the company started selling this week. "I still love Pfizer long term," he said.
Some of the largest funds, like the California Public Employees Retirement System, are indexed to mirror the entire market and do not follow industry-by-industry investing strategies. Others, like the $45 billion College Retirement Equities Fund, are standing pat, taking a long-range view.
Courtney Kling, a pharmaceutical analyst in New York with the college retirement fund, said it had made no big changes in its $3.15 billion drug portfolio, which included 6.9 million Pfizer shares on Dec. 31. Her fund had the company's third largest institutional holding, according to CDA/ Spectrum, which compiles Securities and Exchange 13(f) institutional portfolio filings. Fidelity was first with 11.8 million shares of Pfizer, followed by Jennison Associates with 6.3 million shares.
Pfizer makes up 11 percent of the $965 million Fidelity Select Healthcare Fund, said Andrew Offit, the fund's manager. Fidelity replaced some drug stocks with other pharmaceuticals, he added. He also likes Upjohn, which he says is undervalued.
Hemant K. Shah, an analyst with HKS & Company in Warren, N.J., projected the average earnings growth for the big pharmaceuticals to be a strong 12 percent in 1992, down from 15 percent last year. He said stock prices were rising on average by about 7 percent, down from 10 to 12 percent increases in 1991.
Drug prices are under growing pressure from large buyers like hospitals and insurers, which can often choose among similar products and cheaper generic versions of drugs that have lost patent protection. "The decline will have a big effect on their bottom lines," Mr. Shah said. He recommends Upjohn, Warner-Lambert and Glaxo P.L.C. "American Home Products, with a 3.4 percent dividend yield, is an opportunity for a conservative investor," he added.
Neil B. Sweig, an analyst with Brenner Securities in New York, said the three months ending March 31 "will probably turn out to be one of the worst quarters for drug stocks in the past 10 years." He likes American Cyanamid, Eli Lilly and Syntex for the short term, adding Johnson & Johnson and Pfizer as longer-term choices.
Mr. Offit at Fidelity looks at a brighter side. Although his health-care stocks have declined by about 10 percent since Jan. 1, he said, they had risen about 15 percent in December. He added, "This is hardly the end of health care."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Forecasting Tool Gives Nod to Bush

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
WILL the moderate economic recovery that now seems to be getting under way be enough to keep President Bush in the White House for four more years?
The answer is yes, according to an econometric forecasting equation developed by Ray C. Fair, an economist at Yale University. The Fair equation, estimated from data covering all Presidential elections from 1916 through 1988, predicts that Mr. Bush will win 57.2 percent of the popular vote in November on the assumption that the American economy grows by only 1.6 percent this year, the latest consensus forecast of the 51 leading economists surveyed by Blue Chip Economic Indicators. The consensus is for 3.1 percent inflation this year. 
 The Fair equation derives its predictions of Presidential elections from three major factors -- the growth rate of real per capita gross national product in the second and third quarters of the election year, the rate of inflation during the two-year period prior to the election and a one percentage point bonus for incumbent Presidents or candidates from their own party.
In the last 19 Presidential elections, the equation, applied retroactively, made only three wrong calls, each in very close elections. In 1960, John F. Kennedy defeated Richard M. Nixon by winning 50.1 percent of the popular vote, not losing by the predicted 49.2 percent. In 1968, Hubert H. Humphrey lost to Mr. Nixon, getting only 49.6 percent, not the model's predicted 51.3 percent. And in 1976, Jimmy Carter beat Gerald R. Ford, winning 51.1 percent of the vote, more than the predicted 49.6 percent. If the one percentage point bonus for incumbency had been left out of the equation, the model's predictions would have been right for all three elections.
The model has hit the last three elections almost on the nose. It predicted that Ronald Reagan would defeat Jimmy Carter in 1980 by 55.4 percent; Mr. Reagan actually got 55.3 percent. In 1984, the equation predicted 58.3 percent for Mr. Reagan over Walter F. Mondale; Mr. Reagan actually got 59.2 percent. And in 1988, the model predicted that Michael S. Dukakis would get 46.8 percent of the two-party vote against Mr. Reagan; Mr. Dukakis actually got 46.1 percent. Thus, in these elections, the Fair equation called the point spreads with average errors of less than six-tenths of 1 percent.
How reliable is the Fair equation likely to be in predicting that President Bush will beat Gov. Bill Clinton, who now seems to have the Democratic nomination sewed up after Paul Tsongas's withdrawal yesterday?
Mr. Fair states that the equation would have to be off by a bigger margin than it has ever been since 1916 for Mr. Bush to lose. Its biggest error was in 1964 when it predicted that President Lyndon B. Johnson would defeat Barry Goldwater by just 54.2 percent of the two-party vote; Mr. Johnson actually got 61.3 percent, a 7.1 percentage point miss. A miss of that size in 1992 would bring Mr. Bush's winning margin down to 50.1 percent.
But that prediction is on the assumption that the economy continues to advance in the second and third quarters. Even so, according to Mr. Fair, "It takes a very bad economy to defeat a Republican incumbent running again." With inflation low and likely to stay low, he contends that the only way Mr. Bush would be in danger of defeat would be if the economic recovery aborted, as it did last spring, and fell back into recession between now and November. The Federal Reserve is not likely to let that happen.
Is there, nevertheless, a chance that this time the Fair model could be wrong, even if the economy continues to advance at a moderate pace and the inflation rate stays down?
One reason this business-cycle-based political forecasting equation might be wrong is that this has not been a characteristic short-term recession but a long-term period of structural adjustment, to which the model might not apply in catching the mood of the electorate. During Mr. Bush's first three years in office, the economy has had one of the slowest growth records in its history: 2.5 percent in 1989, 1 percent in 1990 and negative seven-tenths of 1 percent in 1991. If the real growth this year comes in at 1.6 percent, the four-year average for Mr. Bush's first term would be just 1 percent per annum -- not enough to sustain the growth of the labor force.
Another reason is that the recovery is extremely uneven. Some states like New York, California and Connecticut still seem in deep trouble. Defense cutbacks are hurting some areas. With unemployment last month at 7.3 percent, its highest level of this recession, some big manufacturers like General Motors have announced big plant closings and layoffs still to come. Worries about America's role in the world economy intensify uncertainties.
The Fair model's bonus to incumbent Presidents may apply under normal circumstances, but this year there appears to be what many commentators are calling an "anti-incumbency" mood among voters, who could make this election exceptional. It seems too soon to lock up the November election in a forecasting equation.

HEADLINE: Review/Opera;
A 'Coq d'Or' That's Plain But Not Bad To Look At

BYLINE: By BERNARD HOLLAND

 BODY:
Cultural adversaries for so much of this century, Russian and American music have tended to sin in the same directions: toward love of size, the pursuit of technique for its own sake, the confusing of pressure and intensity with beauty.
Indeed, when the Bolshoi Opera brought "Eugene Onegin" to New York last year, many listeners were unhappily surprised to find Tchaikovsky's delicate domestic drama smothered, and all but lost, in a gargantuan set and sprawling production. For operagoers knowledgeable in Franco Zeffirelli's inflations of Puccini and Verdi at the Metropolitan Opera, the experience was not the delight of discovery but disappointment born of the depressingly familiar. 
 Now comes the mild and modest St. Petersburg National Opera, formerly, and better known as, the Maly Opera and a David among Goliaths in the current war of touring Russian companies. The second item in the St. Petersburg's three-opera repertory at the New York State Theater had its first showing on Wednesday night: "Le Coq d'Or" by Rimsky-Korsakov. Reversing the established process -- a slender framework burdened with grandiosity -- this ensemble takes a work aspiring to spectacle and reduces it to living-room size.
This postage-stamp "Coq d'Or" is often wise, but it is a wisdom in part forced on it by hard times. Without the visual means to render Arabian Nights settings in all their luxury, the St. Petersburg looks to dependable singing and a staging that catches the sly humor of Pushkin's original. City walls are formed by patchwork drapes that rise and fall. King Dodon's beloved bed assumes wheels and becomes his war vehicle. It is a deft little touch of surreality that also doesn't cost much.
Mythic beasts, winged and with bulging breasts, parade with modesty. The golden rooster of Rimsky-Korsakov's title has wings made to flap endearingly as it signals the approach of enemies. Dancing girls create simple patterns on this smallish stage. The men -- from simple warriors to the King himself -- move in a measured, high-stepping prance that is perhaps the Slavic equivalent of Groucho Marx's famous gait.
This is an opera about stupidity in high places, which may account for its trouble with government censors of the time. (The premiere of "Le Coq d'Or" was withheld until a year after Rimsky-Korsakov's death in 1908.) Its performance problems are at the same time its greatest assets as an opera: the need for singers who can dance. For when they are found, the dancing serves as a powerful illusion of dramatic continuity, keeping our eyes occupied when the music stops for a vocal set piece.
Valery Kochkin as King Dodon galumphs nicely in his balletic scene. He is subtly, not blatantly, ridiculous and the frayed tone and intonation are happy representations of befuddled middle age.
One rejoiced in the clear, healthy tenor of Anatoly Voropayev, yet such a young sound emanating from such an aged Astrologer was a little disconcerting. As the Queen of Shama khan, Yelena Ustinova found the high notes, but her paleness of sound and an unhappy habit of drifting into sharpness gave her performance an ephemeral, uncentered quality.
Aleksandr Nenadovsky (Prince Afron), Aleksandr Petrov (Prince Guidon), Leonid Gladkov (General Polkan), Tatyana Cherkassova (the Rooster's voice) and Nina Potasheva (Amelfa) were all strong performers. Vladimir Ziva conducted an orchestra whose lightness and clarity matched the stage with some exactness.
Those expecting visual tricks -- and there are arguments that grand opera owes us a few -- will find none here. The Queen disappears not in a cloud of smoke or through some trapdoor but simply behind a crowd of courtiers. We are also deprived of the rooster's deadly attack on Dodon; he is revealed after the fact, an inanimate prop perched on his forehead. Perhaps this production does err on the side of simplicity; but if its means approach primitiveness, its execution does not. The St. Petersburg National Opera offers a stage work, stripped of its fancy clothes. The bare body revealed is not at all hard to look at.
"Le Coq d'Or" repeats twice on Sunday, again on March 28, and then again on April 2 and 3.
 
Le Coq d'Or
Opera in three acts by Nikolai Rimsky-Korsakov, libretto by V. Belsky, after a story by Pushkin; conductor, Vladimir Ziva; director, Stanislav Gaudassinsky; sets by Aleksandr Gorenshtein; costumes by Yekaterina Rapai. Performed by the St. Petersburg National Opera at the New York State Theater.
 
King Dodon . . . Valery Kochkin
Prince Afron . . . Aleksandr Nenadovsky
Prince Guidon . . . Aleksandr Petrov
General Polkan . . . Leonid Gladkov
Amelfa . . . Nina Potasheva
The Astrologer . . . Anatoly Voropayev
Queen of Shamakhan . . . Yelena Ustinova
Le Coq d'Or . . . Tatyana Cherkassova

HEADLINE: Dow Gains 7.15 Points, To 3,261.40

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks closed higher yesterday in heavy trading as investors bought into the market for a number of reasons, including a strong bond market, a larger-than-expected drop in weekly jobless claims and a rebound in the Tokyo stock market.
The Dow Jones industrial average gained 7.15 points to finish at 3,261.40, with buying sustained by professional traders ahead of the "triple witching" expiration of certain options yesterday and today. 
 The rally in the bond market pushed the yield on the Treasury's long bond below 8 percent for the first time in days, making it a less attractive alternative to stocks.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was heavy, at 197.3 million shares, up from 194.1 million on Wednesday, as advances outnumbered declines by 926 to 781.
Some investors were on the sidelines ahead of yesterday's portion of the triple witching, anticipating increased volatility at the end, but some traders noted that over that last few years the unwinding process, or closing of positions, had begun to take place days before the deadline.
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 0.65 point, to 409.80, while the American Stock Exchange composite gained 1.20 points, to 402.17. In Nasdaq trading, the composite was up 1.02 points, to 625.96, with the Russell 2,000 up 0.32 point, to 208.47.
Bernard Spilko, a senior vice president at the New York branch of Bank Julius Baer, also noted the lack of volatility at the end of the session. "S.& P. put-call ratios were about even," he said. "Therefore, little volatility is expected today."
Helping to shore up stocks here is the "nervousness in the Euromarkets, coupled with anticipation of a continuing strong U.S. dollar, which is bringing foreign investors into the U.S. equity market," Mr. Spilko said.
"This market is likely to trade in a range of 3,200 to 3,300 on the Dow for the next several months," he continued."The upside potential is limited because the market is ahead of itself, and the downside is cushioned by investors looking for better yields than six-month maturities are offering."
In trading yesterday, takeover rumors were behind Warner-Lambert's rise of 1 1/2, to 65. Talk among the trading desks had it that Glaxo Holdings P.L.C. planned to make a bid to acquire the seventh-largest pharmaceutical company in the United States, which declined comment.
But Kent Blair, an analyst with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc., said he did not believe it likely that Glaxo was interested, because it had repeatedly said it did not want to make a major acquisition outside the pharmaceutical industry.
Ford Motor jumped to its highest level in a year on expectations, traders said, that the auto maker would turn a small profit in the first quarter, after incurring $2.8 billion in losses over the last five quarters.
On Wednesday, Jack Kirnan, an analyst at Kidder, Peabody, said Ford should report a profit of 25 cents a share, based on improved margins and lower incentives. The stock closed at 40 1/8, up 1 1/8, on nearly five million shares traded.

HEADLINE: Mr. Tsongas Departs, Gracefully

 BODY:
The fatal flaw in Paul Tsongas's campaign was that his message never reached much beyond well-educated, upper-income voters. But there was something unusually principled about his quest for the Democratic Presidential nomination. He was consistent, honest, uncalculating. His presence will be missed in the forthcoming Connecticut and New York primaries.
Mr. Tsongas ended his campaign yesterday, citing a depleted war chest. He may also have decided he could not recover from his poor showing in Illinois and Michigan. Whatever the reason, his withdrawal becomes him. He never pretended to be other than what he is, a public-spirited citizen with interesting ideas, an understated style and a self-deprecating sense of humor. In the same spirit, he concluded that it would be dishonorable to masquerade as a viable candidate when all he could really be was a spoiler. 
 Mr. Tsongas refused to alter his positions to satisfy different constituencies. He broached the possibility of reducing cost of living increases for Social Security recipients, though that was political suicide in Florida. His call for sharply higher gasoline taxes alienated voters everywhere, though it's the best energy policy imaginable. And he resisted the shameless strategies of other Democrats for a nearly useless middle-class tax cut.
But in the end his remedies for reviving the economy were too one-sided to build a broad coalition. His basic solution was to boost corporate investment. Yet when Bill Clinton urged investment in people as well -- through retraining and broader educational opportunities -- Mr. Tsongas's program seemed narrow by comparison.
There is little doubt, however, that Paul Tsongas is a decent man with much to offer. With characteristic humor, he said yesterday that though he was no longer available for the Presidency he would happily become president of the Speedo bathing suit company -- a reference to photographs showing him doing laps in the pool, fully recovered from the cancer that forced him to leave the Senate.
Here's a better suggestion: Why not contrive another way back to public service? The country would be richer for it.

HEADLINE: HORSE RACING;
The Exclusive, Haute Training of Arazi

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER CLAREY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LAMORLAYE, France, March 19

 BODY:
A videocassette is making the rounds in this small, thoroughbred-rich community an hour's drive north from Paris. It is a cassette containing footage of the Breeders' Cup Juvenile in Churchill Downs last Nov. 2, a race in which a Lamorlaye resident named Arazi exploded past 13 other horses to win by 4 3/4 lengths and become an instant Kentucky Derby favorite.
"We've all seen it five or six times," said Yves de Chevigny, director of the training sites in Lamorlaye and nearby Chantilly. "Arazi was the Porsche. The others were the motor scooters." 
 Robert Durepaire, Arazi's assistant trainer, prefers another analogy: "It was like an American film. The horse starts in last place to build the suspense. Then he blows everybody away for the happy ending. I just hope this film isn't finished."
Durepaire need not worry; the suspense is building again. Arazi, the Kentucky-born chestnut colt with the extra gear, has resumed full workouts in Lamorlaye under the watch of his silver-haired French trainer, Francois Boutin. Horse and trainer spend the early morning on an enormous, rolling expanse of terrain called "Les Aigles," a short walk from Boutin's estate and 200-horse stable. Arazi spends the remainder of the day in an inconspicuous barn at the end of a narrow street lined with middle-class residences.
 
Trying to Be a European First
 No European-trained horse has won the Kentucky Derby (the British-trained Bold Arrangement finished second in 1986), but an Arazi victory would be more than a coup for Old World racing. It would set a precedent for economical preparation. American-trained 3-year-olds normally race three, four or five times before trying the mile-and-a-quarter Derby. Arazi will only race once: in the 1,600-meter Prix Omnium in Saint Cloud, France, on April 7.
That race, like most in this country, will be on grass. Boutin selected it, in part, because Saint Cloud is the only major French track where horses run clockwise, as they do in the United States, instead of counterclockwise.
According to Churchill Downs records, which date only to 1955, no horse has raced in the Kentucky Derby with only one start as a 3-year-old. Fifteen have raced with two starts in that span, including one winner, Sunny's Halo in 1983.
"I think that for Arazi, one race is enough," said Boutin. "Maybe I'm fooling myself, and if things don't work out, people can say it's my fault. But Arazi is a horse who ran a lot as a 2-year-old. He doesn't need a lot of racework to show what he can do. He prepares very quickly. He's not a horse to put on weight. This should be no problem for him."
 
Was This Really Necessary?
 Boutin, 55, is a farmer's son from the Normandy region who has been one of France's top trainers for the last decade. He expressed confidence in the health of his colt, who underwent arthroscopic knee surgery in Kentucky to remove bone chips in his left and right forelegs just four days after his Breeders' Cup victory.
"He's fine. I see no difference," Boutin said. "But I must admit that personally, I was against the operation. It wasn't necessary. He wasn't
suffering in the least."
The decision to operate was made by Arazi's co-owners: Allen E. Paulson, an American aerospace executive, and Sheik Mohammed ibn Rashid al-Maktoum of Dhubai, who purchased a half share of the colt last October.
"After we bought our share, we had Arazi X-rayed all over, and they picked up some small lesions on his knees," said Anthony Stroud, a Briton who manages Sheik Mohammed's breeding farm in Newmarket. "The veterinarians recommended arthroscopic removal, and we believe in listening to veterinarians."
 
Safe in His Stall
 Arazi resumed light workouts in France in mid-December and resumed full workouts on Feb. 15. The two thick bandages he wears in his stall are the only physical evidence of the operation. "Just a precaution," Durepaire said. "We don't want him banging into anything."
The majority of Arazi's work is done on the sand tracks that rim Les Aigles, which is the centerpiece of a thoroughbred community that includes 100 trainers and over 3,000 horses. On Tuesdays and Saturdays, Arazi takes to the grass, where he runs in a group of other horses in an attempt to simulate competition. This approach is rare in the United States, where horses often train alone on the same dirt tracks where they race.
Although Arazi will not race on dirt before the Derby, Boutin plans to run him twice on the dirt track in Lamorlaye, which is the only dirt track in France and based partly on the design of Santa Anita in California. Arazi trained there before the Breeders' Cup.
 
A Smooth Transition
 "I think Arazi already has proved that he can make the transition from grass to dirt," said the American trainer Charlie Whittingham. "He blew by them others like they were tied."
While Americans are busy comparing him to Secretariat and Swaps, the French are busy comparing him to their Sea Bird, who in 1965 won the Epsom Derby, the most prestigious race in Europe. "We see a horse like this once every 30 years," said de Chevigny.
The French are quick to point out that his sire, Blushing Groom, and mother, Danseur Fabuleux, each trained for a time in France.
"Arazi is really very French in his style," Boutin said. "In my mind, he's most marked by Weld Risk, a French horse who was the grandfather of Blushing Groom. I knew Weld Risk well. He could handle distance, and I think Arazi can, too."
Arazi came to Lamorlaye in December 1990, after Boutin picked him out of a group of Paulson's yearlings who had been selected for their "European" potential. "Mr. Paulson's manager showed me 12 horses, and I was permitted to choose five," Boutin said. "I liked Arazi from the start."
The colt placed second in his first race as a 2-year old and then won his next six starts -- all on grass -- heading into the Breeders' Cup. His first victory came in a low-level 1,200-meter race; his last three came in Grade I events, including the 1,600-meter Grand Criterium, France's most prestigious race for 2-year-olds.
"He's got a big engine, simple as that," said John Hammond, an Englishman who is one of the top trainers in France. "And like all great horses, he has a marvelous turn of foot." Arazi also appears to be blessed with a fine temperament. First-time visitors to his stall are greeted with a rub of the nose and a lick.
"He's very curious about everything around him and extremely easy-going," said Raymond Lamonarca, Arazi's groom and exercise rider. "He can fall asleep in a flash. Nothing seems to bother him. You put some horses on an airplane, and they panic. You put Arazi on an airplane, and it's just like another day in his stall."
Arazi has grown about a half-inch and gained some weight in his haunches since his 2-year-old campaign but remains a colt of average size and unremarkable appearance.
"He's not a whole lot to look at," said jockey Steve Cauthen, who won the Triple Crown aboard Affirmed in 1978 and will ride Arazi for the first time in Saint Cloud. "But once he starts moving, he's exceptional. He reminds me a lot of Affirmed in comportment and demeanor and intelligence. My only hope is that I get to ride him more than once."
 
Two Jockeys, Two Continents
 Because of a pre-purchase agreement between Sheik Mohammed and Paulson, Cauthen, who is based in England and under contract with the Sheik, will ride Arazi only in Europe. When Arazi races in the United States, he will wear Paulson's colors and be ridden by Paulson's jockey of choice, Patrick Valenzuela.
"It would, of course, be better to have just one jockey," Boutin said. "But what can we do?"
The more provocative question is what Arazi will do if he wins the Kentucky Derby. Paulson would like Arazi to race for the Triple Crown, but there is a strong possibility that the colt would skip the final two legs and return to Europe to train for the Epsom Derby on June 3 in England. No horse has ever won the Kentucky Derby and Epsom Derby.
"We will discuss it with Mr. Paulson prior to the Kentucky Derby and probably won't arrive at any decisions until after," Stroud said. "Obviously, we would favor a European campaign."
Whatever Arazi does this summer, he will spend the bulk of his future in Europe. As part of the purchase agreement, he will stand at stud for Sheik Mohammed in Newmarket. "We feel he will greatly enhance the breed in Europe," Stroud said. "That was our main reason for going ahead and buying part of this horse."
For the moment, however, Arazi's spirit belongs to neither Paulson nor the Sheik. It belongs to Lamorlaye and the region of Chantilly, where thorougbreds have been training and racing since the early 19th century.
"This is really marvelous," de Chevigny said. "We are beginning to believe that our community is home to the best horse in the world."

A sports article yesterday about the French race horse Arazi referred incorrectly to the track where he will make his competitive debut as a 3-year-old. The track, Saint-Cloud, is the only major one in France where horses run counterclockwise, as they do in the United States.

HEADLINE: A Film Series With an Eye For Offbeat Relationships

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN

 BODY:
CHRISTOPHER MUNCH'S sweetly intimate film, "The Hours and Times," takes a footnote from the history of the Beatles -- a 1963 weekend getaway to Barcelona, Spain, by John Lennon with the group's manager, Brian Epstein -- and spins it into an imaginary portrait of a relationship. One of the aims of the trip is to explore the boundaries of a friendship that is as complicated as it is close. Epstein is in love with Lennon, who doesn't return his passion but is open-minded enough to consider the possibility of sexual involvement. Finally, in an awkward encounter in a hotel bathtub, the boundaries become more set.
"The Hours and Times," which will be shown in the New Directors/New Films series on April 3 and 4, epitomizes the attitude of many of the films to be presented in this year's festival, which begins screenings this evening at the Museum of Modern Art. At a time when the mass media's portrayal of the world tends to put everyone into cliched niches, many of the film makers are looking at relationships in ways that are far more problematic than Hollywood's cookie-cutter mentality admits. 
 The Australian Jocelyn Moorhouse's film "Proof" is similarly open-ended in its darkly comic portrayal of the relationships among a blind photographer, his love-smitten housekeeper and a waiter who helps the photographer to take his pictures.
"The film is about three people who see themselves in a very negative light, as powerless," Ms. Moorhouse says. "What interested me most was the concept of someone shut off from the visual world most of us share, but who refuses to accept that. At the same time, I didn't want to sentimentalize blind people, for I don't believe a handicap automatically ennobles someone." Ms. Moorhouse's film opens the series, which is jointly presented by the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the department of film of the Museum of Modern Art. For the next two and a half weeks, New Directors will present 22 programs, representing 14 countries, at the museum's Roy and Niuta Titus Theaters.
One of the most prestigious international showcases of film-making talent, New Directors usually offers an overview of the economic state and the artistic mood of the international film business.
The movies' financial well-being is often determined by political events. The fact that there are no films this year from Poland and Czechoslovakia suggests that financing has temporarily dried up there.
And the outlook of this year's two Russian selections, "Satan" and "Hey, You Wild Geese," is bleakly pessimistic.
Elsewhere in the series, however, the mood is both rebellious and introspective. More than in previous years, sex and issues of sexuality are recurrent themes.
Four films -- "The Hours and Times," "The Living End," "Swoon," and "Le Ciel de Paris" -- have some sort of gay content. And except for "Le Ciel," a French film whose director, Danniel Danniel, died of AIDS last July, they are American films.
In others, like the Spanish director Vicente Aranda's steamy film noir "Lovers," sex becomes a metaphor for something else. In "Lovers," it is a response to the dreary repressive climate in Spain under the Franco regime in the 1950's. "I find that a great many of the films and film makers represented this year are dealing with interpersonal relationships," said Richard Pena, program director of the Film Society of Lincoln Center. "Many of these relationships are intense. You have an almost classical sense of creating characters who are well rounded and even contradictory. The gay film movement, if you want to call it that, has reached a kind of maturity in the sense that you have artists who no longer feel obligated to make 'gay is good' films. They can make extremely problematic, controversial films like 'Swoon' and 'The Living End.' "
 
Attacking a Myth
 "Swoon," by Tom Kalin, a 30-year-old film maker who lives in New York, explores the notorious 1920's case of Nathan Leopold and Richard Loeb, well-to-do Chicago youths who were homosexually involved and who kidnapped and murdered a young boy. The events helped inspire Alfred Hitchcock's film "Rope" and Meyer Levin's best-selling novel "Compulsion." In Mr. Kalin's film, the events are re-enacted in a style that mixes period and contemporary elements along with vintage documentary fragments.
"The Leopold and Loeb case is the place where homosexuality and pathology became linked in the American mind and in psychoanalytic discourse," Mr. Kalin says. "It was used as evidence that when two men get together and have a tangled relationship, it will inevitably lead to violence. I wanted to unpack that myth in a way that separated the pathology from the homosexuality by showing that the two had different motivations for what they did. The film also questions the way history is written."
 
Despair Over AIDS
 Gregg Araki's "Living End," which might be described as a gay, post-punk "Thelma and Louise," couldn't be more different in temperament from Mr. Kalin's film. Using a post-punk cinematic vocabulary, it follows the chaotic journey of two young men, both of them H.I.V.-positive, who hit the road from Los Angeles, have adventures and end up in the desert contemplating a sex-and-death ritual.
What the director describes as the film's "living for the moment urgency" was inspired by the AIDS crisis and by alternative underground rock music.
"I don't see any movies, hardly watch TV and rarely read, but I'm into alternative industrial music," says the 32-year-old director. "There is also a romanticism in post-punk nihilism. One of my favorite genres from film school was the couple-on-the-run movie, in which a hostile, irrational universe descends on the two doomed lovers. Although my film has its angry side, I always thought it was a love story at its core."
Unlike Mr. Kalin and Mr. Araki, Mr. Munch, the director of "The Hours and Times," insists that his film is largely unconcerned with sexual politics.
"The overriding consideration for me was just to paint that emotional reality as accurately and as uncompromisingly as I could," Mr. Munch says. "Obviously, we don't know the specific facts about what happened on their actual trip to Barcelona. But I think the film is faithful to the emotional content of their friendship. Most of all, the film tries to deconstruct stereotypes in people's minds about compelling friendships that don't fall into any easily identifiable category."
 
No Apologies
 In other films, that sense of rebellion against stereotypical attitudes extends beyond matters of sexuality. Camille Billops and James Hatch's film, "Finding Christa," is a documentary account of Ms. Billops's reunion with the grown-up daughter whom she had given up for adoption because she didn't want to be saddled with a baby at a young age. Far from an apology or an admission of any kind of failure to take responsibility by Ms. Billops, the film offers a joyful portrait of her daughter who, in meeting her biological mother, finds a second family that is as warm and loving as the one that raised her.
"It is a hard film, because a lot of people will not accept the reasons I didn't want to be a mother," Ms. Billops says. "But I perceive of it as a heroic film and the giving up of my daughter as a heroic act. I wasn't broke, I wasn't crazy, I just didn't want to be a mother. I wanted the adventure that men enjoy. I tell my daughter that I'm sorry about the hurt I caused her but not the act, because everyone is not meant to be a mother."
"Finding Christa" is on the same program with "June Roses," a semi-autobiographical feature by Christine Noschese that also deals with a woman's defiance of convention. It is set in Brooklyn in 1952, and portrays a smart, artistically inclined housewife and mother of two whose nervous breakdown is remembered through the eyes of a young daughter whom she has pushed into taking ballet classes. The movie uncannily evokes both the look and the oppressively conformist mood of the McCarthy era.
"The film has to do with what made me a feminist in the sense of what I saw when I was growing up," Ms. Noschese recalls. "Back then, women were getting electric-shock treatments for wanting things. A lot of people today don't realize the frustrations that drove a lot of us into the early women's movement. We saw our mothers as very intelligent but still unable to fulfill their dreams, and saw how they put all that energy on their kids. But living your life through someone else is no way to live."
 
More Mean Streets
 Although Brooklyn is also the setting for Nick Gomez's "Laws of Gravity," the two films are so unlike that they might as well be set on different continents. Mr. Gomez's film, which was shot entirely with hand-held cameras and takes place in the present, follows the meanderings of a bunch of petty criminals and their girlfriends in Brooklyn's Greenpoint section. Stylistically, the movie is reminiscent at times of Martin Scorsese's "Mean Streets."
"I think I'm more of a chronicler than Scorsese, whose interests are more personal and psychological," says Mr. Gomez, who grew up in Somerville, Mass., in an environment not unlike that of his film.
"I didn't intend to make a statement," he continues. "For me, the challenge was to try to depict people whom the average person on the street wouldn't find appealing. I see the characters as sort of modern-day frontiersmen in the way they live a hand-to-mouth existence under extreme conditions."
Mr. Gomez's film, which will be shown tomorrow and Sunday, is one of seven feature-length selections by American directors in the series. The number of American works attests to the vitality of this country's independent-film movement at a moment when Hollywood is feeling the pinch of recession. The number of quality American films submitted for New Directors this year was so large that there was even some discussion about the possibility of making the series all-American.
According to the selection committee, the flowering of American independent films can be traced back to the success three years ago of Steven Soderbergh's "Sex, Lies and Videotape," which helped loosen the purse strings of both independent producers and private foundations.
"What has developed in the American independent cinema is a very savvy generation of producers," says Mr. Pena. "They are people who are good with money and who understand that it's not a privilege but a business. They also understand the international scene and how to work the festival circuits. It has made all the difference."
Others say they believe there has also been a shift in the artistic climate. The more formulaic Hollywood becomes, the more room there is for films that do not chase after mass-market success.
Laurence Kardish, of the Museum of Modern Art's film department, discerns in all this vitality the completion of a cycle.
"Something happened to independent film 20 years ago," he says. "There was a conservative backlash in which we didn't see the promise of the late 60's and early 70's realized. Now it's finally happening."
 
What's On and When During the Festival
 The New Directors/New Films series, a collaboration of the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the film department at the Museum of Modern Art, begins tonight and runs through April 5 at the Roy and Niuta Titus Theaters at the museum, 11 West 53d Street, Manhattan. Tickets to each screening, at $7 ($5 for members), are available at the museum. A series ticket is $135 ($95 for members). Information: (212) 708-9480. Sold-out or added screenings are noted. Occasionally, returned tickets for sold-out screenings are available at show time. Here is the schedule.

HEADLINE: Short Positions at 19-Month Low on the Big Board

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
With many bears running for cover, the number of shares in New York Stock Exchange-listed companies sold short and not yet covered has fallen to a 19-month low, the Big Board reported yesterday.
The exchange said that on March 13, the short position was down 4.3 percent, to 691.1 million shares, a drop of 30.9 million in a month and the lowest since Aug. 15, 1990, when the figure was 669 million. 
 The short position represents the number of shares that have been borrowed and sold short, normally by traders who hope the price will decline so that they can buy the shares back later at a lower price. In total, the short position sometimes serves as a contrary indicator. By that measure, when the shorts are most active, stock prices may be set to rise, while prices may be vulnerable when short-sellers are least willing to place bets against stocks.
 
Position in August 1990
 In August 1990, when the short-position was low, stocks were beginning a rapid decline, brought on by the beginning of the recession and the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. By December of that year, the number of shares sold short had risen to 855.8 million, a 28 percent increase, and the stock market was poised to rise sharply.
The American Stock Exchange reported a smaller decline in short interest, of about five-tenths of 1 percent, or 300,000 shares, to 62.3 million on March 13. The figure was the lowest for the Amex since January 1990.
Stock prices did not rise sharply from mid-February through mid-March, the period covered by the report, but many short-sellers had been devastated by the rapid rise in prices that began in mid-December.
 
BankAmerica at Top
 The largest short-interest position was in shares of BankAmerica, where the position rose by 5.5 million shares, to 17.8 million. Much of that increase no doubt related to merger arbitrage connected with its pending acquisition of Security Pacific.
Arbitrage, in this case related to a new issue of convertible preferred stock, may also have played a role in the 4.5-million-share rise in the short interest at Chrysler, which left the auto maker with a short position of 10.8 million shares, the second largest. But negative sentiment about Chrysler, which had its bond rating lowered, also played a role. It appears that the shorts did not score a winner with that one, as the shares rose for much of the period.
Citicorp, a longtime favorite of short-sellers, rose sharply early in 1992 and has held on to the gains. In the most recent month, the short position was reduced by 3.3 million shares, to 7.3 million.
Short-sellers raised their bets against Sears, Roebuck, raising the short position by almost 50 percent, to 2.3 million shares.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Economic Issues;
TAX BILL IS PASSED BY THE DEMOCRATS AND BUSH VETOS IT

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 20

 BODY:
Clearly foreshadowing the general election campaign to come, President Bush and Congressional Democrats slugged it out today over taxes, spending and the affections of the middle class, their favorite election-year economic issues.
Aside from an exchange of sharp attacks intended to portray Mr. Bush as a lackey of the rich and the Democratic Congress as more interested in "pork" than progress, the Democrats passed a tax bill that Mr. Bush promptly vetoed, and he proposed spending cuts that he expected them to resist. 
 The compelling undertone in today's shrill exchanges was the issue of responsibility for the flabby economy, historically the worst issue an incumbent President can face. As it was framed today, Democrats said Mr. Bush had ignored it; he said they were holding the economic recovery "hostage" as they pursued partisan gain.
 
Majorities Are Slim
 By majorities slimmer than their margins in both houses, the Democrats passed a bill that would provide tax credits to families with incomes of less than $70,000. But those credits were to be financed by increasing the maximum tax rate to 36 percent, from 31 percent, and by a surcharge on incomes over $1 million. Mr. Bush said those increases were intolerable.
Mr. Bush denounced the measure and complained that Congress had refused to pass his seven-point economic growth program by today, the deadline he set in his State of the Union speech on Jan. 28. And he carried the attack to Congress by demanding that Congress withdraw $4 billion in Federal spending it had already approved. Mr. Bush called them "items of pork," and drove the attack home by assailing "a Democratic caucus which cannot manage a tiny bank or a tiny post office."
 
Clinton Backs Concept
 At the White House, in a speech to an invited audience of Republican loyalists, Mr. Bush said he had signed his veto message even before the bill reached him, because "raising taxes will not create jobs." He has been under intense criticism from conservative Republicans, especially Patrick J. Buchanan, his challenger, for abandoning his 1988 pledge of "no new taxes" and agreeing in 1990 to raise the maximum rate to 31 percent.
Although the bill passed with majorities too slight to override a veto, the issue will persist into the fall Presidential election campaign. Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, the Democratic front-runner, has supported tax cuts for the middle class paid for by higher rates at the top.
Mr. Clinton had no direct comment on the bill today. But a spokesman in Little Rock said that while he supported the general concept of the bill, he did not endorse it in its entirety.
Mr. Bush complained that Congressional Democrats were allowing the recession to drag on by not acting on his program, but in Congress Democrats concentrated on their theme of fairness, to be achieved by taxing the wealthy to help the middle class.
Just before the House passed the bill, 211 to 189, Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader, insisted, "We're simply asking the wealthiest people in the country, the people who have done the best, to pay their fair share of the tax burden in this country."
While Mr. Bush complained of inaction on his anti-recession proposals, most of them were included in some form or other in the Democrats' $77.5 billion, five-year tax bill, hammered out Thursday night between House and Senate negotiators.
 
Difference on Capital Gains
 But its capital gains tax cut was far less generous than Mr. Bush's, providing little or no reduction for the wealthiest taxpayers. Its accelerated depreciation provisions were slimmer than his. And it omitted entirely the $5,000 tax credit he proposed for first-time home buyers. Other provisions aiding corporations, real estate and home building were included much as he wrote them.
The middle-class tax cut in the bill married the approaches of Democrats in the House and Senate, who have sought to make that cause an issue since last spring.
The bill provided, for 1992 and 1993, a tax credit of up to $150 for single people and $300 for working couples, a stripped-down version of the House provision. For 1994 and thereafter, it would shift to a permanent tax credit of $300 for each child under the age of 16, which was the Senate plan proposed by Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, chairman of the Finance Committee. These credits would not be available to taxpayers with incomes over $70,000.
Over five years, the cost of those credits would be $42.4 billion. But that would be more than paid for by raising the top tax rate to 36 percent, a rate that would kick in for individuals with taxable income of $115,000 and couples with $140,000, and by the surcharge of an extra 10 percent on all taxable income in excess of $1 million. Those increases would raise $60.2 billion.
These provisions provoked some of the sharpest debate. Representative David Dreier, Republican of California, discerned a "manifesto for class warfare." Representative Bill Archer, Republican of Texas, called them "job-destroying tax increases." He said, "Rather than put people back to work, the Democratic leaders have attempted to create a bogus political issue for November."
But Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who heads the House Ways and Means Committee, said, "Only 1 percent of all taxpayers would have a rate increase under this bill, only 1 million of the richest taxpayers in this country." And Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, said Republican Administrations always wanted tax cuts for the wealthy, advocating a "trickle down" economic theory. "The American people have been trickled on for 12 years," he said.
 
67 Cuts Proposed
 Even before the bill got to him to veto, Mr. Bush sent Congress 67 messages proposing $3.6 billion of cuts in spending of money that had already been appropriated. Most of the total, $2.96 billion, would come from halting spending on two SSN-21 Seawolf submarines. Other targets ranged from agricultural research projects relating to blackbirds, Vidalia onions, Appalachian hardwoods and lowbush blueberries, and other items like the Alliance of Residential Theaters in New York.
If Congress does not agree to these cuts within 45 days his proposal will have no effect. But Congressional Republicans could force votes on them. Mr. Bush told a cheerful White House audience that applauded repeatedly, even at references to generally obscure court decisions and laws, that he would work with Republicans to guarantee such "line-by-line votes on items of pork."
 
More Cuts Threatened
 But House Democrats said the Appropriations Committee would consider his requests promptly and might add other items of its own, especially from Defense Department spending. "We will reach the same bottom line number that's being proposed by the President," said Representative Leon E. Panetta, the California Democrat who heads the House Budget Committee.
Mr. Panetta said Mr. Bush had always had authority to propose rescissions, as these cuts are called, but was doing it today only because "he needs a little diversion so that the American people don't notice that veto" of the middle-class tax cut legislation.
 
Other Major Provisions
 But there was far more than that to the hefty tax bill. Its other major provisions, though largely ignored in today's debate, included these:
*Reducing taxes on capital gains, though not as much as Mr. Bush wanted. The bill would have reduced them to zero for families with incomes under $34,000, but left them at 28 percent for upper-income taxpayers. Mr. Bush wanted a maximum rate of 15.4 percent. The bill would also have cut them to a maximum of 14 percent on investments in new small businesses held for at least five years.
*Restoring complete deductibility, at all income levels, of up to $2,000 in contributions to individual retirement accounts. The bill would also create a new kind of I.R.A., with tax-free status for withdrawn income if left on deposit for at least five years.
*Repealing the luxury tax on yachts, planes, furs and jewelry and indexing for inflation the tax on expensive cars.
*Allowing an extra 5 percent of depreciation for this year and next on new business investment in plants and equipment.
The conferees dropped a Senate provision on health insurance. It would prohibit insurance companies from canceling coverage or excluding members of small groups because of existing health problems or prior claims, and try to eliminate gaps in coverage for workers changing jobs. It would also seek to end the wide disparities in health insurance premiums.
But that measure is likely to be seen again before Congress adjourns this fall, as are many of the smaller items in the bill Mr. Bush rejected. While there is no Congressional timetable for action, a number of popular tax preferences expire this summer, and they are likely to be adopted again, along perhaps with easier provisions for the real estate industry and possibly the repeal of the luxury taxes.
But just as a White House aide predicted that Mr. Bush would seek to get Congress to vote on spending measures again and again, everyone expected the political arguments to be repeated, and repeated.
Mr. Bentsen scoffed at Mr. Bush, saying: "The talk is, he wants to re-create the 1948 campaign, when a feisty Harry Truman came from behind by attacking a 'do-nothing' Republican Congress. Well, I knew Harry Truman. I worked with Harry Truman. And George Bush is a decent man, but he's no Harry Truman."
