HEADLINE: Iraq Agrees to Destroy Missiles To Meet U.N. Cease-Fire Terms

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, March 20

 BODY:
Faced with veiled American and British threats of military force, Iraq has backed down in its latest confrontation with the Security Council and agreed to destroy its ballistic missile equipment as required by the cease-fire resolution that ended the Persian Gulf war, a Council official announced today.
Rolf Ekeus, head of the special commission set up by the Council to oversee the elimination of Iraq's weapons of mass destruction after the war, said Baghdad also agreed Thursday night to provide full details next month of its programs for building nuclear, chemical and biological weapons. 
 President Saddam Hussein's Government refused last month to discard its buildings and equipment for producing and repairing ballistic missiles, saying it wanted to convert them to civilian use.
 
Suspicions Are Confirmed
 Confirming the Security Council's suspicions, Iraq also admitted Thursday night that it had concealed about 90 ballistic missiles, though it asserts that it eventually destroyed them last summer, Mr. Ekeus said. He said Baghdad also revealed that it had a large number of chemical warheads that could be fitted onto its Scud and longer-range missiles.
Mr. Ekeus described the developments as "good news" and said they appeared to indicate a "change of policy" by Baghdad.
Mr. Ekeus said Iraq had made the disclosures and communicated its new position Thursday night in a letter presented by its United Nations representative, Abdul Amir al-Anbari. A team of United Nations ballistic missile experts is to arrive in Baghdad this weekend to oversee the destruction of some of the equipment and to check out Iraq's disclosures about concealed missiles and chemical warheads, Mr. Ekeus added.
The Bush Administration reacted cautiously to Baghdad's pledge of cooperation. A spokeswoman for the State Department in Washington, Phyllis Young, said tonight: "We have a copy of the letter and we're examining it. We're in touch with the U.N. special commission. The special ballistics team goes to Iraq tomorrow, and we want to see how Iraq cooperates and what they can achieve."
 
Military Contingency Plan
 Tensions over Iraq's refusal to destroy the equipment or to disclose full details of its programs for building weapons have risen steadily in recent weeks. Only today, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. Colin L. Powell, told a Senate committee that the United States had prepared contingency plans for a military strike on Iraqi weapons sites.
Months of intransigence led to a direct confrontation here last week between an increasingly irate Security Council and Iraq's Deputy Prime Minister, Tariq Aziz. The meeting ended with Mr. Aziz's assuring the Council of Iraq's "good will" and promising wider cooperation.
"We now have some reason to take Iraq's assurances of good will more seriously," Mr. Ekeus said today.
The special commission on eliminating Iraqi weapons had given Baghdad until the end of next week to prepare the equipment for destruction as the United States and Britain hinted that they might do the job themselves with a military strike.
In his testimony today before the Senate Armed Services Committee, General Powell made clear that the armed forces were ready to enforce the Security Council's orders if Baghdad continued to stall.
"We have a variety of tools available to us to make sure that Iraq does comply -- diplomatic tools, economic tools, political tools, yes, the armed forces of the United States," he said. "And I can assure this committee that if we are called upon to be a part of this solution, we will perform our role in an absolutely professional way with desired results."
General Powell was responding to questions from committee members about a report in The Washington Post that said he opposed another strike against Iraq.
He added later: "The United States armed forces are prepared to execute any mission given to us by the President of the United States. You can be sure that we have thought through how we would accomplish any mission given to us by the President."
The latest showdown between Baghdad and the Security Council follows the pattern of previous confrontations, with Iraq initially refusing to cooperate with its orders and claiming it had no weapons of mass destruction, then being forced into a humiliating retreat when confronted with overwhelming evidence of its deception or threatened with another strike.
 
Doubts After Gulf War
 Iraq had reported last year to the commission that it had only 64 ballistic missiles, but the panel suspected that President Hussein was probably still hiding others. The doubts arose after the commission compared the total of 800 that the Soviet Union said it had supplied to Baghdad with estimates of the number fired last year during the Persian Gulf war and in Iraq's eight-year war with Iran.
Iraq's disclosure that it had a large number of chemical warheads that could be fitted on its Scud and longer-range al-Husseini missiles contrasted with its earlier reports that it had only 30 such warheads, a figure judged by many experts to be suspiciously low.
Baghdad promised to submit full details on its nuclear, chemical and biological weapons programs in April. United Nations officials said they had demanded that Iraq disclose the existence of any hidden nuclear reactors or storage sites in the desert, as well as complete information on foreign companies that have supplied them with relevant equipment and technology.
Iraq has already handed over a long document in Arabic that it says provides information about its military industries. The special commission had asked for the information so it could draw up plans for monitoring production to insure Iraq does not try to make prohibited weapons again.
 
Some Conversion Permitted
 If Baghdad follows through on its commitments, it will soon be stripped of all its nuclear, chemical and biological weapons as well as its ballistic missiles and the plants and equipment used to make them. Most of Iraq's nuclear equipment has already been destroyed.
The newly declared chemical warheads will be added to other chemical weapons stocks that the United Nations is currently destroying. Some of the plants used to make those weapons are also being dismantled, although Iraq is being allowed to convert some chemical equipment for civilian use.
Iraq has been authorized to keep all of its tanks, artillery pieces, mortars and missiles with a range of under 90 miles, as well as lighter arms left over from the gulf war, though it is banned from importing any military equipment.
The Vienna-based International Atomic Energy Agency, which is charged with eliminating Iraq's nuclear program, will decide this weekend how much of Iraq's nuclear weapons plant at Al Atheer must be destroyed. The plant, about 22 miles southwest of Baghdad, escaped damage in the gulf war, and Iraq has sent a team to Vienna to plead for its conversion to civilian ends. The United States is demanding its destruction.
 
Lingering Disputes
 The true purpose of the plant at Al Atheer, where Iraq intended to assemble and test its first nuclear device, was only discovered by the allied military coalition after the end of the fighting last year. Most of Iraq's other weapons plants were hit during the allied bombing campaign.
While officials say Iraq appears to be starting to comply with the Security Council's cease-fire terms in a serious way, other areas of potential dispute remain.
Baghdad still has not formally accepted the Security Council resolution calling for long-term monitoring of its military factories, although it appears now to be cooperating with the inspections. And it has not formally accepted the Council resolution laying down rules under which it can sell oil to finance imports of food and medicine and to compensate the victims of its invasion of Kuwait.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Iraqi Warheads Destroyed
 BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 20 (Reuters) -- A United Nations team announced today that it had completed its mission of destroying 500 leaking nerve-gas rockets in southern Iraq with cooperation from Iraqi authorities.
"We destroyed 500 warheads, rockets and partial missiles, each one containing 6.1 liters of chemical agent," said Michel Desgranges, who led the team.
The chemical in the rockets was Sarin.
He said the rockets, destroyed at a site near Nasiriya, 180 miles south of Baghdad, weighed 150 pounds each and had a range of up to 20 miles.
 Mr. Desgranges said that the mission was a success and that relations with the Iraqi authorities, which provided workers to help the United Nations team, were "good and normal."

HEADLINE: U.S. Is Working on Soviet Aid Package

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 20

 BODY:
The State Department is working on a large-scale aid package for the former Soviet Union, but the White House remains hesitant to move forward on the multibillion dollar package, Congressional and Administration officials said today.
But several of the officials said they expect President Bush, who was embarrassed last week by former President Richard M. Nixon's criticism of American policy toward the former Soviet Union, to begin pushing for the package over the next few weeks or months. They said the White House is taking a warmer view of more aid to Russia and the other newly independent republics after shying away from foreign aid increases because of election-year accusations that it was focusing on foreign affairs to the detriment of domestic concerns. 
 State Department officials said the package would probably involve a $12 billion contribution to the International Monetary Fund, $645 million in humanitarian aid already announced, and part of an estimated $6 billion fund that several industrial nations are planning in an effort to stabilize the ruble.
One senior Treasury official said the ruble stabilization fund could be established in May or June, a move that President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia says is crucial to increase confidence in his nation's currency and fledgling market economy.
 
Senators Lobby With Baker
 Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who is chairman of the Armed Services Committee, Richard G. Lugar, an Indiana Republican who is a member of the Foreign Relations Commitee, and two other senators met with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d on Wednesday to urge him to step up efforts to aid Russia and the other republics.
"Baker indicated that the Administration would be asking the Congress for support on I.M.F. replenishment," Senator Lugar said in an interview today. "He understood that it was controversial."
Mr. Lugar and Mr. Nunn and the two senators who accompanied them on a recent trip to Russia and Ukraine -- John W. Warner, Republican of Virginia, and Jeff Bingaman, Democrat of New Mexico -- are scheduled to meet with President Bush on Monday to press him on aid.
"The question really is with the President and the White House," Senator Nunn said in an interview today. "State is ready to move out though they're not really organized yet."
"The problem," he added, "is getting leadership on this issue."
 
Prod From Nixon
 A senior State Department official said the department has not finished its internal review of an aid package. The official said another factor Mr. Baker has to decide is whether to push the package as part of a resolution to continue foreign aid that expires at the end of this month or whether to wait for another opportunity.
Last week, former President Nixon called on President Bush to take a vigorous lead on the issue, saying America's aid to the former Soviet Union has been "pathetically inadequate."
At a conference in Washington sponsored by the Nixon Library, Mr. Nixon threw President Bush on the defensive on the issue of aid to Russia, and many liberals and conservatives joined the former President in saying that more aid was vital to shore up Russia's economy to insure the former Soviet Union does not become fertile ground for a new dictatorship.
President Bush responded that he recognized Moscow's needs for assistance, but pointed out, "we're living in a time of constrained resources," and defended his own actions by saying, "I don't have a blank check." Many supporters of increased aid were disappointed by Mr. Bush's response, saying that Mr. Nixon had given him an opportunity to make a major speech calling for large-scale aid.
An Administration official said today that the White House has long been working on aid to the former Soviet Union, noting the $645 million in humanitarian aid that President Bush announced in January. The official said there was no dramatic shift by the White House on aid to Russia.
"It's evolutionary," the official said. "This is what the President has been saying all along."
 
Congress Urges Aid Package
 Several Senators have urged the Administration to develop an aid package so that it could make one big drive to push the aid plan through Congress, rather than pass different pieces at different times.
"There is going to be only one chance for a package that will move in a comprehensive way to address most of the problems within the republics," said Senator Lugar, referring to the former Soviet Union. "It will have to be multidisciplinary."
He said he thought the President would push an aid package in April, May or June, but some officials said it could come as early as next week when the Congress is expected to take up continued spending for foreign aid.
Lawmakers have been reluctant to increase spending abroad during a recession at home and one White House official sought to play down the cost of aid to Russia today. He said the $12 billion contribution to the I.M.F. would in effect be an interest-paying deposit in the international lending organization. The contribution to the stabilization fund would be like a loan that would be drawn on only if the fund had to be tapped to defend the ruble against depreciation, he added. According to the I.M.F. about $6 billion would be needed to finance such a fund.
Jeffrey Sachs, a Harvard economics professor who is an adviser to Russia and a supporter of aid to the former Soviet Union, estimates that the United States and Japan would each put up $1.2 billion for the stabilization fund, while the countries of Western Europe put up $3 billion. The remainder, he said, would come from other countries.
Administration officials have long said that a stabilization fund should not be set until Russia has slashed its budget deficit, reined in its fast-growing money supply, removed price controls and taken other painful steps to set up a market economy.
But Russian officials have complained that the Group of Seven major industrialized countries sometimes seem to want Moscow to create so much economic stability before a stabilization fund is set up that by that time such a fund would be unnecessary.
"The Russians are moving very fast," said Stanley Fischer, a former World Bank chief economist who is now a professor at the Massachusetts Institue of Technology. "They have done a lot on the budget side. They have tightened their monetary policy. With external support they can go the last few yards."

HEADLINE: Kohl Is Expected to Act as Trade Envoy in Talks With Bush

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, March 20

 BODY:
Chancellor Helmut Kohl, who is emerging as Europe's most powerful leader, is expected to play the role of trade envoy this weekend in private talks with President Bush at Camp David, Md.
Although trade matters will be at the top of the agenda and foreign-policy issues will be discussed, the talks on Saturday and Sunday are being described as a personal meeting. 
 But Mr. Kohl will also be acting as an unofficial envoy of European countries who are at odds with the United States over trade and economic issues.
Aides say the Chancellor and Mr. Bush will try to forge a compromise that could lead to the long-delayed completion of the latest round of international trade negotiations of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, or GATT.
 
European Farm Subsidies
 The latest round, which involves 108 nations and began in Uruguay in 1986, was scheduled to have been completed in Brussels in December 1990. But the conclusion has been blocked by the refusal of France and its partners in the European Community to cut heavy subsidies to their farmers.
The United States and other nations that are dependent on agricultural exports have pressed the Western Europeans to cut their farm subsidies by as much as 36 percent.
 
Corn Gluten Dispute
 The main commodity holding up agreement is corn gluten, a cereal substitute that is a major export item. American farmers sold $696 million in corn gluten to Europeans last year and could sell more if subsidies were discontinued.
Lobbyists for American farmers like the U.S. Feed Grains Council say they will fight to insure rejection of "the whole agreement" if it includes a compromise that limits their access to European agricultural markets.
Senator Charles E. Grassley, an Iowa Republican who is on the House Agriculture Committee, wrote in a letter to a Bush Administration official, "Any agreement which puts a cap on corn gluten exports will severely upset Midwestern agricultural interests since this is the type of value-added export we are trying to increase."
In Washington, a senior official in the Bush Administration said that Mr. Kohl should expect a "blunt" message from Mr. Bush on the agreement this weekend. He said the German Chancellor had promised to press the French on the issue of agricultural subsidies two years ago but had failed to produce a compromise.
 
Aid to Ex-Soviet Lands
 "The Administration had commitments from Kohl to work this issue going back to 1990, but Kohl felt he couldn't make a move then because of German reunification and elections coming up," said the official, who insisted on not being identified. "Even in the wake of all that, he hasn't been able to move the ball forward."
Nonetheless, the Administration does not expect Mr. Bush to win much more this weekend than another promise from Mr. Kohl to urge France to be more flexible, the official said.
The two leaders are also expected to discuss the situation in the former Soviet Union. Germany has provided about 60 percent of all Western aid to the former Soviet republics and wants the United States to contribute more.
Mr. Kohl is also expected to urge Mr. Bush to avoid further reductions in the number of United States troops in Europe.
President Bush plans to reduce American military strength in Europe to about 150,000 soldiers, sailors and airmen by 1995, fewer than half the number that were there in late 1989, when the Berlin wall came down.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Democrats;
Clinton Says Golfing at All-White Club Was Mistake

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, March 20

 BODY:
After months of presenting himself as a Southern candidate with a good civil rights record, Gov. Bill Clinton has suddenly found himself under criticism for a classic gesture of racial separation: playing golf at an all-white country club.
Mr. Clinton was chided by a leader of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People in Little Rock and by Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia for playing golf on Wednesday at the Country Club of Little Rock, an upper-crust bastion in the Arkansas state capital. The rebuke by Dale Charles, president of the Little Rock chapter of the civil rights group was first reported on Thursday by The Washington Times. 
 Mr. Clinton quickly admitted that he had made a mistake and vowed never to play there again until it was integrated.
He said as part of his defense that his chief of staff, William Bowen, was leading an effort to integrate the club. Mr. Bowen said he and others were sponsoring nonwhite candidates for membership in the organization, but no application had been acted on yet. Club officials did not return telephone calls today.
"I'm going to do something unconventional for a politician -- when I make a mistake, I'm going to say I made a mistake, not go into some long, labored exercise," Mr. Clinton said today as he campaigned here, speaking of his efforts to "unite the nation across racial and economic lines" and accusing President Bush and the Republican Party of dividing the country racially.
 
Call to Wilder
 Mr. Clinton telephoned Mr. Wilder today, apparently to express the same kind of regrets he expressed publicly here, and he also met with members of minority groups in Hartford and New Haven as he campaigned for Tuesday's Democratic primary.
By offering a swift mea culpa, the Democratic front-runner was clearly hoping to minimize the incident as quickly as possible as he tries to focus on strengthening his sudden position as the seemingly unassailable leader in what is now a two-man race for the Democratic Presidential nomination.
But Mr. Clinton's own explanation made it clear that he was aware that the country club, where he is an honorary member as Governor, has no nonwhite members. "A guy asked me to play nine holes of golf," Mr. Clinton said. "It was the only place we had time to play. I should not have done it."
Mr. Bowen said Mr. Clinton played this week with Mark Grobmeyer, a Little Rock lawyer and longtime associate.
 
Action Contradicts Campaign
 The Governor's misstep seemed especially maladroit given his effort to take a strong stance favoring civil rights in the campaign and to overcome the issues of personal conduct that have periodically troubled his nomination bid. In addition the Clinton organization has shown an obvious concern to calculate the political ramifications of virtually every move the Governor makes.
Mr. Wilder seized on that point in a statement he issued Thursday in response to Mr. Charles's criticism of Mr. Clinton.
"Governor Clinton, a man besieged with stories about his personal life in the past few months, has taken to lecturing Americans about personal responsibility," he said. "All I can say to Governor Clinton is, doctor, heal thyself."
Mr. Wilder said, "It is inconceivable to me that a sitting Governor would either accept membership or recreate in a club that openly discriminates against blacks and other minorities."
Glenn Davidson, Mr. Wilder's spokesman, said he did not know what Mr. Clinton told Mr. Wilder in the telephone call."
The issue of membership at country clubs and golf clubs has been a delicate topic for decades, and an obvious trap for politicians. Candidates routinely review their memberships and other contacts with private organizations to insure that they are politically clean. In December 1990, Vice President Dan Quayle came under fire for playing at the Cypress Point Club in Pebble Beach, Calif., which had been ruled ineligible for a major golf tournament because all its members were white.
Mr. Quayle's office declined comment today on Mr. Clinton's actions.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Connecticut;
To Cheers, Brown Jabs Campaign 'Gong Show'

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRIDGEPORT, Conn, March 20

 BODY:
Edmund G. Brown Jr. came to City Hall here today, declaring at a noontime rally that being Governor of California was "the major leagues," that the United States should build "B-2 bullet trains instead of B-2 bombers," and that the campaign for President is "a Gong Show" run by the wealthy.
He was cheered long and loudly. 
 Taking aim at politics as usual, Mr. Brown and his politics-as-the-unusual campaign bore down today as he sought to take advantage of Paul E. Tsongas's withdrawal from the Democratic race only days before Connecticut's Presidential primary on Tuesday.
If his attacks on the establishment have made some critics call him a "political terrorist," the rally here and others in Hartford and New Haven on Thursday showed that he continues to appeal to voters who feel left out of the country's economy or shut out of its discourse.
The crowds that came to hear him seemed convinced that he was genuine, that he was a career politician who, as he says, "rubbed my nose" in big-money politics and now has crossed the street to join the real people. They laughed as he derisively recalled the critics, when he was Governor, who called him Flake and Moonbeam.
"Jerry Brown seems to be the only one speaking to the population I serve," said Vonda McKeithan, a 24-year-old Y.W.C.A. worker in Bridgeport. "What makes him crazy? That he's different? I'd think that would appeal to young people."
In the next two weeks Mr. Brown, who has made strong showings in several states, hopes to establish his candidacy in votes in Connecticut on Tuesday and in New York and Wisconsin on April 7.
This is their opportunity, staff members said, to disprove the political experts who immediately concluded that Mr. Tsongas's withdrawal had delivered the Democratic nomination to Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas.
On Thursday, only hours after Mr. Tsongas suspended his campaign, Mr. Brown complained to labor leaders in New Haven that the first question a reporter asked him was, "When are you going to withdraw?"
 
Party Chiefs and Bolsheviks
 Referring to pronouncements that the campaign was all but over, he told the Bridgeport crowd: "We have a media and party hierarchy that actually wants to shut down debate. It reminds me of the Bolsheviks."
What Mr. Brown still has to overcome at the national level, he effectively manages each day at rallies like the one here, in the Common Council chambers where Bridgeport's bankruptcy crisis was played out nearly a year ago.
He attributes the country's economic problems to a ruling elite that is out of touch because it spends its time with wealthy contributors who finance its campaigns with $1,000 checks, "the people who always figure out a way to prosper even as more Americans suffer."
He asks people to raise their hands if they have never given a candidate $1,000, the maximum under Federal law, and when all hands are up, he says, "People like you are not the kind of people most successful Presidential candidates spend time with."
He accepts no contributions larger than $100, and each rally ends with him reminding people of his "800" telephone number for contributions and with volunteers passing around buckets to collect checks or cash.
 
The 'Moonbeam' Question
 Mr. Brown takes care of the Moonbeam question -- whether he is a "serious" person -- by reviewing his record as Governor of California, "the major leagues" compared with certain other states, like Mr. Clinton's.
"I think he'll make a wonderful President," said Louis Costanzo, a retired union carpenter from Bridgeport, adding that he was especially impressed by Mr. Brown's record as Governor. "That speaks for itself," he said.
And Mr. Brown offers visions of how the Federal Government could create jobs by converting military programs like the B-2 bomber to the manufacture of high-speed bullet trains like France and Japan have, and creating a construction program to make the nation's homes, factories and offices energy-efficient.
As people walked out of City Hall today, some were chuckling over Mr. Brown's visions. "Imagine promising Bridgeport a bullet train," one man said. But across the lobby, a table staffed by volunteers was ringed with people waiting to contribute money.

HEADLINE: Powell Criticizes Further Military Cuts

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 20

 BODY:
Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, today issued the sharpest criticism to date of a plan in the House of Representatives to double the size of military budget cuts the Bush Administration had proposed for next year.
Testifying before the Senate Armed Services Committee, General Powell said a move by the House to cut an additional $7 billion from the Administration's proposed $281 billion military budget for the next fiscal year could threaten American military readiness. 
 A senior House aide rebutted General Powell's assertion, saying the Pentagon was using scare tactics to discourage serious debate on deeper reductions in military spending.
 
'Discredited Tactics'
 "The Pentagon is resorting to the old discredited tactics that any defense cuts will have dire consequences," said Vernon A. Guidry Jr., an aide to Representative Les Aspin, the Wisconsin Democrat who heads the Armed Services Committee.
Mr. Guidry said additional cuts could be made in areas like Pentagon supply inventories and overseas installations without hurting American military readiness.
Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, along with six Republican committee members today sided with General Powell's criticism of the House plan, foreshadowing an impending clash in the Senate and House over the size and pace of additional reductions in military spending.
Senator Nunn said in an interview after the hearing that it "would be difficult to make substantial" cuts beyond what Mr. Bush had proposed in the fiscal year 1993, which begins on Oct. 1. But he said additional reductions were likely after 1993.
 
Putting Pressure on Lawmakers
 General Powell said today that the House plan would force the Pentagon to cut 300,000 additional troops. The general's testimony today, capped by a five-minute videotaped interview of Army soldiers at Fort Bragg, N.C., lamenting their uncertain futures, represented an escalation in a carefully calculated public-relations campaign he and Defense Secretary Dick Cheney have waged with lawmakers in recent weeks to illustrate the potential risks to larger cuts in military spending.
Lawmakers have become increasingly nervous about cutting back more deeply in troop strength and possibly adding to unemployment lines during a recession and election year.
General Powell said today, for example, that further cuts in troops would drastically cut training for pilots, sailors and soldiers, and possibly even lead to higher casualties from peacetime training accidents.
Led by Mr. Aspin, House Democrats have said Congress can trim the Pentagon's fiscal 1993 budget without cutting more troops or jeopardizing their training.
Mr. Aspin has proposed several alternatives to the Pentagon's budgets through 1997, and recommended the cuts in the fiscal 1993 budget that were eventually adopted as the basis for the House budget resolution.
 
List of Savings
 At today's hearing, Senator James Exon, Democrat of Nebraska, said he would soon compile a list of $4 billion in potential savings from as many as 150 medium- and smaller-size weapons and weapons research programs.
General Powell also criticized Mr. Aspin's proposed alternative "base forces" of active Army divisions, Navy ships and Air Force wings for the rest of the decade, as "fundamentally flawed" and "overly simplistic."
Mr. Aspin favors cutting the Army's 12 active divisions to nine, cutting the Air Force's 15 tactical air wings to 10, and slashing the Navy fleet to 340 ships, from 450 ships that the Pentagon proposes, by 1995.
General Powell said the Pentagon's proposed base force "anticipated the breakup of the Soviet Union." No Defense Department official has ever claimed to accurately predict the Soviet demise.
Under repeated questioning from Senator Carl Levin, Democrat of Michigan, General Powell backpedaled slightly, saying that Pentagon planners had anticipated a "fundamental, historic realignment" of the former Soviet republics.
Later, after Mr. Levin left the hearing, General Powell said in response to a follow-up question from Senator Connie Mack, Republican of Florida, "I did not know it would break up."

HEADLINE: Chinese Smugglers' Lucrative Cargo: Humans

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, March 20

 BODY:
In growing numbers, ships from mainland China are sailing toward America, their holds packed with a frightened and seasick human cargo destined mostly for labor in the restaurants and sweatshops of New York's Chinatown.
Five ships carrying a total of about 600 people have been discovered since January and as many as nine more are being monitored now as they head for Los Angeles, said Bruce J. Nicholl, an official at the Immigration and Naturalization Service in Washington. 
 The new tactic represents a major expansion of the far-flung smuggling networks that for years have brought small groups of Chinese laborers to the United States through Canada and Central America.
International Chinese crime syndicates, many with roots in ancient secret societies called triads or tongs, have begun to add their resources and muscle to the enterprise of human smuggling, Mr. Nicholl said.
The immigration service is barely keeping pace, and even in cases where immigrants are caught here they often are released pending hearings, or for lack of detention centers, and simply disappear into an underworld of forced labor, drug dealing and crime.
"This is kind of 19th-century stuff now where the tongs are not just shipping illegals but trafficking in people as human slaves," said Peter Kwong, a professor of political science at the State University of New York College at Old Westbury.
For a price of $25,000 to $30,000, part of which goes to bribe Chinese officials, poor farmers and laborers from southern China are following earlier immigrants in search of prosperity in America. And like their predecessors who helped build the nation's railroads, most are destined for years of servitude as they labor to pay off the cost of their passage.
"Most of them end up in pretty squalid conditions as indentured servants in restaurants and packing houses and garment factories," said Mr. Nicholl, who is the immigration service's expert on Chinese smuggling. Others "can end up actually enslaved to the triads as prostitutes or enforcers or drug runners or pickpockets."
He said as many as 25,000 Chinese have entered the country illegally, mostly smuggled in by air, in the last three years; the ocean routes appeared to have been put into operation about a year ago.
Most of the new immigrants come from Fujian, a southern coastal Chinese province with a history of migration and human smuggling, and most are headed for the Fujianese enclave of New York's Chinatown, he said.
 
Kidnapped and Beaten
 There, Mr. Kwong said, they are subject to exploitation and to a growing wave of violence by the syndicates enforcing the repayment of their debts with torture, kidnapping and sometimes murder.
"Mostly they are handcuffed within an apartment and severely beaten with anything from claw hammers to sticks," said Lieut. Joseph Pollini of the New York City Police Department. "They are told they have to pay $10,000 or $15,000 above their original fee, and a lot of drastic things take place."
Just today, he said, the last of eight men was convicted of kidnapping in the first such incident to have been uncovered, in November 1990. Since then, arrests have been made in seven similar kidnappings.
Partly because of the violence surrounding the smuggling operations, the department is forming a new unit to deal with Asian organized crime.
"The tragic thing is that these illegals are so desperate to get money that they are willing to work at any price," Mr. Kwong said. "So the situation in Chinatown is that wages are getting lower and lower."
A Fujianese service economy has sprung up in New York, including "travel agencies" that help coordinate contacts and payoffs to the smugglers.
"I heard of one woman on East Broadway who emptied her village, which was about 2,000 people," Mr. Kwong said, "and she was not the only one doing that."
The Fujianese are known as tough and hard-working, he said, and those who have paid off their debts after several years of labor are beginning to enjoy the rewards of their rough passage by opening Chinese takeout restaurants, mainly in poor areas of New York City.
 
Dreams of Success
 Dreams of such success inspired the 84 men packed for 50 days into the fetid hold of the 150-foot Taiwan-registered trawler Jinn Yin No. 1, which was seized off the California coast last month.
"It was my goal and my dream to come to the United States," said G. Ling, a 22-year-old student who comes from a family of truck drivers and who is now being held at an immigration service detention center in Long Beach pending a hearing on his status. "But we suffered so much: so crowded, so cold in the ship, not enough food, no water to drink, no place to wash."
C. Chen, 31, a professional diver who, like Mr. Ling, declined to give his full name, said the terrified passengers wept, prayed and vomited as the rusting boat, with its crew of seven, struggled through a typhoon and survived two fires.
He said many people from his grandparents' village near the Fujianese city of Fuzhou had come to America and prospered and that some of these had returned home for visits, tempting others to follow with stories of prosperity.
"Since the day I was born I wanted to come to America," Mr. Chen said, speaking through an interpreter. "We wanted to apply to the United States government to come the legal way, but too many people want to come. With so many people in China how long would it take us? The rest of our lives?"
In 1990, the most recent year for which figures are available, 31,800 people succeeded in immigrating legally to the United States from mainland China, putting that country in sixth place as a source of legal immigration.
Gu Kechen, a 21-year-old carpenter, said he had made a $2,500 down payment in China and that relatives in New York had guaranteed the balance of his $25,000 passage. "I don't know how I will pay them back," he said. "The important thing was to get to America."
Though they are now subject to deportation, the men under detention here still stand a chance of completing their journey to New York. Many will be released on bond either because of overcrowding at detention centers or because they apply for political asylum, officials and immigration lawyers said. When that happens, the chances are that they will simply disappear.
The results are hundreds of millions of dollars in profits for the traffickers, who operate what Mr. Nicholl called "the most sophisticated and largest and most expensive smuggling operation that exists in the world today."
As of last year, he said, "We have identified as many as 30 different smuggling routes coming into the United States."
People who cannot pay the full price for passage, Mr. Kwong said, sometimes travel as couriers on a drug-smuggling run from Fujian through Burma and Thailand, with stops in Latin America.
"Every time we get a handle on what they are doing and how they are doing it, things change," Mr. Nicholl said. When the first shipload was captured off Los Angeles last September with 118 smuggled passengers, he said, "We were sort of in a state of shock."

HEADLINE: Review/Pop;
Evoking A Youthful Sinatra

BYLINE: By JON PARELES

 BODY:
If he wanted to, Harry Connick Jr. could ride his Frank Sinatra imitation toward a lucrative career of singing old pop standards for nostalgic fans. He refuses to do so, a choice that bolstered his concert on Thursday night, the opening of a sold-out, 15-show engagement through April 7 at the Paramount.
The Sinatra imitation is only passable; it helps that Mr. Connick is skinny and looks good in a tuxedo. Like the young Mr. Sinatra, Mr. Connick is a baritone, and he has picked up the Sinatra style of widening the vibrato as a sustained note goes on. (He also has some of Mr. Sinatra's arrogance, boasting between songs that after he told off some audience members in Atlantic City, they lost $100,000 gambling.) But he can't match the young Mr. Sinatra's effortlessness, his precise pitch, or, most important, the sense of storytelling in a song. Regardless of what he's singing, Mr. Connick usually sounds emotionally nonchalant and musically studious. Yet on Thursday, the crowd burst into applause whenever Mr. Connick started a song like "All of Me" or "It Had to Be You." 
 In a show that lasted more than two hours, Mr. Connick flaunted other skills. He played piano improvisations that juxtaposed modern-jazz harmony and florid New Orleans barrelhouse style. He sang his own songs from the album "Blue Light, Red Light" (Columbia), often with lyrics by Ramsey McLean, that harked back to prerock pop. He briefly danced and played drums. He paid tribute to New Orleans jazz and sang a mildly risque version of "Sheik of Araby." And he directed a 17-piece big band in his own arrangements. He even tried to sing gospel in a finale that brought together his band and the opening act, Raymond Myles, a gospel-pop tenor with a 20-member choir. Mr. Connick's churchy benevolence cracked, however, when he called someone in the stage crew "you stupid fool" for nearly raising a curtain too soon.
Mr. Connick does best in his most thankless job, as band leader and arranger. He drew split-second accuracy from his musicians in arrangements that were both demanding and ingenious. He has assembled strong soloists, including Russell Malone on guitar and banjo, Leroy Jones on trumpet, Louis Ford on clarinet, Lucien Barbarin on trombone and Shannon Powell on drums -- not coincidentally, the makings of a traditional New Orleans jazz combo -- and Jerry Weldon on saxophone.
Mr. Connick leads a big band in the era of music video and sound bites, and he knows it. Band members, equipped with wireless microphones, roamed across the stage and into the audience; computerized spotlights bathed the bandstand in hot pastels. Often, Mr. Connick seems to have calculated his arrangements for a short attention span. In almost every song, fast or slow, a high-note trumpet climax brayed that the band is, indeed, big and brassy. Yet between the blares, Mr. Connick came up with finely balanced reed-section filigrees, subtle brass support and clever tempo shifts.
The opening overture, jump-cutting between be-bop dissonances and swing-era harmony, suggested that Mr. Connick is torn between sure-fire crowd-pleasing and modernist adventures, and the concert reinforced that impression. Mr. Connick would allow himself some brooding piano improvisations, to the audience's indifference, then turn "Sweet Georgia Brown" into a Liberace-like showpiece, drawing shouts of pleasure.
The crooners and composers of the big-band era were also entertainers, of course. But it's not the 1930's anymore, even with a recession economy. It may be beyond Mr. Connick to heal the rift between modern jazz and more popular entertainment that arose after World War II, especially with a strategy that depends so heavily on looking back. Still, it's encouraging that he isn't twice as corny.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Harry Connick Jr. performing on Thursday night, the opening of a sold-out, 15-show engagement through April 7 at the Paramount. (George Kalinsky/Paramount)

HEADLINE: Volunteer Ambulance Corps Fill the Gaps

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

 BODY:
The Tri-Community Volunteer Ambulance Corps officially came into being at 5:36 last Saturday evening when its only ambulance responded to its first emergency -- a car accident on Clarendon Road in Brooklyn. And, as the crew merrily pointed out, they beat the Emergency Medical Service to the scene by a good 20 minutes.
"That's why we're here," the corps' ebullient driver, Darryl Ellis, said as he climbed back into the ambulance to wait until another emergency call sputtered over the police radio. 
 He did not wait long. By night's end, the ambulance had careered back and forth on the hard streets of Brownsville, East Flatbush and Crown Heights. Two more car accidents. A crack addict with a cracked rib. An alcoholic's seizure. A man collapsed on a sidewalk.
In an area where poverty and violence are adding more strain to an already burdened Emergency Medical Service, the city's newest volunteer ambulance corps is offering some relief. For the volunteers, it also offers something else: a sense of neighborhood pride.
"We saw them in all the other neighborhoods," said the corps' founder and president, Granville Barrett. "But there was nothing in this neighborhood. If they could have them, we thought we could have the same thing here."
There are 39 volunteer ambulance corps in New York City -- most of them in Brooklyn and Queens. Some corps have been around for years, including Bravo in Bay Ridge and the College Point Volunteer Ambulance Corps, the city's oldest, which was founded in 1942.
But there has been a surge of new corps in recent years, beginning with the creation of the Bedford-Stuyvesant Volunteer Ambulance Corps in 1989. What was once a fixture of rural and suburban communities and New York City's more remote neighborhoods has increasingly come to be seen as a necessity everywhere.
Besides Tri-Community, two other volunteer corps -- in Park Slope and East New York -- have applied to the State Department of Health for licenses and expect to begin operating in May and June. There are also plans to start services in Cypress Hills and East Harlem.
"Communities are recognizing that the resources are dwindling and there is a need to supplement existing services," said Steven E. Glass, the president of the Park Slope Volunteer Ambulance Corps, which, when approved, will respond to emergencies in an area from Third Avenue to Flatbush Avenue, including Prospect Park.
All the new corps were born of a feeling that the E.M.S. -- which answers a million emergency calls each year with 335 ambulances -- has become too overwhelmed to answer every call, in every neighborhood, at every moment.
For its part, the E.M.S. has by and large welcomed the new corps. A spokeswoman, Lynn Shulman, said that while the volunteers answered only about 20,000 calls last year, they filled in important service. "They're very important for their communities," she said. "And they help us out at times, too."
 
No Charge
 The ambulance corps, whose volunteers are certified paramedics and emergency medical technicians, do not charge to treat or transport patients. They do not compete with the E.M.S., but rather augment it, helping to better allocate service.
"Minutes count when it comes to lives," said Mr. Barrett, a tall, soft-talking immigrant from Jamaica who has himself been an emergency medical technician at the E.M.S. for 10 years. "Seconds do."
Mr. Barrett and John Bell, a Brownsville real-estate agent and landlord, decided to form Tri-Community in 1990. Following the example of the Bedford-Stuyvesant corps, where Mr. Barrett often volunteered, they began raising money and support. Until they received a $40,000 grant from the Robin Hood Foundation last year, a lot of expenses came out of their own pockets, including the $1,000 fee to apply for a license.
Last October, they bought a used ambulance for $2,000 at a lot in East New York. The ambulance was refurbished by Hatzolah, the volunteer ambulance corps whose response to the car accident in Crown Heights last August that killed Gavin Cato and touched off three days of violence angered many blacks in the community.
 
'More Than an Ambulance'
 The corps' headquarters is a rented storefront on 93d Street at Rutland Road in Brownsville. It is sparse, with second-, maybe third-hand furniture that starkly contrasts the neat, sterile packages of bandages, oxygen masks and other medical supplies. Duct tape holds maps and posters to the cinderblock walls. A police scanner sits on a dusty table, a coat hanger as its antenna.
Mr. Barrett envisions great things for the space. "We want to be more than an ambulance," he said. "We want to be a center for learning, a center for the community."
Already Medgar Evers College in Crown Heights holds classes there on Mondays and Wednesdays for students seeking general equivalency diplomas, and a cadre of neighborhood youths have made it a hangout. Mr. Barrett, a certified instructor, plans to hold classes to teach cardiopulmonary resuscitation and other life-saving procedures, hoping volunteers can train to be emergency medical technicians and find jobs in a community where unemployment is high.
Finally, last Saturday, after two years of preparation and paperwork, the corps was ready to roll. The volunteers -- 7 of a total of 15 -- arrived early. They put on their uniforms. They checked the ambulance.
Mr. Barrett drew the crew together for what amounted to a roll call (except everybody knew everybody). He turned to the driver, Mr. Ellis, who by day is an elevator mechanic in Manhattan.
"Don't be a Speedy Gonzalez," Mr. Barrett told him. "Stop at red lights. Remember, you don't have the right of way."
"We're here to help people, not hurt them," said another volunteer, Gladwin Thornhill.
"Besides," Mr. Barrett said. "It's our only ambulance."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "We saw them in all the other neighborhoods," said Granville Barrett, second from left, founder and president of the Tri-Community Volunteer Ambulance Corps. "But there was nothing in this neighborhood. If they could have them, we thought we could have the same thing here." He spoke with the ambulance crew before responding to their first emergency last Saturday in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn. (Edward Keating/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Confidence Indexes Show Brighter Consumer Outlook

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
Consumer confidence, which had remained gloomy even as consumer buying had begun to rise, appears to be moving up again after a long slide.
The University of Michigan index of consumer sentiment, which edged up a bit in February, spurted more than 8 percent in the first half of March to 74.6 from 68.8. 
 Two other widely followed surveys are giving off small signs of growing optimism but have yet to show a decisive upturn. The weekly ABC/ Money Magazine poll, which has been hovering near its recession lows, perked up a bit in the last week. The Conference Board will not release its March figures until the 31st, but the February responses were more positive late in the month than they had been earlier, said Fabian Linden, executive director of the organization's Consumer Research Center. The index fell sharply in February.
The confidence measures are cheering forecasters, Bush Administration officials and marketers who have been watching the readings as anxiously as intensive-care nurses monitoring vital signs. The downbeat mood earlier this year had seemed to contradict statistical reports and anecdotal evidence of renewed spending. To economists, improvement in the confidence indexes is critical evidence that the recent jump in retail sales was not a fluke and that the economic recovery is not necessarily doomed to fizzle.
"I look for confirmation of other reports that the economy is improving," said Edward Yardeni, chief economist at C. J. Lawrence. "We economists need all the help we can get."
Edward McKelvey, an economist at Goldman, Sachs, said, "It helps make you comfortable with the idea that there's something real going on." Goldman now predicts that consumer spending will rise at a nearly 5 percent clip after inflation, which would lift the overall economy.
Economists had worried that consumers' pessimism could turn into a self-fulfilling prophecy. A DRI/McGraw Hill calculation showed that if consumers remained deeply worried, retail sales would be $20 billion lower, and 100,000 fewer cars and 40,000 fewer houses would be sold this year.
This is not the first time that consumers have begun to open their pocketbooks before their spirits brightened. In 1991, for example, retail sales surged in February but confidence did not revive until a month later. One reason that moods take longer to mend than actual spending at the end of a slump: consumers can no longer postpone increasingly urgent purchases, like new tires, and there are plenty of bargains to tempt them.
 
Ups and Downs
 "Our data are much more precise in indicating the timing of a downturn, rather than an upturn," Richard Curtin, the director of the University of Michigan survey, acknowledges.
It is also not that unusual for the different polls to be out of line with one another for a month or two because they collect their data differently. The Conference Board, for example, gathers data by mail surveys, sending out 5,000 questionnaires every month to a revolving pool of families drawn from a larger pool, while the University of Michigan conducts a longer telephone interview with 500 families in a random sample drawn from across the United States. The margins of error built into any survey can also show up as differences.
Of course, confidence measures have never been a perfect predictor of consumer spending. But recent academic studies of the two longer-running polls conclude that factoring in confidence does make spending forecasts more accurate.
 
Discretionary Dollars
 The mood of consumers affects discretionary spending on everything from air-conditioners to cruises, and, according to Morgan Stanley, discretionary spending accounts for about one of every three dollars consumers spend.
The predictive record is especially good regarding spending on long-lasting big-ticket items, according to Adrian Throop, an economist at the San Francisco Federal Reserve. James Wilcox, an economist at the University of California at Berkeley, has also found a significant correlation between changes in consumer sentiment and total spending a quarter later.
"Confidence isn't as important as some other factors," said Richard Hagenauer, a market analyst at Whirlpool. "But it can make the difference for us between a good year and a not so good year."

HEADLINE: Informal Latin Economy Saves Day

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LA PAZ, Bolivia

 BODY:
On every downtown city block here, men and women sit hawking their wares. From Bic lighters to Snickers candy bars to Brut shaving cream to Japanese television sets.
This helter-skelter commerce is only the most visible part of a vast informal economy that includes home building in Brazil, large parts of the bus system in Lima, Peru, and textile manufacturing in Bolivia. 
 Economists say that in the aftermath of a coup attempt in Venezuela earlier this year that has many politicians wondering how to strengthen the democratic process here, this segment of Latin America's economy, once scorned for evading taxes and fees, has become government's best friend.
The reason: Many Latin governments are in the delicate and lengthy process of reordering their economies, laying off tens of thousands of workers and cutting back on social programs. But that is not resulting in long lines of the unemployed because the informal economy is creating millions of jobs, feeding families and generating some of the most vibrant economic growth on the continent.
In industrialized countries, such marginal business activity might be shut down and outlawed. But not here. More and more politicians are realizing that letting the informal economy alone buys them much-needed time to attract new foreign investment, modernize industry and find new sources of development, without fear of social pressure that might push them back into the days of military government and subversive terrorist groups.
"This part of the economy is one of the most socially stabilizing factors in Latin America," said Grisela Mendoza, an economist with the consulting firm of Muller & Associates in La Paz. "These are some of the most robust segments of our economies."
Businesses in the informal economy often pay no taxes, have no licenses, offer no social security or medical benefits and sometimes deal in smuggled goods. But they also buttress parts of the formal economy -- so much so that governments are increasingly using a hands-off approach in dealing with the unlicensed, tax-free sector.
"Governments are finding that many of these companies over time tend to integrate naturally" with established businesses, said Francisco Leon, an economist with the United Nations Economic Commission for Latin America and the Caribbean.
In Chile, for example, he said many small businesses that do not pay taxes make goods that they then sell to large tax-paying companies. Those transactions separate the informal economy from a pure black market, bolster the industrial sector and help the informal sector to grow and mature.
 
Sharp Recent Growth
 The informal sector, though long a part of Latin American commerce, has grown sharply in the last decade. In Bolivia, economists calculate that if the informal economy did not exist, the country's unemployment rate of 7 percent would jump to 35 percent.
"I think it's safe to say that if you didn't have the informals you would have riots in the street in many capitals," said Hernando de Soto, a Peruvian economist and former adviser to President Alberto Fujimori.
A recent study by the United Nations Regional Program for Employment in Latin America and the Caribbean found that employment in the informal sector had risen to almost 35 percent of total urban employment,from 20 percent at the end of the 1970's. At the same time, urban unemployment fell to about 5 percent, from a peak of nearly 10 percent in 1983.
The informal economy represents up to 40 percent of urban employment in many countries, and in Peru economists say the figure is closer to 70 percent. This implies total employment at close to 40 million. Exact numbers are next to impossible to calculate by the very nature of this sector.
"You can't afford to crack down on these people," Mr. de Soto said. "They are in the informal sector because they have no choice. They have no access to credit. They cannot get their business application approved. Or they are just prohibited from opening such a business. They have nowhere else to go. If you start to crack down on them, they are bound to explode into political or violent opposition."
 
How It's Defined
 How economists define the informal sector varies widely. Most include only companies engaged in legal activities but not registered with the government because of excessive red tape, that do not pay taxes and fees, and do not provide their workers with required social security benefits and health coverage.
Still others include those involved in contraband trade and even drug trafficking and money laundering. Some economists say contraband trafficking -- excluding the cocaine trade -- accounts for only 11 percent of the sector's economic activity.
Many companies try to show at least some form of adherence to the laws. The United Nations study, for example, found that in Mexico only 27 percent of its small, informal-sector companies had not at least tried to register with the Government.
It is precisely the slowness with which government agencies move that leads many companies to work outside the law.
 
Long Waits Are Common
 In Ecuador, for example, it takes 180 to 240 days for a manufacturing company to register with the Government. In Venezuela, it takes up to 310 days; in Guatemala, up to 525 days.
Brazil, Mexico and Chile all require more than 20 applications before a company can be approved for business. This leads to tremendous start up costs, which make it nearly impossible for small entrepreneurs to follow the rules.
Moreover, complying with government regulations can be prohibitive. The United Nations labor group found that the cost of running a business in a number of Latin American countries could be as high as 70 percent of the company's annual revenues.
So businessmen skirt the law.
In Uruguay, a common practice is getting permission to manufacture, say, cosmetics, a license relatively easy to obtain. The business then manufactures a broad range of industrial chemicals, which it can argue are either integral to cosmetics or an offshoot of that business.
 
'License Pending'
 In Venezuela, small entrepreneurs often apply for a license to do business and then put in their windows a sign that reads "License Pending."
"They just make the application once and do nothing more," said Victor E. Tokman, executive director of the United Nations Regional Employment Program. "So when the inspector comes around they point to the application."
While some have argued that informal sectors are bound to disintegrate because they pay low wages, that contention has been disputed by some economists. Mr. Tokman says that on average, informal-economy wages are roughly comparable to minimum wages in Latin countries. Muller & Associates found that in comparing worker wages in the formal sector with those of the informal sector, the informal-sector workers often earned as much as $7 a month more.
"In one poll we found that 38 percent of those interviewed said that they preferred the independent work of the micro-entrepreneur," the firm said. "The informality offers a flexibility and independence that the formal companies cannot match." Formal employment relationships do provide health care, vacation and other benefits, but government clinics provide low-cost health care to all people.
 
Challenge for Governments
 The challenge for Latin governments, as they grow, is to incorporate the informal sectors into the mainstream of their economies, reducing tax evasion and enabling governments to crack down on illegal activities.
Mr. de Soto argues that while the informal economy offers governments a breathing space, sooner or later these entrepreneurs will get tired of not have legal title to land and businesses and of being locked out of credit.
"These people are getting very politically active and they are not taking things so easily any more," he said. "If over time they still cannot get a loan, or title to their land, you will find them moving toward guerrilla groups, to the side of certain military factions, to downright criminal activity."

HEADLINE: Prices of Treasury Securities Drop

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities fell sharply yesterday, and long-term interest rates moved back above 8 percent.
Sellers emerged early in the session, in response to rumors that an account was unloading $500 million worth of bonds. Subsequent sales of corporate bonds by retail accounts forced the securities firms that bought the corporate debt to sell additional Treasury securities as a hedge against those purchases. 
 "The market is having a tough time again," one Government securities trader said. "It was starting to ignore bad news, but all of a sudden when a seller shows up, people run for cover. There is a lot of supply coming, and people are sitting on their hands."
Next week, the Treasury will sell $14.75 billion of new two-year notes and $10.25 billion of new five-year securities, record amounts for both issues.
 
 
Thin Volume
 Analysts said the size of yesterday's price decline -- as much as 7/8 point for some long-term securities -- was exaggerated because trading volume was extremely thin.
"The market was coming off of three days when it did pretty well, and had pretty much burnt off what had been an oversold position," said Ward McCarthy, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a firm in Princeton, N.J.
Mr. McCarthy said a surprisingly large improvement in a March survey of business conditions by the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia provided another excuse to sell.
The Philadelphia Fed's survey, which covers businesses in the Mid-dle Atlantic States, is seen by some as a fairly accurate early indicator of the better-known monthly survey of the nation's purchasing managers, which will be released on April 1.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 percent bonds of 2021 were offered late yesterday at a price of 9917/32, down 7/8 point, to yield 8.04 percent. That compared with 7.96 percent late Thursday and 8.06 percent on March 13.
Among outstanding Treasury note issues, the 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 996/32 late yesterday, down 15/32, to yield 7.61 percent. And the 5 3/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 997/32, down 3/32, to yield 5.80 percent.
 
 
Short-Term Rates Move Up
 Short-term Treasury bill rates inched higher.
Three-month bills were offered late yesterday at 4.05 percent, up a basis point, or one one-hundredth of a percentage point. Six-month bills rose by a similar amount, to a late offered rate of 4.22 percent.
In the corporate bond market, the Tosco Corporation offered a total of $300 million worth of 12-year and 5-year high-yield bonds through an underwriting group led by Lehman Brothers.
The $200 million worth of 12-year first-mortgage bonds were priced at $100, or par, to yield 9 5/8 percent. The remaining $100 million worth of five-year 9 percent securities were also priced at $100.
All of the securities sold are non-callable for life.
The issue is rated Ba-1 by Moody's Investors Service and BB+ by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Mixed Amid Concern About U.S.-Iraq Tensions

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was mixed in choppy trading yesterday amid concerns about the Middle East and rumors of possible central bank intervention in the markets.
The dollar, extremely sensitive to news and rumors regarding Iraq, was driven up by reports of a possible United States-Iraq face-off over United Nations demands that Baghdad destroy its remaining weapons of mass destruction. 
 Later, the dollar declined after reports that Iraq had apparently headed off a confrontation by making disclosures about its Scud missile and chemical weapons programs and promising to permit United Nations demolition of both, said Mike Faust, a currency market analyst with MMS International.
The dollar tends to rise when international tensions increase and fall when those tensions show signs of easing.
Mr. Faust said there was also mild talk in the market early yesterday -- when the dollar was up against the mark and the Japanese yen -- that the Federal Reserve might sell dollars against both currencies to bring the dollar down.
The Fed and the Bank of Japan intervened in January to try to stop the dollar's advance against the yen, which was falling in response to the weakened Japanese economy.
The dollar rose as high at 1.6840 German marks, breaking through the psychologically important 1.6800-mark level, Mr. Faust said. But the dollar then fell back to finish only slightly above Thursday's levels.
The dollar closed at 1.6730 marks in New York, up from Thursday's 1.67125. In earlier European trading, it closed at 1.6785, up from 1.6705.
The dollar closed at 133.85 Japanese yen in New York, up from 133.65. In Tokyo, markets were closed for a national holiday. In London, the dollar rose to 134.05 yen from 132.55.
The British pound rose against the dollar in New York, closing at $1.7120, up from $1.71075. In London the pound fell to $1.7045 from $1.7105.
In the precious-metals market, gold continued to rally in Europe on tensions between Iraq and the United States but then fell in New York as Iraq seemed closer to complying with United Nations demands. The metal is seen as a safe haven for investors during times of international strife.
Gold is still trading at its lowest levels in almost six years. On Thursday, it rose for the first time in a week.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York gold closed at $338.20 an ounce, down 60 cents from Thursday. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $338.25, off 50 cents.

HEADLINE: Tax Bill Veto Is No Loss

 BODY:
Congress worked feverishly and successfully to pass an economic recovery plan before yesterday's deadline set by President Bush in his State of the Union address. It need not have bothered. The bill provided paltry relief for middle-class families, no relief from the recession and virtually nothing to spur long-term growth. Worse yet, it reinstated a bevy of tax shelters of the type that were demolished by the glorious 1986 tax reform.
Mr. Bush's veto of the measure, though delivered for all the wrong reasons, was therefore welcome. 
 Congress won't let matters stand. But what in the bill is worth saving?
For starters, Congress can forget about trying to jump-start the economy. The economy has already begun to revive, if only slowly. Any stimulus Congress could now deliver would come too late.
The centerpiece of the tax bill is a dollar-a-day cut for middle-class families, paid for in part by raising the tax rate on the highest-earning families to 36 percent from 31 percent and by imposing a 10 percent surtax on incomes over $1 million.
This approach is wrong-headed. Incomes of middle-class workers have indeed stagnated for two decades. But the problem is low wages, not high taxes. The answer is more investment, both public and private, so that work is more productive. Eventually this will require higher taxes.
The tax bill seeks a misguided cut of the tax on capital gains. Nearly every analysis concludes that it would have a minuscule impact on savings and investment -- especially so because Congress insisted on applying the tax cut to past investment. That's a nonsensical way to spur future investment and would shower well-to-do investors with windfall profit.
Another irresponsible provision is the so-called backloaded individual retirement accounts. Here, investors would be allowed to earn tax-exempt interest. But the provision would open a gaping budget deficit after five years or so, forcing a future Congress to raise taxes or slash public spending.
The bill, dishearteningly, rebuilds tax breaks for real estate and other special interests. Once this starts, there's no telling where it will end.
Sprinkled amid all the bad are a few provisions worth fighting for. The bill would wisely make permanent the low-income housing tax credit, which promotes new home construction in urban ghettos. It simplifies the earned income tax credit -- an effective income supplement for low-paid workers -- so that more eligible families will get what's due. And some of the new subsidies for corporate investment may be worth keeping, provided they fit into a plan for comprehensive reform of the corporate taxes.
But the list of good reforms is appallingly short. Mr. Bush vetoed the bill because, he contended, taking back part of the huge tax cuts that were handed to the wealthy by Mr. Reagan would imperil the economy. Absurd reason. But right outcome.

HEADLINE: Wrong War, Wrong Weapons, Wrong Thinking

BYLINE: By Adlai E. Stevenson; Adlai E. Stevenson, a Democrat and Senator from Illinois from 1970 to 1991, is chairman of an international merchant banking firm.

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
President Bush and Congress have declared war on recession. But they are fighting the wrong war, and, as in yesterday's tax cut jousting, both sides are using the wrong weapons.
Though the recession may be receding, the real weaknesses in the economy are structural and not amenable to quick fixes. The real war is over economic competitiveness; the trouble with fighting this real war is that it has been a loser politically. Competitiveness is not a tidy subject that readily captures the public's imagination. 
 Economic adjustment and diversification, the development of skills, energy policy, public investment, capital formation, the regulation of financial services, technological innovation, foreign marketing, financing trade -- these are elements of the war to improve competitiveness. But it has been difficult for Presidential candidates to communicate more than simplicities and imagery.
Almost 20 years ago, Congress held hearings and began studies on competitiveness issues involving such sectors as steel, cars, consumer electronics, semiconductors, as well as emerging industries. Reports, speeches, legislative initiatives followed. Academicians weighed in.
But as the challenge from abroad materialized, energies seemed to dissipate. Economic reformers in Congress were denigrated as "neo-liberals," and "industrial policy" was characterized as "picking winners and losers." Then came the "magic of the marketplace," the Reagan era's casino economy and, today, still more competitiveness studies.
In the meantime, other countries, led by Japan, focused on improving their industrial competitiveness. Typically, the U.S. bailed out Chrysler instead of helping to modernize the auto industry. Restraints on Japanese auto exports enabled Japan's producers to increase prices and profits and invest in U.S. production, seizing a larger market share. And now , as Japan imposes more restraints on itself, Detroit still isn't satisfied. Today, Congress and President Bush propose tax reductions that could increase the Federal debt and long-term interest rates, weakening the dollar without stimulating an economy that isn't responding to the stimulus of a deficit approaching $400 billion.
President Bush has offered no long-term measures to arm us for this competition other than banking reforms. Other leaders seek votes with expedients like unemployment benefits while threatening trade retaliation, blaming other nations for our own failures.
More foreign competition is on the way. Europe is integrating. Less developed and former Communist countries are reforming. China is on the move. In East Asian capitalist countries, policies are based more on economics and less on domestic politics, and the economics are not based on free-market orthodoxy. Growth and competitiveness drive these governments. They foster savings, production and exports, something we don't do. Elite bureaucracies in close cooperation with industry formulate and carry out economic policy for the long haul.
Segments of U.S. industry are adjusting to the foreign competition and becoming more efficient, and some business leaders are learning from Japan. But it is still difficult to detect rational policy making in Washington. It remains more responsive to political pressure and opportunism than economic necessity.
The early hearings in Congress helped a few reformers realize that the U.S. in effect had an industrial policy -- a complex web of tax concessions, loans, grants, guarantees and selective trade protection. But it was a de facto industrial policy -- unsystematic and politically motivated. We concluded that the most important thing to do was simply to get politics out of Government decision making and inject economic pragmatism into it. The net result would mean less Government intervention, not more.
Bashing President Bush and Japan has not gone over with many voters. If Gov. Bill Clinton can focus on the real war, articulate a vision of America's place in the future and lead us toward the next century, not just the next election, he will give Americans more confidence in themselves. Paul Tsongas, one of the early reformers in Congress, resisted quick fixes. He was ahead of his time then and now.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 24, 1992, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, Adlai E. Stevenson's Senate tenure was misstated in an article on Saturday. He represented Illinois from 1970 to 1981.

HEADLINE: The Fed Is Investigating Dealings in U.S. Note

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve Bank of New York confirmed yesterday that it was conducting an investigation into a possible squeeze of seven-year Treasury notes.
Reports that the New York Fed and the Treasury Department were asking major government securities dealers about a squeeze were initially carried late Thursday by the Bloomberg News Service. 
 Concern about the possible squeeze prompted the Fed to send letters on March 10 to all primary dealers -- the 38 banks and investment firms approved for direct dealing with the Federal Reserve Bank of New York -- requesting daily information since March 11 on each firm's immediate and net forward position in the 6 3/8 percent seven-year notes. The request sought information on notes held or controlled through repurchase transactions.
 
An Active Market
 The seven-year notes, which were auctioned in January just as interest rates bottomed, have been trading expensively in the repurchase market since February and have become more difficult to borrow since the New York Fed's letter was mailed, traders said.
In the overnight repo market, in which firms use securities as collateral for an overnight loan, the seven-year security is in such demand that it now trades at 3/4 of 1 percent, compared with an overnight financing rate of 4.15 percent. That means a trader who wants to borrow the seven-year notes to satisfy a customer order or cover a short position must agree to lend money at less than 1 percent to the dealer who has the notes.
Peter Bakstansky, a spokesman for the New York Fed, acknowledged the letters had been sent. Officials at the Treasury Department declined comment.
The inquiry is representative of the New York Fed's shift in responsibilities from surveillance of the primary dealers to market surveillance, Mr. Bakstansky said. That change was prompted by the Salomon Brothers scandal that erupted in August and the resulting changes in the government securities market recommended in a January report by the Fed, the Treasury Department and the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Salomon admitted in August that at an auction of two-year notes on May 22 it had bought almost 94 percent of the offering, an amount far in excess of allotments allowed by the Treasury to any one securities firm.
 
Conducting an Inquiry
 Mr. Bakstansky said of the current investigation on the seven-year note, "We are suggesting there is a squeeze." "
Credit market participants said reasons for the apparent squeeze had more to do with natural market forces than with any deliberate manipulation.
Most investors who own the 6 3/8 percent issue are probably unwilling to sell, analysts said, because the price of the security in the cash market has fallen sharply since it was auctioned.
Late yesterday the 6 3/8 percent securities were offered at a price of 94 26/32 , to yield 7.35 percent.
Under the new market guidelines, the Treasury Department could decide to "reopen" the issue and sell more of the seven-year notes to eliminate the shortage.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 23, 1992, Monday / April 8, 1992, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Saturday about the Federal Reserve Bank of New York's investigation of the market for seven-year Treasury notes omitted a word and thus misstated the bank's position on the inquiry. While confirming that the bank had asked 38 dealers for information on their holdings of the notes, a bank spokesman, Peter Bakstansky, said Friday, "We are not suggesting there is a squeeze."
An article in Business Day on March 21 about trading the day before in the credit markets misstated the amount of two-year Treasury notes purchased by Salomon Brothers at an auction on May 22, 1991. Salomon bought more than the 35 percent allotment allowed by the Treasury, but not as much as 94 percent.
