HEADLINE: Technology Hasn't Kept Its Promises

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Cut Off from the New Reality" (Op-Ed, Feb. 23), David Gelerntner laments the decline of science and technology as American ideals: artists and visionaries nowadays ignore the glamour of new inventions, students avoid science courses, commercial desktop computers sit idle, and no one looks forward anymore to a future made brighter by jet planes, atomic power and robots. 
 He's right. In the 1950's, atomic scientist ranked with cowboy and fireman as typical responses when boys were asked what they wanted to be when they grew up. In 1957 Sputnik added paranoia to fascination as fuel for our romance with science. As late as 1980, when the computer made the cover of the major news magazines, there was a widely shared expectation that computers would rapidly revolutionize educational and domestic life in the United States.
No such revolution has happened. On the contrary, far from bringing us to a utopia where, for example, electricity is too cheap to meter, our scientific achievements have become objects of suspicion.
People ask why, if our computers and machines are so proficient, we have 33 million poor, faltering schools, 20,000 toxic waste sites, a $3.5 trillion national debt and this lingering recession. There is a growing intuition, more unspoken than articulated outside of academe, that the technology-dominated textures of our culture are poisonous to people's deepest sense of the richness and worth of their own lives.
The chief benefits of most domestic technology are efficiency and pleasure. Both, though addictive, quickly reach a point of diminishing returns when pursued to satisfy the needs of the spirit.
The youngster who spends a fine spring day playing computer games alone admits to a certain unspoken rage, in that the day was not spent bicycling country roads with friends or building a treehouse. Children who witness parental divorce in a household full of state-of-the-art appliances wonder what real human purpose, finally, all those machines have.
Mr. Gelerntner is right about the effects of our apathy toward technology, but wrong about the causes. It does not proceed so much from laziness or ignorance as from a sort of desperate wisdom.
 
RAY J. SHERER
Camp Hill, Pa., March 1, 1992

HEADLINE: CAMPUS LIFE: S.M.U.;
The Student as Tutor And Also as Neighbor

DATELINE: DALLAS

 BODY:
Four Southern Methodist University students here are taking their education a step further in a new course this semester by living in an urban neighborhood to learn about urban living firsthand.
The students are living in what had been a crack house in a predominantly Hispanic neighborhood, East Garrett Park, which is being renovated by Dallas Habitat for Humanity, a nonprofit housing agency that builds homes with low-income families. Each family has to devote 400 hours of work to building their own home. 
 While living in East Garrett Park, which is minutes away from the campus, the students provide tutoring for neighborhood children.
Cris Lake, a senior political science major from Dallas, who began the program, said that living in a community takes tutoring a step further. He said that when his tutoring sessions are finished, the university students do not turn their backs on the children, leaving them "to the drug dealers and prostitutes."
 
Learning Way of Life
 "These kids face things that college students never faced," Mr. Lake said. "If college students can't get a very good grasp of what's going on, then how can we possibly consider trying to work on these problems?"
"The first day of my senior year, the first person I spoke with when I moved in, was a prostitute," he said. "That's what these kids have to face every day."
These students are enrolled in "Problems in American History: Studies in Urban Culture," a history course that explores the development of urban culture. Marilyn Johnson, the assistant professor of history who teaches the course, said the class explores urban politics, economy and social relations, migration and the development of minority neighborhoods in American cities.
The 14 students taking the course must devote a minimum of six hours a week to tutoring inner-city children. The four students living in East Garrett Park are doing so on their own; the university does not sponsor this part of the project because of the liabilities involved, the administration said.
 
'Real-Life Skills'
 Another student living in the East Garrett Park house, Cris Crane, a senior anthropology and sociology major from Austin, Tex., said, "It's really important to us that we live down here."
Kelly Perkins, a senior history major who is also from Austin, said she valued the course because she was learning "real-life skills."
The associate dean of undergraduate studies and administration, James Hopkins, said the course was an acknowledgment of the university's responsibility to the community.
"Universities in urban centers must form a creative partnership with their cities," he said.
 
Neighbor Is Excited
 One neighborhood resident, Donna Ortega, a 29-year-old whose daughter participates in the tutoring sessions, said she had been excited about having the students living next door.
"To me, it's been a huge difference," she said. "I feel a whole lot better in my house at night. I feel like they're going to look over me."
Alfredo Regalado, a 12-year-old who attends the tutoring sessions, said he had grown close to the students living nearby.
"They're always around," he said. "They help you and they go and chitchat with you. It's kind of safer because they're always passing around. They're your buddies."
But the future of the program will be in the students' hands. Mr. Lake said: "The burden is on us to insure that students continue living out here next semester. But we're extremely hopeful that with the increasing interest, we'll be able to convince the administration that this is a program S.M.U. should embrace."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "It's really important to us that we live down here," said Cris Crane, one of the Southern Methodist University students who are taking their education a step further by living in an urban neighborhood in Dallas. (Mark Perlstein for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: NEXT LEVEL;
Clinton Turns His Energies To Bush Battle

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

 BODY:
After all the candidate forums, all the Holiday Inns, all the box lunches, all the tarmac news conferences, all the panic and the exhaustion and the adrenaline buzz of watching large groups of people whipsawed by gossip and rumor and personal attacks, the Democrats finally seem close to choosing a nominee.
Sometimes it felt like Lonesome Dove, a cross-country cattle drive with amphetamine timing. Now, of course, it will begin anew. 
 Governor Bill Clinton of Arkansas was making all the appropriate comments last week, saying that he took nothing for granted and would continue to campaign hard for the nomination in the remaining 21 primaries and caucuses. But former Senator Paul E. Tsongas's rueful withdrawal after his losses in Illinois and Michigan left the Governor from Arkansas as the presumed nominee, with seven times the delegates of his remaining rival, the maverick former California Governor Edmund G. Brown Jr.
Already, Democratic leaders, who created this jam-packed primary schedule in hopes of producing an early nominee -- and, miraculously, seem to have achieved just that -- were turning their attention to George Bush.
Over at the Democratic National Committee, where memories of how the Democrats were out-campaigned and out-researched in 1988 run deep, they have been clipping and studying and looking for booby traps in the Bush record. Down at Bush-Quayle headquarters, similar "opposition research" is under way on the Democrats. Out on the campaign trail, the shape of the coming debate is already emerging.
If Mr. Clinton has his way, this will be an election about change -- yes or no. The 1980's, he argues, are over, their economic policies repudiated, and the country desperately needs a fresh new direction. He campaigned against Mr. Tsongas by calling him a man who wanted to continue "trickle down" economics, notably a cut in the tax on capital gains, rather than redress the inequities of the decade with measures like a middle-class tax cut and greater investment in education and training.
Mr. Clinton's aides believe his message needs fairly little retrofitting for the general election. From their perspective, he has simply left behind the body double for the real thing. "George Bush is the ultimate believer in the 1980's and the ultimate believer in trickle down," said James Carville, a top strategist for the Clinton campaign. "George Bush wouldn't know change if it ran over him."
Robert Teeter, the chairman of the Bush campaign, counters calmly that it will be easy to avoid getting trapped in the role of Mr. Status Quo Incumbent, a role that every incumbent who can read polls desperately fears this year. "The obstacle to change is Congress," Mr. Teeter said in an interview on Friday. "Every poll shows that the number of people who recognize that is increasing. And it's not a Republican Congress."
The Republicans, in other words, are not foolish enough to cede this ground to the opposition. It may be harder for a party in power for 12 years to present itself as an agent of change, but Ronald Reagan did it deftly in 1988: "We are the change," he told the Republican convention in New Orleans.
 
Ready for Something New

 As Mr. Bush vetoed the Congressional tax measure late last week, asserting that it would not ease the nation's economic plight, there were a lot of references to change.
"If the Democratic leadership that runs the status quo Congress will not help us change America, we have to change it without them," he said. "Change is nothing to fear." The idea behind all this, of course, is simple enough: Eight out of ten Americans in recent polls say the economy is in bad shape, and huge majorities have told poll takers that they think the country is headed in the wrong direction. Change is the last thing they fear.
Oratory can only help an incumbent President so much; what Mr. Bush probably needs most is continued improvement in the economy. He has other, related needs: His approval ratings have been hovering at 40 percent. The old Reagan coalition seems to be fraying badly; in the 1980's, a growing economy helped keep socially liberal baby boomers and conservative Christians under the same tent. And Patrick J. Buchanan's angry primary attacks casting Mr. Bush as a man who breaks his word and jettisons his principles have opened some wounds.
Still, Mr. Clinton's path is anything but clear, beginning with the approaching primaries in Connecticut and New York. To begin with, there is Mr. Brown, who shows very little inclination to fade away. The endgame with him may not be as difficult as the endgame was with the Rev. Jesse Jackson in 1984 and 1988, because it will not involve the sensitive issue of racial respect; the political always seemed fused with the personal when a nominee negotiated with Mr. Jackson.
 
Why Democrats Worry
 Still, Mr. Brown is viewed by many Democrats as a dangerous opponent because he seems to revel in throwing bombs. The Clinton forces will be trying to undercut his "we the people" appeal by focusing on his support for a flat tax, which they will present as a giveaway to the rich -- which, of course, fits neatly with their general election themes.
The deeper issue for Mr. Clinton is the fear within the party that some new character issue will emerge. Even those who dislike Mr. Clinton are somewhat amazed at his ability to plow through charges of marital infidelity, of manipulating his draft status to avoid Vietnam, and, most recently, of conflict of interest stemming from the partnership of his wife, Hillary, in a law firm that does business with the state of Arkansas.
But Democrats still worry. Many in the party believe that anything that distracts the public's attention from the economy this fall will hurt the Democrats' chances.
The Clintons seem to be trying to appeal to generational solidarity: if the standard is perfection, Mr. Clinton asks, who could pass? And, by extension, should the messy lives of the baby boomers forever foreclose them from power?
For all of that, Mr. Clinton has been given a great gift. This was a short campaign, waged largely by Presidential novices who were always scrambling for money and the limelight; they fell quickly and they fell hard. They also left with considerable grace, as Mr. Tsongas did last week.
Always left standing was Mr. Clinton, maneuvering through the complicated politics of South Florida or Chicago's City Hall, picking up endorsements wherever he went, eyes glittering and very, very hungry.
For all the talk of demographics and the broad forces of economics and culture, Mr. Clinton's campaign teaches once again that simple fire in the belly can do a lot. After the emotional detachment of Michael S. Dukakis, after the ambivalence and calculation of the Democrats who pondered a race last year but decided against it, Mr. Clinton and his crew provide a dose of political id for the Democrats.
They want the White House and they want it bad.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Israel Confronts the Idea of Life Without Washington

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN

DATELINE: JERUSALEM

 BODY:
Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir told a couple of American journalists half a dozen years ago that he wanted to be remembered after leaving office as the Israeli leader who "kept things quiet."
When it comes to Israel's most important relationship, that with the United States, events obviously haven't worked out quite the way he hoped. Today, relations between the two countries are an unquiet mess. 
 Inevitably, there are sharp debates over whether blame lies with the Shamir Government, for showing capital-lettered intransigence on settlement construction, or with the Bush Administration, for its equally bone-rattling coldness toward a democratic ally.
Either way, this is perhaps the lowest point in the decades-old partnership, serious enough to persuade some Israelis that there is a Humpty Dumpty break that cannot be put back together again. At least not in quite the same way. Israel's strength has "always depended on our alliance with a strong and supportive superpower," wrote Gidon Samet, a columnist for the newspaper Haaretz. "Now it is gradually withdrawing that support. In the long run, the end result will be to reduce not only Israel's ability to honorably support itself financially but also to defend itself."
One obvious reason for the gloom was that, after months of sturm und drang, Mr. Bush last week drove a stake through the heart of Israel's request for $10 billion in United States loan guarantees to resettle Jewish emigres from the former Soviet Union. The aid was doomed because Mr. Shamir, defying the President's objections, insists on continued Israeli settlement activity in the occupied territories. Shamir loyalists now grumble that the Administration never intended to provide the loan guarantees in the first place. The rift leaves Israeli economic planners to contemplate the likely consequences, with most predicting that belts are going to be worn tighter around here by next winter.
A second big worry set in over the last 10 days, affecting Israel's top priority: security. A spate of reports by American news organizations said the Administration was disturbed that Israel may have played fast and loose with promises not to hand third countries the arms technology it gets from the United States unless Washington approves. One accusation was that Israel had given China technology from the Scud-bumping Patriot missile. Other stories told of missile components, cluster bombs and assorted hardware going on to South Africa, Chile and elsewhere.
 
Israeli Denials
 The Israeli response, unequivocally, is that the charges are bunk. Why, officials ask, would they pass along technology that could let China develop better missiles that could then be sold to Arabs?
A common view here is that the sudden American press leaks must be part of a get-Israel campaign, possibly aimed at hobbling the country's arms imports and defense industry exports. A few military specialists say the strategic relationship with the United States may be at a turning point. For most Israelis, that is not comforting. They were hardly reassured after the United States Navy lost track of a North Korean ship suspected of carrying missiles to Iran and Syria. Nor are they soothed by the Americans' threat to bomb Iraq again to get rid of Saddam Hussein's remaining weapons of mass destruction. That, Israelis fear, could send more Iraqi Scuds their way, and this time they cannot be expected to absorb the blows without retaliation.
As it is, many Israelis feel they are already in a war. Arab attacks in and around the occupied territories have risen sharply in the last month, and there is a new readiness of the Israeli Army to shoot on sight. Last Tuesday, in Jaffa, two Israelis were killed and 19 wounded by a knife-flailing Palestinian from the Gaza Strip. Then, later that day, a bomb devastated Israel's embassy in Buenos Aires, killing at least 29 people, including 4 Israelis. The disaster put many here in a wagons-in-a-circle mood, bitter enough even to blame the United States for inspiring the violence by allowing Arabs to think, in the words of a high-ranking official, that "the Americans have thrown Israel to the dogs."
Passions like that, born of grief, may subside. Israel is at the edge of a campaign for June national elections, and the opposition Labor Party can be counted on to turn its fire on Mr. Shamir and his Likud Party. While Labor was quiet in last week's funereal climate, its new leader, Yitzhak Rabin, has argued in the past that Likud is to blame for the perilous shape of relations with the United States. Indeed, should a who-lost-America debate develop, many Israelis (and many American Jews) are ready to name Mr. Shamir himself -- for poking his thumb in Mr. Bush's eye over settlements and for suggesting that he cares more about his ideological right wing than easing the financial pain of Soviet Jews.
Some opinion polls give Labor a slight edge. But political experts caution that, besides the obvious fact that Election Day is three months away, Israeli voters are capable of an emotionalism that tends to favor Likud when they feel the way many did last week -- resentful and convinced that forces out there are trying to wash them away. Even now, some in Likud are saying that Mr. Rabin is really Washington's candidate.
A Likud victory would leave the Bush Administration with everything it presumably does not want: Mr. Shamir still in power, an active settlements policy still in effect and an Israel so distrustful that it will take no security risks for peace with the Arabs. And that would be hard for Mr. Bush to boast about come November, when he must face his own electorate.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
The Latest Technology Fuels the Oldest of Drives

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
As increasing numbers of Americans, searching for intimacy in the age of AIDS, turn to computer keyboards to aid their fantasies, computerized sex play is becoming a growing issue for the companies that sell on-line information services. The possibility of increased law-enforcement surveillance and new restrictions could hamper the electronic networking that the computer industry sees as one of its most promising vehicles for new economic growth.
Last fall, a 42-year-old man in Fremont, Calif., using a nationwide computer conferencing system, posed as a 13-year-old homosexual boy. He said he was electronically approached by someone identifying himself as a 50-year-old New Yorker who tried to arrange a meeting. In Massachusetts in January, a man was indicted for raping a 12-year-old boy whom he befriended through a computer bulletin board. 
 While computer video games with sexually explicit cartoon-like animations have been available and routinely exchanged over networks for a decade, these incidents arose from a newer phenomenon -- an emerging form of interactive computer sex play. Like telephone encounters, in which people dial 900 numbers to listen to fantasies described by an anonymous sexual surrogate, computer bulletin boards and conferencing systems permit individuals who don't know each other to "meet" and exchange intimacies by typing messages back and forth.
Unlike telephone conversations, however, which convey some information about age and sex, the computer permits people to hide their identity entirely. At a computer keyboard it is possible to assume any identity and change roles on a whim.
The user of a computer connected to a data network can simply type messages that show up instantly on the screen of another user around the corner or hundreds or thousands of miles away.
Bulletin boards or "chat" systems provide an important source of revenue for many on-line computer services like Compuserve and America Online. (Prodigy, a joint venture of Sears and I.B.M., does not permit a chat feature and discourages electronic messaging with high fees.)
Until Minitel, the French computerized information service, began cracking down on the so-called "Rose" services, the sex-oriented messages constituted more than 20 percent of the usage on its conferencing system. They dropped to less than 10 percent in the last year.
Yet in the United States keyboard sex-oriented communication is on the rise. "There is a lot of heavy clicking out there," said Paul Saffo, a researcher at the Institute for the Future in Silicon Valley, who studies the impact of computer technology.
One recent evening, users of the America Online network had the opportunity to visit a series of "rooms" offering, for example, "Naughty Girls," "Romance Connection" and a "Gay Room." After meeting electronically in the public room -- actually a window in which comments from many users scroll by -- new friends adjourned to private rooms for intimate conversations, often using noms de plume or "handles."
Roger Dietz, the man from Fremont, Calif., told newspapers and television stations that he has been in contact with 20 to 30 pedophiles using America Online.
Mr. Dietz, a computer designer for a Silicon Valley company, said in a phone interview that he had subscribed to the service to see if child pornography was being traded, as he had heard. "For me child pornography is where the line is crossed," he said.
After the incident America Online turned over computer files that contained pornographic materials to the F.B.I. The company said it prohibits messages that are defamatory, obscene, profane, racially threatening or illegal, but that it does not, and cannot, monitor private electronic mail. "It's none of our business and it shouldn't be our business," Stephen Case, the company's president, said.
Gerard Van der Leun, a spokesman for the Electronic Frontier Foundation, a public interest computing group that has focused on civil liberties, said that his organization has heard from people concerned about sexually explicit photographs being transmitted via computer networks. "These people have been up and transmitting since the technology first existed," he said. "If someone wants to see erotic pictures it's much simpler to go to any newsstand in America."
Future computer conferencing promises to become even more graphic. This fall Sierra On-Line, a software publisher in Coarsegold, Calif., began commercial service of a network that lets subscribers control animated graphic simulations in interactive versions of the company's computer games.
Many, such as chess, checkers or simulated airplane dogfights, are familiar and aimed at all ages. But one will be an interactive version of its best-selling adult software program, Leisure Suit Larry. In the personal computer version, a computer user can control an animated cartoon-like character through a set of interactions with female characters. In the network version, to be called Larry Land and restricted to people who sign a statement that they are 18 or older, users will be able to configure the appearance of their own characters and engage in a variety of adventures with cartoon characters controlled by other users. When sex takes place, only faces will be visible on the screen, said Kenneth A. Williams, Sierra On-Line's president.
"We want it to be G-rated," he said. "On the screen you will see a close-up of your partner's face and you will have buttons to control your own facial expression."
He said he realized the service might prove controversial. "It's going to pose some interesting social questions," he said. "Will real-life spouses get jealous? It's going to cause more than one divorce, I suspect."
Mr. Williams said that he had attempted to interest the software industry in a rating system, similar to the system used by the movie industry. But officials at the Software Publishing Association said there was little need for it because sex and violence are not generally part of commercial software. "We may have to re-evaluate this with the advent of multimedia," said Kenneth Wasch, president of the Software Publishers Association. Technology is rapidly leading to a new generation of software that runs television-quality animations coupled with sound and data capabilities, he said.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Bush's Other Race: Defeating the Recession

BYLINE: By LEONARD SILK

 BODY:
With the Presidential race now narrowed, almost certainly, to George Bush versus Bill Clinton, another race is shaping up as critical: George Bush versus the sluggish American economy. The question is whether Mr. Bush can make the economy strong enough fast enough to insure his re-election.
No business cycle in America is more predictable than the four-year political one: Presidential election years are, with rare exceptions, years of economic expansion, and 1992 looks like no exception. 
 As this year's campaign warms up, the economy is showing signs of warming, too. One indicator, released last week by the Commerce Department, was a jump in housing starts of 9.6 percent in February over January, which itself was higher than first estimated. The spurt lifted private housing starts to an annual rate of 1.3 million homes -- 29 percent higher than a year earlier.
Other signs have been the rise in retail sales at seasonally adjusted rates of 2.1 percent in January and 1.3 percent in February, after zero growth in the fourth quarter of 1991; the uptick of industrial production by six-tenths of 1 percent in February, after an eight-tenths of 1 percent decline in January; and the increase in payroll employment by 164,000 jobs in February after a drop of 149,000 in January.
Yet, until now, the pace has been too slow to bring down the jobless rate. Unemployment jumped to 7.3 percent last month, the highest since the recession began in July 1990. The economy will have to run much faster than it has in the now-ending first quarter, when it scarcely grew at all, to reduce unemployment before November.
Will that happen? Only the naive believe that the customary economic expansion in the fourth year of the political business cycle is a happy coincidence arranged by a Providence smiling on Presidential incumbents. Most skeptics, economists and Presidents themselves believe, as Franklin D. Roosevelt said, that "we planned it that way" -- or at least tried.
Bringing the economy in stronger is harder than it used to be, partly because of the estimated $400 billion deficit, which inhibits big tax cuts or spending increases, and partly because a more sophisticated public would look cynically, even fearfully, at a Federal Reserve Board that tried to jazz up the money supply to keep a President in office. If expectations of inflation rose, banks and other lenders would raise interest rates to compensate for the loss of value of their principal. And rising interest rates could spoil the recovery.
Such concerns have not deterred President Bush, Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady or Michael J. Boskin, Mr. Bush's chief economic adviser, from pressing Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, for an easier monetary policy and lower interest rates. They contend that, with so much spare industrial capacity and unemployed labor, inflation is not a problem. Many Democratic Congressmen and economists have joined them to prod the Fed.
 
The Fed Gets Aggressive
 The conservative and anti-inflationist Mr. Greenspan was extremely cautious about easing monetary policy until late last year, while maintaining, in Congressional testimony a year ago, that the Fed had eased "aggressively." But a leading monetary economist, Prof. Benjamin M. Friedman of Harvard, contends that the decline in short-term rates last year, roughly one and three-fourths percentage points, may represent, given lower inflation, "little decline, and perhaps none at all, in the real interest rates that primarily matter for either stimulating or retarding business activity."
On the threshold of the Presidential election year, however, the Fed did move. Just before Christmas, it cut the discount rate it charges commercial banks by a full point to 3.5 percent, its lowest level in a quarter of a century.
Although short-term, inflation-adjusted interest rates are still historically high, there is little question that the Fed has become more aggressive. It has increased its purchase of Treasury securities in the open market, injecting more cash into banks and increasing their lending ability. From the first quarter of 1990 through the final quarter of 1991, the Fed's holdings of Treasury securities increased by one-third, from $233 billion to $312 billion.
 
Politics and the Money Supply
 Some conservative economists harshly criticize the Fed for moving too fast to do the President's bidding and fear that converting too much of the national debt into cash will kick off inflation again. This is a familiar story, says Prof. Thomas Havrilesky of Duke University. In "The Federal Reserve Chairman as Hero: Our Defense Against Monetary Excesses?" in the current issue of The Cato Journal, a conservative publication, he concludes that "over the last 40 years political pressure on Federal Reserve officials has grown intense" -- and has usually succeeded.
The politicization of monetary policy, he argues, was set up by the Banking Act of 1935, which increased the power of the Federal Reserve Board and the Federal Open Market Committee at the expense of the regional Federal Reserve Banks; and the Fed's ability to contain monetary excesses was further weakened by the Full Employment Act of 1946.
"The historical record shows that the great money expansions under Presidents Johnson, Nixon, Carter and Reagan were preceded by signals to the Federal Reserve to do something about adverse movements in interest rates or exchange rates," Professor Havrilesky said. Because the lag between rapid monetary growth and rising inflation is likely to be a year or more, Presidents, whatever their political ideology, can hardly resist pressuring the Fed in election years.
However, some economists, including pragmatic conservatives like Mr. Boskin, the President's adviser, as well as liberals and middle-of-the-roaders, believe that pressure for greater monetary growth is a healthy corrective for the conservatism of central bankers in times of unemployment, overcapacity, recession or sluggish growth with low inflation.
During the Great Depression, the Fed was timid even when deflation was the problem. But this time the Fed appears to have eased money in time for the November election; the reductions in interest rates are starting to percolate through the system, especially by raising housing construction. This will affect lumber, concrete, steel, plumbing fixtures, furniture, streets, sewers and other public works, and perhaps even autos.
Whether the spur will be strong enough remains to be seen. The economy is not some great mechanical instrument, like a mighty Wurlitzer organ, on which the Fed can reliably play first on the high notes to stimulate the economy and then on the low notes to slow it down. The Fed cannot precisely control the money supply or the speed at which it turns over. Meanwhile, monetary policy is the only lever for an Administration seeking to boost economic growth. President Bush proposed a fiscal package including a cut in the capital gains tax, a $5,000 credit for first-time homebuyers and tax breaks for professional real-estate investors but Congress rejected it.
Then the President vetoed on Friday a Democratic bill, by Representative Dan Rostenkowski and Senator Lloyd Bentsen, similar to his own but callingfor a cut in middle-income taxes to be offset by a rise in upper-income taxes. Mr. Bush, challenged by the right-wing Republican Patrick Buchanan, said his worst mistake was forsaking his "no new taxes" pledge and that he would never do it again.
To punish the Democrats for not giving him his self-described stimulative tax program by March 20, the President has promised to knock out $4 billion of what he considers waste; desirable as that might be for the long haul, it would not speed recoveryin the short run.
But the President's willingness to take that chance implies his confidence that Mr. Greenspan has delivered on the Fed's commitment to get the economy growing again -- and, implicitly, to keep it growing through 1992.
There is nothing Bill Clinton can do or, probably, would do to prevent a recovery, even if he could. He might wish, like St. Augustine, to be made "virtuous, but not yet." But his commitment to business, farmers, workers, the middle class and minorities is to unite them in an effort to improve the economy and to attack social, educational, environmental and industrial problems, to advance living standards and make America more competitive. He's got to be for more growth and more jobs now.
And the more that actually happens, the more Mr. Bush is likely to win in November. That's the real advantage of incumbency in an election year -- and the real explanation of the four-year political business cycle.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Political Ads May Wound, But Not Win Races

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT

 BODY:
By most accounts, it was during the 1988 Presidential campaign that media consulting really triumphed over message. Together George Bush and Michael S. Dukakis spent a record $50 million on television advertising and it is widely believed that the Republicans' notoriously inflammatory Willie Horton ad helped seal the doom of the Democratic ticket.
This year, not surprisingly, the Presidential candidates have already spent millions on commercials and seem on their way to matching the 1988 total. Commentators have dusted off their warnings about the power of advertising. 
 There are reasons to believe, however, that these warnings may be overstated. Political scientists who have explored the subject have, so far, failed to discover any direct connection between running ads and winning votes. Some have even concluded that television advertisements are a relatively ineffective use of resources.
"Advertising is something you've got to do," said Michael Robinson, a professor of government at Georgetown University. "But it is clearly the single most overrated club in a candidate's pack."
Professor Robinson examined the correlation between winning and spending on advertising in the last two Presidential campaigns and found that the connection was, at best, weak. In 60 primaries in the 1988 campaign -- 30 in each party -- in which one candidate significantly outspent the others, the big spender won only 40 percent of the time.
In the Georgia primary, Senator Al Gore of Tennessee outspent the Rev. Jesse Jackson 5 to 1, but Mr. Jackson still won. And in Maryland, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas outspent George Bush by 2 to 1 and still lost.
Because many of the primaries had three or more contestants, Professor Robinson concluded, "one could say that big spenders did better than expected. But they did not do very well -- better than chance, but not much better."
Big spenders have also had their shares of losses in 1992. While the final figures are not yet available, Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska is believed to have waged the most expensive media campaign in New Hampshire; he came in third.
Measuring advertising's effects is a lot like studying the ties between television violence and crime: there are so many other factors at work that it is tough to draw neat conclusions. During a campaign, voters learn about the candidates from a range of sources as diverse as their surroundings: local politicians, friends, news reports, televised debates and, of course, commercials.
Darrell West, a Brown University political science professor who studied 40 years of Presidential campaign advertising, said that what ads do best is raise issues that may influence votes. In the 1964 campaign, he said, commercials that President Lyndon B. Johnson ran with pictures of nuclear explosions turned the hawkishness of his opponent, Barry Goldwater, into a central campaign issue.
But, Professor West said, it is hard to find connections between ad campaigns and victories and, in the end, the best indicator of whether the incumbent's party will win is the state of the economy.
"Ads are incredibly influential in shaping campaign dynamics," he said. "But they're not nearly as influential in terms of the final vote."
One of the first systematic studies of Presidential campaign advertising was done in 1972 by Tom Patterson, a political science professor at Syracuse University. He analyzed the ads that candidates were broadcasting and the news the networks were airing, then assembled panels of voters and asked them what they knew about the candidates.
Professor Patterson concluded that messages in the ads came across more clearly to voters than messages on the news, and that ads communicate most effectively to people who do not watch the news. But from this, he said, it is possible to demonstrate only that advertising conveys information, not that this information translates into votes.
"There's an effect there," Professor Patterson said. "But I certainly wouldn't say advertising decides elections."
The putative power of advertising reached its height in 1988 with the Willie Horton ad, which showed a black man who had been given a weekend pass from a prison in Massachusetts while Mr. Dukakis was governor. While on furlough, he viciously raped a white woman and beat her fiance. The advertisement was aired in September by a political action committee supporting President Bush, and was followed by another ad with the same theme -- but without Willie Horton -- aired by the Bush campaign itself.
In the aftermath of the election, critics of television-driven campaigning often credited these attack ads with President Bush's victory. But several researchers argue that the connection -- if there is one -- is indirect. They note that Mr. Bush's most significant surge in the polls took place around the Republican convention in August -- before the Horton ads began. And the most important factor in this surge, they say, was not advertising, but the news coverage of the convention.
"It's a myth that these ads elected George Bush," said Robert Lichter, co-director of the Center for Media and Public Affairs in Washington. "Free media is more important than paid media. These moments when you see big shifts in the polls you can usually associate with something that is happening in the news."
Professor Robinson of Georgetown also argues that news coverage helped President Bush more than commercials did. In general, he says, Presidential candidates would be better off focusing less attention and money on advertising.
"The first thing I would say to candidates," he said, "is 'See if you can buy some journalists.' "

SECTION: Section 4; Page 16; Column 4; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 920 words

HEADLINE: THE NEW YORK REGION;
New York Medicaid Strained by Newly Poor

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK

DATELINE: ALBANY

 BODY:
BARRY T. BERBERICH, the director of long-term care for New York's Medicaid program, has a favorite horror story.
It involves a New York City woman who qualified last year for Medicaid by impoverishing herself a few weeks before applying. To get Medicaid to pay for the health-care services she was receiving in her home, the woman transferred her assets -- enough to generate $168,000 in annual interest income -- to another person. 
 The horror was not so much that a New Yorker would brazenly abuse a tax-supported public health program. After all, thousands of middle-class and wealthy people in New York State and elsewhere, aided by a cottage industry of lawyers, have taken advantage of state and Federal loopholes to qualify for Medicaid benefits when they needed long-term health care.
The real horror, at least for a state in fiscal distress, has been the lack of political will in both Albany and Washington to close the loopholes.
Many advocates for the poor, who are fighting budget cuts in welfare and Medicaid programs for the truly needy, see that as evidence of an insidious syndrome. Although long-term care is the most costly and fastest growing part of the state's Medicaid program, it has enjoyed a measure of political protection because it is largely a middle-class entitlement program, they say.
Some state officials concede the point.
"It is often much easier from a political point of view to deal with issues that are just perceived as welfare," said Michael J. Dowling, director of health, education and human services for Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. "With long-term care, you are dealing with a clientele that is largely not the traditional welfare population. They are getting public assistance, but the public doesn't perceive the welfare population as being the elderly and disabled."
Yet Medicaid spending on the elderly and disabled, who make up a quarter of the state's Medicaid recipients, accounts for two-thirds of the state's Medicaid costs.
Many are middle class or wealthy people who qualify for Medicaid after transferring their assets or taking advantage of other loopholes. About 500 New York City residents qualify each year for Medicaid after shielding assets in trusts, which is allowed by Federal law. Others are covered because state law grants Medicaid benefits to anyone whose spouse simply refuses to pay health-care costs. New York law also allows residents to qualify for Medicaid coverage for nursing home care while a spouse keeps up to $66,000 in assets.
This year's fiscal crisis has made long-term care far more vulnerable than in the past. Budget negotiations in recent weeks have included discussions on whether to increase taxes on nursing home revenues, clamp down on the use of trusts and other loopholes and restrict the number of hours that Medicaid will pay for attendants who cook, clean and shop for the homebound.
Carl S. Young, president of the New York Association of Homes and Services for the Aging, said such cuts will almost certainly put some of the state's 630 nursing homes out of business. Nursing homes already have lost $200 million to state budget cuts in the last three years, and the state's recent decision to delay Medicaid reimbursement payments by two weeks left some nursing homes on the brink of insolvency, he said.
"There are facilities that are so close to the bone that they send couriers to pick up Medicaid reimbursement checks from the state rather than waiting for them to come by mail," Mr. Young said. "It's the only way they can make their payrolls."
Whatever the condition of the nursing homes, Medicaid spending on long-term care has not been subjected to the same political assault experienced by programs that solely benefit the poor.
The highly public campaign being waged by the Republicans who control the State Senate has focused on proposals to fingerprint welfare recipients, restrict Medicaid coverage for the able-bodied poor and cut welfare grant levels.
The Senate Republicans refer to New York as "the Cadillac of welfare states," a claim that Mr. Cuomo ridicules given that welfare recipients live well below the poverty level. What is less arguable is that New York provides Cadillac long-term care coverage, and that it is long-term care costs that are driving the explosive growth in Medicaid spending.
From 1986 to 1990, Medicaid spending for long-term care increased by 82 percent, to $4.9 billion, while all Medicaid spending grew by 65 percent, to $11.6 billion, according to the state Department of Social Services.
A recent study by Jane S. Little, an economist with the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston, showed that New York's spending on its average Medicaid recipient in 1989 was 48 percent above the national average. Its Medicaid spending on recipients in skilled nursing facilities was 122 percent above the national average.
The high costs were not simply a reflection of health care in New York. The state's per capita health care bill for all residents was only 16 percent above the national average.
Assembly Majority Leader James R. Tallon, Jr., a Binghampton Democrat and an expert on Medicaid, said one reason for the high cost has been the rapid expansion of programs to care for long-term care patients at home.
But Mr. Young attributed the high spending rates to the costs of labor and state regulation. "New York State as a government has never met a regulation it didn't like, and that's not always bad," he said. "But there's a cost attached to that."

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 1; Column 2; National Desk

LENGTH: 1656 words

HEADLINE: The Young Face of Inner City Unemployment

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, March 21

 BODY:
Salvador Martinez ran a hand through his short-cropped hair, smoothed his freshly ironed T-shirt and walked through the warehouse door of the Vargas Furniture Manufacturing Company, hoping to find work as a laborer.
An 18-year-old high school dropout from one of the poorest neighborhoods of Los Angeles, he has never held a steady job, and the more he looks for one the more he thinks he never will. 
 Economic analysts say he may well be right. It is no surprise that as jobs become harder to find at every level, the people who are hurting the most are those who have always had it hardest: young members of minorities from the inner cities.
Almost half of the teen-agers in urban poverty areas are without jobs, with young blacks having the highest rate of unemployment, said John Bregger, an assistant commissioner in the Bureau of Labor Statistics in Washington.
And as jobs become scarcer, economists say, poorly prepared black and Hispanic young people are being pushed off the bottom rung of the economic ladder by working-class whites who are themselves being pushed down the same ladder.
A few days on the streets with some of these young men and women showed how ill-prepared they are not only for the workplace but for the job hunt itself, coming as they do from communities where unemployment is often handed down from generation to generation, like a trade.
A former gang member with a bullet wound, gang tattoo and a jail record as his resume, Mr. Martinez said he had been trying to find work for four months to help support his parents and the child his girlfriend is expecting.
He had already tried most of the factories, warehouses and meat markets in the area, but he nurtured a special hope for Vargas because his father had once worked in a furniture factory.
"I wonder if you've got any more applications," Mr. Martinez said, taking a deep breath and peering through a small plate-glass window at the Vargas warehouse.
"We're not giving them out," came a voice from inside.
"O.K., thank you," Mr. Martinez said, and the job interview was over.
"Another usual day," he said, climbing into the cab of his father's pickup truck to continue his search. "Most of the places I go, they say they have no openings right now. Some other places say, 'I'll give you a call.' That's all I ever get."
Back at Vargas, the woman inside the window, a telephone operator, said young men like Mr. Martinez came by all the time to look for work.
"If I gave this boy an application, the whole area around would hear about it and people would appear out of nowhere," said the telephone operator, Marilyn Raygoza. "When we do have jobs, we post them, and we get scores of people, lines and lines of people around the block."
If Mr. Martinez had asked when applications would be given out or had asked for the manager or had even asked for the manager's name, she said, she might have taken more notice of him and given him some help.
But everywhere his father drove him on this usual day, his questions were the same and the answers were the same.
"Got any applications?" he asked at the Tampico Spice Company, where the air was thick with the mingled smells of cumin, bay leaves and coriander.
"No, we don't," said the warehouse supervisor, Aurelio Cardenas, looking up briefly from his lunch.
"O.K., thank you," Mr. Martinez replied, and left.
Perhaps, Mr. Cardenas said, if the young man had gone around back to the manager, he could at least have learned when applications would be given out. "You've got to keep coming back," he said. "It's the only way."
Last year, the unemployment rate for black teen-agers in poor urban areas was 43.4 percent, said Mr. Bregger, the Labor Department analyst.The figure would be even higher if it included those who make do with part-time work and those who have given up the job hunt altogether. "This is the highest unemployment-rate group you are going to find in the country: young blacks living in metropolitan poverty areas," he said.
The unemployment rate for Hispanic teen-agers like Mr. Martinez in poor urban areas was 28.6 percent last year.
 
Scarlet Letter
 One contributing factor is a dropout rate that rises from 60 percent to nearly 80 percent in some largely black and Hispanic high schools in Los Angeles. Many of these dropouts can barely read and write, said James Johnson, an expert on urban problems and a professor at the University of California, Los Angeles.
Those inner city young people who do stay in high school will at least be taught how to fill out a job application, although, said one teacher, Connie Covert, "I'm not sure all of them realize the importance of it."
"They may also have a prison record -- the scarlet letter of unemployability -- and they are locked into communities where there are no opportunities, no jobs," he said. "I don't think many of them find employment."
In the Nickerson Gardens housing project in Watts, not far from Mr. Martinez's home, idle young men stand about in groups or wander among the purple two-story buildings, stopping sometimes to swing on the swings of a playground.
Managers of the project estimate that 60 percent to 75 percent of the 1,061 families here receive some form of government assistance.
One unemployed resident is Sean Neal, 19, a gang member since the age of 14 who has already spent a year and a half in a juvenile detention center and who lives with his mother, who is also unemployed.
He has rarely ventured beyond the project, and the very idea of hunting for a job is almost beyond him. "I heard about a company where they make plugs and things," he said. "But I don't really have time right now to go check it out. At least, I don't have transportation to go."
Another is Shamiena Byrd, 17, who quit school three years ago because that was what most of her friends were doing. She is now working toward a high school equivalency diploma and holds a part-time secretarial job at a day-care center in the project.
There are few businesses here in Watts, and beyond its boundaries young black people looking for work in fast-food restaurants or elsewhere carry with them the stigma of where they are from.
"A lot of times, the system doesn't look at who you are but where you come from," Miss Byrd said. "Because of the reputation that Watts has, they usually think anybody that comes from Watts, they're bad."
And many times, she said, they are right.
"I have to say most girls -- most women -- around here, they are on welfare. Most of the guys, they sell drugs. That's just how it is," she said. "A lot of people, they feel like, 'Working at McDonald's, that's not going to get me the new car I want, or clothes.' But selling drugs, that's quick money, that's easy."
She said such people sometimes filled out a job application simply to continue receiving unemployment benefits, and some employers said many applicants were clearly more interested in the application forms than in the jobs.
Miss Byrd said it was also not unusual for young people to use their unemployment checks as seed money for drug dealing.
"If you was raised up in Watts, people put you down," said David Harrell, 19. "You've got to know somebody to have a good job, and I don't know anybody."
 
No Fast Food
 A job counselor at Community Youth Gang Services, a city-financed social agency, said it was often difficult to persuade young people from the projects to look for work, particularly when they have so little chance of finding employment.
"They don't want to work at fast food; that's not cool," said the counselor, Terri Holmes. "They prefer to do laborers' jobs in warehouses, or be baggage handlers at the airport.
"But a lot come in and tell you they can make a better living selling drugs," Ms. Holmes said. "To them, they are working. If they are out selling drugs, that's a job. It takes talent. It's not easy selling drugs. You have to look over your back constantly. You could be arrested or killed."
When Mr. Martinez came by her office for help, Ms. Holmes sent him to a United Auto Workers office that referred him to two auto-parts supply outlets for job interviews.
"I told them I just need a job," he said later. "I told them the truth. I told them I don't have experience, but I know how to stack stock. It's not that hard a job. They just said there's no jobs, that's all."
Mr. Martinez once worked for nine weeks as a laborer for the city Department of Public Works, but as so often happens to day laborers, he was dropped when the work ran out.
"You get frustrated," he said. "When I was at the D.P.W., two of my friends were there trying to get jobs like me, but they gave up. They're selling drugs right now. It's like the last possibility, the only way you're going to make money."
Mr. Martinez knows that life. He joined the Florence Southside gang at the age of 13, served six months of a two-year sentence for assault with a deadly weapon when he was 15, and was shot through the upper arm in a gang confrontation when he was 17, the year he dropped out of high school.
Some of his friends, observing his futile job hunt, have urged him to join them selling drugs. But he said he had seen enough of life to know that that option was "just a ticket to go to jail."
On the other hand, the only work Mr. Martinez has had in recent months is 28 hours of unpaid labor to work off a $138 traffic violation.
 
Dream Job
 Asked about his ambition, Mr. Martinez laughed. "I don't have an ambition," he said. "I just want a job."
But then he let himself dream for a moment.
"When I used to have part-time work here in the meat market, I used to be a box boy. That was nice," he said.
"What I'd really like is, I'd like to work for the city. I enjoyed the nine weeks I worked for the city. I used to clean up the streets in a crew van, cut the edges of the grass that grows in the alleys. That would have been just perfect."

PUB-DATE: March 22, 1992

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 1; Column 4; National Desk

LENGTH: 1795 words

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
New Kind of Potomac Fever Is Caused by Spartan Living

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 21

 BODY:
A guillotine has not yet appeared on the Potomac, but the mood here is very tense.
For years, the capital has had a caste system that allowed its top officials immunities and emoluments and deference and perquisites. 
 Now that voters have sent a message that they are fed up with pampering, preening and prodigal behavior among the Washington aristocracy, many here are gloomily assessing whether it is worth living in a world where they are expected to behave like ordinary mortals.
 
Des Moines or Albany?
 "You might as well be in Des Moines," grumped John C. White, a lawyer and former Democratic Party national chairman.
Joseph Canzeri, a public relations consultant who was an aide to Nelson A. Rockefeller, complained, "It might as well be Albany."
Tom Korologos, a Republican lobbyist, said, "Why not just go to Salt Lake City and open a gas station?"
Jack Brooks, the cigar-chomping veteran Texas Congressman, said he was not enmeshed in the House banking affair but that he was disgusted with what he sees as the sanctimonious tone of the debate on privilege.
"There is a move afoot to destroy the Congress as we know it," he drawled. "In the future, the kind of people who run for Congress will be coming up here living in sleeping bags and sleeping in their offices and riding bicycles to work."
Pause for effect. "Or they'll be right-wing extremists getting chauffered around in Cadillacs," he went on, in a cutting reference to Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the minority whip who has been prodding the Democratic leadership on the scandal but who wrote overdrafts himself and still rides in limousines.
Mr. White, another ebullient Texan, agreed that "the Great Man syndrome is important."
"They've already taken the sex and drinking out of politics," Mr. White said. "Hell, if they get this thing to where you can't exhibit a little sense of power -- that's what drives this city," he went on, a bit tongue in cheek. "If you don't have a policeman to stop traffic to let you walk across the street like you are somebody, how are you going to know you're somebody?"
And with that insight into the psychology of power, Mr. White raised intriguing question about politicians' struggles to take a more spartan stance to appease voters whose tempers are ragged from the long recession: How can Beltway mandarins who signal their status through their trappings and perks feed their egos in a no-frills universe?
Or could the zealous reformers be going too far? Is it so wrong for members of Congress to have, say, free use of a gym, and a modest one at that?
"Clearly, the bloom is off the place, so far as members feeling fed up with having to put up with this kind of nickle-and-dime criticism," said Representative Charlie Rose, a Democrat from North Carolina. "A member of Congress from a sun belt state came up to me today and said: 'I gave up a good job as county executive with good pay to come up here in the middle of all of this. I could be playing golf this afternoon if I was home.' "
 
The Good Old Days
 Mr. Canzeri, in a burst of wheeler-dealer nostalgia, agreed: "Give me some smoke and some back rooms."
Under Washington tribal customs, there were always supposed to be Mr. Fixits like Bobby Baker to provide anything a legislator desired, from a bag of cash to a willing young lady, or men like Jack Russ, the recently deposed sergeant-at-arms responsible for the House bank, who rose by making life a bit easier for his 435 bosses.
Now, such faciliators and fixers are scarcer. After Mr. Russ's ouster, the House postmaster, Robert V. Rota, resigned. Representative Bill Thomas of California, the ranking Republican on the House Administration Committee, which has jurisdiction over the post office, said the resignation signaled the "post-plantation" mentality in Congress. And Mr. Rose, the chairman of the committee, said the problem with "Can't Say No Rota" was an "overabundance of trying to be helpful to everybody.
 
A World Turned Around
 That used to be the whole point. But when practices that are de rigueur in one era suddenly seem sleazy in another, Washington power figures can get caught in a political and moral wind shear.
All last week, Representative Jim Nussle, a 31-year-old freshman from Iowa and the youngest member of Congress, sat in his office like Robespierre, scribbling a bill that would ban all luxuries for House members, from free flowers from the Botanical Garden to free prescription drugs to cut-rate haircuts.
When Speaker Thomas S. Foley announced on Friday that he was ending many of the perquisites that Mr. Nussle and other young legislators had complained about, Mr. Nussle was jubilant. "This is a red-letter day for the Nussle reform movement," said Mr. Nussle, who wore a bag on his head on the floor of the House a few weeks ago to show how embarrassed he was about the bank scandal.
 
Thomas Hearings Pivotal
 Mr. Nussle said that, for his constituents, the last straw was the Judiciary Committee's televised hearings last autumn on Prof. Anita F. Hill's charges of sexual harassment against Judge Clarence Thomas.
"That really woke them up that we needed sweeping reforms," he said. "They didn't realize that those guys in Congress were that old or that they can't talk off the cuff anymore."
Mr. Nussle's ideas are embodied in "The Nussle Congressional Reform Package," which he says has been written in language he picked up from his constituents. Typical chapter headings are: "New Blood," "Use a Stamp" and "Go Home.
Mr. Nussle's efforts are playing well at home. The Waterloo Courier ran a picture of what it called THE BAG used by Mr. Nussle, who says he has had inquiries about whether it belongs in the Smithsonian as a symbol of the voter uprising of the 90's.
 
Clean, as in Cincinnati
 Representative John Boehner of Ohio, another of the freshmen Republicans who call themselves the Group of Seven, who are rebelling against privilege, agreed that the American people now realize that politics does not have to be like it is in New York and Chicago, where "people almost expect politicians to be less than honorable." Instead, he said, politics can be "clean and decent, like where I come from in Cincinnati."
Self-indulgence is fast becoming unfashionable. In tune with the new puritanism, the caricature of pot-bellied lawmakers pursuing young women on Capitol Hill is fast fading with the chilling effect of the Thomas hearings and the undoing of Senator Brock Adams of Washington amid accusations of sexual misconduct.
"There's a mortal death fear sweeping Washington that the voters have finally figured it out, that they've discovered they can take matters into their own hands," said Michael McCurry, a Democratic consultant. "Politicans are afraid that the game is up."
 
Time to Clean House?
 Mitch Daniels, a business executive in Indianapolis who worked as the political director in the Reagan White House, said that every few years, Washington goes through "tremors" on the issue of cleaning house in "the Club," as the old boys' world of Congress is known.
This time, Mr. Daniels said, he believes that "this could be the year the tremors get a little more seismic."
Kenneth M. Duberstein, a Republican consultant, said many political observers are predicting that there may soon be as many as 90 to 125 new members of Congress after November.
"It will be interesting as we go to a perkless society," Mr. Duberstein mused. "Will they turn the House gym into a day-care center?"
 
Down-to-Earth Carter
 When he was President, Jimmy Carter tried to cut back on imperial perks. He wanted to carry his own bags, and he even wanted to give up the Presidential limousine for a regular old car, until the Secret Service told him to forget it.
But he fell victim to the entrenched ways of Washington. When Mr. Carter's approval ratings dropped and his friend Charles Kirbo asked a group of Washington's "wise men" for advice, he got some from Jim Rowe, a former aide to Franklin D. Roosevelt. It was that Mr. Carter should "abandon his cardigan-sweater routine and seem more Presidential," as Harry McPherson wrote in his memoir, "A Political Education."
Richard M. Nixon, on the other hand, went too far in the other direction. When he ordered that the White House guards wear uniforms modeled after those of European palace guards, including parade caps and braided shoulder pieces, critics pounced on them as too imperial and they were quickly dropped (and later lent to the Southern Utah State College marching band.)
Michael R. Beschloss, the historian and author of "The Crisis Years: Kennedy and Khrushchev, 1960 to 1963," said that Americans were ambivalent on this point, because they have two opposing longings: "They are very distrustful of authority, and like Jefferson, they want to throw everyone out every 20 years, and they have a longing for a monarch."
But while Americans may not want to see a President carry his own bags, even in the present anti-privilege mood, they do think the House of Representatives should be the least lordly institution.
 
Putting Green Donations
 Although Democrats threaten to make the privileged backgrounds of President Bush and Vice President Dan Quayle an issue in the general election, the White House does not seem overly concerned.
A White House official told a House Appropriations subcommittee this week that a putting green and a swimming pool have been built on the grounds of Mr. Quayle's official residence, paid for from a fund of about $390,000 in "private donations" for renovations desired by the Quayles.
As if the source of the money mattered. Everyone in Washington knows that when private donors give for a putting green they know this is not one of the thousand points of light. They want something in return, whether it is a chance to be heard on business regulations or an invitation to a state dinner.
Even Ralph Nader does not believe that Washington will ever become a Naderville, where the President must do without official flower arrangers.
 
Comment by Nader
 Mr. Nader evoked the days of Thomas Jefferson, who walked out of the White House after his inauguration and went back to the boarding house where he had lived to have supper with his fellow tenants.
Mr. Nader knows those days are gone forever. "There will always be powerful men with minute minds trying to kick over the ship of state trying to get another freebee or perk or another $25,000 on their salary," said Mr. Nader.
Mr. White predicted that "we'll get tired of showing off in our hairshirt and move on to something else."
Charlie Rose agreed. "I doubt," he said drily, "if we will ever be called the nation's monk class."

HEADLINE: U.S. and Israel at Sea

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 21

 BODY:
At a convention here last week for young American Jewish donors to Israel, the Israeli Ambassador, Zalman Shoval, made an impassioned and revealing appeal to get United States-Israel relations back on track.
Pointing to the Muslim republics of Central Asia that were once part of the Soviet Union, Mr. Shoval asked, "Is there not a danger that they will become fundamentalist and anti-Western and present a danger to the Middle East more than the Soviet Union once did?" Therefore, he continued, is it wise for the Bush Administration to "disregard" Israel as a strategic ally at this time? After all, he concluded, "the strategic relationship between the United States and Israel now is as important as it ever was -- even more." 
 The urgency of Mr. Shoval's appeal was revealing: Israeli leaders seem to be recognizing belatedly that with the end of the cold war a sea change has taken place in their relationship with Washington and they can no longer argue as effectively as before that they are a "strategic asset" for the United States. The Israelis are scrambling to find a new basis for the relationship with Washington.
Differences over what that relationship should be are at the core of all the recent tensions between the two countries -- from loan guarantees for housing immigrants to charges of improper sales of American arms technology.
 
Old Politics in New Era
 The Israeli Prime Minister, Yitzhak Shamir, "is still trying to play cold-war politics in a post-cold-war era, and it just isn't flying," said Steven L. Spiegel, a historian of the United States-Israel relationship. "In the old days, the two sides would have a fight, and then make up, usually on terms acceptable to Israel. But that isn't happening now because the whole context for the relationship is changing. Shamir still wants to play football, and Bush is telling him the football season is over. Now we are playing basketball."
To be sure, American officials say, the Middle East remains an unstable area and Israel a potentially useful ally, but against whom? Because the threats have grown so much more nebulous, the value to Washington of any particular strategic ally is also more nebulous. Also, with the end of the cold war, Washington is concerned much less with military alliances generally, and much more with a country's economic importance or its efforts to promote stability in its neighborhood.
Further, President Bush, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and the national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, all come from a wing of the foreign policy establishment that never believed Israel was a strategic asset -- an assumption they feel was confirmed by the Persian Gulf war, when they had to spend their energy keeping Israel out of the fighting so they could keep the Arabs in. Added together, these factors mean that Washington has a very different idea of what the relationship with Israel should be in the wake of the cold war.
The situation, a senior Administration official said, can be summarized this way: Israel wants to continue acting as America's policeman in a region where it is convinced American and Israeli interests face real threats -- even if they are not immediately apparent. But Mr. Bush wants the Israelis to be America's catalyst for a peace process that he is convinced can promote real regional stability -- even if that is not immediately apparent.
 
'Shared Values' Needed
 "The Israelis are deluding themselves if they think that strategic politics alone has been or ever will be enough to make this relationship work," said a senior policy maker dealing with the Middle East. "Like any special relationship, it has to be based on something more -- shared values."
Before the 1980's, shared values between two democracies were indeed the foundation of the United States-Israel relationship. But the Israeli invasion of Lebanon in 1982, the Israeli crackdown on the Palestinian uprising and the rise to power of an Israeli Likud Government driven by a religious-nationalist agenda have combined to make it very hard for some Americans to feel the sense of shared values with Israel that they once did.
In the early 1980's, Likud leaders understood that, and they began to emphasize the role of Israel as a strategic asset for the United States against the Soviet Union. This dovetailed neatly with the interests and obsessions of the Reagan Administration. This strategic argument, though, was like a blanket that was keeping the relationship warm; once it was removed at the end of the cold war, both sides discovered that underneath the old relationship had badly eroded, American officials say.
When this is coupled with the general turning inward by Americans today, and the fact that neither Mr. Bush nor Mr. Baker came into office with a deep emotional commitment to the relationship with Israel, it accounts for the increasing alienation between the two countries. This alienation was starkly apparent in the dispute over Israel's request for loan guarantees, which Mr. Bush refused to grant unless Israel froze settlement-building in the occupied territories.
Administration officials have been pointing out to leading American Jews that something very unhealthy, even dangerous, has happened in the fight between Israel and the Administration over this issue: The case for Israel has increasingly become the almost exclusive preserve of American Jews, rather than the cause of a broad consensus of Americans.
The fact that an American President would reject loan guarantees for Israel -- in an election year -- and find overwhelming support for his position in all national polls, suggests that Israel is badly out of step with the public mood. Samuel Lewis, a former American Ambassador to Israel, said: "When it gets down to just the American Jewish community as the only ones ready to go out and fight Israel's battles, that is very dangerous for Israel and for the role of American Jews in American society."
The end of the cold war requires Israel and many other American allies to shift ties with Washington from "a politics of shared enemies to a politics of shared opportunities," said Yaron Ezrahi, a political theorist at Hebrew University in Jerusalem. "That is what our leadership, and the American Jewish leadership, have not understood."
 
The Peace Standard
 Since the end of the cold war, the United States has increasingly judged allies on whether they are promoting peace and stability in their region. Administration officials insist that by putting together the Arab-Israeli peace process that started in Madrid, they have given Israel a new lease on a special relationship, by basing it not on a shared enemy, but rather on a shared opportunity for peace. The deal proposed by Mr. Baker after the round in Madrid included a freeze on Israeli settlements in return for an end to the Arab boycott of Israel and a suspension of the Palestinian uprising in the occupied territories. While both Mr. Shamir and the Palestinians rejected it, the Administration focused more of its wrath on Israel because it expected more.
"What seems to rankle Bush and Baker is that for them everyone is changing and adapting -- except Israel," Mr. Spiegel said. "When they look around, every country they deal with, from South Africa to the Soviet Union and from Albania to Nicaragua, has a new policy, but Israel is behaving as if the Berlin wall was still up and as if Madrid never happened. I think that is what is grating on Bush, and he is saying to Shamir: 'You don't want to see the world has changed? Then boom, I will hit you over the head with it.' "
Hope for the future lies with the Madrid process, said Stephen P. Cohen, of the Montreal-based Center for Middle East Peace. The importance of that process, he said, is that "it brings together both values and strategy" -- that is, it holds out the prospect of a Middle East based on Arab-Israeli reconciliation, in which Israeli and American moral values and strategic interests are in harmony, rather than clashing.
 
Importance of Cash
 But Madrid is not a cure-all, because post-cold-war foreign policy relies not only on strategy and morality, but also on cash, which is in increasingly short supply in the United States. The loan guarantees were killed not only by settlements, but also by the general American aversion to foreign aid in an election year.
The recent charges of improper Israeli transfers of American arms technology to third countries are also related to the financial issues growing out of the end of the cold war. Israeli arms companies, like their American and Russian counterparts, must now increasingly try to sell weapons abroad not for foreign policy reasons but for profits, because without the cold war all domestic arms budgets are being reduced.
American officials say that they have known for years that Israel was probably crossing the line in reselling American technology, but that they looked the other way. Now that the world's total arms-sale pie has shrunk and Israel is seen as a more significant competitor, many American military officials are no longer willing to avert their eyes. And this will be a constant source of tension.

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN;
Clinton Starts Setting Sights on Fall and Bush

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
Gov. Bill Clinton campaigned across New York and Connecticut yesterday, courting teachers' votes, fighting off Edmund G. Brown Jr. and asserting that President Bush vetoed the Congressional tax and economic growth package as "cover" for a reluctance to raise taxes on the upper class.
Starting his day in New York City, Mr. Clinton collected the endorsements of local members of Congress and the New York State United Teachers union. He also used the Bush Administration's decision to relax restrictions on abortion counseling in federally financed clinics as a chance to needle the President on an issue that has divided Mr. Bush's own party. 
 "On this issue, as on so many others, it's hard to divine a real conviction on the part of the President," the Arkansas Governor said.
But even as Mr. Clinton kept his eyes focused on the President and the fall election, he also did some local campaigning aimed at the primary next Tuesday in Connecticut and the one on April 7 in New York. He strolled through downtown New Haven, ate pizza and then flew to Buffalo, where he engaged Mr. Brown in a debate.
The dual aims of Mr. Clinton's campaigning reflects the unsettled position of his campaign as it scrambles to reshape its strategy for a political landscape that has shifted dramatically in recent days.
For months the Clinton organization focused on a multi-candidate struggle for the Democratic nomination. Now it has suddenly turned into a lopsided race between Mr. Clinton and Mr. Brown. The former California Governor is far behind in the struggle for delegates to the Democratic National Convention in July.
Though his aides said he was hoping at first to take some time off after former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts suspended his campaign on Thursday, Mr. Clinton decided to continue on the primary trail to avoid giving the appearance that he was taking the nomination for granted.
Tailoring the schedule literally on the fly, campaign aides said today that they would not begin any major strategy shifts until after the New York and California primaries, the latter on June 2. But the shift in Mr. Clinton's focus and his growing stature as the primary spokesman for the Democrats was evident as he assailed Mr. Bush for vetoing the emergency economic measures offered by Congress on Friday.
He asserted that Congress was trying to "give some modest relief to middle-income families whose incomes have gone down while their taxes have gone up" and that Mr. Bush offered objections to the Democratic plan as "cover for the fact that he simply cannot bear to raise taxes on the upper class."
Mr. Clinton also delivered a strong attack on the Administration's policy on Israel, a perennial political issue in New York. "All they have done is hit on Israel," he said. But Mr. Clinton denied he was tailoring his remarks for his New York audience, saying, "I don't think I've pandered on this issue."
At the news conference he received endorsements from three Democratic lawmakers from New York , Representatives Charles E. Schumer, Ted Weiss and Jose E. Serrano.
