HEADLINE: JAPANESE SHIFTING THEIR INVESTMENTS BACK TOWARD HOME

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 21

 BODY:
After investing hundreds of billions of dollars abroad during the 1980's, Japan has reversed course and is pulling money into the country at a rapid rate.
Japanese banks are lending less to foreign customers, particularly in places where business conditions are difficult, like California. Japanese corporations are building fewer plants abroad and acquiring fewer companies. And big Japanese investors are selling, rather than buying, the American securities they spent nearly a decade buying in large sums. 
 At the same time, foreign investors have become the largest purchasers of Japanese stocks and bonds. The result is that instead of $100 billion or more flowing out of Japan each year, $30 billion to $40 billion a year is flowing in.
 
The Tide Shifts
 The sharp and unexpected swing in Japanese capital is putting upward pressure on interest rates in the United States and making it tougher for other countries -- including Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union -- to import the money they need to grow, some economists say.
With the flood tide of Japanese money having dried up, these other countries must find alternative sources of money, reduce their demands or compete harder for what money is available by offering higher interest rates to attract investment.
During the years of enormous Japanese investment in the United States, some economists warned that the United States was left vulnerable to an abrupt withdrawal. If the Japanese merely slowed their purchases of United States Treasury bonds, the economists cautioned, it might cause havoc in the markets.
 
Recession Eased Withdrawal
 What has spared the United States such withdrawal symptoms has been the American recession, said Kenneth S. Courtis, an economist in Tokyo with Deutsche Bank Capital Markets, because the slowdown reduced demand for money.
But as the American economy struggles to shake off recession, the pinch may be felt more. "It is not a matter of pulling the trigger in Tokyo and having the gun go off in New York," Mr. Courtis said. "It's more like a slow squeeze."
Last year Japan brought home $36.6 billion more than it invested overseas. (Figures are not yet available on the flow of money between the United States and Japan.) That was the first time since 1980 that Japan imported more long-term capital than it sent abroad.
Long-term capital involves acquisitions of real estate, stocks or bonds and investments in companies, the building of plants and long-term bank lending. These include the construction of large automobile plants by the big Japanese auto makers and such prominent takeovers as the $2 billion purchase of Columbia Records by Sony in 1988, the $6.13 billion acquisition of MCA by Matsushita Electric Industrial in 1990 and the $846 million deal for control of the Rockefeller Group, the owner of Rockefeller Center in Manhattan.
While some experts thought the 1991 figures might be temporary, many economists are concluding that the flood of money Japan sent abroad during the 1980's was an aberration that may not be repeated soon.
Two years of volatile declines in the Japanese stock market and a looming economic slump here are accentuating this trend by making the money supply much tighter at home.
From 1985 to the end of 1990 Japan exported an astounding $596.2 billion in long-term investments, helping finance the United States budget deficit, corporate takeovers, construction of Japanese auto plants abroad and a host of other investments around the world.
One broad lesson is that in an era when borders are increasingly open to large shifts of money, often with a few keystrokes on a computer in a brokerage house trading room, the flow of money can change direction swiftly than most people had thought possible. The United States in particular is finding out that the huge flow of Japanese investment, on which it came to depend, is not a given.
"What you saw in previous years was in some senses not a normal situation," said Hirohiko Okumura, a former Bank of Japan official and now chief economist at the Nomura Research Institute. "It is not well-appreciated on Wall Street or in Washington, but the character of Japanese money is changing. It is not automatic that that money will flow to the United States anymore. Japanese investors are getting more sophisticated, and more cautious."
The huge shift by no means suggests Japan is getting poorer or losing its ability to influence the global financial markets. Indeed, Japan remains the world's largest creditor nation.
What is in some ways puzzling about the trend is that Japan's trade surpluses, which helped fuel the original investment boom, are swelling to record levels after narrowing briefly in the late 1980's. Last year Japan's trade surplus with the world reached $103 billion, and it is expected to grow this year. Forty percent of the surplus comes in trade with the United States.
But Japan is now marshaling its money for use at home, as it nurses a creaky financial system, awakens to the sobering reality that many overseas investments were ill-advised and tries to revive a slowing economy with heavy Government spending. The Government announced Thursday that the economy actually shrank slightly in the fourth quarter of 1991.
 
Economy Slows Sharply
 "The first priority should be to provide money to Japanese borrowers, even though loan demand in Japan has not been very strong," said Yoshihiko Miyabe, deputy general manager of the international planning department of the Yasuda Trust and Banking Corporation. "No bank can increase its exposure overseas now."
The poor planning behind many investments is another factor. For example, a Japanese investor recently suffered what is believed to be a $340 million loss after owning the famous Pebble Beach golf club for just 18 months. Many wealthy Japanese have lost so much money at home as stock market lost nearly half its value in the last two years that they have no means or appetite for investments overseas.
Billions were also lost through the purchase of foreign stocks and bonds because of sharp swings in the value of the yen against other currencies. Many big Japanese investors were relatively new to international investment and failed to protect themselves by hedging their investments.
 
Insurers' Heavy Loss
 The clearest sign of this came after 1985, when Japan and the United States agreed to halve the value of the dollar against the yen in an attempt to reduce the American trade deficit. A weaker dollar makes it less expensive for foreigners to buy American goods. Japan's life insurers reported losing from 1985 through 1987, in yen terms, the equivalent of about $30 billion in the value of their American securities holdings, because of the decline in the dollar's value.
"Life insurance companies normally do not like taking risks," Josei Ito, president of the Nippon Life Insurance Company, the world's largest insurer, was quoted as saying in an interview earlier this year. "It was unusual that they were investing so much of their capital overseas."
And Mr. Miyabe of Yasuda Trust added: "We have to be much more careful about foreign exchange risk than we were. That is the biggest reason we are not going to increase our allocation for United States securities in the near future."
Other big Japanese financial institutions are following that strategy.
From 1988 to the end of 1990, Japanese investors put about $52 billion into the United States, snapping up everything from tire makers and real estate to new factories. In the first nine months of last year, that figure plummeted to $2.3 billion. The Japanese made a net investment of $30.7 billion in United States Government securities in 1988, the peak year; they are now net sellers of government securities.
The ailing Japanese stock market is clearly reflecting and contributing to the new approach, economists say. Last week the stock market was flirting with a five-year low.
 
'A Winding Down'
 Because Japanese banks have a major portion of their basic capital -- the safety cushion they have against bad debts -- invested in stocks, they have been hit particularly hard.
"You're seeing a winding down of the positions that the Japanese banks established abroad," said Kermit Schoenholtz, an economist with Salomon Brothers Asia. "It's happening at a rapid pace."
Mr. Okumura of Nomura Research said the shift in the flow of money is also a sign that Japanese investors have moved into the second phase of their international financial expansion. Japanese banks, insurance companies and brokerage houses at first merely wanted to build up substantial portfolios, Mr. Okumura said, no matter what the exchange rates were. Now, he said, they are managing and shifting those assets, rather than increasing them sharply.
If exchange rates are unattractive, as he contends they are now, the institutions will keep their money in Japan.
"America automatically expected Japan to recycle its surpluses to the United States," Mr. Okumura said. "But that is not going to happen, at least at these exchange rates."

HEADLINE: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Campaign Journal;
Grace Under Pressure? It's Working for Clinton

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY

 BODY:
Once the votes are in, political consultants and journalists know exactly what it took to win a campaign. They can often explain it all using one or two television images: a brilliantly uplifting or nasty commercial, a blunder in a debate, a humiliating shot on the evening news, a sound bite like "Where's the beef?".
But this year's Democratic campaign looks inconveniently complicated even in hindsight. If there was one dominant image on television, it was the calm smiling face of Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, but you couldn't really call that a defining moment because it lasted more than two months, through moment after moment that would have defined other politicians as ex-candidates. 
 Mr. Clinton persevered with a fairly consistent and straightforward message in debates, sound bites, and commercials. It was a carefully calculated strategy, right down to the timing of his television appearances on election nights, but he avoided obvious gimmicks like the "pander bear" that former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts held up at a press conference or the protectionist commercial that had Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska in front of a hockey net.
 
Serenity at Work
 And Mr. Clinton had the serenity to make the message work on television, whether he was speaking directly to the camera in his commercials or fending off reporters asking about the latest scandal. Sometimes he looked too smug -- his self-satisfied look didn't seem entirely appropriate during his confession of marital failings on CBS's "60 Minutes" -- but at least he didn't look terrified or defensive.
He repeatedly put on performances like the one at the airport tarmac in Houston just before the Texas primary after an article appeared in The New York Times about a real-estate partnership involving him and the owner of a savings and loan in Arkansas. Local newscasts featured live reports from the airport describing the article as yet another blow to Mr. Clinton.
But Mr. Clinton looked unscathed as he walked through the reporters shouting questions about the article. "It's not right," he said, smiling and shaking his head. He promised to issue a rebuttal promptly, but there was nothing combative in his tone or his face. It was a kind, helpful look that seemed to say: Don't worry, they got it all wrong, but I'm sure they meant well. Everybody makes mistakes, and we'll get it straightened out in no time.
 
A Reagan Approach
 Mr. Clinton occasionally turned defensive, such as when he tried to blame his problems on a Republican conspiracy, but he generally avoided the Nixon approach to the press. His was more like the contented, unflappable style of Ronald Reagan, and to some viewers he seemed to be too much of an actor.
Mr. Clinton's fondness for statistics and think-tank jargon helped allay suspicions that he was too smooth. Maybe he seemed like a game-show host, but at least it was an intelligent game show. His approach also suited the mood of this year's voters, according to academic researchers who have been conducting focus groups around the country.
"People are looking for issues and serious messages," said Marion Just, a political scientist directing a project at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University. "In our focus groups the people got bored very quickly with clips from the evening news about who was ahead in the horse race or who staged what event that day. But when we showed them the campaign ads, they got interested because the ads offered focused information about the candidates' positions."
Mr. Clinton's commercials featured biographical information about him, shots of him talking about his proposals, and text on the screen offering specific critiques of his rivals' proposals. He combined his economic proposals aimed at the middle-class with promises to help the poor, and Dr. Montague Kern, another political scientist, found that the combination worked well.
 
Effective Commercials
 "The men in our focus groups tended to respond to the economic proposals and to his promise of welfare reform," she said, "while the women responded more to promises of providing better health care and education. His ad showing him with a family that couldn't get health insurance was very effective. When you combine the message he got across with the good political organization he built, you've got a powerful force."
Mr. Clinton also seemed to benefit from the unprecedented number of nationally televised debates this campaign season. ABC, NBC, PBS and CNN each carried one, and there were a half dozen others on local television and the C-Span public-affairs cable channel.
It is difficult to gauge the impact of debates during the primaries. Although this year's attracted millions of viewers -- the one on ABC got a larger audience than the "Tonight Show" during that time slot -- these viewers tend to be political junkies who already have opinions about the candidates.
But then, these political junkies also tend to have a disproportionate influence on primary elections, particularly when the turnout is as low as it was this year, and they apparently liked Mr. Clinton's polite, articulate style in the debates. According to exit polls in New Hampshire, Colorado, Illinois and Michigan, voters who listed the candidates' performance in the debates as a major factor in their decision were more likely than other voters to favor Mr. Clinton.
What seems to have distinguished Mr. Clinton most was his steady performance through all the debates and all the campaign.
"This campaign wasn't won by a dramatic moment on the airwaves," said Leslie Dach, the communications director for the 1988 Dukakis campaign. "Inside the Beltway the most talked-about ad was the one that didn't work, the one with Bob Kerrey in front of a hockey net. What mattered was that Bill Clinton stuck to his guns and his message about the economy. He wasn't fazed, even in adversity, and he did everything with a smile."

HEADLINE: New York Tourism Supported

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
Tourism will continue to be a growth industry for New York City through the end of the decade, a yearlong study commissioned by the New York City Convention and Visitors Bureau says. But it adds that growth could be stifled by high taxes as well as by public and private indifference.
The 62-page study, titled "New York Tourism 2000" and released yesterday, was prepared by Hunt & Hunt, an international tourism industry consulting organization, under guidelines developed by 21 New York tourism and community leaders. 
 New York's 25 million tourists in 1990, including 5.6 million foreign visitors, generated more than 124,000 jobs, or about 3.5 percent of the city's total employment. "Without these visitor-supported jobs," the study says, "New York City's 1990 unemployment rate of 6.8 percent would have stood at approximately 10.1 percent." It said tourist spending should reach $16.5 billion in the year 2000, 71 percent higher than in 1990, and generate $825 million in city taxes and $660 million for the state.
But because tourism is discretionary, the study warns, New York could suffer from the perception that it is expensive and dangerous. In fact, the city ranked 30th in the F.B.I.'s total crime index in 1990, it said, and its visitors bureau should do more to correct the false impression. And New York's reputation as expensive would be reduced if New York State repealed its recent 5 percent occupancy tax on rooms costing $100 or more. Pointing out that the tax falls most heavily New York City hotels, the study calls it punitive and counterproductive.
 
Marketing Neighborhoods
 The report also recommends establishing an official tourism policy at both the state and city levels, and encouraging the development and marketing of neighborhoods throughout the five boroughs. Last Wednesday, the city announced a $250,000 program of matching grants to enable community groups in each borough to promote tourism in their neighborhoods.
The study also recommended that the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center explore ways to accommodate additional conventions and trade shows, which draw a high percentage of overnight visitors, rather than hold so high a percentage of public shows, which attract local visitors who use fewer hotel rooms and spend less money.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: Coaches Howard and Foote Offer Advice With a Capital Hey!;
For the Yanks, A Hitting Tutor Who's a Jolly Good Bellow

BYLINE: By MICHAEL MARTINEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.

 BODY:
The voice bellows from everywhere: from the coaches' room in the clubhouse every morning, from the back field beyond the left-field fence at Fort Lauderdale Stadium, from the covered batting cages near the grandstand. It's always there.
Frank Howard, the Yankees' ubiquitous hitting coach, is the first to arrive and the last to leave each day at spring training. He will hit fungoes until it is too dark to see the ball. He will offer advice and counsel to every last hitter in camp, from Andy Stankiewicz to Kevin Maas. He will never stop moving, consoling, teaching. 
 "Hondo gets instant respect and earned respect," Buck Showalter, the rookie Yankee manager, said not long ago. "He has a high level of intensity, great work habits, loyalty and a big heart. I've never seen a man stay focused for nine innings like he does."
Howard, known throughout the clubhouse as Hondo, seems focused every waking moment. There is no wasted time, no unnecessary talk, no uncertainty about what is happening -- only the basso-profundo voice directing things.
"We call it Camp Hondo," outfielder Bernie Williams said of Howard's back-field workouts, far from the view of spring-training fans. "It's hectic, but it's enjoyable."
The 54-year-old Howard is beginning his 34th year in baseball. Half of that time, he has been a coach. As a player, he hit 382 homers, playing most of his career with the Los Angeles Dodgers and the Washington Senators. As a coach, he is known as much for his enthusiasm as his work ethic.
Some young players, given the option of making a three-hour bus ride for an exhibition game or staying behind to work out with Howard, prefer the bumpy trip.
"I treat them all the same," Howard said of the players in camp. "My philosophy -- and they know it -- is that I understand if they make a mistake because I probably made the same one. If they give us a good effort and are dedicated, we've got to do everything we can to help them. If they don't, then we've got to make them aware that there are 20 million kids who want to play major league baseball, but only 600 of them do."
Howard's primary theories about the game come from the old school, but he also concedes that modern technology has made the game better. His only complaint: too much practice, not enough games.
"Sometimes," he said, "we get into a category of what I call practice players. Today's kids work longer, have better instruction, better training facilities and equipment than we ever had the luxury of having. What they don't have is the chance to play enough ball games so they can learn how to handle pressurized situations.
"I've felt that all my life. I believe in instruction, but if it were up to me, I'd have a kid playing a doubleheader every day."
 
A Man of Imposing Size
 There is also this about Howard that commands respect: his size. He is 6 feet 8 inches tall and weighs 300 pounds, but he calls himself "a pussycat."
"People say, 'You're such an intimidating force because of your size,' but it doesn't even enter my mind," he said. "Intimidation is just a word. I call it being a big leaguer. It's more than ability; it's a state of mind."
In his time, there has been a scuffle here and there. As a Met coach, Howard once lifted Craig Swan by his lapels after the pitcher berated Manager George Bamberger on a charter flight. "You shouldn't be talking that way to the skipper," Howard gently scolded Swan, whose feet dangled above the ground.
"I've seen Hondo mad maybe twice," Showalter said. "It's scary."
Showalter also remembers coming to the clubhouse early one day last season thinking the place was empty. It wasn't. Soon enough, he heard the clanging of weights nearby. He peeked around a corner, saw Howard seated, half-clothed and covered with perspiration, pumping a pair of dumbbells.
"He was saying: 'C'mon, Hondo, be the best you can be. Work harder, harder. Be the best coach you can be,' " Showalter recalled. "I just sat there for a half hour, listening and watching him."
And loyal: When Dallas Green was dismissed as manager in 1989, Howard, the hitting coach, was offered a chance to become the manager at Class AAA Columbus by George Steinbrenner. Howard refused, even though the decision left him unemployed. "I came to the dance with the man," he said of Green, "I'm going to leave with him."
 
INSIDE PITCH
 ANDY STANKIEWICZ hit a grand slam homer in the eighth inning to lift the Yankees to a 13-10 victory Saturday over Minnesota in a split-squad game at Joe Robbie Stadium in Miami. The 27-year-old Stankiewicz has never played in the majors. Starter ED MARTEL tossed four impressive innings, but is a long shot to make the rotation. DON MATTINGLY took an airplane flight from Miami to Tampa after the game, avoiding a four-hour bus trip.

HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
Making the Islanders Their Business

BYLINE: By JOE LAPOINTE

 BODY:
The four investors about to take control of the Islanders do not have extensive backgrounds in professional hockey management, but all have learned about the sport in peripheral ways.
If their partial purchase of the troubled franchise is approved, as expected, this week, they will attempt to turn around a sports business that has plunged in less than a decade from one of the most successful in the sport to one of the worst managed in the front office and least effective on the ice. 
 All four executives-in-waiting say they are aware of what is wrong and are eager to begin the process of change.
Although novices in the hockey business, they are successful in the world of finance, well-grounded on Long Island and at least acquainted with the world's fastest team sport and how it is presented at Nassau Coliseum.
Here are quick introductions:
*Robert Rosenthal, who will become one of two co-chairmen, lived in a Westbury apartment building with several members of the expansion Islanders in the early 1970's. Back then, he sat in season-ticket seats behind the penalty box and occasionally debated the rules with Philadelphia's Dave Schultz, the biggest and baddest of the Broad Street Bullies. "I have never been known for not being vocal," Rosenthal said in a recent interview. "That's why they made the glass higher behind the penalty box. To protect me."
*Jerome Grossman, who will become the new team president, learned the sport at the amateur level by driving his child to practices and games at all hours of the day and night. His offspring still plays occasionally: She is a defensewoman.
*Stephen Walsh, set to become the other co-chairman, is the son of a Ranger fan and is a former ticket buyer at the Coliseum who perceives things through the eyes, and ears, of a customer. He wants to change plenty of things, starting with the organ music, which, he said, has always "bugged" him. "It sounds like I'm at a roller-skating rink," he said. "I want it different, more upbeat. More fun. I don't want to listen to 1940 organ music, plain and simple."
*Ralph Palleschi, who will become the executive vice president, is learning the business from the ground floor, literally. Last weekend, when he and his partners posed for photographs in front of one goal at the Coliseum, Palleschi was impressed by the size of the playing surface from that perspective. "I never realized how long the ice was," he said.
All four should learn plenty of things in the very near future. Although they are believed to be buying only 10 percent of the team from John O. Pickett Jr., they have options to buy up to 50 percent. Most important, all parties say, they will have full control to operate a franchise that needs direction and focus.
A decade ago, in the era from 1980 through 1983, the Islanders won the Stanley Cup in four consecutive seasons and sold virtually every ticket for every game. They were considered a model franchise for a league on the rise. And the Long Island economy was booming.
This season, if they don't make the playoffs, they will have missed post-season play in three of the last four springs, the time of year when most franchises make their biggest profits. Their attendance average is less than 10,000 a game, the lowest in the league. Their planned new practice headquarters remains only partially built and stalled by financial problems.
The team's radio network barely covers parts of recession-plagued Long Island and is impossible to hear in some sections of the primary market. Star players like Bryan Trottier, Pat LaFontaine and Brent Sutter have left the roster under less than happy circumstances. Around the troubled league, people ask, "What's wrong with that franchise?"
"We view the Islanders as an under-utilized, under-managed business franchise, brand name, whatever you want to call it, with a great recognition factor and a great market," Walsh said. "We know we have a good opportunity here. All business goes through cycles. The Long Island economy is going to come back. Maybe the resurgence of the Islanders will be coincidental with the resurgence of Long Island."
Certainly the new bosses know plenty about economics. Rosenthal and Palleschi are former executives with Entenmann's, the bakery, and now operate First Long Island Investors. Walsh and Grossman have Wall Street backgrounds and currently play major roles with Walsh, Greenwood & Company, an investment firm.
The four came together last summer after Walsh and Rosenthal played golf at a country club and began talking, as businessmen will, about deals. All four live on Long Island and are involved in many charities and civic institutions. They say their stewardship will be a contrast to that of Pickett, who lives in Florida and is rarely seen or heard from.
"We are very much aware of the past reputation of the ownership being inaccessible," Rosenthal said. "We are four Long Island business people and four Long Island fans rolled into one. We are going to be energetic, enthusiastic and we recognize there is a big challenge for us to conquer."
As president, Grossman will work out of Nassau Coliseum and handle the day-to-day operations of the club. Palleschi will handle the financial affairs. Walsh and Rosenthal will concentrate on the involvement of fans and businesses from the Island community, a far-flung and diverse collection of quaint villages and modern subdivisions and farms and mansions and shopping malls and often-clogged traffic arteries. The executives plan to meet at least once a week.
"The Long Island community is a difficult community to put your arms around because of the geography of Long Island," Rosenthal said. "We embrace Long Island, and Long Island embraces the Islanders."
Bill Torrey, currently the chairman of the board and general manager, has been asked to remain as general manager, but hasn't given the new group his response. Because the general manager will name the coach, this leaves the future of Coach Al Arbour in question.
In interviews last week, the new executives all said they approve of Torrey's trade-based overhaul of the roster this season and they said they have faith in both Torrey and Arbour.
The details of their financial deal with Pickett are also somewhat murky. Neither Pickett nor his new partners would name the percentage of the team being sold or the amount of money changing hands. The N.H.L.'s president, John Ziegler, through a spokesman, Gary Meagher, said last week that the piece is 10 percent. In that most hockey franchises are valued between $50 million and $100 million, a 10 percent share of the Islanders should be worth between $5 million and $10 million.
In addition to the four executives, there are an unspecified number of other investors but they have no control of team operations.
Pickett, in a telephone interview from his home in Florida last week, said that "the new group has the right to buy up to 50 percent any time they want -- it's their timetable." Can the new partners go beyond 50 percent? Do they have first option to buy Pickett's remaining percentage if another buyer approaches him?
"We have a right to buy from him before he can sell to anyone else," Grossman said.
But doesn't Pickett, the majority owner, have final approval over the operating budget?
"There are certain things they would probably want to discuss with me," Pickett said, "but I want to stress that I can't think of a single thing I wouldn't want them to have free will in. If you don't do that, you might as well be there running it yourself."
 
Getting Started
 Islander executives of the future were in Chicago on Friday for what they hoped would be approval of the Board of Governors.
Because the players union set a March 30 strike deadline on Friday morning, the collective-bargaining crisis dominated discussion and partial transfer of Islander ownership was tabled until this week, Ziegler said, adding that the board liked the Islander proposal and that the delay in no way signaled disapproval.
In some ways, the new group is already behaving as if it is in control. Current employees are acting on "suggestions" from the new executives involving ticket prices for playoffs and promotions for later this month. The new executives say they will freeze most ticket prices, lower some others and consider plans for remodeling the Coliseum or for building a new arena.
Grossman has traveled with the team to road games on its chartered airplane and up the Coliseum stairs to interview fans in the back rows. He's been asking for their suggestions. They've been giving him an earful.

HEADLINE: HOME CLINIC;
Wall or Ceiling Projects Not for Inexperienced

BYLINE: By JOHN WARDE

 BODY:
INEXPERIENCE can be a harsh teacher, as when a seemingly straightforward project like remodeling a wall or ceiling by attaching paneling or new wallboard goes awry because of uneven surfaces underneath.
Unless the surfaces for new wall and ceiling materials are flat and smooth, and either plumb in the case of walls or level in the case of most ceilings, panels will not fit squarely, nor will they mask the bumps and hollows they are intended to conceal. 
 The solution is to install a grid of narrow wood strips called furring strips against the existing surface before attaching the new material. During construction, wood wedges called shims are placed behind parts of the grid to create a fastening surface.
To determine the need for furring strips, assess the surface. Check first for flatness by stretching a string across the surface between diagonal corners and between the sides and ends at several places.
Hold or attach identical small blocks of wood beneath the ends of the string to keep them away from the surface by a uniform amount. Note the distance between the surface and the string in each position.
If the distance varies less than a quarter-inch along the string's length, consider the surface flat. If further tests reveal no other flaws, furring strips are probably unnecessary, except to provide a fastening surface.
Check walls to see whether they are plumb. Hold a carpenter's square against the corners -- the square should fit if the corners form right angles -- and use a plumb bob to determine whether the walls are vertical. Hang the bob from the ceiling to the floor from a point about an inch from one wall. Measure between the string and the wall at the ceiling and floor. If the measurements are the same, that section of the wall is vertical. Perform the process also in the middle of the wall and near the other end.
Check ceilings to see whether they are level. That can be done at the same time that they are checked for flatness by attaching a line level, a small vial containing a bubble, to the string. If the ceiling is level, the bubble will be centered in the vial during all measurements.
Be practical when evaluating both tests. Generally, installing furring strips over a flat surface is worth the effort only when surfaces are out of alignment by more than three-eighths of an inch.
Furring strips for frame walls and ceilings usually consist of 1 x 3-inch lumber. Economy grade is usually adequate, provided the boards are not warped.
On walls, the principal or longest strips of a grid are customarily fastened to lie perpendicular to the long edges of the paneling or wallboard sheets they will support. The strips are spaced so that their centerlines are 16 inches apart, and extra strips are added, if necessary, to lie beneath the sheets' long edges. With standard sheets, which are four feet wide, extra strips should not be needed.
On ceilings, the principal strips are perpendicular to the joists at intervals of 12 inches between the strips' centerlines. If plumbing or wiring is attached underneath joists, a double layer of strips can be installed. That will lower the finished ceiling a few inches.
That is done by attaching the strips of the first layer to the joists, but spaced so that the centerlines are 24 to 32 inches apart. Then the strips of the second layer are attached across the first group, parallel to the joists, at intervals of 12 inches between centerlines.
With all arrangements, the grid is completed by attaching short strips perpendicular to the principals to support the sheets' remaining edges. Short strips can also be added elsewhere for additional support.
Start installing furring strips by attaching a principal strip across one end of the surface. Use pairs of drywall screws at least two inches long to anchor the strip temporarily to the studs or joists behind it. Leave room between the screws in each pair so that their heads will not interfere with the fasteners to be driven into the middle of the strips to secure the new wall or ceiling material.
Use a long level or a straight-edged board to make sure that the strip is flat. Loosen screws to straighten the strip wherever necessary, and insert shims to fill all gaps between the strip and the surface at stud or joist locations.
For shims, use pairs of wedge-shaped cedar-shingle scraps. To install a shim, slide a pair of shingles toward each other from opposite sides of the strip so that their tips overlap between the strip and the surface.
Install and shim another strip the same way across the opposite end of the surface, and a third one near the middle. Determine the exact location according to the centerline spacings for all the strips. Repeat the tests for flatness, plumb and level, and adjust all three strips until the surface they form is acceptable.
Finish fastening the strips and use them as guides for adding the remaining strips, the principal ones first and then short strips. Be sure to fasten strips around the perimeters of windows and doorways.
When installing a double layer of furring, use just principal strips for the first layer. Install the short strips and extras with the second layer.
For furring masonry, 2 x 2-inch strips and masonry nails are recommended. Cover the surface first with a vapor barrier of plastic sheeting or liquid and then mount the strips. But adjust and test their alignment before driving fasteners completely home.

LENGTH: 460 words

HEADLINE: End Kashmir's Misery

 BODY:
When imperial Britain agreed to partition India and Pakistan, some 562 princely rulers had to decide which country to join. The Maharajah of Kashmir, a Hindu, couldn't make up his mind. As he hesitated, his predominantly Muslim subjects rebelled in favor of Pakistan and their cause was taken up by invading Muslim irregulars.
This marked the beginning of a bitter conflict that has bred wars between Pakistan and India, and brought misery to the people of Kashmir. In a transformed world, both countries would benefit from a solution, preferably under U.N. auspices. Washington could help by discreetly nudging two proud countries toward settlement. 
 India's claim to Kashmir stems from its military rescue of the Maharajah, who then agreed to Kashmir's accession to India. Lord Mountbatten, India's Governor General, said that when order was restored, Britain hoped that a plebiscite would determine Kashmir's future.
In 1948 India promised a vote, but never delivered. Three wars and innumerable skirmishes have been fought over Kashmir, whose western third has come under Pakistani control while the rest of the old princely realm forms Jammu and Kashmir, India's only state with a Muslim majority. Periodically, Kashmir erupts into violence.
Islamabad and New Delhi accuse each other of fomenting terrorism, abusing human rights and flouting world law. As the dispute sputters on, Kashmiris endure mass arrests, diminished citizenship and economic collapse. Srinagar and the Vale of Kashmir, once magnets for tourism, have become forlorn zones of strife.
India insists that a solution lies in direct talks with Pakistan, without U.N. involvement. It no longer holds to its old promise to let Kashmiris decide their own future in a plebiscite. That's no longer necessary, New Delhi argues, because Kashmiris can vote in local elections and because a defeated Pakistan signed a 1972 accord in Simla committing the two countries to a bilateral settlement.
For its part, Pakistan wants a settlement based on U.N. declarations calling for a plebiscite. But it would not be a true plebiscite. Pakistan would limit Kashmiris to choosing between it and India. This ignores a surge of support for independence. If Pakistan is serious about self-determination, then six million Kashmiris deserve that choice, too. And if India is serious about seeking a permanent seat on the Security Council, why scorn the U.N. in its own region?
In a changing world, the Kashmir dispute belongs higher on the agenda. The old security concerns that drove India toward Moscow, and Pakistan toward Washington and Beijing, have lost their intensity. India, as the paramount power in the subcontinent, would enhance its stature by moving to a U.N. settlement.

GRAPHIC: Map of Kashmir and Jammu.

HEADLINE: Where Was the Crime in House Bank Affair?;
Too Many Privileges

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The so-called bank scandal involving overdrafts by members of the House of Representatives would not be significant if it did not taunt us with the reminder of the much wider problem of elected officials who horde privileges for themselves that they deny the average citizen, whose interest they claim to represent. 
 Free short-term loans from the House bank pale beside the costs and insult of their first-class travel, personal use of Congressional staffs, entertainment excesses and gifts from powerful influentials who seek favor.
But what galls many of us most is that members of Congress, along with the President and ranking figures in his Administration, all reserve one of the most enviable and expensive perquisites conceivable. These Government elites enjoy superb, cost-free, health care from one of the finest systems of socialized medicine in the world, while fiercely opposing it for massive numbers of Americans who face a frightening health care crisis.
This cornucopia of privileges for top Government officials increasingly insulates them from the realities of American life and is fast disqualifying them from representing us. We implore Congress -- and the President -- to join the rest of us in the personal sacrifice needed during this recession. For the poor and newly unemployed this is more accurately a depression.
 
EDWARD H. PEEPLES
Richmond, March 13, 1992
 
The writer is associate professor of preventive medicine at the Medical College of Virginia.

HEADLINE: Is the Recession Over?

 BODY:
Retail sales are up. Industrial production is up. So are housing starts, non-farm employment, exports and business confidence. Even department store sales in the New York area are finally turning around.
At the same time, inflation, interest rates, new jobless claims and personal debt are all, gratifyingly, down. 
 Is the recession over? Finally, after 19 months, the answer appears to be yes.
But before anyone gets too excited, a dose of reality. The difference between recession and recovery may be little more than a statistical technicality. The economy may not be falling, but neither is it rising very quickly.
The outlook is for more of the same: slow, perhaps even glacial, improvement. Unemployment may continue to rise for three to six months, perhaps longer. And there is always the possibility that the recovery will abort.
Still, moving up beats moving down. There is light, if only dim, at the end of the economic tunnel.
The U.S. economy has been wallowing in recession for more than a year and a half and stagnating for about three years. Output hasn't fallen very much -- the drop has been only half the size of recent recessions. But it has sent more than a million Americans onto the jobless rolls.
Only last fall did the Federal Reserve Board turn from mouse to tiger -- pushing down interest rates in order to jump-start the economy. In February the Fed followed with a cut in reserve requirements, which freed banks to lend more money.
Last spring, the economy also ticked up, only to turn back down again during the summer. There's no guarantee that a 1992 recovery won't also abort. But that's unlikely because the Fed's new policy should keep sectors that depend on low-interest loans -- residential housing, consumer durables and corporate investment -- healthy. Another optimistic sign: Inventories are low, so as retail sales pick up, stores will have to send orders to factories to speed up production.
Not everything is rosy. Robert Gordon, an economics professor at Northwestern University and a member of the committee that determines the stop and start dates of recessions for the National Bureau of Economic Research, says one-third of the economy will continue to stagnate. Commercial real estate is dead; until vacant office space is filled, there won't be new construction. And the defense industry is headed down, fast. Even exports -- which have been the main source of new jobs during the last few years -- will probably slow because the Japanese and German economies are running into trouble.
Mr. Gordon predicts that output will grow by 2 or 3 percent a year. That is about half the rate of a normal recovery and barely enough to keep unemployment steady. Indeed, Mr. Gordon expects unemployment to hover around 7 percent, then fall by the middle of next year to around 6.5 percent -- more than one percentage point above the rate that prevailed before the recession.
The best guess is that unemployment will stay steady or edge a bit higher because companies are unlikely to make permanent hires until they're convinced recovery is for real. When might that be? Perhaps early fall. Just in time to affect the November elections, one way or the other.

HEADLINE: Do Teachers Lead The Greediest?

 BODY:
Each year, newspapers run a section on the "neediest" people in the community. I propose an additional list of the "greediest" people. Until recently that dubious honor would have gone to the top political people in the Nassau government. But now they have accepted 5 percent cuts in salary (it should have been at least 10 percent, but let's be thankful for small favors), and the teachers and administrators in our school districts are winning the title of "greediest" hands down.
We have been hit with a severe recession. Woolworth's, Grumman, Newmark & Lewis, General Motors, Pan-Am, Macy's, etc., have been closing shop or reducing operations and firing people left and right. Many local stores on Long Island, unable to keep up with the unending tax increases and reduced sales, have gone out of business and lie empty. 
 But the teachers and administrators, who have constantly demanded and gotten annual raises of two and a half times the increases in living costs, laugh at the unfortunates and insist they will accept no cuts in salaries and benefits, no freezes, only more and more increases. It has been shown that school districts on Long Island have half the number of pupils they used to have, yet spend twice as much and keep the same number of administrators and the same inefficient number of small districts.
Public-school teachers who have reached the 15th step now get approximately $77,000 a year in salary and benefits. They enjoy short workdays, are on the job only nine and a half months a year and thus earn $2,160 for every week they work. Many end up with more than $77,000 and also receive handsome extra fees from students from their building whom they tutor after school.
It was therefore, unconscionable of John F. DeGregorio, regional director of the New York State United Teachers' Union, to state that teachers have the right to keep seeking large increases because "they are not going to take the position of subsidizing the place they work." ["School Boards Face Hostility as Teachers Seek Raises" Feb. 2.] Mr. DeGregorio is standing truth on its head.
It is the hard-pressed taxpayers who have been subsidizing well-heeled teachers. Furthermore, when he says that the "possibility of strikes always exists," he neglects to mention that in return for receiving all kinds of special privileges, the teachers' unions accepted the state law making strikes by them illegal. They flout the law by frequently threatening to strike, thereby cowing P.T.A. people to support them, lest they take it out on their children.
 
MARTIN DAVIS
Woodmere

HEADLINE: Garbage Could Raise Taxes 40 Percent

 BODY:
"Soaring Garbage Fees Plague Town Officials" [March 1] accurately reflects the dilemma of towns' attempting to satisfy New York State mandates that balloon local taxes.
New York State law essentially says that towns must dispose of garbage in one or more high-tech ways or ship it out of state. The usual high-tech solution is incineration, with the residual ash going to a double-plastic-lined landfill. As your article points out, that costs about $500 per household each year. Shipping garbage across the United States is no solution. It is expensive, environmentally irresponsible and will not be tolerated for long by the importing states. 
 Imagine what a $500-per-household tax increase will do to a small rural town like Southold. The town tax bill will increase by 40 percent. Could Southold make some wise choices and do it more cheaply? Not likely, with a small dispersed population, no economies of scale and remote distance to garbage plants elsewhere on the island. Everyone acknowledges that Long Island taxes are already among the highest in the nation and driving out large numbers of our residents. Certainly they are a major deterrent to the relocation of new businesses and residents to our towns.
And what will we get for this record 40 percent tax increase? In the case of Southold, there is no benefit at all. The town recently completed a detailed D.E.C.-authorized study of the ground-water leaching from our open landfill and found no significant contamination. Why require a municipality to spend $500 per household per year in the name of environmental protection when there is no significant environmental benefit?
 
THOMAS WICKHAM
Councilman, Town of Southold

HEADLINE: Getting to Work: Other Views

 BODY:
"Getting to Work Will Never Be the Same" does not note a critical additional option open to many employers, and even to some of their employees. Leave.
Environmental pollution most assuredly is a critical issue. But those planning to solve the problem must take into account this opt-out option. 
 Furthermore, as we proceed in the name of free trade to open our markets to goods and services from all countries, regardless of their environmental practices, we inevitably encourage the opt-out option of importing rather than producing domestically. Importing is not confined to manufactured goods, but is spreading now to services as well.
Data can be manipulated as easily in, and transmitted from, far-off places as here at home. No commuting subsidies are required for workers in Mexico, India, Ireland or the Caribbean. Companies forced to deal with this here may well find this a significant addition to their cost of production calculations, especially when measured against their offshore competitors.
One hopes that those planning our noncommuting future recognize that unemployment also has a quality-of-life cost. Telecommuting sounds good when the commuters are local people working at home. How good will it sound to New Jersey when the commuters are offshore and pay no taxes?
 
SETH M. BODNER
Summit
