HEADLINE: A $78 Million Year: Steve Ross Defends His Paycheck

BYLINE: BY ROGER COHEN; Roger Cohen is the European economic correspondent of The New York Times, based in Paris.

 BODY:
Steve Ross looks like a humbled man. Slumped in a leather chair, the chairman and co-chief executive officer of Time Warner, the world's largest media and entertainment company, winces as he reaches for a glass of water. His smile is wan, his jowls sag, his once athletic frame appears bloated. "It's been a rough couple of years," he says in a voice that sometimes descends to a Brandoesque murmur. "I've been hurt tremendously."
The physical pain Ross feels is concentrated, excruciatingly, in his back. Every movement is cumbersome; rising to his feet an intricate maneuver. Although his office, with its paintings by Mark Rothko and Arshile Gorky, suggests a life of sumptuous ease, Ross's appearance amounts to eloquent testimony that money is not everything. 
 In fact, although he is not yet aware of this, his backache is caused in part by cancer. A prostate tumor has been pressing on his spine. Indeed, this rare interview last November in his 29th-floor office overlooking Rockefeller Plaza will be his last before doctors order him to undergo chemotherapy and confine him to his homes on Park Avenue and in East Hampton, L.I.
From Ross's words, it is clear his physical distress, while severe, is only part of a deeper pain. At the age of 64, a time when most self-made millionaires are looking back in satisfaction at their achievements, Ross -- or Steve, as he prefers to be known -- seems far from a man at peace. "I've never known him so upset and frustrated," says an old friend, Gershon Kekst, who owns a public relations company. "The cancer and chemotherapy are nothing compared to the way he feels about the abuse he's suffering."
For Ross, once the debonair darling of Wall Street and Hollywood, the trouble began more than two years ago, after he agreed to let Time Inc. pay $14 billion for Warner Communications, the company he had built over three decades from a Manhattan funeral-parlor-cum-rent-a-car business into a global entertainment conglomerate. The last big deal of the 80's, the Time Warner merger was supposed to be the career capper for Ross, a man who grew up in a poor Jewish family in Brooklyn. The deal placed him at the head of a $12 billion company, with assets ranging from Time magazine to Batman. Ross, it appeared, was going to be the king of the Brave New World of global communications.
But instead of crowning his life's work, the merger proved a morass. It saddled Ross with myriad new problems -- not the least of which was how to deal with the $11.4 billion of debt incurred by Time to complete the transaction. More personally, it burdened him with a co-chief executive, N. J. (Nick) Nicholas Jr. of Time, whom Ross did not particularly like from the outset and later grew to distrust. Only after two trying years -- and with the threat of his death from cancer hanging over the company -- was Ross able to engineer an extraordinary boardroom shake-up last month, ousting the secretive, bean-counting Nicholas and replacing him with Gerald M. Levin, a more accessible and extroverted executive who had been Time Warner's vice chairman.
"With Steve's cancer, we all felt, my God, what if we're left with Nicholas?" says one Time Warner executive who's worked under Ross for a decade. "In two years here, I'd seen Nicholas for 20 minutes. None of us knew what he was doing."
Yet Ross's problems went far beyond Nick Nicholas. While the Time Warner deal was conceived in the gung-ho 80's, it was born at a moment when debt and greed were going out of fashion. As the deal drew increasing criticism, Ross, already one of the most famous chief executives in the country, found himself on the hot seat. He was vilified not only as America's leading symbol of lavish executive compensation and exploited shareholders, but also as the man who had demeaned an American institution, Henry R. Luce's Time Inc. Steve Ross joined Michael Milken and Ivan Boesky in the pantheon of avarice.
"I don't blame Ross as much as the Time board," says Andrew Heiskell, the company's former chairman. "But if I do blame him, it's for epitomizing the 80's disease that said money, money, money is the only thing that counts."
Ross seems weary. The tall, unfailingly ebullient, painstakingly coiffed corporate chieftain who steered Warner to so many years of remarkable growth is a different man. The eyes are plaintive. Some people who have spent long hours with him, and remain skeptical, warn of the "poor-Steve ploy." But as Ross awkwardly pulls his chair closer to the table in front of him, he seems sincere when he says: "When you're constantly attacked, you wanna go out and shoot yourself."
Shaking his head, he goes on: "There is malice and forethought in the inaccurate attacks on my compensation. Nobody wants to understand that the money was my reward for 30 years work at Warner. Still, given the value of these assets we've put together in Time Warner, you've just got to pay the piper."
With the $78.2 million he received in 1990 alone -- more than any other executive of a public company -- Ross can afford to pay several pipers. This sum included a one-time payment of $74.9 million for Ross's interests in Warner, but that fact tends to be glossed over. Coming shortly before 605 staff members of Time Warner's recession-hit publishing division were laid off last year, the payout made him a villain to many of his own employees. "Ross's 1990 pay was two and a half times the combined salaries of the people laid off," says Key Martin, president of the Newspaper Guild at Time Warner. "That's absurd."
"Steve's pay has become a lightning rod," says Reginald K. Brack Jr., the chairman of Time Inc. and the man who actually ordered the 605 layoffs. "It's hard to even fathom that kind of money."
The excoriation has been deeply wounding for Ross, a man far more accustomed to being hailed as a media visionary -- renowned for having bet on videos, MTV and Nickelodeon when most other corporate leaders thought cable was just a piece of thick wire.
Friends say Ross has taken the criticism especially hard because of a surprisingly strong need for affection. As one Time Warner board member puts it: "Steve wants to be loved and he's being hated." And Felix G. Rohatyn, a senior partner at Lazard Freres, the Wall Street investment bank, says: "Steve bleeds internally a lot, and takes criticism very hard while trying not to show it. But these are things that have affected his health."
Now spending most of his time at Cody House (Cody is Ross's nickname for his wife, Courtney Sale), a lovely but not extravagant home overlooking East Hampton's Georgica Pond, he has plenty of time to ponder these problems. In December, Ross's wife cut short a planned yearlong world tour with their 8-year-old daughter, Nicole, and returned home to care for him. A total of six chemotherapy sessions have been scheduled through the end of next month. "Chemo," Sale says, "is no picnic.
As Ross goes through this wrenching period of self-scrutiny, a number of questions are swirling around him and his empire. His critics say he is perhaps America's most greedy and manipulative businessman. His admirers say that, in the backlash against 80's excesses, he has been unfairly crucified for compensation due him in accordance with a basic precept of American capitalism: that the marketplace rewards merit. Which view is true?
The myth of Steve Ross's invincibility -- one of the business world's most enduring -- has taken a pummeling since the Time Warner merger in January 1990. Can Ross's ultimate deal, the creation of Time Warner -- a company that lost $326 million in the last two years and still groans under the weight of enormous debt -- be made to work over the long term? Finally, can Steve Ross, who suffered a serious heart attack in 1980, bounce back one more time?
BORN STEVEN JAY RECHNITZ IN THE WORKING-CLASS Flatbush section of Brooklyn, Steve Ross knew hardship early. Two years after Ross's birth in 1927, his father, a builder, lost his money in the Depression. Changing the family name to Ross in order to find work, his father struggled for the remaining years of his life. On his death bed, he summoned his son to offer a piece of advice: There are those who work all day; those who dream all day and never do a thing, and those who spend an hour dreaming before going to work to fulfill those dreams. "Go into the third category," his father said, "because there's virtually no competition."
This tale -- which bears the sentimental, almost schmaltzy, stamp of most Ross reminiscences -- has assumed a central place in his life story. "Dreamer" is the term Ross uses most often to describe himself, along with "visionary" and "risk taker." "If you're not a risk taker," Ross says, "you should get the hell out of business." Ross believes that the nuts-and-bolts manager, obsessed with the short term, is the bane of American business. This, in essence, was his problem with Nicholas.
Ross was street smart by an early age. At 8, he was carrying bags of groceries in exchange for a nickel. He would also borrow money from his father, walk 20 blocks to a supermarket selling cut-rate cigarettes by the carton and then resell the cigarettes to his father by the pack for a profit. "I think, subliminally, I learned a lot about expanding a business when I was very young," Ross says.
Entirely self-taught, Ross has never had much time for conventional management, and an aversion to administrative detail has persisted throughout his career. As one former employee notes, "I doubt that Ross could manage a candy store day to day."
A remarkable gift for numbers appears to have buttressed his swaggering, macro approach. Indeed, David Geffen, a former Ross protege who had a falling out with his boss in 1989 during negotiations over the value of the record business he'd built at Warner, describes talking numbers with Ross as being "about as evenly matched as playing tennis with Boris Becker."
Armed with these talents but scant higher education, Ross went to work for an uncle in Manhattan's garment district. He was penniless. But, at the age of 26, he married well. His wife -- the first of three -- was Carol Rosenthal, whose father, Edward, owned the Riverside Memorial Chapel, a successful funeral-parlor business.
According to a story that has become legendary in the business world, his wife's uncle, who provided limousines for funeral services, asked Ross to take a look at his limousine company, which was losing money. Ross went up to the Bronx and watched for a couple of days. "I saw the cars go out for the funerals at 7:30 in the morning and come back at 4 in the afternoon," Ross recalls. "And then I saw the cars sit there all night. So I called up Carey Limousine and asked: 'Suppose I could rent you limousines? Isn't your busiest time the evening, when people go to the theater?' "
An agreement was reached. The funeral limousines were rented out at night to Carey. It was the first of many deals for a man who would become widely known as a consummate deal maker. "Steve loves making deals," says Barbra Streisand, a longtime friend whose films have sometimes been produced by Warner, "whether with Time or bracelet makers in the Caribbean."
The ability to charm prospective business partners -- some say beguile and then skewer -- stayed with Ross. "He speaks softly, he's congenial," Geffen says. "But he's a killer who's happiest when taking your pants down."
Ross quickly applied his business gifts. In the late 50's, he started Abbey Rent-A-Car. Later, he added a parking-garage business called Kinney and an office-cleaning operation. The company went public in 1962. Renamed Kinney Service, this hybrid corporation, with its hodgepodge of businesses, had a market value of $12.5 million.
In this unlikely way was created the company that would become Warner Communications -- producers of Madonna, "Dirty Harry" and "J.F.K." But a look back at the way Kinney was run in 1962 offers important clues to Ross's future successes and difficulties.
Though a public corporation, Kinney was operated very much like a family company by a close-knit group of scrappy Jewish entrepreneurs. It was short on controls, long on trust and freewheeling ambition. The prevailing view, as Ross puts it, was that "errors of commission would not sink you, errors of omission might."
By 1966, Kinney had decided to expand into entertainment. A first step was the purchase in 1967 of the Ashley Famous talent agency, whose owner, Ted Ashley, was struck by one thing Ross said: "Get me in a room with somebody who wants to make a deal, and I'll find a way to make the deal."
He had the talent to do so. Ross was a brilliant head of Warner Communications Inc. -- as Kinney was renamed in 1972. Three years earlier, Ross had succeeded in buying the ailing Warner Brothers-Seven Arts studio and record business for about $400 million. After selling off the old Kinney businesses, Ross put good people in charge of his new media properties and let them run. By granting autonomy and implementing an incentive-based compensation system, he commanded loyalty in a fickle industry. Frank G. Wells, who worked as an executive at Warner in the 70's and is now president of Disney, recalls Ross giving him just one piece of advice: "Make your own mistakes and don't give me any surprises."
When movies flopped, Ross told his people not to worry: the next one would do better. He almost never interfered in the making of a film. When a huge blockbuster, like "Batman," came along, the bonuses were commensurately large. "Incentive compensation," Ross says, "is the most important thing in business."
Robert A. Daly, chairman of Warner Brothers, speaks to the point. "We'll kill for the company," he says, "because everybody is made to feel like principals, not employees." The results speak for themselves. For two decades, Warner has thrived, knowing only two management teams in all that time.
Ross loved working in what he saw as another "people industry." At funerals, he'd had to learn to deal with grief; in Hollywood, with the egos of stars.
Ross took a sugar daddy's delight in making his stars happy -- dispensing extravagant gifts and invitations to weekend trips on Warner planes to Warner villas in Acapulco or Aspen. It was all part of fostering what Warner President Terry Semel calls "the family atmosphere." With Ross seeing little of his own family (he and Carol, who had two children, were divorced in 1978), he seems to have grown increasingly commited to his extended family at Warner.
Jenette Kahn, editor in chief of Time Warner's DC Comics division, observes that "on notes from Steve, if he knows you, he will cross out 'Sincerely' or 'Best Regards' and put 'Much Love.' " Another woman who knows Ross well sees in him not only a need for affection but for something deeper -- love. She believes Ross, having struggled all his life with profound insecurities, has sought from professional relationships what he has not been able to get from personal ones. The photographs in Ross's office -- of the chairman with Dustin Hoffman and Steven Spielberg in Paris one hung-over Christmas morning, of his daughter Nicole posing with Barbra Streisand -- suggest a man whose identity is very much bound up with the friendship of the stars.
Spielberg, who describes Ross as "one of my greatest friends," is one of those who has enjoyed the use of the Acapulco villa. "Look," says Ross, "Spielberg goes down there on the company plane and wakes up in the middle of the night after a nightmare. He can't sleep, and in the morning he gets up and writes the script for 'The Goonies.' That's worth tens of millions to us."
But don't ask Ross how many corporate planes there are. "Jesus, that's a good question," he mutters. "I don't know. I think we've got seven, all over the lot."
Despite such haziness on the details, there can be little disputing that the Ross system has worked. A company worth $12.5 million in 1962 was sold to Time for $14 billion in 1990. Even Graef S. Crystal, a compensation expert who has been extremely critical of the size of Ross's pay, acknowledges that Warner has done better than 88 percent of companies over the last two decades.
It was not just Ross's way with talented people that propelled Warner. He also had a knack for seeing the growth potential in businesses long before others did. Warner bought into cable in 1971 -- when there was still much contempt for the new medium. Ross understood the possibilities of "narrow casting," of reaching target audiences through specialized programming. This was the thinking that led to the hugely successful MTV and Nickelodeon.
Robert J. Morgado, the chairman of the Warner Music Group, which Ross helped build into the world's largest record company, attributes much of this success to what he calls Ross's dependability. "You know there'll never be scapegoats," says Morgado. "He just wants to know, how do we fix things and move forward?"
 AT TIMES IN ROSS'S LIFE, there has been plenty to fix. He has a notable gift for complicating his existence by playing fast and loose with the truth. This gift is evident in such minor matters as mythologizing autobiographical details of his war record and "experiences" as a professional football player -- two points made by Richard M. Clurman in a recent critical book on Ross and the merger.
But there have also been matters of greater gravity. Ross has experienced two major disasters in his career. The first, known as the Westchester Premier Theater Affair, was a bribery and racketeering scandal involving Warner officers and close friends. The second was the off-the-cliff collapse of the company's Atari video-games business. In both cases, Ross was guilty, at the very least, of misjudgment and negligent management.
"Atari," Felix Rohatyn says, "showed serious weakness in Warner's management structure. Ross was too trusting of the people around him. He did not want to impose controls."
Both problems hit Ross in the early 80's -- a time when he was recovering from a heart attack and in the midst of a bitter divorce from his second wife, Amanda Burden. Nothing in Ross's life had provided stronger proof of his heady social ascent than his marriage to Burden, the daughter of Barbara (Babe) Paley, the second wife of the late CBS chairman, William S. Paley. But the 16-month union was apparently based on little more than a fleeting infatuation.
Emanuel Gerard, Warner's former co-chief operating officer, remembers the whole period as "horrendous. Ross was like a rat in a hole." Ross had good reason to feel cornered. In the Westchester theater case, two Warner officials were indicted for their part in a racketeering scheme involving a mob-connected theater in Tarrytown, N.Y. One Warner officer, Solomon Weiss, was convicted and received a sentence of five years community service and a fine of $58,000. The other, Jay Emmett, who pleaded guilty in exchange for his cooperation, received a suspended sentence. At the time, some observers, including the chief prosecutor, Nathaniel H. Akerman, contended that the two men had taken the fall for their boss, but this allegation was never substantiated.
"I knew nothing about Westchester," Ross insists today. "The first thing I did when I heard about it was report it to the lawyers and outside directors on the audit committee." He pauses, then adds: "I haven't the slightest idea why the innuendo keeps coming back. It hurts me, because I live by my integrity."
Ross was also roundly criticized for his role in the Atari debacle. Acquired for a song in 1976, Atari video games would experience a rise and fall of Hula-Hoop-esque proportions. In a few tumultuous days in December 1982, the precipitous decline of Atari's business in the face of new video-game competition wiped out nearly 50 percent of Warner's share value and ultimately cost the company more than $1 billion. But Gerard, the Warner official overseeing Atari at the time, was not fired. "Ross's way of dealing with things tends to be not to deal with what is unpleasant," says Gerard, who left the company in 1984 of his own volition. "Mr. Tough Guy, he's not."
A real Mr. Tough Guy was soon to appear on the Warner horizon. He was Herbert J. Siegel, the chairman of Chris-Craft Industries -- a no-nonsense executive whowould eventually threaten Ross's hold on the company. When Rupert Murdoch made a run at Warner in late 1983, trying to buy cheap after the Atari-linked stock slump, Siegel had come to the rescue, acquiring about 20 percent. But once inside, Siegel went into a state of shock. "Atari was losing $1 million a day, including  weekends," he recalls. To the ultraconservative Siegel, the company seemed to be operating under "no controls and no desire to control."
Over the next five years, the differences between the two men intensified, pitting Ross's prodigality against Siegel's pay-as-you-go parsimony. The bickering continued until the merger with Time, when Siegel cashed in, making a profit of more than $2 billion. "My job is to build businesses," says Ross. "But to Siegel, a plane was lavish."
 THE ROSS-SIEGEL conflict foreshadowed the clash of corporate cultures that emerged soon after the merger was finalized. Nick Nicholas, Ross's new co-chief executive, was as uncomfortable as Siegel with Warner's free-spending, undisciplined ways. There was also a collision of styles between the low-key Ivy League Time-Incers (as they liked to be called) and the glitzy Warner executives.
Still, the deal looked good on paper. Warner's business was 40 percent international; Time's, just 9 percent. Warner had no magazines; Time Inc. had a 23-title stable, including People, Sports Illustrated and Time itself, the three biggest advertising draws in American publishing. Time Inc. had no music; Warner had the world's largest record business. Both were big in cable, a capital-intensive business that would be strengthened by joining forces.
From both sides, the deal seemed to make perfect sense. To J. Richard Munro, the former chief executive of Time Inc., it was a long-term way of protecting a publishing giant that enjoyed "a monopoly on print in a world going toward video and movies." To Ross, it provided further proof of his apotheosis. What Amanda Burden had been to the New York social scene, Time Inc. was to corporate America.
The corporate marriage, however, turned out little better than the personal one. Indeed, the two companies have yet to integrate. Fierce partisanship, a media recession, the Ross-Nicholas misalliance and the inherent difficulties of blending entertainment with journalism have all contributed to this impasse. While individual businesses have done well, the much vaunted concept of corporate synergy, repeated like a mantra by Time Warner executives, has proved empty. "There's been little merging of cultures," says Michael J. Fuchs, the head of HBO.
Nowhere have these problems been more apparent than in the issue of church and state -- the Lucian terms forever invoked by Time-Incers to describe the editorial and business sides of their operations and the sacred importance of keeping them separate. "We've had church and state up to here," says one Warner director, reflecting the exasperation of his colleagues at being repeatedly warned not to interfere in Time's editorial operations.
"At Warner, I never interfered on the artistic side, never saw a movie before it came out," Ross says. "Yet here I'm under these ludicrous attacks that I'll ruin church and state. With all this bull, I even feel apprehensive about going over there to the Time-Life Building." (Ross and other top executives are in the former Warner Building, renamed Time Warner, because, as Nicholas once explained, "We just couldn't rename the Time-Life Building.")
Ross has also been blamed -- unjustly, it appears -- for allegedly trying to influence coverage of stories in which he has a personal interest. Last May, when the compensation expert Graef Crystal encountered problems with his annual chart in Fortune detailing how much chief exeuctives are paid, he assumed the objections were coming from Ross. Only later did he hear that the source was Nicholas, who apparently wanted his 1990 pay -- estimated by Crystal at $17.5 million -- downplayed. In the end, Ross led the compensation table, while Nicholas's pay package was revised downward to $7.4 million and relegated to a footnote. "It was all about protecting Nick, who did not want to look like a big pig," says Crystal, who quit in protest. (Nicholas denies any interference in the compensation table.)
Still, Ross is clearly ill at ease about being close to journalists. "I think it's very difficult now that I'm on the inside of a journalistic company to do a lot of other things," he says. "You're always being scrutinized. And you've got a lot of competitors out there."
Many journalists in the Time magazine group are equally uncomfortable about their proximity to Ross. They believe the magazines have gone soft, reduced to what Ross knows and loves: entertainment. "Jesus," says one senior Time writer on the West Coast. "We had a memo last year saying news pegs were no longer important for stories. We almost have to give excuses if we write a story with a peg."
Tensions between the two organizations have put a decided crimp in Ross's unorthodox style. At Warner, he could do what he liked. At Time Warner, however, the fact that his chief financial aide, Oded Aboodi, collects a Time Warner salary, while simultaneously charging the company fees and doing independent work, raises eyebrows. "I have a nonexclusive contract," Aboodi explains. "It's nice to have my health benefits and office paid by Time Warner."
Nicholas was unused to such cozy arrangements. His precision and thriftiness clashed with Ross's largesse and unstructured ways. When Nicholas reacted to the news of Ross's cancer last November by behaving as though he were the sole skipper of the ship, it was the final straw. As he had with Siegel, Ross was able to draw on the unshakeable loyalties of the old Warner board members to force Nicholas out.
The ouster dramatically demonstrated Ross's still formidable power. But the compensation issue still hovers over him, as it does, to a lesser degree, over the other key executives who profited so much from the merger. To a man, Ross, Munro, Nicholas and Levin all lay the blame for the opprobrium they've suffered at the door of Martin S. Davis, the chief executive of Paramount. Acknowledging that his rejection of Davis's bid of $200 a share for the company inspired an explosion of stockholder outrage, Munro still defends the move as being in the best interest of Time. "Martin Davis is not the kind of fellow I would have wanted to get into bed with," he says. "It's that cut and dried."
The rejection of the offer, however, was anything but cut and dried. The original plan for a debt-free merger of Time and Warner had to be scrapped, because it would have had to be put to a shareholders' vote; Time shareholders would no doubt have opted for the sale at the $200 price. Instead, in order to avoid the clutches of Paramount, Time was obliged to buy Warner for $14 billion and incurred $11.4 billion of debt. This heavy leveraging so depressed the stock and limited the corporation's maneuverability that, in the view of one Time Warner director, it delayed "for five years what would have been a company that had the financial freedom to really go global."
Since the price of Time Warner shares has been well below $200 the last couple of years and is now at about $105, Time shareholders, many of whom are employees, have been angry ever since the Paramount offer was rejected. Much of their anger has been directed at Ross.
"I can understand why Time shareholders are still miffed," says Gordon Crawford, a senior vice president of Capital Research, a California group heavily invested in Time Warner. "But they should not blame their management's decision on Ross. He took very good care of his Warner shareholders. He never turned down $200 a share from Parmount. It irritates the heck out of me."
It is true that Ross took care of Warner shareholders, who got $70 a share from Time. Some of them, who had been there since the days of Kinney, became rich. Ross himself received a total of $196 million -- to be paid out over several years. "Look," Ross says wearily, "without that phony $200 offer from Davis, my contract and all the other contracts would hardly have come under scrutiny. But people are frustrated, I understand that." Davis, for his part, insists his offer was bona fide. He describes the Time Warner management contracts that were part of the merger agreement as "a rape of shareholders."
One of the most generous contracts went to Munro, a major architect of the merger. He retired in May 1990, but is currently earning $750,000 a year plus bonuses for chairing the Time Warner executive committee, which meets no more than once or twice a year. "I'm embarrassed by the question of 'Should I be paid this money?' " Munro says. "This is a terrible moment to be quote overcompensated, when people are being fired."
Ross, seeking to vindicate himself and the deal, has "worked harder than ever before in his life," says one friend, the attorney Arthur Liman. For much of the last two years Ross has been on airplanes, criss-crossing the world in a search for strategic partners. Finally, last October, he secured a $1 billion investment from two Japanese companies, the electronics giant Toshiba and the C. Itoh & Company. A similar deal is supposedly in the works with a European partner.
And, after a bungled attempt at a rights offering featuring a coercive formula that only exacerbated shareholder enmity, the company did manage to raise $2.7 billion last year with a revised offering. All this has reduced the debt level to $8.7 billion. In the last couple of months, Time Warner stock has surged about $25.
But the question persists: Is Ross worth all that money? Ross and his aides point to the $135 million Steve Jobs made by selling his shares in Apple, the $327 million Lew Wasserman earned by selling MCA to Matsushita and to Bill Gates, who became a billionaire with the success of his software giant, Microsoft. Surely, they argue, Ross deserved his $78.2 million paycheck in salary and bonuses in 1990 -- $74.9 million of which represented a one-time payout for his interests in Warner, the company he had built from a hollow shell?
It is a specious argument, however. To call Ross, as he and many of those around him do, a "company founder," like Jobs or Gates, is not accurate; Warner Brothers Pictures was started in 1923 by Jack, Harry and Albert Warner. More importantly, most founders own a big chunk of stock in their companies, which assures their fortunes if their enterprises succeed but also puts them at great risk. Throughout his career, Ross never owned more than about 1 or 2 percent of the companies he ran.
"I was so busy, I never got round to it," Ross says. "I never looked after me all these years."
Ross did not exactly live like a pauper, however. During the early years at Warner, he had a salary of about $300,000 and lavish perks. It was not until the late 70's that Ross engineered the first of his multimillion-dollar annual contracts, but his conflict with Siegel in the 80's put these big payouts on hold. "When you finally have a partner who starts irritating the hell out of you," Ross says, "you start thinking, hey, I had better start planning my future financially."
To rectify this, Ross began to insist on increasingly elaborate contracts filled with bonuses, massive stock-option plans and other intricate financial devices. Apparently, Ross wanted it both ways. Such compensation packages, which cost nothing and carry no risk, and actual stock ownership, prey to the ups and downs of the market, are completely different.
As Graef Crystal points out: "The annoying part of owning stock is that if the market sinks, you lose real money." Indeed, if an Atari-like disaster had befallen Bill Gates at Microsoft, his fortune would have been decimated. But Ross never placed himself in harm's way. "Ross has tended to prefer a safety net under him when he walks across Niagara," Crystal says.
The most elaborate safety net of Ross's career was provided by the 55-page, 10-year Warner contract, which he signed in February 1987. That board-approved agreement was then adjusted to become his much-discussed contract at Time Warner. As Ross's aide Aboodi concedes, "This 1987 contract was an attempt to make up for lost time."
The 1987 contract guaranteed Ross, who at the time owned less than 1 percent of Warner, about $14 million a year over a decade -- provided Warner's stock and earnings rose 10 percent annually. Vehemently opposed by Siegel, it was a labyrinthine concoction of stock options, bonuses, deferred compensation schemes, golden parachutes and posthumous guarantees.
What ultimately grates on many people is that the $74.9 million payout Ross received in 1990 and the additional $121.1 million he will earn over the next several years was not in consideration of Warner stock he owned. Rather, it was a payment for Warner stock options and other performance bonuses he had secured in the controversial 1987 contract. Then, on top of all this, he won another 1.8 million stock options from the Time Warner merger agreement. These options are not worth anything now (their exercise price is $150) but may be worth a lot one day. (Stock options, usually granted for a 10-year period, lock in a share price. If the company's stock goes above that price, the owner of the stock options profits but loses nothing if the stock fails to reach that price.)
Again, Ross has set up a scenario with no downside risk and great upside potential. The spectacle of huge rewards without corresponding performance or risk appears to be feeding the current outcry against the excesses of executive compensation. Founders, dreamers, risk takers and visionaries make their fortunes a slightly different way from Steven J. Ross.
THE SETTING SUN sends a shimmering glow over the partially iced surface of Georgica Pond. From his house in East Hampton, Ross has a beautiful view across the water. Here, his illness has reunited him with his family. Everywhere, there are photos of his children and grandchildren. The air of tranquility is occasionally punctuated by a boistrous African parrot named Mini, who is wont to squawk obscenities.
"I'm a family person," Ross says. "I hate parties. That's another thing people misunderstand."
According to those close to him, the chemotherapy is going well. The first session halved the tumor's size. There is no indication that the cancer has spread. Ross feels terrible sometimes and his hair has fallen out. But, says his wife, Courtney, "he is very motivated to get well."
He remains confident about the future of Time Warner. Beneath the debt, Time Warner has a remarkable set of assets, which produced operating income of $2.3 billion last year. Interest payments, tax and other charges wiped all that out, leaving the company with a net loss of $99 million -- a sharp improvement, however, on the previous year.
As the debt load eases, the underlying earning power of the magazines, music, movies, programming and cable will likely prevail. And, with the departure of Nicholas and installation of the highly regarded Levin -- whose allegience is clearly to the joint enterprise -- it may finally prove possible to really merge the two companies.
Levin, an affable intellectual with a strong commercial sense, believes that Time Warner has a sure winner in cable. Penetration (of households with television sets), now at 60.6 percent, will go to 85 percent, he predicts. As that happens, cable advertising, now at about $2 billion a year, will grow rapidly. Seldom, according to Levin, has a business been such a mathematical certainty. Wall Street already appears to be taking note. "Time Warner is the best positioned of all international media companies," says Christopher Dixon, a media analyst at Paine Webber.
The company has also started putting a 150-channel interactive cable system into Queens that Ross believes is a precursor of a world in which the television set will become an all-purpose computer-cum-entertainment box. He contends that the new technology will ultimately encourage reading, but he gets lost as he tries to explain it. "So anyhow," he says, "getting back to . . . I don't even know what we were talking about . . . The written word is the key." Later, he says something "has just slipped my word." He often meanders in a disturbing way.
Ross is a sick man fighting for his life. He is due to leave the job of chief executive to Levin on July 24, 1994, but friends say he may do that sooner now that he has his man in place. Certainly, to continue the frenetic pace of the past two years seems unthinkable.
The task confronting him remains enormous. Warner was a morale-driven company, but today "morale is terrible," admits the publishing group chief, Brack. Before his removal, Nicholas insisted that Henry Luce would have been "ecstatic if he saw the company today." Few would agree.
Ross, ever mistrustful of journalists, has no one to blame but himself for now living in a house full of them. Before the Time Warner deal went through, his friend Liman had warned him: "We're not in our teens any more. You've got a great company with Warner. Do you really want this -- a co-C.E.O., a different board, a different culture?"
Ross thought he could live with all that, if it enabled him to fulfill his ambition of building the world's mightiest media and entertainment company. Now he is not so sure. "A million things hit us," he says.
In difficult moments, Ross says, he remembers the lines in "Hamlet" of Polonius to Laertes that his father used to quote to him. One of the lines is "Neither a borrower nor a lender be." Another is "This above all: to thine own self be true."
As he recites the verses, there is no flicker of self-doubt or irony on Ross's face. He believes he has lived his life this way.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 2; Arts & Leisure Desk

HEADLINE: Pondering the Riddle of Creativity

BYLINE: By DANIEL GOLEMAN; Daniel Goleman is the co-author, with Paul Kaufman and Michael Ray, of "The Creative Spirit," the companion volume to the four-part PBS series of the same name beginning April 2.

 BODY:
There is something bedazzling about the creative act: always a surprise, it shocks with its unimaginable perfection, its strange eloquence, its balance between the fresh and the familiar. Perhaps it's because we want to make such magic ourselves that we are so intrigued by how others do it. And so we turn to psychology to unravel the mysteries of creativity.
But despite a long fascination with the creative mind, psychology has been singularly uncreative in explaining it. There is, for example, the popular if romanticized view that takes van Gogh as its prototype of the creative genius: an emotional cripple who, if cured of his neurosis, would lose his talents. That theory, with roots as ancient as Aristotle, has gone out the window with findings that show creativity flourishing with emotional maturity (though a little manic depression in the family may not hurt, especially for writers). 
 Other theories try to reduce the creative act to elementary abilities. One such theory was "divergence," a knack measured by how many novel ideas one could come up with for using such items as a junked car. Such theories merely trivialize the topic.
In recent years these piecemeal approaches have been rejected by a new generation of psychologists who seek more satisfying understanding of the creative spirit, whether it is embodied in the young artist starting in the proverbial garret or a titan like Martha Graham, innovating into her 90's.
Three major new theories of creativity nest inside one another like Russian dolls. One focuses on the role of the sheer pleasures of creation during the inspired moment. A second tracks the forces at work in the lives of creative geniuses like Eliot and Picasso, Einstein and Gandhi, people who have risen beyond the top of their form to recreate the form itself. A third steps back to assess the social forces that give rise to a renaissance.
These theories signify a sweeping shift in the study of the imagination. Rather than seeing creative ability as something akin to intelligence, something like a creative I.Q., psychologists are examining the creative moment itself. Glimpses of the lives and work of three creative artists -- the realistic painter Gregory Gillespie, the film maker George Lucas and the Polish playwright Janusz Glowacki -- illuminate these theories.
 
 
Gregory Gillespie
The Thrill Of the Moment
 Consider the artist Gregory Gillespie in his studio in a meadow near Amherst, Mass., pondering whether to add images of himself and hisdaughter, Juliana, to a life-size super-realistic nude portrait of his wife, Peggy, sitting on a kitchen stool. At times like this, when he contemplates the intricacies of composition or is rapt, putting brush to canvas, Mr. Gillespie says he feels "super-alert." Time dissolves, and a day passes like an hour.
That elastic sense of time -- vanishing into a kind of hyperspeed or crystallizing into stop-frame slow motion -- is a mark of what psychologists call the "flow" state, an altered awareness found in people performing at their peak. First discovered in studies in which people from rock climbers to chess masters described moments when they had outdone themselves, flow is now being charted as the thrill that motivates artists to keep at it year after year.
Mr. Gillespie's paintings are now in the permanent collection of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Whitney Museum and the Hirshhorn. But when he began he was willing to live in near-poverty rather than work a full-time job so he would have time to paint. "I loved it," says the artist, who is 55. "I felt painting was the greatest job I could have, even though I wasn't making a cent from it."
Such early disregard for financial reward is a hallmark of nascent artists who later have successful careers, according to Prof. Mike Csikzentmihalyi, a University of Chicago psychologist who has led the research on flow and creativity. He and his colleagues studied 200 artists, first in art school, and then 18 years later. Those who had most savored the joy of painting itself, valuing the process more than the product, stayed with it; from their ranks eventually emerged the most successful. But those who had been spurred by fantasies of fame and wealth had largely disappeared from the art world soon after graduation.
"Painters must want to paint above all else," says Professor Csikzentmihalyi. "If the artist in front of the canvas begins to wonder how much he will sell it for, or what the critics will think of it, he won't be able to pursue original avenues. Creative achievements depend on single-minded immersion."
Flow hooks artists on their medium in the first place, but it also drives them to push beyond their limits, to innovate and experiment. The Chicago researchers find that flow occurs when a person's skills are in exquisite balance with the challenges presented. If the challenge is too easy, there is boredom; if it's too taxing, anxiety results.
A novice musician feels "in flow" performing a well-rehearsed repertory; a master musician needs the most technically challenging pieces to get in flow; the world-class musician ups the ante by interpreting those most challenging pieces.
The signs of such an evolution are evident in the retrospective survey of Mr. Gillespie's self-portraits from 1969 to 1991, now at the Forum Gallery on 57th Street in Manhattan. The earliest work is technically primitive, using tight, restricted brushstrokes to depict the artist at 33. The portrait shows a man who seems to be glowering with intensity at the struggle to master his medium. "I was just learning how to make it look realistic," Mr. Gillespie recalls.
By 1975 a self-portrait is so vividly realistic that at first glance it could be taken for a photograph. But soon after mastering that hyper-realistic technique, Mr. Gillespie moved on to a signature style, a visual equivalent to magical surrealism in which murky Rorschach-like subworlds lurk in the corners and shadows, populated by a mix of fetuses, torsos, genitalia and intestines: the tension betwen id and ego made visible.
Recently, Mr. Gillespie has moved on again. "I lost interest in being able to render microscopic detail," he said. "What challenges me now about painting a figure is using a looser technique -- bigger brushes, broader strokes, painting more quickly."
He also uses life-size cutouts of painted objects, trying them out in several of the many paintings he works on at once. He welcomes visitors' suggestions about what elements to put where. Says Mr. Gillespie: "I'm always on the lookout for something new to try. It keeps it fresh for me."
 
George Lucas
Challenges Over a Lifetime
 The lifelong trajectory of creative geniuses, fueled by the pursuit of flow, is the focus of the second new theory. That theory encompasses the psychological and social forces at work in such a life, and such phenomena as the so-called 10-year rule, the natural rhythm at which artists seem to have breakthroughs.
The 10-year rule has emerged from a major study by Howard Gardner, a psychologist at Harvard University. Professor Gardner examined the lives of a handful of virtuosos, each of whose work has transformed its field. For example: T. S. Eliot, who graduated from Harvard in 1910, had completed a draft of "The Waste Land" by 1921. Picasso, who left art school to live as a painter in Barcelona at 17, painted "Les Desmoiselles d'Avignon" at 26. Stravinsky, who began his apprenticeship as a composer with Rimsky-Korsakov in 1902, stunned the musical world with his score for "The Rites of Spring" just a decade later.
In the realm of American movie making, George Lucas entered film school in 1964 at the age of 20, finished his breakthrough movie "American Graffiti" just eight years later and turned to work on the "Star Wars" trilogy soon after that. Now 47, he will be given the Irving Thalberg award during the Academy Award presentations on March 30, in recognition of his creative innovations in film.
Typically high-level creators have come from geographical regions removed from the centers of power, and from families that valued discipline and achievement. "There's something to be said for being a big fish in a little pond when you're young," says Professor Gardner. "It gives you a certain feeling of invulnerability" that, along with self-discipline, shields an artist from the rebuffs that, predictably, assail every revolutionary creation.
Mr. Lucas, who grew up the son of a businessman in rural Modesto, Calif., stresses the importance of perseverance in his own success. "Persistence and tenacity are the reasons I've come this far," he said. "In film, especially when you are starting out, everyone says, no, you can't possibly do it that way."
That happened when Mr. Lucas was seeking financing for "American Graffiti." "No one would touch it; it took two years of pounding on doors," said Mr. Lucas. "For one thing, I was telling four separate stories simultaneously, intercutting them into a single whole. Now it's a standard style, especially on TV shows. Then it was an experiment in editing."
The second objection Mr. Lucas faced was to the film's soundtrack. "It was a musical montage. I structured each scene around a song. I took an operatic format and converted it to the modern cinematic medium. I was told it would be too disturbing, that people wouldn't sit still through 110 minutes of music."
But Mr. Lucas persevered, with the encouragement of close friends. That, too, Professor Gardner finds, is a common element in the careers of the highly creative: they rapidly bond with a set others who are exploring new terrain within their field, and who offer one another crucial support, exchanging ideas and boosting morale. For Mr. Lucas, the band included his mentor, Francis Ford Coppola, Steven Spielberg, Martin Scorsese and Brian De Palma, all starting out as young film makers.
Until then, Mr. Lucas recalls, the film industry had been largely closed to those who were not shaped by the culture of the studios. Such marginality is another theme in the lives of the highly creative, Professor Gardner finds, even after their breakthrough has won them acceptance and influence. Continuing to seek a marginal status helps the creator maintain a crucial freshness. "Whenever they risked becoming members of the establishment in their field, they would again shift course," says Professor Gardner.
Mr. Lucas has maintained that distance by making Marin County his base of operations. "Once I saw that films could be made anywhere, that you didn't need giant sound stages and big studios, I saw no reason to move back to Los Angeles," said Mr. Lucas. "I felt film making should be decentralized, and that Hollywood was too insulated. It was a 60's philosophy."
Professor Gardner finds another pattern: a second breakthrough, which, he says, is "also noteworthy, but less dramatic -- a kind of coming home that places the person's work in a broader frame, reconciling it with basic values."
To be sure, Mr. Lucas has made several cinematic breakthroughs, not least his "Star Wars" trilogy, in which he created a modern myth. But his biggest recent artistic gamble is his new ABC series, "The Young Indiana Jones Chronicles" (Wednesday nights at 9). "I'm taking PBS-style 'Masterpiece Theater' and moving it to network TV," said Mr. Lucas. The series tracks the early years of Mr. Lucas's film hero Indiana Jones, the swashbuckling archeologist. In the TV series, he says, "The creative challenge is to tell interesting stories that introduce people to historical figures and deal with larger issues like comparative religion and ecology."
Despite the skepticism of many critics, the first episode placed in the top 10 shows for the week. But whether Mr. Lucas has beaten conventional wisdom with this gamble is not yet clear. Mr. Lucas is aware that he is again battling the mainstream. "TV is a tabloid medium of sorts, wanting the current hot issues rather than the perennial ones," he said. "But you have to do what your muses tell you."
 
 
Janusz Glowacki
Awaiting The Renaissance
 No matter how talented creative artists may be, they are to a degree dependent on the time and place in which they live. Perhaps the most ambitious of the new theories takes the grand view, asking what, over the last 2,500 years of human history, accounts for the rise and fall of golden ages of creativity -- and where we can expect another renaissance. The answers are put forth by Dean Keith Simonton, a psychologist at the University of California at Davis, who predicts that the new republics of the Soviet Union and the newly free nations of Eastern Europe show the greatest promise.
His conclusions: great wealth, geographic expansion, a centralized nation-state and waging wars all have little or nothing to do with producing a creative society. Instead, political fragmentation emerged as the single best social predictor of grand escalations in creativity. For instance, Italy during the Renaissance was not a single nation, but a bevy of city-states vying for power. The Germany that spawned Goethe, Hegel, Schiller, Mozart and Beethoven was made up of myriad small states, adrift from the decayed Holy Roman Empire. Monolithic states, by contrast, squelch creativity.
"The Russification process, where an imperial state gobbles up its neighbors and drives them to cultural homogeneity, can undermine the creative potential of the entire society," Professor Simonton says.
Typically a creative upsurge takes place about 20 years after a rebellion, as the first generation of artists matures free of the paralyzing limitations of a restrictive, monolithic power.
"You shouldn't expect a golden age overnight, but I'd predict one could begin in the second decade of the next century," says Professor Simonton. "First the emerging republics will have to re-establish their unique cultural identities and build up their economies. While wealth does not breed creativity, poverty pretty much prevents it."
Poverty is why, in the short term, many Eastern European artists are pessimistic about the creative climate. "It's such a huge financial mess in Poland now that independence has been a big disappointment for the arts," said Janusz Glowacki, a Polish playwright who spends time in both Poland and the United States. "They've been closing theaters and firing actors. Even very good writers are having trouble getting publishers. Mostly everyone's just trying to survive."
If it is any consolation, Professor Simonton has also found, in an analysis of 1,935 compositions in the classical repertory, that those pieces created under conditions of civil unrest were most likely to have lasting popularity.
That may be good news for Mr. Glowacki's own work. The 53-year-old novelist and playwright emigrated to the United States in 1981, when martial law was declared in Poland and the Solidarity labor movement was outlawed. He is best known for his plays "Cinders" and "Hunting Cockroaches," both of which have been produced Off Broadway and in many theaters throughout the world, including in Eastern Europe.
"Hunting Cockroaches," presented in 1987 at the Manhattan Theater Club with Ron Silver and Dianne Wiest, is a semi-autobiographical work about a writer and his wife, an actress, who have fled Poland and are adjusting to life in a tenement on the Lower East Side of Manhattan. "Cinders," produced at the Public Theater in 1984 with Christopher Walken, revolves around a staging of "Cinderella" in a girls' reform school and addresses how a totalitarian regime breaks the will of its critics.
These days in Eastern Europe, says Mr. Glowacki, while novelists and playwrights "can write without censorship, they're being censored by the economy. The first rank of writers are suffering a lot."

HEADLINE: CLASSICAL VIEW;
Newness That Makes No Apology

BYLINE: By Edward Rothstein

 BODY:
The lobby of the $72 million Wortham Theater Center in Houston is peculiarly revealing about that city's cultural life. The main entrance to the three-acre complex, which houses both the Houston Grand Opera and the Houston Ballet, opens almost immediately onto a grand escalator flanked by enormous sculptures of banners and torches. But on reaching the top, one can only gasp in surprise. There is no statuary as at La Scala, nor is there the cramped artificiality of the Metropolitan Opera lobby. The entrances to the 2,176-seat Alice and George Brown Theater and to the 1,066-seat Lillie and Roy Cullen Theater are nowhere to be seen. The reception area is simply an enormous empty space.
A football field further in (or so it seems), there are a coffee bar and souvenir stand, a winding line of cushioned benches and a small cafe, all dwarfed by the room itself. Walking through it is like entering a train station. This is a place, it seems, built for thousands of commuters, all on their way somewhere from someplace else. Despite the escalator's heraldic sculptures, this entrance does not really serve as an induction into a particular world; it makes no claim on one's attention aside from its sheer size. It is, curiously, a monument to the transience of its visitors and seeming testimony to the impermanence of the artistic objects contained within. The lobby is simply a celebration of newness. 
 It is a monument that is not undeserved, for Houston, lacking long and deep artistic traditions, is a typical American city. The opera company was founded in 1955; the symphony goes back to 1913, but only during the last two decades has it had a year-round program; a chamber-music organization, Da Camera, is just in its fourth season.
Yet Houston's artistic achievements have an unusual range. In 1987, the Wortham Center was built with private financing as an imposing home for the performing arts. (In the same year, the distinguished Menil Collection opened, a museum housing artworks collected by Dominique and John de Menil.) During the last 20 years, with David Gockley as director, the Houston Grand Opera has achieved a worldwide reputation for the presentation of new works and important productions of mainstream repertory. Last month, for example, Robert Wilson's eccentric, haunting version of "Parsifal" was given its premiere. (The band in the pit was the Houston Symphony under its music director, Christoph Eschenbach; it could easily have competed with more tradition-bound European ensembles.) As for Da Camera, its director, the violinist Sergiu Luca, has put together programs that should be the envy of other groups -- a concert of works written during composers' final years, a concert juxtaposing the music of Elliott Carter and Olivier Messiaen, or a concert of music influenced by Goethe.
There is also a wide range to these artistic enterprises. In the Houston Grand Opera, in fact, Mr. Gockley has combined various aspects of the New York City Opera, the Met and the Brooklyn Academy of Music. He is fast on his feet, smart in his marketing and musically ambitious. The company has an astonishing track record even outside the boundaries of traditional opera. It brought "Show Boat," "Hello, Dolly!" and "Porgy and Bess" to Broadway. Its international status has partly come from avant-gardish championing of works by Meredith Monk, Philip Glass and John Adams. Da Camera also has crossover programs (combining jazz and classical) and is founded on the notion that widespread problems plague programming -- a perspective gained from being on the outskirts of a culture.
It is as if the absence of long social and musical traditions has led to great freedom. The arts are less imposing here, so more accepted and exploratory: a cabdriver told me, as if fulfilling his typical role of journalistic touchstone, how much he had loved Mr. Wilson's "Parsifal." Such an atmosphere can lead to greater adventurousness; it can also lead to shallower effect as I found in Gretry's "Beauty and the Beast" and Robert Moran's "Desert of Roses," two other productions I saw last month.
Shallow roots also fail to provide assistance in difficult times. The late 1980's marked a vast expansion of Houston's cultural life just as its economic boom was ending. The impact has been delayed. This season, the Houston Grand Opera, after growing from a $420,000 budget in 1972 to an $18 million budget in 1991, is contracting. The Da Camera society is in imminent danger of extinction; it cannot offer donors social cachet or attract the sustained support the Grand Opera is struggling for, though its demise would be a serious debit for Houstonian culture. In seeking new audiences, the opera company has just announced Opera New World, a program that will attempt to create diversity in audiences and programming -- a risky procedure. Its success will depend on whether the emphasis is on the education of newcomers to the operatic tradition, or whether, in a contemporary cliche, the tradition itself is viewed as irredeemably elitist.
In all these respects, in its failures and its successes, its promises and its ominous rumblings, Houston may be archetypally American, demonstrating possibilities and risks inherent in fast growth. It also raises questions we must face if art-music traditions are to have a future in their American incarnations. In the meantime, we seem to wait in a cultural train depot like Wortham's lobby, spotting new arrivals, then casually moving on in search of newer charms.

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Nudging the Market;
Sonyma Drops Its Rates

 BODY:
With 30-year fixed rate mortgages offered by New York banks edging upwards -- the average rate was 9.15 percent last week and is expected to go to 9.25 percent this week -- low- and moderate-income homebuyers may be tempted by the latest offering from the State of New York Mortgage Agency (Sonyma). The agency dropped its rate last week to the lowest level in eight years -- 7.25 percent for the first five years and 8.20 percent for the remaining 25 years.
"Things were slow," said John N. Spano, a vice president at Sonyma, explaining that the agency's loans had dropped from $412 million in 1990 to $350 million in 1991. 
 By Jan. 10 of this year, regular mortgage rates hit an 18-year low, averaging 8.42 percent, according to Paul Havemann, vice president of HSH Associates, a mortgage information service in Butler, N.J. At those levels, Sonyma's loans had lost their competitive advantage. Historically its rates were two percentage points below the market.
The loans are available to first-time homebuyers and others, with income limits that vary from county to county. (For details, call 800 382 HOME.)
State mortgage rates may also come down in New Jersey and Connecticut. The New Jersey Housing and Mortgage Finance Agency, now offering 8.8 percent mortgages, plans to drop rates in about a month. The Connecticut Housing Finance Authority, with fixed rates from 8.0 to 8.5 percent, is now considering ways of remarketing its bonds and lowering its rates.

HEADLINE: Is It Time to End Rent Regulation?

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

 BODY:
FOR almost half a century, rent regulation, which has provided virtual lifetime guarantees of inexpensive or below-market-price apartments to hundreds of thousands of families, regardless of means, has been politically untouchable in New York City.
In the last year, though, a rising vacancy rate, the city's urgent need for more tax revenues and studies projecting that deregulation would have a limited impact on most apartment residents have brought hope to landlords and fear to tenants that the controversial system will soon be reconsidered, if not revamped. 
 "As the economy changes, as circumstances change, then we have got to look at the rules and regulations," said Councilman Archie H. Spigner, chairman of the City Council's Committee on Housing and Building. "Personally, I'm happy to see the vacancy rate go up. It means the citizens have more options."
Apartment vacancy rates lie at the heart of the struggle over rent regulation. The system, enacted in 1943 as part of a wartime emergency housing act, is designed to prevent landlords from gouging tenants when there is a shortage of rental housing. Under the state's Emergency Tenant Protection Act, the City Council must determine every three years whether the vacancy rate is still below 5 percent. If it is, rent regulation remains in effect. But some classes of apartments that have vacancy rates above 5 percent, such as luxury units, can be excluded.
The vacancy rates are calculated triennially for the city by the Federal Bureau of the Census. In 1987, only 2.46 percent of two million rental units were found vacant. In 1990, though, the bureau could not conduct the survey because it was busy with the decennial national census. Instead, city officials relied on first-quarter 1990 figures from a smaller-than-usual Census Bureau survey of about 2,000 apartments. This showed a vacancy rate of 4.2 percent, allowing the city to renew rent control for 155,000 apartments and rent stabilization for 900,000.
Rent controlled apartments are those built before 1947 that have been continuously occupied by a tenant, or a legal successor, since 1971. When rent-controlled apartments are vacated their rents rise to market level and they become rent stabilized. Apartments built between 1947 and 1974 are also rent-stabilized, as are those built afterward under the city's tax abatement programs. The stabilization ends in new buildings when the abatement expires after 10 or 12 years.
In May 1991, the Rent Stabilization Association, an organization of property owners that opposes rent regulation, sued the city to end controls. It argued that the 1990 survey was invalid and that even if it was valid, the city should have used figures from a similar small survey done in the fourth quarter of 1990, which showed a 5.2 percent vacancy rate.
The matter rests in State Supreme Court in Queens, and lengthy appeals are likely regardless of the outcome.
Further complicating the issue, the Census Bureau did a full survey of about 18,000 apartments in 1991. The vacancy rate shown by that survey was 3.78 percent, the highest since the bureau began the studies in 1960. Details, which will provide vacancy rates for individual classes of apartments, are not expected to be released until late summer.
"WE have never seen the vacancy rates like this before, and it makes you wonder why we should continue rent control and who it benefits," said John J. Gilbert 3d, president of the Rent Stabilization Association.
Mr. Gilbert said the association plans to petition the city later this year for a recalculation of the 3.78 percent vacancy rate. He cited a 4.1 rate in the 10-year census survey, the decline in rents in the city and the increasing ease of renting an apartment.
The association is also appealing the outcome of a 1987 action in which it sued the city for not ending rent regulation on apartments renting for more than $1,000 a month. In that suit, the association cited the 1987 census survey that showed vacancy rates of 5.8 percent to 6.5 percent for those apartments, even though the overall vacancy rate was only 2.46 percent. The State Supreme Court ruled against the association because, according to Mr. Gilbert, the association had made a technical error in its supporting statistical evidence.
"All trends point to a line piercing the 5 percent mark within three years," Mr. Gilbert said. "You would think that the city would be looking at ways to phase out rent regulations."
Supporters of rent control dispute Mr. Gilbert's assessment of the vacancy rates. And even if the rate has surpassed 5 percent, they believe this is a glitch caused by the recession and the glut of unsold co-op and condominium apartments that have been turned into rental units.
"It's cyclical," said Michael McKee, chairman of the New York State Tenant and Neighborhood Coalition. "We went through the same things in the 60's, a glut caused by overbuilding. But the glut we see now will not be forever; it will be absorbed."
Mr. McKee also opposes partial rent deregulation, such as on luxury apartments. He questioned what would constitute a luxury-level rent, citing, for example, several roommates living in a $2,000-a-month apartment. "Four or five people paying $500 aren't exactly rich," he said.
He also said that decontrolling property classes with a vacancy rate above 5 percent would only lead to a reinstatement of controls at a higher rent level when the vacancy rate falls. As for a means test, he said, it would be difficult to administer and lead to a chipping away of the political support for rent regulation for middle-income and lower-income tenants.
More important, perhaps, Mr. McKee and many supporters of rent regulation oppose deregulation on philosophical grounds; they believe is a right and units should be built and regulated by government edict.
"It is absurd to think that at 4.5 percent we have a housing emergency and at 5.2 percent we don't," Mr. McKee said.
Supporters of decontrol, however, believe strongly in private property rights. They also contend that the city and state, rather than property owners, should provide the means for affordable housing. "Rent subsidies and payments would work better," Mr. Gilbert said.
Although supporters of rent regulation believe that abolishing the system would force thousands of tenants, many of them with low incomes, from their long-held apartments, a study released last month by the Rent Stabilization Association found that for most of the city outside of Manhattan the impact would be minimal. The study was done for the association by the Joint Center for Housing Studies at Harvard University
According to the study, based on the differences in rents between unregulated apartments and rent-stabilized dwellings in the same areas, there is now little difference between regulated rents and market rents in Brooklyn, Queens, the Bronx and Staten Island. And in some places, such as Lower Manhattan and several neighborhoods in Brooklyn, regulated rents are higher.
In most of Manhattan, though, the study found that rent control and stabilization provide subsidies for renters of up to $63 a month in northern Manhattan, $434 a month on the Upper East Side and $599 a month in Turtle Bay.
"Four out of five boroughs do not benefit from rent regulation and would not be affected by decontrol," Mr. Gilbert said. "Even in Manhattan, rent increases could be minimized by a broad decontrol measure."
He also blamed rent regulation for increases in building abandonments and the rising number of delinquencies showing up on the city's property tax rolls. Other complaints include the economic disincentive to landlords for making repairs, renovations or improving services.
Then there is the annual $24 million cost of having the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal administer the program, which has long been criticized as ineffective in resolving grievances and rent disputes.
Of that $24 million, $8.5 million comes from landlords who pay $10 a unit. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's 1992-93 budget request calls for increasing the fee to $15 to generate an additional $4.6 million to avert a 3 percent staff reduction that could further slow the administration of rent regulation.
"The cost of administering it has jumped from $7 million in 1984," said Jack Freund, director of research and development for the Rent Stabilization Association, which administered the rent-stabilization program for the city before the state's involvement.
The Commissioner of the state Division of Housing and Community Renewal, Angelo J. Aponte, said the increases came because of rising labor costs and additional responsibilities imposed by the Federal Government. He also said that many of the division's administrative problems stemmed from a backlog of cases it inherited when, in what is now widely considered a failed effort at reform, it took over rent-regulation from the city and the Rent Stabilization Association.
Mr. Aponte added that changes in New York City's system of rent control were needed to make it easier to administer, but he opposes scrapping rent regulation outright. He dismissed a means test because it would increase the department's administrative burden. And luxury decontrol, he said, is a minute issue unworthy of consideration.
"There is a need to have tenant protection on the books," he said.
Mr. Gilbert, however, noted a growing trend in the nation, in places like San Francisco and Brookline, Mass., to repeal or reject rent-regulation laws. "Deregulation, it is coming, it is happening, and it will continue to come for the rest of this decade," he said.
He added that a bill sponsored by Senator Joseph L. Bruno, Republican-Conservative of Rensselaer, was approved by the State Senate's Housing and Community Development Committee two weeks ago. It would end rent regulation in one year for tenants with annual incomes of more than $100,000 and for apartments renting for $2,000 or more a month.
The bill made it through the committee last year but was not voted on by the full Senate.
"There will be a vote this year," said Edward Stahr, director of research for the Legislative Commission on Public-Private Cooperation, which is headed by Mr. Bruno and which drafted the bill.
MR. GILBERT also said that a report released last year by the Citizen's Budget Commission projected that the city could collect an additional $80 million to $100 million a year in property taxes if rent regulation was removed from high-income households upon vacancy.
"Decontrol can help prevent abandonment and provide New York City with desperately needed revenue to pay for police, firemen and sanitation workers," he said.
Besides the Rent Stabilization Association, pressure to phase out rent regulation is coming from newly formed alliances between the owners of co-ops and rental buildings.
"It is a phenomenon that is increasing now," Mr. Freund said. "There is a mutuality of concerns with rising taxes and the remaining rent-controlled tenants left in buildings."
But even those who wish to dismantle rent regulation believe it is not politically practicable to eliminate it entirely. Borough President Guy V. Molinari of Staten Island said the City Council should begin exploring options such as decontrolling apartments when they become vacant, applying a means tests for tenants or imposing decontrol only on the small number of rent-controlled apartments that rent for over $750 or $1,000 a month.
Tenants in rent-controlled apartments have a statutory right to occupy their apartments for as long as they want without a lease. Once a rent-controlled apartment becomes vacant, its rent may be raised to market level and made subject to rent-stabilization, with a limit on annual rent increases based on an index of operating costs.
"There is enough sentiment today to pass some legislation, but we are not sure how far we can go," Mr. Molinari said. "We are playing around with threshold figures, maybe $750 a month, maybe $1,000. We read about these stars who are making millions of dollars and living in a rent-controlled apartment. That's immoral."
Indeed, there are myriad, well-publicized cases of the rich and famous paying far below market rents for large apartments, thanks to the city's rent-regulation system. Or of single retirees living in regulated apartments that could be used to house large families. Or of tenants who use their regulated units as pied-a-terres. A Southampton, L.I., family of five, for example, was recently evicted from a rent-controlled, 450-square-foot studio apartment in Manhattan that they contended was their primary residence.
In recent weeks, rent-control critics have also cited the case of Herbert and Dorothy Vogel, the retired postal clerk and retired librarian who amassed a world-class art collection and donated it to the National Gallery in Washington. The couple live in a rent-controlled Manhattan apartment that, at least in part, is thought to have given them the financial freedom to pursue their passion for paintings.
Mr. Gilbert has argued that such an example is a gross misuse of rent control because it is meant to provide the poor and middle class with affordable housing -- not make them Medicis. He added that the Vogels' situation drew little criticism because they donated much of the proceeds of their lifetime rent subsidy to the public rather than frittering it away on sports cars, fur coats or second homes in the Hamptons.
The Vogels declined to be interviewed, except about art. The Division of Housing and Community Renewal, which keeps records about tenants who live in rent-regulated apartments, would not release any information about the Vogels' rent and the size and location of their apartment.
Many tenants lucky enough to live in rent-regulated apartments insist that the system, while helping them, also helps the city by keeping them from fleeing for the suburbs.
Catherine Saxton, for example, has been living in a six-and-a-half-room duplex apartment with a garden on the Upper East Side of Manhattan for the last 18 years. The monthly rent started at $350 and now is $650.
"The only reason I have been able to do what I have done -- run a business, meet a payroll -- is because I have a rent-controlled apartment," said Ms. Saxton, who owns a public relations firm and lives alone. "I feel sorry for the people above me. They pay two to three times as much."
Regulation supporters also note that the median annual income for households in rent-controlled apartments in 1986, the last year for which figures are available, was $10,182. For rent-stabilized units, the median income was $17,000 in pre-1947 buildings and $24,400 in post-1947 buildings.
"ThE profile of rent-regulated tenants is, from our point of view, working people, elderly and poor," Mr. McKee said. "The myth about the major beneficiaries being upper-income white Manhattanites is a vicious effort by the real estate lobby to misrepresent who lives in rent-regulated apartments."
Opponents of regulation, though, said that most of the high-end rent-regulated and rent-stabilized apartments -- those 72,000 units that rent for more than $750 a month -- are occupied not by low-income families seeking affordable housing but by one- and two-person households that have a median annual income of $47,000.
"You have plenty of housing in New York, but you have the wrong people living there," Mr. Gilbert said.
One of the strongest supporters of rent regulation, Borough President Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan, would not say if she would back a means test or any form of decontrol, even if the vacancy rate rose above 5 percent.
"People point out the inconsistencies and irrationalities in the system, and I think they need looking at," she said. "But you can only raise questions about the city rent-regulation program in the proper context and that is affordable housing. Until we have the systems and procedures in place for affordable housing, there is likely to be very little change."
Rent-regulation opponents, however, counter that such sentiments are merely a smoke screen designed to keep the system in place.
"The obstacles to radical change are merely political -- no one wants to offend rent-controlled and stabilized tenants," said Robert Cicchillo, of the Alexander Brett real estate management company in Manhattan. "But the current economic climate and the general realization that rent control has not helped those it was intended to help suggest that changes could take place very quickly."
