HEADLINE: Tsongas Departure Changes the Game For State's Moment In the Political Sun

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

 BODY:
THE state's Democratic Presidential primary campaign changed abruptly last week, leaving supporters of Paul E. Tsongas, the former Massachusetts Senator, adrift and available to be courted all over again by the remaining candidates.
Mr. Tsongas, a native of Lowell, Mass., had been heavily favored at one time to win the Connecticut primary on Tuesday. But he dropped out of the race on Thursday, saying his campaign was running out of money. 
 Mr. Tsongas's announcement left an unknown but certainly large proportion of the state's 654,532 registered Democrats, who may have stopped listening to the other candidates, starved for information. Democrats are now left to choose between Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, the party's clear front-runner, and Edmund G. Brown Jr., the former California Governor, who attracted large numbers of disaffected, angry working-class votes in the primaries in Michigan and Illinois, when Mr. Tsongas was still in the race. Mr. Brown and Mr. Clinton had announced ambitious campaign schedules in Connecticut even before Mr. Tsongas's departure.
Mr. Tsongas may get a large number of votes in the primary despite his withdrawal. Because he dropped out too late to have his name removed from the ballot, residents will still be able to vote for him, and some of his supporters will be working precisely toward that end. Delegates pledged to Mr. Tsongas in the primary would go uncommitted to the Democratic convention in Manhattan this summer. Other names on the Democratic ballot include Senators Tom Harkin of Iowa and Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, both of whom abandoned their campaigns for the Presidency. For the remaining candidates, the task changed overnight. Mr. Clinton, who had sought to challenge Mr. Tsongas in the New Englander's own backyard, became the Connecticut front-runner who had to watch out for a challenge by Mr. Brown. Mr. Brown, meanwhile, was given an opportunity to cast himself as the sole alternative to Mr. Clinton, who is now considered the almost certain Democratic nominee because of his previous victories in primaries around the country.
"The choice is between business as usual and real change," Mr. Brown said.
But even if the game has changed, the backdrop and the issues -- especially the state's battered economy -- have not. In 1988, when Connecticut last stepped into the brief national spotlight of a Presidential primary, the economy was flush, and the state was viewed as a ripe source of campaign contributions. George Bush, then the Vice President, called Connecticut a sterling example of the fruits of economic growth that Republican policies had fostered.
Since the recession began in 1989, the state's residents have seen home prices fall with the health of the construction industry. Homelessness, unemployment and business failures have all soared, and uncertainty about job security has become the angst of the hour.
"People in the state of Connecticut are looking to government for answers," said the state Democratic Party chairman, Edward L. Marcus. In 1988 "things were acceptable to people economically," Mr. Marcus said. "Now they're totally unacceptable. There's anger and there's disappointment."
But upon whom do the voters take the anger out? Do the men bringing their presidential ambitions to the state this week offer real solutions for Connecticut?
Is it better to stay the course with a vote for President Bush or embrace the middle-class tax cut proposals favored by Mr. Clinton? Would the so-called peace dividend from cutbacks in military spending be better used to fuel investment in industry or to encourage private consumption that could stimulate the economy?
And then there is the even trickier question, which candidate do the voters believe? "I'm tired of the promises, the promises, the promises," said Angelo Brown, a Hartford resident who confronted Mr. Tsongas at a campaign stop at the Polish National Home in the city on Wednesday. "What makes you so different?"
 
'No Prince Charming Out There'
 But other residents said they were pleased just to be able to vent some steam at the candidates and said Connecticut was still getting at least an airing of the issues.
"There's no Prince Charming out there this year, but I think we are getting a good discussion of the issues," said Ernest Kulka, a Torrington Democrat who said he was uncommitted but leaning toward a vote for Mr. Brown, "because he's more radical."
Mr. Clinton has centered his campaign around what he calls "the forgotten middle class." He would push for an immediate 10 percent income tax cut. And to help states like Connecticut make the transition from the cold war economy, he outlined a four-point plan that he said would help workers, companies and communities make the adjustment, through training and assistance programs.
"For 10 years, the middle class has declined, poverty has exploded, and only the rich are doing better," Mr. Clinton says in his campaign literature. "Together we can take our country back."
 
Protest Among Republicans
 Mr. Brown also favors cutting taxes, but he has also pledged to "move off the backlog every single public works project in America to put people to work." He would also reduce foreign aid and invest the money in improving the economy.
President Bush, who is not campaigning actively in the state, outlined his economic proposals in his budget plans announced in January. They include cutting the capital gains tax rate and raising the personal tax exemption for middle-income families with children to $500 for each child.
Neither of the President's rivals on the ballot, Patrick J. Buchanan, the conservative commentator, or David Duke, the former Ku Klux Klan leader, has actively campaigned in the state and have no organizations here. Because the other contenders have not sought votes, any votes for Republican other than Mr. Bush could be viewed as a protest.
"The higher the protest vote, the more that people are looking for a change, almost any change," said Robert G. Jaekle, a former Republican leader of the State House of Representatives who is seeking the Republican nomination to challenge United States Senator Christopher J. Dodd in November. "But I don't see it as much anti-Republican or anti-Democrat as anti-incumbent."
The measures of what might constitute a no-confidence vote for Mr. Bush also vary greatly. Mr. Marcus at the State Democratic Party said that given Mr. Buchanan's low profile in the state and Mr. Bush's historic popularity and family ties, anything higher than 15 percent against the President would constitute "a defeat." The President grew up in Greenwich and his father, Prescott Bush, was a United States Senator from Connecticut from 1952 to 1963.
 
Looking at the Turnout
 The state's Republican Party chairman, Richard Foley Jr., said that localized votes against the President will be the thing to watch.
"If Buchanan is getting a 20 percent statewide average, and in some areas he's getting 40, it's time to take a look," Mr. Foley said.
Political leaders said that one of the other factors to watch would be the turnout. In 1988, 36.8 percent of the 660,848 people listed as registered Democrats in the state came out to vote. (Michael S. Dukakis, then the Governor of Massachusetts, won; the Rev. Jesse Jackson came in second.) Republicans only saw a 23.8 percent turnout out of 439,053 registered party members, with Mr. Bush receiving more than 70 percent of the votes.
Most politicians in the state say the turnout could be even lower this year, perhaps below 20 percent in both parties. But much, as always, is decided in the final days, as candidates succeed or fail in sparking voters' imaginations.
The polls will be open from 6 A.M. to 8 P.M. on Tuesday. At stake are 53 Democratic and 35 Republican delegates.
Because no other state has a Presidential primary this week, the eyes of the nation will be on Connecticut.
"The fact that it's a stand-alone primary guarantees it its 15 minutes of fame," said Mr. Foley.

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:

Calculating Co-op Tax
 
Question: We are a small 16-unit co-op. As a non-profit corporation we have a small interest-bearing savings account and an account that holds maintenance money to cover the cost of repairs. If there is no money in our account at the close of our fiscal year can we avoid incurring either Federal or state tax obligations? . . . Isabel Hall, Jackson Heights, Queens
 
Answer: No. Your tax liability would have less to do with the balance in your accounts at the end of the year than with how the income was earned. Robert Kobel, a spokesman for the New York office of the Internal Revenue Service, said Federal tax rules give residential co-ops options in calculating their income taxes. As a corporate entity you could elect to be taxed as a regular corporation according to a graduated scale based on income. Using this formula for calculating your taxes would require that you file forms 1120 or 112A.
I.R.S. rules give co-ops the ability to exempt certain types of income like shareholders' maintenance from their taxable income. However, other income, such as rent from any commercial space, fees from building concessions or interest earned on savings accounts or investments, would be taxed at a flat 30 percent rate. A co-op taking these deductions would file using Form 1120H.
New York state tax policy follows the Federal rules in what it allows co-ops to deduct for unrelated business income. The basic corporate tax rate in New York state is 8 percent on taxable income under $290,000 and 9 percent for income above that level. But the taxable income of most co-ops is so small that the majority end up paying only the minimum flat tax required of all corporations, which is $325.
Currently in effect is a 10 percent temporary surcharge for tax years ending between July 1, 1992, and June 30, 1993, as well as a 15 percent Metropolitan Transportation Business surcharge that would apply to co-ops in the M.T.A.'s 12-county commuter region.
More information on New York State tax rules is available by calling 1-800-225-5829.
 
Breaking a Lease
 
Question: I am 23-year-old person in-between jobs. In an effort to cut down on expenses, I have considered finding a cheaper place to live. My lease runs for several more months. Would I face monetary penalties if I moved out? . . . Kevin Curton, Stamford, Conn.
 
Answer: Not penalties, but the laws that govern residential leases in Connecticut make tenants responsible for the rent, during the term of their leases, until the landlord finds a new tenant. However, Victor Feigenbaum, the attorney who is in charge of the Housing Session in Connecticut State Court, said that in this situation a landlord has the obligation to mitigate the tenant's losses by making an effort to relet the apartment. The landlord would have to show, for example, that he had advertised the apartment or listed it with an agent.
Some leases have an unemployment escape clause that would release a jobless tenant who moves out from responsibility for the rent, but they are rare. Nevertheless, you should check your lease for such a clause.
 
SCRIE Eligibility
 
Question: I am 67 years old and retired and living on a limited income. I have lived for more than 25 years in an apartment in a two-family house. Do I qualify for the city's Senior Citizen Rent Increase Exemption program? . . . Eugene Myer, Bayside, Queens
 
Answer: No. According to Roz Post, a spokesman for Department of Housing Preservation and Development, the program is limited to tenants in rent-controlled, rent- stabilized and Mitchell-Lama apartments. Tenants in two-family houses are not covered.
However, you might qualify for assistance under the Section 8 program, a Federal rent-subsidy program. In order to take advantage of it, your landlord would have to agree to participate. If he does, your rent could be reduced to no more than 30 percent of your income. For more information on Section 8 eligibility call 212-306-3000.

HEADLINE: Volunteers Offer Worldwide Advice

BYLINE: By JACK CAVANAUGH

 BODY:
THREE days a week, Charlie Bevis of Westport drives 30 miles round trip to the world headquarters of the International Executive Service Corps in Stamford, where he puts in a full day of work on various global communications projects.
On two occasions, Mr. Bevis also has spent time on extended assignments for the corps in Belize and Costa Rica, helping improve and expand television operations. The Central American assignments, like his work at the corps' headquarters, entails a great deal of creativity and responsibility. Yet, since joining the service corps four years ago, Mr. Bevis has received no pay. Nor have any of the 41 other executive volunteers at the group's headquarters in the South End of Stamford, including 17 who, like Mr. Bevis, have worked on projects abroad. 
 Most of the volunteers live in Fairfield County, as do 17 salaried executives of the organization, including Thomas S. Carroll of New Canaan, the president and chief executive, who previously held the same titles with Lever Brothers.
 
Expertise Around the World
 Of all the diverse companies that have established their headquarters in Stamford in the last two decades, the International Executive Service Corps may well be the oddest. Not only is it staffed with a large number of highly successful retired executives who volunteer their time, but it includes a "skills bank" of more than 12,000 other retired executives throughout the country, many of whom have worked on some of the 14,000 advisory projects undertaken by the organization in 101 countries.
Determined to stay active after a successful career in a variety of fields, the retired executives are imparting their expertise in countries throughout the world, mainly in less-developed nations. Most of the volunteers are in their 60's and 70's. Kaj Osterfeld, a financial management executive from River Edge, N.J., who worked on more than 20 of the corps' projects overseas, stayed active until he was 84 years old.
Men predominate among the volunteers, although in recent years more and more women have joined the organization, which is financed by the United States Agency for International Development, American corporations and foundations, and overseas clients and governments.
The volunteer executives said they enjoyed the work, even though they receive only travel and living expenses for themselves and their spouses while they are abroad and only mileage and lunch money when working at the Stamford headquarters.
"It's a challenge, and I like challenges," said Mr. Bevis, 75, a former vice president for the National Broadcasting Company who runs his own advertising and public relations company out of his Westport home. "American business has been very good to me and has taught me a lot. If I can share my expertise and help other countries save money in a time of debt financing, it is very satisfying."
"Giving money to other countries in itself is not always the answer," Mr. Bevis said in an interview at the Stamford headquarters. "Sharing knowledge can be just as important, and sometimes even more so. By doing what we do overseas, we also project an image of America that is good. For too many years, Americans went abroad and took and took from other countries, leaving many of them barren. Now we at I.E.S.C. have he opportunity to give something back. Besides all that, staying active with I.E.S.C. keeps me going and out of a rocking chair."
 
TV Station in Belize
 During a two-week assignment in Belize in 1990, Mr. Bevis, who was with NBC for 30 years, helped establish a new program schedule for a television station there and aided in the start of transmitting and receiving programs by satellite.
In Costa Rica, where Mr. Bevis and his wife, Connie, spent three months in the fall of 1990, he analyzed the operations of the main television station and then made suggestions and demonstrated new techniques, which he said were eventually adopted.
"For one thing, I noticed that the anchor men all wore dark suits and were very somber," Mr. Bevis said. "I suggested that they lighten up and even laugh occasionally. And I recommended that they wear brighter clothing, more like what typical Costa Rican business people wear."
He said the Costa Ricans welcomed his suggestions about their on-camera demeanor and clothing. "It made a big difference," he said. "They also appreciated some other suggestions, like the one I made that they use a helicopter in covering a road race."
Like many spouses of volunteer executivesabroad, Mrs. Bevis found a volunteer job on her own in Costa Rica, working in a library. A number of wives, like Berni Walter of Southbury, have taught English overseas. During tours in Indonesia and Bulgaria, Mrs. Walter, a former preschool teacher in Wilton, taught English to adults, and in the Philippines she worked with children at a day-care center. Following a month in Bulgaria with her husband, Dawes, last fall, Mrs. Walter wrote an orientation manual for future volunteers in that country.
 
5 Projects in 7 Years
 Mr. Walter, a 66-year-old retired oil company executive with a background in marketing and government relations, has worked on five overseas projects in the last seven years. They have included helping decentralize the Chamber of Commerce in the Philippines during the final days of the Marcos Government in 1985, designing a career planning and placement center at Trisakti University in Indonesia that now serves as a model for other universities in the country, visiting seven universities in Thailand to determine what kind of management assistance they need to strengthen the country's university system and helping establish a nonprofit political analysis center in Bulgaria to ease the transition to democracy.
"I regard my work as a give-back to the national interest of our country," said Mr. Walter, who was a vice president of the University of Bridgeport from 1981 to 1984 after he retired from the oil business. "My wife and I have met some marvelous people from I.E.S.C. during our trips abroad, and we've been able to have a lot of fun and make a lot of friends. And the management of I.E.S.C. is absolutely inspiring. Through our work, I feel that we've become part of an international family."
At the age of 67, when many former business executives tend to restrict trips abroad to pleasure, Frank Barch of Norwalk expects to spend several months in Uruguay and Brazil on volunteer projects this year. A retired operations executive for the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, Mr. Barch has been on assignments for the corps in eight countries in the last seven years.
 
Stock Exchange in Botswana
 In Poland last November, Mr. Barch advised a company that had just been made a private business how to compete in international markets. During previous assignments, he showed a company in Thailand how to improve the quality of diesel engines it was producing, taught workers in El Salvador how to manufacture bicycles to meet international standards (many of the bicycles are now being exported to Spain, Italy and the United States), and taught workers at a Portuguese plant how to increase the production of gym shoes by 22 percent.
"The experiences have been broadening and challenging," Mr. Barch said. "Also, it's been both stimulating and fun."
Many of the executives became involved after friends told them about the organization. One is William McIntire, a retired investment banker who is serving his second term as the Treasurer in Darien, where he lives with his wife, Patricia. During three assignments in Africa, Mr. McIntire has helped establish a stock exchange in Botswana, advised officials in Zimbabwe on ways to stimulate manufacturers to produce more goods and aided in developing a capital market in Losotho.
Some of the retired executives' wives have also served as volunteer workers at the group's headquarters. Both John Jinishian and his wife, Lucy, who live in Old Greenwich, spend two days a week at the Stamford offices. Mr. Jinishian, who retired in 1983 as a vice president of Champion International, has worked on projects in Honduras and Costa Rica and is a volunteer recruiter. Mrs. Jinishian, who taught English to adults in Honduras during her husband's assignment, assists volunteers and their wives when they return home.
Another Connecticut couple, Martha and Lawrence Aasen of Westport, are both volunteers with the organization, specializing in public relations, and have worked together on projects in Guatemala and Botswana. In addition, Mrs. Aasen, a former public information officer at the United Nations, spends two days a week at headquarters as an executive recruiter.
"We're both idealists, and we love to travel," said Mr. Aasen who also does some freelance public relations at home. "And we feel we're doing some good."
Mrs. Aasen added, "With us, they're getting two for the price of one."

SECTION: Section 12CN; Page 1; Column 5; Connecticut Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1393 words

HEADLINE: Investors Seek Scraps Of Real Estate Empire

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON

 BODY:
ON July 12, 1991, Jonathan Googel and Benjamin Sisti sat before a hostile audience in an auditorium at the University of Hartford, taking questions from creditors of their bankrupt company, Colonial Realty. The meeting was led by Hal M. Hirsch, a trustee appointed by a Federal judge to take over Colonial's affairs.
Creditors charged that the company was either an outright fraud or one of the worst-managed businesses ever patched together. Accountants said they could not separate Colonial's finances from those of Mr. Googel, Mr. Sisti and the scores of investment partnerships they had created. 
 After the two partners refused to answer Mr. Hirsch's questions about who had been in charge at Colonial, the trustee listened impatiently as a lawyer for workers at the Summit Hotel, which Colonial had closed in 1990, asked Mr. Googel about a meeting with members of the workers' union.
 
'That Was Worth It'
 Had Mr. Googel attended as a general partner of Colonial Realty? As a general partner of one of his partnerships, Colonial Constitution? In some other capacity?
"On behalf of what entity did you attend the meeting?" the lawyer asked.
Mr. Googel hesitated. Finally he replied, "I don't know what entity I was that day."
"That was worth it," Mr. Hirsch said with satisfaction.
Colonial Realty, based in West Hartford, collapsed in 1990, when Mr. Googel and Mr. Sisti ran out of investors willing to buy $50,000 shares in their real estate partnerships, and they could no longer find banks willing to lend to them. By the time the company was forced into bankruptcy, as many as 6,000 people had invested a total of $350 million, and banks had lent hundreds of millions more.
The collapse has spawned thousands of lawsuits, as lenders and investors fight to cut their losses at each other's expense. There is little left to Colonial itself. Last fall its office furniture and other equipment were auctioned, and its interests in 29 real estate partnerships are to be sold next month.
As Colonial's bankruptcy case moves toward its unhappy resolution, however, thousands of Connecticut residents are grappling with the knowledge that they invested large sums in something that, under intense examination, seems hardly to have existed at all. "Colonial Realty really owned nothing -- nothing," said Mark Shipman, a lawyer in Hartford who represented Colonial in bankruptcy until the trustee was appointed. "It was a property manager at the will of the general partners. But they looked at Colonial as something that was much larger and more defined."
So did the investors. John R. Gorman, a lawyer in New Haven who represents investors, said: "If there is a common psychological aspect to this, it is that people beat up on themselves. It's absolutely astounding that people could be the victim of misrepresentation, forgery and fraud and still beat up on themselves."
Within weeks of Colonial's bankruptcy in September 1990, it was evident that Mr. Googel was hardly alone in his confusion over Colonial's many entities. As accountants dug into financial records, they saw that Colonial was little more than an enormous pyramid of debt with almost no assets of its own.
If investors were counting on the personal guarantees offered by Mr. Googel and Mr. Sisti, who had represented their worth at more than $75 million apiece, the partners' wealth was nearly irrelevant. They and their creation, Colonial, owed $1.4 billion.
Colonial was unlike many other large real estate syndicators that collapsed at the end of the 1980's, because there was fraud within the company. Its chief financial officer, Frank Shuch, was facing charges of embezzling $6 million when he killed himself on Feb. 11. Lawsuits charge that Colonial falsified financial statements to obtain loans that, in some cases, were secured by forging investors' names to promissory notes.
 
Hopes of Rising Prices
 Mr. Googel and Mr. Sisti, the subjects of investigations by the F.B.I. and Internal Revenue Service, blamed Mr. Shuch for the fraud before they stopped discussing Colonial publicly.
But economists and other experts say Colonial was in many ways a common phenomenon of its time, a rank real estate speculation, if not a deliberate Ponzi scheme, that could stay afloat only as long as people believed that the real estate boom of the mid-80's would last forever.
As long as real estate prices kept rising, they say, the actual value of property almost did not matter. Colonial could pay too much for properties, borrow too much on them, take too much of investors' capital in fees and still promise big returns based on 10 more years of rising prices.
Banks lent freely, because they made their profits on lending fees, rather than the properties, while a rising market covered any short-term losses.
"The banks were falling all over themselves to lend them money," Mr. Shipman said. "They were competing, saying, please, take their money.
"You didn't have lending officers in banks. You had salesmen, and their product was money."
 
In the Business of Borrowing
 Individuals were willing to invest, because they saw fortunes rising all around them, as surging prices for houses and other real estate created an estimated $1.5 trillion in new wealth in the Northeast, said Karl E. Case, a professor of economics at Wellesley College. "We began to behave as if we really had that wealth," he said.
Colonial and its partners, however, created deals that could be propped up only with loans and fees taken from new deals, even in a healthy market. Mr. Googel and Mr. Sisti were not developers; they were in the business of borrowing money to buy property to resell to others. The falling real estate market that began taking a toll on developers and bankers in 1989 did not cause its collapse, but magnified its cost.
In their last partnership, for example, to syndicate Constitution Plaza, an office complex in downtown Hartford, the prospectus shows that Mr. Googel and Mr. Sisti set out to raise $169 million in mortgages and investors' shares on a property for which they paid $94.5 million. With the plaza's buildings now valued at less than $70 million, $100 million has evaporated in a single deal.
"The simple fact is that we had inflated values that went away, and somebody has to bear that cost," Mr. Case said.
Some people did make money on Colonial's deals, starting with those who sold properties to the partnerships, like the Travelers Companies, which sold Constitution Plaza, and the United Technologies Corporation, which sold the Gold Building, on Main Street in Hartford, which houses its headquarters.
"It's a game of musical chairs," said John Clapp, a professor at the University of Connecticut Center for Real Estate and Urban Economic Affairs in Storrs. "The money goes into a round of buying and selling, and the last person to buy is left standing, holding the bag."
 
Emphasized Big Payoffs
 The final tragedy of Colonial is that those left holding some of the heaviest bags, the individuals who invested in Colonial partnerships from 1986 on, are almost the only people who actually expected to make money on real estate. Court papers show that Colonial's partners took as much as $100 million from loans and commissions. Banks took their profits from lending fees. Until Federal tax changes in 1986, even Colonial's investors did not buy shares expecting the deals to make a profit; the investments were tax shelters that paid off immediately in tax writeoffs.
It was only after 1986, as Colonial put together more and larger deals, that its sales force emphasized big payoffs to attract thousands of middle-class people. Many were persuaded to invest by friends, accountants or lawyers, who may have been paid commissions by Colonial.
Most didn't have the assets to qualify as limited partners, but they were never told that securities laws required a means test. Instead, they have found that Colonial employees altered, or forged, their financial statements to show net worths above the required $1 million. Many of the investors now are being sued by banks that want to collect on Colonial's promissory notes.
"It's hard for people now, who feel they got swindled, to recognize that in the early deals people never expected to make money," said Mr. Shipman, an investor in one early partnership.

HEADLINE: ABOUT NEW JERSEY

BYLINE: By Anthony DePalma

 BODY:
IT is a hell as ferocious as in any city. Nearly everything has been leveled, and the unholy ground has been left fallow for so long that the ailanthus trees grow 25 feet high. The sidewalks have been pummeled to dust; the street is just strips of jagged asphalt.
Only three buildings stand on the block. One has been almost totally consumed by fire. One is empty but for the old couple who have lived there for 45 years but who never come out. 
 Only the last one, a flimsy three-story wood frame building of the type that has fed fires all over Newark, is filled with desperate families who lock themselves in at night and keep their window shades drawn.
It has a name -- Chester Street, between Broadway and McCarter Highway in the rag-tag frontier of Newark's North Ward. But to the people of El Templo Candelero, it is the promised land.
"We could have built somewhere else but we decided to build here," said Victor M. Capeles, turning in the frigid March night to embrace all that he can see on Chester Street. "Our purpose is to help people and the community, not run away from neighborhoods like this."
Mr. Capeles is administrator of an unusual group of Puerto Rican-born Americans in Newark, a city where those who speak Spanish have long been at the bottom of the economic and political totem pole. Roughly 70 people -- old women, young men, children and parents -- who believe they are Jewish in spirit have purchased five city lots on Chester Street and are building the first temple in Newark in more than 50 years.
While few Jews live in Newark today, for many years they were one of the city's most prominent and powerful groups. At the turn of the century, their enclave around Prince Street in the Central Ward teemed with the same outburst of immigrant life as Hester Street in Manhattan's Lower East Side.
Their heyday came in the 1930's, when their neat homes and sturdy synagogues covered most of the Clinton Hill and Weequahic sections of the city. High Street -- now Martin Luther King Jr. Boulevard -- was a Jewish Fifth Avenue, lined with mansions and imposing institutional buildings that bespoke a people who understood community.
Nearly all of that is gone now; all but one of the synagogues are closed. For many reasons not unique to them, the most successful Jews started leaving Newark right after World War II and moving into expanding suburbs like West Orange and Livingston. Then, after the summer of 1967, when race riots turned Newark into a cauldron of hate and fear, the flight became an exodus.
It is one of the delicious contradictions of urban life that in that same troubled year of 1967 the Templo Candelero -- Temple Menorah -- was established in a three-story building on lower Park Avenue, not far from Barringer High School and Sacred Heart Cathedral.
The ground-floor space that had once held a store was fitted with a tabernacle and a menorah and the sacred ancient writings of the Old Testament, especially the Pentateuch, the first five books of the Bible.
The congregation celebrates Passover, observes the Jewish calendar, keeps the same dietary ban on shellfish, pork and other items listed in Leviticus, sings in Hebrew during ceremonies, even dances the same spirited Jewish dances during celebrations.
But it has never been recognized by any official Jewish organization because the members believe that a Messiah -- Yahshua -- has already come, and He was Jesus.
For 25 years the congregation grew. Last year it decided it was time to build a real temple. Most of the members had been born in Puerto Rico, where the Congregation of Yahweh -- as the religious movement is known -- was begun in 1939, although most were not converted from their native Catholicism or Pentecostalism until they lived in Newark. They spoke English poorly and worked at modest jobs in factories and warehouses. They lived all over Newark.
The leader of the congregation is Jorge Rivera, who is called pastor, not rabbi. He said the members of the congregation had considered many sites in many different neighborhoods, but it became clear once they saw the available land on Chester Street that it was the place for them to send down roots.
They bought five city lots for $50,000, which is some indication of how little anyone else thought of the area. Even some of the members thought building there was a crazy idea.
"I told them, 'Where do you want to go, the suburbs?' " the pastor said. "Who are you going to preach to there? We've got to be in the city where the bums and the drug addicts are so they can see."'
The five lots had been vacant for more than 15 years. A blocklong automobile junkyard is right behind them, and the street was so deserted that it became a favorite place for prostitutes to bring their customers.
A few months ago, the bulldozers came in and cleared the garbage. The ailanthus trees were cut. A foundation was poured, and cinder block walls began to rise on a 50-foot-by-80-foot contemporary-style temple with a tall peaked roof. In an architect's rendering, a hugh menorah embellishes the facade, facing Chester Street.
Getting together the money for such an undertaking wasn't easy. The congregation had $20,000 in its account when work began. It solicited contributions and held auctions and sales to raise more.
The main temple in Paterson, with which Temple Menorah is associated, provided $45,000. Now the pastor and Mr. Capeles are negotiating with the Valley National Bank for a construction loan to complete the project.
Although the night was frigid, the pastor walked hatless and quite proud in front of the construction site. The steel frame rising out of the ground amid so much neglect and ruin might have been taken for an apparition.
"It is our hope, and our faith, that we will be finished by July," he said.
Hope and faith. The emergency survival kit of any city, but an absolute necessity for surviving in a place that has been through as much as Newark in the last 25 years.
The greatest tragedy in Newark came after the riots, when there seemed to be almost no hope there. Everyone had walked away -- from Chester Street and from whole painfully wounded neighborhoods in the city.
Things are different now, in some ways at least. Evidence of this comes when Mr. Capeles goes to City Hall to ask about the many other empty lots on Chester Street, planning at some point to build a day-care center and perhaps some affordable housing for members of the temple and for other poor people in the city.
He is told that he will have to wait until the next auction, when Newark will sell property to the highest bidder. There was a time when the city couldn't give away land.
Mr. Capeles and the pastor are humble men with strong faith, and that makes them bold. Bold enough to believe that what they do on this desolate corner of a big city can change things to such an extent that other people will notice and be changed too.
"Sometimes what people really need is a push from someone else," Mr. Capeles said. "They're afraid to go ahead and walk the first step. It's going to give a push to the whole North Ward when people see the difference we made here."
It just might.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 2; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 2797 words

HEADLINE: Den Fujita, Japan's Mr. Joint-Venture

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
The first thing you need to know about Den Fujita is that he is the man who made the hamburger a Japanese icon.
In the 21 years since he launched the fast-food phenomenon here in a 50-50 venture with the McDonald's Corporation, Mr. Fujita has so saturated Japan with golden arches that they often seem etched in the popular imagination as deeply as the Imperial chrysanthemum. Many young Japanese would be surprised to learn that the Bi-gu Ma-ku was not invented on the Ginza. 
 This canny entrepreneur has also taken on the traditional notion that Japan is and should remain a nation of small shopkeepers. While American trade negotiators launched a frontal assault, he quietly pressed the Government to ease laws that had made it next to impossible to build large-scale stores. That cleared the way for what is regarded as one of the most promising new retail chains in Japan, Toys "R" Us, in which his business owns a 20 percent stake.
He has brought beef patties and french fries to people who were said to prefer rice. He introduced large-scale discounting to people who supposedly wanted only cozy but high-priced neighborhood shops. In a nation whose economic vigor comes from its exporting prowess, Mr. Fujita is a master importer. In a land of conformists, this virtuoso of self-advertisement is a classic contrarian.
While the Japanese are constantly urged to sacrifice for the collective good, he loudly declares himself a prophet of the cult of money -- a creed he has developed in a series of best- selling books in which he explains, in all seriousness, that he learned his business methods by observing the tactics "the Jews" use to exercise secret control over the world.
The 66-year-old Mr. Fujita, whose fortune is estimated by some at more than $1 billion, has prospered by taking the most un-Japanese ideas and products and making the Japanese love them. That is why even with his curious and some would say insulting philosophy, he is probably the most sought after joint-venture partner for American and European companies trying to make their way in this complex market. His latest joint venture: a deal with Blockbuster Video to develop a chain of 15 rental stores. Three have already opened.
"When I began to describe my views, some people said, 'This is just propaganda,' " the loquacious Mr. Fujita commented during an interview in his 44th-floor office here, decorated with rows of safety helmets because of an obsession with earthquakes. "They don't say that now."
 
A Message for Gaijin
 But there is a subtler reason for the remarkable success this unusual man has achieved, which carries an important message for foreigners trying to do business in Japan, or simply trying to gain a fresh perspective on the sometimes obscure soul of a country that can be as full of contradictions as Mr. Fujita.
Behind his philosophical ramblings and contemptuous remarks about the colorless Japanese business establishment -- he calls its leaders "scrap iron" -- is a lesson in how much change is really taking place under the surface of Japan's economy, and how one can seize the new opportunities. He has thrived not so much by overthrowing the system, but by seeing through many of the outdated myths the Japanese spread about themselves and turning them to his advantage.
Mr. Fujita has also long recognized that the accepted wisdom, even if it is wrong, limits the competition, since so few here are willing to go against the grain. Indeed, beyond the wacky claims -- Mr. Fujita says he believes Osakan businessmen are craftier than those from Tokyo because Jews settled in Osaka about 1,000 years ago, and that the Japanese will become blond if they eat enough hamburgers -- is a bottom-line manager who has found a way to open a seemingly closed system to outside influences.
"In business, the only justice is winning," Mr. Fujita has written. "There is neither clean money nor dirty money. In a capitalistic society, all methods of making money are acceptable."
His foreign business partners generally say they have embraced him because he is so hard-nosed -- and successful. "The truth is that when we came here there were not a lot of people who could maneuver through the bureaucracy," said James R. Cantalupo, president of McDonald's International. "He really knew how to do that. His rare quality is that he can bridge the two cultures."
Asked about Mr. Fujita's odd philosophy, Robert C. Nakasone, vice chairman of New Jersey-based Toys "R" Us, said, "This stuff never seemed to affect his business thinking, frankly. He's very much a pragmatist."
 
Fortunes of War
 There were few signs in Mr. Fujita's privileged youth in Osaka that he would grow to be so different. His father earned a comfortable living as an engineer at a British company. Mr. Fujita went to a prestigious high school and then entered Tokyo University's law department -- the training ground for Japan's government and business elite.
It was around this time that he began to see that change, even under the grimmest of circumstances, offered money-making opportunities. Mr. Fujita said he lost his father and two sisters in American bombing raids. But during the American Occupation, while he was still a university student, he realized that the best wages were being paid to translators working for Japan's former enemies.
His English language skills took him to General MacArthur's headquarters in downtown Tokyo, just across the moat from the Imperial Palace. In 1950, Mr. Fujita stepped off the accepted path for top university graduates and formed his own trading house, Fujita & Company.
Mr. Fujita clearly benefited from the fact that in an economy where most everything was rationed and imports were severely restricted, those who could navigate the barriers enjoyed generally strong demand and little competition. Fujita & Company prospered by importing, among other things, Christian Dior handbags and other women's accessories.
But Mr. Fujita's real break came in 1971, when McDonald's selected him as its partner in Japan. McDonald's wanted a strong entrepreneur who would be completely committed to the hamburger business.
"The Japanese are very hard-working, but very weak, very small and our faces are so pale," Mr. Fujita said without a trace of irony, explaining why he shifted from handbags to french fries. "I thought we had to strengthen ourselves. That's when I thought of beef."
McDonald's learned quickly that once they got past this cosmic reasoning Mr. Fujita was a very practical and stubborn businessman. For example, McDonald's insisted on a suburban setting for the first restaurant -- just like in the United States. Mr. Fujita would hear nothing of it. He insisted on the Ginza, Tokyo's central shopping district. He reasoned that in the context of a country where a love of hamburgers was not a given, a higher profile site was a necessity.
Mr. Fujita won. The Ginza store became one of the world's busiest McDonald's.
McDonald's had trouble lining up franchisees initially, so it kept ownership of most of the restaurants itself, bringing even more profits to Mr. Fujita. Today, only 155 of the 867 shops in Japan are owned by independent franchisees. In the meantime, Mr. Fujita found another way to capitalize on the arrangement. He had the privately held Fujita & Company -- now run by his two sons -- import many of the products McDonald's was using here, from Idaho potatoes to furniture.
What Mr. Fujita did not do was meddle with McDonald's way of making and selling food. The company's manual was imported largely unaltered. A Hanbaga Daigaku (Hamburger University) was set up to train the staff. Other than the Japanese and English on the menus, it was hard to tell the difference between a Japanese or American restaurant -- other than price. A Japanese Big Mac costs 380 yen, or about $2.90 -- inexpensive, given the price of other food; a cheeseburger here is 240 yen, or about $1.80. In Manhattan, a Big Mac is $2.89, a cheeseburger 99 cents.
 
A Man of Influence
 Mr. Fujita's forte was obtaining all the government approvals necessary for running and expanding the business. He brags, in fact, about his political influence, particularly his ties with Michio Watanabe, the current Foreign Minister. Perhaps more important, Mr. Fujita managed the critical issue of finding real estate in a country with some of the most expensive property in the world. Over time he has developed an impressive data base on property across Japan -- an asset that was a particular attraction for his next major partner, Toys "R" Us.
Sales at McDonald's Japan rocketed from 205 million yen that first year to 50 billion yen in 1980 and 207.7 billion yen last year, the equivalent of $1.6 billion. Japan now accounts for nearly 10 percent of McDonald's total sales. Nearly half a billion hamburgers were consumed here last year. McDonald's became Japan's leading restaurant chain in 1982.
"Most people cannot see the future," Mr. Fujita said. "But I am telling you, in 1994 we will make 400 billion yen in revenues. People laugh. You wait. I know how to do it." Sales of Fujita & Company have also zoomed up to 31.7 billion yen in the fiscal year that ended on Feb. 29, from 17.9 billion yen in 1987.
In 1972 Mr. Fujita began his career as a writer. His first book, "The Jewish Way of Doing Business," sold more than 200,000 copies in the first month. The book has been reprinted 63 times, selling more than a million copies. It is a combination autobiography and how-to book that purports to explain the business secrets all Jews know and use.
That was followed by other hits, including, "Stupid People Lose Money," "How to Become Number One in Business," "How to Blow the Rich Man's Bugle Like the Jews Do," and "Using Super-Commonsense in Your Money-Making Strategies." A general theme is that the reader can win wealth and power by emulating the methods used by the great Jews.
"I personally don't pay much attention to that," said Mr. Cantalupo. "You have to put all that in the context of the human being. I have the utmost respect for him as a businessman and he's a pleasure to deal with as a person."
In fact, Mr. Fujita's writings are part of a popular Japanese literary genre. For decades books on supposed Jewish conspiracies have been produced in great numbers in Japan. They generally reflect less on Judaism, about which the authors rarely seem to have a very deep understanding, than on the Japanese themselves. Popular literature often depicts the Japanese as a chosen but embattled people who need to stick together to survive the forces arrayed against them. They identify with the image of the Jews they have produced.
Mr. Fujita insisted that he did not consider it insulting to characterize Jews purely as stereotypes.
"Please don't misunderstand," he said. "I'm trying to do something good for the Jewish people. Most Jewish people speak two or three different languages. They're good at mathematics. The Japanese should learn from that."
Mr. Fujita was catapulted into prominence once again when he agreed to have McDonald's Japan take a 20 percent interest in Toys "R" Us's new Japanese operations. Once again, it was not just another foreign company seeking entry into Japan, but a harbinger of major changes.
 
Skirting Restrictions
 The old laws permitted local merchants to raise a host of objections to the opening of large retail establishments, a kind of veto on competition. It was common for approvals to take 10 years or more. Toys "R" Us decided to challenge the restrictions.
The two problems were attacking the laws and finding a partner. The United States Government began work on the first priority years ago, pressing for changes in trade negotiations. On the second issue, Toys "R" Us, America's largest specialty retailer, pursued Mr. Fujita.
"To be honest with you, we'd followed him and knew about him," said Mr. Nakasone of Toys "R" Us. "He was not only our first choice, but our second, third, fourth, fifth and so on. After our first meeting we felt even more so that he was the right partner. We could see that he was a bit of a maverick. He was not only bilingual, but bicultural. He saw the potential for our business there immediately. He shared our impatience for trying to get it growing."
Mr. Fujita brought to the deal his knowledge of the bureaucracy and, most important, his real estate data base. That has proven valuable to Toys R' Us, which is about to open its third store here.
"This is really a real estate deal, not a retailing deal," said Mike Allen, an analyst at Barclays de Zoete Wedd Securities here. "But that does not make it any less important."
Because it has become increasingly difficult to find good sites for new McDonald's restaurants, Mr. Fujita said that as part of his new deal he will be constructing McDonald's at many of the new shopping centers where the Toys "R" Us stores will be located. Each will feed off the traffic created by the other.
Mr. Fujita said he had no immediate plans for new ventures, other than a longstanding desire to purchase a Japanese professional baseball club. But Japanese rules prohibit acquisition of a team by a company with a 50 percent or more foreign interest.
As one might expect, Mr. Fujita is undaunted by the challenge and has already chosen a name for the franchise -- the Bi-gu Ma-kus.
"If you want to understand the way I think, it is this," Mr. Fujita said, gesturing with a finger. "If 80 percent of the people say this is wrong, then you do it. If 80 percent say do it, don't go that way."
 
 
 
CATERING TO RICE LOYALISTS
 One of Den Fujita's concerns has been that McDonald's growth in Japan will level off. So he has constantly tinkered with the menu and considered other measures to maintain strong sales growth, experimenting with such new products as hot dogs, a shrimp burger and fried chicken.
Two years ago, he conducted an extensive survey of customers' desires and discovered that Japanese eating habits had changed dramatically over the past several decades.
"Of the people who eat out in the evenings, 40 percent eat rice, 36 percent eat bread and meat and 24 percent eat noodles," he said. "Before, most people ate rice. So we had really seen a big shift toward meat." More to the point, however, was that MacDonald's was still missing 40 percent of the market -- the rice eaters -- and there were no signs they could be converted to hamburgers.
"I realized that I didn't have to change the whole strategy, but just alter the menu," he said. So McDonald's Japan now features several rice dishes after 5:00 P.M. "If that's where the business is promising, I'll try it," Mr. Fujita said.

 
 
THE UNAPOLOGETIC MEMOIRS OF A 'GINZA JEW'
 Den Fujita's first book "Yudaya no Shoho," or "The Jewish Way of Doing Business," has sold more than a million copies. Some excerpts:
From the time I was small I wanted to be a diplomat. I once told a neighbor who was a diplomat about my aspiration. But he said immediately, "I'm sorry to say, but you won't be accepted. There is an unwritten rule that people who speak Osaka dialect cannot become diplomats."
Just like the Jews, Osaka people are the victims of discrimination, in this case at the hands of people from Tokyo. Just like the G.I.'s I knew, who discriminated against Jews out of fear that the Jews could take away their money, people from Tokyo discriminate against Osakans because they are afraid they cannot compete against Osaka businessmen.
When I was working as an interpreter, I was a student at Tokyo University's law department. Already my father had died and I had to earn my tuition and living expenses. All traditional morals and values seemed to have been destroyed at that time because of Japan's defeat in the war. I had nothing but the fighting spirit of someone from Osaka. We may have lost the war, but I did not want to be beaten by social chaos or hunger or even by G.H.Q. [General Headquarters for the American Occupation Forces]. So I dared to enter the enemy's headquarters for a job.
Business people in and out of Japan call me a "Ginza Jew." I am satisfied with that and even call myself a "Ginza Jew." I am proud of being Japanese, but as a businessman I am happy being known as a Jew. Now Jews from around the world call me a "Ginza Jew," too, and treat me like an insider. They treat me differently than gentiles. The title of "Ginza Jew" is invaluable to me in doing business with Jewish traders who control business life in many countries.
Nonetheless, there is no shortage of examples of how I was laughed at, stepped on and insulted by Jews. But I endured these insults, just like the Jews have endured all their hardships.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 15; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 848 words

HEADLINE: World Markets;
In Tokyo's Decline, a Glint of Silver

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
Is there any hope for Tokyo? The blue-chip Nikkei index of 225 shares crashed below 20,000 last week and approached 19,457.90, exactly half of what the index was worth at its record high at the end of 1989.
The optimists say the market is down so far that it is poised for a rebound. The Japanese economy is in a slump, but a turnaround should be at hand. The Japanese Government is expected to take actions soon, including cutting official interest rates, to revive the economy and the stock market. 
 But, the pessimists argue, the outlook is even worse than people think because the underpinnings of the economy, like the banking system, are shaky. And the stock market boom at the end of the 1980's happened amid conditions that are not likely to return soon, including very low interest rates.
"The strongest argument for Japan is that it is cheap relative to recent history," said Michael Metz, chief market strategist for Oppenheimer & Company in New York. "But it is fanciful to think that markets are so stable and rational. This will swing to a much more serious undervaluation before it is over."
Given the current gloom in Tokyo, Mr. Metz and other bears sound very convincing these days, but Sander Cseh, who runs his own small investing shop as Cseh International in Berwyn, Pa., is sticking with Japan.
In fact, a month ago he increased his exposure in Japan, bringing the Japanese share of his $55 million portfolio, which is invested entirely outside the United States, up to 29 percent. The fall in the Tokyo market since then has cut the percentage to around 27 percent.
"You are not going to find many people positive on the market at the bottom," he said. "But I think we are close to it." He said he was reassured by the rally on Thursday, when the Nikkei 225 rose 2.1 percent and closed at 20,185.09. The broader Topix index, with 1,222 shares, surged 3.1 percent, to close at 1,451.14. The relatively heavy volume of 550 million shares was also positive, he said. (The stock market was closed on Friday for the vernal equinox holiday.)
Obviously, Mr. Cseh (pronounced SHAY) has not done very well with his Japanese stocks so far. But he takes an approach that shows investors they can minimize their risk in this very volatile market, which on average has had daily moves 50 percent larger than those in the United States over the last 15 months. Through Thursday, Mr. Cseh's Japanese stocks were down 15 percent in dollar terms while the Nikkei index was off 18 percent in dollars. The broader Topix index was down 21 percent.
For starters, Mr. Cseh stays away from the most expensive Japanese stocks. This means stocks that have very high price-to-earnings ratios, for which Japan's market is famous. So he begins by eliminating 60 percent of the stocks in Tokyo. Then he weeds through the 40 percent at the bottom of the price-earnings scale, those that currently have ratios below 34. And here he makes his choices, picking companies that he thinks have better-than-average balance sheets and companies with strong product lines.
Among the stocks he does not have are Japanese banks, which have price-earnings ratios that are seven times those in the United States and Britain.
But Mr. Cseh does end up with stocks that are well known. On his list are Toyota, which has a price-earnings ratio of only 16, and Toshiba, which has a ratio of 26. Fuji Photo, with a ratio of 15, is also on the list.
Among the companies that do most of their business in Japan are Shimizu, a construction company with a rating of 15; Sekisui House, a maker of prefabricated houses, with a 15 price-earnings ratio, and Mabuchi Motors, which manufacturers small motors. It has a 23 ratio.
Over time, with this method he has come out ahead of the Japanese market itself and benchmarks used to measure money managers' performances. His Japanese stocks gained 12.1 percent in 1991, while the Nikkei, in dollars, was up 4.9 percent. In 1990, when markets around the world crashed, his Japanese portfolio fell 21.8 percent compared with a drop of 35.1 percent in the Nikkei.
The Japanese market, as measured by the Morgan Stanley Capital International Index, an important benchmark for portfolio managers, was up 9.1 percent in dollars in 1991 and down 36.3 percent in 1990.
Mr. Cseh's whole portfolio is off 4.5 percent in dollar terms this year through Thursday, in contrast to a drop of 11.5 percent for the comparable Morgan Stanley index for Europe, Australia and the Far East. In 1991 his international portfolio rose 15 percent while the Morgan Stanley index was up 12.1 percent.
Mr. Cseh's performance does not show Toyko is for everyone. But it suggests investing there can be less painful than many people assume.
"The market can go to extremes, so I can be buffeted one more time," he said, acknowledging the deep split with the Tokyo bears. "But I am looking at the second-largest economy in the world and probably the fastest-growing economy of the industrialized countries, and I think that in the long term it is going to be an attractive market."

HEADLINE: Business Diary/March 15-20

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL
 
De Klerk's Mandate Frees South Africa for a New Day 

The new world order made it to South Africa last week when the white minority electorate gave President F. W. de Klerk an overwhelming mandate to end its monopoly on political power. Mr. de Klerk's ruling National Party has been negotiating with other groups, including the African National Congress, headed by Nelson Mandela, to write a new constitution. After a period of transition "it is a foregone conclusion that Mandela will be South Africa's president," said Prakash Sethi, an adviser to a black South African business group. "The transition is likely to be peaceful," he said. South Africa's economy is in shambles from years of sanctions. Though the United States lifted sanctions last year, many states and cities have kept them in place. "The British and Germans who stayed have a large economic base and will increase investment faster than the Americans can get back in," Mr. Sethi said.
 
Japan's Gesture
 
The offer looked generous enough. Japan, which exports cars to the United States under the 1981 Voluntary Restraint Agreement, said last week it would limit the number of cars going to the United States to 1.65 million, down from 2.3 million, the current limit. That gesture, Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry said, would help Detroit's Big Three recover from last year's combined losses of $4.5 billion. But Detroit was skeptical. Since Japan only exported 1.7 million vehicles to the United States last year, its proposal would simply keep the "same volume their auto makers imported into the United States from Japan in 1991," said Harold A. Poling, chairman of the Ford Motor Company. "So, where is the reduction?" he asked.

No Compromise on Israel

When President Bush rejected Israel's request for loan guarantees last week, he said it was because Israel had refused to stop building settlements in the occupied West Bank and Gaza. Israel wants guarantees so it can borrow $10 billion in the world's capital markets at more favorable rates to build housing for immigrants from the ex-Soviet Union. That is a different matter from settling the West Bank and Gaza, it says. To move beyond the impasse, Congress proposed a compromise. Grant Israel an immediate $1 billion in guarantees, said Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, but keep the remaining $9 billion in reserve, subject to Mr. Bush's approval. Mr. Bush said no.
 
A New Export Champ
 
The figures were cheery last week. The trade deficit narrowed to $5.77 billion, a drop of 3.9 percent, the Commerce Department said. But those numbers may actually signal the end of a trend. It takes two years, economists say, for changes in the value of the dollar to affect the balance of trade. Two years ago the dollar started turning up. "From here on out, exports should be petering out," said Samuel D. Kahan, chief economist at Fuji Securities in Chicago.

Losing Money on Herman's
 
Back in 1989, Isosceles P.L.C., the big British buyout firm, snatched up Herman's Sporting Goods when it bought the Gateway Supermarket chain. It made the purchase just in time to see sales drop during the recession. Herman's, which had about $600 million in sales last year, had hefty losses. Last week, Isosceles said it was putting Herman's on the block. "In today's market, I can't imagine they would get $200 million for it," said John Horan, the publisher of Sporting Goods Intelligence, a newsletter based in Glen Mills, Pa. That's half of what Herman's was valued at when Gateway was sold.

Exhausted Honda Executive
 
For the Honda Motor Company it was a big loss. Shoichiro Irimajiri, one of its most important executives, resigned last week. The timing could not have been worse. Honda is in the midst of reorganizing its operations. Mr. Irimajiri, who brought Honda's manufacturing prowess to Marysville, Ohio, and gave its once-stodgy cars a jazzier look "is in a state of such physical and mental exhaustion that he is unable to continue his work," said Shin Tanaka, a company spokesman. "The whole headquarters is in shock," the company said.

What's Slow for Japan . . .
 
Japan is used to loping along at growth rates of 5 percent or more. But last week the Bank of Japan said growth turned negative in the fourth quarter of 1991 -- but barely. Japan's gross national product contracted by 0.2 percent. Over all, growth for the year was still 3.2 percent, slow for the Japanese but a rate the United States still aspires to. "The data indicates growth of just 1 to 2 percent this year," said Carl Weinberg, chief economist at High Frequency Economics, a consulting firm.
 
 
 
COMPANIES

 
Macy's Holiday Letdown
 
R.H. Macy & Company slashed prices during last year's holiday season, hoping to raise enough money to keep creditors at bay. The strategy did not work. Sales tumbled and Macy filed in February for bankruptcy protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. Last week, citing those holiday season write-offs, Macy reported a loss of $671.6 million in its second quarter. In the same period the year before, Macy earned $78 million. About $606 million of the losses resulted from one-time charges. "I think they will have further restructuring charges and, at least in this quarter, their results are likely to be similar to the second quarter," said Walter F. Loeb, a retail consultant. Retail analysts expect to see Macy close more stores.
 
Dow Gives Up Implants
 
Last week the Dow Corning Corporation said it would no longer make silicone-gel breast implants, but would set up a $10 million fund to pay for research and help some women pay to have implants removed. Though it had 30 percent of the market -- 1 percent of its business -- that 1 percent brought most of its recent headaches. The implants have been implicated in a number of health problems.
 
Making a $2 Million Point
 
How much is an idea for a movie that made $350 million worth? Only $150,000, according to judge Harvey A. Schneider of the Los Angeles Superior Court. That is how much he awarded Art Buchwald for an idea that led to Paramount Pictures' "Coming to America," starring Eddie Murphy. "We won the legal case," said Zazi Pope, Mr. Buchwald's lawyer. The victory was not cheap: legal fees were $2.25 million.

Bigger Than a 747
 
The McDonnell Douglas Corporation is rethinking its next commercial plane. Instead of producing the 375-seat MD-12 tri-jet, McDonnell said last week it is looking into a much larger craft. What it has in mind is a 600-seat, four-engine plane that would compete directly with the Boeing 747. "We have said we are looking at alternatives and we have talked to potential airline customers," said John Thom, a spokesman for the company.

Trump's Shrinking Debt
 
In his heyday, Donald Trump bought a lot of snazzy real estate at inflated prices. He paid $409 million for the Plaza Hotel -- all of it borrowed -- which his creditors valued at $260 million. His empire began unraveling two years ago. Last week he agreed to give up 49 percent of the Plaza to a group of banks headed by Citibank; the banks will cancel $125 million of his personally guaranteed debt, plus accrued interest. The deal also offers more favorable terms on the $300 million left on the Plaza's mortgage. In 1990, Mr. Trump was personally liable for $900 million. If this deal goes through, he will owe a mere $115 million.

Colt's in Chapter 11
 
The Colt's Manufacturing Company, whose .45 caliber six-shooter left an indelible impression on the lore of the West, filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. Colt's, based in Hartford, received a $10 million line of credit from the Connecticut Development Authority and a bank. Colt's lost markets to competitors with more advanced products. Even the Hartford police use Smith & Wesson pistols.
 
 
 
ECONOMY

 
Prices Are Under Control
 
With growth still struggling to get above zero, inflation, at least at the consumer level, remains contained. The Consumer Price Index increased three-tenths of 1 percent in February, the Labor Department said.
 
Which Comes First?
 
It's a case of chicken-and-egg economics. To sustain a recovery, consumers must spend. But before they will, they must have jobs. And companies don't hire until the consumers spend. Too little spending and too little job growth derailed last year's recovery, economists say. Has that changed? "I can't tell you that anyone is suggesting to us that they are in a strong rehiring mode at this moment," said Thomas M. Hoenig, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City. "They are hopeful, but they are also cautious."

An End To Tsongas Economics
 
When Paul E. Tsongas withdrew from the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination last week, he took his lower-capital-gains, no-tax-cuts-for-the-middle-class strategy with him. What's left for the Democrats to debate is far more populist. Gov. Bill Clinton said he would raise taxes on the rich -- those who earn more than $200,000 a year -- and reduce taxes on the middle class. Former Gov. Jerry Brown -- borrowing an idea once espoused by Ronald Reagan -- said he wants to scrap the system in favor of a 13 percent flat tax. But few give Mr. Brown a chance of capturing the nomination.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
A Weak Europe Could Prevent U.S. Recovery

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
RisinG exports have been one of the few economic success stories for America in the past several years, a sign of "growing U.S. competitiveness in world markets," as Commerce Secretary Barbara H. Franklin put it last week. But now the exports are shrinking, and that fact may endanger the economic recovery.
In January, the Commerce Department reported last week, exports fell for the third straight month, largely because of a fall in shipments of capital equipment used by businesses abroad. The problem does not seem to be American competitiveness, although the stronger dollar is not helping. Foreign economies simply are buying less as they experience their own weakness. 
 Until the recent setbacks, the trade figures had been looking a lot better. With exports rising by 7.8 percent in 1991, the United States moved past Germany to become the world's leading exporter. The trade deficit remains big, but not nearly as large as it used to be.
The fear of some economists is that world markets may soon shrink. In 1991, the total volume of world merchandise trade managed to rise by only 1.5 percent, in contrast to a 13.5 percent gain in 1990. With Germany and much of the European continent in or near recession, with the British downturn dragging on and with Japan's economy looking shakier than it has in years, the prospects for finding buyers for more American exports do not seem bright.
When times are tough, it is common for countries to try to increase exports and cut imports. Obviously, not everybody can do that at the same time, and while economists generally agree that freer trade provides a net benefit for the world, politicians often see it differently. In the 1930's, when the Depression brought on shrinkage of world trade, countries responded with protectionism and competitive devaluation of currencies.
There is a danger that those cycles will be repeated in the current decade, despite the fact that every major government says it is committed to freer trade. The so-called Uruguay Round of world trade talks, which was supposed to reach an agreement a year ago, struggles on. Helmut Kohl, the German Chancellor, is trying this weekend to persuade President Bush to accept a compromise that could be seen as hurting American farmers. Mr. Kohl's chances of success seem to be slim.
The conventional wisdom on Wall Street is that the trade figures are not especially important, especially when there are signs of a consumer-led recovery.
A dissenting view comes from Gert von der Linde, the chief economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, who notes that in this recession the export sector of the economy has grown to be larger than the combination of housing and autos. He fears the slide in exports will negate other gains and is recommending that investors stay in cash. "We are," he said Friday, "in the early to medium stages of a worldwide recession."

HEADLINE: Technology;
Gridlock at the Chip-to-Microprocessor Intersection

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
The push to build ever-faster desktop computers has hit a bottleneck. Microprocessors, the brains of such computers, continue to increase in speed. But like powerful engines that are starved for fuel, these microprocessors are often kept waiting because memory chips, which store information, cannot supply them with data fast enough.
Because of the bottleneck, both semiconductor companies and computer designers are devising faster dynamic random access memories, or D-RAM's, the main type of memory used in computers. They are also devising faster data highways to shuttle information between the microprocessors and the memory. 
 The result, experts say, will be a profusion of new types of D-RAM's in coming years, some tailored for particular processors or particular tasks and all geared for speed. That could represent a big shift in D-RAM technology, which so far has undergone very little basic change in design.
Such developments could also alter the economics of the D-RAM business. Until now, D-RAM's have been the jelly beans of the semiconductor industry, with vendors competing mainly on price. The D-RAM business has become a game for large Japanese and Korean companies that manufacture in huge volumes and can afford to lose money for years. Although it is far from certain, the shift toward faster and more specialized memories might allow profitable niches to develop, where even small American companies might prosper.
This month, Rambus Inc., a Silicon Valley startup company, announced it had developed a fundamental new design for D-RAM's that could increase tenfold the speed with which the memory chips can transfer data to the microprocessor. In an effort to establish its approach as a standard, the Mountain View, Calif., company has licensed its technology to three of Japan's largest chip makers: Fujitsu, NEC and Toshiba.
Other companies are working on similar technologies. And several industry organizations are working on proposed standards for faster D-RAM's and for faster links between memory and the microprocessor.
"Everybody has the problem; so everyone is going to be seeking solutions," said John Moussouris, president of Microunity Systems Engineering of Sunnyvale, Calif., a startup that is working on increasing the "bandwidth" of communications between the microprocessor and other parts of the computer. "What's limiting the speed of digital systems today is not the speed of the transistors but really the speed of the wires, and particularly the speed of the wires that go between chips," he said.
Until now, makers of engineering work stations and high-end personal computers have been coping with the memory bottleneck by storing frequently used information in a smaller "cache" memory made from faster, more expensive chips known as static RAM's. The idea is equivalent to keeping files in a desk drawer rather than back in the main file room.
But S-RAM's make the computer more expensive, and they are tricky to manage. Data must constantly be swapped between the main D-RAM memory and the cache memory to insure that needed information is in the cache memory at the proper time. If the main D-RAM memory were faster, cache memory might be reduced or eliminated and computers could be less expensive. But makers of S-RAM's hope to retain their business by using some of the same speed-enhancing techniques.
A memory chip can be likened to a house with its rooms arranged in rows and columns. Each room contains a single bit of data, either a zero or a one. A megabit chip, which contains more than one million bits of information, has 1,024 rows and 1,024 columns of rooms.
The problem is that the houses have quadrupled in size every few years, so that a house today contains four million rooms compared with only 1,000 rooms two decades ago. Yet the hallways have not been widened commensurately nor has the number of exits increased. Many D-RAM's are still like houses with only one door that is wide enough for only one inhabitant to pass through.
"The D-RAM hasn't changed in its basic configuration since the 4K," said Betty Prince, new-product manager for memories at Texas Instruments. She was alluding to the 4,000-bit memory, introduced in the early 70's.
Meanwhile, microprocessors have been getting faster, owing in part to the development of a technique called reduced instruction set computing, or RISC. A microprocessor these days might go knocking on the D-RAM's door for a piece of data every 20-billionths of a second. But it takes at least 50-billionths of a second for the requested data to emerge from the house. Like a boy arriving to pick up his date, the microprocessor is often made to cool its heels.
D-RAM makers have already employed several techniques to speed up the flow of information. One approach has been simply to add another door. The video RAM, a specialized D-RAM used to store information for computer screen displays, is like a house with two doors, said Gene Cloud, vice president of semiconductor marketing at Micron Technology of Boise, Idaho. Information needed by the microprocessor goes out the front door, and information for the screen goes out the back door.
Micron has recently introduced a "triple-port" D-RAM with three doors. Another approach has been to make the door wider, so four, eight or even 16 bits can emerge at once.
In still other cases, all the needed data reside on the same hallway. Once the first room is found, the others can be found and emptied quickly. This technique has been used in what are called page-mode RAM's.
But while these techniques have helped, experts say even-greater increases in speed will be made possible by more fundamental changes in the design of D-RAM's.
Many in the D-RAM business expect that the next big leap will come from what are called synchronous D-RAM's because they operate in lockstep with the microprocessor. Because of this synchronization, the microprocessor knocks on the D-RAM's door only when a bit is ready to come out. The D-RAM is not moving any faster, but the microprocessor does other tasks instead of wasting time in waiting. This results in a sharp increase in computer speed.
Yet another approach is to design a special pathway, known as a bus, to carry bits from the memory to the microprocessor. This is the approach taken by Rambus. Both the memory chips and the microprocessor have to be modified to allow them to spit out data fast enough to use the Rambus pathway. The company said that the special D-RAM's would initially cost 20 to 25 percent more than regular D-RAM's but that the overall cost of the computer might be reduced because less cache memory would be needed.
Many industry experts say that the Rambus approach is clever and that the company is off to a good start by getting three of the largest memory chip makers to incorporate its technology in their memory chips. But some experts say Rambus's technique will be slow to catch on because it requires a complete redesign of computers and because some computer companies might prefer to use the solutions being developed by industry standard-setting groups.
Another question for Rambus and other companies pursuing faster memory technology is whether computer companies will be willing to pay extra for faster D-RAM's. Some experts say that in the past they have been reluctant to do so. "I can guarantee you that most of the industry will vote with their wallet," said Mr. Cloud of Micron.
Speeding up D-RAM's, of course, will not end the quest for faster computers. Something else will then become the bottleneck, the weakest link in the chain.
Indeed, speeding up the memory bandwidth could worsen bottlenecks elsewhere in the computer, said Mr. Moussouris of Microunity Systems. As an analogy, he said, adding exits and entry ramps to speed up traffic on a highway could instead slow down traffic if it causes more cars to bunch together at a narrow spot in the road. "Bandwidth is a discipline that is very unforgiving," he said.
