HEADLINE: Keeping the Faith In the Gas Patch

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES

DATELINE: THE WOODLANDS, Tex.

 BODY:
This is a cruel season for drillers of natural gas. Depressed prices and revenues have driven hundreds of small, family-owned companies out of business and pushed giants like Mobil, Chevron and ARCO to explore overseas, where costs are lower and big discoveries more likely.
But George P. Mitchell, an iconoclast in the gas patch for more than 40 years, is still at it. Creator of one of the nation's biggest independent producers and processors of natural gas, the Mitchell Energy and Development Corporation, the 71-year-old Mr. Mitchell is laying plans to drill for more gas, not less, near home. He sees the swarming by rivals into South America, Russia and the Middle East as charged with political risks. Computer-enhanced techniques will so bolster the efforts of exploration geologists over the next 10 years, he says, that a dry hole in North America will prove rare in the next century. 
 "We'll give a one-way airline ticket to anybody who wants to go overseas -- to Russia, to Venezuela, or anywhere else," the bald-pated Mr. Mitchell said with a grin. "Leave this country to us. I think the potential of the next 10 years is excellent."
Mr. Mitchell has often taken a divergent path. While other independent gas producers forage in the gas-rich Gulf of Mexico, Mitchell Energy still gets more than 90 percent of gas output from wells in the Southwest. A gas field in Wise County, Tex., northwest of Fort Worth, has been the backbone of his business since he discovered it in 1953. His experimentation with new and unproven technologies has over time allowed Mitchell Energy to tap reserves in these areas that have stymied others -- and at a low cost. And because he has kept control of 63 percent of Mitchell Energy's common shares, valued at about $450 million, he has been able to diversify into areas that might be considered strange by some. For instance, Mitchell Energy owns the 25,000-acre Woodlands development here, 27 miles north of Houston, headquarters to several companies, including Mr. Mitchell's.
Now, he plans to take advantage of the depressed market by snapping up domestic reserves that bigger companies have put on the auction block. Last year, Mitchell Energy paid the Houston-based Enron Corporation more than $11 million to increase its sizable drilling prospects in southeast New Mexico, where it now has 75,000 acres under lease, up from 14,000 in 1989.
Mr. Mitchell's optimism about gas is pegged partly to the hope that the nation will burn more gas as clean-air standards mandated by Congress tighten through the 1990's. Natural gas is cleaner burning than either coal or oil, and cheaper and more abundant in North America than oil.
Then too, Auto plants, steel mills and other fuel-gulping manufacturers have substituted natural gas for fuel oil in the last few years because gas has been cheaper. The biggest potential demand is in the dozens of new electric power plants that the nation will build this decade.
Studies by the National Petroleum Council, a group of oil-industry executives, and the Gas Supply Committee, an industry association, put the nation's potential gas supplies at about 50 years at current consumption rates. And many industry executives and analysts agree with Mr. Mitchell that if prices were to double, to $2.50 or more per 1,000 cubic feet, drilling activity in the United States could triple, multiplying production from existing fields and the finding of new ones.
Prices have remained depressed, and the number of rigs drilling for natural gas is at a 50-year low partly because of a supply glut created by Federal policies that overstimulated gas drilling in the late 70's in hopes of reducing the country's reliance on foreign oil.Other contributors to the glut include improvements in technology that raised drilling success rates, and big companies that produced gas rapidly and regardless of price to generate cash for investing in what they considered brighter foreign projects.
The last decade has been especially brutal for producers in North America, with its aging fields. Even Mr. Mitchell pared his employee count when prices collapsed in 1986. "We thought the gas bubble would be gone three or four years ago, but we were wrong," he said.
The son of a Greek immigrant railroad worker named Sava Paraskivoupolis who later adopted the name of a Midwestern paymaster called Mike Mitchell, Mr. Mitchell is one of a handful of independent oil-and-gas operators who can afford to be patient. "George is a very sharp individual," said Carol Freedenthal, president of the Jofree Corporation, a consulting firm for natural gas producers based in Houston. "He doesn't get caught in a bureaucratic mess like a lot of bigger companies. He can turn around relatively fast when things get tough."
In a year when most energy companies posted lower profits and plummeting stock values because of weak prices, Mitchell Energy's earnings held almost firm, slipping to $44.3 million in the fiscal year ended Jan. 31 from $47.3 million the previous year. Unlike many of its competitors, Mitchell never recorded a loss during the industry's roller-coaster ride through the 1980's. The closely held stock, meanwhile, has been trading in a narrow range around $15 a share.
Its relative health is partly due to Mitchell's long-term supply contracts -- at an average price last year of a healthy $2.80 per thousand cubic feet. More than half of its output is pledged in a contract with the Natural Gas Pipeline, a unit of Occidental Petroleum, which is paying $3.25 per 1,000 cubic feet for gas this year and more in later years. Mr. Mitchell revised terms three years ago on the deal, originally signed in 1977 when gas supplies were tight and prices for long-term contracts exceeded $7.
Mitchell Energy has also been insulated from falling gas prices by its gas liquids processing and transmission business, which accounted for more than half of its operating profits in the year ended Jan. 31. The liquids business prospers when gas prices are low because gas is the basic raw material, and petrochemical plants use gas liquids like ethane and propane as fuel when they are cheaper than crude oil. Mitchell Energy, the nation's 12th-largest producer of liquids, figures it earns 14 cents of profit on a 35-cent gallon of gas liquids when gas sells for $1.50.
Even Wall Street likes gas liquids at the moment. The nation's leader, Phillips Petroleum, plans to sell 51 percent of its gas liquids unit, GPM Gas, to the public. The big gas processing company that Occidental Petroleum sold last year, Trident NGL Inc., just announced plans to raise about $300 million in an initial public offering.
The third leg of Mitchell Energy's operations, land development near Houston, is also doing well. The Woodlands, Mr. Mitchell's visionary planned community that Wall Street said was a costly extravagance in its 1960's infancy, is Houston's hottest housing development. Its operating income rose to $22.7 million for the 1992 fiscal year, from $15.9 million a year earlier before a one-time charge of $11.6 million. About 10,000 people work in the area, and 33,000 live there, numbers Mr. Mitchell expects will multiply in another 30 or 40 years.
Mr. Mitchell has used his huge wealth -- which briefly topped $1 billion and now is estimated at half that, mostly in his company's stock -- to follow his convictions about energy as well as his broader interests in Houston and Galveston real estate, biotechnology ventures, scientific research and politics. (Paid $871,000 by Mitchell Energy in fiscal 1991, the most recent figure available, he also gets nearly $12 million a year in company dividends.)
In gas fields, Mr. Mitchell, a geologist trained at Texas A & M University, has backed untested technology, such as mobile gas processing stations, that has helped cut costs. Mitchell Energy has 57 gas processing plants, most of which can be hauled to other sites when aging wells are shut down. He is experimenting with a technique to free potentially large gas supplies from very hard, or "tight," rock formations by drilling horizontally through cracks in layers of shale.
Mitchell is one of the only natural-gas producers building its own gas storage site, in an underground coastal salt dome. It is also a partner with Conoco Inc. in a new plant to produce a component for cleaner-burning gasoline called methyl-tertiary butyl ether.
Mr. Mitchell, said a Houston energy consultant who has known him since the 1950's, "analyzes an opportunity, and then continues to chip away for five, 10, 15 or 20 years. He is very, very persistent and tenacious. Everything he does is related to building the value of his company."
George Mitchell plans to have virtually all of his Mitchell Energy stock transferred to a foundation after his death. In addition to his holdings, his wife, Cynthia Woods Mitchell, owns more than a million shares. But only one of their 10 children has any role at Mitchell Energy. M. Kent Mitchell, a 38-year-old real estate developer in North Carolina, has been a director since 1988. Mr. Mitchell's other children pursue careers ranging from archeology to marine science to film directing.
Many company employees wonder privately whether, foundation or no foundation, Mitchell Energy will be broken up after Mr. Mitchell departs. For the record, Mr. Mitchell says the growing Woodlands should not be sold for at least another 10 years and he maintains that natural gas -- now supplying just under 25 percent of American needs -- will become the nation's preferred energy source for the first half of the next century.
"It's a tough market out there now," he said. "Everybody is trimming back. But we will not find enough oil in this country to offset the declines in production. Natural gas is the fuel for the next 35 years."

 
 
A VISION SHAPED BY TEXAS
 George P. Mitchell of Mitchell Energy says he has put millions of the company's money into nonenergy deals to spur Houston's depressed economy, help make it less dependent on energy and perhaps lure what he hopes will be growing companies into his Manhattan-sized development, the Woodlands.
A series of investments that Mr. Mitchell organized in small, new biotechnology companies in Houston in the early 1980's apparently is about to bear fruit, he said. Stock in five of 18 companies spawned mostly from research at medical schools and hospitals in the Houston area either has been sold or will soon be sold for the first time this year, he said, with perhaps another three to follow.
He also organized and is a major financial supporter of the Houston Advanced Research Center, a consortium that started with Rice University, the University of Houston, Texas A & M and the University of Texas at Austin and now has nine members.
One of the center's biggest successes was research on magnets and site geology that played a role in Texas's winning of the contract for the superconducting super collider, the $8.4 billion atom smasher being built south of Dallas. Mitchell Energy contributes $3.5 million a year to the research center's $14 million annual budget.
A self-described political independent and an outspoken advocate of fees on cheap oil imports, in 1988 he supported the Democratic Presidential nominee, Michael Dukakis, and his running mate, Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Senator and long-time Washington ally of Mr. Mitchell on energy issues. But this year, Mr. Mitchell says, he will be in George Bush's camp. One reason is that the President wants to continue Federal funding for the superconducting super collider.
